PREFACE
         This code of the Village of Oak Lawn, as supplemented, contains
ordinances up to and including ordinance 25-12-38, passed July 22, 2025.
Ordinances of the Village adopted after said ordinance supersede the provisions
of this code to the extent that they are in conflict or inconsistent therewith.
Consult the Village office in order to ascertain whether any particular
provision of the code has been amended, superseded or repealed.

                     Cincinnati, Ohio

VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 25-13-44
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING TITLE 3, CHAPTER 3 (LIQUOR CONTROL), SECTION 3- 3-6
(CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES, CLOSING HOURS)
OF THE VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN VILLAGE CODE
                            
WHEREAS, the Village of Oak Lawn (the "Village") is a home rule municipality,
having all of the powers and authority granted to such municipalities pursuant
to Article VII, Section 6 of the Illinois Constitution of 1970, including the
right to exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its
government and affairs; and
 
WHEREAS, the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1, provides that the
corporate authorities of each municipality may pass all ordinances and make all
rules and regulations proper or necessary, to carry into effect the powers
granted to municipalities, with such fines or penalties as may be deemed
proper; and
 
WHEREAS, the Liquor Control Act of 1934 (235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.) (the “Act”)
grants to the Village the power, by general ordinance or resolution, to
determine, among other things, the number, kind and classification of licenses
for sale at retail of alcoholic liquor not inconsistent with the Act, the
amount of local licensee fees to be paid for licenses issued, the penalties for
the violation of regulations and restrictions relative to operation under local
licenses, and to establish such further regulations and restrictions upon the
issuance of and operations under local licenses not inconsistent with law as
the public good and convenience may require; and
 
WHEREAS, pursuant to the authority granted under the Liquor Control Act of 1934
(235 ILCS 5/6-1 et seq.), and in accordance with the home rule authority
granted to home rule municipalities pursuant to Article VII, Section 6 of the
Illinois Constitution of 1970, the President and Board of Trustees of the
Village of Oak Lawn find that it is in the best interests of the Village, its
officials, employees, residents, property owners and the public to approve the
amendments to the Village of Oak Lawn Village Code as set forth below:
NOW, THEREFORE, BE IT ORDAINED BY THE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS:
 
SECTION ONE: Recitals.  Each of the Whereas clauses above are incorporated by
reference into this Section 1 and made a part hereof as material and operative
provisions of this Ordinance.
 
SECTION TWO: Code Amendments.  Title 3, Chapter 3 (Liquor Control), Section 3-
3-6 (Classification of Licenses, Closing Hours) of the Village of Oak Lawn
Village Code is amended to read as follows, with additions underlined and
deletions stricken through:
“ 3-3-6: CLASSIFICATION OF LIQUOR LICENSES, CLOSING HOURS:
 
CLASS “LIQ-C” CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES (COP): The Class “LIC-C” COP License
applies to and encompasses establishments operating in the retail sale of
alcoholic liquor to be consumed on premises, such as taverns, bars, nightclubs,
pubs, lounges, full-service restaurants, hotels, banquet halls, theaters, for-
profit clubs and bowling alleys, and includes the following previous liquor
license classifications: A, AV, E, EV, G, GV, H, HV, I, IV, J, JV, K, KV, L,
LV, M, MV, Q, QV.  No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away, or offered
for sale in, upon, or about the specified licensed premises between the hours
of (1) two o’clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. on weekdays and
Saturdays, (2) two o’clock (2:00) A.M. and nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. on Sundays
for alcoholic liquors for consumption on said premises.
A “full-service restaurant” shall be defined as any public place kept, used,
maintained, advertised, and held out to the public as a place where meals are
actually and regularly served, with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining
room equipment and with adequate staff to take orders, prepare food, and serve
the food in a full-service operation rather than a fast food service operation.
The principal business of a “full-service restaurant” is the service of said
meals and said service of meals shall constitute at least sixty percent (60%)
of the gross income of the establishment, as distinguished from the principal
business being the service of alcoholic beverages with service of food as a
supplement to the service of alcoholic beverages.
 
CLASS “LIQ-C-BW” CONSUMPTION ON PREMISES (COP) – BEER AND WINE ONLY: The Class
“LIC-C-BW” COP License applies to and encompasses establishments operating in
the retail sale of beer and wine only to be consumed on premises, such as
taverns, bars, nightclubs, pubs, lounges, full-service restaurants, hotels,
banquet halls, theaters, for-profit clubs and bowling alleys, and includes the
following previous liquor license classifications: BV, F, FV.  No alcoholic
liquor shall be sold, given away, or offered for sale in, upon, or about the
specified licensed premises between the hours of (1) two o’clock (2:00) A.M.
and seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. on weekdays and Saturdays, (2) two o’clock (2:00)
A.M. and nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. on Sundays for alcoholic liquors for
consumption on said premises.
 
A “full-service restaurant” shall be defined as any public place kept, used,
maintained, advertised, and held out to the public as a place where meals are
actually and regularly served, with adequate and sanitary kitchen and dining
room equipment and with adequate staff to take orders, prepare food, and serve
the food in a full-service operation rather than a fast food service operation.
The principal business of a “full-service restaurant” is the service of said
meals and said service of meals shall constitute at least sixty percent (60%)
of the gross income of the establishment, as distinguished from the principal
business being the service of alcoholic beverages with service of food as a
supplement to the service of alcoholic beverages.
 
CLASS “LIQ-P” PACKAGED GOODS LICENSE: Establishments and Retail Stores. The
Class LIQ-P Packaged Goods Licenses described below apply to and encompass
establishments operating in the retail sale of alcoholic liquor enclosed in the
original manufacturer sealed and labeled container/package, such as liquor
stores, grocery stores, drugstores, and convenience stores, and include the
following previous liquor license classifications: A, B, D, Q, and S. The Class
LIQ-P Packaged Goods Licenses shall authorize the retail sale of alcoholic
liquor enclosed in the original manufacturer sealed and labeled container/
package, not for consumption on the premises where sold.
 
Effective as of July 1, 2025, as a condition to obtaining and maintaining a
Class “LIQ- P1” or Class “LIQ-P2” Packaged Goods License, licensees are
required to install, maintain, and operate a high-resolution video surveillance
security system within the licensed store premises, which shall record the
activities within all parts of the licensed store premises and shall function
twenty-four (24) hours a day and be linked to the Village’s Axon Fusus security
monitoring system. Licensees shall have until December 31, 2025, to install
such video surveillance security system and link it with the Village’s system.
Licensees shall post signage notifying patrons and employees that the store
premises are under video surveillance.
1.   CLASS “LIQ-P1” PACKAGED GOODS LICENSE: Establishments and Retail Stores,
other than Convenience Stores, e.g., Liquor Stores, Grocery Stores, and
Drugstores. The Class “LIQ-P1” Packaged Goods License shall authorize the
retail sale of all alcoholic liquor in its original manufacturer sealed and
labeled container/package only, not for consumption on the premises where sold.
No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or
about the specified premises so licensed between the hours of two o’clock (2:
00) A.M. and seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. on weekdays and Saturdays and two
o’clock (2:00) A.M and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. on Sundays.
 
2.   CLASS “LIQ-P2” PACKAGED GOODS LICENSE: Convenience Stores Only. The Class
“LIQ-P2” Packaged Goods License shall authorize the storage, distribution, and
retail sale of alcoholic liquor, and single servings of beer, in their original
manufacturer sealed and labeled containers/packages only, not for consumption
on the premises where sold, as an adjunct to a convenience store. However, the
holder of a Class “LIQ-P2” Packaged Goods License shall be prohibited from
selling any hard alcohol or spirits in quantities of less than one- fifth (1/5)
of a gallon, as well as single servings of beer larger than thirty-two (32)
ounces. Single servings of beer shall be kept in a locked display case at all
times during which the sale of beer is permitted, and with only the cashier or
other authorized store employee able to unlock said display case. The area set
aside for liquor sales shall not exceed twenty percent (20%) of the floor area
of the convenience store. For purposes of determining the allowable beer and
wine sales area, the licensee shall submit a floor plan of the convenience
store at the time of application for the license. Areas of the convenience
store, to which access by customers is prohibited, shall not be counted in the
floor area calculation. All beer and wine on display for sale shall be kept in
a locked display case at all times during which the sale of beer and/or wine is
prohibited, with only the cashier or other authorized store employee able to
unlock said display case. All extra beer and wine stock shall be kept in a
storage room, with access limited only to store employees. No more than two (2)
signs, banners, posters, or any combination thereof, advertising beer and/or
wine, shall be visible from the exterior of the convenience store. Beer and/or
wine may only be sold, given away, or offered for sale in, upon, or about the
specified premises so licensed between the hours of seven o’clock (7:00) A.M.
and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on weekdays and Saturdays and between the hours
of nine o’clock (9:00) A.M. and eleven o’clock (11:00) P.M. on Sundays.
 
CLASS “LIQ-M” MANUFACTURER’S LICENSE: The Class “LIQ-M” Manufacturer’s License
authorizes the manufacture, production, storage, and sale of alcoholic liquor
on the licensed premises, and the sale of retail alcoholic liquor, as well as
the sale of alcoholic liquor-related products, and includes the following
previous liquor license classifications: R, T, V. Class “LIQ-M” licensees may
sell alcoholic liquor they manufacture to wholesalers, licensed retailers, and
directly to consumers for off premises consumption in packaged form only. Class
“LIQ-M” licensees may also purchase bulk wine for blending purposes from
licensed out-of-state wine sellers. All alcoholic liquor must be manufactured
and labeled in accordance with Federal regulations from the U.S. Department of
the Treasury Tobacco Tax and Trade Bureau (“TTB”) (formerly, the Bureau of
Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms) and/or any other applicable federal agency.
Licensees must obtain and maintain all required Federal, State and local
licenses and permits, as applicable. Nothing in the issuance of a Class “LIQ-M”
license shall be considered to relieve the licensee of any responsibility for
complying with all applicable Federal, State and local laws and regulations
relating to the manufacture, production, storage, and/or sale of alcoholic
liquor products. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold, given away, or offered for
sale in, upon or about the specified premises so licensed between the hours of
two o’clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o’clock (7:00) A.M. on weekdays and
Saturdays, and between the hours of two o’clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o’clock
(11:00) A.M. on Sundays.
 
CLASS “LIQ-NP” NON-PROFIT LICENSE: The Class “LIQ-NP” Non-Profit License shall
authorize the retail sale on the specified premises of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on said premises only, and such license shall be authorized only
for issuance to not for profit clubs and organizations including, but not
limited to, the Knights Of Columbus and Veterans Of Foreign Wars  and includes
the following previous liquor license classification: K. No alcoholic liquor
shall be sold, given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified
premises so licensed between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven
o'clock (7:00) A.M. on weekdays and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock
(11:00) A.M. on Sundays.
 
CLASS “LIQ-SE” SPECIAL EVENTS ONLY LICENSE: The Class “LIQ-SE” Special Events
License shall authorize the sale or giving away of alcoholic liquor for
consumption on the premises where sold or given away at any specific event
sponsored by any club, organization or individual and includes the following
previous liquor license classification: C. No alcoholic liquor shall be sold,
given away or offered for sale in, upon or about the specified premises so
licensed between the hours of two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and seven o'clock (7:00)
A.M. on weekdays and two o'clock (2:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. on
Sundays. All Class “LIQ-SE” licenses shall expire ten (10) days after the date
of issue.
 
CLASS “LIQ-S-VG” VIDEO GAMING SUPPLEMENTAL LIQUOR LICENSE: A Class “LIQ-S-VG”
Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License shall authorize eligible liquor
license holders to conduct video gaming, as defined under the Illinois Video
Gaming Act, 230 ILCS 40/1 et seq., on their licensed premises, so long as the
licensee also has a video gaming license issued by the Illinois Gaming Board
pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois Video Gaming Act and all the rules,
regulations, and restrictions imposed by the Illinois Gaming Board; provided,
video gaming shall not be permitted during the hours alcoholic liquor sales are
prohibited. A licensed establishment that already holds a liquor license which
authorizes the retail sale of alcoholic liquor for consumption on the licensed
premises (hereinafter the “primary liquor license”), shall be eligible for the
Class “LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License to conduct video
gaming on the licensed premises, in accordance with the rules and regulations
of the Illinois Gaming Board license and the primary liquor license. The Class
“LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License is required in addition to
the establishment’s primary liquor license, and includes the following previous
liquor license classifications: BV, EV, FV, GV, HV, IV, JV, KV, LV, MV, QV, RV,
VV. Video gaming, as defined under the Illinois Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 40/1 et seq., shall not be allowed in an establishment
without the Class “LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License.
 
 
All new liquor licenses issued and all liquor licenses renewed after the
effective date of this section shall be in compliance with the above classes
and shall accurately reflect the nature of the licensee's actual business.
 
Any person holding a valid liquor license as of June 30, 2025, shall not be
required to submit a new application for a liquor license; instead, any person
holding such a valid license may apply for a renewal of its primary Liquor
License in the manner provided by this chapter and will receive its renewal
license under the new corresponding classification, so long as all other
requirements of this Code pertaining to the renewal of liquor licenses are met
and the applicable renewal fee is timely paid.
 
Any person holding a valid liquor license in the following classifications as
of June 30, 2025, shall not be required to submit a new application for a Class
“LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License, if such person has either
received or applied for a video gaming license issued by the State of Illinois:
Class AV, BV, EV, FV, GV, HV, IV, JV, KV, LV, or MV; instead, any person
holding such a valid license and has either received or applied for a video
gaming license from the State of Illinois may apply for a renewal of its
primary Liquor License and an add-on CLASS “LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental
Liquor License in the manner provided by this chapter and will receive its
renewal license under the new corresponding classification along with the CLASS
“LIQ-S-VG” Video Gaming Supplemental Liquor License, so long as all other
requirements of this Code pertaining to the renewal of liquor licenses are met
and the applicable renewal fee is timely paid.
 
(Ords. 14-09-18, 14-23-50, 14-28-67, 15-14-56, 15-19-76, 15-19-77, 16-10-29,
18-07-22, 18-23-78, 19-11-31, 19-13-42, 23-21-87)”
 
 
SECTION THREE: Severability.  If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of
this Ordinance is held invalid, the invalidity of such section, paragraph,
clause or provision shall not affect any of the other provisions of this
Ordinance.
 
SECTION FOUR : Repealer.  Any policy, resolution or ordinance of the Village
that conflicts with the provisions of this Ordinance shall be and is hereby
repealed to the extent of such conflict.
 
SECTION FIVE: Effective Date.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect
from and after its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.
 
   ADOPTED this 26th day of August 2025, pursuant to a roll call vote as
follows:
 
   AYES: Trustees Stalker, Soch, Pembroke, Olejniczak, and Mallo
   NAYS:    
   ABSENT: Trustee Desmond
 
APPROVED by me this 26th day of August 2025, and attested by the Village Clerk
on the same day.

                         Village President
