VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 25-14-47
 
AN ORDINANCE AMENDING VARIOUS SECTIONS OF TITLE 8 (PUBLIC
HEALTH AND SANITATION), CHAPTER 5 (GARBAGE, REFUSE AND ELECTRONIC RECYCLING) OF
THE VILLAGE CODE OF OAK LAWN
                            
WHEREAS, the Village of Oak Lawn (the "Village") is a home rule municipality,
having all of the powers and authority granted to such municipalities pursuant
to Article VII, Section 6 of the Illinois Constitution of 1970, particularly
the right to exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its
government and affairs, including, but not limited to, the power to regulate
for the protection of the public health, safety, morals and welfare; and
 
WHEREAS, Section 11-19-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-19-1,
provides that the corporate authorities of each municipality may enter into
contracts for the collection and disposal of municipal waste; and
 
WHEREAS, on July 22nd, 2025, at a regular meeting of the Village of Oak Lawn
Board of Trustees, the Village President and Board of Trustees of the Village
adopted Resolution No. 25-12-56, approving a bid from Flood Brothers Disposal
Company (“Flood Brothers”) to provide refuse, recyclables, landscape,
electronic and hazardous waste collection and disposal services to the Village;
and
 
WHEREAS, since the adoption of Resolution No. 25-12-56, Village Staff has
finalized the terms of a service agreement with Flood Brothers, including the
fees charged for services and the requirements for various refuse, recycling,
and landscape waste containers, among other terms; and
 
WHEREAS, in order to reflect the agreed terms of the service agreement with
Flood Brothers, Village Staff has recommended various amendments to the Oak
Lawn Village Code (the “Village Code”) relative to garbage, refuse and
electronic recycling; and
 
WHEREAS, the Village President and Board of Trustees of the Village find that
the following Code Amendments are in the best interests of the Village, its
residents, property owners, business owners and the public, and hereby approve
the Code Amendments as set forth below.
 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND THE BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE
VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS:
 
SECTION ONE: Recitals.  Each of the Whereas clauses above are incorporated by
reference into this Section 1 and made a part hereof as material and operative
provisions of this Ordinance.
 
SECTION TWO: Amendment to the Oak Lawn Village Code. Subsection 8-5-5
(Containers Required, Specifications), in Title 8 (Public Health and
Sanitation), Chapter 5 (Garbage, Refuse and Electronic Recycling), of the Oak
Lawn Village Code is hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows
(additions to existing text marked with underlined text; deletions to existing
text marked using strikethrough):
 
“8-5-5: CONTAINERS REQUIRED, SPECIFICATIONS:
For the purposes of this Subsection 8-5-5, the term Village shall include the
Village’s service provider contracted to provide garbage, refuse and electronic
recycling services to the Village. The Village’s contracted service provider
hereunder shall also be referred to as the “Village Contractor.”
A. Every occupant, person, owner, lessee or tenant in possession of any house,
building, condominium, or apartment in the village shall at all times maintain
in good order and repair a container or containers for trash and garbage.
B. A container shall be a can of galvanized iron or noncorrodible material,
rodentproof, watertight, with a tightfitting lid, and of the type commonly sold
as a garbage can, of a suitable gauge and construction to ensure durability, of
a capacity of not less than ten (10) gallons and not to exceed thirty three
(33) gallons for single-family and two-family residences.
B. Refuse shall be collected by the Village only if it is set out in a Village
Contractor- supplied blue 96, 64, or 35-gallon cart, or in a customer-supplied
water-tight, rodent- proof container made of galvanized metal or other non-
corrodible material, with handles and lid, commonly sold as a garbage can, of a
suitable gauge and construction to insure durability, with a capacity of not
less than ten (10) gallons and not more than thirty-three (33) gallons.
Additional Village Contractor-supplied carts may be available to rent for an
annual fee. Any wet refuse must be wrapped in a suitable material. Fiber drums,
oil drums, cylindrical metal barrels, and cardboard containers, regardless of
size or capacity, are prohibited from use as a refuse container.
C. Recycling shall be collected by the Village only if it is set out in a
Village Contractor-supplied green 96, 64, or 35-gallon cart, or an 18-gallon
bin. Additional Village Contractor-supplied carts may be available to rent for
an annual fee.
D. Landscape waste shall be collected by the Village only if it is set out in a
Village Contractor-supplied or customer-supplied (up to 3 carts) brown 96, 64,
or 35-gallon cart, two-ply Kraft thirty (30) gallon paper bags, or a customer-
supplied unlined container with functional handles and lid, no larger than
thirty-three (33) gallons in capacity, and clearly marked with a "Yard Waste"
sticker. Any landscape waste shall be deposited loose in the container, and
each container shall not exceed sixty (60) pounds in weight when carrying a
full load of landscape waste. Village Contractor-supplied 96-gallon yard waste
carts are available to rent for an annual fee.
E. Any material that is not set out in approved containers shall not be
collected by the Village. If the Village Contractor encounters nonconforming
material, a notice shall be left on the container or attached to the material.
This notice shall specify the reason(s) for not collecting the material. A
duplicate copy of the notice shall be provided to the Village’s Public Works
office within twenty-four (24) hours. Such notice is subject to review and
approval by the Village. The Village will notify the Village Contractor if
additional steps must be taken.
CF. Filthy, leaking or defective receptacles should be cleaned, repaired or
replaced as directed by the appropriate representative of the village. (1951
Code 2-6-26, 2-6-17, 6-6- 3; Ord. 06-10-55)”
 
SECTION THREE: Amendment to the Oak Lawn Village Code. Subpart B (Hours of
Collection; Days Prohibited), of Subsection 8-5-6 (Collection Regulations,
Requirements) in Title 8 (Public Health and Sanitation), Chapter 5 (Garbage,
Refuse and Electronic Recycling) of the Oak Lawn Village Code is hereby amended
to read in its entirety as follows (additions to existing text marked with
underlined text; deletions to existing text marked using strikethrough):
 
“B. Hours Of Collection; Days Prohibited:
 
1. Under its powers as a home rule municipality the village restricts the time
of refuse and garbage collection within the village limits by firms under
contract to the village and by firms licensed by the village to do so to five
thirty six o'clock (5:30 6:00) A.M. until six thirty o'clock (6:30 6:00) P.M.
 
2. No collection of garbage shall be made on Sundays or holidays.”
 
SECTION FOUR: Amendment to the Oak Lawn Village Code. Subsection 8-5-7 (Charges
for Village Collection) in Title 8 (Public Health and Sanitation), Chapter 5
(Garbage, Refuse and Electronic Recycling) of the Oak Lawn Village Code is
hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows (additions to existing text
marked with underlined text; deletions to existing text marked using
strikethrough):
 
“8-5-7: CHARGES FOR VILLAGE COLLECTION:
 
For the purposes of this Subsection 8-5-7, the term Village shall include the
Village’s service provider contracted to provide garbage, refuse and electronic
recycling services to the Village. The Village’s contracted service provider
hereunder shall also be referred to as the “Village Contractor.”
 
A. Effective October 1, 20242025, refuse, recycling, and landscape waste
collection charges for each residential and nonresidential account shall be as
follows:
 
      1. Residential quarterly billing:
      
a. Seniors (over age 65): Sixty-seven dollars and forty-four cents
($67.44) Fifty-eight dollars and sixty-five cents ($58.65);
         
      b. Person(s) with a disability: Sixty-seven dollars and forty-four cents
          ($67.44) Fifty-eight dollars and sixty-five cents ($58.65);
 
(1) “Person(s) with a disability” as used in this section means any person who
is, and who is expected to indefinitely continue to be, subject to any of the
five (5) types of disabilities consistent with the term as defined in the
Illinois State Statute, 15 Illinois Compiled Statutes 335/4A; or person(s) with
a disability that are receiving social security or SSI benefits. This reduction
shall only apply to homeowners with a disability as defined above or
alternatively, legal guardians of a person with a disability who reside in the
residence of the applicant seeking the reduction.
(2) The Village of Oak Lawn recognizes that it lacks the resources to establish
a system for determining whether an applicant under this section is a “person
(s) with a disability” as defined herein. As a result, in order to receive the
reduction allowed under this section, the Village of Oak Lawn will only accept
the following documents as validation of proof that the applicant is a “person
with a disability” or has a disability and is receiving social security or SSI
benefits:
 
(A) Person(s) with a disability validation. The applicant must provide a valid
“Illinois person with a disability identification card” obtained through the
Illinois Secretary of State as provided for in 15 Illinois Compiled Statutes
335/4.
 
(B) Social security validation. The applicant must provide a current social
security or SSI benefit verification letter which contains the applicant’s
current residence, age and disability.
 
c. Nonseniors: Seventy-six dollars and seventy-four cents ($76.74) Sixty- nine
dollars ($69.00).
 
2. Nonresidential monthly billing:
   
a. All customers: Twenty-five dollars and fifty-eight cents ($25.58) Twenty-
three dollars ($23.00).
         
   All charges shall be billed to and paid by the occupant, owner or owner’s
agent, tenant, or individual in whose name the water account appears, or
otherwise as the Village Collector may provide. Collection of the charges for
water provided, sewage treated and refuse collected shall not be collected
separately from each other. Wherever refuse disposal is not required for a full
billing cycle, the individual furnished the service shall pay on a pro rata
basis for portions of the billing cycle during which he receives services. The
basic charge shall entitle each account to a weekly collection of all household
waste including garbage, rubbish and recyclables.
 
B. Only one of the following listed items may be placed out for pick up,
without additional charge, each week:
 
1. Furniture and large household goods, to include, but not be limited to,
televisions, hot water heaters, sofas, dressers, lamps, chairs, tables,
mattresses, rolls of carpet (not more than 4 feet in length).
 
2. Small amounts of sod, earth, and rocks, provided the items listed are put
into a suitable container not exceeding sixty (60) pounds.
 
3. Household Cconstruction material (except new construction) including, but
not limited to, furnaces, bathtubs, shower stalls, doors, windows, and other
items that are considered part of a dwelling. It shall also include loose
remodeling and repair construction materials, provided such items are put in a
suitable container or in a bundle not exceeding four feet (4') in length, and
not weighing over sixty (60) pounds.
 
Customers who wish to set out more than one of the items listed per week will
be directed to contact the contractor to make arrangements for collection at an
additional cost.
 
Dead animals and white goods (such as refrigerators, air conditioners,
freezers, washing machines, dryers, dishwashers, microwaves, etc.) will be
collected at no additional charge.
 
C. Organic (living) Christmas trees shall be collected, free of charge, a
minimum of two during the first three (23) weeks after January 1 of each year
from each dwelling serviced under this contract. Christmas trees shall be
collected on regularly scheduled collection days. The trees must be free from
foreign materials such as, but not limited to, tinsel, wires, ornaments, or
bags, and shall be recycled.
 
D. In an effort to encourage management of landscape waste at a location, the
pick up of landscape waste is to be provided on the same day and as part of the
regular refuse pick up, between the first full week in April through the second
full week in December. April 1 and November 30 of each year.
 
Bundles of brush or tree clippings shall be collected as part of the regular
landscape waste pick up, provided the weight of such bundles does not exceed
sixty (60) pounds, the length of material does not exceed four feet (4'), and/
or the diameter of each bundle does not exceed three feet (3'). Logs over four
inches (4") in diameter must be stacked separately at the curb and cut into
lengths of twenty four inches (24") with individual pieces not exceeding eight
inches (8") in diameter. The foregoing does not include any branches or trees
cut by private contractors hired by the customer.
 
E. The Village Contractor will collect the following items on a fee basis via
curbside pickup. All fee-based collections are to be arranged between the
resident and the Village Contractor, who shall charge the resident directly and
may require payment prior to service.
 
   1. Electronic Waste, including televisions.
 
2. Tires (separate from the rims) and White Goods (refrigerators, air
conditioners, freezers, washing machines, dryers, dishwashers, microwaves,
etc.)
 
3. Hazardous Waste including, but not limited to, automotive waste products,
garden chemicals, household cleaners, paint products, swimming pool chemicals,
and miscellaneous household hazardous waste.
 
From time to time the Village may host an Electronic and Hazardous Waste event.
The contractor will charge a fee per item with the fees posted at the event.
(Ords. 13-15-56, 14-04-10, 14-13-25, 15-05-18, 16-06-12, 17-04-09, 18-24-83,
19-23-74, 20-19-56, 21-21-98, 22-19-64, 23-15-60, 24-16-60)”
 
SECTION FIVE: Amendment to the Oak Lawn Village Code. Subsection 8-5-9
(Consumer Electronic Recycling) in Title 8 (Public Health and Sanitation),
Chapter 5 (Garbage, Refuse and Electronic Recycling) of the Oak Lawn Village
Code is hereby deleted in its entirety.
 
SECTION SIX: Severability.    If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of
this Ordinance is held invalid, the invalidity of such section, paragraph,
clause or provision shall not affect any of the other provisions of this
Ordinance.
 
SECTION SEVEN: Repealer.  Any policy, resolution or ordinance of the Village
that conflicts with the provisions of this Ordinance shall be and is hereby
repealed to the extent of such conflict.
 
SECTION EIGHT: Effective Date.  This Ordinance shall be in full force and
effect from and after its passage and approval in the manner provided by law.

Published in pamphlet form by authority of the President and Board of Trustees
of the
Village of Oak Lawn
 
 
 
VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN
COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS
 
ORDINANCE NO. 25-15-53
 
AN ORDINANCE MAKING FURTHER AMENDMENTS TO SECTION 3-1-1-7 (FEE SCHEDULES) OF
TITLE 3 (BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS), CHAPTER 1 (GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR
BUSINESSES, CERTIFICATES, LICENSES AND PERMITS) AND VARIOUS OTHER SECTIONS OF
THE OAK LAWN VILLAGE CODE RELATIVE TO BUSINESS AND OTHER LICENSING AND
REGISTRATION, AND RELATED FEES (UPDATE ORDINANCE NO. 2)
 
WHEREAS, the Village of Oak Lawn (the "Village") is a home rule municipality,
having all of the powers and authority granted to such municipalities pursuant
to Article VII, Section 6 of the Illinois Constitution of 1970, including the
right to exercise any power and perform any function pertaining to its
government and affairs; and
 
   WHEREAS, for the past several years, Village staff has undertaken a
comprehensive review of the Village’s business licensing ordinances and fees,
which have not been comprehensively reviewed in over twenty (20) years, and
have recommended many changes with the goals of creating a simplified licensing
and registration process, modernizing fee structures, addressing
inconsistencies, promoting equity among businesses, and creating administrative
efficiencies; and
 
WHEREAS, it is anticipated that the end result will be implementation of a
significantly simplified business licensing, registration and related business
fee structure; and
 
WHEREAS, Village staff has, during the pendency of its review and analysis of
its business licensing ordinances, process, structure and fees, implemented a
series of licensing fee holidays that have benefited Oak Lawn businesses; and
   
WHEREAS, the review is now nearing completion, and an ordinance creating a new
and simplified business licensing, registration and related business fee
structure was recently approved at the Village’s July 22, 2025 Board of
Trustees meeting; and
 
WHEREAS, subsequent to that, an Ordinance making certain clarifying and other
changes regarding licensing, registration and fees within the Village was
considered and approved at the Village’s August 26, 2025 Board of Trustees
meeting; and
 
WHEREAS, since that time, it has been determined by staff that certain
additional clarifying and other changes regarding licensing, registration and
fees within the Village are required (the “Proposed Code Amendments”), as set
forth below in this Ordinance; and
 
WHEREAS, pursuant to the Village’s home rule authority, and other authority
granted to the Village by the applicable provisions of the Illinois Municipal
Code (65 ILCS 5/ et seq.), the President and Board of Trustees of the Village
of Oak Lawn find that the below Code Amendments are in the best interests of
the Village, its residents, property owners, business owners and the public,
and they approve the Code Amendments as set forth below.
 
BE IT ORDAINED BY THE VILLAGE PRESIDENT AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE VILLAGE OF
OAK LAWN, COOK COUNTY, ILLINOIS, AS FOLLOWS:
 
   SECTION ONE: Each Whereas paragraph set forth above is incorporated by
reference into this Section 1.
 
SECTION TWO: Title 3 (Business and License Regulations), Chapter 1 (General
Provisions for Businesses, Certificates, Licenses and Permits), Section 3-1-1-
7 (Fee Schedules) of the Oak Lawn Village Code is hereby amended to read in its
entirety as follows (new text is marked with underlining; deletions to existing
text marked using strikethrough):
 
“3-1-1-7: FEE SCHEDULES:
 
A.   Payment of Fees Required: All commercial establishments or business
activities (collectively referred to in this section as “businesses”), and
certain other entities subject to licensing, registration or permitting,
located or taking place within the Village are required to pay the licensing,
registration or permitting fees set forth in the tables below, as applicable,
on an annual basis.
 
B. Licensing, Registration and/or Fee Year or Term; Prorations: Except where
otherwise specified in this section:
 
   1. The license, registration and/or fee year or term for all fees specified
in Tables 1 through 6 below is from October 1 through September 30 of each
year, except that the license, registration and/or fee year or term immediately
following the enactment of this Ordinance shall run from July 1, 2025 through
September 30, 2026, with all payments due by November 30, 2025. For subsequent
years, tThe renewal period opens on July 1 and closes on September 30 each
year, and all payments are due by September 30 of each year.
   2. When a fee is owed for the first time in the second half of a license,
registration and/or fee year or term, it shall be prorated by 50% for that year
or term only.
 
   3. All fees must be paid at the time of application. In the event an
application is denied, the fee shall be returned, absent a $50 processing
charge.
 
   4. In no event shall any rebate or refund be made of any fee, or part
thereof, by reason of death or by any reason of nonuse of the license or
registration or discontinuance of the operation of the commercial establishment
or business activity.
 
   5. Per Section 1-17-2 of this Code, no license, permit, certificate or other
approval regulated or issued by the Village under the authority of this Code,
or renewal thereof, shall be issued to any person or entity who is indebted to
the Village due to a failure to pay any debt, tax, fine, fee, or penalty, or
any renewal thereof, as determined solely by the Village Manager.
 
C.   General Rules on Calculation of Fees and Square Footage of Interior Space
Calculations: Except where otherwise indicated, the following rules shall apply
to the calculation of fees and the determination of square footage of interior
space as that term is used in this section and the Tables below:
 
   1. Total square footage of interior space applicable for the determination
of the yearly license fee where based on square footage shall include the sum
total of all the floor area in use or reserved for or retained for the use of
the business, including, but not restricted to, principal and accessory floor
area, cellars and basements, storage, or detached accessory buildings, even
though any such floor area may be temporarily vacant or not in use.
 
   2. Businesses that occupy multiple floors in a building will derive total
square-footage by adding the interior square footage of all the floors they
occupy.
 
   3. Businesses with multiple locations in the village that operate as
separate businesses (e.g., franchise restaurants) will register and/or license
each location separately and pay registration and licensing fees for each, and
each will be issued their own business license.
The maximum annual fee that a business is required to pay as their base
licensing fee based on square footage of interior space is $5,000.
 
   4. Businesses or entities with multiple locations in the Village that serve
as support for the primary business location (e.g., maintenance, storage, back-
office, etc.) derive total square footage of interior space by the sum of the
total interior square footage of all their facilities and locations within the
Village.
 
   45. Where a fee is based on square footage, under-reporting of square
footage will be subject to a fine of $1.00 per under-reported square foot.
 
D.   Village-Based Businesses: The following Table 1 applies to all village-
based businesses, except in those cases where a business is specifically listed
in Table 2, effective with the licensing period commencing July 1, 2025:

1.   Commercial establishments or business activities licensed by the IDFPR or
otherwise licensed exclusively by the State of Illinois or federal government
shall pay a minimum fee of $150 regardless of square feet of space occupied.
2.   Commercial establishments or business activities licensed by the IDFPR
will pay a single annual registration fee for the establishment or activity
(i.e. legal entity), not per licensed professional.
3.   Underreporting of gaming terminals is subject to a fine of $5,000 per
underreported machine
4.   Underreporting of towing vehicles is subject to a fine of $5,000 per
underreported vehicle.
5.   A minimum fee of $150 is required for businesses with a physical location
(s) in the Village (non-home based), even in the event the business is less
than 750 square feet of interior space or consists only of a post office box.
6.   The maximum annual combined registration and licensing fee that a business
is required
to pay based on square footage of interior space is $5,000.
7.   Businesses or entities with multiple locations in the Village that serve
as support for the primary business location (e.g., maintenance, storage, back-
office, etc.) derive total square footage of interior space by the sum of the
total interior square footage of all their facilities and locations within the
Village.
8.   Mobile Home Park operators will derive total square footage by adding the
total square footage of the individual mobile homes on the property plus the
square footage of any administrative office(s) on site.
1.   Commercial establishments or business activities licensed by the IDFPR
will pay a single annual registration fee for the establishment or activity
(i.e. legal entity), not per licensed professional.
2.   A minimum fee of $150 is required, even in the event the business is less
than 750 square feet of interior space.
3.   Commercial establishments with multiple locations in the village that
operate as separate businesses (e.g., franchise restaurants) will register each
location separately and pay a license fees for each, and each will be issued
their own business license.
4.   Mobile Home Park operators will derive total square footage by adding the
total square footage of the individual mobile homes on the property plus the
square footage of any administrative office(s) on site.
5.   Commercial establishments or business activities licensed by the IDFPR
shall pay a minimum fee of $150 regardless of square feet of space occupied.

SECTION 3: Section 6-5B-7 (Responsibilities of Owner, Agent and/or Manager) of
Article B (Rental Occupancy Permit Program) in Title 6 (Building Regulations),
Chapter 5 (Property Maintenance Regulations), of the Village Code of Oak Lawn
is hereby amended to read in its entirety as follows (additions to existing
text marked with underlined text; deletions to existing text marked using
strikethrough):
 
“6-5B-7: RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNER, AGENT AND/OR MANAGER:
A.   Definitions: For the purposes of this article, the following terms shall
have the meanings hereinafter ascribed to them:
DWELLING: Any enclosed space which is wholly or partly used or intended to be
used, rented, leased, let or hired out to be occupied, or that is occupied for
living purposes.
DWELLING UNIT: A single unit providing complete, independent living facilities
for one or more persons, including permanent provisions for living, sleeping,
eating, cooking and sanitation.
IMMEDIATE FAMILY: Immediate family means kinship members including:
(1) Mother: A female parent;
(2) Father: A male parent;
(3) Son: A male child of the parent(s);
(4) Daughter: A female child of the parent(s);
(5) Brother: A male child of the same parent(s);
(6) Sister: A female child of the same parent(s);
(7) Grandfather: A parent's father;
(8) Grandmother: A parent's mother;
(9) Grandson: A child's son;
(10) Granddaughter: A child's daughter.
 
MANAGING AGENT: Any person or firm, acting for another, with authority to rent
or otherwise authorize occupancy, manage and make expenditures.
NON-OWNER OCCUPIED RESIDENTIAL DWELLING UNIT: Any multiple dwelling or dwelling
unit which is not owner occupied, and which is either rented, leased, occupied
or made available for leasing or rental or occupancy to others by the property
owner or his/her agent. The occupancy of a single room or the sharing of a
dwelling unit between the property owner of the dwelling unit and others shall
not constitute a non-owner occupied residential dwelling unit. The term
includes the occupancy of property pursuant to articles of agreement for
purchase or a contract for deed until the deed is delivered by the owner.
B.   Permit Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to rent, lease or
otherwise allow a dwelling or dwelling unit under their ownership to be
occupied by others as a non- owner occupied residential dwelling unit unless a
non-owner occupied residential dwelling unit permit is in effect, as provided
by this article. Permits shall be issued by the Community Development Director
or their designee for a period of one year from July 1 to June 30. Any permit
may be transferred to another person, subject to completion and approval of a
new permit application by the new permitee. In the event an owner can submit a
sworn affidavit that an immediate family member is occupying the dwelling, the
owner shall not be required to register the property after submittal and
Village review and approval of said affidavit. The owner shall instead submit
the name and contact phone number for the occupant for the Village records.
C.   Application: No non-owner occupied residential dwelling unit permit shall
be issued except upon a receipt of a completed Village of Oak Lawn landlord
permit application filed with the Community Development Director or his
designee. Except as hereinafter provided, such applications shall be submitted
to the Community Development Director or his designee no later than July 1
preceding the permit year being applied for with the appropriate fees. The
applications shall set forth, but not be limited to, the following information:
1.   Full name and address of the legal owner; if owned by a trust, a trust
disclosure is required.
2.   The permit application shall designate three (3) contacts, including the
property owner, their names, addresses and phone numbers for twenty four (24)
hour contact in case of an emergency.
3.   The permit application shall list all the non-owner occupied residential
dwelling units owned or managed by the applicant in the Village of Oak Lawn.
4.   Proof of ongoing rodent abatement services and quarterly rodent activity
reports are required to register all non-owner occupied residential dwelling
unit properties.
5.   A roster of current tenants.
6.   An affidavit of other proof regarding the existence of a working fire
alarm/alarm system for the property.
D.   Reports: The permitee shall report to the Code Enforcement Department any
changes in the information provided on the application or a conveyance of the
property, within seven (7) days of said change or conveyance.
E.   Issuance Of Permit; Payment of Permitting Fees; Fee: No permit shall be
issued until the applicable permit fees as set forth in Section 3-1-1-7 of this
Code have been paid.
Renewal shall be required annually. 
F.   Outstanding Monies Due And Owing The Village: Before a permit may be
issued to a permitteepermitee hereunder, the permittee shall pay all
outstanding fees, fines or penalties due and owing the Village.
G.   Fire Alarms/Alarm Systems: All non-owner occupied residential dwelling
properties must have a working fire-alarm system. Such systems are subject to
inspection by the Village at any time. The penalty for inoperable or non-
existent fire-alarm/alarm systems is five (5) times the applicable annual per
unit fee set forth in Section 3-1-1- 7 of this Code, multiplied by the number
of units in the building.”
 
SECTION 4:    The fees imposed in the Ordinance are, in most cases, intended to
replace existing fees. There may therefore be, in certain instances, existing
fees located elsewhere in the Code that the fees imposed here are intended to
replace. Where a direct conflict exists between a fee imposed here and a fee
located elsewhere in the Oak Lawn Village Code, it is the intent of the
President and Board of Trustees that the fee imposed in this Ordinance shall
prevail and that the fee not be required to be paid twice. Conflicting fees
located elsewhere in the Code shall be deleted in a subsequent ordinance.
 
   SECTION 5: Any policy, resolution or ordinance of the Village that conflicts
with the provisions of this Ordinance shall be and is hereby repealed to the
extent of such conflict.
 
   SECTION 6: This Ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after
its adoption, approval, and publication in the manner provided by law.
   ADOPTED this 23rd day of September, 2025, pursuant to a roll call vote as
follows:
 
   AYES:  Trustees Soch, Pembroke, Olejniczak, Mallo, Stalker and Desmond
   NAYS:    
   ABSENT:    
 
APPROVED by me this 23rd day of September, 2025, and attested by the Village
Clerk on the same day.

1-1-7: Illinois Compiled Statutes
1-1-1: TITLE:
Upon adoption by the Board of Trustees, this Village Code is hereby declared to
be and shall hereafter constitute the official Village Code of Oak Lawn. This
Village Code of ordinances shall be known and cited as the OAK LAWN VILLAGE
CODE, and it is hereby published by authority of the Board of Trustees and
shall be kept up to date as provided in Section
1-1-3 of this Chapter under the direction of the Village Attorney, acting for
said Village Board of Trustees. Any reference to the number of any section
contained herein shall be understood to refer to the position of the same
number, its appropriate chapter and title heading, and to the general penalty
clause relating thereto, as well as to the section itself, when reference is
made to this Village Code by title in any legal document. (1951 Code 19-1-1;
1985 Code)
1-1-2: ACCEPTANCE:
This Village Code, as hereby presented in printed form, shall hereafter be
received without further proof in all courts and in all administrative
tribunals of this State as the ordinances of the Village of general and
permanent effect, except the excluded ordinances enumerated in Section
1-2-1 of this Code. (1985 Code)
1-1-3: AMENDMENTS:
Any ordinance amending this Village Code shall set forth the title, chapter and
section number of the section or sections to be amended, and this shall
constitute a sufficient compliance with any statutory requirement pertaining to
the amendment or revision by ordinance of any part of this Village Code. All
such amendments or revisions by ordinance shall be immediately forwarded to the
codifiers and the said ordinance material shall be prepared for insertion in
its proper place in each copy of this Village Code. Each such replacement page
shall be properly identified and shall be inserted in each individual copy of
this Village Code. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
1-1-4: CODE ALTERATIONS:
It shall be deemed unlawful for any person to alter, change, replace or deface
in any way any section or any page of this Village Code in such a manner that
the meaning of any phrase or order may be changed or omitted. Replacement pages
may be inserted according to the official instructions when so authorized by
the Village Board. The Clerk shall see that the replacement pages are properly
inserted in the official copies maintained in the office of the Clerk. Any
person having in his custody an official copy of this Village Code shall make
every effort to maintain this Code in an up to date and efficient manner. He
shall see to the immediate insertion of new or replacement pages when such are
delivered to him or made available to him through the office of the Village
Clerk. Said Code books, while in actual possession of officials and other
interested persons, shall be and remain the property of the Village and shall
be returned to the office of the Clerk when directed so to do by order of the
Village Board. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
1-1-5: INTERPRETATION AND APPLICATION:
In the interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, said
provisions shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the
promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general
welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the
subject matter than the general provision imposed by the Code, the provision
imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be
controlling. (1951 Code 19-1-2)
1-1-6: HISTORICAL CITATION PROCEDURE:
The following is an example of the method used in citing the various provisions
of the 1951 Municipal Code as said provisions are found in this Code. The
appropriate amending ordinances are listed in numerical order following the
1951 Code citation: (1951 Code 2-9-6; Ords. 487, 76-7-12). In the 1951 Code
reference, the first number indicates the Chapter, the second number indicates
the Article and the third number indicates the section; also, the ordinance
citations show only the ordinance number and not the date and section of the
ordinance. (1985 Code)
1-1-7: ILLINOIS COMPILED STATUTES:
Pursuant to Public Act 87-1005, the Illinois Revised Statutes were recodified
as the Illinois Compiled Statutes. As such, all references contained in this
Code to the Illinois Revised Statutes are hereby revised to read as if said
reference is to the corresponding section of the Illinois Compiled Statutes, as
such correspondence is shown on the official cross-reference published by the
Illinois Legislative Reference Bureau, as more fully set forth in the Tables
Volume of the State Bar Association Edition of the Illinois Compiled Statutes
published by West Publishing Co. A copy of said cross-reference publication is
on file with the Village Clerk. (Ord. 93-12-43)
CHAPTER 2
SAVING CLAUSE
SECTION:
1-2-1: Repeal of General Ordinances
1-2-2: Public Utility Ordinances
1-2-3: Court Proceedings
1-2-4: Severability Clause
1-2-1: REPEAL OF GENERAL ORDINANCES:
All general ordinances of the Village passed prior to the adoption of this
Village Code are hereby repealed, except such as are included in this Village
Code or are by necessary implication herein reserved from repeal (subject to
the saving clauses contained in the following sections), and excluding the
following ordinances which are not hereby repealed: tax levy ordinances;
appropriation ordinances; ordinances relating to boundaries and annexations;
franchise ordinances and other ordinances granting special rights to persons or
corporations; contract ordinances and ordinances authorizing the execution of a
contract or the issuance of warrants; salary ordinances; ordinances
establishing, naming or vacating streets, alleys or other public places;
improvement ordinances; bond ordinances; ordinances relating to elections;
ordinances relating to the transfer or acceptance of real estate by or from the
Village; and all special ordinances. (1985 Code)
1-2-2: PUBLIC UTILITY ORDINANCES:
No ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with streets and other
public ways, or relating to the conduct, duties, service or rates of public
utilities shall be replaced by virtue of the preceding section, excepting as
this Village Code may contain provisions for such matters, in which case this
Village Code shall be considered as amending such ordinance or ordinances in
respect to such provisions only. (1985 Code)
1-2-3: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
No new ordinance shall be construed or held to repeal a former ordinance,
whether such former ordinance is expressly repealed or not, as to any offense
committed against such former ordinance or as to any act done, any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment so incurred, or any right accrued or claim arising
under the former ordinance, or in any way whatever to affect any such offense
or act so committed or so done, or any penalty, forfeiture or punishment so
incurred or any right accrued or claim arising before the new ordinance takes
effect, save only that proceedings thereafter shall conform to the ordinance in
force at the time of such proceeding, so far as practicable. If any penalty,
forfeiture or punishment be mitigated by any provision of a new ordinance, such
provisions may be, by the consent of the party affected, applied to any
judgment announced after the new ordinance takes effect.
This Section shall extend to all repeals, either by express words or
implication, whether the repeal is in the ordinance making any new provisions
upon the same subject or in any other ordinance.
Nothing contained in this Chapter shall be construed as abating any action now
pending under or by virtue of any general ordinance of the Village herein
repealed and the provisions of all general ordinances contained in this Code
shall be deemed to be continuing provisions and not a new enactment of the same
provision; nor shall this Chapter be deemed as discontinuing, abating,
modifying or altering any penalty accrued or to accrue, or as affecting the
liability of any person, firm or corporation, or as waiving any right of the
Village under any ordinance or provision thereof in force at the time of the
adoption of this Village Code. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
1-2-4: SEVERABILITY CLAUSE:
If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase
of this Village Code or any part thereof is for any reason held to be
unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent
jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of
the remaining portions of this Code, or any part thereof. The Village Board of
Trustees hereby declares that it would have passed each section, subsection,
subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause or phrase thereof irrespective of the
fact that any one or more sections, subsections, subdivisions, paragraphs,
sentences, clauses or phrases be declared unconstitutional, invalid or
ineffective. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
CHAPTER 3
DEFINITIONS
SECTION:
1-3-1: Construction of Words
1-3-2: Definitions
1-3-3: Catchlines
1-3-1: CONSTRUCTION OF WORDS:
Whenever any word in any section of this Village Code importing the plural
number is used in describing or referring to any matters, parties or persons,
any single matter, party or person shall be deemed to be included, although
distributive words may not have been used. When any subject matter, party or
person is referred to in this Village Code by words importing the singular
number only, or the masculine gender, several matters, parties or persons and
females as well as males and bodies corporate shall be applied to any section
of this Village Code which contains any express provision excluding such
construction or where the subject matter or content may be repugnant thereto.
All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in his Code
shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the
Board of Trustees may be fully carried out.
   A.   Ordinance: The word "ordinance" contained in the ordinances of the
Village has been changed in the content of this Village Code to "title",
"chapter", "section" and/or "subsection" or words of like import for
organizational and clarification purposes only. Such change to the Village's
ordinances is not meant to amend the passage and effective dates of such
original ordinances.
   B.   Computation of Time: Whenever a notice is required to be given or an
act to be done a certain length of time before any proceeding shall be had, the
day on which such notice is given, or such act is done, shall be counted in
computing the time, but the day on which such proceeding is to be held shall
not be counted. Time shall mean Central Standard Time, except when the State of
Illinois is on Daylight Saving Time and then it shall mean Central Daylight
Saving Time.
   C.   Delegation of Authority: Whenever a provision appears requiring the
head of a department or some other Village officer to do some act or perform
some duty, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section
specify otherwise.
   D.   Joint Authority: All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or
more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a
majority of such persons or officers.
   E.   Nontechnical and Technical Words: Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired peculiar and appropriate
meanings in law shall be construed and understood according to such meanings.
   F.   Shall: The word "shall" is mandatory. (1951 Code 19-1-2; 1985 Code)
1-3-2: DEFINITIONS:
Whenever the following words or terms are used in
this Code, they shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them, unless the
context makes such meaning repugnant thereto:
AGENT: A person on behalf of another.
BOARD: Unless otherwise indicated, the Board of Trustees of the Village.
CODE: The Village Code of Oak Lawn, Illinois and amendments thereto.
CORPORATE or VILLAGE LIMITS: The legal boundaries of the Village of Oak Lawn.
COUNTY: The County of Cook, State of Illinois.
EMPLOYEES: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village employee by
title only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words, "of the
Village of Oak Lawn".
FEE: A sum of money charged by the Village for the carrying on of a business,
profession or occupation.
FISCAL YEAR: The fiscal year of the Village shall be the same as the calendar
year.
LICENSE: The permission granted for the carrying on of a business, profession
or occupation.
MAYOR: See Village President.
MISDEMEANOR: Any offense for which a sentence to a term of imprisonment in
other than a penitentiary for less than one year may be imposed.
MONTH: A calendar month.
NUISANCE: Anything offensive or obnoxious to the health and welfare of the
inhabitants of the Village; or any act or thing repugnant to, or creating a
hazard to, or having a detrimental effect on the property of another person or
to the community.
OATH: Shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by
law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words
"swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed".
OCCUPANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person
who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or
with others.
OFFENSE: Any act forbidden by any provision of this Code or the omission of any
act required by the provisions of this Code.
OFFICERS: Whenever reference is made in this Code to a Village officer by title
only, this shall be construed as though followed by the words "of the Village
of Oak Lawn".
OPERATOR: The person who is in charge of any operation, business or profession.
OWNER: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any part
owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or lessee of the whole or a
part of such building or land.
PERSON: Any public or private corporation, firm, partnership, association,
organization, government or any other group acting as a unit, as well as a
natural person.
PERSONAL PROPERTY: Every description of money, goods, chattels, effects,
evidence of rights in action and all written instruments by which any pecuniary
obligation, right or title to property is created, acknowledged, transferred,
increased, defeated, discharged or diminished and every right of interest
therein.
PRECEDING, FOLLOWING: Next before and next after, respectively.
PROPERTY: Includes real and personal property.
REAL PROPERTY: Includes lands, tenements and hereditaments.
RETAILER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, this term shall be understood
to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles or things in small
quantities direct to the consumer.
SIDEWALK: Any portion of a street between the curb line and the adjacent
property line, intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways.
SIGNATURE OR SUBSCRIPTION: Includes a mark when the person cannot write.
STATE: The State of Illinois.
STREET: This term shall include alleys, lanes, courts, boulevards, public
squares, public places and sidewalks.
TENANT: As applied to a building or land, this term shall include any person
who occupies the whole or any part of such building or land, whether alone or
with others.
VILLAGE: The Village of Oak Lawn, County of Cook, State of Illinois.
VILLAGE PRESIDENT: The President of the Village may be referred to as "Mayor"
or "President" of the Village.
WHOLESALER AND WHOLESALE DEALER: Unless otherwise specifically defined, such
terms shall be understood to relate to the sale of goods, merchandise, articles
or things in quantity to persons who purchase for the purpose of resale.
WRITTEN; IN WRITING: May include printing and any other mode of representing
words and letters, but when the written signature of any person is required by
law to any official or public writing or bond required by law, it shall be in
the proper handwriting of such person, or in case he is unable to write, by his
proper mark.
YEAR: A calendar year. (1951 Code 2-8-2, 19-1-2; Ord. 68-26-72; 1985 Code)
1-3-3: CATCHLINES:
The catchlines of the several sections of this Code are intended as mere
catchwords to indicate the content of the section and shall not be deemed or
taken to be titles of such sections, nor be deemed to govern, limit, modify or
in any manner affect the scope, meaning or intent of the provisions of any
division or section hereof, nor unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or re-
enacted. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
CHAPTER 4
GENERAL PENALTY
SECTION:
1-4-1: General Penalty
1-4-1-1: Imprisonment Fine Surcharge
1-4-2: Citation Procedure (Rep. by Ord. 08-16-41)
1-4-3: Application Of Provisions
1-4-4: Liability Of Officers
1-4-5: Alternative Penalties; Compliance Tickets (Rep. by Ord. 08-16-41)
1-4-6: Release Of Liens; Fees
1-4-7: Community Service
1-4-8: Repeat Offenders
1-4-1: GENERAL PENALTY:
Except as otherwise provided in section
1-4-1-1 of this chapter, any person convicted of a violation of any section or
provision of this code, where no other penalty is set forth, shall be punished
by a fine not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and not to exceed seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for any offense. The person upon whom any fine
or penalty is imposed, upon order of the court before which the conviction is
had, may be imprisoned until the fine, penalty and costs are paid. No
imprisonment, however, shall exceed six (6) months for any one offense. (Ord.
09-03-09)
1-4-1-1: IMPRISONMENT FINE SURCHARGE:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary set forth in this code, in the event
that a person is arrested and imprisoned for a violation of any provision of
this code, and such person is subsequently convicted for said violation, the
fine assessed for the violation shall be increased by the amount of eighty
dollars ($80.00) per day for each day (or portion thereof) that the violator
was imprisoned in the village jail (the "imprisonment fine surcharge"). The
imprisonment fine surcharge shall be assessed by the court, the administrative
adjudication hearing officer, or such other tribunal of competent jurisdiction
before which the conviction is had. (Ord. 09-03-09)
1-4-2: CITATION PROCEDURE:
(Rep. by Ord. 08-16-41)
1-4-3: APPLICATION OF PROVISIONS:
The penalty provided in this chapter shall be applicable to every section of
this code the same as though it were a part of each and every separate section.
Any person convicted of a violation of any section of this code where any duty
is prescribed or obligation imposed, or where any action which is of a
continuing nature is forbidden or is declared to be unlawful, shall be deemed
guilty of a misdemeanor. A separate offense shall be deemed committed upon each
day such duty or obligation remains unperformed or such act continues, unless
otherwise specifically provided in this code.
In all cases where the same offense is made punishable or is created by
different clauses or sections of this code, the prosecuting officer may elect
under which to proceed; but not more than one recovery shall be had against the
same person for the same offense; provided, that the revocation of a license or
permit shall not be considered a recovery or penalty so as to bar any other
penalty being enforced.
Whenever the doing of any act or the omission to do any act constitutes a
breach of any section or provision of this code and there shall be no fine or
penalty specifically declared for such breach, the provisions of this chapter
shall apply. (1951 Code 19-1-3; 1985 Code)
1-4-4: LIABILITY OF OFFICERS:
No provision of this code designating the duties of any officer or employee
shall be so construed as to make such officer or employee liable for any fine
or penalty provided for a failure to perform such duty, unless the intention of
the board of trustees to impose such fine or penalty on such officer or
employee is specifically and clearly expressed in the section creating the
duty. (1951 Code 19-1-4; 1985 Code)
1-4-5: ALTERNATIVE PENALTIES; COMPLIANCE TICKETS:
(Rep. by Ord. 08-16-41)
1-4-6: RELEASE OF LIENS; FEES:
Whenever the village has placed a lien against a parcel of property as a result
of any provision of this code or state statute, said lien shall not be released
until the village has received reimbursement for the following costs, in
addition to payment of the lien amount:
   A.   The actual cost of preparing the lien document;
   B.   The actual cost of recording the lien; and
   C.   The actual cost of preparing the release of lien document. (Ord. 94-3-
11)
1-4-7: COMMUNITY SERVICE:
In lieu of, or in addition to, the general penalties set forth in section
1-4-1 of this chapter, or any other section of this code which provides for a
monetary penalty for violation thereof, any person convicted of a violation of
any provision or section of this code may be required to perform some
reasonable public service work/community service work. (Ord. 95-20-78)
1-4-8: REPEAT OFFENDERS:
   A.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this code which may require the
issuance of a notice of violation and a cure period prior to the issuance of a
court citation for a violation of this code, no such notice of violation or
cure period shall be required where a person or said person's property is in
violation of this code and said person has been issued a notice of violation
relative to the same violation within the previous twelve (12) month period. In
such case, a court citation can be immediately issued relative to the
identified code violation.
   B.   In the event that any person has been found guilty of a violation of
this code by a court of competent jurisdiction within the twelve (12) month
period preceding a second conviction for the same offense, unless a greater
minimum fine is provided for in the code provision that has been violated, the
minimum fine for said second offense shall be not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00). (Ord. 97-11-52)
CHAPTER 5
VILLAGE PRESIDENT
SECTION:
1-5-1: Election, Term Of Office, Qualifications
1-5-2: Salary
1-5-3: Function As Mayor
1-5-4: Powers And Duties
1-5-5: Ordinance Approval Or Veto
1-5-6: President Pro Tempore
1-5-7: Emergency Interim Village President
1-5-1: ELECTION, TERM OF OFFICE, QUALIFICATIONS:
There shall be elected at the regular village election a president of the
village, who shall hold his office for four (4) years and until his successor
is elected and qualified. He shall be a citizen of the United States, a
qualified elector, and shall have resided within the corporate limits of the
village for at least one year next preceding the election at which he is a
candidate. (1951 Code 1-2-1)
1-5-2: SALARY:
The president shall devote such time to the duties of his office as the
faithful discharge thereof may require and shall receive the following as
compensation:
   A.   As established in 2005, the president currently receives such salary as
reflected in the most recent pay and benefit ordinance.
   B.   Beginning June 1, 2025, for terms commencing after the consolidated
election in April of 2025, the use of pay and benefit ordinances to set
salaries will be discontinued, and, instead, the president shall receive a
salary of $4,200 per month, payable in accordance with the village’s regular
bi-weekly payroll schedule. Beginning June 1, 2026, and each June 1st
thereafter for as long as the individual remains in office, an incumbent
president shall receive an increase in the compensation then in effect equal to
the percent change in the Chicago Area Consumer Price Index for all Urban
Consumers (CPI-U) as calculated and published by the federal government for the
period beginning May of the previous year and ending April of the current year,
rounded to the next highest dollar amount as appropriate for purposes of
resulting in an even dollar amount for payroll purposes. Thereafter, newly
elected non-incumbent presidents’ compensation shall begin at a rate of $4,200
per month, payable in accordance with the village’s regular bi-weekly payroll
schedule, and after twelve months will be increased annually on June 1st of
each year, as indicated above based on the applicable CPI-U, for as long as the
individual remains in office.
   C.   Beginning June 1, 2025, for terms commencing after the April 2025
consolidated election, the village president shall not receive any additional
compensation for serving as Liquor Commissioner.
   D.   In addition, the village president is currently eligible, and will
remain eligible, to participate in the following village group employee benefit
plans, on the same basis and terms that are applicable to non-union employees:
group health insurance, health insurance buy-out, dental and vision insurance,
life insurance, and flexible benefit plan. In addition, the village president
is currently eligible, and will remain eligible, to participate in other
voluntary benefit plans, such as accident, critical illness, hospital, and
legal, with costs to be fully paid by the participants.
   E.   In accordance with Resolution No. 13-11-28, the village president is
not eligible to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF).
   F.   No other compensation shall be allowed the village president. (1951
Code 1-2-2, 1-2-3; Ords. 65-40-2, 68(8)-11-38, 82-1-4, 82-1-5, 82-11-42, 83-9-
18; 1985 Code; Ords. 93-9-27, 94-12-53, 05-15-50; 24-18-67)
1-5-3: FUNCTION AS MAYOR:
The president of the board of trustees shall perform the duties and exercise
the powers conferred upon the mayor of a city. The president may be referred to
as mayor. He may sign as mayor in his official capacity as president. Where the
word "president" is used throughout this code and in any village matter, it
shall also mean "mayor". If the word "mayor" is used, it shall also mean
"president". (1951 Code 1-2-3; Ord. 65-40-2)
1-5-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   General: The president shall supervise the conduct of all appointed
officers and see that they faithfully and efficiently discharge the duties of
their respective offices; he shall inquire into all reasonable complaints made
against them and cause all their neglects or violations of duties to be
promptly corrected; and he shall, from time to time, give the board of trustees
such information relative to the affairs of the village as he may deem proper
and recommend to it consideration of any measure he may deem expedient, tending
to the well being, security and improvement of the village.
   B.   Pardons: The president may, for good and sufficient reasons, release
any person convicted of or any person imprisoned for violation of any village
ordinance. The president shall cause a proper record thereof to be made and
shall report such release with the cause therefor to the board of trustees at
its first session thereafter. The president shall have the power to direct the
prosecuting attorney to nonsuit any ordinance violation pending in the circuit
court.
   C.   Sign Documents; Revoke Licenses:
      1.   The president shall sign all commissions, licenses, permits and
warrants granted, issued or ordered by the board of trustees, or authorized by
the ordinances of the village, and may revoke any such licenses for the causes
herein provided.
      2.   The president shall sign, and is hereby authorized to sign in behalf
of the village, all instruments necessary to the prompt prosecution or defense
of any or all actions brought by or against said village including bonds for
injunction. (1951 Code 1-2-6, 1-2-8, 1-2-9, 1-2-11; 1985 Code)
1-5-5: ORDINANCE APPROVAL OR VETO:
   A.   Veto Powers: The president of the board of trustees may exercise the
same veto powers, and with like effect, as the mayor of a city, and the board
of trustees may pass ordinances over such veto in like manner as a city
council.
   B.   Procedure: The president shall carefully inspect all ordinances passed
by the board of trustees and fix his official signature to such as he may
approve and return them to the village clerk. Such ordinances as he shall not
approve shall be returned to the board of trustees, with his objections thereto
in writing, at the next regular meeting of the board of trustees occurring
after the passage thereof. Such veto may extend to any one or more items or
appropriations contained in any ordinance making appropriations, or to the
entire ordinance and in case the veto only extends to a part of such ordinance,
the residue thereof shall take effect and be in force; but in case the
president shall fail to return any ordinance with his objections thereto by the
time aforesaid, he shall be deemed to have approved such ordinance and the same
shall take effect accordingly. (1951 Code 1-2-3, 1-2-7; Ord. 65-40-2)
1-5-6: PRESIDENT PRO TEMPORE:
During a temporary absence of the president or his inability to act, the board
of trustees shall elect one of its members to act as a president pro tempore
who, during the president's absence or disability, shall possess the powers of
the president. (1951 Code 1-2-4)
1-5-7: EMERGENCY INTERIM VILLAGE PRESIDENT:
The village president shall designate in writing and file with the village
clerk and village manager at least three (3) and no more than seven (7)
emergency interim successor village presidents pursuant to the emergency
interim executive succession act 1  to act in the event of the unavailability
of the president during an emergency. As provided by the act, the following
terms shall have the meanings hereinafter ascribed to them:
ATTACK: An attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States
causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property
or persons in the United States in any manner by sabotage or by the use of
bombs, missiles, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological
or biological means or other weapons or processes.
DISASTER: A situation determined by the governor to be an occurrence or threat
of catastrophic and widespread injury or loss of life or property resulting
from any natural or manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood,
earthquake, epidemic and explosion.
EMERGENCY: An attack or a disaster.
EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSOR: A person designated pursuant to this chapter in
the event the president is unavailable to exercise the powers and discharge the
duties of president until a successor is appointed or elected and qualified as
may be provided by the constitution, statutes, charters and ordinances or until
the lawful incumbent is able to resume the exercise of the powers and discharge
the duties of the office.
UNAVAILABLE: Means either that a vacancy in the office of president exists and
there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of the powers and discharge the
duties of the office or that the lawful incumbent of the office (including any
deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an office because of
a vacancy) and his duly authorized deputy are absent or unable to exercise the
powers and discharge the duties of the office. (Ord. 09-13-28)
 
Notes

CHAPTER 6
VILLAGE BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
1-6-1: Legislative Body
1-6-2: Compensation
1-6-3: Meetings Of The Board
1-6-4: Quorum
1-6-5: Rules Of Order
1-6-6: Election Districts
1-6-1: LEGISLATIVE BODY:
The legislative body of the village shall consist of the president of the
village and six (6) trustees who shall possess the qualifications for office,
be elected by the legal voters of the municipality, take the oath of office and
perform the duties provided by the Illinois Compiled Statutes 1  and this code.
The six (6) trustees shall represent six (6) districts within the village such
that there shall be one trustee from each of six (6) districts as established
in section
1-6-6 of this chapter according to law. (1951 Code 1-1-1; 1985 Code)
