1-6-2: COMPENSATION:
   A.   As established in 1985, each trustee currently receives such
compensation as reflected in the most recent pay and benefit ordinance.
   B.   Beginning June 1, 2025, for trustees whose terms commence in May, 2025,
after the consolidated election in April of 2025, the use of pay and benefit
ordinances to set salaries will be discontinued, and, instead, such trustees
shall receive a salary of $1,500 per month, payable in accordance with the
village’s regular bi-weekly payroll schedule. Further, beginning June 1, 2026,
and each June 1st thereafter for as long as the individual remains in office,
such incumbent trustees shall receive an increase in the compensation then in
effect equal to the percent change in the Chicago Area Consumer Price Index for
all Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as calculated and published by the federal
government for the period beginning May of the previous year and ending April
of the current year, rounded to the next highest dollar amount as appropriate
for purposes of resulting in an even dollar amount for payroll purposes.
Thereafter, a newly elected non-incumbent trustee’s compensation shall begin at
a rate of $1,500 per month, payable in accordance with the village’s regular
bi-weekly payroll schedule, and after twelve months will be increased annually
on June 1st of each year, as indicated above based on the applicable CPI-U, for
as long as the individual remains in office.
   C.   Beginning June 1, 2027, for trustees whose terms commence in May, 2027,
after the consolidated election in April of 2027, the use of pay and benefit
ordinances to set salaries will be discontinued, and, instead, such trustees
shall receive a salary of $1,500 per month, payable in accordance with the
village’s regular bi-weekly payroll schedule. Further, beginning June 1, 2028,
and each June 1st thereafter for as long as the individual remains in office,
such incumbent trustees shall receive an increase in the compensation then in
effect equal to the percent change in the Chicago Area Consumer Price Index for
all Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as calculated and published by the federal
government for the period beginning May of the previous year and ending April
of the current year, rounded to the next highest dollar amount as appropriate
for purposes of resulting in an even dollar amount for payroll purposes.
Thereafter, a newly elected non-incumbent trustee’s compensation shall begin at
a rate of $1,500 per month, payable in accordance with the village’s regular
bi-weekly payroll schedule, and after twelve months will be increased annually
on June 1st of each year thereafter, as indicated above based on the applicable
CPI-U, for as long as the individual remains in office.
   D.   In addition, village trustees are currently eligible, and will remain
eligible, to participate in the following village group employee benefit plans,
on the same basis and terms that are applicable to non-union employees: group
health insurance, health insurance buy-out, dental and vision insurance, life
insurance, and flexible benefit plan. In addition, village trustees are
currently eligible, and will remain eligible, to participate in other voluntary
benefit plans, such as accident, critical illness, hospital, and legal, with
costs to be fully paid by the participants.
   E.   In accordance with Resolution Nos. 13-11-28 and 17-14-53, village
trustees are not eligible to participate in the Illinois Municipal Retirement
Fund (IMRF).
   F.   No other compensation shall be allowed to a village trustee. (1985
Code, Ord. 24-18-67)
1-6-3: MEETINGS OF THE BOARD:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Regular meetings of the president and board of
trustees shall be held on the second and fourth Tuesday of each month. The
regular meeting held on the second Tuesday of each month shall be at seven
thirty o'clock (7:30) P.M. at the village hall. The meeting on the fourth
Tuesday of each month shall be at nine o’clock (9:00) a.m. at the village hall.
In case such meeting time shall fall on a legal holiday, then such meeting
shall be held the following day after such legal holiday, or, by a two-thirds
(2/3) vote of the board, the meeting may be eliminated or rescheduled. Any
regular meeting which does not fall on a legal holiday may be eliminated or
rescheduled by a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the board. Any regular meeting which
does not fall on a legal holiday may be canceled or rescheduled by a two-thirds
(2/3) vote of the board.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be held at any time on call of
the president or any two (2) or more trustees. Such call shall be in writing,
duly signed and shall be presented to the clerk who shall proceed immediately
to cause notice of the same to be served upon the president and trustees in
person or by registered letter, and in such notice shall be described in brief
the nature or object of the call.
   C.   Open To The Public: Meetings of every kind and nature shall be open to
the public, except where specifically exempted by statute. A meeting may be
open to the public and then closed to the public for the purpose of considering
matters specifically allowed to be considered at a closed meeting by statute 1
. Final action on all matters considered at a closed meeting shall be made at
an open meeting.
   D.   Public Notice: A schedule of all the regular meetings of the board of
trustees and of any board or committee shall be posted on all the buildings of
the village having an office. In addition thereto, there shall be posted on the
bulletin boards of all of said buildings at least twenty four (24) hours before
said meeting, a notice of any special meeting or any reconvened regular meeting
where the subject was not on the agenda at the scheduled regular meeting.
Notices shall be sent to news media when required by statute.
   E.   Public Announcement Policy:
      1.   Prior to regularly scheduled Oak Lawn village board meetings, Oak
Lawn families, Oak Lawn businesses, and nonprofit organizations will be given a
maximum three (3) minute time slot to present public announcements which will
be aired on the village's public access channel. Speakers will be required to
sign in and will be taken in that order. Any speaker that has had a time slot
within the last month will be moved to the end of the list to provide equal
access to all. Any props are limited to being of poster size. Filming will
begin promptly at seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and end at seven twenty five
o'clock (7:25) P.M. for the regular meeting on the second Tuesday of the month,
filming will begin promptly at eight thirty o’clock (8:30) A.M. and end at nine
o’clock (9:00) A.M. for the regular meeting on the fourth Tuesday of the month.
Speakers will be taken as long as there is time allotted.
      2.   The village of Oak Lawn reserves the right to cancel any
announcement it deems inappropriate including, but not limited to, commercial
advertisements and political announcements in support of any one candidate,
cause, or viewpoint subject to a pending vote or ballot question or does not
meet the requirements of being a not for profit, an Oak Lawn family, or Oak
Lawn business. The village of Oak Lawn does not guarantee the number of
showings or the times of the showings. The village does not endorse any one
organization over another nor does it provide editing or video enhancements to
the output. (1951 Code 1-1-2, 1-1-3, 1-1-4; Ords. 69-6-17, 73-16-15, 73-29-56,
73-35-68, 73-40-78, 81-36-76; 1985 Code; Ords. 86-3-10, 92-17-64, 05-12-31, 12-
20-68, 19-28-91)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
1-6-4: QUORUM:
A majority of the board of trustees elected shall constitute a quorum to do
business, but a smaller number may adjourn from time to time, and may compel
the attendance of absentees under such penalties as may be prescribed by
ordinance. (1951 Code 1-1-4)
1-6-5: RULES OF ORDER:
The following shall be the rules of order for the conduct of village business
by the president and board of trustees:
   A.   Opening Of Meetings: The village president shall take the chair at the
time designated for the commencement of the meeting. The president shall
immediately call the members to order.
The clerk shall proceed to call the roll of members, marking the members
present and absent for inclusion in the minutes. If a quorum is present, the
clerk shall announce that fact, and the board shall proceed with the order of
business.
   B.   Procedure In The Absence Of The President: If the president is not
present, the Board of Trustees shall elect an acting Chairman who shall act in
the President's stead. At such a meeting, the Clerk shall preside at the
commencement of the meeting for the purpose of calling the roll of members and
entertaining motions on the question of an acting Chairman. The acting Chairman
shall serve only until the adjournment of that meeting.
   C.   Order Of Business: The order of business at a Village Board meeting
shall be:
      1.   Call to order, roll call, Pledge Of Allegiance.
      2.   Public participation. Each person who desires to speak shall write
his/her name on a sign in sheet to be provided by the village clerk and then
wait until they are recognized by the village president, or temporary
chairperson in the absence of the village president. When recognized, each
person who desires to speak will then state his/her name and any comment or
question he/she may have. Each person who desires to speak shall have a maximum
of three (3) minutes to address the village board. This portion of the meeting
shall generally not exceed thirty (30) minutes, unless a majority of the
village board agrees to extend the time allotted for public participation for
that specific meeting.
      3.   Approval of minutes of previous meeting(s).
      4.   Employee recognition and awards.
      5.   New business of trustees.
      6.   Consent agenda.
      7.   Village manager's report.
      8.   Village attorney's report.
      9.   Committee reports.
      10.   Village clerk's report.
      11.   Semimonthly disbursements.
      12.   Village president's report.
      13.   Adjournment.
   D.   Powers Of The President: The Village President, as Chairman, shall
preserve order and decorum. The President may speak upon and decide all
questions of order, subject to an appeal to the Village Board. The President
shall conduct all business before the Board with fairness and impartiality to a
speedy and proper result.
   E.   Questions And Motions: Every question shall be distinctly stated by the
President before it is open for debate. Every question shall be reduced to
writing by its maker if requested by the President, Clerk or any Board member.
   F.   Addressing The Board: Any Board member who wishes to speak shall
audibly address the Chair as "Mr. President" or "Madam President". The Board
member may not speak further until recognized and named.
Trustees shall treat each other with respect and will address and refer to each
other as "Trustee (name)". The Village President and Trustees shall treat the
other members as equals. No Board member shall make any comments about another
Board member which are not pertinent to the discussions of the issue at hand.
The Chairman is obliged to recognize any Board member who wishes to speak
before a question is put to a vote.
   G.   Order And Decorum:
      1.   The Chairman shall preserve order among the audience and act to
remove anyone from the premises who, after due notice, continues to speak to
the Board without being recognized or who disrupts the decorum of the meeting.
Should the Chairman fail to call such an audience member to order, a Trustee
may request that the Chairman call the person to order by calling for a point
of order. A Trustee who is called to order shall immediately stop speaking.
Upon a request for a point of order, the Chairman must rule as to whether the
person is out of order.
      2.   The Chairman shall enforce order seriously and without regard to
political allegiance. The Chairman shall prevent disturbances against the
Board.
      3.   If there is no appeal, the decision of the Chairman shall be
conclusive. However, if a Trustee appeals the decision of the Chairman, the
Board shall decide the matter without debate by a roll call. The question shall
be: "Shall the decision of the Chairman be upheld?".
   H.   Consideration Of Motions: When a motion has been made and seconded, it
shall be debated. Following debate, the question shall be called for a vote.
Should the Chairman fail to call the question, or refuse to call the question,
any Trustee can address the Chairman and state, "Call the question". If the
Chairman continues to refuse to call the question, the Trustee can call for a
point of order, which requires the Chairman to make a ruling, which ruling may
then be appealed.
   I.   Duty To Vote: Whenever any Trustee, or the Village President, has a
present interest in the matter before the Board, he or she shall not vote on
the matter and shall explain the reason for his or her abstention. The vote of
a member who passes, votes "present", or votes "abstain", shall be added to the
majority of those voting on the question, unless the vote is a tie.
   J.   Consideration Of Postponed Questions: When a question is postponed
indefinitely, it shall not be voted upon before the next regular Board meeting.
   K.   Standing Committees:
      1.   The Committee of the Whole shall consist of all Trustees. The
remaining standing committees shall consist of three (3) Trustees appointed
upon motion by one (1) Trustee and approved by a majority vote of the Village
Board. A standing committee may also consist of ex officio members as
identified in this chapter. The Chairperson of each standing committee shall be
appointed by the members of the committee.
      2.   The President shall be a nonvoting ex officio member of all standing
committees of which the President is not an appointed member. The President
shall be the Chairman of the Committee of the Whole.
      3.   The members of the standing committees shall be appointed annually
at the second regular meeting of the Board of Trustees in May of each year for
a term of one (1) year. If no action is taken to replace any committee member,
each serving committee member shall retain said committee member position for
an additional one (1) year term.
      4.   The standing committees of the Village Board shall be:
         a.   Finance and Technology;
         b.   Public Works;
         c.   Legislative, License, and Ethics;
         d.   Public Safety; and
         e.   Committee of the Whole.
   L.   Special Committees: Special committees may be appointed for the
consideration of any particular matter. When the Board accepts the final report
of a special committee, the committee shall stand discharged without vote
unless otherwise ordered.
   M.   Committee Reports: All committees to which any matter has been referred
shall report, in writing, if any Trustee so requests. Any committee member may
present a minority report to the Board.
   N.   Petitions And Communications:
      1.   Requirements: All petitions or communications shall be addressed to
the President and Board of Trustees, be in writing, and filed by the Clerk.
      2.   Presentation: Any Trustee presenting a communication, petition,
ordinance, resolution or similar matter shall briefly state its nature before
presenting it.
   O.   Preservation Of Papers By Clerk: The Clerk shall preserve all committee
reports, ordinances, resolutions, petitions and communications, and similar
materials to be voted on.
   P.   Rules Of Order: In all cases not covered by these rules, the provisions
in the latest published edition of "Robert's Rules of Order Revised" shall
govern in all cases to which they are applicable and in which they are not
inconsistent with the statutes or laws of the State of Illinois.
   Q.   Suspension Of Rules: The rules of procedure can be suspended by a two-
thirds (2/3) vote of the President and Trustees voting jointly. (Ords. 92-17-
64, 95-11-35, 96-10-50, 05-12-31, 05-13-40, 10-12-22, 13-09-29, 14-06-14, 17-
15-56, 21-14-71)
1-6-6: ELECTION DISTRICTS:
   A.   For purposes of electing the Trustees of the Village, the boundaries of
the Village’s six (6) districts shall be as follows:
      1.   The district map, together with the description of district
boundaries, identified as the "Official District Map for the Village of Oak
Lawn," is hereby adopted as the official village map for trustee purposes.
Districts of the Village shall be properly identified by the word "District"
followed by the Arabic numeral corresponding to the District number assigned by
the redistricting ordinance.
      2.   A copy of the map showing generally the area and boundaries of each
district together with a supplement describing the boundaries using census
blocks as determined by the United States Census Bureau of each District is on
file in the Village Clerk's office. In general, the centerline of the
identified right-of-way in a redistricting ordinance shall be the boundary line
unless otherwise noted.
      3.   Territory annexed into the Village following the adoption of a
redistricting ordinance shall, upon annexation and without further action by
the President and Board of Trustees be made a part of the adjacent or
surrounding district, provided that whenever two or more districts surround or
are contiguous with the annexed territory, the President and Board of Trustees,
shall provide as part of the ordinance annexing the territory, what District or
Districts the territory shall be made a part of.
   B.   All streets or other geographic features referenced in subsection A of
this section are those that are so shown on the maps published by the United
States bureau of the census for the 2000 census.
   C.   Any part of the village that has not been described as included in one
of the districts set forth in subsection A of this section shall be included
within the district that:
      1.   Is contiguous to the part; and
      2.   Contains the least population of all districts contiguous to the
part according to the 2000 census.
   D.   If any part of the village is described in subsection A of this section
as being in more than one district, said part shall be included within the
district that:
      1.   Is one of the districts in which that part is described in
subsection A of this section;
      2.   Is contiguous to that part; and
      3.   Contains the least population according to the 2000 census.
   E.   If any part of the village:
      1.   Is described in subsection A of this section as being in one
district; and
      2.   Is entirely surrounded by another district;
the part shall be incorporated into the district that surrounds the part.
   F.   If any part of the village:
      1.   Is described in subsection A of this section as being in one
district; and
      2.   Is not contiguous to another part of that district;
the part shall be included with the contiguous district that contains the least
population according to the 2000 census. (Ord. 2002-17-68, 22-16-53)
CHAPTER 7
COMMITTEES
SECTION:
1-7-1: Finance And Technology Committee
1-7-2: Traffic Safety Committee
1-7-3: Public Works Committee
1-7-4: Legislative, License, And Ethics Committee
1-7-5: Public Safety Committee
1-7-6: Committee Of The Whole
1-7-1: FINANCE AND TECHNOLOGY COMMITTEE:
   A.   Membership: A Finance and Technology Committee shall be appointed upon
motion by one (1) Trustee and approved by a majority of the Village Board. Said
Finance and Technology Committee shall consist of three (3) Trustees and the
committee shall appoint a Chairperson from among its members at the committee's
June meeting. The Village President, Village Treasurer, Village Manager, and IT
Director shall be ex officio members of the Finance and Technology Committee.
   B.   Meetings: The Finance and Technology Committee shall meet annually and
may hold special meetings as needed. Three (3) days' notice of the time and
place of regular and special meetings shall be given in writing by the
Secretary at the direction of the Chairman or upon the written request of not
less than two (2) members.
   C.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The power of the Finance and Technology Committee shall be to review
policies and recommend changes to the Board of Trustees. The committee shall
have the power to require Village department heads and employees to appear
before it and answer questions and assist the committee in its deliberations.
In addition, the committee shall review and advise the Board of Trustees in
relation to fiscal and technology policies of the Village, including the
following:
         a.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees regarding short and long
term investment policy of funds under their control or direction.
         b.   Examine and interpret the financial reporting system for the
Board of Trustees and recommend possible changes in it.
         c.   Review and interpret for the Board of Trustees the annual audit
as prepared by certified public accountants retained by the Village.
         d.   Advise the Board of Trustees in the selection of certified public
accountants to be used by the Village, and frequency of their change.
         e.   On behalf of the Board of Trustees, review the reports required
to be filed with the Village pursuant to the terms of subsection
9-5-12B of this Code and make recommendations thereon to the Board.
         f.   Participate with and make recommendations to the Board of
Trustees in the three (3) year reviews of each licensee pursuant to subsection
9-5-14A of this Code.
         g.   From time to time, prepare and recommend to the Board of Trustees
plans for specific improvements to or amendments to title 9, chapter 5 of this
Code.
         h.   Study, review and advise the Village Board on utilizing
technology to make Village operations more efficient and resident friendly, and
to enhance communications with residents.
      2.   The Finance and Technology Committee, established pursuant to this
section shall exercise such powers and perform such functions in connection
therewith the BTN and title 9, chapter 5 of this Code as the Village Board
shall from time to time provide the following information including, but not
limited to:
         a.   The committee shall advise the Village Board with respect to all
aspects of the grantee's actions in connection with the BTN in the Village.
         b.   The committee shall review all aspects of the grantee's actions
in connection with the BTN.
         c.   The committee, if it deems it necessary and according to such
procedural rules as it may decide which afford the grantee and a subscriber a
fair hearing, may conduct hearings in review of grantee decisions and actions
with respect to section
9-5-10 of this Code. Decisions by the committee with respect to such hearings
shall be binding upon the grantee.
   D.   Relation With Other Agencies: The Finance and Technology Committee
shall not review matters under the control of the pension fund boards 1  or the
agencies having jurisdiction over Village related funds, but only those under
control or direction of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 17-15-56)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 7 and 8 of this Code.
1-7-2: TRAFFIC SAFETY COMMITTEE 2 :
   A.   Appointment And Membership:
      1.   There is hereby created and established a seven (7) member Traffic
Safety Committee, whereby the President shall appoint one (1) member and each
Village Trustee shall appoint one (1) member to the Committee from their
district. All appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1 of
the calendar year. Members of the Traffic Safety Committee serving as of the
effective date hereof shall serve until the end of the term to which appointed
and until their successors are named and qualified. Effective September 1,
2019, a full term shall be four (4) years and terms shall be staggered so not
more than three (3) expire each year. Such staggered terms shall coincide with
District 1, 3, and 5 appointees to expire opposite years of District 2, 4, and
6 appointees. For purposes of this Chapter, such appointments for District 2,
4, and 6 beginning on September 1, 2019, shall have initial term limit to end
in calendar year 2021 so as to initiate such staggered terms. If a vacancy
exists following the failure and/or refusal by a Village Trustee to appoint a
member by October 1 of the calendar year, an appointment shall be made by a
recommendation from the President with approval of the majority of the Village
Board.
         a.   The President and Board of Trustees may compel attendance of any
absent member and may remove any such member from said Committee if that member
misses three (3) consecutive meetings. The removal shall be initiated by the
President and subject to the confirmation of such removal by the advice and
consent of the Village Board.
         b.   Each member of the Committee shall receive a sum of one hundred
dollars ($100.00) per meeting for every properly posted meeting attended, or
such prorated portion thereof as shall represent the time served in a given
calendar year, with a minimum annual renumeration of $500.00 per member if the
member attends 70% or more of all properly posted meetings. This remuneration
is intended to cover normal and necessary expenses of the member. Additional or
unusual expenses may be covered as budgeted upon receipt of proper evidence of
expenditure and approval by this Committee.
         c.   All appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1
the calendar year. Members of the Traffic Safety Committee shall serve as of
the effective date hereof and shall serve until the end of the term to which
appointed and until their successors are named and qualified.
      2.   A Chairman shall be selected by the committee from its membership.
      3.   Members of staff who shall sit with the committee and act as
advisors, but shall not have committee voting privileges, shall consist of at
least one (1) member from each of the following Village departments:
         Department of Community Development and Growth Management
         Police Department
         Public Works Department
   B.   Meetings:
      1.   Regular Meetings: Meetings shall be held at every month on the 1st
Thursday of said month, except that the Board may, by rule, provide for
changing the date for seasonal reasons in the event there is no pending
business.
      2.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the chairman or
by any three (3) members of the Board.
      3.   Open To The Public: All meetings of the Architectural Review &
Preservation Commission and its committees shall be open meetings as required
under the applicable statutes of the State of Illinois and codes of the
Village.
   C.   Duties And Responsibilities: The Traffic Safety Committee shall review
and advise the Board of Trustees in relation to the traffic policies of the
Village, including the following:
      1.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees regarding short term and
long term traffic policies;
      2.   Review and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees on all
citizens' petitions for traffic control changes, including, but not limited to,
requests for speed reductions, stop signs and traffic control devices;
      3.   Review and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees on all
traffic studies prepared by consultants hired by the Village.
   D.   Powers: The power of the Traffic Safety Committee shall be to review
traffic policies and recommend changes to the Board of Trustees.
   E.   Procedure For Traffic Changes: The following procedures shall be
followed for all requests for traffic changes:
      Step 1: All requests for traffic control devices must be in writing,
regardless of their origin. Requests must be submitted to the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management no later than ten (10) days prior
to the next scheduled meeting, to assure placement on the agenda.
      Step 2: The Department of Community Development and Growth Management
will assign a number and send a response to the petitioner indicating that his
request will be discussed at the next meeting and he will be invited to attend.
No more than three (3) persons involved with the petition will be permitted to
speak to the subject.
      Step 3: The Department of Community Development and Growth Management
will send a copy of the request to each of the members of the Traffic Safety
Committee.
      Step 4: Upon receipt of copy of request, the area representative will
make immediate personal contact with petitioner to discuss the nature of the
request.
      Step 5: The request will be submitted to the Traffic Safety Committee as
an agenda item. The Traffic Safety Committee, petitioner, and staff will
informally discuss the request made and study the information presented in
order to arrive at a consensus of the members regarding the request.
      Step 6: Pursuant to the discussions which take place in step 5 of this
subsection, staff will propose their recommendations regarding the item.
      Step 7: The item will again be placed on the agenda of the committee,
accompanied by staff recommendations.
      Step 8: The staff and Traffic Safety Committee will make a joint
recommendation as to the disposition of the request.
      Step 9: Staff will prepare any sign drawings which may be necessary to
assist in the posting of the signs as recommended.
      Step 10: The request will be submitted to the Village President and Board
for action, accompanied by the following documents:
         1. The final report of the staff;
          2. The joint recommendation of the Traffic Safety Committee and
staff;
         3. Any sign drawing which may be necessary.
      Step 11: The Board of Trustees will either approve or deny the ordinance
as presented.
      Step 12: If the request is denied by the Board of Trustees, the matter
will be referred back to the Traffic Safety Committee to reevaluate its
recommendations. If the conclusions of the Traffic Safety Committee remain as
originally suggested, the item will be placed on file for later routine follow-
up on an ongoing basis. If the committee recommendation is amended or revised
from that which it originally made, the matter will return to step 5 of this
subsection and continue on from there. If the request is approved by the Board
of Trustees, the Village Attorney will be authorized to prepare the required
ordinance for adoption.
      Step 13: The Village Attorney will submit a copy of the proposed
ordinance to the Department of Community Development and Growth Management to
assure conformity with the approved request.
      Step 14: Upon approval by the Department of Community Development and
Growth Management, the Village Attorney will present the proposed ordinance to
the Board of Trustees for approval and adoption.
      Step 15: Immediately after passage of the ordinance, the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management shall issue a written order to the
Public Works Department for the installation of signs, as required by the
ordinance.
      Step 16: No sooner than ten (10) days after adoption of the ordinance,
the Public Works Department will post signs as required by the ordinance, and
drawings (if necessary) as approved by the Board of Trustees.
      Step 17: The Police Department will begin enforcement of the ordinance
immediately following the installation of signs.
   F.   Emergency Traffic Changes: Where a requested traffic change involves
serious imminent safety issues that cannot be addressed adequately through the
procedure for traffic changes as outlined in subsection E of this section, the
requested change may be heard directly by the Village Board without going
through the procedure for traffic changes as outlined in subsection E of this
section. (Ord. 84-5-10, 1985 Code, Ords. 92-02-12, 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 01-09-31,
06-23-137, 19-16-67, 23-13-47)
 
Notes
2 2. See title 11, "Motor Vehicles And Traffic", of this Code.
1-7-3: PUBLIC WORKS COMMITTEE:
   A.   Appointment And Membership: A Public Works Committee shall be appointed
upon motion by one (1) Trustee and approved by a majority of the Village Board.
Said Public Works Committee shall consist of three (3) Trustees, and the
committee shall appoint a Chairperson from among its members at the committee's
June meeting. The Director of Public Works, Village President and Village
Engineer shall be ex officio members of the Public Works Committee.
   B.   Meetings: The Public Works Committee shall meet annually and may hold
special meetings as needed. Three (3) days' notice of the time and place of
regular and special meetings shall be given in writing by the Secretary at the
direction of the Chairman or upon the written request of not less than two (2)
members.
   C.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The power of the Public Works Committee shall be to review policies
and recommend changes to the Board of Trustees. In addition, the committee
shall have the power to require Village department heads and employees to
appear before it and answer questions and assist the committee in its
deliberations.
      2.   The Public Works Committee shall review and advise the Board of
Trustees in relation to public works and waterworks policies of the Village,
including the following:
         a.   Investigate and make studies of the Public Works Department and
its policies and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees relative
thereto.
         b.   Investigate and make studies of the waterworks system and make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees relative thereto.
         c.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees regarding short term and
long term maintenance and repair needs of streets, curbs, sidewalks,
streetlights, sewers, water mains and appurtenances and public buildings under
the jurisdiction of the Department of Public Works of the Village.
         d.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees regarding short term and
long term maintenance and repair needs of water mains and appurtenances of the
complete waterworks system.
         e.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees regarding all contracts
for the sale of water by the Village to other communities and entities.
         f.   Periodically review and advise the Board of Trustees as to
personnel and equipment needs of the Public Works Department. (Ord. 17-15-56)
1-7-4: LEGISLATIVE, LICENSE, AND ETHICS COMMITTEE:
   A.   Appointment And Membership: The Legislative, License, and Ethics
Committee shall be appointed upon motion by one (1) Trustee and approved by a
majority of the Village Board. Said Legislative, License, and Ethics Committee
shall consist of three (3) Trustees, and the committee shall appoint a
Chairperson from among its members at its June meeting. The Village President
shall be an ex officio member of the Legislative, License, and Ethics
Committee.
   B.   Meetings: The Legislative, License, and Ethics Committee shall meet
annually and may hold special meetings as needed. Three (3) days notice of the
time and place of regular and special meetings shall be given in writing by the
Secretary at the direction of the Chairman or upon the written request of not
less than two (2) members.
   C.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The power of the Legislative, License, and Ethics Committee shall be
to review policies and recommend changes to the Board of Trustees. In addition,
the committee shall have the power to require Village officers, department
heads, and employees to appear before it and answer questions and assist the
committee in its deliberations.
      2.   The Legislative, License, and Ethics Committee shall review and
advise the Board of Trustees in relation to legal policies, ordinances amending
this Code, licenses and license fees, and the Village of Oak Lawn ethics
ordinance including the following:
         a.   Review and advise the Board of Trustees on Municipal Code
violations and the prosecution and administrative adjudication thereof.
         b.   Perform detailed work and prepare the text of suggested
ordinances.
         c.   Periodically review this Code and recommend amendments,
additions, and repeals of Code provisions to the Board of Trustees.
         d.   Periodically review the procedure for issuance of business
licenses in the Village and make recommendations to the Board of Trustees
relative thereto.
         e.   Review the number and types of licenses issued in the Village and
make recommendations thereon to the Board of Trustees.
         f.   Review ethics ordinances adopted by other municipalities and
Ethics Code suggestions brought forward by the citizens of the Village and make
recommendations to the Board of Trustees relative thereto. (Ord. 17-15-56)
1-7-5: PUBLIC SAFETY COMMITTEE:
   A.   Appointment And Membership: The Public Safety Committee shall be
appointed upon motion by one (1) Trustee and approved by a majority of the
Village Board. Said Public Safety Committee shall consist of three (3)
Trustees, and the committee shall appoint a Chairperson from among its members
at its June meeting. The Village President shall be an ex officio member of the
Public Safety Committee.
   B.   Meetings: The Public Safety Committee shall meet annually and may hold
special meetings as needed. Three (3) days' notice of the time and place of
regular and special meetings shall be given in writing by the Secretary at the
direction of the Chairman or upon the written request of not less than two (2)
members.
   C.   Powers And Duties:
      1.   The power of the Public Safety Committee shall be to review policies
and recommend changes to the Board of Trustees. In addition, the committee
shall have the power to require Village department heads and employees to
appear before it and answer questions and assist the committee in its
deliberations.
      2.   The Public Safety Committee shall give advice to the Fire Chief and
Police Chief when asked.
      3.   The Public Safety Committee shall review and advise the Board of
Trustees in relation to public safety policies of the Village, including the
following:
         a.   Provide support to works of ongoing projects of the Police and
Fire Departments.
         b.   Provide guidance on police and fire activities in accordance with
the Village policy. (Ord. 17-15-56)
1-7-6: COMMITTEE OF THE WHOLE:
   A.   Membership: The Committee of the Whole shall consist of the Village
President and all Trustees currently holding office. The Village President
shall be Chairperson of the Committee of the Whole, and the Village Treasurer,
Manager and Director of Administrative Services shall be ex officio members of
the committee.
   B.   Meetings: Committee of the Whole meetings shall be held on the second
Tuesday of each month at six fifteen o'clock (6:15) P.M. at the Oak Lawn
Village Hall immediately preceding the regular Village Board meeting if
requested by the Village President or three (3) or more Trustees. When such
meeting time shall fall on a legal holiday, then such meeting shall be held on
the same day as the rescheduled, regular Village Board meeting. Committee of
the Whole meetings shall end at the hour of seven fifteen o'clock (7:15) P.M.,
when practicable.
   C.   Purpose: The purpose of the Committee of the Whole meetings shall be
primarily for discussing and vetting items which will be brought before the
Village Board for eventual consideration and approval. Routine committee and
commission referrals need not be placed on the Committee of the Whole agenda
unless said referrals require a presentation and/or upon which discussion is
anticipated. In no event shall the Committee of the Whole vote on ordinances or
resolutions.
   D.   Agenda: The agenda shall be prepared by the Village Clerk and shall be
in the following form:
      1.   Roll call
      2.   Pledge of Allegiance
      3.   Items for discussion on the regular meeting agenda
      4.   Items for discussion on the next or future meeting agendas
      5.   Adjournment. (Ord. 17-15-56)
CHAPTER 8
VILLAGE CLERK
SECTION:
1-8-1: Bond
1-8-2: Duties
1-8-3: Hold Office Of Collector
1-8-4: Deputy Village Clerk; Appointment And Powers
1-8-5: Compensation
1-8-1: BOND:
Before entering upon the duties of the office of village clerk, the clerk shall
execute a bond with security payable to the village in the penal sum of five
thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful performance of the
duties of the office according to law and the ordinances of the village. (1951
Code 1-3, 2-4; Ords. 67-1-3, 76-2-5)
1-8-2: DUTIES:
   A.   General: The village clerk shall, in addition to the duties now imposed
upon such officer by statute, perform the following duties:
      1.   The clerk shall keep an office for the transaction of village
business.
      2.   The clerk shall issue notices of meetings to the president and
members of the village board, and when directed by that body, to the members of
the different committees of that body and to all persons whose attendance will
be required before that body or any such committee when so directed. The clerk
shall also issue and cause to be served notices of said meetings. The clerk
shall also cause the notices to be sent, posted and published as required by
subsection
1-6-3D of this title.
      3.   The clerk shall attest all the licenses granted under the ordinances
of the village.
      4.   The clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the officers of the
village and to the various committees, all bills, resolutions, communications
and other documents referring to such officers and committees.
      5.   The clerk shall, without delay, deliver to the president all
ordinances or resolutions under the clerk's charge which may require approval
or other action by the president, with all papers and information on which the
same were founded.
      6.   The clerk shall perform such other duties as may be required by the
president and board of trustees and the ordinances of the village.
   B.   Corporate Seal And Records: The clerk shall keep the corporate seal and
affix the same to all papers which require it. The clerk shall keep all records
and papers belonging to the village and attend all meetings of the president
and board of trustees, and keep a full record of its proceedings in the
journal. The clerk shall make proper copies of all papers duly filed in such
office and make transcripts from the journal and other records and files of
such office, certified by the clerk under the corporate seal.
   C.   Record, Publish Ordinances: All ordinances passed by the president and
board of trustees shall be recorded by the clerk in a book kept for that
purpose before the next regular meeting after they go into effect.
If the ordinance requires publication, the clerk shall cause the same to be
duly published. The board of trustees may authorize the publication of said
ordinance in a newspaper published in the village or to be published in a book
or pamphlet form. The clerk shall note at the foot of the record of each
ordinance, a memorandum of the date of its passage and approval or otherwise
becoming effective, and if published, the date of the publication of such
ordinances. The original shall be filed in the office of said clerk with a
certificate of publication or posting attached to the ordinance requiring
publication.
   D.   Notify Elected And Appointed Officers: It shall be the duty of the
village clerk, within five (5) days after the result of an election is declared
or an appointment made, to notify all persons elected or appointed to office.
Unless such persons shall respectively qualify in ten (10) days after such
notice, the office shall become and be vacant.
   E.   File Tax Levy Ordinances: It shall be the duty of the village clerk, on
or before the second Tuesday in September in each year, to file with the county
clerk of Cook County, Illinois, a certified copy of the levy ordinance in which
the total amount of appropriations for all corporate purposes of the village
legally made are levied and assessed for the current fiscal year.
   F.   Receive, Pass On Communications: All petitions, remonstrances, bids,
bills or other communications addressed to the village or board of trustees
shall be received by the clerk and read by the clerk at the board meeting next
succeeding their receipt, unless otherwise ordered by the village board.
   G.   Publication Of Legal Notices: The village clerk or a designated
representative shall be responsible for coordinating and publishing all legal
notices and designating the newspaper in which such notices are to be
published. All boards, commissions, committees and bureaus of the village shall
send all legal notices to the village clerk's office for publication,
designating the date or dates on which it is to be published. Upon request, the
village clerk shall supply any such board, commission, committee or bureau with
a publisher's certificate showing the date or dates on which any such notice
was published. (1951 Code 1-3, 2-4; Ords. 67-1-3, 76-2-5, 83-20-49)
1-8-3: HOLD OFFICE OF COLLECTOR:
Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-8-3, the village clerk shall hold
the office of village collector. No additional compensation shall be paid to
the village clerk for the fulfillment of such duties. (1985 Code, Ord. 24-18-
67)
1-8-4: DEPUTY VILLAGE CLERK; APPOINTMENT AND POWERS:
   A.   The village clerk may appoint one deputy village clerk, which deputy
village clerk shall have the power and duty to execute all documents required
by law or ordinance to be executed by the village clerk and to affix the seal
of the village thereto, whenever required.
   B.   The appointment of the deputy village clerk shall be made by the
village clerk and the deputy village clerk shall serve at the pleasure of and
perform such duties as directed by the village clerk.
   C.   In signing any document as described in subsection A of this section,
the deputy village clerk shall sign the name of the clerk followed with the
word "by" and the deputy village clerk's own name, and the words "deputy
village clerk".
   D.   Such duties shall be exercised at the direction of the village clerk,
or when the president and board of trustees have determined by resolution that
the village clerk is temporarily or permanently incapacitated and unable to
perform such functions.
   E.   The deputy clerk shall receive such compensation as determined by the
village clerk, in consultation with the Village Manager, and shall be eligible
to participate in all employee benefit plans, on the same terms as other non-
union village employees. (Ords. 93-11-40, 24-18-67)
1-8-5: COMPENSATION:
   A.   The Village Clerk currently receives such compensation as reflected in
the most recent pay and benefit ordinance.
   B.   Beginning June 1, 2025, for village clerks whose terms commence in May,
2025, after the consolidated election in April of 2025, the use of pay and
benefit ordinances to set salaries will be discontinued, and, instead, the
village clerk shall receive a salary of $5,000 per month, payable in accordance
with the village’s regular bi-weekly payroll schedule. Further, beginning June
1, 2026, and on each June 1st thereafter for as long as the individual remains
in office, incumbent village clerks shall receive an increase in the
compensation then in effect equal to the percent change in the Chicago Area
Consumer Price Index for all Urban Consumers (CPI-U) as calculated and
published by the federal government for the period beginning May of the
previous year and ending April of the current year, rounded to the next highest
dollar amount as appropriate for purposes of resulting in an even dollar amount
for payroll purposes. Thereafter, a newly elected non-incumbent village clerk’s
compensation shall begin at a rate of $5,000 per month, payable in accordance
with the village’s regular bi-weekly payroll schedule, and after twelve months
will be increased annually on June 1st of each year thereafter, as indicated
above based on the applicable CPI-U, for as long as the individual remains in
office.
   C.   In addition, as a part of compensation, the village clerk is currently
eligible, and will remain eligible, to participate in the following village
group employee benefit plans, on the same basis and terms that are applicable
to non-union employees: group health insurance, health insurance buy-out,
dental and vision insurance, life insurance, and flexible benefit plan. In
addition, the village clerk is currently eligible, and will remain eligible, to
participate in other voluntary benefit plans, such as accident, critical
illness, hospital, and legal, with costs to be fully paid by the participants.
   D.   The village clerk is currently eligible to participate in the Illinois
Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF).
   E.   No other compensation shall be allowed to the village clerk. (Ord. 24-
18-67)
CHAPTER 9
VILLAGE OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES 1
SECTION:
1-9-1: Administrative Organizational Plan
