Notes
1 1. A personnel policy manual is adopted as the policy of the village, a copy
  of which is on file with the village.
1-9-1: ADMINISTRATIVE ORGANIZATIONAL PLAN:
   A.   Short Title: This section shall be known as the ADMINISTRATIVE
REORGANIZATION ORDINANCE.
   B.   Administrative Officers Appointed: The village manager, as the
administrative head of the village, shall appoint people to five (5) positions
to be entitled directors, a fire chief and a police chief, who shall serve
until such time as they may resign or be replaced by the village manager, to be
given the following titles, which are hereby created:
      Director of administrative services
      Director of quality control
      Director of public works
      Fire chief
      Police chief
The village manager is authorized to appoint, suspend or discharge the
aforementioned three (3) directors, the police chief and the fire chief without
the consent of the board of trustees.
C.   Supervisory Duties; Assistants And Deputies Designated: The three (3)
directors shall each direct, coordinate and supervise two (2) or more specific
areas of service in the village, which positions shall be headed by persons
known as assistant directors or as otherwise entitled herein. The fire chief
shall supervise and direct one (1) deputy fire chief. The police chief shall
appoint, supervise, and direct one deputy police chief. All of these positions
shall be filled by an appointment by the village manager and shall serve until
such time as they resign or are replaced by the village manager, with the
exception of the deputy police chief, which shall be filled by an appointment
by the chief of police and shall serve until such time as he or she resigns or
is replaced by the chief of police.
      1.   The director of administrative services shall have under his direct
supervision the following:
         Assistant director for administration and personnel
         Assistant director for data processing
         Comptroller
      2.   The director of quality control shall have under his direct
supervision the following:
         Assistant director for code compliance
         Assistant director for quality control
      3.   The director of public works shall have under his direct supervision
the following:
         Assistant director for equipment maintenance
         Assistant director for streets and sewers
         Water Division Manager
         a.   The Water Division Manager shall have under his direct
supervision an Assistant Water Division Manager who shall be appointed by the
Village Manager.
   D.   When Office To Become Operational: All positions named in this section
shall become operational upon the appointment by the village manager of persons
to fill the named positions, subject to the guidelines of this section.
   E.   Effect Of Plan On Present Employees: It shall be the policy of the
village to retain persons presently in the employ of the village to fill
similar positions under the “administrative reorganization ordinance”. No
present employee shall be separated as a direct result of implementation of
this plan.
   F.   Reclassification, Wage Rate: When reclassification of a position shall
result in a reduction in grade, the employee so affected shall continue to be
paid at the same rate as the higher grade upon assumption of the new position,
but will receive no increases in salary until the pay set for the employee’s
new position classification reaches the level of this current salary.
Thereafter, said employee shall receive all pay increases due him pursuant to
the ordinances, rules and regulations of the village.
   G.   Implementation Of Plan: The positions created under this section shall
be implemented by enactment of an ordinance that will amend the position, pay
and benefits ordinance of the village by setting forth the new position classes
and grades and concurrently abolishing classes and grades being replaced.
   H.   Police And Fire Department Personnel: Until further implementation of
this section, the village manager shall have the authority to appoint, suspend
or discharge the chief of police, the fire chief, and the deputy fire chief
without the consent of the board of trustees. The chief of police, the fire
chief, and the deputy fire chief need not be appointed from the members of the
police or fire departments. The power of appointment or disciplinary action of
all other officers of the police and fire departments, except the police
department's code enforcement officer, shall rest in the board of fire and
police commissioners of the village 1 , heretofore created and now acting
pursuant to the provisions of the Illinois municipal code. The chief of police
shall have the power to appoint, suspend or discharge the code enforcement
officer for the police department. In the event the village manager discharges
the chief of police, fire chief, or the deputy fire chief prior to being
eligible to retire on pension, they shall be considered as on furlough from the
rank they held with the Village immediately prior to their appointment as chief
of police, fire chief, or deputy fire chief, if any, not including positions
previously appointed by the Village Manager. If the chief of police, fire
chief, or deputy fire chief resigns from or is discharged from their appointed
position prior to attaining eligibility to retire on pension, they shall revert
to and be established in such prior rank, if any, not including positions
previously appointed by the Village Manager, and thereafter be entitled to all
the benefits and emoluments of such prior rank, without regard as to whether a
vacancy then exists in such rank, as established under the fire and police
commission act. 2  
(Ords. 76-7-10, 81-12-19; 1985 Code; Ords. 89-13-30, 91-23-98, 92-02-10, 93-5-
13, 10-12-23, 19-15-51, 25-11-25)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 6 of this code.
2 2. 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-1 et seq.
1-9-2: ELECTION OF OFFICERS:
   A.   Procedure For Election: Elections for municipal offices shall be held
in accordance with and at the time prescribed by statute and this code.
   B.   Village President, Village Clerk And Village Trustees:
      1.   The election for the officers of the village, to include the village
president, village clerk and three (3) village trustees shall be for a four (4)
year term and shall be held on the third Tuesday in April of every other odd
numbered year commencing April 15, 1969.
      2.   The election of three (3) village trustees for a four (4) year term
shall be held on the third Tuesday of April of the odd numbered year commencing
April 20, 1971.
      3.   Effective for any person elected to the office of village president,
village clerk, or village trustee at the April 9, 2015, consolidated election
and all those elected to such offices thereafter:
         a.   No person shall serve as village president for more than three
(3) consecutive four (4) year terms.
         b.   No person shall serve as village clerk for more than three (3)
consecutive four (4) year terms.
         c.   No person shall serve as village trustee for more than three (3)
consecutive four (4) year terms.
   C.   Library Trustees: The election of two (2) library trustees of the Oak
Lawn public library district for a six (6) year term shall be held on the third
Tuesday of April of every odd numbered year commencing April 15, 1969.
   D.   Vacancies In Office: In the event that any of the aforementioned
offices shall become vacant due to death, resignation, disqualification, or
other cause prior to ten (10) days before the last day for filing nominating
petitions for the next general election, then said office shall be filled for
the unexpired term at the next general election of the village.
   E.   Inauguration Date: Pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-10-
15, the inauguration date for the elected officers of the village (village
president, 6 trustees and village clerk) is hereby established as the first
regular village board meeting in May following the election. (1951 Code 2-8-7;
Ords. 68(8), 04-19-94, 15-05-19)
1-9-3: OATH REQUIRED:
All officers of the village, whether elected or appointed, shall before
entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe the
following oath or affirmation:
I do solemnly swear (or affirm, as the case may be), that I will support the
Constitution of the United States, and the Constitution of the State of
Illinois, and that I will faithfully discharge the duties of the office of
                      of the Village of Oak Lawn, according to the best of my
ability.
This oath, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the clerk, except
that the oaths of firemen and policemen shall be filed with the board of police
and fire commissioners. (1951 Code 2-1-3)
1-9-4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   General: The officers of the village shall give bonds in the sums and
within the times prescribed by the board of trustees. Said bonds shall be as
provided by law. Should good cause exist in the judgment and discretion of the
board of trustees, any officer may be required, from time to time, to give
additional bonds in such sums and within such time as the board may by
resolution direct.
   B.   Conditions Of Bonds, Sureties 1 : The bond of each officer shall be
executed to the village with two (2) or more sureties conditioned for the
faithful performance of the duties of his office, and the payment to the proper
officer of all monies coming into his hands by virtue of his office. Each of
said sureties shall be freeholders of Cook County, and shall schedule real
estate therein, clear of all encumbrances and other legal obligations, in value
not less than the penal sum of said bond, which schedule shall be made
separately by said sureties and sworn to before some officer authorized to
administer oaths, and attached to said bond. Provided, that any officer of the
village may procure as surety upon any bond he may be required to give, any
responsible surety company or corporation; and provided, further, that no
member of the board of trustees shall sign any bond in any case wherein the
village is interested.
   C.   Approval, Filing Of Bonds: The bonds of all village officers shall be
subject to the approval of the president and board of trustees. After the
approval as aforesaid, the clerk shall endorse thereon the date thereof and
file the same in his office except the bond of the clerk, which shall be filed
with the treasurer.
   D.   Required Bond Amounts: Bonds shall be required for all village
officers, and certain specified employees, in the following amounts:
      1.   Village president: No bond required as per 65 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/5-3-8.
      2.   Trustees: No bond required as per 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-
3-8.
      3.   Village clerk: See section
1-8-1 of this title.
      4.   Village manager: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
      5.   Village treasurer: See section
1-9C-2 of this chapter.
      6.   Village collector: See section
1-9E-2 of this chapter.
      7.   Village department heads: Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) each.
      8.   Cashiers in the finance department: Five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) each.
      9.   All other village officers: One dollar ($1.00) each. (1951 Code
2-1-4,
2-1-5,
2-1-6; Ord. 94-12-53)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  1-11-8 of this title.
1-9-5: FAILURE TO GIVE BOND:
If any person elected or appointed to any office of the village shall fail to
qualify by taking, subscribing and filing his official bond as herein provided,
within ten (10) days after he is officially notified of his election or
appointment, the office shall become vacant. (1951 Code
2-1-7)
1-9-6: PAYMENT OF SALARIES:
Unless otherwise specified in this code, the salary and pay of all officers and
employees shall be paid semimonthly to each person entitled thereto. (1951 Code
2-1-8)
1-9-7: DUTIES:
   A.   General: Each officer, besides the specific duties which may be
required of him by virtue of his office, shall also perform such other and
further duties, and be subject to such rules and regulations, as the manager or
president and board of trustees may, from time to time, require.
   B.   Deliver Effects To Successor: Any person being an officer or employee
of the village, whose term has expired or who has resigned or has been removed
from office, shall, within ten (10) days after notification and request,
deliver to his successor in office all property, books and effects of every
description in his possession belonging to the village or pertaining to his
office. (1951 Code
2-1-9, 2-1-10)
1-9-8: RECORDS OPEN FOR INSPECTION, REPORTS:
All books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries, accounts and memoranda of each
and every officer and employee of the village may be examined at any time by
the manager or the president, and the president and board of trustees may, by
resolution, call upon any officer to make a report in writing of any subject
matter which said board may designate in such resolution and within such time
as said resolution may prescribe. (1951 Code 2-1-11)
1-9-9: OFFICE HOURS:
The offices of village officers shall be open for business at such hours as
shall be prescribed by resolution by the village board. (1951 Code 2-1-12)
1-9-10: BENEFITS:
   A.   Village Benefit Plans: Village employees and certain village officers
will be eligible to participate in employee benefit plans, as described in this
code and in the Oak Lawn Benefit Handbook, as amended from time to time.
   B.   Benefits Not Guaranteed And Subject To Change: The benefits provided in
this section are not guaranteed and are subject to change at any time in the
sole discretion of the Village in accordance with all applicable law.
   C.   Paid Leave; Minimum Wage:
      1.   Employees of the Village of Oak Lawn: Pursuant to Village of Oak
Lawn Ordinance No. 23-21-78 and Ordinance No. 24-01-04, such Ordinances govern
and supersede all provisions of the Illinois Paid Leave for All Workers Act and
Cook County Ordinance No. 24-0583 relative to the employment relationship
between the Village of Oak Lawn and its employees. No additional obligations
with regard to mandatory paid leave, including without limitation, any
obligations adopted under the Paid Leave for All Workers Act by the State of
Illinois and/or obligations adopted under the Cook County Ordinance No. 24-0583
by the County of Cook, shall apply to the Village in its capacity as an
employer, except those required by Federal or State of Illinois laws and
regulations preempting the Village’s home rule authority.
      2.   Other Employers within the Village of Oak Lawn: For the purposes of
this subsection, the term “employee” means an individual permitted and/or hired
to work by an employer regardless of the number of persons the employer
employs, or the number of hours worked, and the term “employer” means any
person, firm or corporation employing one (1) or more employees, or seeking to
employ one (1) or more employees, if the employer has its principal place of
business within the Village of Oak Lawn, or does business within the Village of
Oak Lawn.
   For the purposes of this subsection, the term “employer” does not mean:
         a.   The government of the United States or a corporation wholly owned
by the government of the United States;
         b.   An Indian tribe or a corporation wholly owned by an Indian tribe;
         c.   The government of the State or any agency or department thereof;
or
         d.   The government of any municipality.
   Employers located within the Village of Oak Lawn shall comply with all
Federal and State employment laws and guidelines with regard to paid leave,
including paid sick leave, and the payment of minimum wage. Employee
eligibility for paid leave, including paid sick leave, and payment of minimum
wage shall be pursuant to all Federal and State employment laws and guidelines.
   No additional obligations with regard to paid leave, including paid sick
leave, or payment of minimum wage, including, without limitation, any
additional obligations adopted by the County of Cook Board of Commissioners,
shall apply to employers located within the Village of Oak Lawn, including
units of local government, generally, and public school districts and park
districts, specifically, and the Village opts out of any such regulations or
requirements, except those required by Federal and State law or the Village of
Oak Lawn.
   Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to affect the validity or change
the terms of any collective bargaining agreement in effect on January 1, 2024.
   Nothing in this subsection shall be deemed to prohibit or discourage any
employer from providing leave or benefits greater or more generous than what is
required under this subsection or state or Federal law. Employers shall remain
ultimately responsible for determining whether or not to provide paid leave,
and how much paid leave to provide to their employees, as long as the minimum
amount of paid leave required by this subsection is provided. The Village shall
not be responsible for any claims based on or relating to alleged non-
compliance with the Paid Leave for All Workers Act, any Cook County Ordinance,
or any regulations thereunder. (Ords. 11-22-54, 17-10-21, 24-02-07, 24-18-67)
ARTICLE A. VILLAGE MANAGER
SECTION:
1-9A-1: Village Manager; Appointment
1-9A-2: Term Of Office; Removal
1-9A-3: Qualifications (Rep. by Ord. 05-22-84)
1-9A-4: Powers And Duties
1-9A-5: Salary
1-9A-6: Acting Manager
1-9A-7: Emergency Interim Village Manager
1-9A-1: VILLAGE MANAGER; APPOINTMENT:
There shall be and is hereby established the office of village manager who
shall be appointed by the village president and board of trustees. The village
manager shall be appointed without regard to his political beliefs and need not
be a resident of the village, but shall reside at a residence within a ten (10)
mile radius of the village, as measured from the village hall, within one year
of his/her appointment. (Ord. 94-5-21)
1-9A-2: TERM OF OFFICE; REMOVAL:
The village manager shall be appointed for an indefinite term and may be
removed at any time by a majority vote of the president and board of trustees.
(Ords. 48, 420)
1-9A-3: QUALIFICATIONS:
(Rep. by Ord. 05-22-84)
1-9A-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   The village manager shall be the administrative head of the government
of the village, and shall be responsible for the efficient administration of
all departments of the village.
   B.   The powers and duties of the village manager shall be:
      1.   To enforce the laws and ordinances within the village.
      2.   To appoint the following officers:
         a.   The chief of the police department;
         b.   The chief of the fire department;
         c.   The village attorney;
      and to appoint and remove or suspend all department heads. The village
manager is authorized to appoint, suspend or discharge the chief of the police
department and the chief of the fire department without consent of the board of
trustees.
      3.   To exercise control of all departments and divisions created by 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/5-3-5(3), by any ordinances of the village, and by
this article and amendments thereto.
      4.   To attend all meetings of the board of trustees with the right to
take part in the discussion but with no right to vote.
      5.   To recommend to the board of trustees for adoption, such measures as
he may deem necessary or expedient.
      6.   To see that all terms and conditions imposed in favor of the village
or its inhabitants in any contract or public utility franchise are faithfully
kept and performed.
      7.   To make, in the ordinary course of business, all purchases of
materials, supplies, and services necessary for the village as provided for in
the annual appropriation ordinance; provided, that on purchases of more than
twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00), he shall first procure the approval of
the village board before making such purchases and in all cases he shall comply
with the statutory provisions as to solicitation of bids.
      8.   To have and exercise the power, authority and duties of any director
of a department or division thereof during the time when the office of any such
director shall be vacant or no person shall have been appointed thereto.
      9.   To act as agent for the local liquor control commissioner or the
Liquor and Tobacco Licensing and Review Board in all matters pertaining to the
administration of the licensing and control of the sale of alcoholic liquors
within the village, and the administration of the statutes of the state, and
the ordinances of the village pertaining thereto1.
      10.   To issue all licenses and permits not otherwise provided for by
this code or the statutes of the state.
      11.   To appoint, remove or suspend all electrical and plumbing
inspectors of the village.
(Ords. 14-34-75, 19-16-63, 25-12-38)
1-9A-5: SALARY:
The manager shall receive the salary prescribed by the president and board of
trustees, payable semimonthly. (Ord. 545)
1-9A-6: ACTING MANAGER:
In case of the absence or disability of the manager, the president and board of
trustees may designate a qualified administrative officer of the village to
perform the duties of the manager during such absence or disability. (Ords. 48,
420)
1-9A-7: EMERGENCY INTERIM VILLAGE MANAGER:
The village manager shall designate in writing and file with the village clerk
and village president at least three (3) and no more than seven (7) emergency
interim successor village managers pursuant to the emergency interim executive
succession act 1  to act in the event of the unavailability of the village
manager during an emergency. As provided by the act, the following terms shall
have the meanings hereinafter ascribed to them:
ATTACK: An attack or series of attacks by an enemy of the United States
causing, or which may cause, substantial damage or injury to civilian property
or persons in the United States in any manner by sabotage or by the use of
bombs, missiles, shellfire, or atomic, radiological, chemical, bacteriological
or biological means or other weapons or processes.
DISASTER: A situation determined by the governor to be an occurrence or threat
of catastrophic and widespread injury or loss of life or property resulting
from any natural or manmade cause, including, but not limited to, fire, flood,
earthquake, epidemic and explosion.
EMERGENCY: An attack or a disaster.
EMERGENCY INTERIM SUCCESSOR: A person designated pursuant to this article in
the event the village manager is unavailable to exercise the powers and
discharge the duties of village manager until a successor is appointed or
elected and qualified as may be provided by the constitution, statutes,
charters and ordinances or until the lawful incumbent is able to resume the
exercise of the powers and discharge the duties of the office.
UNAVAILABLE: Means either that a vacancy in the office of village manager
exists and there is no deputy authorized to exercise all of the powers and
discharge the duties of the office or that the lawful incumbent of the office
(including any deputy exercising the powers and discharging the duties of an
office because of a vacancy) and his duly authorized deputy are absent or
unable to exercise the powers and discharge the duties of the office. (Ord. 09-
13-28)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 275/1 et seq.
ARTICLE B. VILLAGE ATTORNEY
SECTION:
1-9B-1: Office Established
1-9B-2: Bond (Rep. by Ord. 94-12-53)
1-9B-3: Powers and Duties
1-9B-4: Compensation
1-9B-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED:
There shall be and is hereby established the office of Village Attorney. (Ord.
71-19-45)
1-9B-2: BOND:
(Rep. by Ord. 94-12-53)
1-9B-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   General: The Village Attorney shall conduct all the law business of the
Village and draw such ordinances, deeds, leases and other papers as may be
required of him by the President and Board of Trustees, or any committee
thereof or the Village Manager.
   B.   Legal Opinions: The Village Attorney shall give his opinion, in
writing, to the Board of Trustees or any committee thereof or the President or
the Village Manager, when requested, on legal questions arising under or
concerning any ordinance of the Village, and on questions and subjects in which
the Village shall be legally interested.
   C.   Surrender Effects of Office: Upon the expiration of his term of office,
the Village Attorney shall forthwith turn over to his successor in office all
dockets, deeds, leases or other papers in his hands belonging to the Village or
delivered to him by the Village or any of its officers and all papers in
actions prosecuted or defended by him then pending and undetermined. (1951 Code
2-2-2, 2-2-3, 2-2-4)
1-9B-4: COMPENSATION:
The Village Attorney shall be paid a monthly retainer for his general counsel
and advice in such an amount as may be agreed upon or directed by the President
and Board of Trustees. For litigation and special assessment or special
taxation he shall charge such reasonable fee as shall be agreed upon by the
President and Board of Trustees. For other services not covered in this
Section, he shall charge on a quantum meruit basis, in the absence of any
specific agreement with the Village Board. (1951 Code 2-2-5)
ARTICLE C. VILLAGE TREASURER
SECTION:
1-9C-1: Appointment
1-9C-2: Bond and Salary
1-9C-3: Duties
1-9C-4: Deputy Treasurer
1-9C-1: APPOINTMENT:
The Village Treasurer shall be appointed by the President, with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 93-10-34)
1-9C-2: BOND AND SALARY:
   A.   Bond: The Village Treasurer, before entering upon the duties of his
office, shall execute to the Village a bond conditioned for the faithful
discharge of his duties with sureties to be approved by the President and Board
of Trustees in a sum not less than three (3) times the latest Federal census
population or any subsequent census figures used for motor fuel tax purposes by
the Village.
   B.   Salary: The compensation of the Village Treasurer shall be $4,800
annually, payable through the village’s regular payroll in twenty-six (26)
equal installments. The Treasurer is not eligible to participate in the
Illinois Municipal Retirement Fund (IMRF) or in any village benefit plan. (1951
Code 2-3-1, 2-3-5; Ords. 72-1-1, 24-18-67)
1-9C-3: DUTIES:
   A.   General: The Treasurer, through the office of the Department of
Administrative Services, shall receive all monies belonging to the Village and
shall render at the end of each and every month, and oftener if required, a
statement under oath to the Board of Trustees, showing the state of Treasury at
the date of such account and the balance of the money in the Treasury. Said
statement shall set forth all the monies received by him, from whom, and on
what account they shall have been received; also all monies paid out by him,
and on what account they shall have been paid, and shall perform such other
duties as are set forth in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-35-40 to 5/3.1-
35-85.
   B.   Books Required, Open for Inspection: The Treasurer shall cause to be
kept books of account, in such manner as to accurately show all monies received
by him, from whom, and on what account they shall have been paid. Said books
shall be kept in such manner as to be readily understood and investigated;
which books and all papers and files of said office shall at all times be open
to the examination of the Manager and the President and Board of Trustees or
any member thereof.
   C.   Accounting: The Village Treasurer shall keep by double entry, a full
detailed account of all Village funds, general tax receipts and receipts from
other sources, also a bond account, sinking fund account and forfeit account in
the Village ledger. He shall keep a "special fund" ledger in which all special
funds shall be kept separately by numbers and names of the special funds,
showing the total amount of each fund and installment of same to be collected
and each account to show the total collections and disbursements on account of
same. He shall also keep an auxiliary account with the Village Clerk-Collector
and the County Collector, showing all moneys received and disbursed by the
Village Treasurer.
   D.   Annual Account: The Village Treasurer is specifically charged with the
duty to prepare, publish and file the annual account, in accordance with the
provisions of sections 3-10-5.1 to 3-10-5.4 of chapter 24 of the Illinois
Revised Statutes and with the preparation and filing of the annual audit as
provided for in article 8, division 8 of said chapter 24. (1951 Code 2-3-2, 2-
3-3, 2-3-4, 2-3-5; 1985 Code)
1-9C-4: DEPUTY TREASURER:
The Treasurer is hereby authorized to designate the Director of Administrative
Services to serve as Deputy Treasurer. Said Deputy Treasurer shall have all the
powers and authority granted by State statute or this Village Code to the
Treasurer. Said designation shall be made by way of letter, addressed to the
President and Board of Trustees, with copies to the Village Manager and the
Director of Administrative Services. (Ord. 91-10-45)
ARTICLE D. BUDGET OFFICER
SECTION:
1-9D-1: Office Established, Appointment, Compensation
1-9D-2: Powers and Duties
1-9D-1: OFFICE ESTABLISHED, APPOINTMENT, COMPENSATION:
There is hereby established the office of Budget Officer in the Village who
shall be appointed by the Village Manager and shall serve for an indefinite
term. The Budget Officer shall be compensated for his services as shall be
established by ordinance of the Village. (Ord. 68-(8)-8-29)
1-9D-2: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Budget Officer shall have the following powers and duties:
   A.   Permit and encourage the use of efficient planning, budgeting,
auditing, reporting, accounting and other fiscal management procedures.
   B.   Compile an annual budget in accordance with section 8-2-9.3 of chapter
24 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, and any amendments thereto 1 .
   C.   Examine all books and records of all Municipal departments, commissions
and boards which relate to monies received by the Municipality, Municipal
departments, commissions and boards, and paid out by the Municipality,
Municipal departments, commissions and boards, debts and accounts receivable
and amounts owed by or to the Municipality, Municipal departments, commissions
and boards.
   D.   Obtain such additional information from the Municipality, Municipal
departments, commissions and boards as may be useful to the Budget Officer for
purposes of compiling a Municipal budget, such information to be furnished by
the Municipality, Municipal departments, commissions and boards in the form
required by the Budget Officer. Any department, commission or board which
refuses to make such information as is requested of it available to the Budget
Officer shall not be permitted to make expenditures under any subsequent budget
for the Municipality until such Municipal department, commission or board shall
comply in full with the request of the Budget Officer.
   E.   Establish and maintain such procedures as shall insure that no
expenditures are made by the Municipality, Municipal departments, commissions
or boards except as authorized by the budget. (Ord. 68-(8)-8-29)

  1-11-1 of this Municipal Code.
ARTICLE E. VILLAGE COLLECTOR

Village Clerk shall hold the office of the Village Collector. (1985 Code)
1-9E-2: BOND REQUIREMENTS:

Collector shall execute a bond with security payable to the Village in the
penal sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), conditioned upon the faithful

the Village. Notwithstanding the foregoing, where the Village Clerk serves as
Village Collector, and the Clerk has been bonded pursuant to Section
1-8-1 of this Code, no additional bond shall be required under this Section
provided the Clerk's bond also references the Clerk's duties as Collector.
(1985 Code; Ord. 94-12-53)

Illinois Municipal Code 1 . (1985 Code)

officer of the village. The Assistant Village Administrator may head one or
more departments as directed by the Village Manager and shall be responsible to
the Village Manager and the Board of Trustees for the proper administration of
all affairs of the village assigned to be performed by the Assistant Village
Manager. (Ord. 20-15-44)

CHAPTER 11
MUNICIPAL FINANCES
SECTION:
1-11-1: Annual Budget
1-11-2: Village Depositories
1-11-3: Investments
1-11-4: Authority To Borrow Money
1-11-5: Contracts And Purchases
1-11-5-1: Responsible Bidder Requirements
