1-15-1: POLICY STATEMENT:
It is the policy of the village that, in all cases, its elected and appointed
officials, employees and board, commission and committee members perform their
duties for the benefit of the citizens of the village. They shall conduct the
government of the village with integrity and impartiality, without allowing
prejudice, favoritism, or the opportunity for personal gain to influence their
decisions or actions or to interfere with serving the public interest.
Therefore, all such persons should avoid accepting or retaining any economic
benefits or opportunities that could impair or represent an actual threat to
the exercise of independent judgment. It is further policy of the Village that
all appearances of impropriety shall be avoided. The Village Board of Trustees
has determined that the provisions and purpose of this section set forth
ethical principals and regulations applicable to public officials and employees
in the Village of Oak Lawn. Furthermore, it has been determined that this
section will contribute to the public confidence in the integrity, ability, and
performance of public officials in the Village. (Ords. 00-19-60, 20-09-24)
1-15-2: APPLICABILITY:
The provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise indicated, shall apply to
all elected village officials, all appointed village officials, all village
employees and all members of boards, commissions and committees who serve with
compensation. Said individuals shall be collectively referred to throughout
this chapter as the "covered individuals". (Ord. 00-19-60)
1-15-3: RESPONSIBILITIES OF PUBLIC OFFICE/EMPLOYMENT:
The covered individuals are agents of public purpose and hold office for the
benefit of the public. They are bound to uphold the constitution of the United
States Of America and the constitution of the state of Illinois and to carry
out impartially the laws of the United States Of America, the state of Illinois
and the village.
All covered individuals shall abide by and act in conformance with all state
statutes which address the conduct of the officers and employees of
municipalities including, but not limited to, the following statutory
provisions, to the extent applicable to the respective covered individuals:
   A.   The general prohibited interests in contracts provisions of the
Illinois municipal code - 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-10;
   B.   The misconduct provisions of the Illinois municipal code - 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3.1-55-15;
   C.   The official misconduct provisions of the Illinois criminal code - 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/33-3;
   D.   The public contracts provisions of the Illinois criminal code - 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/33E-1 through 50/33E-13;
   E.   The public officer prohibited activities act - 50 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 105/0.01 et seq.; and
   F.   Disclosure of economic interests - 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 420/3-
301 et seq. (Ord. 00-19-60)
1-15-4: CHAPTER UPDATES:
The village's legislative, license, and ethics committee is charged with the
duty to review the ethics code ordinances adopted by other municipalities and
ethics code suggestions brought forward by the citizens of the village. Based
upon said review, the legislative, license, and ethics committee shall make
recommendations to the president and board of trustees relative to adding
additional sections to this chapter. (Ords. 00-19-60, 13-09-29)
1-15-5: STATE OFFICIALS AND EMPLOYEES ETHICS ACT:
   A.   The regulations of section 5-15 1  and article 10 2  of the state
officials and employees ethics act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/1-1 et
seq. (hereinafter referred to as the "act" in this section), are hereby adopted
by reference and made applicable to the officers and employees of the village
to the extent required by 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5.
   B.   The solicitation or acceptance of gifts prohibited to be solicited or
accepted under the act, by any officer or any employee of the village, is
hereby prohibited.
   C.   The offering or making of gifts prohibited to be offered or made to an
officer or employee of the village under the act, is hereby prohibited.
   D.   The participation in political activities prohibited under the act, by
any officer or employee of the village, is hereby prohibited.
   E.   For purposes of this section, the terms "officer" and "employee" shall
be defined as set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/70-5(c).
   F.   To the extent allowed by law, the penalties for violations of this
section shall be the same as those penalties set forth in 5 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 430/50-5 for similar violations of the act.
   G.   This section does not repeal or otherwise amend or modify any existing
ordinances or policies which regulate the conduct of village officers and
employees. To the extent that any such existing ordinances or policies are less
restrictive than this section, however, the provisions of this section shall
prevail in accordance with the provisions of 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 430/
70-5(a).
   H.   Any amendment to the act that becomes effective after the effective
date of this section shall be incorporated into this section by reference and
shall be applicable to the solicitation, acceptance, offering and making of
gifts and to prohibited political activities. However, any amendment that makes
its provisions optional for adoption by municipalities shall not be
incorporated into this section by reference without formal action by the
corporate authorities of the village.
   I.   If the Illinois supreme court declares the act unconstitutional in its
entirety, then this section shall be repealed as of the date that the Illinois
supreme court's decision becomes final and not subject to any further appeals
or rehearings. This section shall be deemed repealed without further action by
the corporate authorities of the village if the act is found unconstitutional
by the Illinois supreme court.
   J.   If the Illinois supreme court declares part of the act unconstitutional
but upholds the constitutionality of the remainder of the act; or does not
address the remainder of the act, then the remainder of the act as adopted by
this section shall remain in full force and effect; however, that part of this
section relating to the part of the act found unconstitutional shall be deemed
repealed without further action by the corporate authorities of the village.
(Ord. 04-09-43)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 430/5-15.
2 2. 5 ILCS 430/10-10 - 10-40.
1-15-5-1: ALLEGATIONS OF SEXUAL HARASSMENT AGAINST AN ELECTED OFFICIAL BY AN
ELECTED OFFICIAL:
   A.   Pursuant to Section 70-5 of the Act, elected Village officials are
encouraged to promptly report claims of sexual harassment by another elected
official. Every effort should be made to file such complaints as soon as
possible., while facts are known, and potential witnesses are available. If the
elected official feels comfortable doing so, he or she should directly inform
the harassing individual that the individual's conduct or communication is
offensive and must stop.
   B.   This Section
1-15-5-1 through
1-15-5-3 of the Village Code of Oak Lawn, as amended from time to time, shall
not supersede or otherwise affect existing anti-harassment policies applicable
to any other Village officer, appointed official, employee, or contractor.
(Ord. 20-09-24)
1-15-5-2: REPORTING CLAIMS OF SEXUAL HARASSMENT FOR ELECTED OFFICIALS:
All complaints of sexual harassment against an elected official by another
elected official shall be registered with the Village Attorney in writing. The
Village attorney shall provide the President and Board of Trustees with notice
that an allegation of sexual harassment has been filed by one elected official
against another. Reports of sexual harassment will be confidential to the
greatest extent possible. (Ord. 20-09-24)
1-15-5-3: INDEPENDENT REVIEW OF SEXUAL HARASSMENT ALLEGATIONS MADE AGAINST AN
ELECTED OFFICIAL BY AN ELECTED OFFICIAL:
   A.   When a complaint of sexual harassment has been registered with the
Village Attorney, the Village Attorney shall inform the Village President and
Board of Trustees of said complaint. Upon receiving notice of said complaint,
the Village President and the Board of Trustees shall appoint a qualified law
firm or independent counsel with experience in workplace investigations to
conduct an independent review of the allegations. The independent legal counsel
shall investigate the complaint and during such investigation shall keep his or
her investigation confidential to the greatest extent possible. The
investigator shall prepare a written report determining whether the complaint
was founded or unfounded and the investigator shall submit it to the Village
President and Board of Trustees.
   B.   In the instance where the independent legal counsel renders a report
finding a violation of the Village's sexual harassment policy the report shall
also contain recommended remedies and methods to ensure future compliance with
the policy. If the investigator finds that the elected official that is the
subject of the investigation has engaged in sexual harassment, the matter will
be addressed in accordance with the authority of the Board. (20-09-24)
1-15-6: HIRING AND CONTRACT DECISIONS:
All hiring and contract decisions made by the president and village board, and
the village manager, shall be made with transparency. Specifically, the
following requirements shall be adhered to in such decisions:
   A.   All elected and appointed officials, board or commission members, and
all Village employees shall adhere to the provisions of Section 3.1-15-15 of
the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-1, et seq., as amended.
   B.   All elected and appointed officials, board or commission members, and
all Village employees shall adhere to the provisions of Section 2 of the Public
Officer Prohibited Activities Act, 50 ILCS 105/0.01, et seq.
   C.   All elected and appointed officials, board or commission members, and
all Village employees, and all contracts or agreements entered into by the
Village, shall adhere to the provisions of Section 3, 3.1, and 3.2 of the
Public Officer Prohibited Activities Act, 50 ILCS 105/0.01, et seq., as
amended, and to Section 3.1-55-10 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/1-
1-1, et seq., as amended. (Ords. 13-08-26, 20-09-24)
1-15-7: CONFLICTS OF INTEREST AND IMPROPER INFLUENCE:
1-15-7-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall apply for purposes of this section
1-15-7:
ADMINISTRATIVE ACTION: Any decision on, or any proposal, consideration,
enactment or making of any rule, regulation, or any other official
nonministerial action or nonaction by any village department, village
commission, or by any official or employee of any village department, or any
matter which is within the official jurisdiction of the village manager's
office.
AGENCY: The corporate authorities of the village of Oak Lawn, any committee or
other subdivision thereof, any village department or other administrative unit,
commission, board, or other division of the government of the village.
COMPENSATION: Money, thing of value or other pecuniary benefit received or to
be received in return for, or as reimbursement for, services rendered or to be
rendered.
CONTRACT MANAGEMENT AUTHORITY: Personal involvement in or direct supervisory
responsibility for the formulation or execution of a village contract,
including, without limitation, the preparation of specifications, evaluation of
bids or proposals, negotiation of contract terms or supervision of performance.
COVERED RELATIVE: The spouse or domestic partner of any official, candidate for
village office, or employee, or the immediate family, and relatives residing in
the same residence with the official, candidate for village office, or
employee.
DOING BUSINESS: Any one or any combination of sales, purchases, leases or
contracts to, from or with the village or any village department in an amount
in excess of ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) in any twelve (12) consecutive
months.
EMPLOYEE: An individual employed by the village, whether part time or full
time, but excludes elected officials, the village manager, department heads,
and village contractors.
EXPENDITURE: A payment, distribution, loan, advance, deposit, or gift of money
or anything of value.
FINANCIAL INTEREST: An interest held by an official or employee that is valued
or capable of valuation in monetary terms with a current value of more than one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00), provided that such interest shall not include: a)
the authorized compensation paid to an official or employee for any office or
employment; b) a time or demand deposit in a financial institution; or c) an
endowment or insurance policy or annuity contract purchased from an insurance
company; or d) any ownership through purchase at fair market value or
inheritance of the shares of a mutual fund corporation, regardless of the value
of or dividends on such shares, if such shares are registered on a securities
exchange pursuant to the securities exchange act of 1934, as amended; or e) any
ownership through purchase at fair market value or inheritance of not more than
fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000.00) worth of the shares of a corporation, or
any corporate subsidiary, parent or affiliate thereof, regardless of the
dividends on such shares, if such shares are registered on a securities
exchange pursuant to the securities exchange act of 1934, as amended. Such
interest also shall not include any ownership by a current official or employee
through purchase at fair market value or inheritance of less than one percent
(1%) of the shares of a corporation, or any corporate subsidiary, parent or
affiliate thereof, regardless of the value or dividends on such shares, if such
shares are registered on a securities exchange pursuant to the securities
exchange act of 1934, as amended, and if such ownership existed before November
1, 2012.
GIFT: Anything of value given without fair market consideration.
LEGISLATION: Any ordinance, resolution, amendment, nomination, report or any
other matter pending or proposed before the board of trustees or a committee
thereof or any appointed village board, including any other matter which may be
the subject of board action.
LEGISLATIVE ACTION: The introduction, sponsorship, consideration, debate,
amendment, passage, defeat, approval, veto or other official action or
nonaction on any ordinance, resolution, motion, order, appointment, application
or other matter pending or proposed before the village board or any committee
or subcommittee thereof.
PERSON: Any individual, entity, corporation, partnership, firm, association,
union, trust, estate, as well as any parent or subsidiary of any of the
foregoing, whether or not operated for profit.
PROFESSIONAL SERVICES: Services in any occupation requiring advanced or
specialized education and training, including, without limitation, law,
accounting, insurance, real estate, engineering, medicine, architecture,
dentistry, banking, finance, public relations, education or consulting.
RELATIVE: A person who is related to an official, candidate for village office,
or employee as spouse or as any of the following, whether by blood or by
adoption: parent, child, brother or sister, aunt or uncle, niece or nephew,
grandparent, grandchild, father-in-law, mother-in-law, son-in-law, daughter-in-
law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law, stepfather or stepmother, stepson or
stepdaughter, stepbrother or stepsister, half-brother or half- sister.
SEEKING TO DO BUSINESS:
   A.   Taking any action within the past six (6) months to obtain a contract
or business from the village when, if such action were successful, it would
result in the person's doing business with the village; and
   B.   The contract or business sought has not been awarded to any person.
VILLAGE: The village of Oak Lawn.
VILLAGE CONTRACTOR: Any person (including his or her agents or employees acting
within the scope of their employment) who is paid from the general fund of the
village or any other special fund of the village or pursuant to village
ordinance, for services to the village, regardless of the nature of the
relationship of such individual to the village. For purposes other than this
chapter a "village contractor" shall not include officials and employees.
VILLAGE OFFICIAL: Any elected official in the village of Oak Lawn, the village
manager, any person appointed to a village commission, committee, or board, and
all department heads.
VILLAGE PROPERTY: Any building or portion thereof owned or exclusively leased
by the village. "Village property" does not, however, include any portion of a
building that is rented or leased from the village by a private person or
entity. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-7-2: FIDUCIARY DUTY:
Village officials and employees shall at all times in the performance of their
public duties owe a fiduciary duty to the village. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-7-3: IMPROPER INFLUENCE:
   A.   No village official, department head, or employee shall make,
participate in making or in any way attempt to use his or her position to
influence any village governmental decision or action in which he or she knows
or has reason to know that he or she has any financial interest distinguishable
from its effect on the public generally, or from which he or she has derived
any income or compensation during the preceding twelve (12) months or from
which he or she reasonably expects to derive any income or compensation in the
following twelve (12) months.
   B.   No village official or department head, or any person acting at the
direction of such village official or department head, shall contact either
orally or in writing any other village official, department head, or employee
with respect to any matter involving any person with whom the elected official
or department head has any business relationship that creates a financial
interest on the part of the official or department head, or the domestic
partner or spouse of the official or department head, or from whom or which he
or she has derived any income or compensation during the preceding twelve (12)
months or from whom or which he or she reasonably expects to derive any income
or compensation in the following twelve (12) months. In addition, no elected
official or department head may participate in any discussion in any village
committee hearing or meeting or in any village board meeting or vote on any
matter involving the person with whom the elected official or department head
has any business relationship that creates a financial interest on the part of
the official or department head, or the domestic partner or spouse of the
official or department head, or from whom or which he or she has derived any
income or compensation during the preceding twelve (12) months or from whom or
which he reasonably expects to derive any income or compensation in the
following twelve (12) months. (Ords. 13-17-64, 19-28-95)
1-15-7-4: VILLAGE OWNED PROPERTY:
No village official or employee shall engage in or permit the unauthorized use
of village owned property. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-7-5: USE OR DISCLOSURE OF CONFIDENTIAL INFORMATION:
No current or former village officials or employees shall use or disclose,
other than in the performance of his or her official duties and
responsibilities, or as may be required by law, confidential information gained
in the course of or by reason of his or her position or employment. For
purposes of this section, "confidential information" means any information that
may not be obtained pursuant to the Illinois freedom of information act, as
amended. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-7-6: CONFLICTS OF INTEREST; APPEARANCE OF IMPROPRIETY:
   A.   No village official, department head, or employee shall make or
participate in the making of any governmental decision with respect to any
matter in which he or she has any financial interest distinguishable from that
of the general public, or from which he or she has derived any income or
compensation during the preceding twelve (12) months or from which he or she
reasonably expects to derive any income or compensation in the following twelve
(12) months.
   B.   1. Any elected or appointed official who has any financial interest
distinguishable from that of the general public or all trustees in any matter
pending before the village board or any board committee, or from which he or
she has derived any income or compensation during the preceding twelve (12)
months or from which he or she reasonably expects to derive any income or
compensation in the following twelve (12) months shall publicly disclose the
nature and extent of such interest on the records of proceedings of the village
board, and shall also notify the village clerk of such interest within ninety
six (96) hours of delivery by the village clerk to the member, of the
introduction of any ordinance, resolution, order or other matter to be
considered by the village board, or as soon thereafter as the member is or
should be aware of such potential conflict of interest. The village clerk shall
make such disclosures available for public inspection and copying immediately
upon receipt. He or she shall abstain from voting on the matter but shall be
counted present for purposes of a quorum. The obligation to report a potential
conflict of interest under this subsection arises as soon as the member of the
village board is or should be aware of such potential conflict.
      2.   To avoid even an appearance of impropriety, any member of the
village board who has any business relationship that creates a financial
interest on the part of such member, or the domestic partner or spouse of such
member, with a person or entity with a matter pending before the village board
or any village committee or commission, or from whom or which he or she has
derived any income or compensation during the preceding twelve (12) months or
from whom or which he or she reasonably expects to derive any income or
compensation in the following twelve (12) months, shall publicly disclose the
nature of such business relationship or income or compensation on the records
of proceedings of the village board, and shall also notify the village clerk of
such relationship within ninety six (96) hours of delivery by the village clerk
to the member, of the introduction of any ordinance, resolution, order or other
matter before the village board, or as soon thereafter as the member is or
should be aware of such potential conflict of interest. The village clerk shall
make such disclosures available for public inspection and copying immediately
upon receipt. He or she shall abstain from voting on the matter but shall be
counted present for purposes of a quorum. The obligation to report a potential
conflict of interest under this subsection arises as soon as the member of the
village board is or should be aware of such potential conflict. For purposes of
this subsection B2 only: "matter pending before the village board or any
council committee" shall refer to any action involving the award of loan funds,
grant funds or bond proceeds, bond inducement ordinances, leases, land sales,
zoning matters, or the creation of tax increment financing districts. (Ords.
13-17-64, 19-28-95)
1-15-7-7: REPRESENTATION OF OTHER PERSONS:
   A.   No village official, department head, or employee may represent, or
derive any income or compensation from the representation of, any person other
than the village in any formal or informal proceeding or transaction before any
village commission or board in which the commission's or board's action or
nonaction is of a nonministerial nature; provided that nothing in this
subsection shall preclude any employee from performing the duties of his or her
employment, or any village official or department head from appearing without
compensation before any village commission or board on behalf of the residents
of Oak Lawn in the course of his or her duties as a village official or
department head.
   B.   No village official, department head, or employee may derive any income
or compensation from the representation of any person, in any judicial or
quasi-judicial proceeding before any administrative agency or court in which
the village is a party and that person's interest is adverse to that of the
village. (Ords. 13-17-64, 19-28-95)
1-15-7-8: POSTEMPLOYMENT RESTRICTIONS ON ASSISTANCE AND REPRESENTATION:
   A.   No former village official or employee shall assist or represent any
person other than the village in any judicial or administrative proceeding
involving the village if the official or employee participated personally and
substantially in the proceeding during his or her term of office or employment.
   B.   No former village official or employee shall, for a period of one year
after the termination of the official's or employee's term of office or
employment, assist or represent any person in any business transaction
involving the village, if the official or employee participated personally and
substantially in the subject matter of the transaction during his or her term
of office or employment; provided, that if the official or employee exercised
contract management authority with respect to a contract this prohibition shall
be permanent as to that contract.
   C.   Nothing in this section shall be construed to restrict a former village
official's or employee's activities on behalf of, and while employed by,
another government agency. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-7-9: INTEREST IN VILLAGE BUSINESS:
   A.   No village official, department head, or employee shall have a
financial interest in his or her own name or in the name of any other person in
any contract, work or business of the village, or in the sale of any article,
whenever the expense, price or consideration of the contract, work, business or
sale is paid with funds belonging to or administered by the village, or is
authorized by ordinance; provided, however, for purposes of this subsection,
any of the following shall not constitute a financial interest in any contract,
work or business of the village:
      1.   Ownership of less than one percent (1%) of the outstanding common
stock in any entity or its parent, subsidiary or affiliate, regardless of the
value of dividends paid or accrued on such stock, and such stock is registered
on a securities exchange pursuant to the securities exchange act of 1934, as
amended;
      2.   Compensation for property taken pursuant to the village's eminent
domain power; and
      3.   Any interest of a relative which interest is related to or derived
from the relative's independent occupation, business or profession.
   B.   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in this section, no village
official, department head, or employee who has contract management authority
over any contract, work or business of the village shall have a financial
interest in any entity which is a contractor, subcontractor, or otherwise a
party to that contract, work or business.
   C.   Unless sold pursuant to a process of competitive bidding following
public notice, no village official, department head, or employee shall have a
financial interest in the purchase of any property that: 1) belongs to the
village, or 2) is sold for taxes or assessments, or 3) is sold by virtue of
legal process at the suit of the village. (Ords. 13-17-64, 19-28-95)
1-15-7-10: CONTRACT INDUCEMENTS:
   A.   No payment, gratuity or offer of employment shall be made in connection
with any village contract, by or on behalf of a subcontractor to the prime
contractor or higher tier subcontractor or any person associated therewith, as
an inducement for the award of a subcontract or order.
   B.   No village official, department head, or employee shall exercise
contract management authority where any relative or the domestic partner of the
official, department head, or employee is employed by or has contracts with
persons doing village work over which the village official, department head, or
employee has or exercises contract management authority.
   C.   No village official, department head, or employee shall use or permit
the use of his or her position to assist any relative, or his or her domestic
partner in securing employment or contracts with persons over whom the
employee, department head, or official exercises contract management authority.
The employment of or contracting with a relative or domestic partner of such a
village official, department head, or employee by such a person within six (6)
months prior to, during the term of, or six (6) months subsequent to the period
of a village contract shall be evidence that said employment or contract was
obtained in violation of this chapter. (Ords. 13-17-64, 19-28-95)
1-15-7-11: INVALID ACTIONS:
All village contracts shall include a provision requiring compliance with this
chapter. Any contracts negotiated, entered into, or performed in violation of
any of the provisions of this chapter shall be voidable as to the village. Any
permit, license, ruling, determination or other official action of a village
department or commission applied for or in any other manner sought, obtained or
undertaken in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be
invalid and without any force or effect whatsoever. (Ord. 13-17-64)
1-15-8: SOLICITATION OF CONTRIBUTIONS ON OR THROUGH VILLAGE PROPERTY:
No public official, village employee, candidate for an elective office,
officer, employee, or agent of any political organization shall intentionally
solicit, accept, offer, or make contributions (as defined in the Illinois
election code) either in person or electronically on or through the use of
village property.
For purposes of this section "village property" means any building or portion
thereof owned or exclusively leased by the village and all village servers,
software systems, and e-mail systems.
An inadvertent solicitation, acceptance, offer or making of a contribution is
not a violation of this section so long as reasonable and timely action is
taken to return the contribution to its source. (Ord. 15-11-40)
CHAPTER 16
REVOLVING LOAN PROGRAM FOR OAK LAWN BUSINESSES
SECTION:
1-16-1: Village Findings
1-16-2: Funding of Business Loan Program
1-16-3: Loan Application Process
1-16-4: Requirements for Loan Application Approval by the Village
1-16-5: Requirements of Program Contracts with Local Banks
1-16-1: VILLAGE FINDINGS:
The President and Board of Trustees specifically find as follows:
   A.   The Village is a home rule unit of government under article VII,
section 6(a) of the Illinois Constitution and, therefore, has the power to
adopt ordinances related to its government and affairs.
   B.   The Village desires to encourage the development of additional
businesses and the growth of existing businesses to diversify its tax base, to
provide for economic stability, to produce increased tax revenue and to provide
related benefits to the Village.
   C.   The Village desires to take action to preserve the economic viability
of the business community before any decline therein takes place.
   D.   In order to meet these goals, the Village has determined that it should
create a funding mechanism to provide low interest loans to qualifying
businesses for the development of new businesses, and the expansion and/or
redevelopment of existing businesses, within the Village.
   E.   That the aforementioned business loan program pertains to the Village's
government and affairs. (Ord. 94-23-99)
1-16-2: FUNDING OF BUSINESS LOAN PROGRAM:
There is hereby set aside for deposit, in up to two (2) banks within the
Village, the total amount of one million dollars ($1,000,000.00), for the
purpose of providing a funding source for a revolving low interest business
loan program (hereinafter the "program") within the Village. Except in the case
that only one local bank is interested in participating in the program under
the terms and conditions set forth in this Chapter, or except in the case that
only one local bank offers the lowest interest rate difference increment as
referenced in subsection 1-16-5D2 below, the amount of five hundred thousand
dollars ($500,000.00) shall be deposited at each of two (2) local banks for
purposes of providing a funding source for the program. If more than two (2)
local banks are interested in participating in the program, and all are
offering the same interest rate difference increment as referenced in
subsection 1-16-5D2 below, said deposits shall be made as directed by the
Village Board after receipt of a recommendation from the Director of the
Department of Administrative services. If only one local bank is interested in
participating in the program, or if only one local bank offers the lowest
interest rate difference increment as referenced in Section 1-16-5D2 below, the
entire one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) shall be deposited in the one
participating local bank. For purposes of administering deposits under the
program, the Village shall accept requests for participation from local banks
for a period of fifteen (15) days following the adoption of the Ordinance 94-
23-99 enacting this provision of the Village Code. Each participating local
bank shall be required to enter into a contract with the Village, in a form
acceptable to and approved by the Village Board, prior to any deposit of funds
at such local bank relative to the program. (Ord. 94-23-99)
1-16-3: LOAN APPLICATION PROCESS:
Loan applications shall be available from, and shall be initially filed with,
the Village's Department of Administrative Services. If the Director of the
Department of Administrative Services, or his/her designee, determines that the
Village criteria for program participation have been met, the applicant shall
be directed to one of the local banks that are participating in the program.
Said local bank shall be advised in writing by the Director of the Department
of Administrative Services, or his/her designee, of the Village's approval of
said applicant. The applicant shall then complete all additional application
materials as may be requested by the local bank processing the application.
Approval of an application by the Village shall not prevent a participating
local bank from rejecting an applicant for program participation if said
applicant fails to meet the loan issuance criteria of said local bank.
Application forms will be available effective January 16, 1995. Applications
shall be accepted and processed by the Village, on a "first come, first-served"
basis, beginning January 31, 1995. (Ord. 94-23-99)
1-16-4: REQUIREMENTS FOR LOAN APPLICATION APPROVAL BY THE VILLAGE:
No application for a loan under the program shall be approved by the Village
unless the applicant meets the following criteria:
   A.   The business project to be financed with the loan must be located
within the Village.
   B.   The items to be financed by the loan are limited to:
      1.   The acquisition of real property;
      2.   The construction of a new building;
      3.   The construction of an addition to an existing building;
      4.   The remodeling or reconstruction of an existing building;
      5.   The construction of additional parking areas in relation to the
business;
      6.   The purchase of business related equipment; or
      7.   The purchase of business related fixtures.
Loans shall not be approved for the refinancing of existing indebtedness
relative to any of the aforementioned items.
   C.   No money is due and owing the Village from the applicant, the business
or in regard to the property in relation to which the loan is being sought.
   D.   The requested loan is for not less than twenty five thousand dollars
($25,000.00) and not more than one hundred fifty thousand dollars
($150,000.00).
   E.   The requested loan must be for a project that will either increase the
amount of local tax revenue generated by the property in relation to which the
loan is being sought, or increase the number of employment opportunities
generated by the business on said property. In this regard, the loan applicant
shall be required to set forth in the loan application the nature and amount of
the anticipated additional local tax revenue and/or jobs that will be generated
as a result of the loan.
   F.   All necessary business licenses have been obtained by the applicant
relative to the proposed business.
   G.   The property in relation to which the loan is being sought and the
proposed/existing business use of said property are in compliance with all
applicable Village codes and ordinances.
In the event that an application for a business license is pending, or a
petition for a variation from certain of the Village's codes and ordinances has
been filed with the Village, the Director of Administrative Services, or his/
her designee, may put a hold on the amount of funds requested by the applicant,
for a period of not more than ninety (90) days, to allow the applicant time to
satisfy the conditions set forth in subsections F and/or G above. (Ord. 94-23-
99)
1-16-5: REQUIREMENTS OF PROGRAM CONTRACTS WITH LOCAL BANKS:
Each contract with a local bank that desires to participate in the program
shall provide, but not be limited to, the following terms and conditions:
   A.   Loans provided by the bank as part of the program shall be subject to
an interest rate equal to the Wall Street prime rate at the time of the
issuance of the loan, minus three percent (3.0%). For example, if the Wall
Street prime rate is eight percent (8.0%), a loan pursuant to the program would
be issued by the bank at five percent (5.0%).
   B.   The term of a loan under the program shall not exceed five (5) years.
   C.   Loans issued pursuant to the program shall have monthly amortization of
principal and interest.
   D.   The Village shall receive interest on the funds deposited by the
Village at the bank, relative to the program, as follows:
      1.   The amount deposited shall initially earn interest at the bank's
interest rate for money market accounts.
      2.   When a loan is issued under the program, that portion of the amount
deposited by the Village equal to the outstanding principal amount of the loan
shall earn interest at a rate equal to the loan interest rate, minus the
increment agreed to by the bank, provided said increment shall not be more than
three percent (3%). The remaining "unloaned" portion of the amount deposited by
the Village shall continue to earn interest at the bank's interest rate for
money market accounts. As loan principal payments are received on a monthly
basis, and as additional loans are made, the amount of the Village's deposit
subject to the money market rate of interest shall be increased/decreased
accordingly on a monthly basis.
   E.   The Village's deposit at the bank relative to the program shall not be
used as security for any loan given by the bank under the program, and any
default by any recipient of a loan under the program shall not be offset
against the Village funds on deposit at the bank.
   F.   To the extent that the Village's deposit of funds at the bank, relative
to the program, exceeds one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00), the deposit
shall be collateralized by the bank using U.S. government securities as the
collateral.
   G.   The bank shall provide the Village with monthly account statements
relative to the Village's funds on deposit at the bank.
   H.   The bank shall provide the Village with quarterly status reports
relative to the loans issued by the bank in regard to the program.
   I.   The bank shall prepare, and file with the appropriate governmental
agency when necessary, all required documentation relative to each loan issued
by the bank.
   J.   The Village shall not be charged any servicing fees by the bank
relative to the program generally, or relative to any loan issued by the bank
pursuant to the program. (Ord. 94-23-99)
CHAPTER 17
GENERAL VILLAGE POLICIES
SECTION:
1-17-1: Nondiscrimination Policy
1-17-1: NONDISCRIMINATION POLICY:
It is hereby declared the policy of the Village that in conducting the business
of the Village there shall be no discrimination based on race, color, national
origin, age, handicap, sex or religion. A copy of this policy shall be posted
at various locations throughout the buildings owned by the Village so that the
employees of the Village are made aware of this policy. The Village's Grant
Administrator, who is responsible for the Village's interaction with the U.S.
Department of Housing and Urban Development relative to the Community
Development Block Grant Program, shall be the employee designated to oversee
the Village's compliance with this policy including, but not limited to,
routinely determining if any complaints against the Village have been filed
with either the U.S. Equal Employment Opportunity Commission or the Illinois
Department of Human Rights. (Ord. 96-15-73)
CHAPTER 18
BUSINESS DISTRICTS
SECTION:
1-18-1: Findings
1-18-2: Designation
1-18-3: Powers
1-18-1: FINDINGS:
Pursuant to public hearings held on June 22, 1999, the President and Board of
Trustees hereby find that it is essential to the economic and social welfare of
the Village that business districts be maintained and revitalized by assuring
opportunities for development or redevelopment and by attracting sound and
stable commercial growth, thereby enhancing the tax base of the Village and
employment opportunities within the Village. (Ord. 99-11-24)
1-18-2: DESIGNATION:
The President and Board of Trustees may designate specific areas of the Village
as business districts when they find that such a designation will facilitate
the maintenance and revitalization of the area in accordance with Section
1-18-2 of this Chapter. (Ord. 99-11-24)
1-18-3: POWERS:
In carrying out development or redevelopment within a designated business
district, the President and Board shall have those powers set forth in 65
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-74.3-3. In addition, the President and Board of
Trustees may exercise such other powers to facilitate development and
redevelopment within a designated business district as deemed necessary
pursuant to the Village's home rule powers as provided by article VII, section
6 of the 1970 Illinois Constitution. (Ord. 99-11-24)
CHAPTER 19
PUBLIC RECORDS
SECTION:
1-19-1: Purpose
1-19-2: Definitions
1-19-3: Freedom Of Information Act
1-19-4: Duplication Costs
1-19-5: Special Service Fee
1-19-6: Original Village Records
1-19-1: PURPOSE:
The Village is incorporated to serve the residents of the Village and to
transact business for the public. The records of these public transactions
shall be open to inspection and review by the public unless there is a
compelling reason for keeping a record private. The purpose of this chapter is
to provide practices and procedures for members of the general public to
receive access to public records of the Village in compliance with the
provisions of the Freedom of Information Act, 5 Illinois Compiled Statutes 140/
1 et seq. (Ord. 03-02-09)
1-19-2: DEFINITIONS:
The definitions of the terms "public records", "records", "person", and
"copying" as used in this chapter shall be found in section 2 of the Freedom of
Information Act 1 , as amended. (Ord. 03-02-09)
 
Notes
1 1. 5 ILCS 140/2.
1-19-3: FREEDOM OF INFORMATION ACT:
Effective January 1, 2010:
   A.   The rules and regulations regarding the Freedom of Information Act 1 ,
as amended, are as follows:
      1.   The Village Clerk is designated as the person to whom all initial
requests for access to the records of the Village are to be referred. Such
requests are to be made at the offices of the Village at 9446 South Raymond
Avenue, Oak Lawn, Illinois, between the hours of eight thirty o'clock (8:30)
A.M. and five o'clock (5:00) P.M., Monday through Friday. In the event that the
Village Clerk is not available during the times described above, the Deputy
Clerk or his/her designee is designated as the person(s) to whom such initial
requests are to be made.
      2.   Any records which are the subject of a request under the Freedom of
Information Act shall be retrieved from such place as they are stored, by the
Village Clerk or Deputy Clerk or his/her designee or by an employee of the
Village acting under the direction of the Village Clerk, Deputy Clerk or his/
her designee. In no event shall records be retrieved by the party requesting
them or by any person who is not employed by the Village.
      3.   Any records that are made available for inspection shall be reviewed
at the Office of the Village Clerk located at 9446 South Raymond Avenue, Oak
Lawn, Illinois, second floor, unless otherwise designated by the Village Clerk.
In no event shall any records be removed from the Office of the Village Clerk
or the location where they are being reviewed if not in the Office of the
Village Clerk, by the requesting party.
      4.   If copies of records are requested, the fee for such copies, whether
certified or not, shall be as set forth in section
1-19-4 of this chapter. The Village Clerk shall maintain a written schedule of
current fees in the Clerk's Office. The fees so charged shall reflect the
actual cost of copying the records, and the cost of certifying the copies, if
certification is requested.
      5.   In responding to a request, the Village shall follow the
requirements of the Freedom of Information Act and shall make their records
available for inspection and copying within five (5) working days after receipt
of the request or within any other permitted time period under the Freedom of
Information Act, as amended. Where appropriate, the Village shall deny the
inspection of or copying of any records based upon the provisions of the
Freedom of Information Act, as amended. A copy of the Freedom of Information
Act shall be available at the Village Clerk's Office for inspection and
copying.
      6.   In the event that a request to inspect or copy records is denied,
the denial may be appealed to the Village Manager. Such an appeal must be made
within fourteen (14) days after the requesting party receives the written
notice denying said request. In the absence of the Village Manager, appeals
from denials of requests for access/copies shall be made to the Village
President in the times set forth above.
   B.   The Village Manager is hereby authorized to make any necessary
administrative rules and regulations to implement said Freedom of Information
Act and the request for documents. (Ord. 10-01-01)
