1 1. See Title 1, Chapter 12 of this Code.
2-3-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED, COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established a Board of Local Improvements for the Village which
shall consist of seven (7) members appointed by the President of the Village
with the consent of the Trustees. (Ords. 71-18-43, 77-30-52, 79-19-29)
2-3-2: OFFICERS:
The President of the Village shall be the president of the Board of Local
Improvements. The members of the Board of Local Improvements may designate one
of its members as secretary of the Board, or the members may appoint a person
other than the members to act as secretary at a compensation to be fixed by the
Village Board of Trustees. (Ords. 71-18-43, 79-19-29)
2-3-3: MEETINGS:
The Board of Local Improvements shall meet upon the call of the President or
any two (2) members. Twenty four (24) hours' notice of such call shall be given
each member; provided, that a meeting be held when all members are present,
without notice. Notices of meetings shall be sent as provided for by subsection
1-6-3D of this Code.
The Director of Office of Quality Control and the Village Attorney shall be
required to attend all meetings of the Board of Local Improvements. (1951 Code
1-6-1, 1-6-3, 2-8-9; Ords. 68, 81-12-19)
2-3-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Board of Local Improvements shall have all of the powers and duties
conferred and imposed by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/9-2-1, Illinois
Municipal Code and such additional duties as may be assigned to it by statute
or ordinance. (Ord. 71-18-43)
CHAPTER 4
CIVIL SERVICE COMMISSION
(Rep. by Ord. 07-23-70)
CHAPTER 5
DEFERRED COMPENSATION PLAN COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-5-1: Commission Established, Composition
2-5-2: Duties
2-5-1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED, COMPOSITION:
The village of Oak Lawn Deferred Compensation Plan Commission is hereby
established. The commission shall have three (3) members and shall be composed
of the Village Manager, Village Treasurer and Finance Director or their
designees. (Ord. 80-11-23; 1985 Code; Ord. 19-16-64)
2-5-2: DUTIES:
The duties of the commission shall be:
   A.   To monitor the administration of the village deferred compensation
plan.
   B.   To advise the village regarding the operation of the plan and the
desirability of amending the plan.
   C.   To participate in determining whether any participants in the plan, who
seek to withdraw deferred compensation because of an unforeseeable emergency,
is entitled to such withdrawal by the terms of the plan and applicable law.
(Ords. 80-11-23, 19-16-64)
CHAPTER 6
BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
SECTION:
2-6-1: Appointment And Term Of Office, Meetings
2-6-2: Qualifications; Oath And Bond; Removal From Office
2-6-3: Officers, Meetings
2-6-4: Compensation
2-6-5: Rules Of The Board
2-6-6: Appointments Of Fire And Police Department Members
2-6-7: Reports
2-6-8: Rooms And Funds For Board
2-6-9: Fire And Police Department Members, Qualifications And Procedures
2-6-9-1: Qualifications Of Applicant
2-6-9-2: Examinations
2-6-9-3: Register Of Eligibles
2-6-9-4: Veteran's Preference
2-6-9-5: Promotions
2-6-9-6: Removals Or Discharges
2-6-9-7: Disability Or Military Leave
2-6-9-8: Reduction Of Forces, Reinstatement
2-6-10: Applicability Of Provisions
2-6-1: APPOINTMENT AND TERM OF OFFICE, MEETINGS:
There is hereby created and established a seven (7) member Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners whereby the President shall appoint one (1) member and
each Village Trustee shall appoint one (1) member from their own district. All
appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1 of the calendar
year. Members of Board of Fire and Police Commissioners serving as of the
effective date hereof shall serve until the end of the term to which appointed
and until their successors are named and qualified. Effective September 1,
2019, a full term shall be four (4) years and terms shall be staggered so not
more than four (4) expire each year. Such staggered terms shall coincide with
District 1, 3, and 5 appointees to expire opposite years of District 2, 4, and
6 appointees. For purposes of this Chapter, such appointments for District 1,
3, and 5 beginning on September 1, 2019, shall have initial term limit to end
in calendar year 2021 so as to initiate such staggered terms.
If a vacancy exists following the failure and/or refusal by a Village Trustee
to appoint a member by October 1 of the calendar year, an appointment shall be
made by a recommendation from the President with approval of the majority of
the Village Board.
The President and Board of Trustees may compel attendance of any absent member
and may remove any such member from said Commission if that member misses three
(3) consecutive meetings. The removal shall be initiated by the President and
subject to the confirmation of such removal by the advice and consent of the
Village Board.
(1951 Code 2-9-1; Ords. 79, 19-16-61, 19-18-69)
2-6-2: QUALIFICATIONS; OATH AND BOND; REMOVAL FROM OFFICE:
The members of the board shall be considered officers of the village, and shall
file an oath and a fidelity bond in such amount as may be required by the board
of trustees 1 .
No person holding an office under the United States, this state or any
political subdivision thereof, or a municipality, shall be a member of the
board of fire and police commissioners or the secretary thereof. The acceptance
of any such office by a member of the board shall be treated as a resignation
of his office as a member of the board or the secretary thereof. No person
shall be appointed a member of the board of fire and police commissioners who
is related, either by blood or marriage up to a degree of first cousin, to any
elected official of the village. No more than two (2) members of the board
shall belong to the same political party existing in the village at the time of
such appointments and as defined in 10 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2. If
only one or no political party exists in the village at the time of such
appointments then state or national political party affiliations shall be
considered in making such appointments. Party affiliation shall be determined
by affidavit of the person appointed as a member of the board.
Members shall not be subject to removal, except for cause, upon written
charges, and after an opportunity to be heard within thirty (30) days in his or
their own defense, before a regular meeting of the board of trustees. A
majority vote of the elected members of such board of trustees shall be
required to remove any such member from office.  (1951 Code 2-9-3; 1985 Code;
Ords. 86-3-9, 19-16-61)
 
Notes
  1. See sections
1 1-9-3 and
  1-9-4 of this code.
2-6-3: OFFICERS, MEETINGS:
   A.   Secretary To The Board: The board may employ a secretary, or may
designate one of its own members to act as secretary. The secretary shall:
      1.   Keep the minutes of the Board's proceedings;
      2.   Be the custodian of all records pertaining to the business of the
Board;
      3.   Keep a record of all examinations held;
      4.   Perform all other duties the Board prescribes; and
      5.   Be custodian of the seal of the Board, if one is adopted. The Board
is hereby authorized to adopt, by resolution, an official seal and to prescribe
the form thereof.
   B.   Regular Meetings: Meetings shall be held at least once every month on
the 1st Wednesday of the month. except that the Board may, by rule, provide for
changing dates for seasonal reasons or in the event there is no pending
business.
   C.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by
any three (3) members of the Commission.
   D.   Open to the Public: All meetings of the Board shall be open meetings as
required under the applicable statutes of the State and the codes of the
Village.
   E.   Robert’s Rules of Order: In all cases not covered by the rules herein
or where they are not applicable, the Board shall be covered by parliamentary
law as laid down in “Robert’s Rules of Order” as revised. (1951 Code 2-9-15;
Ord. 76-7-12; 1985 Code; Ords. 86-3-9, 87-13-53, 19-16-61, 19-18-69, 21-20-92,
22-09-29, 23-01-01)
2-6-4: COMPENSATION:
Each member of the Board shall receive a sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
per meeting for every properly posted meeting attended, or such portion thereof
as shall represent time served in a given calendar year, with a minimum annual
renumeration of $500.00 per member if the member attends 70% or more of all
properly posted meetings. This remuneration is intended to cover normal and
necessary expenses of the member. Additional or unusual expenses may be covered
as budgeted upon receipt of proper evidence of expenditure and approval by this
Commission. (Ords. 76-7-12, 19-16-61, 19-18-69, 23-13-47)
2-6-5: RULES OF THE BOARD:
   A.   Authority: The Board shall make rules:
      1.   To carry out the purpose of this Chapter, and
      2.   For appointments and removals in accordance with the provisions of
this Chapter.
      The Board, from time to time, may make changes in these rules.
   B.   Publication: All these rules and changes therein shall be printed
immediately for distribution. The Board shall give notice of all places where
the printed rules may be obtained and of the date, not less than ten (10) days
subsequent to the time of publication, when the rules or changes therein shall
go into operation. This notice shall be published in one or more newspapers
published in the Village, or, if no newspaper is published therein, then in one
or more newspapers with a general circulation within the Municipality.
   C.   Application Of Rules: These rules of the Board shall apply only to the
conduct of examinations for original appointments, for promotions, and to the
conduct of hearings on charges brought against a member of the Police and Fire
Departments. No rule shall be made by the Board to govern the operation of the
Police or Fire Departments or of the conduct of its members unless the Board of
Trustees specifically authorizes the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners to
make such rules; however, the Board of Trustees may also rescind such
authorization. (1951 Code
2-9-5)
2-6-6: APPOINTMENTS OF FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall appoint all sworn
officers and members of the Fire and Police Departments of the Village, except
the Chief of Police, the Chief of the Fire Department, and the Deputy Fire
Chief, who shall be appointed by the Village Manager without the consent of the
President and the Board of Trustees.
   B.   If a member of the Department is appointed Chief of Police, Chief of
the Fire Department, or Deputy Fire Chief prior to being eligible to retire on
pension, they shall be considered as on furlough from the rank he held with the
Village immediately prior to their appointment as Chief or Deputy Chief, if
any, not including positions previously appointed by the Village Manager. If
they resign as Chief or Deputy Chief or are discharged as Chief or Deputy Chief
prior to attaining eligibility to retire on pension, they shall revert to and
be established in such prior rank, if any, not including positions previously
appointed by the Village Manager, and thereafter be entitled to all the
benefits and emoluments of such prior rank, without regard as to whether a
vacancy then exists in such rank.
   C.   All appointments made by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners to
each Department other than that of the lowest rank shall be from the rank next
below that to which the appointment is made, except in the case of tested Fire
Bureau Chief, which may be made from multiple subordinate ranks as provided in
the fire department collective bargaining agreement.
   D.   The sole authority to issue certificates of appointment shall be vested
in the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners and all certificates of
appointments issued to any officer or member of the Fire or Police Department
shall be signed by the chairman and secretary respectively of the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners of the Village, upon appointment of such officer or
member of the Fire and Police Department by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners.
   E.   Any full-time member of a regular Fire or Police Department of the
Village is a Village officer.
   F.   In order to prevent a stoppage of public business, to meet
extraordinary exigencies, or to prevent material impairment of either the
Police or Fire Department, the Board may make temporary appointments, to remain
in force until regular appointments may be made under the provisions of this
Chapter, but never to exceed sixty (60) days. No temporary appointment of any
one person shall be made more than twice in any calendar year.
(1951 Code 2-9-5, 2-9-12; Ords. 86-3-9, 25-11-25)
2-6-7: REPORTS:
Annually, on May 1 and on such other occasions as the President may request,
the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall submit to the President a
report of its activities, and of the rules in force and the practical effect
thereof. In this report the Board may make suggestions which the Board believes
would result in greater efficiency in the Fire or Police Department. The Board
shall also submit an annual budget request to the Board of Trustees prior to
the end of each fiscal year. The President shall transmit the report to the
Board of Trustees. (1951 Code 2-9-14)
2-6-8: ROOMS AND FUNDS FOR BOARD:
The Board of Trustees shall provide suitable rooms for the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners, and shall allow reasonable use of public buildings for
holding examinations by the Board and shall further provide adequate funds in
the annual appropriation ordinance for the operation of the Board. (Ord. 76-7-
12)
2-6-9: FIRE AND POLICE DEPARTMENT MEMBERS, QUALIFICATIONS AND PROCEDURES:
2-6-9-1:QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANT:
   A.   Residence Requirements: (Repealed)
   B.   Character: No person shall be appointed to the police or fire
department unless he is a person of good character; not a habitual drunkard,
drug addict, gambler, or a person who has been convicted of a felony or a crime
involving moral turpitude. Any such person who is in the department may be
removed on charges brought and after a trial as hereinafter provided. (1951
Code 2-9-6; Ords. 487, 86-3-9, 89-18-49)
2-6-9-2:EXAMINATIONS:
   A.   Examination Required; Disqualifications; Removal: All applicants for a
position in either the fire or police department of the village, under thirty
five (35) years of age, shall be subject to examination, which shall be public,
competitive, and at a cost of twenty five dollars ($25.00) to reimburse the
village for its costs of administration, and shall be subject to reasonable
limitations as to residence, health, habits and moral character. No person with
a record of misdemeanor convictions except those under 720 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/11-6, 5/11-7, 5/11-9, 5/11-14, 5/11-15, 5/11-17, 5/11-18, 5/11-19,
5/12-2, 5/12-6, 5/12-12 et seq., 5/14-4, 5/16-1, 5/21-1.3, 5/24-3.1, 5/24-5, 5/
25-1, 5/28-3, 5/31-1, 5/31-4, 5/31-6, 5/31-7, 5/32-1, 5/32-2, 5/32-3, 5/32-4,
5/32-8, and subsections 1, 6 and 8 of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1 of
the Illinois criminal code 1 , or arrested for any cause but not convicted
thereon shall be disqualified from taking the examination to qualify for a
position in the fire department on grounds of habits or moral character.
Pursuant to the village's home rule powers, as provided by article VII, section
6 of the 1970 Illinois constitution, the age limitation exceptions, as provided
for in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-6(d), shall not be applicable in
determining an individual's eligibility to apply for an entry level position in
either the fire or police department of the village.
Applicants who are twenty (20) years of age and who have successfully completed
two (2) years of law enforcement studies at an accredited college or university
may be considered for appointment to active duty with the police department.
Any such applicant who is appointed to active duty shall not have power to
arrest, nor shall he be permitted to carry firearms, until he reaches twenty
one (21) years of age. Applicants who are eighteen (18) years of age and who
have successfully completed two (2) years of study in fire techniques,
amounting to a total of four (4) high school credits, within the cadet program
of a municipality may be considered for appointment to active duty with the
fire department of the village. The examinations shall be practical in
character and relate to those matters which will fairly test the capacity of
the persons examined to discharge the duties of the positions to which they
seek appointment. No person shall be appointed to the police or fire department
if he does not possess a high school diploma or an equivalent high school
education. The examinations shall include tests of physical qualifications and
health. No person shall be appointed to the police or fire department if he has
suffered the amputation of any limb unless the applicant's duties will be only
clerical or as a radio operator. No applicant shall be examined concerning his
political or religious opinions or affiliations. The examinations shall be
conducted by the board of fire and police commissioners of the village as
hereinafter provided.
No person who is classified by his local selective service draft board as a
conscientious objector, or who has ever been so classified, may be appointed to
the police department.
No person shall be appointed to the police or fire department unless he is a
person of good character; not a habitual drunkard, drug addict, gambler, or a
person who has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude.
However, no person shall be disqualified from appointment to the fire
department because of such person's record of misdemeanor convictions except
those under 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6, 5/11-7, 5/11-9, 5/11-14, 5/
11-15, 5/11-17, 5/11-18, 5/11-19, 5/12-2, 5/12-6, 5/12-12 et seq., 5/14-4, 5/
16-1, 5/21-1.3, 5/24-3.1, 5/24-5, 5/25-1, 5/28-3, 5/31-1, 5/31-4, 5/31-6, 5/31-
7, 5/32-1, 5/32-2, 5/32-3, 5/32-4, 5/32-8, and subsections 1, 6 and 8 of 720
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/24-1 of the Illinois criminal code 2 , or arrest
for any cause without conviction thereon. Any such person who is in the
department may be removed on charges brought and after a trial as hereinafter
provided.
A waiver of the examination fee will be granted to any applicant who attests in
writing that the imposition of said fee will result in a financial hardship. If
any individual, for which the examination fee is waived, is appointed by the
village, said individual shall reimburse the village for the twenty five dollar
($25.00) examination fee within ninety (90) days after being appointed.
   B.   Notice: Notice of the time and place of every examination shall be
given by the board by a publication at least two (2) weeks preceding the
examination, in one or more newspapers published in the village.
   C.   Exemptions: Any member of the police department who has held a position
in the police department for not less than one year prior to May 25, 1954,
shall become a member of the classified service of the police department
without examination.
   D.   Educational Requirements: Notwithstanding anything set forth in
subsection A of this section, pursuant to the village's home rule powers, as
provided by article VII, section 6 of the 1970 Illinois constitution, all
applicants for entry level positions in either the fire or police department of
the village shall have the required education as set forth below:
      1.   Firefighters: Each firefighter applicant, as a minimum training and
educational requirement, shall:
         a.   Possess and maintain a valid CPAT (candidate physical ability
test) card with ladder climb endorsement which is current as of the date of
filing the application for employment.
         b.   Possess License from Illinois Department of Public Health (IDPH)
as an EMT- Paramedic at the date and time of hire.
         c.   In lieu of IDPH EMT-Paramedic license, A firefighter applicant
may possess a National Registry of Emergency Medical Technician - Paramedic
(NREMT-P) certification.
            (1)   The applicant shall be legally eligible for licensure as a
State of Illinois EMT-Paramedic at the date and time of hire.
            (2)   NREMT-P Certification shall be current and valid with
continuing education requirements maintained.
            (3)   The Fire Chief shall have the additional duty to both verify
and certify that the applicant's NREMT-P Certification is official, current and
valid at the date and time of hire.
         d.   Possess Certification from the Illinois Office of State Fire
Marshal as a Basic Operations Firefighter (BOF) or Firefighter II at the date
and time of hire.
         e.   If firefighter applicant has completed training and education but
does not possess certification as Illinois OSFM Basic Operations Firefighter.
            (1)   Possess Certificate of Completion, from accredited fire
academy, college or university for all Illinois OSFM Basic Operations
Firefighter (BOF) requirements.
            (2)   This requirement includes, but is not limited to: training,
education, passing scores on all OSFM BOF written and practical examination
requirements, Co-Requisite course completion for the Illinois OSFM Basic
Operations Firefighter (BOF) at the date and time of hire.
            (3)   The Fire Chief shall have the additional duty to both verify
and certify that the applicant's Certificate of Completion of BOF requirement
is both official and valid at the date and time of hire.
      2.   Police Officers: Each police officer applicant, as a minimum
educational requirement, shall have successfully completed at least sixty (60)
semester or ninety (90) quarter hours of credit at an accredited college or
university as of the date of filing the application for employment. This
requirement will be waived for candidates who have completed four (4) years of
active duty with an honorable discharge in the U.S. military and/or candidates
who meet the criteria of the board's lateral transfer policy. (1951 Code 2-9-6,
2-9-7, 2-9-9; Ords. 84-26-79, 86-3-9, 89-2-5, 96-9-44, 98-7-28, 98-9-44A, 98-9-
44B, 08-26-90, 11-10-10, 22-18-57)
 
Notes
1 1. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
2 1. 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
2-6-9-3: REGISTER OF ELIGIBLES:
   A.   The board of fire and police commissioners shall prepare and keep a
register of persons whose general average standing upon examination is not less
than the minimum fixed by the rules of the board, and who are otherwise
eligible. These persons shall take rank upon the register as candidates in the
order of their relative excellence as determined by examination, without
reference to priority of time of examination.
   B.   Police applicants who have been awarded a certificate attesting to
their successful completion of the minimum standards basic law enforcement
training course, as provided in the Illinois police training act, may be given
preference in appointment over noncertified applicants, all as provided in the
rules and procedures of the board. No such educational preference, however, may
be given to applicants for appointment to the fire department, including
candidates who are licensed as an EMT-B, EMT-I or EMT-P under the emergency
medical systems act. (1951 Code 2-9-10; 1985 Code; Ords. 96-9-44, 98-7-28, 06-
15-93)
2-6-9-4: VETERAN'S PREFERENCE:
   A.   General: Persons who were engaged in the military or naval service of
the United States for a period of at least one year and who were honorably
discharged therefrom, or who are now or may hereafter be on inactive reserve
duty in such military or naval service, not including, however, persons who
were convicted by court martial of disobedience of orders, where such
disobedience consisted in the refusal to perform military service on the
grounds of religious or conscientious objections against war, shall be
preferred for appointments to offices, positions and places of employment in
the fire and police departments of the village coming under the provisions of
this chapter.
   B.   Preferences In Original Appointments: The board of fire and police
commissioners shall give preference for original appointments to persons
designated in subsection A of this section whose names appear on any register
of eligibles resulting from an examination for original entrance in the
classified service of the fire and police departments by adding to the final
grade average which they receive or will receive as the result of any
examination held for original entrance, five (5) points. The numerical result
thus attained shall be applied by the board of fire and police commissioners in
determining the position of such persons on any eligibility list which has been
created as the result of any examination for original entrance for purposes of
preference in certification and appointment from such eligibility list. The
board shall strike off the names of candidates for original appointment after
such names have been on the list for more than two (2) years.
   C.   Promotional Preferences:
      1.   Every member of the classified service of the fire or police
department of this village coming under the provisions of this chapter who was
engaged in the military or naval service of the United States at least one
year, and who was honorably discharged therefrom, who is now or who may
hereafter be on inactive or reserve duty in such military or naval service, not
including, however, persons who were convicted by court martial of disobedience
of orders where such disobedience consisted in the refusal to perform military
service on the grounds of alleged religious or conscientious objections against
war, and whose name appears on existing promotional eligibility registers or
any promotional eligibility register that may hereafter be created as provided
for by this chapter, shall be preferred for promotional appointments of the
fire or police department.
      2.   The board of fire and police commissioners shall give preference for
promotional appointment to persons designated in subsection A of this section
whose names appear on promotional eligibility registers by adding to the final
grade average which they will receive as a result of any promotional
examination, seven-tenths percent (0.7%) of one point for each six (6) months
or fraction thereof of military or naval service not exceeding thirty (30)
months. The numerical result thus attained shall be applied by the board of
fire and police commissioners in determining the position of such persons on
any eligibility list as the result of any promotional examination held for
purposes of preference in certification and appointment from such eligibility
list.
      3.   No person shall receive the preference for a promotional appointment
granted by this chapter after he has received one appointment or promotion from
an eligibility list on which he was allowed such preference.
   D.   Time For Allowance Of Preferences: No person entitled to preference or
credit for military or naval service shall be required to claim military credit
for service in the armed forces before any examination held under the
provisions of this chapter, but such preference shall be given after the
posting or publication of the eligibility list or register at the request of
such person before any certification or appointments are made from the
eligibility register, upon the furnishing of evidence of an honorable discharge
from and proof of such service.
   E.   Applicable Preference Points: Pursuant to the village's home rule
powers, as provided by article VII, section 6 of the 1970 Illinois
constitution, except for military preference points as set forth in subsections
A through D of this section, no other preference points provided for pursuant
to the provisions of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 through 5/10-2.1-
30 shall be applicable to either entry level or promotional examinations given
by the board of fire and police commissioners. (1951 Code 2-9-8; 1985 Code;
Ords. 86-3-9, 94-21-95)
2-6-9-5: PROMOTIONS:
   Except with respect to the offices of Chief of Police, Fire Chief, or Deputy
Fire Chief, the board, by its rules, shall provide for promotion in the fire
and police departments on the basis of ascertained merit and seniority in
service and examination, and shall provide in all cases, where it is
practicable, that vacancies shall be filled by promotion. Promotion to the
positions of Chief of Police, Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief may be made by
appointment by the Village Manager only, with no ascertained merit, seniority,
or examination required; however, such positions need not be appointed from the
current members of the Departments. All examinations for promotion shall be
competitive among such members of the next lower ranks as desire to submit
themselves to examination. All promotions shall be made from the three (3)
having the highest rating, and where there are less than three (3) names on the
promotional eligibility register, as originally posted, or remaining thereon
after appointments have been made therefrom, appointments to fill existing
vacancies shall be made from those names or name remaining on the promotional
register. The method of examination and the rules governing examinations for
promotion shall be the same as provided for applicants for original
appointment, except that original appointments only shall be on probation, as
provided by the rules. The board shall strike off the names of candidates for
promotional appointment after they have remained thereon for more than three
(3) years, provided there is no vacancy existing which can be filled from the
promotional register.
(1951 Code 2-9-11; Ord. 25-11-25)
2-6-9-6: REMOVALS OR DISCHARGES:
   A.   Hearing: Except as hereinabove provided, no officer or member of the
fire or police department of the village shall be removed or discharged except
for cause, upon written charges, and after an opportunity to be heard in his
own defense. The board of fire and police commissioners shall conduct a fair
and impartial hearing of the charges, to be commenced within thirty (30) days
of the filing thereof, which hearing may be continued from time to time. In
case an officer or member is found guilty, the board may discharge him, or may
suspend him not exceeding thirty (30) days without pay. The board may suspend
any officer or member pending the hearing with or without pay, but not to
exceed thirty (30) days. If the board of fire and police commissioners
determines that the charges are not sustained, the officer or member shall be
reimbursed for all wages withheld, if any. In the conduct of this hearing, each
member of the board shall have power to administer oaths and affirmations, and
the board shall have power to secure by its subpoena both the attendance and
testimony of witnesses and the production of books and papers relevant to the
hearing.
   B.   Review: The provisions of 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et
seq., and the rules adopted pursuant thereto, shall apply to and govern all
proceedings for the judicial review of final administrative decisions of the
board of fire and police commissioners hereunder. The term "administrative
decision" is defined as in 735 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101.
   C.   Retirement Age: The age for retirement of policemen or firemen in the
service of the village is sixty five (65) years.
   D.   Suspension By Chief: Nothing in this section shall be construed to
prevent the chief of the fire department or the chief of the police department
from suspending, without pay, a member of his department for a period of not
more than five (5) days, but he shall notify the board in writing of such
suspension. Any police officer or firefighter so suspended may appeal to the
board of fire and police commissioners for a review of the suspension within
twenty four (24) hours after such suspension, and upon such appeal, the board
may sustain the action of the chief of the department, may reverse it with
instructions that the police officer or firefighter receive his pay for the
period involved, or may suspend the officer for an additional period of not
more than thirty (30) days or discharge him, depending upon the facts
presented. (1951 Code 2-9-13; 1985 Code; Ord. 86-3-9)
2-6-9-7: DISABILITY OR MILITARY LEAVE:
A person holding a position in the fire or police department who is injured
while in the performance of his duties and because of such injury is
temporarily unable to continue to perform his duties or who enters the military
or naval service of the United States because of a war in which the United
States is a party belligerent or as required by any act of congress shall, upon
written application to the board, be granted a disability or military leave, as
the case may be.
A person who has been on disability or military leave granted by the board and
who wishes to return to active duty in his certified position shall be credited
with seniority for the period of such leave and, if otherwise qualified, shall
be reinstated to his certified position at the rank or grade held at the start
of the leave, not more than sixty (60) days after his written request for
reinstatement is filed with the board. Such request shall be filed not more
than thirty (30) days after termination of the disability or military or naval
service. (Ord. 76-7-12)
2-6-9-8: REDUCTION OF FORCES, REINSTATEMENT:
   A.   When the force of the fire department or of the police department is
reduced, and positions displaced or abolished, seniority shall prevail and the
officers and members so reduced in rank, or removed from the service of the
fire department or of the police department shall be considered furloughed
without pay.
   B.   If any positions which have been vacated because of reduction in forces
or displacement and abolition of positions, are reinstated, such members and
officers of the fire department or of the police department as are furloughed
from the said positions shall be notified by the board by registered mail of
such reinstatement of positions and shall have prior right to such positions if
otherwise qualified, and in all cases seniority shall prevail. Written
application for such reinstated position must be made by the furloughed person
within thirty (30) days after notification as above provided, and such person
may be required to submit to examination by physicians of both the board of
fire and police commissioners and the appropriate pension board to determine
his physical fitness. (1969 Code 2-226)
2-6-10: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter shall apply only to full time firefighters and
full time police officers of a regularly constituted fire or police department
and not to any other personnel of any kind or description. (1969 Code 2-234;
Ord. 86-3-9)
CHAPTER 7
FIREMEN'S PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2-7-1: Board Established, Composition
2-7-2: Organization
2-7-3: Duties
2-7-1: BOARD ESTABLISHED, COMPOSITION:
There shall be and there is hereby established a board of trustees of the
firemen's pension fund.
The board of trustees of the firemen's pension fund shall consist of five (5)
members, of which two (2) members shall be chosen by the village president, two
(2) members shall be chosen from the active firemen of the village, and one
other member shall be chosen from the firemen of the village who have been duly
retired under the firemen's pension fund act, all in accordance with the
statute in such case made and provided.
The members of this board to be chosen from the active and retired firemen
shall be elected by ballot at elections to be held on the third Monday in April
of the applicable years under the Australian ballot system, at such place in
the village and under such regulations as shall be prescribed by such board;
provided, however, that no person entitled to vote shall cast more than one
vote at such election for each candidate for whom he shall be eligible to vote.
(Ords. 481, 06-03-16)
2-7-2: ORGANIZATION:
   A.   Officers: The board shall elect from its numbers a president and a
secretary. The village treasurer shall be ex officio treasurer of such board.
   B.   Meetings: The pension board shall meet at least quarterly, and shall
hold such additional meetings as may be called by the president of the pension
board. (Ord. 481)
2-7-3: DUTIES:
The pension board shall perform all the duties under the provisions of an act
entitled an act to create a "firemen's pension fund" in cities, incorporated
towns, villages, townships and fire districts having a population of not less
than five thousand (5,000) nor more than two hundred thousand (200,000)
inhabitants, in force July 11, 1919, and all amendments thereto, being 40
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/4-101 et seq. (Ord. 481)
CHAPTER 8
POLICE PENSION FUND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
SECTION:
2-8-1: Board Created, Membership; Terms Of Office
2-8-2: Officers
2-8-3: Meetings
2-8-4: Powers And Duties
2-8-1: BOARD CREATED, MEMBERSHIP; TERMS OF OFFICE:
A board composed of five (5) members, a majority of whom shall be residents of
the village, to be chosen as hereinafter provided, shall be and constitute a
board of trustees to administer the pension fund and designate the
beneficiaries thereof. Said board shall be known as the board of trustees of
the police pension fund of the village. Two (2) of said board members shall be
appointed by the president of the village, one of said members shall serve from
date of appointment until May 31, 1952; the other of said members shall serve
from date of appointment until May 31, 1953. The successors to the foregoing
trustees shall serve for a period of two (2) years or until such time as their
successors are appointed and qualified. The fifth member shall be elected from
the beneficiaries by such beneficiaries. The members to be elected shall be
elected for a period from the date of election until May 31, 1953, and for two
(2) year terms thereafter. The elections shall be held biennially on the third
Monday in April and all appointments shall be made by the president on or
before May 30 of the year in which the appointment is to be made. (1951 Code 3-
31)
2-8-2: OFFICERS:
At the regularly scheduled July meeting, the board shall select from its
members a president, vice president, secretary and assistant secretary, to
serve for the period of one year and until their respective successors are
elected and qualified. (1951 Code 3-33)
2-8-3: MEETINGS:
The board herein provided for shall hold regular quarterly meetings on the
second Tuesday of July, October, January and April of each year and special
meetings upon the call of the president of said board. (1951 Code 3-33)
2-8-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
   A.   Generally: The board of trustees of the pension fund shall have and
exercise all powers and duties provided by law 1 .
   B.   Duties Of Vice President: The vice president of the board shall perform
the duties of the president during any vacancy in that office, or during such
time as the president is absent from the village, or for any other reason is
disqualified, or by reason of illness or other cause is unable to perform his
duties.
   C.   Duties Of Assistant Secretary: The assistant secretary shall act for
the secretary whenever necessary to discharge the functions of such office.
(1951 Code 3-34)

1 1. 40 ILCS 5/3-101 et seq.
CHAPTER 9
EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AGENCY

CHAPTER 10
ELECTRICAL COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-10-1: Commission Established, Membership, Appointment
2-10-2: Duties
2-10-1: COMMISSION ESTABLISHED, MEMBERSHIP, APPOINTMENT:
There is hereby established an Electrical Commission consisting of six (6)
members as follows: The Chief Electrical Inspector of the Village shall be a
member and ex officio chairman of the Commission; of the other five (5)
members, one shall be a registered professional engineer, one an electrical
contractor, one a journeyman electrician, one shall be the Chief of the Fire
Prevention Bureau of the Village, and one representative of an electricity
supply company. If there is no person residing in the Village who is qualified
under any one of these descriptions, the President of the Village may appoint
some other person to fill that position. All members of the Electrical
Commission shall be appointed by the President with the advice and consent of
the Trustees. (1951 Code 21-10-12, 21-10-13; Ord. 78-19-48)
2-10-2: DUTIES:
The Electrical Commission shall recommend safe and practical standards and
specifications for the installation, alteration and use of electrical
equipment, reasonable rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits
by the Electrical Inspection Department, and reasonable fees to be paid for the
inspection by the Inspection Department of all electrical equipment installed
or altered within the Village. All fees so adopted shall be paid into the
Village Treasury. (1951 Code 21-10-14)

CHAPTER 20
ARCHITECTURAL REVIEW AND PRESERVATION COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-20-1: Commission Created, Appointment, Membership
2-20-2: Terms Of Office; Vacancies
2-20-3: Meetings
2-20-4: Powers And Duties
2-20-5:    Nomination And Consideration Of Buildings, Districts, Landmarks And
Structures For Official Historic Designation
2-20-6:    Criteria For Official Historic Designation
2-20-7:    Effect Of Official Historic Designation
2-20-8:    Official Historic Designation
2-20-1: COMMISSION CREATED, APPOINTMENT, MEMBERSHIP:
There is hereby created and established a seven (7) member Architectural Review
and Preservation Commission, whereby the President shall appoint one (1) member
to the Commission and each Village Trustee shall appoint one (1) member from
their own district. Members of the Architectural Review & Preservation
Commission shall be residents of the Village and, as nearly as possible, shall
be representative of the following interested groups of the business community:
construction, finance and architecture and commercial businesses located within
the Village. If a vacancy exists following the failure and/or refusal by a
Village Trustee to appoint a member by October 1 of the calendar year, an
appointment shall be made by a recommendation from the President with approval
of the majority of the Village Board.
The President and Board of Trustees may compel attendance of any absent member
and may remove any such member from said Commission if said member misses three
(3) consecutive meetings. The removal shall be initiated by the President and
subject to the confirmation of such removal by the advice and consent of the
Village Board.
Each member of the Commission shall receive a sum of fifty dollars ($50.00) per
meeting for every meeting attended, or such prorated portion thereof as shall
represent the time served in a given calendar year. This remuneration is
intended to cover normal and necessary expenses of the member. Additional or
unusual expenses may be covered as budgeted upon receipt of proper evidence of
expenditure and approval by this Commission.
(Ords. 13-11-37, 19-16-62)
2-20-2: TERMS OF OFFICE; VACANCIES:
All appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1 of the
calendar year. Members of the Architectural Review and Preservation Commission
serve as of the effective date hereof and shall serve until the end of the term
to which appointed and until their successors are named and qualified.
Effective September 1, 2019 a full term shall be four (4) years, and terms
shall be staggered so that not more than three (3) expire each year. Such
staggered terms shall coincide with District 1, 3, and 5 appointees to expire
opposite years of District 2, 4, and 6 appointees. For purposes of this
Chapter, such appointments for District 2, 4, and 6 beginning on September 1,
2019, shall have initial term limit to end in calendar year 2021 so as to
initiate such staggered terms. Members shall serve until their successors are
named and qualified. Appointments to vacancies shall be for the duration of the
unexpired term. Members shall serve until their successors are named and
qualified. Appointments to vacancies shall be for the duration of the unexpired
term. (Ords. 08-01-02, 19-16-62)
2-20-3: MEETINGS:
   A.   Regular Meetings: Meetings shall be held at every month on the 2nd and
4th Thursday of said month, except for the 4th Thursday in December, and that
the Board may, by rule, provide for changing the date for seasonal reasons of
in the event there is no pending business.
   B.   Special meetings. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by
any three (3) members of the Board.
   C.   Open to the Public: All meetings of the Architectural Review and
Preservation Commission and its committees shall be open meetings as required
under the applicable statutes of the State of Illinois and codes of the
Village.
   D.   The commission, by its rules, may create a subcommittee structure to
enhance efficiency in consideration of commission business. No motion shall be
passed by the commission which could in any manner deprive the owner of, or
restrict the owner in, the use of any building, landmark or structure until
such owner shall first have had the opportunity to be heard at a public meeting
of the commission. Every final decision of the commission and every
recommendation it makes to the village board shall include written findings of
fact, and shall specify the reason or reasons for such decision or
recommendation. The secretary of the commission shall mail notice of any
decision of the commission to the applicant and any other person who has
requested notice of said decision within five (5) days of such decision. Four
(4) commissioners shall constitute a quorum for any regular or special meeting.
A meeting of the commission cannot be called to order without establishment of
a quorum. (Ords. 08-01-02, 19-16-62)
2-20-4: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Architectural Review and Preservation Commission shall perform the
following tasks and prepare a report to the Village Board of Trustees:
   A.   Survey existing commercial buildings and townhomes within the Village
as to exterior design and materials.
   B.   Make recommendations as to the design and materials for new
construction and remodeling of existing commercial buildings and townhomes in
the Village. As for townhomes, the committee shall specifically review and
recommend design and materials as well as exterior elevations.
   C.   Make recommendations as to methods of financing facade improvements for
existing commercial buildings.
   D.   In addition, the committee shall have the power to require Village
department heads and employees to appear before it and answer questions and
assist the committee in its recommendations.
      1.   To conduct an ongoing survey to identify historic buildings,
districts, landmarks and structures within the Village.
      2.   To investigate and make recommendations to the Village Board
concerning the adoption of ordinances designating buildings, districts,
landmarks and structures as historic.
      3.   To keep a register of all buildings, districts, landmarks and
structures that have received official historic designation, including all
information required as part of each designation.
      4.   To create an appropriate system of plaques for identification of
historic buildings, districts, landmarks and structures, and make
recommendations for the design and implementation of specific markings and
signage of streets and routes leading from one historic building, district,
landmark and/or structure to another.
      5.   To advise and assist owners of historic buildings, landmarks and
structures in regard to:
         a.   Identifying the State and Federal agencies through which historic
building, landmark and/or structure designation can be applied for and
obtained;
         b.   The preparation of applications for State or Federal historic
building, landmark and/or structure designation;
         c.   Seeking out grant funds that are available for individuals who
desire to restore historic buildings, landmarks and/or structures;
         d.   The preparation of application for said grant funds; and
         e.   The technical aspects of the preservation, renovation,
rehabilitation and restoration of historic buildings, landmarks and/or
structures.
      6.   To participate in the "certified local government" program of the
National Historic Preservation Act, as amended, and the Illinois Historic
Preservation Agency, and carry out any responsibilities delegated to the
Commission under that program.
      7.   To inform and educate the citizens of the Village concerning the
historic heritage of the Village by publishing appropriate maps, newsletters,
brochures and pamphlets, and by sponsoring programs and seminars.
      8.   To review and comment upon proposed planned unit development, zoning
amendment, special use and variation requests that are submitted to the Village
in regard to historic buildings, districts, landmarks and structures.
      9.   To administer, on behalf of the Village, any historic building,
landmark, or structure that the Village may have or accept as a gift, upon
direction and approval by the Village Board.
      10.   To accept and administer on behalf of the Village such gifts,
grants and money as may be appropriate for the purposes of this Chapter, upon
direction and approval by the Board of Trustees.
      11.   To call upon available Village staff members as well as other
experts for technical advice.
      12.   To testify before all boards, committees and commissions of the
Village, on any matter affecting any historic building, district, landmark, or
structure.
      13.   To confer recognition upon the owners of historic buildings,
landmarks and structures for their historic preservation efforts by means of
certificates, plaques, markers or awards.
      14.   To assist in the development, review or amendment of a historic
building, district, landmark and/or structure preservation component in the
Comprehensive Plan of the Village.
      15.   To periodically review the Zoning Ordinance of the Village (Title 4
of this Code) and to make recommendations to the Village Board concerning any
amendments appropriate for the protection and preservation of historic
buildings, districts, landmarks and structures.
      16.   To review and comment upon Village projects or activities affecting
historic buildings, districts, landmarks or structures.
      17.   To prepare a list of historic buildings, districts, landmarks and
structures within the Village that it feels would meet the requirements for
official historic designation.
To undertake any other action or activity necessary or appropriate to the
implementation of its powers and duties, or to implementation of the purposes
of this Chapter, as assigned from time to time by the Village Board. (Ords. 17-
15-55, 19-16-62)
2-20-5: NOMINATION AND CONSIDERA- TION OF BUILDINGS, DISTRICTS, LANDMARKS AND
STRUCTURES FOR OFFICIAL HISTORIC DESIG- NATION:
   A.   Initiation Of Nomination: Nomination of any building, district,
landmark or structure for consideration for official historic designation shall
be submitted to the Commission on a form prepared by the Commission, and may be
submitted by any of the following:
      1.   A member of the Commission;
      2.   A member of the Zoning and Planning Commission;
      3.   A member of the Village Board;
      4.   Any resident of the Village;
      5.   The owner(s) of record of the building, district, landmark or
structure in question.
   B.   Notification Of Nomination And Public Hearing:
      1.   Where the owner(s) of record of the building, district, landmark or
structure subject to the nomination is/are not the applicant(s), said owner(s)
of record shall be notified, by regular mail, of the nomination. In such event,
no public hearing shall he held in regard to said nomination without the prior
written consent of the owner(s) of record.
      2.   Where the owner(s) of record is/are the applicant(s) or has/have
consented to the nomination pursuant to subsection B1 above, the Commission
shall schedule a public hearing on the nomination within forty five (45) days
following receipt of the completed nomination form and the owner(s) of record's
consent. Notice of such public hearing shall be given by the Commission and the
petitioner at least fifteen (15) days prior thereto by the following methods:
         a.   By requiring that the petitioners post a notice of the public
hearing on the subject property(ies) in a position conspicuously visible and
readable from the street, on a sign of not less than twenty two inches (22") by
twenty eight inches (28"), setting forth the time, date and place of the public
hearing, including the common name and address for the building, landmark or
structure or the common boundaries of the District, which is the subject matter
of the public hearing.
         b.    By mailing a copy of the notice referenced in subsection B2a
above to every person, firm or corporation that has registered with the
Commission for purposes of receiving said notices.
         c.   By mailing a copy of the notice referenced in subsection B2a
above to the taxpayer of record for each lot, tract or parcel which abuts the
subject property or is separated from the subject property by only an alley or
street right of way.
All mailings required by this subsection B shall be by first class U.S. mail,
with the Village staff member or Commission member who performs any such
mailing executing an affidavit as to the mailing having been performed in
compliance herewith.
   C.   Hearing Procedures: The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with
the rules of the Commission. The Commission shall consider all testimony or
evidence relating to the designation criteria, as set forth in Section 6-16-
7 of this Chapter, from any person who makes written submission or appears at
the public hearing.
   D.   Recommendation By The Commission: Within thirty five (35) days
following the close of the public hearing, the Commission shall make a
determination upon the evidence as to whether the nominated building, district,
landmark or structure does or does not meet the criteria for official historic
designation. If the Commission determines that the nominated building,
district, landmark or structure does meet the criteria for official historic
designation, the Commission shall forward its recommendation to the Village
Board. Such a recommendation shall be approved by a roll call vote of the
Commission and shall be accompanied by a report to the Village Board setting
forth the Commission's findings of fact relative to the recommendation. Said
report shall be accompanied by a map showing the location of the nominated
building, landmark or structure, or the boundaries of the nominated district.
   E.   Notification To The Nominator And Owner(s) Of Record: Notice of the
recommendation of the Commission, including a copy of the report, shall be sent
by regular mail to the nominator(s), and the owner(s) of the record if other
than nominator(s), within five (5) days after the recommendation is approved by
the Commission. Said notification shall also set forth the Village Board
meeting at which said recommendation will be discussed.
   F.   Official Historic Designation By The Village Board:
      1.   The Village Board shall, within thirty (30) days after receiving the
recommendation and report of the Commission regarding the nominated building,
district, landmark or structure, either approve of official historic
designation for said building, district, landmark or structure by ordinance, or
reject designation by motion.
      2.   Failure of the Village Board to take action on the Commission's
recommendation within said thirty (30) day period shall be deemed to be a
rejection of the recommendation.
      3.   A certified copy of any ordinance adopted pursuant to subsection F1
above shall be sent by regular mail to the nominator(s), and to the owner(s) of
record if any other than the nominator(s). A copy of said ordinance shall also
be filed with the Zoning and Planning Commission and the Village Building
Department.
      4.   If the Village rejects the recommendation of the Commission, the
Commission may not reconsider the nominated building, district, landmark or
structure for official historic designation for a period of one year from the
date of the Village Board's rejection of the designation unless:
         a.   Significant new information concerning the previously nominated
building, district, landmark or structure, relating to the criteria for
official historic designation, is provided, and
         b.   The Commission votes by an affirmative vote of at least five (5)
Commissioners to reconsider the previously nominated building, district,
landmark or structure. (Ord. 19-16-62)
2-20-6: CRITERIA FOR OFFICIAL HISTORIC DESIGNATION:
Every nominated building, district, landmark or structure must exhibit one or
more of the following specified criteria to receive a recommendation from the
Commission for official historic designation:
   A.   Its location as a site of a significant historic event or activity
which may or may not have taken place within or involved the use of any
existing improvements on the property;
   B.   Its identification with a person or persons who significantly
contributed to the cultural, architectural or economic development of the
Village, State, midwest region or the United States;
   C.   Its exemplification of an architectural type, style or design
distinguished by innovation, rarity, uniqueness or overall quality or design,
materials or craftsmanship;
   D.   Its identification as the work of an architect, designer, engineer or
builder whose individual work is significant in the development of the Village,
State, midwest region or the United States;
   E.   Its exemplification of important planning and urban design techniques
distinguished by innovation, rarity, uniqueness or overall quality of design or
detail;
   F.   Its association with important cultural or social aspects or events in
the history of the Village, State, midwest region or the United States;
   G.   Its representation of a historic theme expressed through distinctive
buildings, landmarks or structures;
   H.   Its unique location or distinctive physical appearance or presence
representing an established and familiar visual feature of a neighborhood,
community or the Village; or
   I.   Its exemplification of a pattern of neighborhood development or
settlement significant to the traditions of the Village, whose components may
lack individual distinction. (Ord. 19-16-62)
2-20-7: EFFECT OF OFFICIAL HISTORIC DESIGNATION:
Once approved for official historic designation, no historic building, landmark
or structure, or building, landmark or structure within a historic district,
may be subjected to alteration or demolition without the prior approval of the
commission. (Ord. 19-16-62)
2-20-8: OFFICIAL HISTORIC DESIGNATION:
   A.   The following Historic Districts have received official historic
designation by the Village Board pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter 2:
none.
   B.   The following historic buildings, landmarks and/or structures have
received official historic designation by the Village Board pursuant to the
provisions of this Chapter 2: none. (Ord. 19-16-62)
CHAPTER 21
ARTS AND EVENTS COMMISSION
SECTION:
2-21-1: Definitions
2-21-2: Commission Created, Appointment, Membership
2-21-3: Terms Of Office
2-21-4: Officers
2-21-5: Removal Of Members, Vacancies
2-21-6: Powers And Duties
2-21-7: Public Arts Fund
2-21-8: Finances
2-21-1: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   The terms "arts" and "art" as used in this section include, but are not
limited to, creative writing, dance, film/video, music, theater, visual arts,
crafts, performing arts, spoken word, environmental arts, multimedia arts,
architectural arts, landscape architecture, and emerging media.
   B.   The term "event" and "events" as used in this section shall mean
community based temporary aggregation of people or attracts for a common
purpose, including but not limited to holidays, festivals, street fairs, arts
and craft shows, carnivals, circuses, rallies, public entertainment, or other
similar events or attractions. (Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-2: COMMISSION CREATED, APPOINTMENT, MEMBER- SHIP:
There is hereby created and established a fourteen (14) member Village of Oak
Lawn Arts and Events Commission, hereinafter referred to as the "commission",
whereby the President shall appoint two (2) members and each Village Trustee
shall appoint two (2) members from their own district. Members shall be chosen
from a diverse range of backgrounds, occupations, and artistic venues, with the
intention of reflecting the full diversity of the Oak Lawn arts community. If a
vacancy exists following the failure and/or refusal by a Village Trustee to
appoint a member by October 1 of the calendar year, an appointment shall be
made by a recommendation from the President with approval of the majority of
the Village Board.
The President and Board of Trustees may compel attendance of any absent member
and may remove any such member from said Commission if that member misses three
(3) consecutive meetings. The removal shall be initiated by the President and
subject to the confirmation of such removal by the advice and consent of the
Village Board.
Each member of the Commission shall receive a sum of one hundred dollars
($100.00) per meeting for every meeting attended, or such prorated portion
thereof as shall represent the time served in a given calendar year, with a
minimum annual remuneration of $500.00 per member if the member attends 70% or
more of all properly posted meetings. This remuneration is intended to cover
normal and necessary expenses of the member. Additional or unusual expenses may
be covered as budgeted upon receipt of proper evidence of expenditure and
approval by this Commission.
   A.   Regular Meetings: Meetings shall be held at every month on the 3rd
Wednesday of said Month, except for the months of December and January with a
maximum of ten (10) meetings a year, except that the Commission may, by rule,
provide for changing the date for seasonal reasons of in the event there is no
pending business.
   B.   Special Meetings: Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by
any three (3) members of the Commission.
   C.   Open To The Public: All meetings of the Arts and Events Commission and
its committees shall be open meetings as required under the applicable statutes
of the State of Illinois and codes of the Village. (Ords. 16-07-16, 19-16-60,
23-13-47)
2-21-3: TERMS OF OFFICE:
All appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1 of the
calendar year. Members of the Arts and Events Commission serving as of the
effective date hereof shall serve until the end of the term to which appointed
and until their successors are named and qualified. Effective September 1,
2019, a full term shall be four (4) years and terms shall be staggered so not
more than eight (8) expire each year. Such staggered terms shall coincide with
District 1, 3, and 5 appointees to expire opposite years of District 2, 4, and
6 appointees. For purposes of this Chapter, such appointments for District 2,
4, and 6 beginning on September 1, 2019, shall have initial term limit to end
in calendar year 2021 so as to initiate such staggered terms.
(Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-4: OFFICERS:
A chairperson and vice chairperson shall be elected annually, at the regular
meeting of the commission closest to September 1 of the calendar year, by and
from the membership, to serve a one year term not to exceed two (2) consecutive
terms. (Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-5: REMOVAL OF MEMBERS, VACANCIES:
Any member of the commission may be removed by the president of the village for
good cause with the approval of a majority of the board of trustees. Any member
of the commission who misses three (3) consecutive regular meetings without
notification shall be subject to removal from said commission. A written
notification from the president of the village will be given the member on
occasion of his removal. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term in
the same manner as the original appointment. The commission may recommend to
the president and board of trustees the removal of one of its members. (Ords.
14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-6: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The commission shall adopt its rules of procedure for whatever regular and
special meetings are deemed by the commission to be advisable and necessary to
the fulfillment of the duties of the commission. Nothing in this chapter shall
be construed as vesting legislative or budgetary discretion or power in the
commission.
The duties and responsibilities of the commission may include, but not be
limited to, the following:
   A.   To explore and recommend to the village president, board of trustees,
village staff, and other groups ways to further the development of, and
interest in the arts, strengthen Oak Lawn's cultural awareness, ways to expand
opportunities for artistic expressions, and offer advice on relevant village
projects.
   B.   To propose to the president and board of trustees an annual public arts
program plan that identifies specific program goals of the year, means of
achievement, proposed expenditures, sources of supplemental revenue, schedule
of execution, necessary resources and responsibilities, and implementation of a
plan to address stated goals.
   C.   To recommend to the president and board of trustees policies regarding
the selection of proposed public arts projects such as the involvement of
artists in selected building projects, criteria for artist and site selection
and other policies relevant to the public arts program. Such policies should
reflect the following three (3) priorities:
      1.   Community accessibility to the arts;
      2.   Artist accessibility to resources; and
      3.   Opportunities for collaboration and partnerships.
   D.   To review relevant proposals and assist in the process by which
artists, arts organizations, community organizations, businesses, developers,
merchant associations, charitable foundations, or any other member of the
general public proposes and creates projects in the arts which are located in
public places owned and maintained by the village of Oak Lawn.
   E.   To approve proposals that are not permanently placed on municipal
property.
   F.   To research and seek additional funding including donations, grants,
and other support to further expand public arts programs.
   G.   To encourage public participation in local artistic and cultural events
and programs.
   H.   To cooperate with other public and private entities regarding the arts.
   I.   To increase artistic recognition through exhibitions and/or
competitions.
   J.   To provide leadership and a voice for the arts in Oak Lawn and to
advocate for the arts in both public and private endeavors.
   K.   To offer educational programming to the public regarding the arts and
to coordinate events and outreach related to the arts.
   L.   The powers and duties of the Arts and Events Commission shall be to
determine when and where events and parades are to be held in the village, the
type of special event or parade, those who shall participate therein, to set
out where the special events are to be held or the parade routes, and to
provide crowd and traffic control in consultation with the village police
department. (Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-7: PUBLIC ARTS FUND:
A public arts fund is hereby created to serve as an account through which funds
from the village, outside grant monies, private and corporate donations for the
arts, and other revenue sources can be received, collected, and distributed.
(Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
2-21-8: FINANCES:
The commission may receive from the village an annual appropriation to be
provided by the president and board of trustees. The commission shall be
empowered to apply for, receive, and obtain monies, funds and grants from
public and private resources upon approval of the board of trustees. The
president and board of trustees must approve all expenditures recommended by
the commission, and shall submit reports as may be designated by the village
manager. (Ords. 14-28-66, 19-16-60)
CHAPTER 22
LIQUOR AND TOBACCO LICENSING REVIEW BOARD
SECTION:
2-22-1: Established; Composition
2-22-2: Compensation, Meetings
2-22-3: Powers And Duties
2-22-1: ESTABLISHED; COMPOSITION:
There is hereby established a Liquor and Tobacco Licensing Review Board which
shall consist of seven (7) persons who are appointed by, and serve at the sole
discretion of, the Village President. (Ords. 15-17-66, 19-16-63, 21-08-41)
2-22-2: COMPENSATION, MEETINGS:
All appointments, except to vacancies, shall begin on September 1 of the
calendar year. Members of the Liquor and Tobacco Licensing Review Board serve
as of the effective date hereof shall serve until the end of the term to which
appointed and until their successors are named and qualified. Effective
September 1, 2019 a full term shall be four (4) years, and terms shall be
staggered so that not more than three (3) expire each year. Such staggered
terms shall coincide with District 1, 3, and 5 appointees to expire opposite
years of District 2, 4, and 6 appointees. For purposes of this Chapter, such
appointments for District 2, 4, and 6 beginning on September 1, 2019, shall
have initial term limit to end in calendar year 2021 so as to initiate such
staggered terms. Members shall serve until their successors are named and
qualified. If a vacancy exists following the failure and/or refusal by a
Village Trustee to appoint a member by October 1 of the calendar year, an
appointment shall be made by a recommendation from the President with approval
of the majority of the Village Board.
The President and Board of Trustees may compel attendance of any absent member
and may remove any such member from said Commission if that member misses three
(3) consecutive meetings. The removal shall be initiated by the President and
subject to the confirmation of such removal by the advice and consent of the
Village Board.
Each member shall receive a sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per meeting
for every properly posted meeting attended, or such prorated portion thereof as
shall represent the time served in a given calendar year, with a minimum annual
remuneration of $500.00 per member if the member attends 70% or more of all
properly posted meetings. This remuneration is intended to cover normal and
necessary expenses of the member. Additional or unusual expenses may be covered
as budgeted upon receipt of proper evidence of expenditure and approval by this
Commission.
   A.   Regular Meetings: Meetings shall be held at every-other month on the
4th Tuesday of said Month, except that the Board may, by rule, provide for
changing the date for seasonal reasons of in the event there is no pending
business.
   B.   Special meetings. Special meetings may be called by the chairman or by
any three (3) members of the Board.
   C.   Open to the Public: All meetings of the Liquor and Tobacco Licensing
Review Board and its committees shall be open meetings as required under the
applicable statutes of the State of Illinois and codes of the Village. (Ords.
15-17-66, 19-16-63, 21-08-41, 21-11-54, 23-13-47)
2-22-3: POWERS AND DUTIES:
The Liquor and Tobacco Licensing Review Board shall perform such functions and
duties as directed or requested by the liquor and tobacco commissioner in
relation to the regulation of licensed activities, including, but not limited
to, the following:
   A.   Review applications and the investigation of applicants for liquor
licenses, and to submit findings and recommendations to the liquor commissioner
setting forth its conclusions respecting such applications.
   B.   Review applications and the investigation of applicants for tobacco
retail licenses, as defined under Title 3, Chapter 15, Section 1, and to submit
findings and recommendations to the commissioner setting forth its conclusions
respecting such applications.
   C.   Conduct disciplinary hearings and submit findings and recommendations
to the commissioner setting forth its conclusions respecting the existence and
nature of any violation of the Oak Lawn liquor code and the appropriate
disciplinary action to be taken, if any.
   D.   Review and recommend changes of the Oak Lawn liquor code to the
president and board of trustees. (Ords. 15-17-66, 19-16-63, 21-08-41)
TITLE 3
BUSINESS AND LICENSE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS FOR BUSINESSES, CERTIFICATES, LICENSES AND PERMITS
SECTION:
3-1-1: Business Regulation Certificates
3-1-1-1: Purpose And Jurisdiction
