3-4-1: APPLICABILITY OF PROVISIONS:
The provisions of this chapter, except as otherwise provided, shall apply to
all amusements as hereinafter defined, whether specifically licensed or
regulated under other provisions of this code or other ordinances, or not.
(1951 Code 9-1-1; Ords. 77-15-19, 19-25-87)
3-4-2: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   The word "amusement" means:
      1.   Any theatrical, dramatic, musical or spectacular performance, motion
picture show, flower, poultry or animal show, animal act, circus, rodeo,
athletic contest, sport, game or similar exhibition for public entertainment,
including, without being limited to, boxing, wrestling, skating, dancing,
swimming, racing, or riding on animals or vehicles, baseball, basketball,
softball, football, tennis, golf, hockey, track and field games, bowling,
billiard and pool games.
      2.   Any entertainment offered for public participation, including,
without being limited to, dancing, carnival, amusement park rides and games,
bowling, billiard and pool games, or video gaming terminal.
   B.   “Person”: Any natural individual that participates in an amusement,
including a firm, organization, society, foundation, institution, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint venture, limited liability company,
public or private corporation, receiver, executor, trustee or other
representative appointed by order of any court, or any other entity recognized
by law.
   C.   “Play”: Each individual push of the video gaming terminal which
initiates the simulation provided by the video gaming terminal. Play shall not
include the push of individual wager amounts, selection of types of games on
the video gaming terminal or entry of any information or printing of winning
receipts.
   D.   “Terminal Operator”: Any individual, partnership, corporation, or
limited liability company that is licensed under the Video Gaming Act, 230 ILCS
40/1 et seq., and that owns, services, and maintains video gaming terminals for
placement in licensed establishments, licensed truck stop establishments,
licensed large truck stop establishments, licensed fraternal establishments, or
licensed veterans establishments.
   E.   “Video Gaming Terminal”: Any electronic video game machine that, upon
insertion of cash, electronic cards or vouchers, or any combination thereof, is
available to play or simulate the play of a video game, including but not
limited to video poker, line up, and blackjack, as authorized by the Illinois
Gaming Board utilizing a video display and microprocessors in which the player
may receive free games or credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does
not include a machine that directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens or is for
amusement purposes only. (1951 Code 9-1-1; Ords. 77-15-19, 19-25-87)
3-4-3: AMUSEMENT TAX IMPOSED:
3-4-3.1: PUSH TAX:
Except as otherwise provided by this Chapter, an amusement tax is imposed upon
any person who participates in the play of a video gaming terminal that takes
place within the jurisdictional boundaries of the Village of Oak Lawn. The rate
of the tax shall be equal to one cent ($0.01) per play on a video gaming
terminal.
The terminal operator of a video gaming terminal may separately itemize and
charge each person who plays a video gaming terminal. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.2: TAX ADDITIONAL:
The tax imposed in this Chapter is in addition to all other taxes imposed by
the State of Illinois or any municipal corporation or political subdivision
thereof. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.3 REGISTRATION:
Every terminal operator of a video gaming terminal(s) located in the Village of
Oak Lawn shall apply for registration as a tax collector with the Village no
later than thirty (30) days after commencing such business or thirty (30) days
after the effective date of this ordinance imposing the push tax, whichever
occurs later. The application shall be submitted to the Village on the forms
provided by the Village and contain such information as reasonably required by
the Village to impose, collect, and audit all amounts related to the push tax.
(Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.4: COLLECTION, PAYMENT, AND ACCOUNTING:
It shall be the joint and several duty of every terminal operator of a video
gaming terminal(s) to secure from each person participating in the play of a
video gaming terminal the push tax imposed by this Chapter. For purposes of
this Chapter, it shall be presumed that the amount of the push tax imposed on
each person, unless the taxpayer or tax collector provides otherwise with
books, records, or other documentary evidence, has been collected from the
person by the terminal operator. Push tax payments accompanied by tax returns
prescribed by the Village shall be remitted to the Village on or before the
20th day of the month following the month in which payment for the push tax is
made.
Every terminal operator of a video gaming terminal who is required to collect
the push tax by this Chapter shall be considered a tax collector for the
Village. All push tax amounts collected shall be held by the terminal operator
as trustee for and on behalf of the Village. The failure of the operator to
collect the tax shall not excuse or release the person from the obligation to
pay the tax. The ultimate incidence of the push tax shall remain on the person
and shall never be shifted to the terminal operator.
Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter, in order to permit sound
fiscal planning and budgeting by the Village, no person shall be entitled to a
refund of, or credit for, the push tax imposed by this Chapter unless the
person files a claim for a refund or credit within one (1) year after the date
on which the push tax was paid or remitted to the Village.
The terminal operator of any video gaming terminal(s) shall be subject to
audit, inspection, and record keeping provisions of this Code. It shall be
unlawful for any terminal operator and/or person to prevent, hinder, or
interfere with the Village's officials, employees, and/or agents designated to
discharge their respective duties in the performance and enforcement of the
provisions of this Chapter. It is the duty of every terminal operator of a
video gaming terminal(s) to keep accurate and complete books and records to
which the Village's officials, employees, and/or agents will at all times have
full access. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.5: RULES AND REGULATIONS; AUTHORIZED:
The Village is authorized to adopt, promulgate, and enforce any additional
rules and regulations pertaining to the interpretation, collection,
administration, and enforcement of this Chapter. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.6: APPLICATION OF VILLAGE CODE:
Any citation under this Chapter may be in addition to any other citations
issued by the Village under any and all applicable sections of the Village
Code. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.7: VIOLATIONS; PENALTIES:
It shall be a violation of this Chapter for a terminal operator to fail to file
a report within the time prescribed in this Chapter.
A terminal operator who falsely reports or fails to report the amount of push
tax due required by this Chapter shall be in violation of Chapter and is
subject to suspension and/or revocation of their terminal operator license. All
payments not remitted when due shall be paid together with a penalty assessment
on the unpaid balance at a rate of 1.5% per month.
Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The Village President/Local Liquor
Commissioner or his or her designee shall have the power to suspend for not
more than thirty (30) days or revoke any video gaming license issued under the
provisions of this chapter for cause, or if he/she determines that a terminal
operator shall have violated any of the provisions of this Chapter, any of the
statutes of the State or any other valid ordinance or resolution enacted by the
President and Board of Trustees of the Village. However, no such license shall
be revoked or suspended except after the holding of a public hearing by the
Village President/Local Liquor Commissioner or his or her designee. Ten (10)
days' notice of the hearing shall be given to the terminal operator.
Alternatively, terminal operator shall have the opportunity to engage in a
prehearing conference and agree to negotiated penalties rather than proceed to
a hearing.
Fine Imposed: In addition, any terminal operator violating the provisions of
this Chapter shall be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
the first offense, and seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for the second
offense, and one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for a third offense and subject a
revocation of any license to operate a video gaming terminal for the third
offense. It shall be deemed a violation of this Chapter for any owner to
knowingly furnish false or inaccurate information to the Village. Each day a
violation continues shall constitute a separate violation. It shall be deemed a
violation of this Chapter for any person to knowingly furnish false or
inaccurate information to the Village. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-3.8: SEIZURE FOR UNLAWFUL USE: 
If the Village determines that the Village shall have a reasonable basis for
believing any owner is using a video gaming terminal in an illegal manner
contrary to the provisions of this Chapter or any other federal, state, or
municipal law and/or regulation, said video gaming terminal may be seized by
the Village, followed by an administrative hearing with notice to the owner
within seven (7) days of seizure to determine the appropriateness of the
seizure, and held until such time as the owner of such video gaming terminal
pays any delinquent push tax amount, reimburses the Village for actual cartage
costs incurred in the seizure and pays the Village twenty dollars ($20.00) for
each day the video gaming terminal has been in storage. (Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-4: INSPECTIONS:
It shall be the duty of the chief of police and the fire chief to see that
every exhibition, amusement, theatrical or other public show is inspected by a
member of the police and fire departments, and to ensure conformity with the
provisions concerning such amusements. (1951 Code 9-1-7; Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-5: STREET SHOWS:
No license shall be granted for any carnival, circus, exhibition show or other
amusement to be given on any public street or sidewalk or in such a place that
the only main accommodation for the public or audience will be in a public
place, except on order of the village board. (1951 Code 9-1-3; Ord. 19-25-87)
3-4-6: PREMISES REQUIREMENTS, EXIT SIGNS:
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant in charge of any building or hall
used as an assembly hall with accommodations for one hundred (100) persons or
more in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures and other entertainments
are offered, operated or presented to provide and place a sign, on which the
word "Exit" shall appear in letters of at least six inches (6") high, over
every door or other opening from such hall to every means of egress therefrom,
and a light shall be provided with a red globe and placed at or over such sign,
which light shall be kept burning during the entire period the hall is open to
the public and until the audience has left the hall. (1951 Code 9-1-13; Ord.
19-25-87)
3-4-7: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Order, Crowding:
      1.   The audience of any amusement, show or theatrical must be orderly
and quiet at all times, and it shall be unlawful for any person attending such
amusement, show or theatrical to create a disturbance in the audience.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to permit or gather such a crowd to witness any
amusement or show as to create a dangerous condition because of fire or other
risks.
   B.   Indecent Shows: It shall be unlawful to present, exhibit, conduct or
take part in any indecent show, theatrical, play, motion picture exhibition or
other form of public amusement or show.
   C.   Exhibition Of Criminals: It shall be unlawful to exhibit any criminal
or the body of any criminal or any person who shall have become notorious
because of the commission of a crime, in any theatrical, exhibit, carnival or
other public place.
   D.   Riots: It shall be unlawful to present any public amusement or show of
any kind which tends to or is calculated to cause or promote any riot or
disturbance.
   E.   Smoking 1 : It shall be unlawful to smoke or carry a lighted cigar,
cigarette or pipe on or beneath the stage or in a dressing room of any building
used as an assembly hall with seating accommodations for more than one hundred
(100) persons or in which theatricals, shows, amusements, lectures or other
entertainments are offered, operated, presented or exhibited. (1951 Code 9-1-6,
9-1-8, 9-1-9, 9-1-10, 9-1-11, 9-1-12; Ord. 19-25-87)
 
Notes
1 1. See also Title 8, Chapter 12 of this code.
ARTICLE A. AMUSEMENT DEVICES
SECTION:
3-4A-1: Mechanical Amusement Devices
3-4A-1-1: Permit Required
3-4A-1-2: Application For Permit, Issuance
3-4A-1-3: Deposit Required For Temporary Permit
3-4A-1-4: Liability Insurance
3-4A-1-5: Term Of Permit
3-4A-1-6: Construction Requirements And Safety Equipment
3-4A-1-7: Inspections
3-4A-1-8: Compliance With Provisions
3-4A-1-9: Penalties
3-4A-2: Automatic Amusement Devices
3-4A-2-1: Definition
3-4A-2-2: Licenses Required
3-4A-2-3: Applications For Licenses
3-4A-2-4: Restrictions On Licenses
3-4A-2-5: License Fees
3-4A-2-6: Investigation Of Applicant, Fee
3-4A-2-7: Payment Of Fees, Emblem Required
3-4A-2-8: Class A And B Licenses
3-4A-2-9: Gambling Devices
3-4A-2-10: Revocation Of License
3-4A-2-11: Penalties
3-4A-1: MECHANICAL AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
3-4A-1-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, erect or install any
mechanical amusement device, roller coaster, scenic railway, water chute,
parachute, rolling device or any other mechanical riding, sailing, sliding or
swinging device in either an existing or a new amusement park, or places or
sites, where such devices are installed, erected or constructed under carnival,
fair or similar auspices, without first obtaining a permit therefor. (Ords. 71-
20-56, 74-15-30, 74-19-39)
3-4A-1-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT, ISSUANCE:
Application for a permit shall be submitted to the director of office of
quality control of the village at least thirty (30) days prior to such
construction, erection, or installation of any mechanical amusement device. The
applicant shall be required to have the Illinois department of labor, carnival
and amusement ride inspection division, inspect all mechanical amusement
devices to be used by the applicant, and shall submit proof, that the Illinois
department of labor, carnival and amusement ride inspection division, has been
requested to make said inspection, within ten (10) days after making
application with the department of quality control. Upon receiving an
application for a permit, the department of quality control shall inform the
applicant of the necessity of immediately contacting the Illinois department of
labor, carnival and amusement ride inspection division, in regard to obtaining
the required inspections of the mechanical amusement devices. In the event that
the applicant does not submit proof of notification of the Illinois department
of labor, carnival and amusement ride inspection division, of the need for an
inspection, within ten (10) days of making application with the department of
quality control, the department of quality control shall give the applicant a
second and final notice, in writing, of the need for an inspection, and of the
potential for requiring the closing down of the mechanical amusement devices in
the event the proper inspections are not obtained. All costs associated with
said inspection shall be the responsibility of the applicant. A copy of the
inspection report shall be filed with the department of quality control.
Permits issued by the department of quality control shall be valid only as to
those mechanical amusement devices which have been inspected by, and have
passed the inspection of, the Illinois department of labor, carnival and
amusement ride inspection division. (Ords. 87-14-55, 87-19-77)
3-4A-1-3: DEPOSIT REQUIRED FOR TEMPORARY PERMIT:
At the time of application for a temporary permit, the applicant shall pay to
the Village as a deposit, an amount equal to one hundred dollars ($100.00) for
each day the aforesaid devices shall be operated. The deposit required shall be
in addition to any fees required under Section
3-1-1-7 of this Title. The following expenses incurred by the Village, as
ultimately determined by the Director of Office of Quality Control, shall be
deducted from the deposit and the balance returned to the applicant within
three (3) days following the removal of the devices:
   A.   Inspection fees, original and daily, as determined by the Director of
Office of Quality Control.
   B.   Special police services, including calls for disturbances created by
patrons as determined by the Chief of Police.
   C.   Cleanup and restoration of premises, as determined by the Public Works
Director. (Ords. 71-20-46, 74-15-30, 74-19-39, 81-12-19)
3-4A-1-4: LIABILITY INSURANCE:
Every permit application for a mechanical amusement riding device shall be
accompanied by a certificate of liability insurance, which will name the
Village and its officers, agents and employees as additional insured, in an
amount not less than one million dollars ($1,000,000.00) for any one person and
two million dollars ($2,000,000.00) for any one accident. The insurance company
is to be approved by the Department of Administrative Services of the Village
and shall be with a company licensed to do business in the State. (Ord. 71-20-
46; 1985 Code)
3-4A-1-5: TERM OF PERMIT:
Every permit issued for a ride or mechanical riding device where same is for a
temporary nature, shall be for a period not to exceed fourteen (14) days.
Permits for permanent installations shall be for a term of one year. (Ord. 71-
20-46)
3-4A-1-6: CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS AND SAFETY EQUIPMENT:
All mechanical amusement riding devices shall be constructed in the manner
hereinafter set forth, and shall be so constructed and designed to withstand
shocks and to afford adequate protection for persons riding thereon. Protective
devices as handrails, handles, safety grips or straps, of suitable design shall
be provided.
   A.   Merry-go-round horses shall be equipped with a bridle and stirrups and
a strap on the horse rod to snap or buckle under the arms of the rider.
   B.   Except for portable-type Ferris wheels, same shall be constructed with
steel frames and tripods supported upon and anchored on concrete piers.
Portable-type Ferris wheels shall be constructed of steel and set on suitable
bases under the towers and the side tripods.
   C.   On all other mechanical amusement riding devices, automatic handlebars
shall be installed where vertical thrust is encountered and catwalks shall be
provided for emergency and maintenance purposes.
   D.   All rides shall be guyed, suitable to withstand wind pressure and
unbalanced load. Footings, blockings and outriggers shall be secured so as to
be stable under all operating conditions.
   E.   No amusement riding device shall be overcrowded or loaded in excess of
its rated safe carrying capacity or safe operating speed.
   F.   All internal combustion engines used in driving riding devices shall be
equipped with an overspeed governor.
   G.   All riding devices shall be fenced, enclosed, barricaded or otherwise
guarded for public protection.
   H.   Every roller coaster-type mechanical riding device shall be equipped
with a terminal brake; there also shall be provided an emergency brake that
will immediately stop the device, and same shall be located for each access.
The emergency brake shall be under the control at all times of the attendant at
the loading platform. In addition thereto there shall be provided a safety
device for each roller coaster-type ride to catch or hold the ride should the
propelling chain break, or any other break or accident that might occur while
the ride is in motion. Anti- rollback devices shall be installed on all
inclined tracks, slides or guides.
   I.   No person shall knowingly use or permit to be used an amusement riding
device which is not properly assembled or which is defective or unsafe in any
of its parts, components, controls or safety equipment. In no case shall a
safety device installed on any amusement riding device be made inoperative.
(Ord. 71-20-46)
3-4A-1-7: INSPECTIONS:
After the erection of the rides and mechanical riding devices, a physical
inspection shall be made of same by the Illinois Department of Labor, Carnival
and Amusement Ride Inspection Division, to ensure conformity with the
provisions of this Section and all other ordinances and statutes relating
hereto. Said inspection shall be made prior to the opening of said rides and
mechanical riding devices to the public.
Where such rides and mechanical riding devices are of a permanent installation,
said inspection shall be made annually prior to the opening of such devices to
the public. (Ord. 87-14-55)
3-4A-1-8: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
No device shall be operated unless compliance is had with the provisions of
this Code and the rules and regulations set forth herein. (Ords. 74-20-46, 74-
15-30, 74-19-39)
3-4A-1-9: PENALTIES:
Any person violating, resisting or opposing the enforcement of this Section
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day such violation shall
continue shall be and constitute a separate offense. (Ords. 71-20-46, 99-5-11)
3-4A-2: AUTOMATIC AMUSEMENT DEVICES:
3-4A-2-1: DEFINITION:
The term "automatic amusement device" shall mean any machine which upon the
insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, may be operated by the public
generally for use as a game, entertainment or amusement, whether or not
registering a score. It shall include, but not be limited to, such devices as
jukeboxes, marble machines, pinball machines, movie and video booths or stands,
games played with any number of balls, spheres or electrically operated devices
upon a table or board having holes, pockets, cups or electrically activated
devices that are actuated by said balls, or spheres or electrical contacts,
electrical impulse and/or cathode tube games, and all games, operations or
transactions similar thereto under whatever name by which they may be
indicated. Said term shall not include a pool or billiard table licensed
pursuant to article B of this chapter. (Ords. 66-24-72, 77-15-18)
3-4A-2-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   A.   Automatic Amusement Device: Any person displaying for public patronage
or keeping for operation, any "automatic amusement device" as herein defined
shall be required to obtain a license from the director of administrative
services upon payment of a license fee 1 .
   B.   Operator's Business: No one shall engage in the "automatic amusement
device operator's business" which is herein defined to mean the conduct or
transaction of the business of distributing, placing, leasing or selling
automatic amusements with an agreement to maintain, service or supply, without
first obtaining a license therefor. (Ord. 77-15-18; 1985 Code)
 
Notes
  1. See section
1 3-1-1-7 of this title and section
  3-4A-2-5 of this article.
3-4A-2-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the director of administrative
services upon a form to be supplied by the village for that purpose and shall
contain the following information:
   A.   Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth;
   B.   Name of manufacturer of the device(s) to be licensed;
   C.   Prior convictions, if any, of applicant;
   D.   Place where machine or device is to be displayed or operated, and the
business conducted at that place;
   E.   Description of machine or device to be covered by the license,
mechanical features and serial number;
   F.   A statement under oath that:
      1.   The machine or device is not a gambling device;
      2.   No more than ten (10) free games can be obtained by any one player;
      3.   The machine or device is not equipped with a "knock off" switch or
other similar mechanism which would cancel free games.
All applications for automatic amusement device licenses must also contain the
applicable information provided for in section
3-3-4 of this title. (Ords. 77-15-18, 82-9-33; 1985 Code)
3-4A-2-4: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSES:
   A.   All applicants for such licenses shall be ineligible for a license
hereunder for the same applicable reasons as those set forth in section
3-3-5 of this title.
   B.   No license shall be issued to any applicant unless he shall be over
twenty one (21) years of age and a citizen of the United States. (Ords. 77-15-
18, 82-9-33)
3-4A-2-5: LICENSE FEES:
Every applicant, before being granted a license, shall pay the annual license
fee set forth in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Code for each license year, which fee shall not be prorated.
Ords. 77-15-18, 81-36-79, 84-6-13, 1985 Code, Ord. 03-20-81, 23-12-42)
3-4A-2-6: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT, FEE:
   A.   Investigation Of Applicant: The original application for a license
shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation and verification of
the facts stated therein and he shall ascertain if the applicant is a person of
good moral character, and either approve or disapprove the application. No
license shall be issued to any applicant unless approved by the chief of
police.
   B.   Fee: Before any action is taken upon any application as provided in
section
3-4A-2-3 of this article, applicant shall pay to the village the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00), no part of which shall be refundable, to cover the
village's costs in reviewing and investigating such applicant. Provided,
however, that in the event the application is approved by the board of trustees
and the applicant applies for the license and pays the initial license fee
within the time provided, said two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be credited
toward the initial license fee.
   C.   Examination Of Records: In conformity with this section
3-4A-2, the department of administrative services, with reasonable prior
written notice, shall have the authority to examine all books and records of
automatic amusement device operators to ensure compliance with this section.
(Ords. 77-15-18, 81-36-79; 1985 Code)
3-4A-2-7: PAYMENT OF FEES, EMBLEM REQUIRED:
All fees shall be paid to the director of administrative services who shall
issue, as evidence of the payment thereof as to each device a self-voiding
adhesive emblem to be placed on each device. Such emblem shall bear the words
"Village of Oak Lawn" and the date it shall become void. It shall be unlawful
for any person to mutilate said emblem during the year for which it is issued.
Each such emblem shall be issued only for a particular machine and may not be
transferred or used in any way whatsoever as the required emblem of any other
machine whether or not such other machine is a new or replacement machine for
the original machine. Each and every machine must have such an emblem issued
for its particular use after the payment of the required fee. If an automatic
amusement machine is replaced with a similar machine, a new emblem will be
issued upon notification in writing to the director of administrative services.
(Ords. 81-36-79, 84-6-13; 1985 Code)
3-4A-2-8: CLASS A AND B LICENSES:
   A.   Class A License: A public place of amusement arcade as defined herein.
      1.   Number Of Licenses: The number of class A amusement arcade licenses
authorized to be issued shall be as amended from time to time by ordinance
adopted by the president and board of trustees and on record in the office of
the village clerk; provided, however, that any license in said class which is
revoked or not issued shall automatically reduce the number of authorized
licenses of the class by the total number of revoked or nonissued licenses in
said class. In addition, the business regulation officer shall notify, in
writing, the village clerk and the board of trustees of any revocation or
nonissuance of any authorized licenses within ten (10) days of such occurrence.
      2.   License Required: It is unlawful for any person to install, use or
permit the installation or use of ten (10) or more automatic amusement device
machines at any place, unless the person in control of such place has the
premises licensed as a "public place of amusement arcade". The term "arcade"
means a place of amusement that includes ten (10) or more automatic amusement
devices.
      3.   Application For License: The applicant for a license under the
provisions of this section must apply for the appropriate license and pay the
initial license fee for such license within fourteen (14) days of the adoption
of the ordinance creating or board approval authorizing the appropriate license
and directing its issuance to the applicant. In the event any applicant fails
to apply for a license and pay the initial license fee within said fourteen
(14) day period, such license shall be revoked and the number of authorized
licenses of the class A involved is automatically reduced by one.
      4.   License Fee: Ten (10) or more automatic amusement devices may be
placed in a single location only if the location has been licensed as a public
place of amusement arcade and the appropriate fee, as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title, has been paid. While coin operated kiddie rides are
assessed the amusement device fee, they are not counted in determining the need
for the arcade license. These fees shall not be prorated.
      5.   Location Of Premises:
         a.   No such amusement arcade licensed under this code shall be
situated or located within one-half (1/2) statute mile in any direction of any
public or private school.
         b.   No class A license shall be issued unless the premises to be
licensed is located in a C-3 regional shopping center zoning classification
under the village's zoning title 1  and not more than one class A license shall
be issued for each such regional shopping center. Provided, however, that where
a class A license has been issued for a premises not located in a C-3 regional
shopping center in accordance with this code prior to the effective date
hereof, such class A license shall continue to be valid and remain in full
force and effect. In the event any such present class A license for a premises
located outside of a C-3 regional shopping center is ever revoked, not
reissued, or the original licensee shall cease operating the business for any
reason whatsoever, the number of class A licenses shall automatically be
reduced accordingly and no new class A license may be issued for any such
location.
      6.   Closing Hours: It shall be unlawful to keep open for business or to
admit the public to any such amusement arcade between the hours of twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight and nine o'clock (9:00) A.M.
      7.   Location Of Devices, Restrictions: All amusement devices in arcades
shall be kept in a separate area segregated, separate and apart from the area
where food and drink are served. No service or consumption of alcoholic
beverages shall be permitted within the segregated area where such devices are
located.
   B.   Class B License: Each business location or place with nine (9) or less
amusement device machines on the premises.
      1.   Number Of Licenses: There shall be no limit on the number of class B
licenses issued.
      2.   Application For License: Applications for class B licenses shall be
made to the business regulation officer on forms to be supplied by said
officer. The business regulation officer shall forward all such applications to
the police chief for investigation. The police chief, within seven (7) working
days after receipt of any such application, shall forward his written
recommendation, together with a copy of the application, to the board of
trustees who shall approve or reject applications for class B licenses at its
next regular board meeting occurring at least seven (7) days after receipt of
the police chief's written recommendation. No class B licenses shall be issued
by the business regulation officer without prior approval of the board of
trustees.
      3.   Number Of Devices: Any premises may have up to, and including, nine
(9) automatic amusement devices; provided, that the annual amusement license
fee, as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title, has been paid for each device and an emblem evidencing
payment of the license fee is affixed to the automatic amusement device at a
conspicuous location. (Ords. 77-15-18, 79-23-38, 80-5-15, 81-7-12, 81-9-17, 81-
14-23, 81-15-25, 81-21-39, 81-28-57, 81-31-59, 81-33-64, 81-35-69, 81-36-79,
81-36-80, 82-9-33, 82-11-43, 82-12-48, 82-16-54, 82-16-55, 82-19-66, 82-22-77,
82-24-92, 83-8-10, 83-16-40; 1985 Code; Ords. 96-3-10, 97-11-53, 01-06-21, 03-
20-81)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 4 of this code.
3-4A-2-9: GAMBLING DEVICES:
Nothing in this section shall in any way be construed to authorize, license or
permit any gambling devices whatsoever, including, but not limited to,
mechanical grab devices and bingo devices, or any mechanism that has been
judicially determined to be a gambling device, or in any way contrary to law.
Provided, however, that bingo games licensed by the state of Illinois and in
compliance with this code shall not be considered gambling.
If the chief of police shall have reason to believe any automatic amusement
device is used as a gambling device, such machine may be seized by the police
and impounded until a hearing is held as herein provided. A finding of guilty
shall result in the destruction of such machines by the police department. A
finding of innocent shall result in the return of said machines to the
licensee. (Ord. 77-15-18)
3-4A-2-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Every license issued under this code is subject to the right, which is hereby
expressly reserved, to revocation of same should the licensee directly or
indirectly permit the operation of any automatic amusement device contrary to
the provisions of this section, the ordinances of the village or the laws of
the state of Illinois. Said license may be revoked by the village manager after
written notice to the licensee, which notice shall specify the ordinance or law
violations with which the licensee is charged, if after the hearing the
licensee is found to be guilty of such violations. Ten (10) days' notice of the
hearing shall be given to the licensee. At such hearing the licensee and his
attorney may present and submit evidence of witnesses in his defense. (Ord. 77-
15-18)
3-4A-2-11: PENALTIES:
Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall be fined not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense; and each day such violation shall continue
shall be regarded as a separate offense. In addition, any violation hereof may
result in having the premises business regulation certificate subject to
revocation proceedings. (Ords. 77-15-18, 99-5-11)
ARTICLE B. BILLIARD/POOL HALLS
SECTION:
3-4B-1: Definition
3-4B-2: License Required
3-4B-3: License Fees
3-4B-4: Application For License
3-4B-5: Number Of Licenses
3-4B-6: Conditions Of License
3-4B-7: Posting Of License
3-4B-8: Penalty
3-4B-9: Suspension/Revocation Of License
3-4B-1: DEFINITION:
For purposes of this code, a "billiard/pool hall" shall be defined as any
location at which more than two (2) billiard and/or pool tables are operated or
kept for use by the public at one business location. (Ord. 93-22-93)
3-4B-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard/pool hall without
first obtaining the appropriate license(s) under this article. (Ord. 93-22-93)
3-4B-3: LICENSE FEES:
License fees in regard to billiard/pool halls shall be as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title. (Ord. 03-20-81)
3-4B-4: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Application for a billiard/pool hall license shall be made to the
village in writing and must be renewed annually providing the following
information:
      1.   The name, address and telephone number of the applicant;
      2.   The location and telephone number of billiard/pool hall;
      3.   A telephone number and the name of a person who may be contacted on
a twenty four (24) hour basis in case of emergency;
      4.   A statement of whether the business will be conducted by a manager
and, if so, the name, address and telephone number of the manager;
      5.   The number of billiard/pool tables to be located on the licensed
premises;
      6.   An overall security plan addressing all facilities and customer/
patron safety, which shall be submitted to the chief of police for
informational purposes, as well as review and comment; and
      7.   An overall parking plan, addressing those locations at which it is
anticipated that patrons will be parking, which shall be submitted to the
director of quality control for informational purposes, as well as review and
comment.
   B.   The village shall review the information in the application and shall
determine whether the premises wherein the billiard/pool hall is located fully
complies with all of the village's regulations including, but not limited to,
life safety, fire prevention, property maintenance, building and zoning
ordinances. (Ord. 93-22-93)
3-4B-5: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of billiard/pool hall licenses authorized to be issued shall be as
amended from time to time by ordinance adopted by the president and board of
trustees and on record in the office of the village clerk. At any time a
billiard/pool hall ceases to do business in the village, the number of licenses
shall be reduced accordingly by operation of law until such time as a formal
amendment to this code is adopted. (Ords. 93-22-93, 96-3-10)
3-4B-6: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Billiard/pool hall licenses shall be subject to the following conditions:
   A.   No billiard or pool table shall be used on any day except between the
hours of ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. and one o'clock (1:00) A.M.
   B.   No person under the age of sixteen (16) shall be allowed in a billiard/
pool hall, unless accompanied by a parent or guardian.
   C.   No licensee shall permit any gambling or riotous, disorderly or immoral
conduct in or about the licensed premises. (Ord. 93-22-93)
3-4B-7: POSTING OF LICENSE:
Every person licensed pursuant to this article shall post said license in a
conspicuous place in his/her/their/its business. (Ord. 93-22-93)
3-4B-8: PENALTY:
It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a billiard/pool hall, other than
in full compliance with this article and/or all other applicable village codes
or ordinances. Any person convicted of a violation of this article shall be
fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). (Ords. 93-22-93, 99-5-11)
3-4B-9: SUSPENSION/REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
   A.   In addition to any fine that may be assessed pursuant to section
3-4B-8 of this article, any license issued pursuant to this article may be
suspended, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days, or revoked, upon a
finding by the village manager, or his/her designee, after a hearing, for any
one or more of the following reasons:
      1.   A violation of any federal, state or local law applicable to the
business or licensed premises; or
      2.   The conviction of the licensee, or any officer or director thereof,
of a felony.
   B.   The procedure for a hearing on suspension/revocation of a license shall
be as follows:
      1.   Notice of said hearing, in writing, shall be given to the licensee
by the village manager, or his/her designee, at least ten (10) days prior to
the time set for the hearing;
      2.   The notice shall set forth the specific grounds of the complaint as
well as the time and place of the hearing;
      3.   The Village Manager, or his/her designee, shall preside at the
hearing and the licensee shall be permitted counsel and the right to submit
evidence and cross examine witnesses;
      4.   The Village Manager, or his/her designee, shall render a written
decision after all evidence has been presented;
      5.   Said written decision may be appealed by the licensee to the
President and Board of Trustees provided a notice of appeal is filed with the
Village Clerk within ten (10) days after the issuance of said written decision.
(Ord. 93-22-93)
ARTICLE C. ROLLER SKATING RINKS
SECTION:
3-4C-1: Application for License
3-4C-2: Restrictions on License
3-4C-3: Building and Premises Requirements
3-4C-4: Conditions of License
3-4C-5: Revocation of License
3-4C-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Each application for a license to establish, operate or maintain a roller
skating rink shall state thereon the name and address of the applicant, name
and address of the owners and beneficial owners and manager thereof, location
of the rink and the maximum number of persons to be accommodated. The
application shall be accompanied by a complete set of plans and specifications
as provided by the Building Code. Said application shall be examined and
approved by the Village Clerk, Director of Office of Quality Control,
Electrical Inspector, Plumbing Inspector, Chief of Police and Board of Trustees
before a license is issued 1 . (1951 Code 9-6-2; Ords. 53, 81-12-19)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Code for license fee.
3-4C-2: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSE:
No license required by this Article shall be issued to:
   A.   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the community
in which he resides;
   B.   A person who is not a citizen of the United States;
   C.   A person who has been convicted of a felony under any Federal or State
law, if the Commissioner determines after investigation that such person has
not been sufficiently rehabilitated to warrant the public trust;
   D.   A person who has been convicted of being the keeper or is keeping a
house of ill fame;
   E.   A person who has been convicted of pandering or other crime or
misdemeanor opposed to decency and morality;
   F.   A person whose license issued under this Article has been revoked for
cause;
   G.   A person who, at the time of application for renewal of any license
issued hereunder, would not be eligible for such license upon a first
application;
   H.   A copartnership, unless all of the members of such copartnership shall
be qualified to obtain a license;
   I.   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent (5%)
of the stock of such corporation, would not be eligible to receive a license
hereunder for any reason other than citizenship and residence within the
political subdivision;
   J.   A corporation unless it is incorporated in Illinois, or unless it is a
foreign corporation which is qualified under the Illinois Business Corporation
Act 1  to transact business in Illinois;
   K.   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent,
unless the manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required by the
licensee;
   L.   A person who has been convicted of a violation of any Federal or State
law concerning the manufacture, possession or sale of alcoholic liquor,
subsequent to the passage of this Section, or has forfeited his bond to appear
in court to answer charges for any such violation;
   M.   A person who does not beneficially own the premises for which a license
is sought, or does not have a lease thereon for the full period for which the
license is to be issued;
   N.   A person who is not a beneficial owner of the business to be operated
by the licensee;
   O.   A person who has been convicted of a gambling or drug related offense;
   P.   A person to whom a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal wagering
stamp has been issued by the Federal government for the current tax period;
   Q.   A copartnership to which a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal
wagering stamp has been issued by the Federal government for the current tax
period, or if any of the partners have been issued a Federal gaming device
stamp or Federal wagering stamp by the Federal government for the current tax
period;
   R.   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or any
stockholder owning in the aggregate more than twenty percent (20%) of the stock
of such corporation, has been issued a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal
wagering stamp for the current tax period; and
   S.   Any premises for which a Federal gaming device stamp or a Federal
wagering stamp has been issued by the Federal government for the current tax
period. (1951 Code
10-4-4; Ord. 78-7-12; 1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. S.H.A. 805 ILCS 5/1.01.
3-4C-3: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Building Regulations 1 :
      1.   No building shall be constructed or remodeled for use as a roller
skating rink unless the same is of fireproof construction, conforms to the
Building Code and contains a minimum of fifteen thousand (15,000) square feet.
      2.   A sufficient supply of drinking water shall be furnished from
approved bubblers.
      3.   Minimum sanitation facilities shall be provided as follows: four
hundred (400) to six hundred (600) capacity, seven (7) toilets and one
additional toilet for each two hundred (200) or fraction thereof of additional
capacity.
      4.   The minimum ventilation shall consist of a mechanical exhaust system
with a capacity equal to three (3) cubic feet of air per minute for each square
foot of floor area and the ventilating openings shall not be less than four
percent (4%) of the floor area.
   B.   Off-Street Parking: Off-street parking shall be provided for roller
skating rinks as set forth in subsection 4-13-4E of this Code. (1951 Code 9-6-
3, 9-6-7; Ord. 53; 1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 6 of this Code for building regulations.
3-4C-4: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
   A.   Closing Hours: It shall be unlawful to operate a roller skating rink
after the hour of eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M., except that the closing time on
Friday, Saturday and any day preceding a legal holiday shall be not later than
twelve o'clock (12:00) midnight.
   B.   Alcoholic Beverages, Gambling Devices: It shall be unlawful to sell,
give, store or permit the use of alcoholic beverages on the premises of any
roller skating rink and to install or operate any gambling device.
   C.   Order, Safety: The owners and manager shall conduct such rink in an
orderly manner and make adequate provision for the safety and protection of
patrons, employees and spectators, including regulations of the number and
speed of skaters.
   D.   Nuisances: It shall be unlawful for the owners or managers to permit or
suffer to permit the commission of a nuisance or breach of morality or safety
or health as defined under the existing laws of the Village and the State of
Illinois.
   E.   Outdoor Skating: It shall be unlawful for the owner or manager of a
roller skating rink to permit any outdoor roller skating on the premises of the
rink. (1951 Code 9-6-5; Ord. 53)
3-4C-5: REVOCATION OF LICENSE 1 :
The Board of Trustees may revoke any roller skating rink license for default in
the payment or performance of any obligation to the Municipality under the
provisions of this Article. (1951 Code 9-6-10; Ord. 53)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section 3-1-6 of this Code for hearing procedure.

ARTICLE E. MOTION PICTURES AND THEATRICALS
SECTION:
3-4E-1: Application For License, Fee
3-4E-2: Building Requirements
3-4E-3: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
3-4E-1: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE:
Applications for motion picture and theatrical licenses shall state, in
addition to the other information required, the place of the intended
performance and the seating capacity thereof. For motion pictures which are to
be presented in premises which are not covered by an annual license, the fee to
be paid shall be five dollars ($5.00) per day 1 ; provided, that no such motion
pictures shall be presented in or on any premises or building which does not
fully comply with the requirements for the construction or maintenance of
buildings for this purpose. (1951 Code 9-4-2, 9-4-4)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-1-7 of this title for license fee.
3-4E-2: BUILDING REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   General: It shall be unlawful to present any public motion picture in
any building or structure which does not contain the number of exits required
by this code or the ordinances of the village or by statute for buildings or
places intended for motion picture performances, or in premises in which the
electric wiring does not fully comply with the ordinances. All places used for
the exhibition of theatricals must be kept adequately ventilated during the
performance and for so long a time as the audience may remain therein.
   B.   Obstructing Aisles, Exits: It shall be unlawful to obstruct or permit
the obstruction of any aisles, corridors or exits leading from any room or
enclosures in which a motion picture performance is being given or in which an
audience for such a performance is gathered. (1951 Code 9-4-8, 9-4-9)
3-4E-3: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Types Of Pictures: It shall be unlawful to offer or present any motion
picture which has a tendency to cause a riot or public disturbance of the
peace, or any immoral, indecent or blasphemous picture or performance 1 .
   B.   Crowding: It shall be unlawful to permit any person, excepting ushers
or other theater employees, to remain standing in a hall or room in which a
motion picture is presented during the time of such performance; and it shall
be unlawful to admit to any such hall more persons than can be accommodated by
the seating arrangements for the premises.
   C.   Scenery: It shall be unlawful to use any scenery in any theater other
than noninflammable scenery or such as shall have been rendered noninflammable
by application of fire prevention coatings.
   D.   Smoking 2 : It shall be unlawful for any person to smoke in a theater.
(1951 Code 9-4-5, 9-4-6, 9-4-7; 1969 Code 11-115)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  10-5-6-3 of this code.
2 2. See also title 8, chapter 12 of this code.

prevent any bullet from piercing it, and so arranged that there will be no
danger from ricocheting bullets or deflected pieces of bullets. (1951 Code

   A.   Order: All persons present in any shooting gallery shall conduct
themselves in an orderly manner, and shall not make or cause any loud or
unnecessary noise.
   B.   Gambling: It shall be unlawful to gamble or bet in any such place.
   C.   Sanitation And Code Compliance: Premises used for shooting galleries
shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition and in compliance with all
provisions of this code applicable thereto. (1951 Code
9-5-2,

SECTION:

3-4G-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to establish, conduct or operate any trampoline amusement
ground, trampoline equipment or devices, which is open to the public, and for
admittance to which a fee is charged, without having first secured a license
therefor. (1951 Code 9-7-1; Ord. 377)
3-4G-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, FEE:
Applications for licenses required by this article shall be made to the clerk
of the village, and shall comply with all of the general provisions of this
code or the ordinances relating to such applications 1 . The annual license fee
shall be as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title. (1951 Code 9-7-1; Ord. 377; 1985 Code; Ord. 03-20-81)
 
Notes

3-4G-3: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful to erect, establish, conduct or operate any trampoline
amusement ground, trampoline equipment or devices, and no license shall be
issued therefor, unless the following provisions are complied with:
   A.   Access To State Highways, Permit: Whenever a trampoline amusement
ground has automobile entrance and exits onto a state highway, access permit
for such shall first be obtained from the state highway department, and copy of
same shall be presented to the village clerk at the time of application for a
license.
   B.   Building Regulations And Requirements: Application for a license shall
be accompanied by a complete set of plans and specifications as provided by the
building code of the village. Said plans shall further provide outdoor
accessible drinking fountain, a minimum of two (2) separate sanitary toilet

Code 9-7-3; Ord. 377)
