In connection with the operation of a trampoline amusement ground, it shall be
unlawful to maintain or operate any loudspeaker or amplifier connected with any
radio, phonograph, microphone, or other device by which sounds are magnified
and made over the public street or public place so as to be disturbing to the
public and adjacent premises. (1951 Code 9-7-4; Ord. 377)
ARTICLE H. CARNIVALS
SECTION:
3-4H-1: License Required
3-4H-2: Application For License
3-4H-3: Scheduling, Community Events Calendar; Fees
3-4H-4: Penalty
3-4H-1: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a carnival or amusement rides 1  in the village
without a license. (Ord. 70-9-13)
 
Notes
1 1. See also section
  3-4A-1 of this chapter.
3-4H-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for license shall be made to the village forty five (45) days prior
to the proposed use of same. The applicant shall furnish the following
information for the issuance of said license:
   A.   Name and address of operator. If a corporation, state of incorporation
and names and addresses of all officers of same.
   B.   Certificates of insurance providing for liability insurance, with the
village as an additional party insured.
   C.   Site location in the village and duration of same.
   D.   Name and address of sponsoring organization, if any, and of officers of
same where applicable.
   E.   An overall parking plan, addressing those locations at which it is
anticipated that patrons will be parking, which shall be submitted to the
director of quality control and police chief for informational purposes, as
well as review and comment. In the event that said parking plan indicates the
use of private parking lots other than parking lots owned by the applicant,
said parking plan shall be accompanied by letters from the owner(s) of said
private parking lot(s) indicating the consent of said owner(s) relative to the
use of said private parking lot(s).
   F.   A site plan for the carnival which indicates the proposed locations of
all rides, game booths, refreshment booths, trucks and trailers used for
transporting the aforementioned rides and booths and mobile living quarters for
employees of the company used to provide said rides and booths. (Ords. 70-9-13,
93-24-112, 01-17-64)
3-4H-3: SCHEDULING, COMMUNITY EVENTS CALENDAR 1 ; FEES:
   A.   The fees required to be paid to the village by a carnival operator
shall be waived by the village if the sponsor is a resident nonprofit
organization. However, the deposit required under section
3-4A-1-3 of this chapter shall be paid. No more than two (2) carnivals may be
sponsored by one nonprofit organization in any calendar year.
   B.   No carnival shall be scheduled on the community events calendar, as
established in section
3-1-7-4 of this title, to commence less than ten (10) days after the scheduled
completion of the most recent one; provided, however, that the village board
may allow a carnival to commence less than ten (10) days after the scheduled
completion of, or at the same time as, another carnival; provided that a
finding is made as to each of the following conditions:
      1.   That the location of the second carnival will not be so close to the
first carnival that traffic congestion will result; and
      2.   That the scheduling of the second carnival, less than ten (10) days
after the scheduled completion of, or at the same time as, the first carnival
will not unduly burden the village's police department in carrying out its
duties throughout the village and, specifically, in maintaining order at both
carnivals; and
      3.   That strict adherence to the ten (10) day requirement would cause
particular hardship to the second carnival license applicant.
   C.   When a carnival is sponsored by a nonprofit organization, the operator
shall guarantee the sponsoring organization a minimum payment of one thousand
five hundred dollars ($1,500.00). (Ords. 76-10-21, 87-21-89)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 3-1-7-4 of this title.
3-4H-4: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense, and each day during or on which a violation occurs
or continues shall constitute a separate offense hereunder. (Ord. 70-9-13; 1985
Code; Ord. 99-5-11)
ARTICLE I. TEEN NIGHTS
(Rep. by Ord. 23-12-42)
ARTICLE J. RAFFLES
SECTION:
3-4J-1: Authority
3-4J-2: Definitions
3-4J-3: Conditions of License
3-4J-4: License Fees, Issuance
3-4J-5: License Issue Restrictions
3-4J-6: Conduct of Raffles; Premises
3-4J-7: Raffles Manager, Bond
3-4J-8: Records
3-4J-9: Additional Restrictions
3-4J-10: Reciprocity
3-4J-11: Queen Of Hearts Raffles
3-4J-1: AUTHORITY:
Notwithstanding the provisions of Section
10-5-5  of this Code relating to gambling, raffles may be conducted in the
Village upon complying with the following regulations. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-2: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this Article, the following definitions apply:
BUSINESS: A voluntary organization composed of individuals and businesses who
have joined together to advance the commercial, financial, industrial and civic
interests of the community.
CHARITABLE: An organization or institution organized and operated to benefit an
indefinite number of the public. The service rendered to those eligible for
benefits must also confer some benefit on the public.
EDUCATIONAL: An organization or institution organized and operated to provide
systematic instruction in useful branches of learning by methods common to
schools and institutions of learning which compare favorably in their scope and
intensity with the course of study presented in tax- supported schools.
FRATERNAL: An organization of persons having a common interest, the primary
interest of which is to promote the welfare of its members and to provide
assistance to the general public in such a way as to lessen the burdens of
government by caring for those that otherwise would be cared for by the
government.
LABOR: An organization composed of workers organized with the objective of
betterment of the conditions of those engaged in such pursuit and the
development of a higher degree of efficiency in their respective occupations.
NET PROCEEDS: The gross receipts from the conduct of raffles, less reasonable
sums expended for prizes, local license fees and other reasonable operating
expenses incurred as a result of operating a raffle.
NONPROFIT: An organization or institution organized and conducted on a not-for-
profit basis with no personal profit incurred to anyone as a result of the
operation.
QUEEN OF HEARTS RAFFLE: A progressive raffle utilizing a standard playing card
deck of fifty-four (54) cards that continues until the “Queen of Hearts,” is
chosen. If the Queen of Hearts is not chosen, the net proceeds of the grand
prize pool carry to the next round, and new tickets are sold, until the winning
ticket reveals the Queen of Hearts.
RAFFLE: A form of lottery, as defined in Section
10-5-5-1  of this Code, conducted by an organization licensed under this
Article, in which:
   A.   The player pays or agrees to pay something of value for a chance,
represented and differentiated by a number or by a combination of numbers or
some other medium, one or more of which chances is to be designated the winning
chance, and
   B.   The winning chance is to be determined through a drawing or by some
other method based on an element of chance by an act or set of acts on the part
of persons conducting or connected with the raffle, except that the winning
chance shall not be determined by the outcome of a publicly exhibited sporting
contest.
   “Raffle” does not include any game designed to simulate: (1) gambling games
as defined in the Illinois Gambling Act, (2) any casino game approved for play
by the Illinois Gaming Board, (3) any games provided by a video gaming
terminal, as defined in the Video Gaming Act, or (4) a savings promotion raffle
authorized under Section 5g of the Illinois Banking Act, Section 7008 of the
Savings Bank Act, Section 42.7 of the Illinois Credit Union Act, Section 5136B
of the National Bank Act, or Section 4 of the Home Owners’ Loan Act.
   Bingo, as regulated by the State of Illinois pursuant to the Bingo License
and Tax Act (230 ILCS 25/1, et seq.), and the State Lottery, as regulated by
the State of Illinois pursuant to the Illinois Lottery Law (20 ILCS 1605/1, et
seq.), shall not be considered raffles subject to the provisions of this
Article.
RELIGIOUS: Any church, congregation, society or organization founded for the
purpose of religious workshop.
VETERANS: An organization or association comprised of members of which
substantially all are individuals who are veterans or spouses, widows or
widowers of veterans, the primary purpose of which is to promote the welfare of
its members and to provide assistance to the general public in such a way as to
confer a public benefit. (Ords. 87-11-44, 24-09-31)
3-4J-3: CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
Raffles shall be conducted only by organizations licensed pursuant to this
Section, and such licenses are subject to the following restrictions:
   A.   The application for license must specify the area or areas within the
Village in which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time period during
which raffle chances will be sold or issued, the time of determination of
winning chances, and the location or locations at which winning chances will be
determined.
   B.   The license application must contain a sworn statement attesting to the
not-for-profit character of the prospective license organization, signed by the
presiding officer and the secretary of their organization.
   C.   Each such license shall be valid only for the number of raffles
specified in the license; said raffles to be conducted during the specific
period of time specified in the license, not to exceed one year.
   D.   Licenses shall be issued to bona fide business, religious, charitable,
labor, fraternal, educational or veterans’ organizations that operate without
profit to their members and which have been in existence continuously for a
period of five (5) years immediately before making application for a license
and which have had during that entire five (5) year period a bona fide
membership engaged in carrying out their objects.
   E.   Licenses shall be issued to any nonprofit fund raising organization
that the Village determines is organized for the sole purpose of providing
financial assistance to an identified individual or group of individuals
suffering extreme financial hardship as the result of illness, disability,
accident or disaster. (Ords. 87-11-44, 87-24-101)
3-4J-4: LICENSE FEES, ISSUANCE:
   A.   There shall be no fee for the license issued under this Article.
   B.   When all the requirements of this Article have been met, the license
shall be issued by the Village Clerk. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-5: LICENSE ISSUE RESTRICTIONS:
No such license shall be issued to:
   A.   Any person who has been convicted of a felony.
   B.   Any person who is or has been a professional gambler or gambling
promoter.
   C.   Any person who is not of good moral character.
   D.   Any firm or corporation in which a person defined in subsections A, B
or C above has a proprietary, equitable or credit interest, or in which such a
person is active or employed.
   E.   Any organization in which a person in subsections A, B or C of this
Section is an officer, director of employee, whether compensated or not.
   F.   Any organization in which a person defined in subsections A, B or C
above is to participate in the management or operation of a raffle as defined
in this Article. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-6: CONDUCT OF RAFFLES; PREMISES:
   A.   The conducting of raffles is subject to the following restrictions:
      1.   The entire net proceeds of any raffle must be exclusively devoted to
the lawful purposes of the organization permitted to conduct that game.
      2.   No person except a bona fide member of the sponsoring organization
may participate in the management or operation of the raffle.
      3.   No person may receive any remuneration or profit for participating
in the management or operation of the raffle.
      4.   A licensee may rent a premises on which to determine the winning
chance or chances in a raffle only from an organization which is also licensed
under this Article.
      5.   Raffle chances may be sold or issued only within the area specified
on the license and winning chances may be determined only at those locations
specified on the licenses.
      6.   No person under the age of eighteen (18) years may participate in
the conducting of raffles of chances. A person under the age of eighteen (18)
years may be within the area where winning chances are being determined only
when accompanied by his parent or guardian.
   B.   If a lessor rents premises where a winning chance or chances on a
raffle are determined, the lessor shall not be criminally liable if the person
who uses the premises for the determining of winning chances does not hold a
license. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-7: RAFFLES MANAGER, BOND:
All operation of and the conduct of raffles shall be under the supervision of a
single raffles manager designated by the organization. The manager shall give a
fidelity bond in the sum of an amount determined by the Village in favor of the
organization conditioned upon his honesty in the performance of his duties.
Terms of the bond shall provide that notice shall be given in writing to the
licensing authority not less than thirty (30) days prior to its cancellation.
The Village may waive this bond requirement by including a waiver provision in
the license issued to an organization under this Article provided that a
license containing such waiver provision shall be granted only where a
unanimous vote of the members of the licensed organization has approved the
waiver of the raffles manager’s bond. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-8: RECORDS:
   A.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles and chances shall keep
the records of its gross receipts, expenses and net proceeds for each single
gathering or occasion at which winning chances are determined. All deductions
from gross receipts for each single gathering or occasion shall be documented
with receipts or other records indicating the amount, a description of the
purchased item or service or other reason for the deductions, and the
recipient. The distribution of net proceeds shall be itemized as to payee,
purpose, amount and date of payment.
   B.   Gross receipts from the operation of raffles programs shall be
segregated from other revenues of the organization, including bingo gross
receipts, if bingo games are also conducted by the same nonprofit organization
pursuant to license therefor issued by the Department of Revenue of the State
of Illinois, and placed in a separate account. Each organization shall have
separate records of its raffles. The person who accounts for gross receipts,
expenses and net proceeds from the operation of raffles shall not be the same
person who accounts for other revenues of the organization.
   C.   Each organization licensed to conduct raffles shall report monthly to
its membership, and to the Village, its gross receipts, expenses and net
proceeds from raffles, and the distribution of net proceeds itemized as
required in this Section.
   D.   Records required by this Section shall be preserved for three (3) years
and organizations shall make available their records relating to operation of
raffles for public inspection at reasonable times and places. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-9: ADDITIONAL RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   The aggregate retail value of all prizes and merchandise awarded by a
licensee in a single raffle should not exceed two hundred thousand dollars
($200,000.00).
   B.   The maximum retail value of each prize awarded in a single raffle
should not exceed two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00).
   C.   The maximum price which may be charged for each raffle chance issued or
sold shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00).
   D.   The maximum number of days during which chances may be issued or sold
shall not exceed one hundred eighty (180) days.
   E.   The above restrictions shall not apply to the Queen of Hearts Raffles.
(Ords. 87-11-44, 24-09-31)
3-4J-10: RECIPROCITY:
The Village Clerk may issue a raffle license to an organization upon payment of
the required license fee, provided that:
   A.   The organization has been issued a raffle license by a municipality
which is adjacent to the Village; and
   B.   Said adjacent municipality’s raffle ordinance is substantially similar
to the provisions of this Article and complies with the requirements of the
Illinois Raffles and Poker Runs Act, 230 ILCS 15/0.01, et seq.; and
   C.   The Village has a written mutual licensing agreement in regard to
raffles with said adjacent municipality.
If the foregoing conditions have been met, the organization need not make
application and need not comply with the provisions of Sections
3-4J-7  and subsection 3-4J-8C. (Ord. 87-11-44)
3-4J-11: QUEEN OF HEARTS RAFFLES:
To the extent there any conflicts with other provisions of this Article J, the
following requirements shall apply to and control Queen of Hearts Raffles:
   A.   In addition to the requirements of Section
3-4J-3 , an application for a Queen of Hearts Raffle license must also include:
      1.   A complete copy of the rules governing the Queen of Hearts Raffle,
which must indicate the percentage of net proceeds of the grand prize pool that
will be paid to the grand prize winner and the percentage of the sponsoring
organization’s share of receipts.
      2.   A plan to maintain the integrity and security of all funds received
for the Queen of Hearts Raffle, including a plan for security for the location
where the raffle will operate.
      3.   Manner in which payout(s) will be made.
      4.   Such proof and documents that the Village may reasonably request to
determine the organization’s ability to comply with this section and the
Illinois Raffles and Poker Runs Act, 230 ILCS 15/0.01, et. seq.
   B.   A Queen of Hearts Raffle shall not be subject to Section
3-4J-9  but shall be limited in the following manner:
      1.   A Queen of Hearts Raffle shall have a limit of two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) paid out to the grand prize winner.
      2.   Any secondary prize(s), if applicable based on the licensee’s rules,
should not exceed two hundred thousand dollars ($200,000.00).
      3.   The maximum price which may be charged for each Queen of Hearts
Raffle chance issued or sold shall not exceed two hundred dollars ($200.00).
      4.   No more tickets may be sold after such a time as sufficient money is
available to pay the $2,000,000.00 grand prize winner. In that event, the
drawing shall continue from that week’s Queen of Hearts Raffle until there is a
grand prize winner.
      5.   Purchasers of Queen of Hearts Raffle tickets must register their
names and addresses with the sponsoring organization.
      6.   The Village may, in its discretion, restrict purchase and
registration of tickets based on safety and health concerns.
   C.   A Queen of Hearts Raffle license shall be valid for a specified period,
not to exceed one (1) year. The Queen of Hearts Raffle must take place at the
location on the application, on the dates and times indicated on the
application. If a Queen of Hearts Raffle cannot be concluded within the
licensed period, the license holder must renew the license. If the license is
not renewed, the Queen of Hearts Raffle must conclude within the license
period. (Ord. 24-09-31)
ARTICLE K. TEENAGE CABARETS/JUICE BARS
SECTION:
3-4K-1: Definition
3-4K-2: License Required
3-4K-3: Application For License
3-4K-4: License Fee
3-4K-5: General Conditions Of License
3-4K-6: Special Conditions Of License
3-4K-7: Location Restriction
3-4K-8: Penalty; Revocation
3-4K-1: DEFINITION:
For purposes of this article, a "teenage cabaret/juice bar" is defined as a
private commercial, recreational and entertainment facility, designed or
intended to be used primarily by, but not limited to, patrons under the age of
twenty one (21) years old, where patrons enjoy dancing, live and recorded music
and entertainment or where videotape presentations are shown. (Ord. 89-21-67)
3-4K-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to operate a teenage cabaret/juice bar within the village
without first having obtained a license therefor as herein provided. (Ord. 89-
21-67)
3-4K-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for such license shall be made to the village clerk and shall
include the following information:
   A.   Name and address of the owner/operator. If a corporation, the state of
incorporation, as well as the names and addresses of all officers of the
corporation;
   B.   The names and addresses and positions of all employees and nonemployee
crowd control and supervision personnel. Said information shall be updated as
new employees and nonemployee crowd control and supervision personnel are
hired;
   C.   The intended hours of operation; and
   D.   The maximum occupancy load of the building or premises to be used, as
determined by the Oak Lawn fire department in accordance with the provisions of
the latest edition of the BOCA basic national building code adopted by the
village.
   E.   Such other information as may be required by the village from time to
time. (Ord. 89-21-67)
3-4K-4: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for a teenage cabaret/juice bar license shall be as set forth in
section
3-1-1-7 of this title. (Ord. 03-20-81)
3-4K-5: GENERAL CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
All teenage cabaret/juice bar licenses shall be subject to the following
conditions:
   A.   The building and premises used must be in full compliance with all
applicable provisions of this code.
   B.   The licensee shall be required to supply at least one qualified crowd
control and supervision person for every one hundred (100) persons, or portion
thereof, permitted to be within the building or premises licensed. Persons
qualified for crowd control shall include, but not be limited to, off duty
police officers and firefighters. Said qualified crowd control and supervision
personnel shall be responsible for crowd control both within the building used
by the licensee and the premises upon which said building is located. In the
event that the licensee uses village off duty police officers for crowd control
and supervision, the licensee shall include the police officers in the workers'
compensation insurance policy for their employees only while employed privately
in connection with the teenage cabaret/juice bar and the village shall be named
as an additional insured in the general liability insurance policy covering the
operation of said teenage cabaret/juice bar in an amount of not less than one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) aggregate coverage.
   C.   All patrons shall enter at only one entrance and be properly identified
and a count of those entering be kept; that all persons and clothing be checked
to make sure that no dangerous implements are brought into said licensed
premises; that once a person has been admitted such person shall not leave and
reenter without again paying the admission charge and being identified and
checked.
   D.   No alcoholic beverages will be served or permitted on the licensed
premises.
   E.   The manager of said teenage cabaret/juice bar shall be an adult,
preferably with experience in the administration of such facilities; that all
employees and nonemployee crowd control and supervision personnel of said
teenage cabaret/juice bar shall be checked by the police department for
previous criminal records. Within three (3) days of the hiring of a new
employee or nonemployee crowd control and supervision person, the owner/
operator shall notify the village clerk in writing of the name of the new
employee or nonemployee crowd control and supervision person so that the police
department can perform the required criminal record check.
   F.   No license required by this article shall be issued to an establishment
which has an employee, or has a nonemployee crowd control and supervision
person, who is a convicted felon, or has been placed on supervision for, or
been convicted of, a violation of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-6, 5/11-
9, 5/11-11, 5/11-14, 5/11-15, 5/11-15.1, 5/11-16, 5/11-17, 5/11-19, 5/11-19.1,
5/11-19.2, 5/11-20, 5/11-20.1, 5/11-21, 5/12-15 or 5/12-16.1.
   G.   The coat check area will be supervised and patrolled.
   H.   Building and fire code regulations shall at all times be enforced.
(Ord. 89-21-67)
3-4K-6: SPECIAL CONDITIONS OF LICENSE:
All teenage cabaret/juice bar licenses shall be subject to the following
special conditions during any period of time when individuals under the age of
eighteen (18) years old are permitted on the licensed premises.
   A.   The hours of operation shall be limited to:
      1.   Fridays: Eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight.
      2.   Saturdays: Eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight.
      3.   Evening preceding holidays: Eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M. to twelve
o'clock (12:00) midnight.
      4.   Sunday through Thursday: Three o'clock (3:00) P.M. to ten o'clock
(10:00) P.M.
   B.   Notwithstanding the aforesaid hours of operation, no provisions of law
establishing a curfew for persons of the ages affected are hereby modified or
repealed and that the licensee of said teenage cabaret/juice bar shall cause to
be audibly announced the curfew hours at least one-half (1/2) hour before said
curfew shall become effective.
   C.   The patrons of the teenage cabaret/juice bar shall be at least fourteen
(14) years of age, and under the age of twenty one (21) years old, and be the
holder of a valid high school identification card or other means of lawful
identification, unless entry is limited on a particular day or during
particular hours to only individuals under the age of fourteen (14) years old.
   D.   The licensee shall make responsible efforts not to permit persons under
seventeen (17) years of age to enter or remain upon the premises after ten
thirty o'clock (10:30) P.M. on Sunday through Thursday or after eleven thirty
o'clock (11:30) P.M. on Friday and Saturday.
   E.   The parents of patrons shall be admitted to observe and as part of the
operating schedule, open houses for parents shall be arranged.
   F.   No smoking or rough dancing shall be permitted, no matches, lighters or
cigarettes shall be allowed to be brought onto the premises. A sign shall be
conspicuously posted informing the patrons what items cannot be brought into
said teenage cabaret/juice bar.
The aforementioned special conditions shall be in addition to the general
conditions set forth in section
3-4K-5 of this article. Where the special conditions of this section are more
restrictive than the general conditions of section
3-4K-5 of this article, the special conditions shall prevail. (Ord. 89-21-67)
3-4K-7: LOCATION RESTRICTION:
Teenage cabarets/juice bars shall be located only in the C-3 regional shopping
district and the M-1 restricted manufacturing district, provided the operator
of said teenage cabaret/juice bar first applies for and receives a special use
permit to operate such an establishment in accordance with the provisions of
title 4, chapter 14 of this code, and teenage cabarets/juice bars shall not be
located within three hundred feet (300') of a park, a school or a church, as
measured from the closest lot line to the closest lot line of the respective
properties. (Ord. 01-14-48)
3-4K-8: PENALTY; REVOCATION:
   A.   Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this
article shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   In addition to the fine provisions of subsection A of this section, the
general license revocation provisions of section
3-1-6 of this title shall be applicable to teenage cabaret/juice bar licensees.
(Ords. 89-21-67, 99-5-11, 01-14-48)
CHAPTER 5
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS AND ITINERANT MERCHANTS
SECTION:
3-5-1: Definitions
3-5-2: License Registration; Fee And Term
3-5-3: Application For License
3-5-4: Issuance Of License
3-5-5: Prohibited Acts
3-5-6: Security
3-5-7: Display Of License
3-5-8: Records Of Purchases
3-5-9: Report Of Rental Of Premises By Owner
3-5-10: Revocation Of License Or Registration
3-5-11: Exemptions
3-5-12:    Penalty
3-5-13:    Street Solicitation
3-5-1: DEFINITIONS:
CHARITABLE ORGANIZATION: Any benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or
eleemosynary person which solicits and collects funds for charitable purposes
including each local, county, or area division of such charitable organization.
CHARITABLE PURPOSE: Any charitable, benevolent, philanthropic, patriotic, or
eleemosynary purpose.
ITINERANT MERCHANT: Any individual, corporation, partnership, organization or
other entity, except those defined in section
3-8-1  of this title, engaged in the sale, delivery or purchase of goods, wares
or merchandise and who for the purpose of conducting such
business temporarily occupies any fixed place of business whether it is a
building, room, vehicle or structure of any kind or vacant lot or other place
and holds less than a year’s lease on any such space.
PEDDLERS: Any individual, corporation, partnership, organization or other
entity which offers goods, wares or merchandise for sale by seeking out
customers in door to door canvasses.
PERSON: Any individual, organization, group, association, partnership,
corporation, trust, or any combination of them.
SOLICITORS: Any individual, corporation, partnership, organization or other
entity which seeks financial or nonfinancial support for political, charitable
or other causes.
STREET SOLICITATION: The act of any person standing in or on any street,
roadway, highway, or intersection within the Village of Oak Lawn for the
purpose of requesting directly or indirectly, money, credit, property,
financial assistance, or other thing of value from the occupant of any vehicle.
(Ords. 93-14-57, 24-19-70)
3-5-2: LICENSE REGISTRATION; FEE AND TERM:
Peddlers, solicitors, and itinerant merchants shall register by applying to
obtain a license to engage in itinerant selling, peddling and soliciting within
the village. Notwithstanding the fact that a corporation, partnership,
organization or other entity may have several individual peddlers, solicitors,
or itinerant merchants in the village at one time, a separate application shall
be submitted for each individual, and each individual shall be required to
obtain a separate license. Each individual, corporation, partnership,
organization or other entity whom the individual is employed by or represents
shall be limited to holding any one or more licenses issued under this chapter
for a cumulative maximum of four (4) weeks per calendar year. The license fee
shall be $125 per week per license and shall be required for each individual
peddler or solicitor. Itinerant merchants, where applicable, shall be licensed
by the state under the Transient Merchant Act of 1987. License fees will be
waived for charitable organizations. (Ords. 93-14-57, 03-20-81, 23-12-42, 24-
19-70)
3-5-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Application for license shall be made upon a form provided by the village
clerk. Each person engaged in peddling or soliciting shall apply for an
individual license. The applicant shall, under oath state in full the
following:
   A.   Applicant’s name, address, phone number, and birth date, together with
a copy of applicant’s driver’s license or state identification card.
   B.   Name of business or organization, whom the applicant is employed by or
represents, and address, phone number and state where business or organization
is incorporated (if applicable).
   C.   Nature of organization or business.
   D.   Name, address, and phone number of the organization’s or business’
representative, owner, manager or operator who will manage or conduct activity
which is subject of the license.
   E.   Type of license sought.
   F.   Location where sale will be held in village; or specific boundaries of
the area where peddling or soliciting will take place.
   G.   Dates during which sale, purchasing, peddling or soliciting will take
place and period of time of license requested, not to exceed a cumulative
maximum of four (4) weeks per calendar year, pursuant to section
3-5-2  of this chapter.
   H.   Description of goods to be sold or purchased, or nature of
solicitation.
   I.   Number of persons to be involved in peddling or solicitation, each of
whom must apply for an individual license, pursuant to section
3-5-2  of this chapter.
   J.   Dates on which previous licenses were issued by the village and
information regarding revocation of prior business licenses.
   K.   Information regarding any convictions of applicant and of owner,
manager or operator for violating any village business regulation, or any state
statute regarding the subject matter of the license.
   L.   Evidence that solicitors, where applicable, have complied with
provisions of the Solicitation for Charity Act, 225 ILCS 460.01 et seq.
   M.   Evidence that itinerant merchants and peddlers, where applicable, have
complied with the provisions of the Transient Merchant Act of 1987.
   N.   Evidence that the applicant has presented their application and
proposed plans for peddling or soliciting activities at a regular meeting of
the President of the Village and the Village Board of Trustees, confirming the
accuracy of all application information referenced in this section at said
meeting. The requirements of this section may be met by presenting plans for
peddling or soliciting activities during the public comment period of a regular
meeting, consistent with the rules governing public comments, or by scheduling
a time for presentation with the Village Clerk.
   O.   Any charitable organization seeking to solicit funds on streets in the
Village must also provide a certificate of insurance with an appropriate level
of insurance as required by village ordinance.
   P.   Any other information required by the village. (Ords. 93-14-57, 24-19-
70)
3-5-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
The clerk, upon receipt of a properly completed application, including evidence
that each applicant has presented their application and proposed plans for
peddling or solicitation activities to the President of the Village and the
Village Board of Trustees, pursuant to section
3-5-3  of this chapter, but in no event later than ten (10) working days after
the receipt of the application, shall either issue a license or notify the
applicant, in writing, that the application has been denied because:
   A.   The applicant has failed to comply with the requirements of this
chapter; or
   B.   The applicant, owner, manager or operator has, within the previous
year, been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter,
its predecessor, or the ordinance of any other municipality, or state or
federal statute regulating selling, soliciting, or peddling; or a violation of
any law where the offense for which the applicant was convicted took place in
connection with the applicant’s alleged selling, soliciting or peddling. (Ords.
93-14-57, 24-19-70)
3-5-5: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Uninvited Peddling Or Soliciting:
      1.   No person shall engage in solicitation or peddling upon any
commercial premises, dwelling house, apartment or other residence after having
been asked by the owner, manager, agent or occupant thereof to leave such
commercial premises or residence.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in peddling or
solicitation upon any commercial premises or residence if such commercial
premises or residence is posted against solicitation or peddling by means of a
notice, prominently displayed upon which is printed the legend:
         NO SOLICITORS OR PEDDLERS
For purposes of this subsection A, a commercial premises, a dwelling house,
apartment or other place of residence shall be deemed to be posted against
solicitation or peddling if there is exhibited, on or near the main entrance to
the premises or on or near the main door to any residence located thereon, a
sign at least three inches by four inches (3" x 4") in size with letters at
least one-third inch (1/3") in height, which bears the above legend. Signs
complying with the foregoing requirements shall be made available at cost at
the office of the village clerk to persons requesting the same.
   B.   False Statements And Representations:
      1.   No person who engages in itinerant selling, purchasing, solicitation
or peddling shall use any plan, scheme or ruse or make any statement which
indicates or implies that his or her purpose is other than to make sales,
purchases, collect funds or seek nonfinancial support for the business or
organization named in the license issued.
      2.   No person who engages in itinerant selling or peddling shall
misrepresent the right of a buyer to rescind or cancel a sale under the
provisions of applicable law.
      3.   It shall be unlawful for any itinerant merchant, peddler or
solicitor to cheat, deceive or make fraudulent misrepresentations, or for any
itinerant merchant or peddler to barter, sell or peddle any goods, merchandise
or wares other than those specified in his or her application for a license.
   C.   Peddling Or Soliciting After Hours: It shall be unlawful for any person
to engage in peddling or solicitation at any time prior to nine o’clock (9:00)
A.M. or after seven o’clock (7:00) P.M., local time, of any weekday; at any
time prior to ten o’clock (10:00) A.M. or after six o’clock (6:00) P.M. on a
Saturday; or at any time on a Sunday or on a state or national holiday.
   D.   Obstructing Traffic: No itinerant merchant, solicitor or peddler shall
interfere with either vehicular or pedestrian traffic on any public right of
way.
   E.   Solicitation On Highways: Pursuant to 625 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/
11-1006(c), no person shall stand on a highway for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except when expressly permitted
by village ordinance. The village shall determine by ordinance where and when
solicitations may take place based on the safety of the solicitors and the
safety of the motorists. The decision shall also take into account the orderly
flow of traffic and may not allow interference with the operation of official
traffic control devices. Solicitation on highways shall further comply with all
other applicable rules and regulations of this chapter. (Ords. 93-14-57, 08-04-
14, 24-19-70)
3-5-6: SECURITY:
Before any license, as provided by this chapter, except those licenses for
which fees are waived, shall be issued, an applicant shall file with the
village clerk security in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), in the
form of a bond executed by the applicant, or owner, manager or operator, as
principal, and two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may be made in the
state to ensure that said applicant, owner, manager or operator shall comply
fully with all the ordinances of the village and the statutes of the state.
Security shall be terminated or returned within ten (10) days after the
expiration of the license if no charges of violations have been brought. If
charges are brought, security shall be held pending the outcome or settlement.
(Ords. 93-14-57, 24-19-70)
3-5-7: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
Licenses under this chapter shall be posted conspicuously where business is to
be conducted. In regard to peddlers and solicitors, a large personal
identification license shall be displayed conspicuously on the outer garment of
the registered peddler or solicitor at all times when engaged in soliciting or
peddling within the village. Itinerant merchants, peddlers and solicitors shall
carry sufficient quantities of business cards, or other written materials, with
accurate contact information, including the name of the licensee and their
business, address, and phone number. Such business cards, or other written
materials with the licensee’s contact information, must be provided to
individuals upon request. (Ords. 93-14-57, 24-19-70)
3-5-8: RECORDS OF PURCHASES:
Every itinerant merchant who engages in purchasing goods shall keep a record of
those goods purchased including the amount paid for each item, the date of
purchase, the seller's name, address, driver's license number and a listing of
two (2) items of identification presented by the seller to verify the seller's
name and address. Such record shall be, at all reasonable times, open to the
inspection of the village's police department. (Ord. 93-14-57)
3-5-9: REPORT OF RENTAL OF PREMISES BY OWNER:
The owner, proprietor or manager of any hotel, motel, store or building of any
type shall report to the chief of police, within eight (8) hours after renting,
the name of any person who shall rent for less than a one year period a room or
other space for the purchase and/or sale of goods, wares or merchandise, giving
the location of the room or space so rented. (Ord. 93-14-57)
3-5-10: REVOCATION OF LICENSE OR REGISTRATION:
Any license or registration under this chapter may be revoked by the village
manager because of any violation of this chapter or of any other ordinance of
the village, or of any state or federal law, but not before the licensee or
registrant has been given at least three (3) days' notice and an opportunity to
be heard by the village manager on the issue of whether said license or
registration should be revoked. (Ord. 93-14-57)
3-5-11: EXEMPTIONS:
Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, the
following shall not be subject to the registration and licensing/permitting
provisions contained in this Chapter:
   A.   Pursuant to the United States supreme court’s holding in Watchtower
Bible and Tract Society of New York, Inc. v. Village of Stratton, (2002 WL
1305851 - June 17, 2002), any person engaging in the door to door advocacy of a
particular position or cause, with or without the distribution of pamphlets,
handbills or literature relative to said position or cause, unless said person
is also engaging in the sale of goods or services, the taking of orders
relative to the sale of goods or services or the solicitation of funds while
engaging in the door to door advocacy of said position or cause; and
   B.   Minors engaged in fundraising activities to support: (1) a federally
chartered charitable organization (such as Girl Scouts or Boy Scouts of
America); (2) an activity organized and operated by a public or private school
or unit of local government; (3) an organization organized as a Not For Profit
entity and registered with the State of Illinois as a Charitable Organization;
or (4) a similar Not For Profit organization that has a chapter or club based
in the Village of Oak Lawn, as approved by the Village Manager.
   C.   Law enforcement personnel, firefighters, or other persons employed to
protect the public safety of the Village, who will be soliciting for charitable
purposes on behalf of a charitable organization, as defined in Section 2 of the
Charitable Games Act, who file an application with the Village in accordance
with Section 11-80-9 of the Illinois Municipal Code, 65 ILCS 5/11-80-9, in
which case the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-80-9 shall apply. (Ords. 02-18-71,
24-19-70)
3-5-12: PENALTY: 
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00) for each offense. Each day of violation, and each violating
individual at each violating location shall be considered a separate offense
under this chapter. (Ord. 24-19-70)
3-5-13: STREET SOLICITATION:
   A.   General Prohibition: Except as expressly permitted below, and subject
to the provisions of Section
3-5-5 of this Code, no person may stand in or on any street, roadway, highway,
or intersection within the Village of Oak Lawn for the purpose of soliciting
contributions from the occupant of any vehicle.
   B.   Exception: A permit may be granted as outlined below, to certain
charitable organizations to solicit contributions from the occupants of stopped
vehicles at certain signalized intersections within the Village of Oak Lawn.
   C.   Application: Applications for permits for street solicitation shall be
made at least thirty (30) days in advance of the earliest date requested, but
in no case prior to January 1st of the applicable year. Applications shall be
submitted to the village clerk, upon the form designated by the village clerk
therefor. Applications shall be accompanied by indications of compliance with
the eligibility requirements of Section
3-5-3 of this chapter and a certificate of insurance in the amount of not less
than $1,000,000.00 per claim and $2,000,000.00 per occurrence, naming the
Village of Oak Lawn as an additional insured party and a certificate holder,
and a signed agreement indemnifying and holding the Village of Oak Lawn
harmless for negligent acts of the organization’s solicitors resulting in
injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which is causally
related to an act of negligence of the soliciting agent. The current
certificate of insurance covering the actual date(s) of solicitation must be
provided to the village clerk at least thirty (30) days before the earliest
requested solicitation date. The village clerk may from time to time amend the
application and/or permit forms within the limitations of this chapter.
   D.   Eligibility: Charitable organizations eligible to apply for
solicitation permits shall be (1) registered with the Illinois Attorney General
as a charitable organization pursuant to the Solicitation for Charity Act, 225
ILCS 460/1 et seq.; (2) engaged in a statewide fund raising activity; and (3)
liable for any injuries to any person or property during the solicitation which
is causally related to an act of ordinary negligence of the soliciting agent.
   E.   Dates Permitted: No charitable organization may conduct more than one
(1) street solicitation fundraiser of up to two (2) consecutive days in length
per year. Permits may only be requested for dates between April 1 and November
15, inclusive.
   F.   Age; Safety Vest and Identification Required: Any person engaged in the
act of street solicitation shall be eighteen (18) years of age or more and
shall be wearing a high visibility yellow or orange safety vest and clear
identification of the organization undertaking the solicitation.
   G.   Safety; Adherence to Traffic Regulations:
      1.   Solicitors shall not approach a moving vehicle or one that does not
have a window down. Solicitors shall approach only after an occupant has given
some sign of assent to approach.
      2.   Solicitors shall only enter the roadway while the traffic signal for
that lane is red and shall not enter the roadway while traffic is moving.
      3.   No solicitor shall at any time enter or remain in the traveled
portion of the roadway or solicit in a manner which impedes the flow of
traffic.
      4.   No person shall solicit in the public right-of-way at any time or
place not designated in the application permit under which the person is
conducting the solicitation.
   H.   Locations; Hours: Solicitations shall only be conducted at approved
traffic control intersections, as designated in the approved permit, when
traffic has come to a full stop. Based on the safety of potential street
solicitors and the safety of motorists, and considering the safe and orderly
flow of traffic, solicitations may be permitted only during daylight hours, but
not earlier than seven o’clock (7:00) a.m. and not later than six o’clock (6:
00) p.m. Central Time, and only at signalized intersection within the corporate
limits of the Village of Oak Lawn.
   I.   Permits: The village clerk shall issue individual permits to street
solicitors affiliated with organizations meeting the application requirements
of this chapter, subject to the limitations above. However, no more than one
permit shall be issued by the Village for the same date for the same
intersection. If applicants affiliated with two (2) or more organizations apply
for permits for the same dates for the same intersection, the village clerk
shall resolve this conflict on a first come, first served basis, based upon the
date and time of application. All street solicitors shall carry, and show on
request, a copy of their permit for street solicitation. Solicitors may only
solicit on behalf of a permitted organization and such solicitation may only
occur during a permitted charitable solicitation event.
   J.   Violations; Adverse Weather: Any violations of the provisions of this
chapter or extraordinarily adverse weather conditions may cause the village to
suspend all soliciting activities.
   K.   Penalty: Any person or organization, charitable or other, violating the
prohibition of this chapter against street solicitation except as expressly
permitted shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day of
violation, and each violating solicitor at each violating location shall be
considered a separate offense under this chapter. Prior violations shall be
considered valid cause to deny subsequent permit applications. (Ord. 24-19-70)
CHAPTER 6
MERCHANDISING
ARTICLE A. COAL YARDS AND LUMBERYARDS
SECTION:
3-6A-1: Coal Yards
3-6A-1-1: Definition
3-6A-1-2: Application For License
3-6A-1-3: Storage Regulations
3-6A-2: Lumberyards
3-6A-1: COAL YARDS:
3-6A-1-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this Chapter, the term "coal yard" shall mean any building,
enclosure, lot or other place where any anthracite, bituminous or lignite coal,
briquette coke, petroleum coke or any other manufactured or patented fuel not
sold by liquid or metered measure, is kept for sale, sold or offered for sale.
(1951 Code
11-2-1)
3-6A-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The application for a license to operate or maintain a coal yard shall state
the location of such coal yard and the name of the person maintaining or
operating the same 1 . (1951 Code
11-2-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Title.
3-6A-1-3: STORAGE REGULATIONS:
   A.   Flammable Liquids: No coal, coke or other solid fuel kept in any coal
yard shall be stored for sale in the same building with fuel oil, gasoline, or
other flammable liquids unless separated therefrom by a fireproof wall.
   B.   Boilers And Furnaces: It shall be the duty of every person conducting
or operating a coal yard to store all soft coal away from the brickwork of
boilers and furnaces.
   C.   Prevention Of Spontaneous Combustion: Whenever coal in storage or
stockpiles in any coal yard shows indications of spontaneous ignition or gives
off gases, it shall be the duty of the licensee, agent or person in charge or
control of the premises to turn over and overhaul such coal pile and remove all
portions of coal showing indications of ignition or coking. The floor or ground
surface of all coal yards shall at all times be kept free from flammable waste
material and accumulations of combustible waste materials. (1951 Code
11-2-4)
3-6A-2: LUMBERYARDS:
The application for a license to keep, conduct or maintain a lumberyard or a
place for the sale, storing or keeping of lumber shall set forth the name of
the applicant and the place where it is desired to keep such lumberyard or the
place to be used for the storage or sale of lumber 1 . (1951 Code
11-9-2)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Title.
ARTICLE B. JUNK DEALERS 1
SECTION:
3-6B-1: Stolen Goods
3-6B-2: Vehicles To Be Marked
3-6B-3: Licenses
3-6B-4: Restrictions
3-6B-5: Definitions
3-6B-6: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Title.
3-6B-1: STOLEN GOODS:
Every junk dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any goods, article
or things of value which may have been lost or stolen shall, upon demand,
produce such article or things to any member of the Police Department for
examination. (1951 Code
11-8-3)
3-6B-2: VEHICLES TO BE MARKED:
Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear
thereon in legible characters, the name and address of the owner thereof. (1951
Code
11-8-4)
3-6B-3: LICENSES:
Every junk dealer shall obtain all licenses required of such junk dealer, and
pay such fees for said licenses, as are set forth in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Title. (Ord. 87-22-97)
3-6B-4: RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to rummage through any items
placed for collection by the Village's refuse collector so as to cause, permit
or suffer any of said items, including, but not limited to, garbage or
offensive substances, to be scattered about, or to remain at the location at
which they were placed for collection by the Village's refuse collector other
than as prescribed in the garbage, refuse and debris regulations contained in
Title 8, Chapter 5 of this Code.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any junk dealer to collect, obtain, possess,
rummage through or pick up any recyclable item placed for collection as part of
the Village recycling program.
   C.   Under its home rule powers, the Village hereby restricts the hours
during which a junk dealer may collect, obtain or procure items set out for
collection by the Village's refuse collector to three o'clock (3:00) P.M. to
ten o'clock (10:00) P.M.
   D.   All junk dealer licenses issued within the Village shall contain a
statement in regard to the restrictions set forth in subsections A, B and C of
this Section, as well as the requirement set forth in Section
3-6B-2 of this Article. (Ord. 89-4-9)
3-6B-5: DEFINITIONS:
JUNK: When used in this Article, shall mean and include old iron, chain, brass,
copper, tin, lead or other base metals, old rope, old bags, rags, wastepaper,
paper clippings, scraps of woolens, clips, bagging, rubber, wood, plastic and
glass, empty bottles of different kinds and sizes when the number of each kind
or size is less than one gross, and all articles and things discarded or no
longer used as a manufactured article composed of, or consisting of, any one or
more of the materials or articles herein mentioned.
JUNK DEALER: When used in this Article, shall include every person, firm or
corporation that shall engage at a junk store in the business of buying,
selling, bartering or exchanging, or that shall collect, receive, store or hold
in possession for sale, barter or exchange any of the things defined herein as
"junk", whether dealing at wholesale or at retail, or as a junk peddler.
JUNK PEDDLER: When used in this Article, shall mean and include every person
who uses a "junk wagon" as defined herein and travels from place to place
within the Village for the purpose of purchasing, collecting, obtaining,
procuring or receiving junk, or makes a business of purchasing or collecting,
obtaining, procuring or receiving junk from anyone who desires to sell it or
give it away, and carries it away upon purchasing, collecting, obtaining,
procuring, or receiving it.
JUNK WAGON: When used in this Article, shall mean every truck, wagon,
automobile, pushcart or other vehicle used by a junk dealer or junk peddler in
the collection, disposition or transportation of junk from one place to
another. (Ord. 89-4-9)
3-6B-6: PENALTY:
Any person who violates the provisions of this Article shall be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00), nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). (Ords. 87-22-97, 99-5-11)

3-6C-1: Definition
3-6C-2: Application for License

The word "florist" as used in this Article shall be construed to mean any
building, room, stand, enclosure, premises, place, establishment or part of

or offering or keeping for sale at wholesale or retail, flowers, plants, trees
or shrubs of all varieties and description. (1951 Code

name and address of the applicant, a description of the place where the
business is to be conducted and the name and home address of the proprietor,
owner and person designated to manage such place of business 1 . (1951 Code
11-5-3)

  3-1-1-7 of this Municipal Code for license fee.
3-6C-3: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
Every establishment where the business of a florist is conducted, managed or
carried on shall be kept in a clean and sanitary condition. No decayed,

possession, growing or disposition of noxious, diseased or infected plants,

ARTICLE E. CONSUMER COMMODITIES
SECTION:
3-6E-1: Definitions
3-6E-2: Price Marking and Display
3-6E-3: Exceptions to Provisions
3-6E-1: DEFINITIONS:
CONSUMER COMMODITY: Any article, product or commodity of any kind or class,
which is produced or distributed for sale at retail to the general public.
PERSON: Any individual, association, partnership or corporation.
SELLING PRICE: The price at which a consumer commodity is sold at retail on any
given date. In the case of commodities weighted by retailers, the selling price
shall only be computed by using the price per one pound as the basis for the
sale; provided, that the metric system may be employed where customary. (Ords.
78-18-44, 78-27-64)
3-6E-2: PRICE MARKING AND DISPLAY:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to display for sale any consumer
commodity unless the selling price is accurately stated in a clear and
conspicuous manner. On any pre-packaged consumer commodity, except those sold
through vending machines, the selling price shall be marked directly on the
package.
   B.   On any consumer commodity which is not pre-packaged, the selling price
shall be stated on a sign contiguous to the point of display of the consumer
commodity so priced. (Ords. 78-18-44, 78-27-64, 78-29-79)
3-6E-3: EXCEPTIONS TO PROVISIONS:
The following items are exempt from the price marking requirements of Section
3-6E-2 above:
   A.   Individual packages of liquor, motor oils, candy, cigars, cigarettes,
razor blades, and small packages of commodities displayed at the check-out
stands, at aisle ends directly across from the check-out stand, or at service
islands, may have a selling price indicated by means of individual signs
adjacent to each commodity or by a general sign stating the selling price of a
group of similar commodities such as hosiery, underwear, shirts, bedsheets,
spreads, pillow cases, batteries, paint and one unit size packages of ice cream
novelties.
      Examples:
         "All gum $0.15 per package".
         "20W motor oil $0.75".
         "10W30 motor oil $0.95".
   B.   Individual cans of frozen fruit juices, envelopes of powdered drinks,
jars of baby foods and continuity or premium offerings may be price marked by
means of individual signs.
      Example:
         "All 71/2 ozs. baby food jars $0.22"
   C.   Multipack commodities may be marked with a total selling price for the
complete multipack unit. The price may be on carrying handle attaching the cans
or bottles. Individual cans or bottles within this multipack unit need not be
marked with a selling price.
      Example: "Soft drinks 6 for $1.00".
   D.   That portion of a display of sale commodities used strictly for display
purposes and not expected to be sold during normal customer response to
advertising may be exempt from selling price marking, provided that portion is
not directly available to customers.
      Example: A section of unpriced packages of canned corn covered with other
packages of canned corn which are marked with a selling price. The amount of a
commodity expected to be sold during a sale period shall be based upon the
individual businesses' previous sales of the identical or similar commodity at
a comparable price at the same location.
   E.   Unit pricing of individual packages of cold cuts in delicatessen
departments displayed on rods may be exempt from the unit pricing requirements
of Section
3-6E-2, provided they are displayed by grouping specific weight categories,
such as eight (8) ounces together, and a sign is clearly and conspicuously
displayed advising consumers "all commodities on rods in this section are
grouped by weight category".
   F.   As an alternative to the price marking requirements of Section
3-6E-2, a retailer may put in place an alternative price notification system,
provided said retailer, and the alternative price notification system, comply
with the following requirements:
      1.   All retailers using an alternative price notification system must
register with the Department of Quality Control. Such registration shall be in
a form as required by the Department of Quality Control and shall, as a
minimum, include the name of the retailer, the location of the store(s) in
which the alternative price notification system has been put in place, a brief
description of the type of system being used, and the name of an individual at
the store who can be contacted in regard to the alternative price notification
system.
      2.   The alternative price notification system must include shelf tags on
conventional grocery shelves which indicate item, size and retail price of each
consumer commodity in a clear and conspicuous manner at the location where each
such commodity is displayed for sale. Said shelf tags shall at all times
indicate the correct retail price, and shall be immediately changed upon any
change in the retail price, whether by reason of a sale on the corresponding
consumer commodity or otherwise.
      3.   The alternative price notification system must be set up so that
each sale is documented by a receipt given to each purchaser which shall
indicate each consumer commodity purchased by name, the selling price of each
such commodity, and the model number, size, weight measure or count where
appropriate.
      4.   The alternative price notification system must operate with a ratio
of no greater than one incorrect price charge for every fifty (50) consumer
items purchased, or ninety eight percent (98%), in accordance with industry
standards for error as to such systems. Once a pricing error is brought to the
attention of the retailer, his agents, or employees, said error shall be
immediately corrected.
      5.   All retailers using an alternative price notification system shall
provide for an automatic double check of such systems whereby a programmer
other than the original programmer verifies the accuracy of the computerized
register system each time that said system is reprogrammed. If an alternative
price notification system includes a computerized system partially controlled
off the store premises, said system must be automatically double checked by a
person on the store premises before the price is exposed to the consumer.
      6.   All retailers using an alternative price notification system shall
maintain a file as to complaints from consumers in regard to the system. Said
retailers shall file a report on a quarterly basis with the Department of
Quality Control. Said reports shall be due on the fifteenth of January, April,
July and October and cover any complaints in regard to the alternative price
notification system received by the retailer during the preceding three (3)
calendar months. Said reports shall indicate the name of the complainant, the
date of the complaint, the location of the store the complaint is in regard to,
the nature of the complaint, and how the complaint was resolved. If no
complaints have been received by a retailer during the three (3) calendar
months' period prior to a quarterly report due date, a letter to this effect
shall be filed with the Department of Quality Control in lieu of the required
report.
      7.   The savings realized by reason of using an alternative price
notification system shall be passed on to the consumer. (Ords. 78-26-70, 84-15-
46)

SERVICES

SECTION:
3-7A-1: Application for License, Investigation
3-7A-2: Prohibited Act, Sales on Public Ways

Applications for auctioneers' licenses shall state the place of business, if
any, intended to be occupied; and the names of any employees, not to exceed two
(2), who are to be authorized to conduct auctions under the authority of the
license 1 . The Chief of Police shall investigate the character of every
applicant for an auctioneer's license and no such license shall issue to any
person who is not of good character. (1951 Code 11-1-2, 11-1-3)

  3-1-1-7 of this Code for license fee.
3-7A-2: PROHIBITED ACT, SALES ON PUBLIC WAYS:
No person shall sell, or attempt to sell, or offer for sale at public auction,
any goods, chattels or personal or real property of any kind upon the public
streets or sidewalks of the Village. (1951 Code 11-1-4)
3-7A-3: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
