conducted by a public officer by virtue of any authority contained in a
mortgage or trust deed. (1951 Code 11-1-5)
ARTICLE B. AUTOMOBILE SERVICES
SECTION:
3-7B-1: Automobile Filling Stations
3-7B-1-1: Definition
3-7B-1-2: Application for License
3-7B-1-3: License Nontransferable
3-7B-1-4: Fire Prevention Regulations
3-7B-1-5: Compliance with Other Provisions
3-7B-1-6: Inspections
3-7B-2: Self-Service and Service Stations
3-7B-2-1: Definitions
3-7B-2-2: Self-Service Station Licensing Provisions
3-7B-2-3: Self-Service Station Rules
3-7B-2-4: Prohibited Conduct at Service Stations
3-7B-3: Public Garages
3-7B-3-1: Definition
3-7B-3-2: Contents of License and Application
3-7B-1: AUTOMOBILE FILLING STATIONS:
3-7B-1-1: DEFINITION:
The term "automobile filling station" as used in this Section is hereby defined
as any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other place within the
Village where a container or containers, tank or tanks, either portable or
stationary, and containing either carbon, bisulphite, gasoline, naphtha,
benzole, hydrocarbon (gas drips) liquefied petroleum gas, acetone, kerosene,
turpentine, or other flammable liquids having a flash point below one hundred
sixty five degrees (165°) F., are kept or located for sale, or the distributing
of any such liquids from such container or tank; provided, however, that the
provisions of this Section shall not apply to any place where such flammable
liquids are kept or sold for medicinal purposes only. (1951 Code
11-4-1)
3-7B-1-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
An application for an automobile filling station license shall set forth the
name and address of the owner or operator of the filling station, the location
of the filling station, a description of each container or tank installed or to
be installed upon the premises, and the capacity of each measured in gallons,
and the type of construction of each building situated upon the premises 1 .
(1951 Code
11-4-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Code for license fee.
3-7B-1-3: LICENSE NONTRANSFERABLE:
No automobile filling station license granted under the provisions of this
Section shall be assigned or transferred to any person other than the licensee
named therein to do business or act under such license. (1951 Code
11-4-6)
3-7B-1-4: FIRE PREVENTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   Smoking: It shall be unlawful for any person to permit smoking in any
automobile filling station.
   B.   Use of Flammable Liquids for Cleaning: Gasoline, benzine, naphtha and
similar flammable liquids shall not be used for washing or cleaning purposes
within any automobile filling station nor in the open air within a distance of
fifty feet (50') of any repair pit or any opening from any basement space.
Provisions of the Basic Fire Prevention Code, 1984, shall apply 1 .
   C.   Waste Disposal: Waste oil or other flammable liquids shall be stored in
metal containers pending removal from the premises. No such waste shall be
permitted to drain into any sewer or storm water drainage system. Rags and
soiled waste shall be kept in metal containers. (1951 Code
11-4-7,
11-4-8,
11-4-9)
 
Notes
1 2. See subsection 7-3-1A of this Code.
3-7B-1-5: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER PROVISIONS:
The construction and equipment of filling stations, including tanks, and the
requirements for safety clearances around same, shall be made and maintained in
accordance with the provisions of the Building Code and other applicable
regulations. (1951 Code 11-4-10)
3-7B-1-6: INSPECTIONS:
Automobile filling stations shall be inspected by the Fire Chief or his
representative at least once every year. (1951 Code 11-4-10)
3-7B-2: SELF-SERVICE AND SERVICE STATIONS:
3-7B-2-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Section, the following words and phrases shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them by these rules and regulations:
APPROVED SELF-SERVICE DISPENSING DEVICE: Any device listed by Underwriters
Laboratories and approved by the Village, but not including coin or card-
operated devices, used for the dispensing of such flammable and combustible
liquids into the fuel tanks of motor vehicles.
AUTHORIZED ATTENDANT: The owner, employee or agent who is authorized by the
licensee hereunder to dispense gasoline and other motor fuels. An authorized
attendant must be sixteen (16) years of age or older.
OWNER: Any person, firm or corporation holding title, lease, license or any
interest in a service station or self-service station.
SELF-SERVICE STATION: That portion of property of a service station where
flammable and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and
subsequently dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel
tanks of motor vehicles by persons other than an authorized service station
attendant.
SERVICE STATION: Any place of business where flammable and combustible liquids
(Class I, II or III liquids as set forth in Article 2, BOCA Basic Fire
Prevention Code, 1984) used as motor fuels are stored and subsequently
dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel tanks of motor
vehicles. (Ord. 79-29-59; 1985 Code)
3-7B-2-2: SELF-SERVICE STATION LICENSING PROVISIONS:
   A.   License Required: No person shall engage in the business of a self-
service station without first obtaining a license therefor.
   B.   Application for License: An application for a self-service license
shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of Section
3-1-2 of this Code and shall be accompanied by complete, detailed plans, in
triplicate, for each service station sought to be used as a self-service
station. Such plans shall be drawn to scale, and shall include the following:
      1.   Lot lines and dimensions;
      2.   Building lines and dimensions;
      3.   Location and size of tanks and pump islands;
      4.   Location of control station;
      5.   Type, make, model and location of dispensing devices or equipment;
      6.   Fire extinguisher locations;
      7.   Clearances;
      8.   Such other relevant information as may be requested by the Fire
Department of the Village.
   C.   Issuance of License, Term and Display: No construction of a self-
service station or modification of an existing service station to conduct self-
service business shall be commenced until such application and plans are given
written approval by the Fire Department of the Village and no such self-service
station shall open for business until inspected and approved by the Fire
Department and until the Chief of the Fire Department issues a self-service
station license, which must be displayed prominently, at all times, at such
self-service station. Said license shall be issued for a period of twelve (12)
months. (Ord. 79-29-59)
3-7B-2-3: SELF-SERVICE STATION RULES:
The following rules shall be followed and enforced at all self-service
stations, and the violation of any one or more of said rules shall constitute
good and just cause for suspension or revocation of a self-service station
license pursuant to Section
3-1-6 of this Code:
   A.   Use of Unattended Devices: The installation or use of unattended self-
service dispensing devices for motor fuel of any kind is hereby prohibited.
   B.   Prohibited Use of Premises: No dwelling or sleeping facilities of any
kind for the owner, authorized attendant or any other person shall be permitted
at a self-service station.
   C.   Non-Public Locations: Dispensing of such flammable and combustible
liquids at locations not open to the public does not require an attendant or
supervisor. Such locations may be used by commercial, industrial, governmental
or manufacturing establishments for fueling vehicles used in connection with
their businesses. However, this shall not include private fraternal clubs or
associations.
   D.   Special Dispensing Devices: Special dispensing devices for motor fuels
are not to be installed or used without prior written approval of the Village
Fire Department.
   E.   Fire Extinguishers: One type ABC fire extinguisher with a capacity of
ten (10) pounds shall be provided for each pump island containing four (4) or
less dispensing pumps; on pump islands containing more than four (4) dispensing
pumps, an additional extinguisher shall be provided for each four (4)
additional dispensing pumps or fraction thereof. Such extinguishers shall be
located at points approved by the Fire Department, away from the dispensing
area but close enough to the dispensing area to be readily available (not to
exceed one hundred feet (100'). Such extinguishers shall be plainly marked,
properly mounted and protected from the weather, and shall be maintained in
operable condition and available at all times when the self- service station is
open to the public. All employees of a self-service station shall be thoroughly
instructed as to the location and proper use of such extinguishers; and shall,
upon request, demonstrate their ability in such use to the approval of
representatives of the Fire Department of the Village.
   F.   Signs:
      1.   Signs giving instructions for the operation of gasoline dispensing
equipment must be conspicuously posted at each self-service station.
      2.   Signs bearing the following words must conspicuously be posted on
each gasoline pump island where self-service is offered:
Self Service Island
WARNING:
(A) Stop Engine;
(B) No Smoking;
(C) It is unlawful and dangerous for any one
other than the authorized attendant to dispense
gasoline into approved containers;
(D) It is unlawful and dangerous to dispense
gasoline without an authorized attendant on duty.
      3.   The signs shall be made of all-weather rigid material and the
wording, lettering, size, design, material, mounting and location of said sign
shall be subject to the reasonable approval of the Village Fire Department.
   G.   Protection of Devices: All fuel-dispensing units shall be mounted or
protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner reasonably
approved by the Village Fire Department.
   H.   Control Station:
      1.   Every self-service station shall maintain a control station in a
location approved by the Fire Department, equipped in such a manner that the
flow of liquid fuel from any or all fuel- dispensing units may be stopped from
such control station. A master electric switch shall be maintained at such
control station so that electric power and pump lighting to all pumps may be
disconnected at one time, and said switch shall be plainly marked and easily
accessible.
      2.   The control station shall be located at ground level not more than
one hundred feet (100") from the farthest pump and shall be so located that the
authorized attendant of such control station shall have a clear and
unobstructed view of all pumps.
      3.   The authorized attendant shall at all times be able to communicate
with persons in the dispensing area. The Fire Department of the Village may, if
necessary, require a communications system between the control station and each
pump island.
   I.   Authorized Attendants:
      1.   Approved self-service dispensing devices are permitted at service
stations available and open to the public; provided, that all dispensing of
such flammable and combustible liquids by a person other than the service
station authorized attendant is under the supervision and control of a
qualified authorized attendant, and the dispensing nozzle is a listed
automatic-closing type and must be approved by the Village Fire Department.
      2.   It shall be the responsibility of the authorized attendant to:
         a.   Dispense such flammable and combustible liquids into approved
portable containers;
         b.   Control sources of ignition; and
         c.   Immediately handle accidental spills and fire extinguishers, if
needed.
The authorized attendant on duty shall be mentally and physically capable of
performing the functions and assuming the responsibility prescribed in this
paragraph.
      3.   At all times when a self-service station is open for public use, the
number of authorized attendants on duty shall be sufficient to safely operate
the self-service station. Not less than one authorized attendant shall be on
duty. No motor fuel shall be dispensed at any time when such authorized
attendant is not at or near the control station or pump island. The authorized
attendant's primary duty shall be to supervise the dispensing of motor fuels,
motor oils and services normally related to such dispensing. Such authorized
attendant shall refuse service to any person to be unable to dispense fuel
safely, and shall shut off the dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow
instructions in compliance with the rules. All authorized attendants and other
employees of the service station shall be thoroughly instructed in the
operation and use of the communication system, the control station and fire
extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units and safety
regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels.
   J.   Sale Of Food And Grocery Items: When any self-service station also
sells food or grocery items, there shall be at least two (2) attendants on duty
at all times when gas is also being sold (1 to observe and control the gasoline
dispensing and the other to make sales of food and grocery items); except, that
if the fire department finds that the layout of the station is to allow an
attendant selling food or grocery items to clearly observe the dispensing of
gasoline and safely control the dispensing area, the fire department may
certify in writing that such self-service station is permitted to operate with
one attendant. (Ords. 79-29-59, 83-17-41)
3-7B-2-4: PROHIBITED CONDUCT AT SERVICE STATIONS:
Except at service stations which hold current and valid self- service station
licenses issued hereunder, no person other than an owner of a service station
or an authorized attendant, shall use or operate any motor fuel dispensing
equipment at any service station. No owner of a service station shall cause or
permit any person to violate the provisions of this section. (Ord. 79-29-59)
3-7B-3: PUBLIC GARAGES:
3-7B-3-1: DEFINITION:
The words "public garage" as used in this section shall be held to mean, and
are hereby defined as meaning any building or other place within the village,
where automobiles, trucks or any similar self-propelled vehicles are kept or
let for hire or reward to any person, whether such vehicles are so hired out or
let with or without an operator for same; or where such vehicles are kept ready
for use and where rent is paid to the keeper thereof for such keeping, and
where such vehicles are repaired or serviced. (1951 Code 12-5-1)
3-7B-3-2: CONTENTS OF LICENSE AND APPLICATION 1 :
   A.   The application for a public garage license shall set forth the name of
the applicant and if an individual or individuals, the place of his or their
residence, and if a corporation, the names of the officers and their places of
residence. Such application shall also contain the location of the place at
which it is intended to keep such garage and the number of vehicles to be kept
in such garage for the purpose of letting for hire or reward.
   B.   Each public garage license shall set forth the location of the garage
and the number of vehicles which the licensees keep or intend to keep at such
licensed garage. (1951 Code 12-5-3, 12-5-5)
 
Notes
1 1. See section 3-1-1-7 of this title for license fee.
ARTICLE C. DRY CLEANING AND DYEING ESTABLISHMENTS 1
SECTION:
3-7C-1: Definitions
3-7C-2: Sanitary Conditions
3-7C-3: Use Of Dangerous Substances
3-7C-4: Quality Of Work
3-7C-5: Inspections
3-7C-6: Violations
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-1-7 of this title for license fee.
3-7C-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this article:
CLEANING AND DYEING ESTABLISHMENT: Includes any place or vehicle where the
service of dry cleaning, wet cleaning as a process incidental to dry cleaning,
dyeing, spotting and/or finishing any fabric is rendered for hire, or is sold,
resold or offered for sale or resale.
CLEANING PLANT: Includes any cleaning and dyeing establishment equipped to
perform dry cleaning.
DRY CLEANING: The process of cleaning fabrics by immersion and agitation, or by
immersion only, in volatile solvents (including, but not by way of limitation,
solvents of petroleum distillate type, the coal tar distillate type, and the
chlorinated hydrocarbon type) and processes incidental thereto (including, but
without limitation, spotting cleaning, wet cleaning and finishing).
FABRIC: Any article of wearing apparel, household furnishings, rugs, textiles,
fur and leather.
FINISHING: The process of pressing and/or reshaping any fabric, which is
designed to restore as nearly as possible the shape, dimension and contour of
said fabric.
PROPRIETOR: Any person by or for whom a cleaning plant is operated.
RETAIL OUTLET: Includes any cleaning and dyeing establishment located within
the village where dry cleaning is sold, solicited or offered for sale, directly
to the retail consumer, and also includes any automobile, truck or other
vehicle operated within the village from which dry cleaning is sold, solicited
or offered for sale, directly to the retail consumer.
RETAILER: Any person or member of the cleaning and dyeing trade by or for whom
a retail outlet is operated.
SPOTTING: The process designed to remove spots or stains which remain in a
fabric after it has been subjected to the other process of dry cleaning. (1951
Code 12-7-1)
3-7C-2: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   Premises And Equipment: Every building or premises used or occupied by
a cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet located
within the village or used or occupied by a cleaning and dyeing plant not
located in the village but which has a retail outlet in the village, shall be
kept in a clean and sanitary condition as to its floors, sidewalls, ceilings,
woodwork and fixtures and as to the tools, machinery, equipment and storage
facilities used and kept in any such buildings or premises. At regular
intervals and at such other times as may be deemed necessary and as shall be
specified by the health and sanitation officer, the floors, sidewalls,
ceilings, woodwork and fixtures of any such building and premises and the
tools, machinery, equipment and storage facilities used or kept thereon shall
be washed or sprayed with a disinfectant in solution or other liquid form or
vapor approved by the Health and Sanitation Officer.
   B.   Employees: No person affected or afflicted with tuberculosis or any
other infectious or communicable disease shall be employed in any dry cleaning
establishment, cleaning plant or retail outlet located within the Village, or
in any cleaning and dyeing establishment or cleaning plant which is not located
in the Village but which has a retail outlet therein. The Health and Sanitation
Officer may require each employee of such cleaning and dyeing plant, cleaning
plant or retail outlet to be examined by a licensed and practicing physician
and may require any proprietor or retailer to file in the office of the Health
and Sanitation Officer, a certificate of health and freedom from tuberculosis
or other infectious or communicable disease for each person employed by him as
such proprietor or retailer, which certificate shall be signed by a licensed
and practicing physician. (1951 Code 12-7-3, 12-7-4; 1985 Code)
3-7C-3: USE OF DANGEROUS SUBSTANCES:
   A.   No chemical or other substance which is poisonous, injurious or
unwholesome to human beings and which is not essential to the service or
process of dry cleaning, dyeing, spotting or finishing shall be used in
rendering any dry cleaning service or performing any such process in any
cleaning and dyeing plant located within the Village or in any cleaning and
dyeing plant or cleaning plant which is not located within the Village but has
a retail outlet within the Village.
   B.   In case any such chemical or other substance which is poisonous,
injurious or unwholesome to human beings is used by any such cleaning and
dyeing establishment or cleaning plant in rendering any such service or
performing any such process essential thereto, then such chemical or other
substance shall be completely removed from the fabric dry cleaned, dyed or
spotted or finished or such chemical or other substance shall be completely and
entirely neutralized and rendered harmless and not noxious to human beings
before such fabric is permitted to leave such establishment or plant for
delivery to the person entitled to the possession thereof upon completion of
the process. (1951 Code 12-7-5)
3-7C-4: QUALITY OF WORK:
   A.   No finished or unfinished dry cleaning sold, solicited or offered for
sale within the Village shall show, upon the dry cleaned fabric being rerinsed
in water white solvent (one gallon to one pound of garment weight), sufficient
dirt or soil residue or other foreign deposits to darken dry solvent below
fifteen (15) Saybold Chorometer.
   B.   Finished dry cleaning sold, solicited or offered for sale within the
Village shall be free from solvent and chemical odors. (1951 Code 12-7-5)
3-7C-5: INSPECTIONS:
The Chief of the Fire Department or his designated representative shall have
the right to enter any building or premises situated within the Village and
used or occupied by any cleaning and dyeing establishment, cleaning plant or
retail outlet in order to examine same and to determine whether or not said
building and premises, or any material, articles or fabric dry cleaned, dyed,
spotted or finished as received, used, kept, maintained or stored on said
building or premises conform to the fire regulations within the Village. (1951
Code 12-7-6; 1985 Code)
3-7C-6: VIOLATIONS:
Any proprietor or retailer who shall represent any fabric as dry cleaned which
does not comply with the requirements of this Article, or who shall violate any
of the provisions of this Article shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. (1951 Code
12-7-12)

3-7D-2: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
The premises used for a barber shop shall be kept in a clean and sanitary
condition and all persons engaged in the operation of such barber shop must
keep themselves clean both as to person and clothing. Utensils and tools must
be sterilized before being used on a patron. It shall be unlawful to keep as a
barber or other employee in any such shop, any person afflicted with a
contagious disease of any kind. The Health and Sanitation Officer shall make or
cause to be made such inspections as may be necessary to insure compliance with
the provisions of this Article. (1951 Code 12-1-4; 1985 Code)

ARTICLE F. ADVERTISING BENCHES
SECTION:
3-7F-1: Permit And Application
3-7F-2: Permit Fee
3-7F-3: Conditions Of Permit
3-7F-4: Revocation Of Permit
3-7F-5: Advertising Benches On Private Property
3-7F-6: Penalty
3-7F-7: Permit Renewal, Five Year Option/Preference Period
3-7F-1: PERMIT AND APPLICATION:
   A.   Applications may be made to and on forms approved by the department of
quality control for rental permits allowing the installation of advertising
benches on public property along the streets and thoroughfares within the
village.
   B.   Each application for an advertising bench permit shall be accompanied
by the correct fee as defined in section
3-7F-2 of this article and said fee shall not be prorated.
   C.   Each year, applications for the one year advertising bench permit shall
be filed no sooner than April 1 preceding the permit year for which the
application applies. In the event that April 1 falls on a Saturday, Sunday or
holiday, the first business day after April 1 shall serve as the first day for
filing said applications.
   D.   The application for an advertising bench permit shall include:
      1.   The name, address and phone number of the business applying for the
license;
      2.   The type of ownership of the business, i.e. whether individual,
partnership, or corporation, etc.;
      3.   The names, complete residence addresses and residence telephone
numbers of all owners of the business; and if any such owner is a corporation,
of the principal officers and registered agent of such corporation;
      4.   A sketch showing the exact location of the proposed site for the
advertising bench in relation to property lines, building lines, street lines
and other facilities or improvements within fifty feet (50') of the proposed
location of said bench;
      5.   A statement as to the reason there is a need for the seating
services, provided by an advertising bench, at the proposed location for the
advertising bench;
      6.   Such other information as may be required by the village, from time
to time.
   E.   As the number of sites, at which advertising benches may be located,
may be limited by the provisions of this article, advertising bench permit
applications shall be processed in the order in which they are filed with the
department of quality control. In the event that two (2) or more applications
are received simultaneously, for the placement of an advertising bench at the
same location, the department of quality control shall break ties and determine
the order of filing as to each separate location, individually, by means of a
lottery or other fair and impartial method of random selection. All concerned
applicants shall be notified by mail of the date, time and place that the
department of quality control shall conduct said lottery or other fair and
impartial method of random selection.
   F.   The department of quality control shall either deny the application,
stating the reasons for such denial, or grant said permit subject to the
following terms:
      1.   The term "advertising bench" as used in this code shall mean any
seat located upon public property along any public street for the accommodation
of passersby or persons awaiting transportation and which contains thereon an
advertisement. The design of such bench shall be subject to approval by the
department of quality control. Detailed design plans shall be submitted with an
application for an advertising bench permit.
      2.   Advertising benches shall be placed at such locations applied for
and for which the applicant has shown, and the department of quality control
has determined, that an actual need for the seating services of said benches
exist. In addition, advertising benches shall only be placed at such locations
determined by the department of quality control not to cause an undue health or
safety hazard, interfere with the right of the public to the proper use of the
streets and thoroughfares, or cause a nuisance as proscribed by either 740
Illinois Compiled Statutes, or title 8, chapter 1 of this code. Provided
further, however, that no advertising bench shall be placed, installed, used or
maintained:
         a.   So as to reduce the clear, continuous combined sidewalk and/or
parkway width to less than five feet (5');
         b.   Within fifteen feet (15') of any fire hydrant or other emergency
facility;
         c.   Within twenty five feet (25') of any intersecting driveway, alley
or street;
         d.   Within ten feet (10') of any marked crosswalk;
         e.   At any location where the width of paved clear space in any
direction for the passageway of pedestrians is reduced to less than five feet
(5');
         f.   At any location where another advertising bench, for which a
valid permit has been obtained, is located, unless the applicant for the second
advertising bench permit can demonstrate to the department of quality control
an actual need for the placement of more than one bench at said location to
provide adequate seating facilities for the use of pedestrians. (Ord. 85-5-15)
3-7F-2: PERMIT FEE:
The permit fee shall be as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title. (Ord. 03-20-81)
3-7F-3: CONDITIONS OF PERMIT:
The rental permit shall be granted upon the following conditions:
   A.   Within seven (7) days of the end of each permit year, the permittee
shall remove his advertising bench from the property of the village unless the
permittee has obtained another advertising bench rental permit for the
placement of the bench at its current location. In the event that the permittee
fails to remove said bench within the seven (7) day period, the village may
remove and store said bench and the permittee shall be responsible for the
village's costs in removing and storing said bench;
   B.   The permittee, upon the removal of an advertising bench, shall restore
the property of the village to the same condition as when the bench was
initially installed, ordinary wear and tear excepted;
   C.   The permittee shall maintain the bench in good working order and in a
safe and clean condition and keep the immediate area surrounding such bench
free from litter and debris;
   D.   The permittee shall save and hold the village harmless from any and all
liability for any reason whatsoever occasioned upon the bench and shall
furnish, at permittee's expense, such public liability insurance as will
protect permittee and the village from all claims for damage to property or
bodily injury, including death, which may arise from the operation under the
permit or in connection therewith and such policy shall name the village of Oak
Lawn as an additional insured, shall be in an amount not less than one hundred
thousand dollars ($100,000.00) combined single limit for any injury to persons
and/or damaged property, and shall provide that the insurance coverage shall
not be canceled or reduced by the insurance carrier without thirty (30) days'
prior written notice to the village. A certificate of such insurance shall be
provided to the village and maintained before and during the installation of
such benches;
   E.   The permittee shall, prior to placing any advertising bench on public
property, deposit with the village a removal and restoration bond issued by a
bonding company acceptable to the village in an amount sufficient to cover the
total cost of removing and storing each bench placed on public property
hereunder plus the cost to restore each site. Such bond is to provide that if
the permittee fails to remove and restore as required by subsections A and C of
this section, the bonding company shall pay the face amount of the bond to the
village for such removal, storing and restoration;
   F.   Rental permits shall be for a term of one year (May 1 through April 30)
and shall not be assignable;
   G.   Each bench shall contain the name of the owner of said bench along with
an emergency phone number for said owner; and
   H.   If at any time an advertising bench is found located on any public
sidewalk, right of way or public way within the village, without a valid
advertising bench rental permit for said location, the department of quality
control shall notify the owner thereof, in writing that said advertising bench
must be removed. In the event that said advertising bench is not removed within
seven (7) days of the date of the written notice to the owner thereof, the
village may remove and store said advertising bench and the owner thereof shall
be responsible for the village's costs in removing and storing said advertising
bench.
   I.   Such other terms and conditions deemed necessary and reasonable by the
department of quality control and/or the president and board of trustees.
(Ords. 85-5-15, 86-21-86)
3-7F-4: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
   A.   Rental permits issued pursuant to this chapter may be revoked by the
village manager after notice and hearing for any of the following causes:
      1.   Fraud, misrepresentation or any false statement contained in the
application for such a permit;
      2.   Violation of any provision of ordinance regulating such rental
permit; or
      3.   Violation of the terms of the rental permit granted.
Notice of hearing for such a revocation shall be given in writing stating the
grounds of the complaint together with the time and place of hearing and shall
be mailed, postage prepaid, to the permittee at the address given in the rental
permit application at least five (5) days prior to the date set for hearing.
   B.   A person aggrieved by a decision of the village manager in revoking a
rental permit shall have the right to appeal to the president and board of
trustees. Such appeal shall be taken by filing a notice of appeal including a
statement of the grounds for the appeal with the village clerk within ten (10)
days after notice of the decision by the village manager has been given. The
president and board of trustees shall set the time and place for hearing such
appeal and notice of such time and place shall be given in the same manner as
specified hereinabove. The president and board of trustees shall have the power
to reverse, affirm, or modify the decision of the village manager and any such
decision made by the president and board of trustees shall be final.
   C.   In the event that no appeal is taken from the village manager's
decision to revoke a rental permit, the owner of the bench for which the permit
has been revoked shall have ten (10) days from the final date for filing an
appeal in which to remove said bench from the village. In the event that an
appeal is filed and the board of trustees upholds the decision of the village
manager to revoke a rental permit, the owner of the bench for which the permit
has been revoked shall have ten (10) days from the date of the board of
trustees' decision in which to remove said bench from the village. In the event
that the owner of the bench, in either of the above two (2) situations, fails
to remove the bench as required, in the ten (10) day period, the village may
remove and store said bench and the owner of said bench shall be responsible
for the village's cost in removing and storing said bench. (Ord. 85-5-15)
3-7F-5: ADVERTISING BENCHES ON PRIVATE PROPERTY:
Any advertising bench located on private property shall, for purposes of this
code, be considered an advertising sign subject to the rules, regulations,
permit requirements and fees applicable to signs and advertising structures as
set forth in title 6, chapter 8 of this code. (Ord. 86-21-86)
3-7F-6: PENALTY:
In addition to the revocation of permit provisions of section
3-7F-4 of this article, any person, firm or corporation violating the
provisions of this article shall be fined not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). (Ords. 86-21-86, 99-5-11)
3-7F-7: PERMIT RENEWAL, FIVE YEAR OPTION/PREFERENCE PERIOD:
   A.   Once a site has been initially determined appropriate for the location
of an advertising bench by the department of quality control, and an
advertising bench permit has been issued for said site, the holder of said
permit shall be entitled to renew said permit for each of the next four (4)
permit years (the useful life of an advertising bench having been determined to
be 5 years by the department of quality control), without said site being
subject to the lottery, as provided by subsection 3-7F-1E of this article, even
if another person, firm or corporation applies for said site, provided that
each year:
      1.   Said permit holder has complied with all the requirements set forth
in this article; and
      2.   Said permit holder has filed his, her or its application for said
site, as provided by section
3-7F-1 of this article, at the same time as, or before, all other applicants
for said site.
   B.   When an advertising bench permit for a particular site is issued to a
person, firm or corporation other than the person, firm or corporation who held
the permit for said site the previous permit year, said new permittee shall be
entitled to the five (5) year option/preference period for said site, provided
said new permittee complies with the requirements of subsection A of this
section. (Ord. 87-6-25)
ARTICLE G. HOME DAYCARE BUSINESSES
SECTION:
3-7G-1: Application For A Permit
3-7G-2: Conditions Of Operation
3-7G-1: APPLICATION FOR A PERMIT:
Every home daycare business operated in the village shall require an annual
home daycare permit. The application for such permit and for any renewal
thereof shall state the name of the applicant and the place where the business
will be conducted and shall include a copy of the applicant's current state
license issued by the Illinois department of children and family services
("DCFS") pursuant to 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10/1 et seq. The fee for
such permit, or renewal thereof, shall be seventy five dollars ($75.00). The
permit shall be valid only for the period May 1 through April 30. (Ord. 07-07-
26)
3-7G-2: CONDITIONS OF OPERATION:
   A.   The home daycare business shall be conducted in such a manner so that
it does not adversely affect the residential character of the residential
zoning district in which it is located or impinge upon the rights or privileges
of neighboring residential uses.
   B.   The home daycare business shall be operated by a member of the
immediate family residing within the dwelling unit used for the business.
   C.   There shall be no signs, advertising, display or activity that will
indicate from the exterior that the building is being used, in part, for any
purpose other than that of a dwelling.
   D.   Media advertising shall be limited to name and telephone number. The
address of the dwelling unit shall not be used in any advertising.
   E.   In lieu of a village business license, a valid license from DCFS shall
be on file with the village's business regulation officer at all times.
   F.   A state fire marshal's inspection shall be completed satisfactorily,
and a copy of the inspection shall be on file with the village business
regulation officer prior to issuance or renewal of a license.
   G.   All activities, including storage, shall be conducted completely within
the dwelling unit or accessory structures, and in no case shall there be
visible outside storage of goods, supplies or equipment with the exception of
playground equipment.
   H.   Should the licensee violate any of the provisions of this title, the
village may suspend or revoke the permit or may fine the permittee, all as
provided in chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 07-07-26)
ARTICLE H. OUTDOOR FOOD AND BEVERAGE SERVICE
SECTION:
3-7H-1: Application For A Permit
3-7H-2: Permit For Liquor Licensee
3-7H-3: Approval By Police
3-7H-4: Conditions Of Operation
3-7H-1: APPLICATION FOR A PERMIT:
Every outdoor restaurant or cafe operated in the village shall require an
annual outdoor food and beverage service permit, which shall be in addition to
other business or liquor licenses required by the village. No additional fee
shall be charged for such permit. The application for such permit and for any
renewal thereof shall state the name of the applicant, the place where the
outdoor service will be conducted and the number of seating spaces to be
provided and shall include a plan illustrating the area where such outdoor
service will take place. The permit shall be issued in conjunction with a
certificate issued for a restaurant in accordance with the provisions of
chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 07-20-56)
3-7H-2: PERMIT FOR LIQUOR LICENSEE:
When liquor is served on the premises of a restaurant for which an outdoor food
and beverage service permit is sought, the applicant for such permit shall also
apply for a class N liquor license. (Ord. 07-20-56)
3-7H-3: APPROVAL BY POLICE:
Prior to issuance of an outdoor food and beverage service permit, the
application shall be reviewed by the police chief or his designee, and approval
of such permit shall not be granted unless the police chief determines that all
necessary design features (e.g., fencing and location) have been provided so
that such service will not be an impediment to the health and welfare of
customers or passers by. (Ord. 07-20-56)
3-7H-4: CONDITIONS OF OPERATION:
   A.   The outdoor food and beverage service shall be conducted in such a
manner so that it does not adversely affect the character of the zoning
district in which it is located or impinge upon the rights or privileges of
neighboring uses.
   B.   The outdoor food and beverage service area shall be enclosed by a
fence, not less than two feet (2') high, and no portion of the service area
shall be permitted to encroach on a public right of way or sidewalk.
   C.   Exit doors from the business premises to the outdoor food and beverage
service area shall remain unblocked and unimpeded at all times.
   D.   The seating capacity in the outdoor food and beverage service area
shall not be included in the calculation of the off street parking requirement
for the business premises.
   E.   Should the permittee violate any of the provisions of this title, the
village may suspend or revoke the permit or may fine the permittee, all as
provided in chapter 1 of this title. (Ord. 07-20-56)
CHAPTER 8
PRECIOUS METALS DEALERS
SECTION:
3-8-1: Definitions
3-8-2: License Required
3-8-3: Application For License
3-8-4: License Fee
3-8-5: Bond
3-8-6: Display Of License
3-8-7: Records
3-8-8: Prohibited Acts
3-8-9: Report Of Rental By Owner
3-8-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following words as used herein shall be
construed to have the meanings herein ascribed:
ITINERANT PURCHASER OF PRECIOUS METALS: Any person, firm or corporation,
whether as owner, agent or employee, and whether a resident of the Village or
not, who engages in the business of purchasing precious metals as defined
herein in the Village, but who does not rent a store, loft, warehouse, office
space or show room by the year or holds less than a year's lease on any such
space.
LOCAL PRECIOUS METALS DEALER: Any person, firm or corporation who engages in
the business of purchasing precious metals as defined herein in the Village,
and who maintains a permanent place of business in the Village, renting space
therein by the year and holding at least a year's lease on such space.
PRECIOUS METALS: Includes, but is not limited to, gold, silver and platinum, in
such forms as coins, rings, bracelets, necklaces, jewelry of all types,
silverware, and any other item containing such precious metals with a retail
value in excess of twenty five dollars ($25.00). (Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any purchaser of "precious metals" as defined in
Section
3-8-1 of this Chapter to engage in such business within the Village without
first obtaining a license therefor in compliance with the provisions hereof.
(Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applicants for license under this Chapter, whether a person, firm or
corporation, shall file a written sworn application signed by the applicant if
an individual, by all partners if a partnership, and by the president if a
corporation, with the Village Clerk, showing:
   A.   The name or names of the person or persons having the management or
supervision of applicant's business during the time that it is proposed that it
will be carried on in the Village; the local address or addresses of such
person or persons while engaged in such business; the permanent address or
addresses of such person or persons; the capacity in which such person or
persons will act (that is, whether as proprietor, agent or otherwise); the name
and address of the person for whose account the business will be carried on, if
any; and if a corporation, under the laws of what state the same is
incorporated;
   B.   The place or places in the Village where it is proposed to carry on
applicant's business, and the length of time during which it is proposed that
said business shall be conducted;
   C.   The place or places, other than the permanent place of business of the
applicant where applicant, within the six (6) months next preceding the date of
said application, conducted an itinerant business, stating the nature thereof
and giving the post office and street address of any building or office in
which such business was conducted;
   D.   A brief statement of the nature and character of the advertising done
or proposed to be done in order to attract customers, and, if required by the
Village Clerk, copies of all said advertising whether by handbills, circulars,
newspaper advertising, or otherwise, shall be attached to said application as
exhibits thereto. (Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-4: LICENSE FEE:
The fee for such a license shall be as provided in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Municipal Code. Provided, however, that any local precious
metal dealer as defined herein who currently holds a valid regulatory
certificate (license) from the Village pursuant to Section
3-1-1 of this Code and who has paid the current regulatory fee is exempt from
payment of said license fee. (Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-5: BOND:
Before any license, as provided by this Chapter, shall be issued for engaging
in an itinerant business as defined in Section
3-8-1 hereof, such applicant shall file with the Village Clerk a bond running
to the Village in the sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), executed by the
applicant, as principal, and two (2) sureties upon whom service of process may
be made in the State of Illinois, conditioned that the said applicant shall
comply fully with all the ordinances of the Village and the statutes of the
State of Illinois. (Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-6: DISPLAY OF LICENSE:
The license issued under this Chapter shall be post- ed conspicuously in the
place where the itinerant business is to be conducted. (Ord. 81-6-11)
3-8-7: RECORDS:
Every licensee hereunder shall keep a book in which shall be legibly written in
ink at the time of each purchase, an accurate account and description in the
English language of the goods, articles, items or things purchased, the amount
of money paid for each, the time of the purchasing the same, and the name
and address of the person selling said goods, article, item or thing, and the
driver's license and social security number of the seller. In the event the
seller does not have a current driver's license or social security number, two
(2) other items of identification verifying the name, address and identity of
the seller must be used as recorded. No entry made in such book shall be
erased, obliterated or defaced.
The said book, as well as every article or thing purchased, shall be at all
reasonable times open to the inspection of any member of the Village's Police
Department. (Ords. 81-6-11, 81-14-24)
3-8-8: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Resale or Change of Items: No coins shall be resold or changed in any
manner for a period of twenty four (24) hours after purchase by any licensee.
No other goods, articles, items or things containing precious metals shall be
resold or changed in any manner for a period of seventy two (72) hours after
purchase by any licensee.
   B.   Purchase From Minors: No licensee shall purchase any goods, articles,
items or things containing precious metals from any person under the age of
eighteen (18) years. (Ords. 81-6-11, 81-14-24)
3-8-9: REPORT OF RENTAL BY OWNER:
The owner, proprietor or manager of any hotel, motel, store or building of any
type shall report, within eight (8) hours after renting, to the Chief of
Police, the name of any person who shall rent a room or other space for the
purchase or sale of precious metals, giving the location of the room or space
so rented. (Ord. 81-6-11; 1985 Code)
CHAPTER 9
TAXICABS
SECTION:
3-9-1: Definition
3-9-2: Application for License
3-9-3: Restrictions on License
3-9-4: Bond or Insurance Required
3-9-5: Tag or Sticker, Display and Transfer
3-9-6: State License Required
3-9-7: Vehicle Requirements
3-9-8: Operation of Taxicabs
3-9-9: Receipt for Payment of Fare
3-9-10: Prohibited Acts
3-9-1: DEFINITION:
The term "taxicab" as used in this Chapter shall mean and include any vehicle
used to carry passengers for hire but not operating on a fixed route. (1951
Code 12-6-2)
3-9-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
Applications for taxicab licenses shall state the name of the applicant, the
intended place of business and the number of cabs to be operated. If the
applicant is a corporation, the names and addresses of the president and
secretary thereof shall be given 1 .
Whenever the number of taxicabs shall be increased during the license year, the
licensee shall notify the Village Clerk of such change. (1951 Code 12-6-1, 12-
6-4, 23-12-42)
 
Notes
  See Section
1 3-1-1-7 of this Municipal Code for license fee applicable to taxi offices or
  dispatch centers.
3-9-3: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSE:
No such taxicab license shall be issued to or held by any person who is not a
person of good character or who has been convicted of a felony; nor shall such
license be issued to or held by any corporation if any officer thereof would be
ineligible for a license under the foregoing conditions. (1951 Code 12-6-3)
3-9-4: BOND OR INSURANCE REQUIRED:
No taxicab shall be operated unless it is covered by a bond or public liability
insurance policy as required by statute 1 . (1951 Code 12-6-7)
 
Notes
1 2. S.H.A. ch. 95 /2, §§8-101 et. seq.
3-9-5: TAG OR STICKER, DISPLAY AND TRANSFER:
The Village Clerk shall issue suitable tags or stickers for the number of cabs
covered by each license. Such tag or sticker shall be displayed in a prominent
place on each taxicab while it is in use and may be transferred to any taxicab
put into service to replace one withdrawn from service. (1951 Code 12-6-4)
3-9-6: STATE LICENSE REQUIRED:
No taxicab shall be operated unless it bears a State license duly issued. The
licensee shall notify the Village Clerk of the motor number and State license
number of each cab operated and of the corresponding Municipal tag or sticker
number. (1951 Code 12-6-4, 12-6-5)
3-9-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Equipment and Inspections: No cab shall be operated unless it is
equipped with proper brakes, lights, tires, horn, muffler, rear vision mirror
and windshield wipers in good condition. It shall be the duty of the Chief of
Police to inspect every taxicab as often as may be necessary to see to the
enforcement of the provisions of this subsection.
   B.   Marking of Vehicles: Each taxicab while operated shall have on each
side, in letters readable from a distance of twenty feet (20'), the name of the
licensee operating it. If more than one cab is operated by a licensee each cab
shall be designated by a different number also to appear on each side of such
cab.
   C.   Meter: No taxicab shall be operated unless it is equipped with a meter
in good condition to record the amount to be charged on each trip, which amount
shall be shown in figures visible to the passenger. (1951 Code 12-6-5, 12-6-11)
3-9-8: OPERATION OF TAXICABS:
   A.   Obedience to Traffic Regulations: It shall be the duty of every driver
of a taxicab to obey all traffic regulations established by statute, this Code
or ordinance 1 .
   B.   Passengers to be Accepted: It shall be the duty of the driver of any
taxicab to accept as a passenger any person who seeks to so use the taxicab,
provided such person is not intoxicated and conducts himself in an orderly
manner. No person shall be admitted to a taxicab occupied by a passenger
without the consent of the passenger.
   C.   Direct Route Required: The driver of a taxicab shall take his passenger
to his destination by the most direct available route from the place where the
passenger enters the cab. (1951 Code 12-6-8, 12-6-10)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 11 of this Code.
3-9-9: RECEIPT FOR PAYMENT OF FARE:
Upon paying his fare each passenger shall be entitled, on request, to a receipt
showing the amount so paid and the name of the company or person operating the
cab, together with the number of the cab if such company or person operates
more than one taxicab in the Village. (1951 Code 12-6-11)
3-9-10: PROHIBITED ACTS:
   A.   Conduct of Drivers: It shall be unlawful for any driver of a taxicab
while on duty to drink any intoxicating liquor, or to use any profane or
obscene language, to shout or to call to prospective passengers, or to disturb
the peace in any way.
   B.   Permitting Unlawful Use of Cab: It shall be unlawful to knowingly
permit any taxicab to be used in the perpetration of an unlawful act.
   C.   Failure to Pay Fare: It shall be unlawful for a passenger to fail or
refuse to pay the lawful fare at the termination of a trip. (1951 Code 12-6-6,
12-6-10, 12-6-11)
CHAPTER 10
MOTELS AND HOTELS
SECTION:
3-10-1: Definitions
3-10-2: Application For License, Approval
3-10-3: Building And Premises Requirements
3-10-4: Sanitary Conditions
3-10-5: Prohibited Acts And Conditions
3-10-6: Inspections
3-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
indicated:
HOTEL: Includes every building or structure kept, used, maintained, advertised
and held out to the public to be a place where lodging, or lodging and food, or
apartments, suites, or other accommodations are offered for a consideration to
guests in which ten (10) or more rooms, apartments or suites, or other
accommodations are used for the lodging, or lodging and food, for such guests.
MOTEL: Any parking lot or garage for the accommodation of motor vehicles where
transient sleeping accommodations are afforded or provided on the same premises
for the public or for the occupants of such automobiles. Provided, that a hotel
which furnishes parking space or has a garage in connection with the hotel
shall not be construed as a motel.
TRANSIENT: The accommodations to any person or persons shall not be for more
than thirty (30) consecutive days. (1951 Code 12-10-1; Ords. 54, 76-36-76, 77-
1-1)
3-10-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE, APPROVAL:
The application for a motel or hotel license shall state thereon the name and
address of the applicant, name and address of the owner or manager thereof,
location of the motel or hotel, and the maximum number of persons and vehicles
to be accommodated. This application shall be accompanied by plans of the motel
or hotel showing fireproof construction and the proposed or existing locations
of all buildings, toilets, bath and washbasin facilities, slop sinks, water
faucets, sewer connections, driveways and other improvements.
The application for a motel or hotel license shall be examined and approved by
the Zoning and Planning Commission and the board of trustees of this village.
(1951 Code 12-10-2; Ord. 54; 1985 Code; Ords. 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
3-10-3: BUILDING AND PREMISES REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Area, Number Of Units: The minimum area for any one motel or hotel unit
shall be three hundred (300) square feet; and no motel or hotel shall be
constructed with less than fifteen (15) units.
   B.   Parking Areas: The motel or hotel areas and driveways shall be surfaced
with asphaltic concrete and service walks shall be constructed of concrete. A
minimum of four hundred (400) square feet of parking space shall be provided
for each unit.
   C.   Fireproof Construction Near Parking Areas: No parking space shall be
provided for motor vehicles within ten feet (10') of any building or structure
used for housing accommodations in a motel or hotel unless the wall facing such
parking space is constructed of fireproof materials and unless windows in such
wall, if any, are equipped with reinforced fire resistant glass.
   D.   Lighting: Any area or premises of a motel or hotel open to use by the
public or by all persons staying in or being accommodated in the motel or hotel
shall be kept adequately lighted at nighttime; provided, that such lights must
be so shaded or otherwise regulated so as to prevent them from shining upon any
adjacent premises. (1951 Code 12-10-2, 12-10-3, 12-10-8; Ord. 54; 1985 Code)
3-10-4: SANITARY CONDITIONS:
   A.   No premises shall be operated as a motel or hotel unless each unit is
equipped with a closet, lavatory and tub or shower. All such sanitary
facilities shall be properly connected to a sanitary sewer system of the
municipality. If the premises are located on a street served not by a municipal
water system, the water shall be tested for purity by the county or state
health department every thirty (30) days.
   B.   All motel or hotel premises must be kept clean and sanitary at all
times, and all waste material must be removed therefrom at least once every
twenty four (24) hours. (1951 Code 12-10-6, 12-10-7; Ord. 54; 1985 Code)
3-10-5: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Illegal Acts: It shall be unlawful to permit any violation of any
ordinance or law on or in any motel or hotel.
   B.   Gambling, Immoral Acts: It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use
of any motel or hotel, or any portion thereof, for gambling, gaming devices or
any immoral purposes.
   C.   Trailers: It shall be unlawful to use or permit the use of any motel or
hotel for the accommodation of a house trailer.
   D.   Rates For Sleeping Accommodations: No hotel or motel licensed or
required to be licensed under this chapter shall: 1) rent any sleeping room by
the hour for any period of fewer than twelve (12) consecutive hours; or 2) rent
any sleeping room more than once within any consecutive twelve (12) hour period
measured from the commencement of one rental to the commencement of the next
rental; or 3) advertise an hourly rate or any other rate for a sleeping room
based on a rental period of fewer than twelve (12) consecutive hours. (1951
Code 12-10-7, 12-10-9; Ord. 54; 1985 Code; Ord. 08-13-35)
3-10-6: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Premises: All motel or hotel premises shall be operated under the
inspection and approval of the health and sanitation officer.
   B.   Parking Areas: The chief of police shall inspect or cause to be
inspected each parking area to see to the compliance with the provisions of
this chapter. (1951 Code 12-10-7; Ord. 54; 1985 Code)
CHAPTER 11
MACHINE SHOPS
SECTION:
3-11-1: Definition
3-11-2: Application For License
3-11-3: Health And Safety Conditions
3-11-4: Nighttime Operations
3-11-1: DEFINITION:
For the purposes of this chapter, the term "machine shop" is hereby defined to
mean a workshop in which machines are made or parts thereof are repaired, or
where parts of machines or tools, implements, dies, gears, screws or other
articles are cut, filed, shaped, punched, stamped, planed, sawed or repaired by
means of a lathe, drill, punch, saw, planer or other machinery. (1951 Code 12-
4-2)
3-11-2: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
The application for a license to conduct or operate a machine shop in the
village shall state the location of said shop, the name of the owner or
operator thereof, a general description of the character of the machinery in
such shop and the nature of the business to be carried on or work to be done
therein and the number of persons expected to be employed in such shop. (1951
Code 12-4-3)
3-11-3: HEALTH AND SAFETY CONDITIONS:
   A.   General: No building, structure or part thereof used for or in
connection with any machine shop shall be so used as to endanger the health or
property of the employees or of the public.
   B.   Maintenance And Cleanliness: The owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or
manager of any machine shop shall cause all floors and other surface around or
beneath any machine or workbench to be kept in good order and repair and shall
have suitable and convenient sanitary receptacles for receiving waste and
cloths used in and about the machine shop for the purpose of cleaning machines
or parts thereof or which are intended for any other necessary use.
   C.   Loud Noise Near Residences: It shall be unlawful to operate within two
hundred feet (200') of any residence, a machine shop wherein pneumatic hammers
or other apparatus are used which cause loud or unusual noises. (1951 Code 12-
4-6, 12-4-7)
3-11-4: NIGHTTIME OPERATIONS:
No machine shop shall be operated in the nighttime between the hours of eight
o'clock (8:00) P.M. and six o'clock (6:00) A.M. in any block in which the
majority of the buildings on both sides of the street are used exclusively for
residential purposes or within one hundred feet (100') of such block. (1951
Code 12-4-5)
CHAPTER 12
ALARM SYSTEMS
SECTION:
3-12-1: Definitions
3-12-2: Permits Required; Exceptions
3-12-3: Alarm Users
3-12-4: Alarm Equipment Suppliers
3-12-5: Possession, Display and Surrender of Permits
3-12-6: License and Permit Fees
3-12-7: Monthly Fee, Reports and Records
3-12-8: Insurance Requirements
3-12-9: False Alarms
3-12-10: Service of Notices
3-12-11: Prohibitions
3-12-12: Automatic Protection Devices, Keying Operation
3-12-13: Operational Defects to be Remedied
3-12-14: Authority to Inspect Installations
3-12-15: Signaling Devices, Financial Institutions
3-12-16: Direct Connections to Police Department
3-12-17: Central Stations
3-12-18: Answering Services; Standards
3-12-19: Alarm Systems; Standards and Inspections
3-12-20: Inspection of Alarm Devices and Businesses
3-12-21: Statistical Data
3-12-22: Testing of Equipment
3-12-23: Notice of Disruption in Service
3-12-24: Liability of Village Limited
3-12-25: Administrative Rules
3-12-26: Penalties for Violations
3-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this Chapter, the following terms have the definitions
ascribed to them:
ALARM EQUIPMENT SUPPLIER: Any person, firm or corporation that manufactures
alarm systems or sells alarm systems from its place of business and does not
sell, install, maintain, alter, repair, replace, service or respond to alarm
systems at the protected premise or premise to be protected.
ALARM SYSTEM: An assembly of equipment and devices (or a single device, such as
a solid state unit) arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring
urgent attention and to which police are expected to respond. In this Chapter,
the term "alarm system" shall include the terms, "automatic projection device",
"burglar alarm system" and "manual holdup alarm systems", as those terms are
hereinafter defined.
ALARM USER: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within
the Village of Oak Lawn except for alarm systems on motor vehicles. Also
included are those alarm systems which employ an audible signal emitting sounds
or a flashing light or beacon designed to alert or signal persons outside the
premises.
AUTOMATIC PROTECTION DEVICE: An electrically operated instrument composed of
sensory apparatus and related hardware which automatically sends over regular
telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise a prerecorded voice alarm
upon receipt of a stimulus from the sensory apparatus that has detected a
physical force or condition inherently characteristic of a fire or unauthorized
intrusion. Also included are devices which are stimulated by direct action by
the alarm user or his employees.
BURGLAR ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system signaling entry or attempted entry into
the area protected by the system.
CENTRAL STATION: An office to which remote alarm and supervisory signaling
devices are connected, where operators supervise the circuits and where guards
are maintained continuously to investigate signals.
CENTRAL STATION EQUIPMENT: The signal receiving, recording or retransmitting
equipment installed in the central station.
CENTRAL STATION SYSTEM: A system in which the operation of electrical
protection circuits and devices are signaled automatically to, recorded in,
maintained and supervised from a central station having trained operators and
guards in attendance at all times.
DIRECT LINE: A telephone line leading directly into the communications center
of the Fire Department or the Police Department that is for use only to report
emergency messages and signals on a person-to-person basis.
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure,
malfunction, improper installation or the improper operation or negligence of
the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. Such
terminology does not include, for example, alarms caused by hurricanes,
tornadoes, earthquakes or other violent conditions, nor by outside agencies or
external forces not under the control of owner or lessee.
FIRE CHIEF: The Chief of the Fire Department of the Village of Oak Lawn or his
authorized representative.
FIRE DEPARTMENT: The Fire Department of the Village of Oak Lawn, Illinois.
INDICATOR: The instrumentation on a monitor panel at the receiving terminal of
a signal line which produces both visual and audible alarm signals when
activated by a signaling device in the same electrical circuit at an
identifiable location of origin.
KEY (TO A TELEPHONE LINE): To use a telephone line for transmitting a message
either by direct connection or by a mechanism not so connected that utilizes
the microphone of a standard telephone to do so.
LOCAL ALARM: A signaling system which, when activated, causes an audible and/or
visual signaling device to be activated in or on the premises within which the
system is installed.
MANUAL HOLDUP ALARM SYSTEM: An alarm system in which the signal transmission is
initiated by the direct action of the person attacked, an observer of the
attack, or by the alarm user or his employees.
OPERATOR TRUNKLINE: A telephone line provided by the telephone company that
leads to an exchange where calls made to "operator" are received by the
company's operators, who respond appropriately to the various types of calls in
accordance with the general instructions of the company.
PERSON: Any individual, partnership, corporation, association or society, but
such term does not include the Village of Oak Lawn.
POLICE CHIEF: The Chief of the Police Department of the Village of Oak Lawn, or
his authorized representative.
POLICE DEPARTMENT: The Police Department of the Village of Oak Lawn, Illinois.
PRIMARY TRUNKLINE: A telephone line leading into the communications center of
the Fire Department or the Police Department that is for the purpose of
handling emergency calls on a person-to-person basis, and which line is
identified by a specific listing among the emergency numbers in the telephone
directory issued by the telephone company serving the Village of Oak Lawn.
PRIVATE ALARM CONTRACTOR: Any person who engages in a business that sells,
installs, maintains, alters, repairs, replaces, services, or responds to alarm
systems at a protected premises or premise to be protected on an emergency
basis and not as a full time security guard; but shall not include a person,
firm or corporation that only manufactures alarm systems or sells alarm systems
from its place of business and does not sell, install, maintain, alter, repair,
replace, service or respond to alarm systems at the protected premises or
premises to be protected, or an electrical contractor who repairs or services
alarm systems on an "emergency call in basis".
PRIVATE ALARM CONTRACTOR AGENCY: Any person, firm, association or corporation
which engages in the private alarm contractor business and which employs one or
more persons in conducting such business.
SIGNAL LINE: A line not connected to any standard telephone equipment which
leads into an indicator panel in the communications center of the police
department or such a panel in either a central station protective system or a
modified central station, and which is designed to transmit electrically an
alarm signal readily identifiable as to location or origin.
SIGNALING DEVICE: An electrically operated instrument composed of sensory
apparatus and related hardware that, upon detection of a physical force or
condition characteristic of an emergency, will excite a signal line in such a
way as to cause both visual and audible signals to be registered by indicators
on a monitor panel at the receiving terminal of that signal line in a central
location.
SPECIAL TRUNKLINE: A telephone line leading into the communications center of
the fire department or the police department that is for the primary purpose of
handling emergency messages which originate from automatic protection devices
and are transmitted directly or through an intermediary.
TELEPHONE COMPANY: The public utility that has a franchise from the village of
Oak Lawn authorizing it to furnish telephone service to subscribers in the
village.
VILLAGE: The village of Oak Lawn, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-2: PERMITS REQUIRED; EXCEPTIONS:
   A.   Alarm Business: It shall be unlawful for any person to own, manage,
conduct or carry on an alarm business within the village without complying with
the provisions of this chapter and without first obtaining a valid private
alarm contractor agency certificate from the state. A copy of said certificate
shall be filed with the chief of police.
   B.   Private Alarm Contractor: It shall be unlawful for any person to work
as a private alarm contractor within the village without complying with the
provisions of this chapter and without first obtaining a valid private alarm
contractor's license from the state. A copy of said license shall be filed with
the chief of police.
   C.   Alarm Equipment Supplier: It shall be unlawful for any person to own,
manage, conduct or carry on an alarm equipment supplier business within the
village without complying with the provisions of this chapter and without first
obtaining a valid alarm equipment supplier license.
   D.   Alarm User: It shall be unlawful for any person to own or possess an
alarm system without complying with the provisions of this chapter and without
obtaining a valid alarm user permit.
   E.   Exceptions: The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to:
1) audible alarms affixed to motor vehicles, 2) the village, its officers,
agents and employees, or 3) the fire alarms subject to the provisions of title
7, chapter 5 of this code. (Ords. 84-15-45, 09-10-24)
3-12-3: ALARM USERS:
   A.   Application For User Permit: Application for permits required under
this chapter shall be made to the chief of police on forms provided by the
police department. Each application for a permit shall be accompanied by the
correct fee, as defined in section
3-12-6 of this chapter.
      1.   Permit Required: Within ninety (90) days after the effective date of
this chapter, every alarm user shall obtain an alarm user permit for each alarm
system he operates within this village from the police chief. This subsection
does not require that private alarm contractor agencies or private alarm
contractors, that are licensed by the state, obtain a permit under this section
when they lease or provide services to alarm system users. If a private alarm
contractor or private alarm contractor agency, that is licensed by the state,
does, however, use an alarm system to protect its own premises, it shall obtain
a permit for such system as required in this section.
      2.   Application For Permit:
         a.   The alarm user applying for the permit required in subsection A1
of this section shall state on a permit application form to be prepared by the
police department and approved by the village attorney: his name, the address
of the residence or business or businesses in or upon which the alarm system
has been or will be installed, his telephone number, the type of alarm system
(local, direct connect, central station, etc.), the private alarm contractor or
private alarm contractor agency selling, installing, monitoring, inspecting,
responding to and/or maintaining the alarm system, including the address and
telephone number of said private alarm contractor agency or private alarm
contractor, and the name and telephone number of at least one other person (in
the case of a corporate alarm user applicant, at least 2 persons) who can be
reached at any time, day or night, and who is authorized to respond to an alarm
signal and who can open the premises in which the system is installed.
         b.   Any alarm user who installs a system ninety (90) days or more
after the effective date of this chapter must submit with the application a
certificate of a state licensed private alarm contractor or private alarm
contractor agency stating that in the opinion of such business the alarm system
complies with section
3-12-19 of this chapter. Such certificate shall satisfy the requirements of
subsection A4 of this section for the year in which the alarm permit is first
obtained.
      3.   Permit Fee: There shall be a twenty five dollar ($25.00) permit fee
yearly in relation to users of alarms, automatic protection devices and burglar
alarm systems other than solely "local alarms" as defined in section
3-12-1 of this chapter.
      4.   Inspections: Every alarm user licensed under this Section shall be
required to have its alarm system inspected at least once a year by a State
licensed private alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor, and post
a certificate of such inspection on the premises where the alarm system is
maintained. The certificate shall state that, in the opinion of the private
alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor:
         a.   The alarm system complies with the applicable provisions of
Section
3-12-19 of this Chapter if the system was installed ninety (90) days or more
after the effective date of this Chapter, or
         b.   The alarm system is safe and reliable if it was installed prior
to ninety (90) days after the effective date of this Chapter.
      5.   Temporary Waiving Of Requirements: An applicant for an alarm user
permit may file a request with the Police Chief, requesting that he temporarily
waive the requirements of subsection A2b and A4a of this Section in
circumstances in which the public's safety, health or welfare is involved.
      6.   The information contained in an alarm user permit application
required by this Section and other information received by the Police Chief
through correspondence or communications with an alarm user shall be securely
maintained and restricted to inspection only by the Police Chief or certain
officers or City employees specifically assigned the responsibility for
handling and processing alarm user permits, in the course of official duties.
If the Police Chief or any employee of the Village is found to have knowingly
or wilfully revealed the information contained in an alarm user permit
application or in correspondence or communications with an alarm user to any
other person for any purpose not related to this Chapter or official law
enforcement matters and without the express written consent of the alarm user
supplying such information, the Police Chief or the Village employee shall be
guilty of a misdemeanor as set forth in this Code.
      7.   Any alarm system user who operates an alarm system without first
obtaining a permit as required by this Section, or who, after having a permit
revoked, or suspended, and after exhausting his rights to hearing and appeal
fails to disconnect his alarm system, shall be in violation of this Chapter.
   B.   Issuance Of Permit: The Chief of Police shall issue a permit within
forty five (45) days of receipt of the completed application if, upon
investigation, there shall appear no reason to deny the application as provided
under subsection C herein.
   C.   Denial Of Application: An application for an alarm user permit shall be
denied if the applicant falsifies any information on the application.
   D.   Revocation Of Permit: An alarm user permit may be revoked by the Chief
of Police for any reason for which the granting of such permit might be
lawfully denied, or for a violation of any provision of this Chapter, or of any
rule or regulation made in implementation thereof by the Chief of Police. An
alarm user permit may be revoked when the alarm user or his agent:
      1.   Fails to respond to his activated alarm within a reasonable time
when requested to do so by the Police Department; or
      2.   His alarm system has signaled an excessive number of alarms.
   E.   Reporting Servicing Information: Each alarm user shall maintain a
current information card with the Police Department, containing his name,
address and telephone number as well as the name, address and telephone number
of a person or persons who can render service to the alarm at any hour of the
day or night. Each alarm user permittee shall immediately inform the Chief of
Police of any and all changes in the information on file with the Police
Department regarding such permit. (Ords. 84-15-45, 95-11-34)
3-12-4: ALARM EQUIPMENT SUPPLIERS:
   A.   Application For License: Each alarm equipment supplier, including those
selling protective devices in the Village for keying to a special trunkline or
an operator trunkline, shall apply to the Chief of Police for a license on a
form to be furnished him. Such application shall be filed within thirty (30)
days of the effective date hereof. Each application shall be signed by the
individual proprietor of such business or by a partner or authorized corporate
official, as appropriate for the type of business organization and shall
include the following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of alarm equipment supplier and
type of business organization (individual, partnership or corporation). If a
partnership, names and addresses of partners; if a corporation, the names and
addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated.
      2.   A description of, and operational specifications for the automatic
protection devices offered to the public, together with a statement that the
equipment does or does not comply with standards of the Underwriters'
Laboratories and/or the National Fire Protection Association.
      3.   A list of criminal convictions, if any, (other than for minor
traffic offenses) of the applicant, or a list of criminal convictions, if any
(other than for minor traffic offenses) of any of the partners, directors and
officers, if the applicant is other than in individual.
      4.   A statement that the applicant is willing to comply with other
reasonable rules and regulations as may be issued by the Chief of Police.
      5.   A statement by the applicant, recognizing that any license granted
to him will relate to the automatic protection device or devices described in
accordance with subsection A2 of this Section, and that the applicant, before
offering to the public any other such device or devices developed in the
future, will file with the Chief of Police a supplemental description like the
one required in subsection A2 of this Section. Only upon approval of the Chief
of Police of the new device or devices shall an existing license be deemed
amended to include authority to sell the new device or devices.
Each application for a license shall be accompanied by the correct fee, as
defined in Section
3-12-6 of this Chapter.
Any alarm equipment supplier who sells an alarm system without first obtaining
a license as required by this Section, or who, after having a license revoked,
or suspended, and after exhausting his rights to hearing and appeal continues
to sell alarm systems, shall be in violation of this Chapter.
   B.   License Proration And Refund:
      1.   An alarm equipment supplier wishing to do business in the Village
shall pay standard licensing fees required of other merchants in the community.
      2.   If the license is issued after the beginning of the calendar year,
the license fee shall be prorated on the basis of remaining months of the
calendar year, including the month when the license is issued.
      3.   No refunds of license fees shall be made.
   C.   Action On Business License Applications: The Police Chief shall cause a
report on the applicant to be prepared, based on the information contained in
the application together with such other relevant information as may be
obtained pertaining to the applicant and his business.
On the basis of this report, the Police Chief shall, within sixty (60) days
after the receipt of an application for an alarm equipment supplier license,
either approve or deny the issuance of a license. Upon making a decision he
shall:
      1.   In the case of approval, notify the applicant, in writing, of the
approval, and inform him that upon the presentation of the acceptance to the
