Village Clerk, or his designated representative, the applicant will be issued a
license to operate.
      2.   In the case of denial, notify the applicant, in writing, of the
denial and of the basis for the denial, which may be nonconformance with any
part of this Chapter. If the basis for the denial can be corrected, the notice
shall so state, and shall explain how these corrections may be made and set a
reasonable time limit for making such corrections. The notice of denial shall
inform the applicant that he may appeal the denial and set forth the procedure
for appeal. The procedure for appeal shall be as follows:
         a.   Within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice of denial, the
applicant shall file a notice of appeal with the Village Manager addressed to
the Board of Trustees and stating the basis of the appeal.
         b.   Within ten (10) days after receipt of the notice of appeal, the
Village Manager or his designated representative shall arrange for a conference
with the applicant and the Police Chief to attempt to reach an agreement
concerning the appeal.
         c.   If the conference fails to settle the matter in a way acceptable
to the applicant, arrangements shall be made to have the appeal heard before
the Board of Trustees. Such hearing shall be held within twenty (20) days after
the conference. The Village Manager shall cause the applicant to be given
written notice of the hearing at least seven (7) days in advance of the date of
the hearing. Notice of such hearing shall also be posted as part of the Board
of Trustees' agenda for that meeting. The applicant may appear before the Board
of Trustees, and the applicant or his designated representative may make an
oral presentation of his appeal, or he may make the appeal through a written
statement, or he may do both. The Board of Trustees shall rule on the appeal
within seven (7) days after it is heard and such ruling shall be final.
   D.   Revocation Of License:
      1.   In addition to the penalties proscribed by law for violation of any
provision of this Chapter, the Village may, after ten (10) days' prior written
notice, cancel or revoke the license of an alarm equipment supplier on any of
the following grounds:
         a.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in any
application for such license.
         b.   Fraud, misrepresentation or false statement contained in the
conduct of the business authorized by such license.
         c.   Violation of any provision of this Chapter.
      2.   No alarm equipment supplier license shall be revoked until a hearing
is held by the Police Chief. Written notice of the time and place of the
hearing shall be served on the holder of the license at least ten (10) days
before the date set for the hearing. The notice shall set forth a summary of
the grounds advanced as the basis for the revocation of the license.
      3.   At the hearing before the Police Chief, the holder of the license,
or his authorized representative shall be given an opportunity to confront and
examine any adverse witness, and to present evidence on his own behalf. After
the hearing, the Police Chief shall either dismiss the complaint or shall
forward the complaint to the Village Manager with his recommendation that the
license be revoked. Within ten (10) days after receiving such recommendation,
the Village Manager shall approve or disapprove the recommendation. In either
event, the Village Manager shall cause the holder of the license to be given
notice in writing of his decision within ten (10) days after making it.
      4.   Any person whose license is revoked pursuant to subsection D3 of
this Section shall have the right, within ten (10) days after receiving notice
in writing of the revocation from the Village Manager, of filing a written
appeal with the Board of Trustees. Such appeal shall set forth in detail the
specific ground or grounds on which it is based. The Board of Trustees shall
hold a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days after its receipt by the
Village and shall cause the appellant to be given at least ten (10) days'
written notice of such hearing. At the hearing, the appellant or his authorized
representative shall have the right to present a written or oral argument, or
both, in support of his appeal. The determination of the Board of Trustees on
the appeal shall be final.
      5.   After notice of revocation has been given, an alarm business
licensee may continue to operate his business until all of his rights of appeal
under this Chapter have been exhausted. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-5: POSSESSION, DISPLAY AND SURRENDER OF PERMITS:
The private alarm contractor agency certificate issued by the State must be
conspicuously displayed at the principal place of business, and every private
alarm contractor license issued by the State must be carried by the private
alarm contractor while he is working, and shall be displayed upon request by
any police officer. An alarm equipment supplier license issued by the Village
must be conspicuously displayed at the principal place of business. Any alarm
user permit or alarm equipment supplier license shall be surrendered to the
Chief of Police upon suspension or revocation. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-6: LICENSE AND PERMIT FEES:
   A.   Alarm user permit fee, as per subsection
3-12-3A3 of this Chapter, yearly      $25.00
   B.   Alarm equipment supplier, yearly   $50.00
   C.   False Alarms 1 : For each false alarm in excess of three (3) in any
calendar year from any alarm system, the alarm user shall be charged a false
alarm service charge as follows:
 
1 – 3 alarms    No charge
4 – 6 alarms    $ 75.00 each
7 – 9 alarms    100.00 each
10 – 12 alarms  150.00 each
13 or more alarms 200.00 each
 
(Ords. 89-21-71, 95-11-34)
 
Notes
1 1. Service charges established by Ord. 95-11-34 are effective August 1, 1995.
3-12-7: MONTHLY FEE, REPORTS AND RECORDS 1 :
   A.   Monthly Fee: Every "private alarm contractor agency" or "private alarm
contractor", as defined in Section
3-12-1 of this Chapter, and security system company which maintains a direct
connection to the communication centers of the Village's Fire and/or Police
Departments by means of a "direct line", "signal line", or "special trunkline",
as defined in Section
3-12-1 of this Chapter, or by any means whatsoever for the benefit and use of
its customers, shall pay to the Village a monthly fee of ten dollars ($10.00)
per subscriber, user or lessee, to cover the Village's administrative and
monitoring costs relative to such connection(s). This ten dollar ($10.00)
monthly fee per subscriber, user or lessee shall be due and payable on the
tenth day of each and every month.
   B.   List Of Subscribers: On or before January 30 of each year, each private
alarm contractor agency, private alarm contractor, or security system company
required to make such monthly payments hereunder shall deliver to the Chief of
Police of the Village a statement sworn to by an officer or owner of any such
private alarm contractor agency or security system company, or by the
individual private alarm contractor, showing it or his total number of
subscribers, users or lessees for the preceding year.
   C.   Records Required: Each such private alarm contractor agency, private
alarm contractor or security system company shall keep and preserve, at all
times while conducting business in the Village, full, complete and true records
of all of its subscribers, users or lessees and shall permit the Chief of
Police or the Chief's representative to examine the records at any and all
reasonable times, and shall, upon the Chief's request, explain the method of
keeping the records.
   D.   Failure To Make Payment Or Report: If any such private alarm contractor
agency, private alarm contractor or security system company shall fail to
promptly make any of the required monthly payments to the Village or omit to
prepare and deliver promptly any yearly statement required hereunder, the
Village may, upon ten (10) days' written notice to both the alarm user and the
private alarm contractor agency, private alarm contractor or security system
company who has failed to make said monthly payments or prepare and deliver
said yearly statements, disconnect said direct connection to the communication
centers of the Village's Fire and/or Police Departments.
   E.   Exemption From Monthly Fees And Record Keeping:
      1.   Any person who is required by any Village code or ordinance or by
any State or Federal law or regulation to maintain an alarm or security system
with a connection to a central station owned and operated by the Village, is
exempt from payment of the ten dollar ($10.00) monthly fee and record keeping
requirements of this Section.
      2.   In addition, all units of local government, including school
districts, and all private individual homeowners who are required to pay a
yearly alarm user fee of twenty five dollars ($25.00) in accordance with
subsection 3-12-6A of this Chapter, are exempt from the ten dollar ($10.00)
monthly fee and record keeping requirements of this Section. (Ords. 84-15-45,
89-21-71, 96-05-21, 98-23-103)
 
Notes
1 1. Fees established by Ord. 98-23-103 are effective January 1, 1999.
3-12-8: INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS:
Each private alarm contractor agency, private alarm contractor or security
system company which maintains a direct connection to and/or equipment at the
communication centers of the Village's Fire and/or Police Department shall
immediately take out and keep in full force at all times while maintaining such
direct connection and/or equipment public liability insurance, including errors
and omissions for equipment malfunction, in the amount of one million dollars
($1,000,000.00) with an insurance company acceptable to the Village Manager.
All such policies of insurance shall name the Village as an additional insured.
Each such private alarm contractor agency, private alarm contractor or security
system company must furnish the Village with a copy of the insurance policy
required hereunder or with a certificate of insurance by the carrier of said
insurance showing that it is at all times kept in force.
Such insurance policy must contain a provision that it may not be cancelled
without at least fifteen (15) days' prior written notice to the Village. (Ord.
84-15-45)
3-12-9: FALSE ALARMS:
   A.   More than three (3) false alarms in a calendar year from any alarm
system for which an alarm user permit has been obtained may constitute grounds
for revocation of such permit, subject to the provisions of this Section.
   B.   After the Police Department has recorded three (3) false alarms within
a calendar year from any alarm user permit holder, it shall notify the permit
holder and the private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency
providing service or inspection to the permit holder in writing of such fact
and require that the permit holder submit a report to the Police Chief within
fifteen (15) days after receipt of such notice, describing efforts to discover
and eliminate the cause or causes of the false alarms. If, however, the alarm
user, by reason of absence from the Village or any other reasonable basis,
requests an extension of time to file the report, the Police Chief shall extend
the fifteen (15) day period. If the permit holder fails to submit such a report
within fifteen (15) days or within any such extended period, the Police Chief
may revoke the user's permit and under such circumstances the user shall not be
entitled to a hearing or appeal under this Section.
   C.   If the alarm user submits a report as required by subsection B of this
Section but the Police Chief determines that the report is unsatisfactory or
that the alarm user has failed to show by the report that he has taken or will
take reasonable steps to eliminate or reduce false alarms, then the Police
Chief may issue written notice of his intent to revoke or suspend the alarm
user's permit.
   D.   If after submission of a report required by subsection B of this
Section which is satisfactory to the Police Chief, the alarm system of the
permit holder incurs one or more false alarms during the same calendar year,
the Police Chief may issue written notice of his intention to revoke or suspend
the alarm user's permit.
   E.   Upon receipt of a notice of intent to revoke or suspend an alarm user's
permit pursuant to subsections C and D of this Section, the alarm permit holder
may, within ten (10) days of such receipt, submit a written request for a
hearing before the Police Chief, setting forth the reasons that his permit
should not be revoked or suspended.
   F.   Written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be served on
the holder of the permit by the Police Chief at least ten (10) days prior to
the date set for the hearing.
   G.   At the hearing before the Police Chief, the holder of the permit, or
his authorized representative, shall have the right to confront and examine
witnesses and to present evidence on his own behalf. After the hearing, the
Police Chief may either issue an order of revocation, withdraw the notice of
revocation or suspend the permit until such time that he is satisfied that the
cause or causes of the false alarms have been eliminated.
   H.   Any person whose permit has been revoked or suspended pursuant to this
Section shall have the right, within ten (10) days after receiving notice of
revocation from the Police Chief, to file a written appeal by certified mail,
return receipt requested, or hand delivery with the Board of Trustees, and no
alarm user shall be required to discontinue use of his alarm system prior to
the expiration of such ten (10) day period. Such appeal shall set forth the
specific ground or grounds on which it is based. The Board of Trustees shall
hold a hearing on the appeal within thirty (30) days after its receipt by the
Village and shall cause the appellant to be given at least ten (10) days'
written notice of such hearing. At the hearing, the appellant or his designated
representative, shall have the right to present written or oral argument, or
both, in support of his appeal. The Board of Trustees shall issue its decision
within ten (10) days after the hearing.
   I.   If a permit holder files an appeal pursuant to subsection H of this
Section, he shall not be required to discontinue the alarm system until a final
decision is made on his appeal.
   J.   An alarm user whose permit has been revoked is not precluded under this
Section from applying for a new permit. The Police Chief, however, is not
required to issue a new permit unless he is satisfied that the alarm user's
system has been properly serviced and its deficiencies corrected. The Police
Chief may impose reasonable restrictions and conditions upon issuing a new
permit to an alarm user with respect to the particular system for which the
permit was revoked. (Ords. 84-15-45, 95-11-34)
3-12-10: SERVICE OF NOTICES:
When a person or the Police Chief, Village Manager, or Board of Trustees has
the right or is required to give notice pursuant to this Chapter, delivery of
said notice, unless specifically stated to be allowable by telephone, shall be
made by certified mail, return receipt requested, or, in lieu thereof, made by
hand by any person eighteen (18) years of age or older. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-11: PROHIBITIONS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for anyone to activate any alarm system for the
purpose of summoning police, except in the event of what is reasonably believed
to be an unlawful act and/or an unauthorized entry on premises. Whenever an
alarm system has been designed and commonly understood to alert others of the
commission of a particular crime, it shall be unlawful for anyone to activate
such alarm system for the purpose of summoning police except in the event of
what is reasonably believed to be such particular crime.
   B.   It shall be unlawful to install or use an alarm system which, upon
activation, emits a sound similar to sirens in use on emergency vehicles or for
civil defense purposes.
   C.   No local (audible) alarm may be installed, maintained or used within
the limits of Oak Lawn unless it shall be controlled by an automatic timing
device which will shut off the audible device after a period not to exceed
fifteen (15) minutes. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-12: AUTOMATIC PROTECTION DEVICES, KEYING OPERATION:
   A.   Information as to Keying Operations: Each private alarm contractor
agency or private alarm contractor engaged on the effective date hereof in
selling or leasing, and/or installing automatic protection devices in the
Village for keying to a special trunkline or an operator trunkline, and each
alarm equipment supplier who sells automatic protection devices in the Village
for keying to a special trunkline or an operator trunkline, shall provide the
following information, in writing, to the Chief of Police:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of private alarm contractor
agency, private alarm contractor, or alarm equipment supplier and type of
business organization (individual, partnership or corporation). If a
partnership, names and addresses of the partners; if a corporation, the names
and addresses of the principal officers and the state where incorporated.
      2.   A description of, and operational specifications for the automatic
protection device offered to the public, together with a statement that the
equipment does, or does not, comply with standards of the Underwriters'
Laboratories and/or the National Fire Protection Association.
      3.   If the device or devices operate at voltage exceeding thirty (30)
volts between conductors, then a statement that any installation in the Village
will be made by a registered electrician, and inspection and approval of the
Village Electrical Inspector.
      4.   A list of names and addresses of persons for whom installations in
the Village have been made by the applicant prior to the effective date hereof.
      5.   A list of criminal convictions, if any (other than for minor traffic
offenses) of the applicant, or a list of criminal convictions, if any (other
than for minor traffic offenses) of the partners, directors, and officers, if
the applicant is other than an individual.
      6.   A statement of the type and availability of service for automatic
protective devices that the applicant proposes to offer the public.
      7.   A statement that the applicant is willing to comply with other
reasonable rules and regulations about details of installation and operation of
such devices, as may be issued by the Chief of Police.
   B.   Restrictions on Keying:
      1.   No automatic protection device that is in stalled after the
effective date hereof by any person on premises of any kind in the Village
shall be keyed to a primary trunkline.
      2.   After the effective date hereof, any private alarm contractor agency
or private alarm contractor who installs automatic protective devices in the
Village for the purpose of sending prerecorded emergency messages directly to
the Police Department shall first obtain necessary instruction, including a
designated telephone number, from the Chief of Police with the type of message
in order to key such device to a special trunkline into that Department.
      3.   Within ninety (90) days after the effective date hereof, all
automatic protection devices in the Village that were keyed on that date to a
primary trunkline shall be disconnected therefrom. The owner or lessee of any
such device shall be responsible for the disconnecting of it.
      4.   An owner or lessee of an automatic protection device who has it
disconnected as required by subsection B3 of this Section, may authorize a
private alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor to key the
automatic protection device to a special trunkline into the Police Department,
provided that the device meets operational requirements, as set forth in this
Chapter, and written approval is obtained from the Chief of Police.
      5.   After the effective date hereof, no one except a private alarm
contractor agency or private alarm contractor shall install any automatic
protective device in the Village and/or key the same to a special trunkline.
   C.   Current List of Installations Required:
      1.   Within thirty (30) days after the effective date hereof, every
private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency who has keyed any
automatic protection devices in the Village to a special or operator trunkline
shall furnish the Chief of Police with a current list of such installations,
showing the following:
         a.   Name, residence address and telephone number of owner or lessee.
         b.   Address of place where device is installed and telephone number
at that location.
         c.   Name and telephone number of any other person at a different
location who is authorized to respond to an emergency and open the place where
the device is installed.
Within ten (10) days after the end of each quarter following the last month
included in the initial list, every private alarm contractor or private alarm
contractor agency shall furnish the Chief of Police with a supplemental list of
any such additional installations that he has keyed to a special or operator
trunkline, along with any corrections or deletions.
      2.   A private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency who
enters business after the effective date hereof and keys an automatic
protection device in the Village to a special or operator trunkline shall, by
the tenth of the second month following the month in which the first
installation is made, furnish the Chief of Police with a list of installations,
as specified in subsection C1 above. Within ten (10) days after the end of each
quarter following the last month included in the initial list, he shall
likewise furnish the Chief of Police with a supplemental list of any such
additional installations, along with any corrections or deletions.
      3.   The information required in subsections C1 and C2 above shall be
restricted to use only by the Chief of Police and the departments concerned.
   D.   Application of Operational Requirements: The operational requirements
set forth herein apply to any automatic protection device that is keyed to a
special or operator trunkline, either through a direct connection to a line of
a telephone or without such a direct connection, but by a mechanism that
utilizes the microphone of a telephone for transmitting messages.
   E.   Operational Requirements: Automatic protective devices installed on
premises of any kind in the Village that are keyed to a special or operator
trunkline shall meet minimum operational requirements, as determined by the
Chief of Police as follows:
      1.   The content of the type of recorded message to be transmitted by
such device must be intelligible and in a format approved by the Chief of
Police concerned as appropriate for the nature of the alarm.
      2.   No recorded message shall be delivered to the Police Department more
than three (3) times as the result of a single stimulus of the sensory
mechanism.
      3.   The length of time for transmitting the recorded message must not
exceed fifteen (15) seconds.
      4.   The time gap between delivery of each recorded message must be in
the range from ten (10) to twelve (12) seconds.
      5.   Such device must be capable of transmitting an alarm message to two
(2) or more recipients, so that upon installation, any message will be sent not
only on a special or operator trunkline but also on the line of an authorized
person having a key to the premises who is available to respond to an
emergency.
      6.   The sensory mechanism used in connection with such devices must be
adjusted to suppress false indications of fire or intrusion, so that the
devices will not be actuated by impulses due to transient pressure changes in
water pipes, short flashes of light, wind noises such as a rattling or
vibrating of doors or windows, vehicular noise adjacent to the installation or
other forces unrelated to genuine alarms.
      7.   All components comprising such a device must be maintained by the
owner or lessee in good repair to assure reliability of operation.
   F.   Instructions on Operation:
      1.   Each alarm equipment supplier, private alarm contractor or private
alarm contractor agency that sells or leases to a person an automatic
protection device which is installed on such person's premises in the Village
after the effective date hereof, and which is keyed to a special or operator
trunkline, shall furnish that person with instructions as to the way the device
operates, along with a maintenance manual and a correct circuit diagram
pertaining to such device.
      2.   Each alarm equipment supplier, private alarm contractor or private
alarm contractor agency, as referred to in subsection F1 above, shall also
furnish the Chief of Police with a copy of the instructions as to the way the
device operates, along with a maintenance manual and a correct circuit diagram.
If the Chief of Police finds such to be incomplete, unclear, or otherwise
inadequate, he may require the alarm equipment supplier, private alarm
contractor or private alarm contractor agency to have the same revised to meet
the Chief of Police's approval and then promptly distributed to persons for
whom installations of such devices have already been made as well as to persons
for whom installations are henceforth made.
   G.   Repair Service:
      1.   Each private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency
that sells or leases to a person an automatic protection device which is
installed on such person's premises in the Village after the effective date
hereof, and which is keyed to a special or operator trunkline, must offer
service, directly or through an agent, on a twenty four (24) hour basis, seven
(7) days a week, to repair such device, so as to correct any malfunction of
same that may occur.
      2.   At the time of installation, each private alarm contractor or
private alarm contractor agency shall furnish to the person for whom an
automatic protection device has been installed, written information as to how
service can be obtained at any time, including the telephone number to call for
service; and such person shall be responsible for having the device repaired as
quickly as possible after he learns, either from his own sources or from
notification by the Chief of Police or any member of the Fire Department, that
the device is not working properly. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-13: OPERATIONAL DEFECTS TO BE REMEDIED:
When messages evidencing failure to comply with the operational requirements
set forth in subsection 3-12-12E are received by the Police Department, and the
Chief of Police concludes that the automatic protection device sending such
messages should be disconnected in order to relieve the Police Department of
the burden of responding to false alarms, he is authorized to demand that the
owner or lessee of such device, or his representative at the place where it is
installed, disconnect such device until it is made to comply with said
operation requirements. If disconnection of the defective automatic protection
device is not accomplished promptly by such demand and the Chief of Police
determines that the malfunctioning device is repeatedly sending false alarms in
succession without an intermittent valid alarm, he may then take whatever steps
are necessary to disconnect the defective automatic protective device. (Ord.
84-15-45)
3-12-14: AUTHORITY TO INSPECT INSTALLATIONS:
For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Chapter, the Chief of the
Fire Department and the Chief of the Police Department shall each have the
authority at reasonable times and upon oral notice, to enter upon any premises
within the Village to inspect the installation and operation of an automatic
protection device or signaling device, the purpose of which is to report an
emergency to the Police Department, either directly or through an intermediary.
(Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-15: SIGNALING DEVICES, FINANCIAL INSTITUTIONS:
Any financial institution that is required by regulations of Federal
supervisory agencies issued pursuant to the Bank Protection Act of 1968 to have
an appropriate device for notifying the Police Department that a burglary or
robbery has occurred or is in progress, may arrange to have the particular
signaling device installed so as to operate pursuant to approval by the Chief
of Police. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-16: DIRECT CONNECTIONS TO POLICE DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Upon the favorable recommendation of the Police Chief and the approval
of the Board of Trustees, alarms from business premises and financial
institutions may be terminated in the Police Department.
   B.   The Police Chief shall have the authority to request bids from private
alarm contractor agencies or private alarm contractors licensed by the State in
accordance with the normal practice in the community to furnish when possible,
at no cost to the Village, a standard annunciator panel. Such services shall be
set forth in the form of a written contract between the private alarm
contractor agency or private alarm contractor and each subscriber. This
subsection, however, relates solely to annunciator panels, connections to
annunciator panels by subscribers, and fees and charges related to the
installation and maintenance of such panels. Any subscriber or alarm user who
obtains authority from the Police Chief and Board of Trustees to terminate its
alarm system in the Police Department may contract with any State licensed
private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency of his choice for
the sale, installation, maintenance, and/or servicing of the alarm system to be
installed on its premises.
   C.   The alarm subscriber approved for a direct connection to the Police
Department or the private alarm contractor or private alarm contractor agency
contracting for servicing the subscriber's alarm system shall be responsible
for obtaining the leased telephone line between subscriber's premises and the
alarm receiving equipment at the Police Department and for furnishing the
appropriate interface equipment, if required, in order to provide an input
signal which is compatible with the receiving equipment used to operate the
standard annunciator panel.
   D.   The provisions of this Chapter contained in sections concerning alarm
user permits and false alarms shall apply to all subscribers or persons having
direct connect systems, except Municipal, County and State agencies exempted by
the Board of Trustees. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-17: CENTRAL STATIONS:
   A.   Standards: In addition to any other requirements imposed by this
Chapter, a private alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor shall
not operate a central station unless the Police Chief finds that the central
station, if operated, will meet the following minimum requirements:
      1.   Compliance with the most recent "Central Station Burglar Alarm Units
Systems" (UL 611) issued by Underwriters' Laboratories or American National
Standards Institute (ANSI SE 2.2). Such standards are hereby adopted and made a
part of this Chapter, and a copy of such standards shall be kept on file at the
Police Department and be available for public inspection. The service provided
may correspond to any of the several grades of service listed in the standards,
but the owner, private alarm contractor agency, private alarm contractor or
other person in responsible control of the premises wherein such alarm system
is located must be present at such premises as soon as is reasonably possible
after being requested to do so by a representative of the Police Department. A
central station may also be a modified central station or telephone answering
service.
      2.   If a central station is currently registered with Underwriters'
Laboratories as a "UL listed central station" or if it is listed as such in
Underwriters' Laboratories' publication, "The Quarterly Supplement", such
registration or listing shall be sufficient evidence of compliance with this
Section.
   B.   Modified Central Stations; Standards: In addition to any other
requirements imposed by this Chapter, a private alarm contractor agency or
private alarm contractor shall not operate a modified central station unless
the Police Chief finds that the modified central station, if operated, will
meet the following minimum standards:
      1.   The premises from which the services are performed must meet any
applicable fire regulations.
      2.   The premises from which the services are performed must be secured
in a manner approved by the Police Chief to prevent entry by unauthorized
persons.
      3.   A large enough number of operators must be on duty at all times to
assure that all emergency messages received will be relayed immediately to the
Police Department over a special trunkline.
      4.   As soon as possible after notifying the Police Department, the
operator concerned shall notify the subscribers involved of such action and the
nature of the emergency message received.
      5.   The modified central station shall certify that all equipment
supervised by the modified central station shall be tested at least once a
year. Where a test result is unsatisfactory, the cause thereof shall be
corrected within twenty four (24) hours, unless circumstances exist that make
such corrections impossible within such time, in which event the cause shall be
corrected within a reasonable time. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-18: ANSWERING SERVICES; STANDARDS:
In addition to any other requirements imposed by this Chapter, a private alarm
contractor agency or private alarm contractor shall not operate an answering
service unless the Police Chief finds that the answering service, if operated,
will meet the following minimum standards:
   A.   The premises from which the services are performed must meet any
applicable fire regulations.
   B.   The premises from which the services are performed must be secured in a
manner approved by the Police Chief to prevent entry by unauthorized persons.
   C.   A large enough number of operators must be on duty at all times to
insure that all emergency messages received will be relayed immediately to the
Police Department over a special trunkline.
   D.   Emergency messages from automatic alarm devices shall be given priority
over all other messages received by the answering services except that fire
alarm signals may have equal priority.
   E.   All operators shall be trained to handle emergency messages.
   F.   As soon as possible after notifying the Police Department, the operator
concerned shall notify the subscriber involved of such action and the nature of
the emergency message received.
   G.   All subscribers of an answering service shall be required by the
service to cooperate in a test of its alarm devices at least once a year to
determine if the device is working properly. The answering service shall
certify that the test results shall be reported promptly, in writing, to the
subscriber and the Police Department. Until the device in question is again
working properly, the Police Department may require that its use be
discontinued. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-19: ALARM SYSTEMS; STANDARDS AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Within six (6) months after the effective date of this Chapter, all
alarm systems installed in commercial or public buildings shall utilize
equipment and methods of installation substantially equivalent to or exceeding
the most recent following minimum applicable UL or ANSI standards; UL 609 (ANSI
SE 2.1) "Local Burglar Alarm Units and Systems".
   B.   Within six (6) months after the effective date of this Chapter, all
alarm systems installed in residences shall utilize equipment which shall be
substantially equivalent to or exceed the most recent minimum applicable UL
Standard 1023 (ANSI SE 2.4) "Household Burglar Alarm Systems Units", and such
equipment shall be installed in a safe, reliable and workmanlike manner.
   C.   The equipment or hardware used and/or the manner of installation of the
alarm system may correspond to any of the several levels of protection or
grades of service listed in the applicable standards; provided, however, that
alarm system users shall not be required to provide protection for all of the
areas or openings which may be required to be protected by the applicable
standards.
   D.   The standards referred to in this Section are hereby adopted as part of
this Chapter subject to the modification and qualifications set forth herein
and a copy of such standards shall be kept on file at the Police Department and
be available for public inspection.
   E.   In those instances where UL and/or ANSI have not established standards
for categories of equipment or where new equipment is undergoing field testing,
the Police Chief may require that the alarm system be inspected at the expense
of the alarm user by a professional electrical engineer who shall certify
whether the alarm system appears to be safe and reliable.
   F.   Alarm systems which input into an automatic alarm device are subject to
the provisions of this Section.
   G.   Tape dialer alarm systems are specifically prohibited within the
Village. By January 1, 1985, all tape dialer alarm systems within the Village
shall be disconnected. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-20: INSPECTION OF ALARM DEVICES AND BUSINESSES:
   A.   For the purpose of enforcing the provisions of this Chapter, the Police
Chief shall have the authority, at reasonable times and upon reasonable oral
notice, to enter any premises in the Village in or upon which alarm systems or
private alarm contractor agencies or private alarm contractors subject to this
Chapter are located to inspect the installation and/or operation of such alarm
systems or private alarm contractor agencies or private alarm contractors on
official police business.
   B.   If such inspection reveals any violations of the provisions of this
Chapter, a written report detailing such violations shall be promptly sent to
the Village Manager and to the owner, lessee, or other person responsible for
the alarm system or private alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor
in violation of this Chapter. Such report shall require the correction within
thirty (30) days after receipt of the notice of the violation discovered and
shall state that a failure to comply may result in the revocation of the alarm
user's permit in accordance with provisions of this Chapter relating to
revocation of licenses and permits. The alarm user shall be granted a
reasonable extension of time to correct such violation upon good cause shown.
   C.   It shall be a misdemeanor under this Code for the Police Chief, Village
Manager, or any Village employee to knowingly and wilfully reveal any business
information obtained during said inspection other than for official police
business or for the administration and enforcement of this Chapter. (Ord. 84-
15-45)
3-12-21: STATISTICAL DATA:
In addition to any other information that may be required to be supplied by the
provisions of this Chapter, the Police Chief may require a private alarm
contractor agency or private alarm contractor to furnish him with certain
statistical data which may be reasonably available relative to specified
periods of operation after the effective date of this Chapter. Any operational
data so furnished shall be for use only by the Village Manager, Police Chief
and Police Department and its use shall be subject to the sanctions of this
Chapter. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-22: TESTING OF EQUIPMENT:
No alarm system designed to transmit emergency messages directly to the Police
Department shall be tested or demonstrated without first obtaining permission
from the Police Chief. Permission is not required to test or demonstrate alarm
devices not transmitting emergency messages directly to the Police Department
unless the messages are to be relayed to the Police Department. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-23: NOTICE OF DISRUPTION IN SERVICE:
When a private alarm contractor agency's or private alarm contractor's service
to its subscribers is disrupted for any reason by the private alarm contractor
agency or the private alarm contractor, or the private alarm contractor agency
or private alarm contractor becomes aware of such disruption, it shall promptly
notify its subscriber by telephone that protection is no longer being provided.
If, however, the private alarm contractor agency or private alarm contractor
has written instructions from its subscriber not to make such notification by
telephone during certain hours, the private alarm contractor agency or private
alarm contractor may comply with such instructions. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-24: LIABILITY OF VILLAGE LIMITED:
The Village shall take every reasonable precaution to assure that alarm signals
and prerecorded alarm messages received by the Village are given appropriate
attention and are acted upon with dispatch. Nevertheless, the Village shall not
be liable for any defects in operation of automatic protection devices and
signal line systems, for any failure or neglect to respond appropriately upon
receipt of any alarm from such a source, nor for the failure or neglect of any
person with a license issued by the State or with a franchise, in connection
with the installation and operation of equipment, the transmission of alarm
signals and prerecorded alarm messages or the relaying of such signals and
messages. In the event that the Village finds it necessary to disconnect a
defective automatic protection device or signaling device, the Village shall
incur no liability by such action. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-25: ADMINISTRATIVE RULES:
The Police Chief shall promulgate such rules as may be necessary for the
implementation of this Chapter and for determination of grounds for clerical
suspension, or revocation or cancellation of any license or permit required by
this Chapter. The rules shall be approved by the Village Manager and Board of
Trustees and shall be open to inspection by the public. (Ord. 84-15-45)
3-12-26: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS:
   A.   The failure of any person to:
      1.   Obtain an alarm system user permit as required in subsection
3-12-3A of this Chapter,
      2.   Obtain an alarm equipment supplier's license as required by
subsection
3-12-4A of this Chapter,
      3.   Make the corrections to alarm systems as required by Section
3-12-20 of this Chapter, or
      4.   Obey any order of the Police Chief or Board of Trustees of
suspension or revocation of an alarm user permit or alarm equipment supplier
license after such person has exhausted his rights to hearings or appeals,
constitutes an offense punishable by a fine of up to seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Each day that such violation continues after the expiration
of the period allowed for compliance under the provisions of this Chapter shall
constitute a misdemeanor.
   B.   Failure of any person to comply with the requirements of written notice
of a violation hereof within three (3) days of receipt of such notice shall
constitute an offense punishable by a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Such notice shall continue in force and effect until full
compliance with the requirements stated therein, and each and every failure to
comply with such notice within twenty four (24) hours after the three (3) days
allowed for compliance shall constitute a separate offense. (Ords. 84-15-45,
99-5-11)
CHAPTER 13
GARAGE AND RUMMAGE SALES
SECTION:
3-13-1: Definition
3-13-2: Permit Required, Fee
3-13-3: Number Of Permits And Duration Of Sale Restricted; Conditions Of Permit
3-13-1: DEFINITION:
The term "garage, rummage, or other like sale" shall mean the public sale by
the owner or occupant of a dwelling unit of items of personal property owned
and accumulated at the dwelling unit in question and sold in or around the
garage area but not within the dwelling unit itself. (Ord. 74-15-32)
3-13-2: PERMIT REQUIRED, FEE:
   The owner or occupants of a dwelling unit shall apply to the Community
Development Department for a permit at least twenty-four (48) hours prior to
beginning a garage, rummage, or other like sale. A permit fee in the amount set
forth in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Code shall be paid at the time of application for each sale.
(Ords. 91-19-82, 25-11-26, 25-12-37)
3-13-3: NUMBER OF PERMITS AND DURATION OF SALE RESTRICTED; CONDITIONS OF
PERMIT:
No more than two (2) permits shall be issued to a dwelling unit during one
calendar year for garage, rummage, or other like sales and no single garage,
rummage or other like sale shall be allowed to continue for more than three (3)
consecutive days.
   A.   Types Of Items To Be Sold: The items to be sold at such a sale shall be
items of personal property, including, but not limited to, household goods,
clothing and furnishings, which have been used in the dwelling unit located on
the premises where the sale is to be conducted. Sale items purchased for
intentional sale or resale may not be sold at such a sale.
   B.   Hours Of Sale: No garage, rummage or other like sale may commence
before the hour of nine o'clock (9:00) A.M. nor extend beyond the hour of six
o'clock (6:00) P.M.
   C.   Use Of Public Ways: No sidewalk or public parkway shall be obstructed
as a result of a garage, rummage or other like sale, nor shall any permanent or
temporary sign be placed in or on the parkway or other public right of way.
(Ords. 91-19-82, 93-18-73)
CHAPTER 14
AUTOMATIC VENDING MACHINES
SECTION:
3-14-1: Definition
3-14-2: Licenses Required
3-14-3: Applications For Licenses
3-14-4: License Fees
3-14-5: Investigation Of Applicant, Fee
3-14-6: Payment Of Fees, Emblem Required
3-14-7: Refund Notice
3-14-8: Revocation Of License
3-14-9: Penalties
3-14-1: DEFINITION:
The term "automatic vending machine" shall mean any machine which upon the
insertion of a coin, slug, token, plate or disc, dispenses a product,
including, but not limited to, candy, a beverage or snack food. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-2: LICENSES REQUIRED:
   Operator's Business: No one shall engage in the automatic vending machine
"operator's business", which is herein defined to mean the conduct or
transaction of the business of distributing, placing, leasing or selling
automatic vending machines with an agreement to maintain, service or supply,
without first obtaining a license therefor and paying the license fee set forth
in section
3-1-1-7 of this Code.
(Ords. 96-9-45, 25-12-37)
3-14-3: APPLICATIONS FOR LICENSES:
Applications for such licenses shall be made to the director of administrative
services upon a form to be supplied by the village for that purpose and shall
contain the following information:
   A.   The applicant's name, sex, date of birth, social security number,
position and percentage of ownership of the business; and the name, sex, date
of birth, social security number, position and percentage of ownership in the
business of every sole owner, partner, corporate officer, director, manager,
and any person who owns five percent (5%) or more of the shares of the
applicant business entity or parent corporations of the applicant business
entity;
   B.   Name of manufacturer of the automatic vending machine to be licensed;
   C.   Prior convictions, if any, of applicant;
   D.   Place where the automatic vending machine is to be displayed or
operated, and the business conducted at that place;
   E.   A description of the automatic vending machine to be covered by the
license, mechanical features and serial number;
   F.   The description of the products available from the automatic vending
machine and the price therefor. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-4: LICENSE FEES:
   No license may issue until the machine operator's business has paid the
appropriate license fees as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this title, with the license year being July 1 through the following
June 30.
(Ords. 96-9-45, 03-20-81, 25-12-37)
3-14-5: INVESTIGATION OF APPLICANT, FEE:
   A.   Investigation Of Applicant: The original application for a license(s)
shall be referred to the chief of police for investigation and verification of
the facts stated therein and he shall ascertain if the applicant is a person of
good moral character, and either approve or disapprove the application. No
license(s) shall be issued to any applicant unless approved by the chief of
police.
   B.   Fee: Before any action is taken upon any new application as provided in
section
3-14-3 of this chapter, the applicant shall pay to the village the sum of two
hundred dollars ($200.00), no part of which shall be refundable, to cover the
village's costs in reviewing and investigating such applicant. Provided,
however, that in the event the application is approved and the applicant
applies for the license(s) and pays the initial license fee(s) within the time
provided, said two hundred dollars ($200.00) shall be credited toward the
initial license fee(s).
   C.   Examination Of Records: As a condition of any license issued under this
chapter, the department of administrative services, with reasonable prior
written notice, shall have the authority to examine all books and records of
anyone holding an automatic vending machine operator's business license to
ensure compliance with this section.
   D.   Renewal: Although applications for the renewal of any licenses issued
pursuant to this chapter shall not require the payment of the investigation fee
set forth in subsection B of this section, said renewals shall be accompanied
by an update of the information required in section
3-14-3 of this chapter for new applications. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-6: PAYMENT OF FEES, EMBLEM REQUIRED:
All fees shall be paid to the director of administrative services who shall
issue, as evidence of the payment thereof, to each automatic vending machine a
self-voiding adhesive emblem to be placed on each automatic vending machine.
Such emblem shall bear the words "Village of Oak Lawn", and the date it shall
become void. It shall be unlawful for any person to mutilate said emblem during
the year for which it is issued.
Each such emblem shall be issued only for a particular automatic vending
machine and may not be transferred or used in any way whatsoever as the
required emblem of any other automatic vending machine whether or not such
other automatic vending machine is a new or replacement automatic vending
machine for the original automatic vending machine. Each and every automatic
vending machine must have such an emblem issued for its particular use after
the payment of the required fee. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-7: REFUND NOTICE:
The name, address and phone number of the person, firm or corporation who may
be contacted if there is a problem with the automatic vending machine shall be
conspicuously posted on each automatic vending machine licensed under this
chapter. It shall be the obligation of the licensee to make sure his/her/its
machines are in compliance with the provisions of this section. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-8: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Every license issued under this section is subject to revocation in accordance
with section
3-1-6 of this title. (Ord. 96-9-45)
3-14-9: PENALTIES:
In addition to, and not in lieu of, the revocation of any license issued under
this section, any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense; and each day such violation
shall continue shall be regarded as a separate offense. (Ord. 96-9-45)
CHAPTER 15
REGULATION OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS
SECTION:
3-15-1: Definitions
3-15-2: License Required
3-15-3: License Application
3-15-4: License Fee
3-15-5: Number Of Tobacco Retailer Licenses
3-15-6: Responsibility For Acts Of Employees
3-15-7: Suspension; Revocation Of License; Fine; Costs
3-15-8: Use Of Premises After License Revocation
3-15-9: Prohibited Sales; Delivery; Signs
3-15-10: Prohibition Against Persons Under The Age Of Sixteen Selling
3-15-11: Purchase By Persons Under The Age Of Twenty-One Prohibited
3-15-12: Possession By Minors Prohibited
3-15-13: Certain Free Distributions Prohibited
3-15-14: Vending Machines - Locking Devices
3-15-15: Penalty
3-15-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them below for the
purpose of this chapter:
ALTERNATIVE NICOTINE PRODUCT: A product or device not consisting of or
containing tobacco that provides for the ingestion into the body of nicotine,
whether by chewing, smoking, absorbing, dissolving, inhaling, snorting,
sniffing, or by any other means.
ELECTRONIC CIGARETTE OR E-CIGARETTE: (1) Any device that employs a battery or
other mechanism to heat a solution or substance to produce a vapor or aerosol
intended for inhalation; (2) any cartridge or container of a solution or
substance intended to be used with or in the device or to refill the device; or
(3) any solution or substance, whether or not it contains nicotine intended for
use in the device. The term "electronic cigarette" or "e-cigarette" includes
any such device, regardless of the details of the product appearance or
marketed name, generally manufactured to resemble a cigarette, cigar, pipe, or
other smoking device, including, but not limited to, vape pens, electronic
cigar, electronic cigarillos, electronic pipes, an electronic hookah, hookah
pen, personal vaporizer and any other alternative nicotine delivery systems
that may be battery operated devices designed to look like and be used in the
same manner as conventional tobacco products. The term "electronic cigarette"
or "e-cigarette" also includes the cartridges and component parts or
accessories of an electronic cigarette, individually or in any combination, as
well as nicotine or non-nicotine fluid and/or solids or other substance/
chemicals used to refill the cartridge.
ILLICIT THC PRODUCT: Any product, material, compound, isomer, acid, salt,
mixture, or preparation:
   (A)   Used or intended for human consumption;
   (B)   That is not made, manufactured, sold, given away, bartered, exchanged,
distributed, furnished, marketed, advertised, or otherwise held out for sale by
cannabis business establishments duly licensed under the Compassionate Use of
Medical Cannabis Program Act (410 ILCS 130/1, et seq.) or the Cannabis
Regulation and Tax Act (410 ILCS 705/1-1, et seq.); and
   (C)   That contains: (1) any amount of synthetic cannabinoids of any kind,
inclusive of acid forms, regardless of name, and including but not limited to
THC-O, delta-8 tetrahydrocannabinol, and delta-10 tetrahydrocannabinol, (2) a
total delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol content concentration level in excess of
0.3% on a dry weight basis, or (3) a total delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol content
in excess of 0.5 milligrams per labeled serving or individual unit or 2.5
milligrams per package regardless of the number of labeled servings or
individual units therein.
KRATOM: Any parts of the plant Mitragyna speciosa, whether growing or not, and
any compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture, or preparation of that
plant, including but not limited to mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, as
defined in Section 5(a) of the Illinois Kratom Control Act, 720 ILCS 642/5(a),
as may be amended.
OWNER: The owner, lessor, or sublessor of any display of tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products, or of any vending
machine which sells tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products. An owner can be one or more persons, a corporation, a
partnership, or any other legal entity, jointly or severally, in whom is vested
all or part of the legal title to the tobacco products, electronic cigarettes,
and/or alternative nicotine products display, or vending machine.
SYNTHETIC CANNABINOID: A cannabinoid-like compound that was produced using
chemical synthesis, chemical modification, or chemical conversion, including in
vitro biosynthesis or other bioconversion of such a method. Synthetic
cannabinoids include the conversion of cannabinoids from one chemical structure
to another, such as tetrahydrocannabinol (THC) that was produced by the
conversion of cannabidiol.
TETRAHYDROCANNABINOL OR THC: Any naturally occurring or synthetic
tetrahydrocannabinol, including its salts, isomers, and salts of isomers
whenever the existence of such salts, isomers, and salts of isomers is possible
within the specific chemical designation and any preparation, mixture, or
substance containing, or mixed or infused with, any detectable amount of
tetrahydrocannabinol or tetrahydrocannabolic acid, including, but not limited
to, delta-8-tetrahydrocannabinol, delta-9-tetrahydrocannabinol, delta-10-
tetrahydrocannabinol, tetrahydrocannabolic acid, tetrahydrocannabipherol, or
hexahydrocannabinol, however derived. For the purposes of this definition,
"isomer" means the optical, position, and geometric isomers.
TOBACCO PRODUCTS: Any product containing or made from tobacco that is intended
for human consumption, whether smoked, heated, chewed, absorbed, dissolved,
inhaled, snorted, sniffed, or ingested by any other means, including, but not
limited to, cigarettes, cigars, little cigars, chewing tobacco, pipe tobacco,
snuff, snus, and any other smokeless tobacco product which contains tobacco
that is finely cut, ground, powdered, or leaf and intended to be placed in the
oral cavity. "Tobacco product" includes any component, part, or accessory of a
tobacco product, whether or not sold separately.
TOBACCO RETAILER: Any retail establishment in which the sale of tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products occurs.
TOTAL DELTA-9 THC CONTENT: The value determined after the process of
decarboxylation, or the application of a conversion factor if the testing
methodology does not include decarboxylation, that expressed the potential
total delta-9 tetrahydrocannabinol content derived from the sum of the THC and
THCA content and reported on a dry weight basis, to be calculated either by
using a chromatograph technique using heat, such as gaschromatography, through
which THCA is converted from its acid form to its neutral form, or by using a
liquid chromatograph technique, which keeps the THCA intact, and using the
following conversion: [Total THC = (0.877 × THCA) + THC] which calculates the
potential total THC in a given sample.
VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical, electric or electronic, self- service device
which, upon insertion of money, tokens or any other form of payment, dispenses
a tobacco product, electronic cigarette, and/or alternative nicotine products.
(Ords. 18-04-14, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, deliver or keep
with the intention of selling, giving away or delivering tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products within the Village
without first having obtained a tobacco retailer's license pursuant to this
chapter. Such license shall be in addition to any other licenses or permits
required by this Code.
(Ords. 16-02-08, 25-12-36)
3-15-3: LICENSE APPLICATION:
   Application for a license hereunder shall be made in writing to the Director
of Community Development or their designee, on a form to be supplied by the
Village, and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of this Code.
   If the application is for a Class 2 Tobacco Retailer License as defined in
Section
3-15-15C of this Chapter, the applicant must attach with the application a map
showing that the business is not operating within one-hundred feet (one hundred
feet (100')) of any preexisting public or private preschool or elementary or
secondary school, day care center, playground, public library, or other
building used for educational or recreational programs for persons under the
age of eighteen (18) years.
   Effective as of July 1, 2025, as a condition to obtaining and maintaining a
Class 1 or 2 Tobacco Retailer License, licensees are required to install,
maintain, and operate a high-resolution video surveillance security system
within the licensed store premises, which shall record the activities within
all parts of the licensed store premises and shall function twenty-four (24)
hours a day and be linked to the Village's Axon Fusus security monitoring
system. Licensees shall have until December 31, 2025, to install such video
surveillance security system and link it with the Village's system. Licensees
shall post signage notifying patrons and employees that the store premises are
under video surveillance.
   Attached to each application, the applicant shall submit an affidavit
attesting that the applicant will conduct business in compliance with all
State, County, and local laws and ordinances.
(Ords. 18-04-14, 21-08-41, 25-12-36)
3-15-4: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   The annual license fees for Class 1 and Class 2 Tobacco Retailer
Licenses, effective for the licensing period beginning July 1, 2025, are set
forth in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Code.
   B.   The initial license fee for a tobacco retailer license shall be paid in
full within fourteen (14) days of the adoption of the ordinance creating the
new license and authorizing its issuance to the applicant. The initial license
shall be valid until the following June 30, unless suspended or revoked in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   C.   A renewal tobacco retailer license shall be valid for a period of one
year beginning on July 1 of an applicable year and expiring on June 30 of the
following year, unless suspended or revoked in accordance with the provisions
of this chapter. The annual fee for a renewal license shall be paid in one lump
sum on or before September 30 of the applicable year.
   D.   A tobacco retailer's license is not transferrable or renewable.
   E.   A tobacco retailer's license shall be in addition to, and not in lieu
of, any automatic vending machine operator's license(s) which may be required
relative to the sale of tobacco products.
(Ords. 96-4-17, 98-9-46, 03-20-83, 21-01-07, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-5: NUMBER OF TOBACCO RETAILER LICENSES:
   A.   The number of Tobacco Retailer licenses authorized to be issued shall
be set and amended from time to time by the President and Board of Trustees and
shall be kept on record in the Office of the Village Clerk.
   B.   Class 1 Tobacco Retailer License:
      1.   Class 1 Tobacco Retailer Licenses shall be issued to grocery stores,
convenience stores, liquor stores, and gasoline stations. Class 1 Tobacco
Retailers sell products other than tobacco products, electronic cigarettes,
and/or alternative nicotine products as their primary business. Class 1 Tobacco
Retailer License authorizes the sale of cigarettes, cigars, and all other
tobacco types, as well as electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine
products. It excludes the sale of any product that contains THC, Illicit THC
Products, Kratom, or Synthetic Cannabinoids.
   C.   Class 2 Tobacco Retailer License:
      1.   Class 2 Tobacco Retailer Licenses shall be issued to any business
wishing to sell tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products, within the Village, excluding grocery stores, convenience
stores, liquor stores, and gasoline stations. Class 2 Tobacco Retailer License
authorizes the sale of cigarettes, cigars, and all other tobacco types, as well
as electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products. It excludes the
sale of any product that contains THC, Illicit THC Products, Kratom, or
Synthetic Cannabinoids. The authorized number of Class 2 Tobacco Retailer
Licenses is set to twelve (12).
   D.   Any Tobacco Retailer license which is revoked or not issued shall
automatically reduce the number of authorized licenses by the total number of
revoked or non-issued licenses. The applicant for a Tobacco Retailer license
under the provisions of this chapter must apply for the appropriate license and
pay the initial annual license fee for such license within fourteen (14) days
of authorizing its issuance to the applicant and adoption of the ordinance
increasing the number of Tobacco Retailer licenses. In the event any applicant
fails to pay the initial license fee within said fourteen (14) day period, such
license shall be revoked, and the number of authorized licenses involved is
automatically reduced by the number of revocations.
(Ords. 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-6: RESPONSIBILITY FOR ACTS OF EMPLOYEES:
   Any person holding a tobacco retailer's license shall be responsible for the
acts of his/her/their/its employees, and any violation of this chapter or any
other provisions of this Code by any such employee that occurs in the course of
his/her employment shall also constitute a violation by the licensee.
(Ords. 18-04-14, 21-08-41, 25-12-36)
3-15-7: SUSPENSION; REVOCATION OF LICENSE; FINE; COSTS:
   A.   The Village President shall be charged with the administration of this
chapter. The Village President may suspend or revoke any license issued under
the provisions of this chapter if he determines that the licensee has violated
any of the provisions of this chapter. In lieu of, or in addition to, the
suspension or revocation of a license, the Village President may levy a fine on
the licensee as defined in section
3-15-14 of this chapter.
   B.   No such license shall be suspended or revoked and no licensee shall be
fined except after a hearing before the Village President, or his designee,
with at least seven (7) days’ prior written notice to the licensee, affording
the licensee an opportunity to appear and defend against the charges contained
in such notice. Notice of said hearing shall be given by certified mail, return
receipt requested, or by personal service.
   C.   The Village President shall within seven (7) days after such hearing,
if he determines after such hearing that the license should be revoked or
suspended, and/or that the licensee should be fined, state the reasons for such
determination in a written order along with the amount of the fine, the period
of suspension and/or that the license has been revoked. A copy of such order
shall be served upon the licensee, in the same manner as required for the
notice of the hearing, within seven (7) days of its issuance.
   D.   Any licensee determined by the Village President to have violated any
of the provisions of this chapter shall pay to the Village the costs of the
hearing before the Village President on such violation. Said costs shall
include, but not be limited to, court reporter fees, the costs of the
transcripts or the recording of the hearing, attorney fees, the cost of
preparing and mailing notices and orders, and all other miscellaneous expenses
incurred by the Village in regard to the hearing. The licensee shall pay said
costs to the Village within thirty (30) days of notification of the amount of
the costs by the Village President. Notification shall be sent in the same
manner as required for the notice of the hearing. Failure to pay said costs
within thirty (30) days of notification shall constitute a violation of this
chapter and may be cause for suspension or revocation of the license, and/or
the levy of a fine. (Ords. 18-04-14, 21-08-41)
3-15-8: USE OF PREMISES AFTER LICENSE REVOCATION:
   When any license issued under this chapter is revoked, no tobacco retailer
license shall be granted to said licensee for a period of six (6) months
thereafter for the premises described in such revoked license.
(Ords. 96-4-17, 04-27-21, 25-12-36)
3-15-9: PROHIBITED SALES; DELIVERY; SIGNS:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away
or deliver any tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products, to any person under twenty-one (21) years of age. Before
selling, offering for sale, giving, or furnishing a tobacco product, electronic
cigarette, or alternative nicotine product to another person, the person
selling, offering for sale, giving, or furnishing the tobacco product,
electronic cigarette, or alternative nicotine product shall verify that the
person is at least twenty one (21) years of age by examining from any person
that appears to be under thirty (30) years of age a government-issued
photographic identification that establishes the person to be twenty one (21)
years of age or older.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any licensee to sell, offer for sale, give
away, possess, deliver or keep with the intention of selling, giving away or
delilvering any tobacco product, electronic cigarette or e-cigarette, and/or
alternative nicotine products, which is in violation of any State, County or
local law.
   C.   It shall be unlawful to sell cigarettes not in the manufacturer-sealed
packs. Single or loose cigarette sales are prohibited.
   D.   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale, give away
or deliver any tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products that contain THC, Illicit THC Products, Kratom, or Synthetic
Cannabinoids. This includes but is not limited to any product: (1) intended for
human consumption by any means, including but not limited to, oral ingestion,
inhalation, smoking, or topical absorption that (2) contains naturally
occurring or synthetic tetrahydrocannabinol, including its salts, isomers, and
salts of isomers whenever the existence of such salts, isomers, and salts of
isomers is possible within the specific chemical designation and any
preparation, mixture, or substance containing, or mixed or infused with, any
detectable amount of tetrahydrocannabinol or tetrahydrocannabolic acid,
including, but not limited to, delta-8-tetrahydrocannabinol, delta-9-
tetrahydrocannabinol, delta-10-tetrahydrocannabinol, tetrahydrocannabolic acid,
tetrahydrocannabipherol, or hexahydrocannabinol, however derived, or any other
substance determined to have similar intoxicating effects on the mind or body.
For the purposes of this definition, "isomer" means the optical, position, and
geometric isomers.
   E.   Signs informing the public of the age restrictions provided for herein
shall be posted at or near every display of tobacco products, electronic
cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products, and on or upon every vending
machine which offers tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or
alternative nicotine products for sale by the owner or operator of such display
of tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine
products, or vending machine, or said owner's or operator's agent, employee, or
independent contractor. Each such sign shall be plainly visible and shall state
in letters at least one inch (1") in height as follows:
      THE SALE OF TOBACCO PRODUCTS, ELECTRONIC CIGARETTES, AND ALTERNATIVE
NICOTINE PRODUCTS TO PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE YEARS OF AGE IS PROHIBITED BY LAW
   F.   Every act or omission regardless of its nature, constituting a
violation of any of the provisions of this section by any owner, operator, or
the agent or employee of such owner and/or operator shall be deemed and held to
be the act of the owner and/or operator; and such owner and/or operator shall
be punished in the same manner as if such act or omission had been done or
omitted by the owner and/or operator personally.
(Ords. 18-04-14, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-10: PROHIBITION AGAINST PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF SIXTEEN SELLING:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage, employ or permit a minor person
under sixteen (16) years of age to sell tobacco products electronic cigarettes,
and/or alternative nicotine products. (Ords. 16-02-08, 21-08-41, 24-05-16)
3-15-11: PURCHASE BY PERSONS UNDER THE AGE OF TWENTY-ONE PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful for any minor person under twenty-one (21) years of age
to purchase any tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products, or to misrepresent his/her identity or age, or to use any
false or altered identification for the purpose of purchasing tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products.
(Ords. 16-02-08, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-12: POSSESSION BY PERSONS UNDER TWENTY-ONE PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful for any person under twenty-one (21) years of age to
possess any tobacco products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative
nicotine products.
(Ords. 16-02-08, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-13: CERTAIN FREE DISTRIBUTIONS PROHIBITED:
   It shall be unlawful for any person in the business of selling or otherwise
distributing, promoting or advertising tobacco products, electronic cigarettes,
and/or alternative nicotine products to give away or deliver tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products free of charge to
any person on any right-of-way, sidewalk, park, playground or other property
owned by the Village, any school district, the Oak Lawn Park District or the
Oak Lawn Public Library.
(Ords. 16-02-08, 21-08-41, 25-12-36)
3-15-14: VENDING MACHINES - LOCKING DEVICES:
   A.   It shall be unlawful to sell, offer for sale, give away, deliver, or
keep with the intention of selling, giving away, or delivering any tobacco
products, electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products by use of
a vending machine, unless such vending machine is equipped with a manual,
electric or electronic locking device controlled by the owner or operator of
the establishment upon which the vending machine is located, or the agent or
employee of such owner or operator, so as to prevent its operation by any
person under twenty-one (21) years of age.
   B.   Any premises where access by any person under twenty-one (21) years of
age is prohibited by law, or premises where the public is generally not
permitted and where vending machines are strictly for the use of employees of
the business located on such premises, shall be exempt from the requirements of
subsection A of this section.
   C.   Vending machines used for the sale of tobacco products, electronic
cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products, and which are required to
have a locking device shall only be used to dispense tobacco products,
electronic cigarettes, and/or alternative nicotine products.
(Ords. 16-02-08, 21-08-41, 24-05-16, 25-12-36)
3-15-15: PENALTY:
   A.   Any person under twenty-one (21) years of age who is found to be in
violation of section
3-15-11 or
3-15-12 of this chapter shall be subject to the following penalties:
      1.   First violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of fifty
dollars ($50.00).
      2.   Second violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of not
less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00).
      3.   Third violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of not
less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00).
      4.   Fourth or further violation within a twelve (12) month period: A
fine of not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
   B.   Any person who is found to be in violation of any section of this
chapter other than section
3-15-11 or
3-15-12 of this chapter shall be subject to the following penalties:
      1.   First violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of not
less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) nor more than two thousand dollars
($2,000.00). Said fine may be in addition to the suspension or revocation of
any tobacco retailer's license held by said person.
      2.   Second violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of not
less than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) nor more than three thousand dollars
($3,000.00). Said fine may be in addition to the suspension or revocation of
any tobacco retailer's license held by said person.
      3.   Third violation within a twelve (12) month period: A fine of three
thousand dollars ($3,000.00) nor more than four thousand dollars ($4,000.00)
and the automatic revocation of any tobacco retailer's license held by said
person.
      4.   Fourth or further violation within a twelve (12) month period: A
fine of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00) nor more than five thousand dollars
($5,000.00) and a minimum of thirty (30) hours of community service. (Ords. 18-
18-70, 21-08-41, 24-05-16)
CHAPTER 16
SURCHARGE FOR EMERGENCY 911 TELEPHONE SYSTEM
SECTION:
3-16-1: Surcharge Imposed
3-16-2: Referendum Authorized
3-16-3: Definitions
3-16-4: Exempt Network Connections
3-16-5: Effective Date Of Surcharge
3-16-6: Remittance
3-16-7: Written Report Of Remittance Required
3-16-8: Erroneous Payment
3-16-1: SURCHARGE IMPOSED:
A surcharge is hereby imposed, subject to the provisions of Section
3-16-2 of this Chapter, upon all billed subscribers of network connections
provided by telecommunications carriers engaged in the business of transmitting
messages by means of electricity originating within the corporate limits of the
Village for funding of the maintenance and improvement of the Village's "911"
emergency telephone system. (Ord. 91-19-85)
3-16-2: REFERENDUM AUTHORIZED:
   A.   A referendum shall be placed by the County Clerk of Cook County on the
March 17, 1992, ballot for all legal voters residing in the Village to vote
upon the following question:
 
Shall the Village of Oak Lawn impose a surcharge of up to one and no/     Y 
100 dollars ($1.00) per month per network connection, which surcharge
expense will be added to the monthly bill you receive for telephone or    N 
telecommunications charges, for the purpose of main- taining and
improving a 9-1-1 Emergency Telephone System?
 
   B.   If a majority of the votes cast upon the question are in favor thereof,
a surcharge is hereby imposed at a rate of one dollar ($1.00) per month per in-
service network connection, as hereinafter defined. A network connection shall
not be deemed to be in service where a subscriber's account is deemed
uncollectible by the telecommunications carrier. (Ord. 91-19-85)
3-16-3: DEFINITIONS:
For purpose of this Chapter the following definitions shall apply:
NETWORK CONNECTIONS: The number of voice grade communications channels directly
between a subscriber and a telecommunications carrier's public switched network
without the intervention of any other telecommunications carriers' switched
network which would be required to carry the subscriber's interpremises
traffic.
TELECOMMUNICATIONS CARRIER: Any natural individual, firm, trust, estate,
partnership, association, joint stock company, joint adventure, corporation,
municipal corporation or political subdivision of this State, or a receiver,
trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court
engaged in the business of transmitting messages by means of electricity.
TRANSMITTING MESSAGES: Shall have the meaning ascribed to the term in section
8-11-2 of the Illinois Municipal Code 1 . (Ord. 91-19-85)
 
Notes
1 1. 65 ILCS 5/8-11-2.
3-16-4: EXEMPT NETWORK CONNECTIONS:
The Village Clerk shall provide any telecommunications carrier subject to the
surcharge with a certified list of those network connections assigned to the
Village to be exempt from imposition of the surcharge. The certified list may
be revised by the Village on sixty (60) days' prior written notice provided to
the telecommunications carriers. (Ord. 91-19-85)
3-16-5: EFFECTIVE DATE OF SURCHARGE:
The surcharge shall be imposed on the first day of the month following the
expiration of thirty (30) days from the date the Village Clerk certifies to any
of the telecommunications carriers who are subject to the surcharge that the
referendum referred to in Section
3-16-2 of this Chapter has passed. (Ord. 91-19-85)
