customer for the next billing cycle following the violation or following the
discovery of the violation. The cable or video provider is responsible for
providing the credits, and the customer is under no obligation to request the
credit. (Ord. 07-25-76)
CHAPTER 26
SPECIAL SERVICE AREA NUMBER 2005-1 SALES TAX
SECTION:
3-26-1: Definitions
3-26-2: Tax Imposed
3-26-3: Exemptions
3-26-4: Exclusions
3-26-5: Passing On The Tax
3-26-6: Collection
3-26-7: Filing Returns And Remittance
3-26-8: Registration
3-26-9: Administration And Maintenance
3-26-10: Failure To Pay Tax
3-26-11: Resale Numbers
3-26-12: Penalty
3-26-1: DEFINITIONS:
   A.   For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
   PERSON: Any natural individual, firm, partnership, association, joint stock
company, joint, public or private corporation, limited liability company, or a
receiver, executor, guardian or other representative appointed by order of any
court.
   RETAILER: Means and includes every "person" engaged in the business of
making "sales at retail".
   SERVICEMAN: Any "person" who is engaged in the occupation of making "sales
of service".
   SPECIAL SERVICE AREA: The special service area established pursuant to
ordinance 06-23-146, adopted December 12, 2006, and legally described as the
following:
      Originally known as:
      Lots 1 and 2 in Boyd's subdivision of part of the southeast 1/4 of the
southeast 1/4 of section 3, township 37 north, range 13, east of the third
principal meridian, (except that part taken for highway purposes), in Cook
County, Illinois;
      Now known as:
      Lots 1 and 2 in the Target Oak Lawn re-subdivision, being a re-
subdivision of Boyd's subdivision of part of the southeast 1/4 of the southeast
1/4 of section 3, township 37 north, range 13, east of the third principal
meridian, (except that part taken for highway purposes), all in Cook County,
Illinois;
      P.I.N.'s: 24-03-410-024 and -025.
      The approximate street location of said territory is described as
follows: The northeast corner of Keeler Avenue and 95th Street, in the village
of Oak Lawn, Illinois.
   TAXPAYER: A "retailer" or "serviceman" who is required to pay either of the
taxes imposed by this chapter.
   VILLAGE: The village of Oak Lawn, Cook County, Illinois.
   B.   Any word or term used in this chapter that is not specifically defined
in this section, including, but not limited to, those words and terms set forth
in this chapter in quotation marks which are defined in either the Illinois
service occupation tax act 1  or the Illinois retailers' occupation tax act 2 ,
shall be given the same meaning as given to those words or terms in the
Illinois service occupation tax act and the Illinois retailers' occupation tax
act. (Ord. 08-19-56)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
2 2. 35 ILCS 120/1 et seq.
3-26-2: TAX IMPOSED:
   A.   A tax is imposed upon all "persons" engaged in the business of making
sales of service (referred to as "servicemen") on all tangible personal
property "transferred" as an incident of a "sale of service", including
"computer software", and including photographs, negatives, and positives that
are the product of "photoprocessing", but not including products of
"photoprocessing" produced for use in motion pictures for public commercial
exhibition, within the "special service area". Unless otherwise provided in
this chapter, the tax imposed by this subsection is at the rate of one-half of
one percent (0.5%) of the "selling price" from the sales of tangible personal
property made in the course of business within the "special service area".
For the purpose of computing this tax, in no event shall the "selling price" be
less than the "cost price" to the "serviceman" of the tangible personal
property "transferred". The "selling price" of each item of tangible personal
property "transferred" as an incident of a "sale of service" may be shown as a
distinct and separate item on the "serviceman's" billing to the service
customer. If the "selling price" is not so shown, the "selling price" of the
tangible personal property is deemed to be fifty percent (50%) of the
"serviceman's" entire billing to the service customer. When, however, a
"serviceman" contracts to design, develop, and produce special order machinery
or equipment, the tax imposed by this subsection shall be based on the
"serviceman's cost price" of the tangible personal property "transferred"
incident to the completion of the contract.
At the election of any registered "serviceman" made for each fiscal year,
"sales of service" in which the aggregate annual "cost price" of tangible
personal property "transferred" as an incident to the "sales of service" is
less than thirty five percent (35%), or seventy five percent (75%) in the case
of "servicemen transferring" prescription drugs or "servicemen" engaged in
"graphic arts production", of the aggregate annual total "gross receipts" from
all "sales of service", the tax imposed by this subsection shall be based on
the "serviceman's cost price" of the tangible personal property "transferred"
incident to the sale of those services.
With respect to gasohol, as defined in the use tax act, 35 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 105/1, the tax imposed by this subsection shall apply to seventy
percent (70%) of the cost price of property transferred as an incident to the
sale of service on or after January 1, 1990, and before July 1, 2003, and to
one hundred percent (100%) of the cost price thereafter.
The tax shall be imposed at the rate of one-half of one percent (0.5%) on food
prepared for immediate consumption and transferred incident to a sale of
service subject to this chapter or the Illinois service occupation tax act, 35
Illinois Compiled Statutes 115/1, by an entity licensed under the hospital
licensing act, 210 Illinois Compiled Statutes 85/1, the nursing home care act,
210 Illinois Compiled Statutes 45/1-101, or the child care act of 1969, 225
Illinois Compiled Statutes 10/1.
For purposes of this chapter, prepaid telephone calling arrangements shall be
considered tangible personal property subject to the tax imposed under this
subsection regardless of the form in which those arrangements may be embodied,
transmitted, or fixed by any method now known or hereafter developed.
Evidence that tangible personal property was sold by any "supplier" for
delivery to a "person" residing or engaged in business in the "special service
area" shall be prima facie evidence that such tangible personal property was
sold for the purpose of resale as an incident to a "sale of service" taxable
under this subsection.
   B.   A tax is imposed upon "persons" engaged in the business of selling at
retail tangible personal property (referred to as "retailers"), including
"computer software", and including photographs, negatives, and positives that
are the product of "photoprocessing", but not including products of
"photoprocessing" produced for use in motion pictures for public commercial
exhibition, within the "special service area". Unless otherwise provided in
this chapter, the tax imposed by this subsection is at the rate of one-half of
one percent (0.5%) of "gross receipts" from the "sales at retail" of personal
property made in the course of business within the "special service area".
With respect to gasohol, as defined in the use tax act, 35 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 105/1, the tax imposed by this subsection shall apply to seventy
percent (70%) of the proceeds of sales made on or after January 1, 1990, and
before July 1, 2003, and to one hundred percent (100%) of the cost price
thereafter.
For purposes of this chapter, prepaid telephone calling arrangements shall be
considered tangible personal property subject to the tax imposed under this
subsection regardless of the form in which those arrangements may be embodied,
transmitted, or fixed by any method now known or hereafter developed.
   C.   Except as provided in section
3-26-3 of this chapter, the taxes imposed by this section shall be imposed on
the same basis as the taxes imposed by the Illinois service occupation tax act
and the Illinois retailers' occupation tax act.
   D.   The taxes imposed by this section are not imposed on any business,
activity, act or privilege to the extent that such business, activity, act or
privilege may not, under the constitutions or statutes of the United States or
the state of Illinois, be made the subject of taxation by the "village".
   E.   The taxes imposed by this section are imposed in addition to all other
taxes imposed by the "village", the state of Illinois or any other municipal
corporation or political subdivision of the state of Illinois. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-3: EXEMPTIONS:
   A.   Exempt from the tax imposed by subsection
3-26-2A of this chapter shall be those items of tangible personal property that
are exempt from taxation under the Illinois service occupation tax act. To the
extent a specific item of tangible personal property described in the Illinois
service occupation tax act is not defined in this chapter, such specific item
shall be given the same meaning under this chapter as given to that specific
item under the Illinois service occupation tax act. In addition, tangible
personal property "transferred" incident to the completion of a maintenance
agreement is exempt from the tax imposed by subsection
3-26-2A of this chapter.
   B.   Exempt from the tax imposed by subsection
3-26-2B of this chapter shall be the "gross receipts" from proceeds from the
sale of those items of tangible personal property that are exempt from taxation
under the Illinois retailers' occupation tax act. To the extent a specific item
of tangible personal property described in the Illinois retailers' occupation
tax act is not defined in this chapter, such specific item shall be given the
same meaning under this chapter as given to that specific item under the
Illinois retailers' occupation tax act.
   C.   Exempt from the tax imposed by subsection
3-26-2A of this chapter are those items of tangible personal property that are
exempt from taxation under the home rule municipal service occupation tax act.
To the extent a specific item of tangible personal property described in
section
8-11-5 of the home rule municipal service occupation tax act is not defined in
this chapter, such specific item shall be given the same meaning under this
chapter as given to that specific item under the home rule municipal service
occupation tax act.
   D.   Exempt from the tax imposed by subsection
3-26-2B of this chapter are those items of tangible personal property that are
exempt from taxation under the home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax
act. To the extent a specific item of tangible personal property described in
section
8-11-1 of the home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax act is not defined
in this chapter, such specific item shall be given the same meaning under this
chapter as given to that specific item under the home rule municipal retailers'
occupation tax act. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-4: EXCLUSIONS:
   A.   "Gross Receipts": Any amount added to the "selling price" of tangible
personal property by the "retailer" because of the "village's" home rule
municipal retailers' occupation tax (see section
3-2-1 of this title), the Illinois retailers' occupation tax or the Illinois
use tax 1  and collected from the "purchaser", shall not be regarded as a part
of the "retailer's gross receipts" that are subject to the tax imposed by this
chapter.
   B.   "Selling Price": Any amount added by a "serviceman" to the "selling
price" of tangible personal property sold by the "serviceperson" as an incident
of a "sale of service" because of the "village's" home rule municipal service
occupation tax (see section
3-2-2 of this title), the Illinois service occupation tax or the Illinois
service use tax 2  and collected from the "purchaser", shall not be regarded as
a part of the "selling price" that is subject to the tax imposed by this
chapter. (Ord. 08-19-56)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 105/1 et seq.
2 2. 35 ILCS 110/1 et seq.
3-26-5: PASSING ON THE TAX:
The legal incidence of the taxes imposed by this chapter is on the "retailer"
and the "serviceman". Nevertheless, the "village" authorizes "persons" subject
to the taxes imposed by this chapter to reimburse themselves for their tax
liability by separately stating such tax as an additional charge, which charge
may be stated in combination, in a single amount, with other state of Illinois
and "village" taxes that "retailers" and "servicemen" are required to collect
and remit to the state of Illinois and the "village". (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-6: COLLECTION:
   A.   The taxes hereby imposed by section
3-26-2 of this chapter, and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an
incident thereto, shall be collected by the "village" treasurer through the
procedures described in section
3-26-7 of this chapter.
   B.   The taxes hereby imposed by section
3-26-2 of this chapter shall be paid in addition to any and all other taxes.
The taxes hereby imposed by section
3-26-2 of this chapter shall be paid to the "village" treasurer by any
"serviceman transferring" tangible personal property as an incident to a "sale
of service" taxable under subsection
3-26-2A of this chapter and by any "retailer" making a sale of tangible
personal property taxable under subsection
3-26-2B of this chapter.
   C.   Any tax required to be paid pursuant to section
3-26-2 of this chapter shall constitute a debt owed by the "retailer" or the
"serviceman" to the "village". (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-7: FILING RETURNS AND REMITTANCE:
   A.   On or before the twentieth day of each month, every "retailer" and
"serviceman" maintaining a place of business within the "special service area"
shall file with the "village" treasurer a remittance return and remit all
applicable tax for the preceding calendar month. The return shall be filed on a
form prescribed by the "village" treasurer, containing such information as the
"village" treasurer may reasonably require.
   B.   Notwithstanding the monthly return requirement of subsection A of this
section, in the event that a "retailer" or "serviceman" maintaining a place of
business within the "special service area" would remit between fifty dollars
($50.00) and one hundred dollars ($100.00) in tax revenue to the "village" per
month, said "taxpayer" shall make a tax return as required on a semiannual,
rather than monthly, basis. Said returns shall be in compliance with subsection
A of this section, except that they shall cover the "sales of service" and the
"sales at retail" during the semiannual (6 month) period, and shall be filed on
or before March 20 and September 20 each year.
   C.   Notwithstanding the monthly return requirement of subsection A of this
section, in the event that a "retailer" or "serviceman" maintaining a place of
business within the "special service area" would remit less than fifty dollars
($50.00) in tax revenue to the "village" per month, said "taxpayer" shall make
a return as required on an annual, rather than monthly, basis. Said returns
shall be in compliance with subsection A of this section, except that they
shall cover "sales of service" and the "sales at retail" during the prior one
year (12 month) period, and shall be filed on or before March 20 each year.
   D.   Where such tangible personal property is sold under a conditional sales
contract, or under any other form of sale wherein the payment of the principal
sum, or a part thereof, is extended beyond the close of the period for which
the return is filed, the "retailer" or the "serviceman", in collecting the tax
may collect, for each tax return period, only the tax applicable to the part of
the "selling price" actually received during such tax return period. (Ord. 08-
19-56)
3-26-8: REGISTRATION:
Every "retailer" or "serviceman" maintaining a place of business within the
"special service register" with the "village" administrative services
department within thirty (30) days after the effective date of this chapter or
the date of becoming a "retailer" or "serviceman" within the "special service
area", whichever is later. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-9: ADMINISTRATION AND MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Every "retailer" engaged in the business of selling tangible personal
property at retail in the "special service area", every "supplier" required or
authorized to collect the taxes hereunder and every "serviceman" making sales
of service within the "special service area" shall keep records and books of
all sales of tangible personal property, together with invoice bills of lading,
sales records, copies of bills of sale, inventories prepared as of December 31
of each year or otherwise annually as has been the custom in the specific trade
and other pertinent papers and documents. Every "retailer" who is engaged in
the business of selling tangible personal property at retail in the "special
service area", every "supplier" required or authorized to collect the taxes
hereunder and every "serviceman" making sales of service in the "special
service area" and who, in connection with such business, also engages in other
activities (including, but not limited to, engaging in a service occupation)
shall keep such additional records and books of all such activities as will
accurately reflect the character and scope of such activities and the amount of
receipts realized therefrom. The "village" may adopt rules that establish
requirements, including record forms and formats, for records required to be
kept and maintained by "taxpayers". For purposes of this section, "records"
means all data maintained by the "taxpayer", including data on paper,
microfilm, microfiche or any type of machine sensible data compilation. All
books and records and other papers and documents which are required by this
section shall be kept in the English language and shall, at all times during
business hours of the day, be subject to inspection by the "village" or its
duly authorized agents and employees.
   B.   To support deductions made on the tax return form, or authorized under
this chapter, on account of receipts from isolated or occasional sales of
tangible personal property, on account of receipts from sales of tangible
personal property for resale, on account of receipts from sales to governmental
bodies or other exempted types of "purchasers", on account of receipts from
sales of tangible personal property in interstate commerce, and on account of
receipts from any other kind of transaction that is not taxable under this
chapter, entries in any books, records or other pertinent papers or documents
of the "taxpayer" in relation thereto shall be in detail sufficient to show the
name and address of the "taxpayer's" customer in each such transaction, the
character of every such transaction, the date of every such transaction, the
amount of receipts realized from every such transaction and such other
information as may be necessary to establish the nontaxable character of such
transaction under this chapter.
   C.   Except in the case of a sale to a "purchaser" who will always resell
and deliver the property to his customers outside the "special service area",
anyone claiming that he has made a nontaxable sale for resale in some form as
tangible personal property shall also keep a record of the "purchaser's"
registration number or resale number with the "village".
   D.   It shall be presumed that all sales of tangible personal property are
subject to tax under this chapter until the contrary is established, and the
burden of proving that a transaction is not taxable hereunder shall be upon the
"retailer" or "serviceman" who would be required to remit the tax to the
"village" if such transaction is taxable. In the course of any audit or
investigation or hearing by the "village" with reference to a given "taxpayer",
if the "village" finds that the "taxpayer" lacks documentary evidence needed to
support the "taxpayer's" claim to exemption from tax hereunder, the "village"
is authorized to notify the "taxpayer" in writing to produce such evidence, and
the "taxpayer" shall have sixty (60) days, subject to the right of the
"village" to extend this period either on request for good cause shown or on
its own motion, from the date when such notice is sent to the "taxpayer" by
certified or registered mail (or delivered to the "taxpayer" if the notice is
served personally) in which to obtain and produce such evidence for the
"village's" inspection, failing which the matter shall be closed, and the
transaction shall be conclusively presumed to be taxable hereunder.
   E.   The "village's" director of administrative services, or any person so
certified as a deputy or representative, may inspect the books and records of a
"retailer" or "serviceman" required to pay either of the taxes levied by
section
3-26-2 of this chapter, and the purpose of such inspection shall be to ensure
the proper administration of said section and enforcement of the collection of
the tax imposed. It is unlawful for any "retailer" or "serviceman" to prevent,
hinder or interfere with the "village's" director of administrative services or
the duly authorized deputy or representative in the discharge of duties in the
enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-10: FAILURE TO PAY TAX:
In the event of failure by any "retailer" or "serviceman" to pay to the
"village" either of the taxes imposed by this chapter by the date the same
shall be due, interest shall accumulate at a rate as imposed by local
government taxpayers' bill of rights act located at chapter 18 of this title.
In addition, a penalty shall be assessed and collected against such "retailer"
or "serviceman" as imposed by the local government taxpayers' bill of rights
act located at chapter 18 of this title.
   A.   Whenever any "retailer" or "serviceman" shall fail to pay any tax as
herein provided, the "village" attorney shall, upon the request of the
"village" president and board of trustees, bring or cause to be brought an
action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of the "village" in any
court of competent jurisdiction.
   B.   If the "village president" or his/her designee, after hearing held,
shall find that such "retailer" or "serviceman" has wilfully avoided payment of
either of the taxes imposed by this chapter, the "village" president may
suspend or revoke all "village" licenses held by such tax evader. Such "person"
may have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing to be held not less than
five (5) days after notice of the time and place of the hearing, said notice,
addressed to him at his last known place of business. Pending notice, hearing
and finding, any license which such "retailer" or "serviceman" may possess
shall be temporarily suspended by the "village" president. Any suspension or
revocation of any license shall not release or discharge such "retailer" or
"serviceman" from his/her/its civil liability for the payment of the tax nor
from prosecution for such offense.
   C.   The "taxpayer" shall be entitled to all rights under this chapter as
provided in the local government taxpayers' bill of rights act located at
chapter 18 of this title. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-11: RESALE NUMBERS:
   A.   If the "purchaser" is not registered with the "village's"
administrative services department as a "taxpayer", but claims to be a reseller
of the tangible personal property in such a way that such resales are not
taxable under this chapter, such "purchaser" (except in the case of an out of
state "purchaser" who will always resell and deliver the property to his
customers outside Illinois) shall apply to the "village's" administrative
services department for a resale number. Such applicant shall state facts which
will show the "village's" administrative services department why such applicant
is not liable for tax under this chapter on any of his resales and shall
furnish such additional information as the "village's" administrative services
department may reasonably require.
   B.   Upon approval of the application, the "village's" administrative
services department shall assign a resale number to the applicant and shall
certify such number to him. The "village's" administrative services department
may cancel any such number which is obtained through misrepresentation, or
which is used to make a purchase tax free when the purchase in fact is not a
purchase for resale, or which no longer applies because of the "purchaser's"
having discontinued the making of tax exempt resales of the property. The
"village's" administrative services department may restrict the use of the
number to one year at a time or to some other definite period if the
"village's" administrative services department finds it impracticable or
otherwise inadvisable to issue such numbers for indefinite periods.
   C.   Except as provided in this section, a "sale at retail" shall be made
tax free on the grounds of being a sale for resale if the "purchaser" has an
active registration number or resale number from the "village's" administrative
services department and furnishes that number to the seller in connection with
certifying to the seller that any sale to such "purchaser" is nontaxable
because of being a sale for resale. Failure to present an active registration
number or resale number and a certification to the seller that a sale is for
resale creates a presumption that a sale is not for resale. This presumption
may be rebutted by other evidence that all of the seller's sales are sale for
resale, or that a particular sale is a sale for resale. (Ord. 08-19-56)
3-26-12: PENALTY:
Any "retailer" or "serviceman" violating the provisions of this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), for each offense. Each day a violation exists
shall be a separate offense. (Ord. 08-19-56)
CHAPTER 27
VEHICLE FUEL TAX
SECTION:
3-27-1: Definitions
3-27-2: Tax Imposed
3-27-3: Exemptions
3-27-4: Payment On Retail Purchase
3-27-5: Collection Of Tax
3-27-6: Registration
3-27-7: Filing Returns
3-27-8: Inventory Report
3-27-9: Use Of Vehicle Fuel Tax Monies
3-27-10: Recordkeeping
3-27-11: Commission On Tax
3-27-12: Sales And Uses Presumed Taxable
3-27-13: Failure To Pay Tax
3-27-14: Severability
3-27-15: Penalties For Violations
3-27-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter the following definitions shall apply unless the
context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning:
DISTRIBUTOR OR VEHICLE FUEL DISTRIBUTOR: Any person who produces, refines,
blends, compounds or manufactures vehicle fuel in the village; or transports or
has transported vehicle fuel to any location in the village; or receives in the
village vehicle fuel on which the village vehicle fuel tax has not been paid;
or sells vehicle fuel to a retail dealer for resale in the village. The term
"distributor" shall include any person who transports vehicle fuel into the
village for his own use and consumption, and not for sale or resale.
PERSON: Any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association,
corporation, joint venture, joint stock company, receiver, trustee,
conservator, legal representative, or other legally recognized entity.
RETAIL DEALER OR RETAIL FUEL DEALER: Any person who is engaged in the business
of selling vehicle fuel in the village to a purchaser for the purchaser's use
or consumption, and not for resale in any form.
SALE AT RETAIL: Any sale to a person for that person's use or consumption and
not for resale to another.
SALE, RESALE OR PURCHASE: Any transfer of ownership or title or both, any
exchange or any barter, whether conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by
any means whatsoever for consideration.
TAX: The village vehicle fuel tax provided for in this chapter.
USE: The exercise of any right to or power over vehicle fuel incident to the
ownership thereof, including, but not limited to, the receipt of vehicle fuel
by any person into a fuel supply tank of a vehicle.
VEHICLE: Any machine or device in, upon or by which any person or property is
or may be transported or drawn upon a rail, street, road, highway or otherwise
upon land, in or upon water, or through the air. The term "vehicle" includes,
without limitation, automobiles, trucks, buses, trains, motorcycles, boats,
airplanes and helicopters.
VEHICLE FUEL: Any volatile and flammable liquid or gas produced, blended or
compounded for the purpose of or which is suitable for operating a vehicle, or
which is used in propelling a vehicle. The term "vehicle fuel" includes,
without limitation, gasoline, gasohol, diesel oil, motor benzol, motor benzene,
propane gas fuel, kerosene and "special fuel" as defined in the motor fuel tax
law 1 .
VILLAGE: The village of Oak Lawn, Cook County, Illinois. (Ord. 10-05-07)
 
Notes
1 1. 35 ILCS 505/1 et seq.
3-27-2: TAX IMPOSED:
A tax is hereby imposed upon the privilege of purchasing or using, in the
village, vehicle fuel purchased in a sale at retail. The tax shall be at a rate
of six cents ($0.06) per gallon of vehicle fuel. The ultimate incidence of and
liability for payment of the tax shall be upon the purchaser or user of the
vehicle fuel, and nothing in this chapter shall be construed to impose a tax
upon the occupation of selling or distributing vehicle fuel. It shall be a
violation of this chapter for any distributor or retail fuel dealer to fail to
add this tax to the retail price of vehicle fuel to absorb the tax. The tax
shall be in addition to any and all other taxes. (Ords. 10-05-07, 20-05-09, 20-
11-27)
3-27-3: EXEMPTIONS:
The tax imposed by this chapter shall not apply to the following sales and uses
of vehicle fuel:
   A.   Sale by a distributor to another distributor holding a valid
registration certificate.
   B.   Sale by a distributor or retail fuel dealer whose place of business is
outside of the village.
   C.   Sale or use for purposes other than for propulsion or operation of a
vehicle.
   D.   Sale to or use by any transportation agency, as defined in the regional
transportation authority act 1 , which is operated by a grant from or has a
service agreement with the regional transportation authority or any of its
service boards.
   E.   Sale of or use of to the extent the tax imposed by this chapter would
violate the state or United States constitution.
   F.   Sale to or use by the federal government or any state or local
government body.
   G.   Sale to or use by any common carrier, certified by the carrier to be
used for consumption, shipment or storage in the conduct of its business as an
air common carrier, for a flight destination outside of the United States.
(Ord. 10-05-07)
 
Notes
1 1. 70 ILCS 3615/1.01 et seq.
3-27-4: PAYMENT ON RETAIL PURCHASE:
The term "use in the village" shall be deemed to occur only at the place in the
village where the vehicle fuel is transferred into the vehicle by which it is
to be consumed. To the extent that a person has paid the tax imposed by this
chapter on the retail purchase of vehicle fuel, he shall be exempt from the
payment of any liability for the tax in the use of such fuel. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-5: COLLECTION OF TAX:
   A.   The village vehicle fuel tax shall be collected by each vehicle fuel
distributor who sells such vehicle fuel to a retail fuel dealer doing business
in the village. Any distributor who shall pay the tax to the village shall
collect the tax from any retail fuel dealer to whom the distributor sells
vehicle fuel. The retail fuel dealer shall in turn then collect the tax from
the purchaser of the vehicle fuel. Any distributor who sells vehicle fuel
directly to a purchaser or user, for delivery in the village, and not for
resale, shall collect the tax from the purchaser or user.
   B.   If any retail fuel dealer receives vehicle fuel upon which the village
vehicle fuel tax has not been collected by the distributor, the retailer dealer
shall remit such tax directly to the village's director of administrative
services by the twentieth day of the month following the month in which he
received such vehicle fuel, and shall collect such tax from his purchasers.
   C.   If any purchaser or user of vehicle fuel receives vehicle fuel upon
which the village fuel tax has not been collected by the distributor or retail
fuel dealer, such purchaser or user shall pay the tax directly to the village
by the twentieth day of the month following the month in which such purchaser
or user made the taxable purchase or use of the vehicle fuel.
   D.   Any tax remittance required to be made directly to the village shall be
made to the village's treasurer and shall be accompanied by a remittance form
prescribed by the village's treasurer.
   E.   Any person who collects the village vehicle fuel tax shall do so as a
trustee for any on account of the village. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-6: REGISTRATION:
Every vehicle fuel distributor doing business on March 1, 2010, shall register
with the village's treasurer on or before March 31, 2010. Every person becoming
a distributor after that date shall register with the village's treasurer
within thirty (30) days after the commencement of such business. (Ord. 10-05-
07)
3-27-7: FILING RETURNS:
Every distributor shall file by the twentieth day of each month with the
village treasurer a remittance return, containing a report of his sales of
vehicle fuel to retail dealers or users in the village occurring in the prior
months. The return shall be in a form prescribed by and furnished by the
village treasurer. If mailed, the return must be postmarked on or before the
twentieth day of the month following the month for which the report is due.
Each such return shall be accompanied by a remittance of the appropriate amount
of tax applicable to the sales reported. Payment shall be made to the village
treasurer. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-8: INVENTORY REPORT:
By March 31, 2010, every retail fuel dealer shall file with the village
treasurer, on forms supplied by the village treasurer for that purpose; an
inventory of all vehicle fuel in the retail fuel dealer's possession on March
1, 2010, at one minute after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. The owner or chief
executive officer of the retail dealer shall sign the inventory report and
attest under oath to its accuracy. With the inventory report, the retail dealer
shall pay to the village the village vehicle fuel tax due on the sale of all
vehicle fuel in the retail dealer's possession on March 1, 2010, at one minute
after twelve o'clock (12:01) A.M. and for which such tax has not been collected
on behalf of the village by a vehicle fuel distributor. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-9: USE OF VEHICLE FUEL TAX MONIES:
Monies collected pursuant to this chapter shall be used for capital
improvements, including, but not limited to: street and alley construction and
rehabilitation, curb and gutter work, storm sewer, bicycle lane markings and
paths, and other street related improvements and to provide revenues for
projects such as right of way and neighborhood revitalization, land
acquisitions, utility and water quality construction projects, and related
costs. All monies collected pursuant to this chapter shall be appropriated to
the newly created 2010 capital improvements BAB fund. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-10: RECORDKEEPING:
Every distributor and every retail fuel dealer required to collect and remit
the tax imposed in this chapter shall keep accurate and complete books and
records of his business of selling vehicle fuel, including the maintenance of
all invoices and other source documents. Every purchaser or user shall keep
accurate and complete books and records of his purchase and uses of vehicle
fuel in the village, including the maintenance of all invoices and other source
documents. All books and records shall be subject to inspection by the village
treasurer, or his/her duly authorized agents or employees of the village, at
all times during regular business hours. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-11: COMMISSION ON TAX:
A distributor or retail fuel dealer remitting the tax to the village shall be
entitled to a commission of one percent (1%) of the tax remitted, to compensate
for the cost of collection, filing returns, and supplying information to the
village treasurer, but in no event shall any commission be allowed on any tax
not remitted when due. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-12: SALES AND USES PRESUMED TAXABLE:
It shall be presumed that all sales and uses of vehicle fuel in the village are
subject to tax under this chapter until the contrary is established. The burden
of proving that a sale or use is not taxable hereunder shall be upon the
distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user so claiming. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-13: FAILURE TO PAY TAX:
   A.   In the event of failure by any distributor, retail fuel dealer,
purchaser or user to pay to the village the tax imposed by this chapter by the
date the same shall be due, interest shall accumulate at a rate as imposed by
chapter 18, "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights Act", of this title. In
addition, a penalty shall be assessed and collected against such distributor,
retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user as imposed by chapter 18, "Local
Government Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights Act", of this title.
   B.   Whenever any distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user shall
fail to pay any tax as herein provided, the village attorney shall, upon the
request of the village president and board of trustees, bring or cause to be
brought an action to enforce the payment of said tax on behalf of the village
in any court of competent jurisdiction.
   C.   If the village president or his/her designee, after hearing held, shall
find that such distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user has wilfully
avoided payment of the tax imposed by this chapter, the village president may
suspend or revoke all village licenses held by such tax evader. Such person may
have an opportunity to be heard at such hearing to be held not less than five
(5) days after notice of the time and place of the hearing, said notice,
addressed to him at his last known place of business. Pending notice, hearing
and finding, any license which such distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser
or user may possess shall be temporarily suspended by the village president.
Any suspension or revocation of any license shall not release or discharge such
distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user from his civil liability for
the payment of the tax nor from prosecution for such offense.
   D.   The distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user shall be
entitled to all rights under this chapter as provided in chapter 18, "Local
Government Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights Act", of this title. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-14: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter or the application of any provision thereof,
is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall not affect
other provisions of this chapter or their application, that can be given effect
without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its application. Each
unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such provision, is
severable, unless otherwise provided. (Ord. 10-05-07)
3-27-15: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS:
Any distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser or user violating the provisions
of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor
more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), for each offense. (Ord. 10-05-
07)
CHAPTER 28
PARKING LOT AND GARAGE OPERATIONS TAX
SECTION:
3-28-1: Short Title
3-28-2: Definitions
3-28-3: Tax Imposed
3-28-4: Rules And Regulations; Authorized; Publication
3-28-5: Inspection
3-28-6: Maintenance Of Records
3-28-7: Claim Checks To Be Issued
3-28-8: Tax Remittance And Returns
3-28-9: Tax To Be Paid To The Village's General Fund
3-28-10: Severability
3-28-11: Fines
3-28-12: Effective Date
3-28-1: SHORT TITLE:
This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the VILLAGE OF OAK LAWN PARKING
LOT AND GARAGE OPERATIONS TAX. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this chapter, whenever any of the following words, terms or
definitions are used, they shall have the meaning ascribed to them in this
section:
MOTOR VEHICLE: Any vehicle which is self-propelled.
OPERATOR: Any person conducting the operation of a "parking lot or garage", as
defined by this chapter, or receiving the consideration for parking or storage
of motor vehicles at such parking place.
PARKING LOT OR GARAGE: Any building, structure, premises, enclosure or other
place, whether enclosed or not, except a public way, within the village of Oak
Lawn, where four (4) or more motor vehicles are stored, housed or parked for
hire, charge, fee or other valuable consideration in a condition ready for use,
including valet parking or where rent or compensation is paid to the owner,
manager or lessee of the premises. Provided, however, that said terms shall not
include residential parking provided for single-family homes or multiple-family
dwelling units wherein an arrangement for such parking is provided on a rental
basis to meet the terms of the Oak Lawn village for off street parking, the
consideration therefor being set forth in the house or apartment lease or in a
separate writing between the landlord and the tenant, whether the parking
charge is payable to the landlord or to the operator of the parking lot or
garage, nor shall said terms include any parking lot or garage owned or
operated by the village of Oak Lawn.
PARKING SPACE: Any parking stall or space, clearly identified, marked with
customary striping lines designating an area set aside for the parking of a
single motor vehicle.
PERSON: Any natural person, trustee, court appointed representative, syndicate,
association, partnership, limited liability company, firm, club, company,
corporation, business trust, institution, agency, government corporation,
municipal corporation, district or other political subdivision, or any other
entity recognized by law as the subject of rights and duties.
VALET PARKING OPERATOR: A person who employs one or more attendants for the
purpose of providing a valet parking service or who contracts his own services,
but not in the capacity of employee, to any business establishment, for the
purpose of providing a valet parking service to such establishment in Oak Lawn.
VALET PARKING SERVICE: A parking service provided to accommodate patrons of any
business establishment, which service is incidental to the business of the
establishment and by which an attendant on behalf of the establishment takes
temporary custody of the patrons' motor vehicle and moves, parks, stores, or
retrieves the vehicle for the patrons' convenience. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-3: TAX IMPOSED:
   A.   There is imposed upon the use and privilege of parking a motor vehicle
in or upon any parking lot or garage in the village of Oak Lawn a tax of one
dollar ($1.00) for each such motor vehicle parked in or upon each parking lot
or garage for which a fee or other valuable consideration is charged even if
the fee is ultimately waived by the operator.
   B.   The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is on
the person who seeks the privilege of occupying space in or upon the parking
lot or garage (such person hereinafter referred to as the "recipient").
   C.   The tax imposed by this chapter shall not apply to residential off
street parking of house or apartment tenants or condominiums, wherein an
arrangement for such parking is provided in the house or apartment lease or in
a separate writing between the landlord and tenant, or if in a condominium
between the condominium association and the owner, occupant or guest of a unit,
whether the parking charge is payable to the landlord, condominium association,
or to the operation of the parking lot or garage.
   D.   The tax imposed by this chapter shall be paid in addition to any and
all other taxes. It shall be the duty of the operator or valet parking operator
of every parking lot or garage to secure the tax from the recipient of the
parking privilege upon each entry into the parking lot or garage for which a
fee or other valuable consideration is charged and to remit the tax to the
department of revenue under procedures prescribed by the village finance
director or as otherwise provided in this chapter.
   E.   Valet parking operators are required to collect and remit the tax
imposed by this chapter, for each motor vehicle parked at a parking lot or
garage, as described in this chapter; however, the valet parking operator is
not required to remit the tax if the valet parking operator pays the tax to the
operator, who shall remit the tax to the village.
   F.   Every person required to collect the tax imposed by this chapter shall
secure the tax from the recipient at the time of the price, charge or rent to
which it applies is collected. If the recipient is given any invoice, receipt
or other statement of the price, charge or rent paid or payable, the tax shall
be stated, charged and shown separately on the document. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-4: RULES AND REGULATIONS; AUTHORIZED; PUBLICATION:
The village's finance director is authorized to adopt, promulgate and enforce
rules and regulations pertaining to the administration and enforcement of this
chapter. Those rules may also be enforced by the village manager or his or her
designee. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-5: INSPECTION:
The director of finance, or any person certified by the director or
representative, may enter the premises of any parking lot or garage during
normal business hours for inspection and examination of books and records for
the proper administration of this chapter and enforcement of the collection of
the tax imposed. It is unlawful for any person to prevent, hinder, or interfere
with the director of finance or the duly authorized deputy or representative in
the discharge of duties in the enforcement of this chapter. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-6: MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every person operating a parking lot or garage
in the village to keep accurate and complete books and records to which the
director of finance, or a representative authorized by the director of finance,
shall have full access, during normal business hours, which records shall
include a daily sheet showing the number of vehicles parked in or on each
parking lot or garage space for which a parking fee has been collected; and the
actual parking lot or garage tax receipts collected from all parking
transactions. For purposes of complying with the provisions of this subsection,
cash register, coin counter, and computer printout data providing the required
information shall be construed as an acceptable accounting method.
   B.   All books and records required by this section shall be retained for at
least four (4) years after the end of the calendar year in which they are
created; provided, however, that an operator on an annual basis may request
approval from the village finance director to discard tickets or tags that were
issued more than one year earlier and the director shall grant such approval if
he or she determines that the operator's books and records satisfy the
requirements of this chapter. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-7: CLAIM CHECKS TO BE ISSUED:
   A.   It shall be the duty of every person operating a parking lot or garage
in the village to issue to the owner or driver parking any motor vehicle in a
parking space, a distinctive ticket claim check or sticker ("ticket").
   B.   The ticket shall bear the date and time of issuance and shall be
accounted for in numerical sequence. Each ticket shall contain the name and
address of the operator of the parking lot or garage upon which parking space
the motor vehicles are parked.
   C.   No person shall operate a "parking lot or garage" as defined in this
chapter without first submitting to the director of finance samples of the
tickets showing the starting and ending numbers, the parking lot or garage
location, and the color and sizes of the tickets; or in the alternative, an
operator may install an automatic entry gate system utilizing sequentially
numbered ticket dispensing device, which system shall provide the director of
finance with printout register and/or statistical information sufficient to
determine parking space usage, which system may be substituted for preprinted
tickets.
   D.   No person shall operate a parking lot or garage in the village in which
parking is permitted on a weekly, monthly or other basis, without requiring the
placement of a sticker upon said motor vehicle, which sticker shall show the
name of the operator and address of the parking lot or garage upon which the
motor vehicle is parked, an identification number in sequence to be placed on
motor vehicle so to be parked the number of the license plate of the motor
vehicle so to be parked and the issuing state; and an indication as to whether
parking is on a weekly or monthly, or other basis, indicating starting and
ending dates of the week, month or other period.
   E.   A sample of the weekly, monthly or other period stickers printed for
the operator shall be submitted to the director of finance for recording and
said operator shall keep a book record of all such stickers issued, showing the
serial number, date, license number of the motor vehicle and the parking charge
imposed. The operator shall remove or cause to be removed and voided said
sticker at the end of the week, month, or other period, and shall cause the
placement of a new sticker upon the motor vehicle at the beginning of each new
period with recordation thereof also placed in the operator's book.
   F.   Or, in the alternative to subsections D and E of this section, the
operator may install a key card system utilizing automatic gates for exiting
purposes, in which event the operator shall provide the director of finance on
or before the thirtieth day of each month during the operation of the parking
lot or garage, a current list of the key cards purchased the previous month,
which card shall contain an identification number, and the amount of tax
assessed as provided in this chapter. Computer printout data or register tape
(as the case may be) shall constitute sufficient evidence of key card purchases
and the appropriate amount of tax assessed.
   G.   Any operator that fails to issue or attach one or more tickets, tags or
receipts in the form or manner provided by this chapter shall be subject to a
fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each motor vehicle to which a ticket, tag or receipt in the
proper form was not issued or upon which a ticket tag was not attached. (Ord.
12-01-05)
3-28-8: TAX REMITTANCE AND RETURNS:
   A.   On or before the last day of each calendar month, every operator shall
file with the department of revenue a remittance and remit all tax due for the
preceding calendar month. The return shall be filed on a form prescribed by the
finance director, containing such information as the finance director may
reasonably require.
   B.   In addition to any other information required by the finance director,
every operator shall report on the remittance return the total amount of
charges collected from recipients during the preceding calendar month for the
privilege of parking a motor vehicle in or upon a parking lot or garage located
in the village of Oak Lawn. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-9: TAX TO BE PAID TO THE VILLAGE'S GENERAL FUND:
All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax under this chapter,
including penalties and interest, shall be paid into village's general fund and
shall be credited to and deposited in the village's general fund. (Ord. 12-01-
05)
3-28-10: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this chapter or the application thereof to any person or
circumstance, is held invalid, the remainder of this chapter and the
application of such provisions to other persons or circumstances shall be
affected thereby. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-11: FINES:
Any person determined to have violated this chapter, as amended, shall be
subject to a fine of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for the first offense,
and a fine of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for the second and each
subsequent offense. Separate and distinct offenses shall be regarded as
committed each day upon which said person shall continue any such violation, or
permit any such violation to exist after notification thereof. It shall be
deemed a violation of this chapter for any person to knowingly furnish false or
inaccurate information to the village. (Ord. 12-01-05)
3-28-12: EFFECTIVE DATE:
The tax imposed by this chapter shall be effective as of March 1, 2012. (Ord.
12-01-05)
CHAPTER 29
VIDEO GAMING
SECTION:
3-29-1: Definition
3-29-2: License Required
3-29-3: Application
3-29-4: Restrictions On Licenses
3-29-5: License Fees
3-29-6: Number Of Licenses
3-29-7: Penalties
3-29-8: Terminal Operators’ Tax
3-29-8.1: Tax Additional
3-29-8.2: Rules
3-29-8.3: Payment And Accounting
3-29-8.4: Failure To Pay Tax
3-29-8.5: Penalties
3-29-8.6: Severability
3-29-1: DEFINITION:
All words and phrases used in this section and not otherwise defined herein,
which are defined in the Video Gaming Act, 230 Illinois Compiled Statutes 40/
1 et seq., shall have the meaning accorded to such words and phrases in said
Act. Unless the context otherwise requires, the following terms used in this
section shall be construed according to the following definitions:
LICENSED ESTABLISHMENT: Any licensed retail establishment where alcoholic
liquor is drawn, poured, mixed, or otherwise served for consumption on the
premises, whether the establishment operates on a nonprofit or for-profit
basis.
TERMINAL OPERATOR: An individual, partnership, corporation, or limited
liability company that is licensed under this Act and that owns, services, and
maintains video gaming terminals for placement in licensed establishments,
licensed truck stop establishments, licensed fraternal establishments, or
licensed veterans establishments.
VIDEO GAMING TERMINAL: Any electronic video game machine that, upon insertion
of cash, electronic cards or vouchers, or any combination thereof, is available
to play or simulate the play of a video game, including but not limited to
video poker, line up, and blackjack, as authorized by the Board as utilizing a
video display and microprocessors in which the player may receive free games or
credits that can be redeemed for cash. The term does not include a machine that
directly dispenses coins, cash, or tokens or is for amusement purposes only.
(Ord. 17-09-19)
3-29-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
No person shall display, operate or otherwise permit the use of any video
gaming terminal without first obtaining a license from the Village upon payment
of a license fee. (Ord. 17-09-19)
3-29-3: APPLICATION:
Applications for a video gaming license shall be made to the Business Licensing
Administrator upon a form to be supplied by the Village and shall contain the
following information:
   A.   Name and address of the applicant, age, date and place of birth;
   B.   Prior convictions, if any, of applicant;
   C.   Place where the video gaming terminal is to be displayed or operated,
and the business conducted at that place;
   D.   Number of video gaming terminals to be displayed or operated;
   E.   Description of video gaming terminal to be covered by the license,
mechanical features and serial number;
   F.   Copy of a valid Illinois Gaming Board license;
   G.   Copy of a valid Illinois liquor license;
   H.   Copy of a valid Village of Oak Lawn liquor license; and
   I.   Such other information as the Village may determine as necessary as set
forth in the application form. (Ord. 17-09-19)
3-29-4: RESTRICTIONS ON LICENSES:
All such video gaming terminals shall at all times be kept, placed, operated
and monitored in accordance with State laws, applicable regulations and
applicable provisions of this Code including, but not limited to:
   A.   All applicants for video gaming license shall be ineligible for such
license for those reasons set forth in section
3-3-5 of this title;
   B.   A valid Village video gaming license must be clearly displayed at the
licensed establishment at all times;
   C.   No more than five (5) video gaming terminals may be located or placed
on a licensed establishment;
   D.   Video gaming terminals shall be placed in an area restricted to persons
twenty one (21) years of age or over;
   E.   Prohibiting persons under the age of twenty one (21) years and persons
who are visibly intoxicated from entering or remaining in the gaming area;
   F.   The video gaming area shall be physically monitored at all times during
the legal hours of operation by an employee over twenty one (21) years of age;
and
   G.   The operation of the video gaming terminals shall only be allowed
during the legal hours of operation allowed for the consumption of alcoholic
beverages at the licensed establishment as consistent with section
3-3-6 of this title pertaining to liquor control. The suspension or revocation
of a licensee's liquor license shall result in the automatic suspension or
revocation of the licensee's video gaming license without refund of any portion
of the license fee and without the requirement of any further action by the
Village.
   H.   The cancellation, suspension, or revocation of a licensee's Illinois
Gaming Board license shall result in the automatic cancellation, suspension, or
revocation of the licensee's video gaming license without refund of any portion
of the license fee and without the requirement of any further action by the
Village. (Ord. 17-09-19)
3-29-5: LICENSE FEES:
   For each license year (July 1 through June 30), the per terminal video game
terminal operator fee set forth in Section
3-1-1-7 of this Code must be paid for each terminal on the licensed premises.
(Ords. 17-09-19, 19-28-94, 25-12-37)
3-29-6: NUMBER OF LICENSES:
The number of video gaming licenses authorized to be issued to licensed
establishments shall be amended from time to time by the Village President and
Board of Trustees and on record of the Village Clerk. Any video gaming license
that lapses or is revoked for any reason shall automatically reduce the number
of authorized video gaming licenses. (Ord. 17-09-19)
3-29-7: PENALTIES:
   A.   Suspension Or Revocation Of License: The Village President/Local Liquor
Commissioner or his or her designee shall have the power to suspend for not
more than thirty (30) days or revoke any video gaming license issued under the
provisions of this chapter for cause, or if he/she determines that the licensee
shall have violated any of the provisions of this Code, any of the statutes of
the State or any other valid ordinance or resolution enacted by the President
and Board of Trustees of the Village. However, no such license shall be revoked
or suspended except after the holding of a public hearing by the Village
President/Local Liquor Commissioner or his or her designee. Ten (10) days'
notice of the hearing shall be given to the licensee. Alternatively, licensees
shall have the opportunity to engage in a prehearing conference and agree to
negotiated penalties rather than proceed to a hearing.
   B.   Fine Imposed: In addition, any licensee violating the provisions of
this chapter shall be fined not less than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) for
each violation. Each day a violation continues shall constitute a separate
violation. (Ords. 17-09-19, 19-16-63)
3-29-8: TERMINAL OPERATORS' TAX:
A tax is imposed for the privilege of operating a video gaming terminal within
the Village upon the terminal operator of a video gaming terminal at a rate of
one cent ($0.01) per play on a video gaming terminal. (Ord. 21-11-58)
3-29-8.1: TAX ADDITIONAL:
The tax imposed in this Section is in addition to all other taxes imposed by
the State of Illinois or any municipal corporation or political subdivision
thereof. (Ord. 21-11-58)
3-29-8.2: RULES:
The Village is authorized to adopt, promulgate, and enforce any additional
rules and regulations pertaining to the interpretation, collection,
administration, and enforcement of this Section. (Ord. 21-11-58)
3-29-8.3: PAYMENT AND ACCOUNTING:
By the 20th day of each month payment of the tax for the preceding month shall
be remitted to the Village along with a completed tax return form as prescribed
by the Village. It shall be deemed a violation of this Chapter for any person
to knowingly furnish false or inaccurate information to the Village.
A terminal operator of any video gaming terminal(s) shall be subject to audit,
inspection, and record keeping provisions of this Code. It shall be unlawful
for any terminal operator and/or person to prevent, hinder, or interfere with
the Village's officials, employees, and/or agents designated to discharge their
respective duties in the performance and enforcement of the provisions of this
Chapter. It is the duty of every terminal operator of a video gaming terminal
(s) to keep accurate and complete books and records to which the Village's
officials, employees, and/or agents will at all times have full access. (Ord.
21-11-58)
3-29-8.4: FAILURE TO PAY TAX:
   A.   In the event of failure by a terminal operator to pay to the village
the tax imposed by this chapter by the date the same shall be due, interest
shall accumulate at a rate as imposed by chapter 18, "Local Government
Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights Act", of this title. In addition, a penalty shall be
assessed and collected against such distributor, retail fuel dealer, purchaser
or user as imposed by chapter 18, "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights
Act", of this title.
   B.   Whenever any terminal operator shall fail to pay any tax as herein
provided, the village attorney shall, upon the request of the village president
and board of trustees, bring or cause to be brought an action to enforce the
payment of said tax on behalf of the village in any court of competent
jurisdiction.
   C.   If the village president or his/her designee, after hearing held, shall
find that such terminal operator has failed to make payment of the tax imposed
by this chapter, the village president may suspend or revoke all village
licenses held by such tax evader. Such terminal operator may have an
opportunity to be heard at such hearing to be held not less than ten (10) days
after notice of the time and place of the hearing, said notice, addressed to
him at his last known place of business. Pending notice, hearing and finding,
any license which terminal operator may possess may be temporarily suspended by
the village president. Any suspension or revocation of any license shall not
release or discharge such terminal from his civil liability for the payment of
the tax nor from prosecution for such offense.
   D.   A terminal operator user shall be entitled to all rights under this
chapter as provided in chapter 18, "Local Government Taxpayers' Bill Of Rights
Act", of this title. (Ord. 21-11-58)
3-29-8.5: PENALTIES:
Any terminal operator violating the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00), for each offense. Each day a violation continues shall
constitute a separate violation. (Ord. 21-11-58)
3-29-8.6: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision of this section or the application of any provision thereof,
is held unconstitutional or otherwise invalid, such occurrence shall not affect
other provisions of this section or their application, that can be given effect
without the unconstitutional or invalid provision or its application. Each
unconstitutional or invalid provision, or application of such provision, is
severable, unless otherwise provided. (Ord. 21-11-58)
CHAPTER 30
SELF-STORAGE FACILITY ACCOMMODATIONS TAX
(Rep. by Ord. 20-03-08)
CHAPTER 31
MOBILE FOOD VENDORS AND VEHICLES
SECTION:
3-31-1: Definitions
3-31-2: License Required
3-31-3: Application For License
3-31-4: Issuance Of License
3-31-5: License
3-31-6: Inspection
3-31-7: Vehicle Requirements/Restrictions
3-31-8: Operation Requirements
3-31-9: Operation Location
3-31-10: Insurance Requirement
3-31-11: Vehicle Storage
3-31-12: Parking Restrictions
3-31-13: License Limitations
3-31-14: Food Sanitation Regulations
3-31-15: Prohibited Acts
3-31-16: Revocation Of License
3-31-17: Penalties
3-31-1: DEFINITIONS:
HEALTH INSPECTOR: The person meeting the qualifications of licensed
environmental health practitioner as defined by the Illinois Department of
Professional Regulations and designated to enforce health regulations pursuant
to the ordinances of the Village of Oak Lawn.
MOBILE FOOD VEHICLE: A fully enclosed motorized mobile vehicle in which ready-
to-eat food is cooked, wrapped, packaged, processed, or portioned for service,
sale, or distribution.
MOBILE FOOD VENDOR: The owner of a mobile food vehicle or the owner's agent,
who, by traveling from place to place upon the public ways, prepares and serves
food from a mobile food vehicle for sale or distribution. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person who does not possess a valid, current
license from the Village to operate a mobile food vehicle, preparing, storing,
or selling any food. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-3: APPLICATION FOR LICENSE:
   A.   Application for license shall be made upon a form provided by the
Village Clerk. The applicant shall, under oath state in full the following:
      1.   Applicant's name, address, phone number and birth date.
      2.   Name of business or organization, address, phone number and state
where business is incorporated (if applicable).
      3.   Name, address, phone number and driver's license number of an owner,
manager or operator, and agents that will conduct activity which is subject of
the license.
      4.   Name of approved commercial supply source.
      5.   Description of preparation methods and food products offered for
sale, including the menu, display, and distribution containers.
      6.   The anticipated volume of food to be stored, prepared, and sold.
      7.   Plans and specifications for the mobile food vehicle, including the
proposed layout, photographs, mechanical schematics, construction materials,
equipment types, dimensions, power source, installation specifications, and
information on any custom fabricated equipment.
      8.   A valid copy of all necessary licenses or permits required by State
Health or Department of Motor Vehicles. This includes proof of food handler
certification training or valid Illinois Food Services Sanitation Manager
Certification as required by the Food Handling Regulation Enforcement Act.
During all times of operation in the Village, at least one certified trained
food handler or someone holding a Food Service Sanitation Manager Certificate
must be present on the vehicle.
      9.   Number of employees.
      10.   Dates on which previous licenses were issued by the Village and
information regarding revocation of prior business licenses, if applicable.
      11.   Information regarding any convictions of applicant mobile food
vendor or any agent, for violating any Village business regulation, or any
State Statute regarding the subject matter of the license.
      12.   A signed statement that the mobile food vendor will not serve
alcohol.
      13.   A signed statement that the mobile food vendor shall hold harmless
the Village and its officers, employees, and agents and shall indemnify and
defend the Village and its officials, employees, and agents against any and all
claims related to the vendor's operations pursuant to the license.
      14.   Any other information deemed reasonable and necessary by the
Village in furtherance of this chapter.
   B.   A license issued under this chapter shall be three hundred dollars
($300.00). (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-4: ISSUANCE OF LICENSE:
   A.   The Village shall give priority to those applicants which maintain a
Village business license or are members of the Oak Lawn Chamber of Commerce at
the time of application submission.
   B.   The Department of Community Development, upon receipt of a properly
completed application, but in no event later than thirty (30) days after the
receipt of the application, shall either issue a license or notify the
applicant, in writing, that the application has been denied because:
      1.   The applicant has failed to comply with the requirements of this
chapter; or
      2.   The applicant, owner, manager or operator has, within the previous
year, been convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter,
its predecessor, or the ordinance of any other municipality, or State or
Federal Statute. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-5: LICENSE:
Each license issued under this chapter shall be valid from the month of June to
October of the year received, unless further authorized in the discretion of
the Village Manager. For calendar year 2019, there shall be six (6) available
licenses to operate a mobile food vehicle from June to October.
The Village Manager may, in his discretion, approve a license subject to the
standards and procedures described herein, to an applicant for a limited use.
An application must be submitted to the Village at least fourteen (14) calendar
days before an applicant submits an application for any event in which a mobile
food vehicle shall be present.
Each license shall be valid for only one vehicle. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-6: INSPECTION:
Prior to the issuance of any license pursuant to this chapter, the health
inspector shall inspect every mobile food truck. If necessary, upon complaint
or direction by the Village, the health inspector may conduct additional
inspections until violations are corrected.
One copy of the inspection report shall be given to the mobile food vendor and
shall be placed conspicuously on the exterior of the mobile food truck. The
health inspector will retain a copy of the report on file at the Village.
The health inspector shall be given specific power to make inspections and for
that purpose enter all vehicles to enforce the environmental health laws of the
Village and to that end make such orders, requirements, decisions, and
determinations as are necessary to the enforcement of applicable environmental
health laws.
Application for the current season shall be received thirty (30) days prior to
Farmers' Market.
   A.   Procedure For Investigations: Upon the receipt of an application for a
license, the Department of Community Development shall schedule an inspection
with the health inspector within forty eight (48) hours of the time of such
receipt. The health inspector shall make the investigation or inspection and
shall make a report thereof favorable or otherwise, within ten (10) days after
receiving the application or a copy thereof.
      1.   The health inspector under the direction of the Director of
Community Development shall make or cause to be made all inspections in
connection with such licenses for the protection of health, the care and
handling of food and the prevention of nuisances and of the spread of disease.
      2.   The Fire Department shall make inspections relative to fire hazards.
      3.   All other investigations, except where otherwise provided, shall be
made by the Chief of Police or by some officer designated by the Manager.
   B.   Inspections, Analyses:
      1.   It shall be the duty of the mobile food vendor to allow inspection
of the mobile food vehicle prior to the receipt of any license and allow the
health inspector to make such inspection, or any officer or employee of the
Village who is authorized or directed to make such inspection at any reasonable
time that admission is requested.
      2.   It shall be the duty of any mobile food vendor to give to the health
inspector or any authorized officer or employee of the Village requesting an
inspection of the same, sufficient samples of such goods to be sold or
distributed.
      3.   In addition to any other penalty which may be provided, the
President may revoke the license or permit of any person who refuses to permit
the health inspector or any officer or employee who is authorized to make such
inspection or take such sample to make the inspection or take an adequate
sample of the desired goods to be sold or distributed or who interferes with
such officer or employee while in the performance of his duty in making such
inspection. Provided that no license or permit shall be revoked for such cause
unless written demand is made upon the licensee or person in charge of the
premises, in the name of the Village, stating that such inspection or sample is
desired at the time it is sought to make the inspection or obtain the sample.
   C.   Food Safety:
      1.   All mobile food vehicles shall be kept in clean and sanitary
condition.
      2.   All food storage, preparation, and distribution food and vehicle
equipment must meet applicable Illinois Department of Public Health standards
and requirements, as well as standards determined by the Village.
      3.   All food, beverages, ice, and other materials sold or used in
preparation of goods to be sold must be obtained from a commercial source
approved by the health inspector.
      4.   All food preparation and food storage that is not done in the mobile
food vehicle should be done at a Village licensed food establishment.
      5.   All waste liquids, garbage, litter, and refuse shall be kept in
leak-proof, nonabsorbent containers which shall be kept covered with tight-
fitting lids and properly disposed of at an affiliated licensed restaurant. No
waste liquids, garbage, litter, or refuse shall be dumped or drained into
sidewalks, streets, gutters, drains, sewers, and trash receptacles other than
agreed locations by the Village. A garbage receptacle shall be easily
accessible for customer use. Vendor shall be responsible for all litter and
garbage left by customers.
   D.   Fee: An inspection fee under this chapter shall be sixty dollars
($60.00). (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-7: VEHICLE REQUIREMENTS/RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   All vehicles used as mobile food vehicles shall meet the following
requirements to be determined by a health inspection by the Village before a
license shall be issued.
      1.   The vehicle shall be enclosed with top and sides.
      2.   The interior floor, walls and ceiling of each vehicle shall be of
smooth, not readily corrodible, impervious material capable of withstanding
repeated washing and scrubbing and shall be finished in a light color. Each
vehicle shall be well painted, in good repair, in good sanitary condition and
shall not be used for other purpose except as provided in this chapter.
      3.   The service sections of the vehicle shall be insect and rodent
proof.
      4.   The name, address, and mobile food license number shall appear on
both sides of the vehicles in letters three inches (3") in height, in
contrasting color.
      5.   All service equipment utilized in the mobile dispenser shall be of
easily cleanable construction and shall be maintained in good repair and shall
be clean. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-8: OPERATION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   All mobile food vehicles shall only operate at designated areas within
the Village, as set forth in this chapter and described on the license.
   B.   No mobile food dispenser shall be equipped with any electronic sound
amplifying device, lights, or noisemakers.
   C.   Sales shall be made from such vehicles only during daylight hours and
not before seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and shall conclude by ten o'clock (10:00)
P.M.
   D.   No sale shall be made from such a vehicle except from the vehicle
thereof and only when such vehicle is legally parked.
   E.   All such vehicles must meet the equipment and safety standards set by
the Illinois Department of Transportation. In addition, all operators of such
vehicles must have a valid Illinois driver's license.
   F.   There shall be no use of detached signage, seating, or any other
equipment not contained within the vehicle.
   G.   Any power required for the mobile food vehicle located on a public way
shall be self-contained and shall not use utilities drawn from the public
right-of-way. No power cable or equipment shall be extended at grade across any
Village street or sidewalk.
   H.   All identifying information, logos, advertising, decorations, or other
displays on the exterior of the vehicle of a mobile food vehicle shall conform
to the Village's Sign Ordinance regulating commercial signage. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-9: OPERATION LOCATION:
Any license approved pursuant to this chapter shall state the location in which
the mobile food vendor may operate the mobile food vehicle. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-10: INSURANCE REQUIREMENT:
Mobile food vendor must provide the Village with a certificate of insurance
showing comprehensive general liability coverage for property damage and
physical injury in the aggregate amount of five hundred thousand dollars
($500,000.00) as well as evidence of automobile insurance required by the State
for operation of the vehicle. The certificate of insurance must state that the
insurer shall notify the Village thirty (30) days before cancelling or revising
the policy. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-11: VEHICLE STORAGE:
The mobile food vendor shall provide name and address where the mobile food
vehicle is to be stored.
The mobile food vendor shall provide the name, address, and frequency of any
cleaning, service, and maintenance to be performed on the mobile food vehicle.
All food service equipment needs to be of commercial grade and meet standards
regarding safe design, nontoxic materials, intended use and workmanship
established by one of the recognized accredited agencies for food service
equipment. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-12: PARKING RESTRICTIONS:
All mobile food vehicles shall be parked only within the designated areas
prescribed in this chapter or listed on the license. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-13: LICENSE LIMITATIONS:
In the interest of preserving public safety and to avoid traffic congestion,
the Village of Oak Lawn, may from time to time, by rule, set a limit on the
number of total licenses available under this chapter. (There shall be a limit
of 6 licenses available pursuant to this chapter.) (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-14: FOOD SANITATION REGULATIONS:
The current and subsequent editions of the Illinois Food Service Administrative
Code (77 Ill. Adm. Code 750), as amended from time to time and promulgated by
the Illinois Department of Public Health, are hereby adopted by reference.
The health inspector shall maintain a record of approved food and beverage
items which may be prepared and sold by mobile food vehicle vendors. Requests
to have a food or beverage item considered for approval shall be submitted in
writing to the health inspector, who shall determine whether the food or
beverage item is capable of preparation and service from the mobile food
vehicle based on the equipment being used and the design and construction of
the vehicle. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-15: PROHIBITED ACTS:
No person shall engage in the operation as a mobile food vendor in any area
within the Village other than areas specifically prescribed by the Village.
No mobile food vendor shall interfere with either vehicular or pedestrian
traffic on any public right-of-way. (Ord. 19-05-08)
3-31-16: REVOCATION OF LICENSE:
Any business operating in violation of the Illinois Food Service Sanitation
Code or any provision of this Code, may have their business license revoked or
suspended if the health inspector or the Village deems that the conditions
constitute an imminent hazard to public health.
Any license or registration under this chapter may be revoked by the Village
