5-2-4: PLATS OF CONSOLIDATION:
   A.   A "plat of consolidation" is defined as a plat which combines one or
more existing lots of record, in whole or in part, into a single lot of record.
   B.   Notwithstanding any other provision of this Chapter which would require
the Zoning and Planning Commission and/or the Village Board to take action in
regard to a proposed plat of subdivision, a plat of consolidation may be
approved administratively by the Director of Community Development and Growth
Management, without need to bring said plat of consolidation before the Zoning
and Planning Commission or the Village Board, provided the lot created by said
plat of consolidation is in full compliance with Section
5-3-3-2 of this Title. (Ords. 98-19-86, 19-16-66)
CHAPTER 3
DESIGN STANDARDS
SECTION:
5-3-1: Conformance To Neighborhood Plan
5-3-2: Streets And Alleys
5-3-3: Lots And Blocks
5-3-3-1: Grading For Drainage
5-3-3-2: Lots
5-3-3-3: Blocks
5-3-4: Reserve Strips
5-3-1: CONFORMANCE TO NEIGHBORHOOD PLAN:
If a suggested plan for the neighborhood or area in which the tract to be
subdivided is located has been made by the Zoning and Planning Commission, the
street layout of the subdivision shall be in general conformance thereto.
(Ords. 79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
5-3-2: STREETS AND ALLEYS:
   A.   Street System: The street system shall relate functionally to the
existing streets in the area adjoining the proposed subdivision.
The street layout shall be devised for the most advantageous development of the
entire neighborhood area. Where necessary to the neighborhood pattern, existing
principal streets in adjoining subdivisions shall be continued and shall be at
least as wide as such existing streets and in alignment with them. The street
layout shall provide for the future projection of the principal streets into
unsubdivided lands adjoining.
   B.   Center Lines: The center lines of all streets wherever practicable,
shall be the continuation of the center lines of existing streets, or shall be
offset at least one hundred feet (100').
   C.   Major Streets: Wherever a subdivision includes a major street, as shown
on the Major Street Plan, such major street shall be platted in the location
and of the width indicated on the Major Street Plan.
   D.   Collector Streets: Collector streets shall be included when it is
apparent that sufficient traffic will flow from the minor streets within the
subdivision, and that such traffic will need to be channeled in control of the
number of access points to the major street.
   E.   Minor Streets: Minor streets shall be so laid out that their use by
through traffic will be discouraged.
   F.   Minor And Major Street Intersections: There shall be a minimum number
of intersections of minor streets with major streets.
   G.   Marginal Access Streets: Where a subdivision has frontage on a major
street, as shown on the Major Street Plan, or on a super highway or other high
volume trafficway, and where it is not feasible to have the lots back to such
high volume streets, provision shall be made for marginal access streets. These
marginal access streets shall be approximately parallel to and on each side of
the major street right of way and separated from such right of way by a strip
of land at least ten feet (10') wide. Separation strips may be provided with
screen planting, but such planting shall be so placed that it does not obstruct
vision at intersections.
   H.   Streets Adjacent to Railroads, Waterways or Major Streets: Where a
subdivision borders on or contains a railroad right of way, waterway or major
street, the Zoning and Planning Commission may require a street approximately
parallel to and on each side of such right of way or major street, at a
distance suitable for appropriate use of the intervening land. Such distance
shall also be determined with due regard for the requirements of approach
grades and future grade separations.
   I.   Alleys: Paved rear alleys not less than twenty feet (20') wide will be
required in all business and industrial districts, except where special
conditions make alleys impracticable; in such cases, adequate off-street
loading space, suitably surfaced, shall be provided. Dead-end alleys shall not
be allowed.
   J.   Half-Streets: Half-streets shall not be permitted.
   K.   Cul-De-Sacs: Cul-de-sacs shall not exceed four hundred feet (400') in
length as measured along the center line from the nearest right of way line of
the intersecting street to the center point of the cul-de-sac, and shall have a
turnaround not less than one hundred twenty feet (120') in diameter of right of
way, and pavement diameter of ninety feet (90') at the closed end.
   L.   Grades: Street grades shall conform in general to the terrain and shall
be not less than one-half of one percent (0.5%) nor more than five percent
(5%). Street grades shall be such as to provide natural surface drainage of
storm water regardless of the presence or absence of storm sewers. The intent
is to avoid depressions or inverts that will flood in flash storms for which
storm sewers are inadequate.
   M.   Right of Way Widths: The minimum right of way widths for streets,
alleys and crosswalkways shall be as follows:
 Feet
                                                                      Feet
Major streets including section line streets                            
(Except in cases where a greater or lesser width is shown on the major 100
street plan)
Half section line streets                                              80
Minor street                                                           66
Cul-de-sac (see also subsection K above)                               66
Marginal access street (without intersecting streets)                  40
Commercial alley                                                       20
Crosswalkway (when required)                                           10
 
   N.   Roadway Widths: The following roadway widths from outside to outside of
curbs are required:
 Feet
                                                     Feet
Major street                                          Variable
Collector street                                      40
Minor street                                          32
Cul-de-sac (see also subsection K above)              32
Marginal access street (without intersecting streets) 28
Alley (in business or industrial district)            20
Crosswalkway                                          8
Sidewalk                                              5
 
   O.   Minimum Curvatures: The minimum of curvature of streets on the center
line shall be:
 
                Feet
Major street     600
Collector street 300
Minor street     100
 
   P.   Tangent Between Reversed Curves: Between reversed curves on all
streets, there shall be a tangent at least one hundred feet (100') long.
   Q.   Angle of Intersections: Street intersections shall be at right angles
or nearly so. Where, because of topographic or other reasons, an intersection
cannot be at right angles, such intersections shall be so designed as to be in
accordance with good engineering practices.
   R.   Curb Radii: Curb radii shall not be less than twenty feet (20'). Where
an angle of intersection less than sixty degrees (60") is permitted, curb radii
shall be increased as necessary for safety.
   S.   Future Streets and Subdivisions: If a tract is subdivided into larger
parcels than ordinary building lots (see subsection
5-3-3-2A of this Chapter), such parcels shall be arranged to allow the opening
of future streets and logical future subdivisions. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-
11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
5-3-3: LOTS AND BLOCKS:
5-3-3-1: GRADING FOR DRAINAGE:
Lots and blocks shall be so graded as to eliminate depressions that would
accumulate storm water. Grades at building sites shall bear such relationships
to roadway and curb grades as to prevent flooding of basement windows or of
entryways, either to basements or to first-floor levels in the absence of
basements. Where deemed necessary, the Director of Office of Quality Control
may require the subdivider to submit working drawings showing contours to which
the property is to be graded in order to provide for the requirements of this
Section. In such cases, building permits shall not be issued unless the lot
plan indicates site and building grades consistent with the grading drawing.
(Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19)
5-3-3-2: LOTS:
   A.   Minimum Width and Depth: Recognizing the character of the various
neighborhoods within the Village and the need for flexibility in the
classification of lot sizes and areas, the minimum lot width and depth
requirement for lots to be subdivided under the requirements of this title
shall be divided into five (5) classes of lots. Applicability of the various
classes of lots shall depend solely upon the character of the existing
surrounding neighborhood, and shall comply with the following requirements:
      Class 1: Blocks in neighborhoods of predominantly twenty five (25) and
thirty foot (30') lots of record and zoned for single-family use, which were
recorded with the appropriate officials of the county of Cook prior to October
1, 1956, may be subdivided into buildable lots which are combinations of two
(2) or more lots or parts thereof. However, in certain situations, a
combination of three (3) existing lots of record to be resubdivided may be
allowed provided all of the lots as proposed contain at least forty five (45)
linear feet of frontage at the building line, and contain not less than five
thousand six hundred (5,600) square feet.
      Notwithstanding the foregoing, the minimum depth of the lots in this
situation shall be one and one-half (11/2) times the proposed frontage of the
lot or one hundred fifteen feet (115'), whichever is greater.
      Class 2: Blocks in neighborhoods where the lot depth of existing lots of
record exceeds one hundred seventy five feet (175') from the front right of way
line to the rear lot line (excluding double frontage lots) and zoned for
single-family uses, which were recorded with the appropriate officials of the
county of Cook prior to October 1, 1956. The minimal lot size in these areas
shall be fifty (50) linear feet at the front building line, and each lot shall
contain at least ten thousand (10,000) square feet. For purposes of this
paragraph, the requirements of subsection B of this section shall not apply.
      Class 3: See section
4-3-2 of this code.
      Class 4: All other lots zoned for single-family use. Lots for single-
family residential use shall be at least fifty five feet (55') wide at building
setback line for interior lots, and sixty feet (60') wide for corner lots, and
shall contain at least six thousand eight hundred seventy five (6,875) square
feet in area for interior lots, and seven thousand five hundred (7,500) square
feet in area for corner lots.
      Class 5: Lots for development or use other than single-family housing,
and lands zoned for regional shopping by the zoning title shall be exempted
from the minimum lot widths and depths, as outlined in this title. These
parcels shall be (re)subdivided in conformance with a plan approved by the
Zoning and Planning Commission and village board, and in compliance with all
other applicable provisions of this title.
   B.   Maximum Depth: The maximum depth of any lot, exclusive of unusable
land, shall be three and one-half (31/2) times the width of the lot, except for
class 2 lots above.
   C.   Lots To Abut On Streets: Every lot shall abut on a dedicated and
improved street for at least twenty five feet (25').
   D.   Setbacks And Side Yards: Minimum setback lines from property lines in
residential zones shall conform with the zoning regulations; except, that there
shall be a side yard along each lot line of a width not less than five feet
(5').
   E.   Property Lines At Corner: Property line at street intersection corners
shall be right angles, or nearly so.
   F.   Side Lines: Side lines of lots shall be approximately at right angles
or radial to the street line.
   G.   Shape: The shape of lots and their orientation shall be appropriate to
the location of the proposed subdivision, and to the type of development
contemplated.
   H.   Double Frontage Lots: Double frontage lots, other than corner lots,
will be permitted only under unusual circumstances.
   I.   Building Sites: Every lot must contain a suitable building site and be
able to conform to the requirements of the building and zoning regulations for
the erection and location of building structures. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-
11-45, 93-9-24, 05-15-52, 07-05-16, 19-16-66)
5-3-3-3: BLOCKS:
   A.   Length: Blocks shall not exceed one thousand two hundred feet (1,200')
in length nor be less than two hundred fifty feet (250') in length; blocks
longer than eight hundred feet (800') in length may be required to have
crosswalk ways.
   B.   Blocks For Industrial And Commercial Use: Blocks intended for
industrial or commercial use shall be designed specifically for such purpose
with adequate space set aside for off street parking and loading and meet
minimum requirements for parking. (Ord. 79-2-5)
5-3-4: RESERVE STRIPS:
There shall be no reservation of strips of land that prevent or limit access to
land dedicated or intended to be dedicated to public use.
Reserved strips controlling the access to public ways or which will prove
taxable for special improvements, will not be approved unless such strips are
necessary for the protection of the public welfare or of substantial property
rights, or both, and in no case except in which control and disposal of the
land comprising such strips is placed definitely within the jurisdiction of the
village under conditions approved by the Zoning and Planning Commission. (Ords.
79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
CHAPTER 4
REQUIRED IMPROVEMENTS
SECTION:
5-4-1: Improvements Required Generally
5-4-2: Roadway Improvements
5-4-3: Driveways
5-4-4: Easements
5-4-5: Stormwater Drainage
5-4-6: Landscaping, Fences
5-4-7: Natural Features
5-4-1: IMPROVEMENTS REQUIRED GENERALLY:
The Zoning and Planning Commission shall have the power to require one or more
of the following improvements depending upon the nature and scope of the
subdivision. The subdivider shall provide, at a minimum, those improvements
that are not existing at the time of submission of the final plat and the
subdivider shall be required to make provision for the installation of same in
accordance with section
5-4A-5 of this chapter. Particular attention shall be given to means for
disposition of stormwater and to the desirability of curb and gutter or other
provision to prevent breakdown of pavement edges. The design, layout and
carrying capacities of stormwater, sanitary sewer and water facilities shall
recognize the future requirements of adjacent undeveloped areas.
Crosswalks.
Curb and gutter.
Driveways and off street parking.
Pavement striping.
Rear yard drainage.
Sanitary sewage facilities.
Sidewalks.
Stormwater drainage facilities.
Street and alley paving.
Street signs.
Streetlights.
Survey monuments.
Topsoil where appropriate.
Traffic control signs.
Water mains and hydrants. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
5-4-2: ROADWAY IMPROVEMENTS:
The subdivider shall, at his own expense, improve all streets in accordance
with the current specifications in effect as amended from time to time by the
village president and board of trustees; provided, however, that the president
and board of trustees may impose more stringent specifications for through
streets within or adjoining a subdivision as a condition precedent to accepting
any subdivision plat. (Ord. 79-2-5)
5-4-3: DRIVEWAYS:
Except where improved alleys are existing, every lot in a subdivision shall be
provided with not more than one paved driveway. Said driveway shall contain
sufficient paved area for the parking of at least two (2) full size
automobiles, unless the only parking space(s) located on said driveway is/are
in the front yard, in which case sufficient paved area for only one full size
automobile will be allowed. Said driveway shall comply with the following:
   A.   Minimum Length And Width: The minimum driveway length shall be from the
street access to a point forty feet (40') behind the minimum setback line, and
the minimum width of said paved driveway shall be nine feet (9'). When the only
parking space(s) located on a driveway is/are in the front yard, the minimum
driveway length, as provided by this subsection, shall not be applicable to the
driveway.
   B.   Maximum Width: In no case shall a driveway for access to a single-
family residential property exceed twenty feet (20') in width at the property
line.
   C.   Number Of Driveways: Not more than one driveway shall be allowed to
service any single-family home unless permission is first granted by the Zoning
and Planning Commission.
   D.   Circular Driveways: For purposes of this chapter a "circular driveway"
is defined as a continuous driveway that provides access to the street via more
than one curb cut on a single street frontage. Any new circular driveway must
be petitioned for before the Zoning and Planning Commission subject to the
provisions of sections
2-1-7-2 and
2-1-7-3 of this code.
   E.   Construction Materials And Standards: The driveway shall be constructed
with a minimum concrete thickness of five inches (5") and a granular bedding
base of two inches (2") minimum compacted thickness, or with a minimum
compacted crushed stone base course of six inches (6") in thickness and an
asphalt surfaced course of two inches (2") in thickness, and all such
construction shall be in accordance with sections
6-1G-1 through
6-1G-3 of this code.
   F.   Access To Streets: Except in the case of a corner lot, the driveway for
a single- family residence shall only access the street in front of the
property serviced by the driveway. In the case of a corner lot, the driveway
for a single-family residence may access either: 1) the street in front of the
property serviced by the driveway ("front load garage") or 2) the street which
abuts the property and intersects the street in front of the property ("side
load garage"). For purposes of this subsection, the "street in front of the
property" shall be defined as the street designated in the mailing address for
the property. In addition to the aforementioned street access, a driveway for a
single-family residence may also access an alley abutting the property. A
variation from the provisions of this subsection may be petitioned for before
the Zoning and Planning Commission subject to the provisions of sections
2-1-7-2 and
2-1-7-3 of this code. (Ords. 12-24-77, 19-16-66)
5-4-4: EASEMENTS:
   A.   All aboveground utilities shall be placed on rear or side property
lines. Where a subdivision is traversed by a watercourse, an appropriate
easement shall be provided for the watercourse in either an open cut or in an
underground conduit, depending upon the density of development.
   B.   Where water mains, sanitary sewers, storm sewers, gas mains, telephone
lines, power lines or other utilities are located on or adjacent to property
lines, adequate easements together with right of ingress or egress thereto and
therefrom shall be provided and platted.
   C.   Said easement shall provide that no structure or building, except a
division fence shall be placed on said easement.
   D.   Easements shall not be less than eight feet (8') in width. Where more
than one underground utility is to occupy the easement, the easement shall be
of such width as to extend five feet (5') at each side beyond the centerline of
the outermost utilities. Additional width shall be provided where necessary to
accommodate utility pole bracing. The Zoning and Planning Commission may
require evidence of approval by the public utility company of easement width.
   E.   The installation of all utilities underground is strongly encouraged.
(Ords. 79-2-5, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24, 19-16-66)
5-4-5: STORMWATER DRAINAGE:
The subdivider shall, subject to riparian rights, dedicate a right of way for
storm drainage purposes, conforming substantially with the lines of any natural
watercourse, channel, stream or creek that traverses the subdivision, or to
provide additional easements for both, to dispose of such stormwater. (Ord. 79-
2-5)
5-4-6: LANDSCAPING, FENCES:
Where a residential subdivision adjoins a railroad right of way, waterway, an
industrial area, a business area or other land use which could have a
depreciating effect on the residential use of the property, buffer strips shall
be provided as required by the zoning title and outlined in section
4-1-6 of this code. Only in unusual circumstances will a wire fence be allowed,
and then only after hardship has been demonstrated by the subdivider. (Ord. 79-
2-5)
5-4-7: NATURAL FEATURES:
Outstanding natural and cultural features, such as scenic spots and
watercourses, shall be preserved insofar as possible. (Ord. 79-2-5)
ARTICLE A. CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS
SECTION:
5-4A-1: Conformance With Village Standards
5-4A-2: Construction Plans And Commencement, Procedure
5-4A-3: Licensed Contractors Required
5-4A-4: Inspections
5-4A-5: Guarantee Of Completion And Maintenance
5-4A-6: Fees
5-4A-7: Acceptance Of Improvements
5-4A-8: Responsibility For Maintenance And Repair
5-4A-9: Applicability Of Other Regulations
5-4A-10: Environmental Assessment As Condition Of Land Dedication Or Donation
5-4A-1: CONFORMANCE WITH VILLAGE STANDARDS:
All improvements shall be in accordance with village standards and requirements
as given in ordinances and regulations in effect at the time of submission of
the final plat. (Ord. 79-2-5)
5-4A-2: CONSTRUCTION PLANS AND COMMENCEMENT, PROCEDURE:
   A.   Preparation: The subdivider shall have working drawings and
specifications for improvements prepared by an Illinois registered professional
engineer retained by the subdivider. The engineer retained by the subdivider
shall be other than an engineer on the village payroll or one retained by the
village.
   B.   Submittal: Before considering the approval of the final plat for any
subdivision, the Zoning and Planning Commission will require that appropriate
working drawings and specifications be submitted for those improvements
required at the time of approval of the preliminary layout.
   C.   Review, Fees: All working drawings, specifications and cost estimates
shall be checked by the director of office of Community Development and Growth
Management or by a consulting firm duly retained by the village. The subdivider
shall reimburse the village for preparation and for checking of working
drawings, specifications and cost estimates in accordance with section
5-4A-6 of this article.
   D.   Conformance To Village Standards: Working drawings and specifications
shall be in accordance with village standards and requirements, as published by
the director of office of Community Development and Growth Management.
   E.   Approval: Approval of the village shall be secured before commencement
of construction of any improvement. Recording of the final plat shall
constitute permission to proceed with construction. If the subdivider elects,
as provided in this Article, to construct an improvement prior to approval of
the final plat, the Village Manager may extend permission to proceed upon
recommendation of the Zoning and Planning Commission together with
certification by the Director of Office of Community Development and Growth
Management that working drawings and specifications have been prepared and
approved, and that engineering fees have been paid and that an inspection bond
has been posted.
   F.   State, County Permission Required: The subdivider shall also secure any
permission required by laws of the State and County, and permission extended by
the Village shall not relieve the subdivider of responsibility to secure State
and County approval. If such permission is required, a copy of said written
permission is to be filed with the Director of Office of Community Development
and Growth Management. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24,
19-16-66)
5-4A-3: LICENSED CONTRACTORS REQUIRED:
The developer shall file with the Director of Office of Quality Control a list
of all contractors and subcontractors who are to participate in construction of
public improvements. Such contractors and subcontractors shall be subject to
the licensing provisions of this Code and Village ordinances, and shall be
subject to disqualification by reason of faulty performance upon past
construction work done in the Village. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19)
5-4A-4: INSPECTIONS:
All public improvements, as defined herein, shall be subject to inspection by
Village inspectors during the course of construction and after construction is
completed. All materials and workmanship used in the construction of such
improvements shall be in compliance with all Village codes and ordinances. All
contractors shall make reasonable tests and provide proof of quality of
materials upon request of such inspectors.
   A.   Notice to Inspect: It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider or
his contractor to notify the Director of Office of Quality Control when work is
to be started and to request assignment of an inspector. The initial
notification that a particular improvement is to be started shall be in writing
and shall reach the Director of Office of Quality Control two (2) working days
in advance of the date that inspection is to begin. The notice shall be
accompanied by an inspection bond in accordance with Section
5-4A-5 of this Article.
   B.   Reports: The Village inspector shall prepare and submit to the Director
of Office of Quality Control each day, a report stating progress of work and
giving his findings as to quality and quantity of materials used. He shall, in
particular, call attention to any circumstances that entail departures from
working drawings and specifications such as unforeseen difficulties of
drainage, ground water, poor subsoil, unstable fill material or other
circumstances. Whenever, in his opinion, such departures are likely to cause
either a lower ultimate standard of performance or a higher construction cost
than could reasonably be anticipated, he shall immediately notify the Director
of Office of Quality Control. When an improvement has been completed, he shall
prepare a summary report and furnish a copy of said report to the developer and
his engineer.
   C.   Approval:
      1.   Approval by the inspector shall not be deemed acceptance of the
improvement by the Village. Acceptance shall be only by action of the Board of
Trustees, and acceptance shall be contingent upon a favorable inspection report
signed by the Director of Office of Quality Control.
      2.   Approval by the inspector shall in no way relieve the subdivider of
full responsibility for adherence by his contractors to specifications and
working drawings, nor for high standards of materials, methods and workmanship.
   D.   Fees: To defray the engineering and inspection expenses incurred by the
Village in preparation or checking of preliminary and final cost estimates,
working drawings, specifications, and in executing inspection responsibilities,
the subdivider shall be required to reimburse the Village as indicated in
Section
5-4A-6 of this Article. These are separate and distinct charges from the fee
paid at the time of submission of either the preliminary or final layouts.
(Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19)
5-4A-5: GUARANTEE OF COMPLETION AND MAINTENANCE:
The Village shall not record the final plat unless and until the subdivider has
guaranteed the completion of all required improvements within a reasonable
period and in compliance with working drawings and specifications, and has
guaranteed to maintain said improvements until they are accepted by the
Village. This guarantee shall be by one or a combination of one or more of
three (3) methods. Only one method shall be applied to one specific
improvement.
   A.   Performance Bond: The subdivider may post a performance bond prepared
in a form approved by the Village Attorney and underwritten by a surety company
listed as approved by the Village Attorney. The amount of the bond shall be not
less than one hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the final estimate of cost
of the improvement as estimated by the Director of Office of Quality Control
under Section
5-4A-6 of this Article. There shall be no reduction in the amount of that
portion of the bond applying to a particular improvement unless and until that
improvement is complete and accepted by the Village. The subgrade, base course
and surface course of a street, alley or parking area shall be considered as a
single improvement from the standpoint of acceptance.
   B.   Cash Deposit: The subdivider may deposit a cash bond with the Village
in accordance with a specific escrow agreement approved by the Village Attorney
and Village Manager and in an amount not less than one hundred twenty five
percent (125%) of the final estimate of cost of the improvements as estimated
by the Director of Office of Quality Control under Section
5-4A-6 of this Article. The deposit shall be held in a special account by the
Village and the agreement may provide for partial payouts as work progresses in
amounts recommended by the Director of Office of Quality Control as
corresponding to the original estimate of unit costs. Partial payouts shall be
contingent upon favorable inspection reports, and the sum of partial payouts
for a single improvement shall not exceed eighty five percent (85%) of the
original deposit for the improvement until and unless the improvement is
complete and accepted by the Village. Payment will be made by the Village only
upon submission of the proper waivers for all labor and materials. The
subgrade, base course and surface course of a street, alley or parking area
shall be considered a single improvement from the standpoint of acceptance.
   C.   Improvement Completion Prior to Final Plat Approval: Upon specific
permission of the Board of Trustees, as recommended by the Zoning and Planning
Commission, the subdivider may elect to complete one or more improvements prior
to approval of the final plat. Where the subdivider elects to guarantee
completion of an improvement by this method, approval of the final plat shall
be contingent upon certification by the Director of Office of Community
Development and Growth Management that the improvement has been completed in
accordance with drawings and specifications; that the inspection reports are
favorable; and that guarantee has been provided to cover cost of maintenance of
the improvement in accordance with subsection
5-4A-8A of this Article. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19, 81-36-78, 92-11-45, 93-9-24,
19-16-66)
5-4A-6:FEES:
The subdivider shall have working drawings, specifications and cost estimates
for improvements prepared by an engineer retained by himself; he shall submit
such drawings, specifications and estimates to the Director of Office of
Quality Control. The application shall be accompanied by two (2) sets of
construction prints, specifications and estimates. The Director of Office of
Quality Control shall inform the subdivider of the amount of the charge for
this service and the charge shall be two percent (2%) of the total estimated
cost of the improvement, as confirmed by the Director of Office of Quality
Control. Checking shall proceed after the subdivider has paid over this fee to
the Office of Quality Control. Additional fees shall be paid for rechecking of
drawings, specifications and estimates arising from revisions made by or
required of the subdivider. There shall be no refund of engineering fees if the
project is abandoned for any reason whatsoever.
   A.   Engineering Fees: The engineering fee is intended to include checking
of preliminary and final cost estimates, working drawings and specifications,
but it is not intended to include inspection or supervision of work.
   B.   Inspection Fees:
      1.   Before grading or construction of improvements is started, the
subdivider or his contractor shall post with the Office of Quality Control a
cash inspection bond in an amount agreed upon between the Director of Office of
Quality Control and the subdivider as being sufficient to provide for
inspection charges at the current per diem rates. From this bond shall be
deducted, each day, the inspection expense incurred by the Village at the rates
set forth below. Any excess of the bond over actual inspection charges will be
refunded to the depositor and cured by the subdivider by depositing a
sufficient sum of money to ensure continuity of inspection.
      2.   It shall be the responsibility of the subdivider to notify the
Director of Office of Quality Control in advance as to the dates that
construction work will commence and complete for purposes of determining the
number of days of inspection charge. In event of dispute only notification in
writing shall be considered as proof of notice.
      3.   Per diem inspection rates shall be equal to one hundred percent
(100%) of the engineer's quoted charge to the Village. If inspection is
performed by an inspector on the Village payroll, the charge shall be one
hundred twenty five percent (125%) of the regular salary paid to the inspector
computed to an hourly basis. There shall be not less than a four (4) hour
charge for time spent in any one day. For time spent outside of the regular
working hours of the inspector, the hourly charge shall be two hundred fifty
percent (250%) of the regular salary paid to the inspector computed to an
hourly basis. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19; 1985 Code)
5-4A-7: ACCEPTANCE OF IMPROVEMENTS:
Acceptance of an improvement by the Village shall be only by resolution of the
Board of Trustees upon recommendation of the Director of Office of Quality
Control. Recommendation shall be contingent upon:
   A.   Fulfillment of the requirements of Section
5-4A-5 of this Article.
   B.   An opinion by the Village Attorney that satisfactory and proper
conveyances and dedications have been made by the subdivider to the Village.
   C.   Improvements being complete and in good repair in accordance with
Village standards and requirements.
   D.   Inspection reports indicating compliance with working drawings and
specifications.
   E.   A single improvement shall not be accepted in part; it shall be
complete throughout the subdivision as indicated in the final plat and working
drawings. The subgrade, base course and surface course of a street, alley or
parking area shall be considered as a single improvement.
Acceptance of an improvement shall constitute release of the applicable portion
of the performance bond, or of the applicable portion of the balance of cash
deposit. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-19)
5-4A-8: RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE AND REPAIR:
   A.   As further assurance of serviceable construction, and to provide for
repair of damage resulting from subsequent construction operations of the
subdivider or his contractors, the subdivider shall be responsible for all
maintenance of an improvement for a period of not less than fifteen (15) months
following completion and acceptance by the Village of construction of that
improvement; providing, in addition, that the subdivider shall be responsible
for all maintenance of roadways, curbs and gutters, sidewalks, parkway strips
and extension boxes and hydrants of water facilities until all construction
work has been completed upon other improvements, dwellings, buildings, fill and
landscaping adjacent to the improvement under consideration. The guarantee of
completion and maintenance shall recognize the possibility of maintenance costs
and the terms of the guarantee shall provide for reimbursement to the Village
for any maintenance expenses incurred by the Village in performing maintenance
work after failure of the subdivider to perform such work upon due notice. The
Village Attorney shall specify the form of such guarantee of completion and
maintenance upon request and recommendation of the Director of Office of
Quality Control.
   B.   The subdivider, his contractors and suppliers shall be responsible
[sic] that existing improvements and the property of the Village are not
damaged or rendered less useful or unsightly by the operations of the
subdivider, his contractors or suppliers. This provision is intended to include
damage or nuisance with respect to the land, improvements or landscaping of the
Village; damage to existing streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter, parkways by
passage thereover of equipment or trucks or by excavation for any purpose; the
spillage or tracking of earth, sand or rock onto existing streets, sidewalks,
curb and gutter or parkways; the washing by storm water of earth or sand onto
streets, sidewalks, curb and gutter or parkways or into catch basins or damage
to water mains, sanitary sewers, culverts or storm sewers. To reduce or
localize the possibility of damage to streets by heavy trucking, the Director
of Office of Quality Control shall instruct the subdivider as to the streets to
be used for access to the subdivision by equipment and trucks, and the
subdivider shall be responsible for enforcement of this instruction upon his
contractors and their suppliers. The subdivider shall make provisions to
prevent washing of earth or sand onto sidewalks, streets, curb and gutter and
into catch basins by storm water. Where deemed advisable, the Director of
Office of Quality Control shall have the power to require, either prior to
commencement of construction or after construction is in process, that the
subdivider post a surety bond to guarantee repair of damages or abatement of
nuisance. Where need for surety bond becomes apparent after construction is in
process, the Director of Office of Quality Control shall have the power to
order construction discontinued until said surety bond has been posted.
Expenses incurred by the Village in repairing damages, cleaning streets,
catchbasins and sewers shall be deducted from the surety. (Ords. 79-2-5, 81-12-
19)
5-4A-9: APPLICABILITY OF OTHER REGULATIONS:
None of the provisions of these regulations pertaining to permission, surety,
fees, acceptances and approval shall be construed as exempting subdividers,
general contractors, sidewalk contractors, cement contractors, sewer builders,
drain layers, electrical contractors, electricians or any other contractor or
craftsman from any other ordinance or regulation of the Village with respect to
licenses, fees, surety inspection or other control. (Ord. 79-2-5)
5-4A-10: ENVIRONMENTAL ASSESSMENT AS CONDITION OF LAND DEDICATION OR DONATION:
   A.   Not less than five (5) days prior to any dedication or donation of real
estate required under any Village ordinance or requirement, the grantor/
dedicator, at its sole cost and expense, shall have caused to be prepared and
submitted to the Village a written report of a site assessment and
environmental audit, in scope, form and substance, and prepared by an
independent, competent and qualified engineer, satisfactory to the Village (the
"environmental audit"), and dated not more than sixty (60) days prior to the
transfer date, showing the engineer made all appropriate inquiry into the
previous ownership and uses of the property consistent with good commercial and
customary practice in an effort to minimize liability, which takes into account
and satisfies the "innocent landowner" provision set forth at 43 U.S.C. 9601
(35), such that consistent with generally accepted engineering practice and
procedure, no evidence or indication came to light which would suggest there
was a release of substances on the property which could necessitate an
environmental response action, and which demonstrates that the property and the
facility complies with, and does not deviate from, all applicable environmental
statutes, laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, including any licenses,
permits or certificates required thereunder.
   B.   The environmental audit shall also demonstrate that the property and
the improvements located thereon, if any, do not contain:
      1.   Asbestos in any form;
      2.   Urea formaldehyde;
      3.   Transformers or other equipment that contain fluid containing
polychlorinated biphenyles;
      4.   Underground storage tanks; or
      5.   Any other chemical, material or substance, the exposure to which is
prohibited, limited or regulated by any Federal, State, County, regional or
local authority (the "authorities") or which poses a hazard to the health and
safety of the occupants of the property or the facility, or the occupants of
adjacent property.
   C.   The environmental audit shall also demonstrate that the property and
facility are not, and have not been, the subject of any past, existing or
threatened investigation, inquiry or proceeding concerning environmental
matters by the authorities, and that no notice or submission concerning
environmental matters has been given or should be given with regard to the
property and the facility to the authorities. The environmental audit shall
demonstrate that the property and facility are not subject to, or covered by,
the requirements of the Emergency Planning and Community Right-To- Know Act of
1986, 42 U.S.C. 11001, et seq., and that the property is not now being used and
has never been used for any activities involving directly or indirectly the
use, treatment, storage or disposal of any hazardous or toxic chemical,
material, substance or waste.
   D.   The grantor/dedicator of the property and/or facility acknowledges and
agrees that the Village shall not be obligated to take title to any land if, in
its sole and exclusive judgment, for any reason whatsoever (including, without
limitation, information revealed by the environmental audit) it determines that
the use or condition of the property, or any part thereof, poses a material
health, safety or environmental hazard. (Ord. 93-21-91)
TITLE 6
BUILDING REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
BUILDING CODE
SECTION:
6-1-1: Short Title
6-1-2: Definitions
6-1-3: Applicability to Existing Buildings
6-1-4: Compliance With Provisions
6-1-5: Building Officers
6-1-6: Architectural Design
6-1-7: Health and Safety Requirements
6-1-8: Violations
6-1-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known and may be cited as The Building Code of Oak Lawn.
(1951 Code 21-17-2)
6-1-2: DEFINITIONS:
Words and terms used in this Chapter, not otherwise defined, shall have the
meanings defined in the zoning ordinance 1 . (1951 Code 21-1-3)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 4 of this Municipal Code.
6-1-3: APPLICABILITY TO EXISTING BUILDINGS:
In construing the several sections of this Chapter, said section shall not be
construed as requiring alterations in the construction or equipment of
buildings or structures in existence at the time of the passage of this
Chapter, unless specific provision is made to the contrary, or unless the
provision is expressly made retroactive, or unless such building shall not have
sufficient or adequate means of egress of ingress. (1951 Code 21-5-26)
6-1-4: COMPLIANCE WITH PROVISIONS:
Every building or structure or part thereof, hereafter constructed, erected,
altered, enlarged, maintained or repaired within the Village shall be so
constructed, erected, altered, enlarged, maintained or repaired in accordance
with the provisions of this Chapter. (1951 Code 21-5-24)
6-1-5: BUILDING OFFICERS:
   A.   Building Officers Designated: The title "building officers" when used
in this Chapter shall mean and include the Director of Office of Quality
Control, the Chief of Police, the Health and Sanitation Officer and all
inspectors and assistants, as provided for by the Board of Trustees.
   B.   Right of Entry Powers: Building officers and their duly authorized
inspectors are hereby empowered, during reasonable hours, to lawfully enter
upon any premises or into any building or structure, or portion thereof,
whether completed or in process of construction, alteration or repair, when
necessary to do so in performance of any duty imposed upon them by this Chapter
or the provisions of the Zoning Ordinance of the Village, or any order or
resolution of the Board of Trustees. (1951 Code 21-1-1, 21-1-2; Ord. 81-12-19)
6-1-6: ARCHITECTURAL DESIGN:
Every building or structure hereinafter constructed, erected, altered or
enlarged, shall be so designed and constructed as to be suitable to its
environment from an architectural standpoint. (1951 Code 21-5-27)
6-1-7: HEALTH AND SAFETY REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be the duty of every owner or occupant of a building to keep in a safe
sanitary condition. (1951 Code 21-5-6)
6-1-8: VIOLATIONS:
   A.   Resisting Officers: Any person hindering or attempting to hinder,
resisting, or attempting to resist, any building officer in the performance of
duty, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be charged with resisting an
officer.
   B.   Generally: Any person who violates, disobeys, omits, neglects or
refuses to comply with, or who resists the enforcement of any of the provisions
of this Chapter, or who shall refuse to remedy a violation of any such
provision, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and subject to a penalty as
provided in Section
1-4-1 of this Code. Each day upon which such violation continues shall
constitute a separate offense. (1951 Code 21-1-2, 21-17-1; 1985 Code)
ARTICLE A. BUILDING PERMITS AND FEES

6-1A-1: PERMIT REQUIRED:
Before proceeding with the erection, construction, alteration, addition,
repair, removal, demolition or the excavation for any building or structure in
the Village, a permit for such erection, construction, alteration, addition,
repair, removal, demolition or excavation shall first be obtained by the owner
or his agent from the Director of Office of Quality Control as provided herein.
(1951 Code 21-2-4; Ords. 79-34-72, 81-12-19, 20-08-21)
6-1A-2: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT, ACCOMPANYING PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Application for building permits shall be made by the owner or his
agent to the Director of Office of Quality Control on forms prepared and kept
on file in the office of said Director. Such application shall describe the
location of the proposed work by setting forth the correct legal description of
the land upon which the building, structure or part thereof is to be erected,
constructed, added, altered or repaired and the street name and number assigned
to the site, the real estate permanent index number, volume and item of the
Cook County Collector's tax warrant for the last year in which general real
estate taxes were assessed; the purpose for which the building or structure is
designed to be used; the length, width and height thereof; the number of rooms;
the total cost of the work proposed to be done under the permit sought; the
name and address of the owner or his agent or architect; and the names of the
licensed general contractors. Said application for a building permit shall also
be accompanied by a plat of survey, showing the proposed location of the
building to be erected on said lot, piece or parcel of land and an agreement to
be signed by the owner, his agent or architect, conditioned that he or his duly
authorized agent or architect, if granted the permit sought, will construct the
work in accordance with the description set forth in the application and
accompanying plans and specifications.
   B.   Applications for building permits (including garages) shall also be
accompanied by a plot plan in triplicate and a full set of plans and
specifications which shall be sufficiently complete so that the proposed
structure could be constructed therefrom by a competent contractor, builder or
engineer without further directions of any kind. Said plot plan and full set of
plans and specifications shall be reviewed by the Department of Quality Control
for compliances with the Village Code. When plans for specifications are
submitted for large, unique or complicated buildings or projects, the Director
of Office of Quality Control may send them to an independent, third-party
agency for plan review. The cost of such review shall be borne by the permit
applicant and is in addition to any such other fees charged by the Village. If
the plot plan and full set of plans and specifications are in compliance with
the Village Code, the three (3) copies of the plot plan shall be stamped
approved and initialed by the Director of Office of Quality Control. One copy
shall be returned to the applicant, one copy filed at the Village Hall, and one
copy retained by said Director.
   C.   All such plans and drawings shall be drawn to a scale of not less than
one-eighth of an inch to the foot (1/8" = 1') on paper or cloth in ink, or by
some process that will not fade or obliterate. All distances and dimensions
shall be accurately figured and drawings made explicit and complete, showing
the lot lines and the location of all plumbing fixtures within such building.
   D.   No permit shall be granted or plans approved unless such plans are made
and signed by such persons as are permitted under the laws of the State to make
plans for buildings as provided in "An Act to provide for the licensing of
architects and regulating the practice of architecture as a profession and to
repeal certain Acts therein named", approved June 24, 1919, and amendments
thereto, or in "An Act to revise the law in relation to the regulation of the
practice of structural engineering" approved June 24, 1919, and amendments
thereto 1 . The architect's seal and identification registration number shall
be attached to the original of said plans filed with the Director of Office of
Quality Control.
   E.   True copies of so much of said plans as may be required, in the opinion
of the Director of Office of Quality Control, to illustrate the features of
construction and equipment of the building referred to, shall be filed with the
Director of Office of Quality Control and shall remain on file in his office.
   F.   Complete plans and specifications of buildings for public or business
use for which permits are granted shall remain on file permanently in said
Director's office.
   G.   In all cases, the approved plan or plans, together with building
permits, must be kept on the premises while the work is in progress.
   H.   No deviation from the approved plans shall be allowed unless revised
plans are resubmitted for approval and approval in writing is granted by the
director of quality control.
   I.   All applications for permits issued under this Article A shall be
accompanied by a copy of each contractor's or subcontractor's current state and
Village licenses, registrations, and certifications, as applicable, as well as
proof of insurance in accordance with Section
6-1A-17. No permits shall be granted to a roofing contractor or subcontractor
without said contractor having first filed with the department of quality
control a copy (or copies, as applicable) of said contractor's current State of
Illinois and Village contractor licenses, registrations, and certifications and
the required proof of insurance.
   J.   Applications for building permits for new buildings or additions to
existing buildings shall be accompanied by a tree preservation plan. Said plan
shall consist of a survey of the parcel in question on which existing trees are
identified, with an indication as to whether said trees are to remain or be cut
down as a result of the proposed construction. Said plan shall be reviewed by
the village forester, and no permit shall be issued until the plan has been
approved by the village forester.
   K.   As a prerequisite to the issuance of any new or renewed business
license, each applicant shall submit to the business license department a
certificate of rodent abatement issued by a licensed exterminator. A copy of
the current rodent abatement certificate shall be kept on file with the
business license department at all times during the effectiveness of any
license.
      Applications for building permits for new commercial buildings, including
those for additions or demolition to existing buildings shall be accompanied by
a site-rodent abatement plan.
      1.   Prior to any demolition or excavation at a new commercial
construction site the owner of the site shall prepare a rodent control
management plan for the detection, inspection and treatment of rodents at the
site. At a minimum, the plan shall include provisions for abatement of the site
by a structural pest control company licensed by the State of Illinois by means
of above-ground bait boxes around the perimeter of the site until all
excavation is completed.
      2.   The owner shall maintain a written record of the plan and any pest
control measures performed by pest management professional at the site and
include any reports and receipts prepared by the structural pest control
company. The plan and records shall be maintained at the new construction site
until construction at the site is completed and open to inspection upon request
by authorized village personnel, including but not limited to employees of the
departments of streets and sanitation and buildings.
      3.   Commercial construction or demolition projects requiring excavation
must include rodent abatement on an as needed basis for all properties within a
three (3) city-block radius of the demolition site during the time of the
demolition project and up to but not more than ninety (90) days after the
demolition project is complete. Any abatement measures on properties included
within the three (3) city-block radius requires the individual property owner's
authorization;
         a.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall
be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. Each day that a violation continues
shall constitute a separate and distinct offense to which a separate fine shall
apply.
         b.   In addition to any other available penalties and remedies
provided, one or more violations of this section at the site may result in a
stop work order issued by the department that issued the citation, directing
that all activity cease for ten (10) days. Any further citation for violation
at the same new construction site within six months after the initial stop work
order may result in the issuance of another ten (10) day stop work order. The
department that issued the ten (10)-day stop work order under this section
shall lift that order only if sufficient evidence of compliance with this
section is provided to the department.
         c.   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly violate a stop
work order issued under this section, or to knowingly cause, permit, encourage,
assist, aid, abet or direct another person to violate a stop work order issued
under this section, or to knowingly in any manner be a party to a violation of
a stop work order issued under this section.
         Any person who violates this subsection upon conviction shall be
punished, as follows:
         (1)   Incarceration for a term not less than three days nor more than
six (6) months; or
         (2)   Community service of not less than 10 hours, nor more than one
hundred (100) hours; or
         (3)   A fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
      6.   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly destroy, deface,
remove, damage, impair, mar, cover or obstruct any stop work order issued under
this section that a village official has posted or affixed at a work site.
      7.   Any person who violates this subsection upon conviction shall be
punished, as follows:
         a.   Incarceration for a term not less than three days, nor more than
six (6) months; or
         b.   Community service of not less than ten (10) hours, nor more than
one hundred (100) hours; or
         c.   A fine of not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00), nor more
than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
The department of community development is authorized to enforce this section.
All references in Title 6 of the Village Code to the "department of quality
control" shall be interpreted to include the "department of community
development." (1951 Code 21-2-7; Ords. 51, 81-12-19, 86-6-15, 87-9-31, 87-9-32,
97-12-57, 20-08-21, 25-08-16)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 305/1 et seq., and 225 ILCS 330/1 et seq., respectively.
6-1A-3: FEES:
6-1A-3-1: BUILDING PERMITS:
   A.   Building Construction: The fees to be charged for building permits for
erecting, altering, repairing or adding to buildings shall be twenty-five
dollars ($25.00) for any structure of which the estimated cost is not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than one thousand dollars ($1,000.00)
and twelve dollars fifty cents ($12.50) for each additional one thousand
dollars ($1,000.00) of estimated cost or part thereof.
   B.   Permit Renewal: Any building permit issued as herein provided, and
which has expired by the terms thereof as provided in subsection
6-1A-6B of this article, may be renewed by payment of an additional fee of
fifty percent (50%) of the original building permit and water/sewer fee.
      1.   If a permit expires by failure to begin construction operations
within six (6) months of the date of issuance of the permit, the permittee must
renew the permit within the succeeding six (6) months or all fees paid therefor
shall be forfeited to the village and the permit, along with zoning ordinance
variations if any, shall become null and void.
      2.   If a permit expires by failure to complete the building within one
year after the date of issuance of the permit, the permittee must renew the
permit within the succeeding three (3) months and before a final inspection is
made or the permits, along with the zoning ordinance variations if any, shall
become null and void. Furthermore, the permittee shall be required to restore
the property back to its original condition by removing any construction
thereon, and if the permittee does not do so, the village, through its
employees, or agents, shall remove same and recover its expenses by the filing
of a lien on the property.
   C.   Cancellation Of Permit: If a permit has been issued and all fees have
been paid and the permittee wishes to cancel the permit within a period of six
(6) months from the date of issuance, an amount in the sum of forty percent
(40%) of the building construction fee, or a minimum of ten twenty dollars
($120.00), whichever amount is greater, shall be retained by the village for
costs incurred by the village for plan review, processing, records and other
expenses.
   D.   Minor Improvement Permit Fees: Notwithstanding anything to the contrary
set forth in this article, a permit shall be required for minor improvements to
a structure or building with respect to roofing, siding and deck installation.
The fees for said permits shall be as follows:
 
Type Of Permit  Fee
Roofing
   Residentia$50.00
   Commercial$100.00
Siding          $50.00
Decking         $50.00
 
(1951 Code 21-2-12; Ords. 74-25-46, 76-16-30, 82-23-83; 1985 Code; Ords. 87-9-
32, 94-4-13, 05-23-86, 08-17-46, 08-19-55, 21-07-29)
6-1A-3-2: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   Generally: All work performed under any permit issued pursuant hereto
must be inspected and approved by the appropriate inspectors of the building
department. There shall be at least four (4) inspections on each single-family
residence building and as many as deemed necessary by the director of the
office of quality control on all other types of buildings. The fee for
inspections shall be as follows:
 
Single-family buildings:
New buildings            $ 50.00
Additions or alterations 50.00
Two-family buildings     100.00
Multiple-family          100.00
                         plus $30.00 per unit over 2 units
 
All other types of buildings based on gross square feet, as follows:
 
0 -      1,500     $ 75.00
1,501 -  2,500     100.00
2,501 -  5,000     125.00
5,001 -  7,500     150.00
7,501 -  10,000    175.00
10,001 - 50,000    200.00
   50,001 and ov250.00
 
The above fee schedule for buildings is based on normal construction practices
and use groups. If a building is in any way unique, then the inspection fees
shall be based on an estimated number of inspections necessary to adequately
ensure proper construction. A certificate of occupancy will only be issued
after all inspection fees have been paid to the village.
When the building being constructed is large, unique, complicated, or involves
extensive or unique structural problems, the director of the office of quality
control may bring in an independent, third party agency to perform the
inspections of the building in question. The cost for such independent, third
party agency inspections shall be borne by the permit applicant and is in
addition to any other fees charged by the village.
   B.   Reinspections: If a building fails to pass inspection and a
reinspection is necessary then a reinspection fee of forty dollars ($40.00)
shall be charged which shall be paid before the reinspection is made.
   C.   Stop Work Orders: If it is necessary to post and enforce a stop work
order, the stop work order will not be removed until a twenty five dollar
($25.00) fee is paid by the permittee. (Ords. 87-9-32, 94-4-13, 08-17-46, 08-
19-55, 21-07-29)
6-1A-3-3: DEMOLITION OF BUILDINGS:
The fees to be charged for demolishing entire existing buildings and related
structures shall be as follows:
 
Type Of Structure                          Fee     Cleanup Bond
Residential garage and accessory buildings $ 50.00 $ 100.00
All single-family homes                    150.00  500.00
All other structures                       250.00  1,000.00
 
Upon written recommendation of the building department and written
authorization by the village manager, fees and/or bonds may be modified or
waived in instances where it is determined that it is in the best interest of
the village to do so. (Ords. 87-9-32, 94-4-13, 05-23-86, 21-07-29)
6-1A-3-4: GARAGES:
The permit fee for garages of one hundred (100) square feet or more shall be
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). This fee shall be inclusive and include
all inspection and occupancy permit fees except optional electrical permits.
(Ords. 94-4-13, 05-23-86, 21-07-29)
6-1A-3-5: STREET AND PARKWAY RESTORATION BOND:
Before any building permits are issued by the village, a cash bond in the
amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be deposited with the village to
ensure the safety of the street and parkway areas during construction, and the
complete restoration and cleanup of the street and parkway. Said bond shall be
drawn upon by the village in the event that the depositor thereof fails to
restore or clean up the street and/or parkway after having been instructed to
do so, in writing, by the village. Upon completion of construction and all
street and parkway restoration and cleanup, the remainder of the bond shall be
returned to the depositor; provided, however, that nothing herein contained
shall preclude the village from maintaining an action against any person to
recover the damage done to any street or parkway area. (Ords. 87-9-32, 94-4-13)

   A.   The fee for single-family residential buildings shall be four hundred
seventy five dollars ($475.00) per building for water used in construction.
   B.   The fee for all other buildings shall be based on gross square foot
area of all floors of the building to be constructed, as follows:

6-1A-3-7: EXEMPTIONS FROM PAYMENT OF FEES:
All building permit fees provided for in this chapter are waived as to all
governmental entities, churches, and eleemosynary institutions; provided,
however, that they shall be required to pay one hundred percent (100%) of the
plumbing and electrical inspection fees and one hundred percent (100%) of the
elevator review/inspection fees 1 . (Ord. 12-27-88)

  6-2A-2 of this title for electrical inspection fees.
6-1A-4: BOND REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Generally: The following bonds shall be deposited, in cash, with the
village before a building permit, electrical permit, or plumbing permit is
issued which requires said bonds. The bond inspection fee is for inspection of
the site and is not refundable. The cash bonds shall be refunded to the person
making the deposit within thirty (30) days after the operating departments have
inspected the site and have certified that all requirements of this chapter
have been complied with by the permittee. The cash bonds shall not be refunded
if work remains to be completed by the permittee to meet the requirements of
this chapter. If the permittee refuses or is unable to complete the work, the
village shall send written notice to the permittee, at the address listed on
the permit, that work shall be completed. If the work is not satisfactorily
completed within thirty (30) days after the notice, the village shall cause the
work to be completed, (including a 25 percent village administration fee) with
payment for said work to be deducted from the cash bonds and any remainder
refunded to the permittee. If the bonds are not sufficient to cover the
payment, the full amount of the bonds shall be forfeited and the permittee
shall be billed for the difference. Any bond remaining after four (4) years of
deposit shall be forfeited to the village to cover administrative costs.
   B.   Single-Family Residences; New Construction:
      1.   The general contractor shall deposit a five hundred dollar ($500.00)
cash bond for each single-family residence and shall pay a twenty five dollar
($25.00) inspection fee.
      2.   The drain layer and/or plumbing contractor shall deposit a five
hundred dollar ($500.00) cash bond for each single-family residence and shall
pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee.
      3.   The electrical contractor shall deposit a five hundred dollar
($500.00) cash bond for each single-family residence and shall pay a twenty
five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee.
   C.   Single-Family Residences; Existing Residence:
      1.   Residential building which is to be owner occupied: The amount of
the bond shall be five hundred dollars ($500.00) where the amount of
construction work being permitted is five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more
and shall pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee. For work less than
five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), the amount of the bond shall be two hundred
fifty dollars ($250.00) and shall pay a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection
fee. An additional plumbing bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00) and
nonrefundable twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee and an additional
electrical bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00) along with a nonrefundable
twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be required.
      2.   Vacant residential building which is to be non-owner occupied: The
amount of the bond shall be ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00) and a
nonrefundable twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee for any residential
building which is being rehabilitated where the building has been vacant just
prior to acquisition thereof and the building will be non-owner occupied after
rehabilitation. An additional plumbing bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00)
with a nonrefundable twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee and an
additional electrical bond of five hundred dollars ($500.00) with a
nonrefundable twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be required.
This category covers buildings which are being substantially rehabilitated for
sale or for rent. A structure is "non-owner occupied" if the person or entity
which purchased the property and is making or contracting for the improvements
does not occupy the same as their principal residence for at least twelve (12)
months after the certificate of occupancy is issued. Such structure must be
entitled to a homeowner's exemption from the Cook County assessor for that
entire twelve (12) month period in order to be owner occupied.
   D.   Multiple-Family Buildings:
      1.   The general contractor shall deposit a cash bond for each building
in the amount shown in the following table.
      2.   The electrical contractor as well as the plumber and/or drain laying
contractor shall deposit an additional and separate cash bond for each building
in the amount shown in the following table.
      3.   In each case, a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be
paid for each bond required on each and every separate building.
 
Apartment Units      Amount Of
For Each Building    Cash Bond
2 units to 5 units   $ 750.00
6 units to 11 units  1,000.00
12 units to 23 units 2,000.00
24 units to 47 units 5,000.00
48 units and up      10,000.00
 
   E.   All Other Types Of Buildings:
      1.   The general contractor shall deposit a cash bond for each building
in the amount shown in the following table.
      2.   The electrical contractor, plumber and/or drain laying contractor
shall deposit an additional and separate cash bond for each building in the
amount shown in the following table.
      3.   In each case, a twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be
paid for each bond required on each and every separate building.
 
Gross Square Foot Amount Of
Area Of Building  Cash Bond

50,000 and over   10,000.00
 
   F.   Street Openings:
      1.   The plumber and drain layer contractor shall deposit a cash bond for
each street opening in the amount of four thousand dollars ($4,000.00). In each
case, a fifty dollar ($50.00) inspection fee shall be paid for each bond
required on each street opening.
   G.   Sidewalks:
      1.   A sidewalk installation bond shall be deposited with the village, in
cash, based upon ten dollars ($10.00) per linear foot. The sidewalk bond is in
addition to any other bond required in this chapter. A twenty five dollar
($25.00) inspection fee shall be paid for each bond required on each and every
separate site.
   H.   Occupation Of Streets During Construction:
      1.   Five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   I.   Permanent Bonds:
      1.   As there are many contractors who do work within the village
continuously through the years, a permanent bond may be deposited with the
village in lieu of separate bonds for each and every building, street opening
and sidewalk. The permanent bond will be refunded only after a written request
is received by the village. Said request shall list the address of the last
work done within the village. The bond will be refunded after one year has
passed from the issuance of the last permit which required a bond. It is
understood that a general contractor permanent bond will include the general
bond as well as the sidewalk bond for all buildings he may build within the
village. However, if the general contractor has a permanent bond of one
thousand dollars ($1,000.00) and wishes to construct multiple-family buildings,
he will be required to deposit additional money to bring his permanent bond up
to the required amount of the bond necessary for any given number of units
under multiple-family buildings as listed in the following table. If the
general contractor wishes to build a commercial building, he will be required
to deposit additional money to bring his permanent bond up to the required
amount of the bond necessary for any given gross square foot area as listed in
the following table. If the general contractor deposits a ten thousand dollar
($10,000.00) permanent cash bond with the village, he may build any type of
building, of any size, under the same permanent cash bond. If charges are made
against the permanent bond, no further permits shall be issued until the full
amount of the required permanent bond is restored. The following table shall
establish the type and amount of the permanent bonds required:

A twenty five dollar ($25.00) inspection fee shall be paid for each and every
