6-8-29:    Window Signs
6-8-30:    Portable Sidewalk Signs
6-8-1: PURPOSE:
This chapter is adopted for the following purposes:
   A.   To preserve and promote the public health, safety, and welfare, through
reasonable, consistent, and non-discriminatory sign standards.
   B.   To preserve property values within the Village by regulating and
controlling the design, location, construction, and maintenance of all signs.
   C.   To advance the economy and the business and industry of the Village by
promoting the reasonable, orderly and effective display of all signs, and
encouraging better communication between signs and the public.
   D.   To enhance the physical appearance of site identification to be in
harmony with the visual character of the associated street corridor and to be
an integral party of the aesthetic of the site and architectural style of
associated buildings the Village by preserving the scenic and natural beauty of
the area.
   E.   To protect the general public, pedestrians, and motorists within the
Village by assuring the design, location, construction, and maintenance of
signs presents safe navigation through discernable information.
   F.   To ensure that signs are constructed, installed and maintained in a
safe and satisfactory manner, except to the extent expressly preempted by state
or federal law, and protect the public from unsafe signs.
   G.   To confirm that signs may cause harm to the public by creating
obstructions, providing distractions to motorist, displacing alternative land
uses, decreasing property values and aesthetics, and endangering the safety of
person and property.
   H.   To protect the public investment in streets and highways by reducing
sign or advertising distractions that may increase traffic accidents.
   I.   To establish the Village's substantial and compelling interest in
regulating signs in a manner as to reduce the effects and impacts signs have on
the public health, safety, and welfare.
   J.   To protect physical and mental well-being of the general public by
recognizing and encouraging a sense of aesthetic appreciation for the visual
environment. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-2: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this chapter, unless the context otherwise indicates, the following
terms and phrases shall have the meanings herein ascribed to them:
ABANDONED SIGN: A sign remaining on a site absent of a display permitted within
this Chapter for six (6) months or longer.
ADVERTISING SIGN: A commercial sign intended to aid, directly or indirectly, in
the sale, use, or promotion of a product, commodity, service, sales event,
activity, entertainment, or real or personal property.
ANIMATED SIGN: A sign which includes action, motion, or color changes, or the
optical
illusion of action, motion or color changes, including signs using electronic
ink, signs set in motion by movement of the atmosphere, or made up of a series
of sections that turn, including any type of screen using animated or scrolling
displays using light bulbs, neon light, light emitting diodes (LEDs) or LCD
screen(s) or any other type of video display.
APPROVED COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: Wood, or materials not more combustible than
wood, and approved plastics.
APPROVED PLASTICS: Only those slow burning plastics such as cellulose acetate
or methyl methacrylate or other plastics of no greater combustibility as now
approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories, Inc., for sign use (UL 48).
AUTOMATIC CHANGEABLE COPY SIGN: A sign which contains electronically displayed
stationary numerical or alphabetical characters which are regularly changed.
AUTOMOBILE DEALERSHIP SIGN: A sign which specifically serves to inform of the
presence of an automobile dealership.
AUTOMOBILE "FOR SALE" SIGNS: Any sign temporarily affixed to an automobile or
other motorized vehicle that directs attention to the fact that a certain
automobile or motorized vehicle is being offered for sale, excluding signs used
for such purposes by commercial car dealers or vendors within the Village. An
automobile "for sale" sign must contain a working telephone number by which the
seller can be contacted. Automobile "for sale" signs shall not be considered
"advertising signs" or "mobile signs" as defined in this chapter.
AWNING: Any secondary covering made of cloth, canvas woven acrylic, cotton or
polyester yarn, vinyl laminated to polyester fabric or metal with aluminum,
iron or steel, or wood frame attached to a building and projecting from a
building, when the same is so erected as to permit its being raised to a
position fiat against the building when not in use or in a permanent extended
rigid position.
AWNING SIGN: A fabric (or similar material) awning that is printed, stamped,
stitched or otherwise applied onto a protective awning, canopy, or other
fabric, plastic, or structural protective cover over a door, entrance, window,
or outdoor service area.
BANNERS: A sign of lightweight flexible fabric or similar material intended to
hang either with or without frames, mounted to a pole (other than a light pole
sign), building or other structure at one or more edges. National flags, state
or municipal flags, or the official flag of any institution or business shall
not be considered banners.
BILLBOARD: Any advertising sign or other commercial sign which directs
attention to a business, commodity, service, entertainment, or attraction sold,
offered or existing elsewhere that upon the same lot where such sign is
displayed.
BULLETIN BOARD SIGN: A changeable sign for displayed news and dates which
pertain to the business or organization whose land the sign sits on.
BUSINESS ENTRANCE IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign displayed near the entrance of a
business displaying the business's name, operating hours, and contact
information.
BUSINESS SIGN: A sign immediately in front of or on a business's building,
which makes the business's presence known to people passing on foot and in
vehicles.
CANOPY: Any structure, other than an awning, made of cloth or metal with metal
frames attached to a building, projecting from a building and carried by a
frame supported by the ground or sidewalk.
CANOPY SIGN: A freestanding canopy which is decorated in such a way to
represent a business on the same tract of property not more than one hundred
feet (100') away.
CHANGEABLE COPY SIGN: An automatic or changeable copy sign that changeable
text, characters, and/or illustrations that allows the sign's display to be
amended, updated or otherwise modified. Electronic message boards are a type of
changeable copy sign.
CIVIC EVENT SIGN: A temporary sign placed with the intention of drawing people
to a public event. The public event must be accessible to everyone.
CONFORMING SIGN: A sign which is legal and conforms to all standards set forth
by this code.
CONSTRUCTION SIGN: Temporary sign placed on a construction site which shows the
name of the construction project, the contractors, the architects, engineers
and/or developers, and the approximate date of completion.
DOUBLE FACED SIGN: A sign which shows the same information to viewers standing
on opposite sides of the sign while in line with the primary street or other
thoroughfare the sign sits along.
ERECT: To build, construct, attach, hang, place, suspend or affix, and includes
the painting of wall signs.
EXTERNALLY ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign lit by light bulbs, whose primary
illumination is obtained through the use of bulbs which are not placed inside
the sign structure.
FACING OR SURFACE: The surface of the sign upon, against or through which the
message is displayed or illustrated on the sign.
FAMILY ANNOUNCEMENT SIGN: A sign which commemorates an event in the household
where the sign is displayed.
FREESTANDING SIGN: A sign which is standing free of any structural support from
other structures or buildings.
FOOT-CANDLE. A unit of emitted light on a surface stated in lumens per square
foot and measurable with an illuminance meter (light meter).
GRAND OPENING SIGN: A sign which commemorates the initial opening period of any
event.
GROUND SIGN: A freestanding sign mounted to the ground with one or more poles
and not a direct part of the building and may be completely or principally
supported by one or more posts or other support structure, which is not
attached to the principal building on the property.
GOVERNMENTAL SIGN: A sign built and intended for the purpose of fulfilling a
government mandated purpose or requirement.
HOLIDAY DECORATIONS: Signs which are erected for the purpose of commemorating a
widely recognized holiday.
HORIZONTAL PROJECTING SIGN: Any sign which is greater in width than in height.
ICONIC SIGN: A sign that has been designated by the Historic Preservation
Commission and/or Architecture Design and Review Commission as providing and
promoting the preservation of the Village's unique character, history, and
identity.
IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign immediately in front of or on a business's
building, which makes the business's presence known to people passing on foot
and in vehicles.
ILLEGAL SIGN: A sign constructed without the issuance of any permit.
ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign which uses electric lighting to stay visible during
the nighttime hours.
INCOMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL: Any material which will not ignite at or below a
temperature of one thousand two hundred degrees Fahrenheit (1,200°F) and will
not continue to burn or glow at that temperature except as provided by
subsection 6-8-11D2 of this chapter.
INFLATABLE SIGNS: Any inflatable object, that is either: a) tethered or
otherwise suspended on top of a structure; or b) fastened to the ground.
INTERNALLY ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign whose primary illumination is obtained
through the use of lights which are placed within the structure itself.
JOINT IDENTIFICATION SIGN: An identification sign which only identifies a
planned development, and does not identify or make references to the individual
uses and tenants of units within the development.
LIGHT POLE SIGN: A banner mounted on street lighting poles with two (2) edges
affixed to a mounting bracket. Two (2) are the most that are allowable on any
light pole. Must contain suitably sized holes to facilitate the passage of
heavy wind without damaging the banner.
MANUAL CHANGEABLE COPY SIGN: A sign which contains manually displayed
stationary numerical or alphabetical characters which are regularly changed.
MARQUEE: Any permanent wall or roof-like construction projecting from the wall
of a building above an entrance.
MARQUEE LIGHTING: Lighting which uses light bulbs, neon light, or light
emitting diodes (LEDs) to create stationary lighting or synthetic movement on a
sign or to attract attention to a sign. The use of such lighting shall be
restricted to wall signs and marquee signs.
MARQUEE SIGN: Any painted, printed or illuminated sign attached to a marquee.
MEMORIAL SIGN: A sign which commemorates an event or series of events in the
past which draw the viewer to reflect upon those events.
MOBILE SIGN: Any electrical or nonelectrical sign designed for use and display
out of doors which is mounted on a trailer with a locking device, or which is
otherwise capable of being easily transported or moved from place to place.
MONUMENT SIGN: A sign, other than a pole sign, with steel supports, placed upon
or supported by the ground independently of any other structure. A sign that is
typically mounted on a masonry base. As distinguished from a ground sign, the
sign base of any monument sign must be a minimum of seventy five percent (75%)
or more of the width of the sign face that is to be situated upon the base. A
sign base less than seventy-five percent (75%) of the width of the sign face is
considered a ground sign.
MOVING SIGN: A sign with a moving mechanical element, whose primary purpose is
to attract attention to the sign.
NAMEPLATE SIGN: A sign used to display the personal name of a person operating
a business above or near said business's main entrance.
NONCONFORMING SIGN: A sign which conformed to all the necessary and relevant
codes when it was built, but presently considered noncompliant or in conflict
due to changes to the code. Also includes signs which have fallen into a state
of disrepair.
OBSOLETE SIGN: A sign which remains unchanged while the physical unit it
represents has either undergone a change in ownership or is vacant.
OFF SITE IDENTIFICATION SIGN: A sign which directs attention to a product or
service sold, offered, created, furnished, or conducted at a location not
directly associated with the property or site at which the sign is located.
ON SITE INFORMATIONAL SIGN: A sign placed on an establishment's property for
the purpose of directing patrons around the property to points of relevance,
such as the entrance and exit.
OTHER ADVERTISING STRUCTURE: Any "marquee", "canopy" or "awning" as further
defined herein.
OUTDOOR ADVERTISING SIGN: A sign providing display space for general commercial
advertising not related to the premises on site at which the sign is located;
commonly referred to as "billboards".
PARAPET SIGN: A sign mounted horizontally against a building's parapet, above
roof level.
PENNANTS: Any lightweight plastic, fabric or other material, whether or not it
contains a message of any kind, suspended from a rope, wire, or string, usually
in series, designed to move in the wind.
PERMANENT SIGN: A sign which is intended to stay intact and relevant for the
foreseeable future, without extensive modification from its as built form.
POLE SIGN: Any sign supported by upright members such as steel columns or poles
with a sign attached thereto, which is a freestanding structure with separate
foundations set into the ground and which is permanent.
POLITICAL SIGNS: A sign which advertises a local, county, state or national
candidate or proposition upon which a ballot is to be cast or vote taken in an
election.
PORTABLE SIDEWALK SIGN: A freestanding sign designed to be easily moved from
place to place and often containing a changeable copy sign element.
PRIVATE SALE SIGN: A temporary sign placed with the intention of drawing
customers to a "garage sale", "yard sale", or similar event.
PRIVATE WARNING SIGN: A warning sign on private property, notifying its viewer
of conditions and/or criteria set by the property's owner.
PROJECTING SIGN: Any sign which is attached to a building or other structure
and extends beyond the line of the said building or structure or beyond the
surface of that portion of the building or structure to which it is attached.
All projecting signs shall be illuminated signs, as defined by this chapter.
PUBLIC CLOCK: A timekeeping device, either digital or with a face and hands,
easily viewable to the public and either placed alongside an identification
sign or decorated to serve as an identification sign as well as a clock.
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A temporary sign placed on property notifying its viewers
that said property is for sale. Includes any relevant contact information.
ROOF SIGN: A sign located on or attached to roof framing.
SCOREBOARD SIGN: A freestanding sign intended to display scores for athletic
events, and also to serve as an outlet for advertisers who sponsor those
athletic events.
SIGN: Includes every sign, billboard, ground sign, wall sign, roof sign,
illuminated sign, light pole sign, projecting sign, temporary sign, mobile
sign, pylon or pole sign, marquee, awning and canopy, and includes any
announcement, declaration demonstration, display illustration or insignia
showing words, figures or pictures.
Any object, device, display or structure, or part thereof, which is used to
advertise, identify, display, direct or attract attention by any means
including words, printed text, letters figures, designs, symbols, pictures,
fixtures, colors, motion, illumination or projected images for the purpose of
delivering a message.
STACKED SIGN: A sign which is physically placed on top of or next to another
sign of similar dimensions and type.
STRUCTURAL TRIM: The molding, battens, cappings, nailing strips, latticing and
platforms which are attached to the sign structure.
SUSPENDED SIGN: An overhead sign hanging over a retail unit lined corridor, and
notifying its viewers where certain units are a short distance before they are
visible immediately to the viewer's right or left.
TEMPORARY BANNER: A banner mounted with the intention of serving for only a
short (finite) period of time, and constructed of nonpermanent materials.
TEMPORARY SIGNS: A sign constructed and intended for a temporary period of
display and is neither permanently installed in the ground nor permanently
affixed to a building, structure, wall or perimeter fencing.
THEATER SIGN: A sign mounted to the front of a cinema or performing arts venue,
with the name of said venue displayed along with a changeable listing of
current shows or performances.
TRANSPORTATION SHELTER ADVERTISEMENTS: Privately owned permanent structures
erected on or adjoining principal rights of way on arterial streets, for the
purpose of providing shelter from the weather for public mass transportation
passengers and containing up to six (6) panels of backlighted advertising.
VEHICLE SIGN: A sign placed on the side of a vehicle for the purpose of
identifying goods or services provided by the vehicle's owner or driver or an
entity which has contracted with the vehicle's owners.
VERTICAL PROJECTING SIGN: Any sign which is greater in height than in width.
WALL SIGN: A sign attached against a wall of a building or other structure,
with the exposed face of the sign parallel to the plane of the wall, and
attached to the exterior front, rear or wall side of any building or structure.
WINDOW SIGN: A sign or display installed, painted upon or placed into, or onto
the interior of a window. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-3: SIGN PERMITS:
   A.   Permits Required: It shall be unlawful for any person to erect, repair,
alter, relocate or maintain within the Village any "sign" or "other advertising
structure" or "awning" or "canopy" for commercial or business use, as defined
in this chapter, without first obtaining a sign permit from the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management and making payment of the fee
required by subsection D of this section. All illuminated signs shall, in
addition, be subject to the provisions of the electrical code, and the permit
fees required thereunder.
   B.   Application For Permit: Applications for sign permits shall be
submitted to the Department of Community Development and Growth Management and
Architectural Review and Preservation Commission. Applications for sign permits
shall be made upon blanks provided by the Department of Community Development
and Growth Management or have attached thereto the following information:
      1.   Name, address and telephone number of the applicant.
      2.   Location of building, structure or lot to which or upon which the
sign or other advertising structure is to be attached or erected.
      3.   Position of the sign or other advertising structure in relation to
adjacent buildings, structures or property lines.
      4.   Two (2) blueprints or ink drawings of the plans, specifications, and
method of construction, and attachment to the building or in the ground.
      5.   Copy of stress sheets and calculations showing the structure is
designed for dead load and wind pressure in any direction in the amount
required by this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the Village.
      6.   Name of person erecting structure.
      7.   Written consent of the owner including name, address and telephone
number of the owner of the building, structure or land to which or on which the
structure is to be erected.
      8.   An electrical permit required and issued for said sign.
      9.   Insurance policy or bond as required by subsection E of this
section.
      10.   Data and information covering sign or signs, of uniqueness of
structure or innovation of materials and design.
      11.   If external or internal illumination, a detailed lighting plan,
including a photometric plan is required. All lighting plans shall include
manufacturer specifications pertaining to light intensity.
   C.   The Approval Of Plans And Specifications: The application for a permit
for erection of a sign or other advertising structure in which electrical
wiring and connections are to be used shall be submitted to the chief
electrical inspector. Said inspector shall examine the plans and specifications
respecting all wiring and connections to determine if the same complies with
the electrical code of the Village. This action of the chief electrical
inspector shall be taken prior to submission of the application to the
Department of Community Development and Growth Management.
   D.   Fees: The following permit fees for such sign or other advertising
structure regulated by this chapter shall be as follows:
 
All signs requiring a permit other than   $ 1.00
those listed below, per sq. ft.
Canopy/awning:                             
   Without signage                     50.00
   With signage                        $1.00 per sq. ft. minimum of $50.00
Marquee, per 10 sq. ft. or fraction       $10.00
thereof of displaying surface
Mobile signs, per 10 sq. ft. or fraction  10.00
thereof of displaying surface
Temporary signs, per 25 sq. ft. or        35.00
fraction thereof
 
When a fee is assessed, in no event shall the minimum fee be less than fifty
dollars ($50.00).
   E.   Bond Or Insurance Required: Every applicant for a permit referred to
herein shall, before the permit is granted, file with the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management a continuing bond in the penal sum
of fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00), executed by the applicant and a surety
company to be approved by the Village attorney and conditioned for the faithful
performance of the provisions of this chapter and all amendments hereto, and of
all laws and ordinances relating to signs and other advertising structures, and
which shall indemnify and save harmless the Village from any and all damages,
judgments, costs or expenses which the Village may incur or suffer by reason of
granting of said permit. Any person lawfully maintaining a sign or other
advertising structure regulated by this chapter at the time of the enactment
hereof shall, within thirty (30) days after said enactment, comply with all the
provisions set forth in this subsection. A public liability insurance policy
issued by an insurance company authorized to do business in the state
conforming to this subsection may be permitted in lieu of a bond, provided that
a noncancelable clause or notification of nonrenewal clause is contained
therein.
   F.   Issuance Of Permit, Expiration: It shall be    the duty of the
Department of Community Development and Growth Management, upon filing of an
application for a sign permit, to examine such plans and specifications and
other data and the premises upon which it is proposed to erect the sign or
other advertising structure and upon compliance with all the requirements of
this chapter and all other laws and ordinances of the Village, the sign permit
shall be issued within fourteen (14) working days. If the work authorized under
a sign permit has not been completed within six (6) months after date of
issuance, the said permit shall become null and void and all fees shall be
forfeited.
   G.   Revocation Of Permit: The Department of Community Development and
Growth Management is hereby authorized and empowered to revoke any permit
issued upon failure of the holder thereof to comply with any provision of this
chapter. See section
3-1-6 of this code for permit revocation hearing provisions.
6-8-4: CONSTRUCTION SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Steel Supports: All outdoor advertising signs shall be constructed on
steel supports when the total area of said sign exceeds one hundred (100)
square feet.
   B.   Wind Pressure Requirements:
      1.   For the purpose of determining wind pressures, all signs shall be
classified as either open or solid. Signs in which the projected area exposed
to wind consists of seventy percent (70%) or more of the gross area as
determined by the overall dimensions shall be classed as solid signs; those in
which the projected exposed area is derived from open letters, figures, strips
and structural framing members, the aggregate total area of which is less than
seventy percent (70%) of the gross area so determined, shall be classed as open
signs.
      2.   All signs shall be designed and constructed to withstand wind
pressures applied to the projected exposed area, allowing for wind in any
direction, in accordance with the following table:
 
Height From     Wind Pressure Pounds Per Square Foot
Ground To Top   Solid Signs Open Signs
Of Sign In Feet
   Less than 17          23
   30 - 49   22          31
   50 - 99   28          39
   100 - 499 33          46
 
   C.   Wire Members: No cable or wire uplifts or guys are permitted.
   D.   Smooth Surface: All signs or other advertising structures which are
located in the property lines, or within five feet (5') thereof, shall have a
smooth surface and no nails, tacks or wires shall be permitted to protrude
therefrom, except electrical reflectors and devices which may extend over the
top and in front of the advertising structures. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-5: ANNUAL INSPECTIONS, FEES:
The division of building, planning and zoning shall inspect annually, or at
such other times which it deems necessary, each sign or other advertising
structure regulated by this chapter for the purpose of ascertaining whether the
same is structurally safe, in need of repair, or verify compliance with
lighting requirements. The sign permittee shall pay to the Village a sum of one
dollar fifty cents ($1.50) multiplied by the number of square feet of area for
each unit so inspected; provided, however, that in no event shall the
inspection fee be less than thirty dollars ($30.00) nor more than fifty dollars
($50.00) per location or business license. No charge shall be made until sign
is actually inspected. No inspection fee other than the permit fee as required
in subsection
6-8-3D of this chapter will be charged during the calendar year in which the
sign or other advertising structure is erected. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-6: GENERAL PROVISIONS:
   A.   Information Required On Signs: Every sign or other advertising
structure hereafter erected shall have painted in a conspicuous place thereon,
in letters not less than one inch (1") in height, the month and year of
erection, the name and address of the erector, the permit number and the
voltage of any electrical apparatus used in the connection therewith. Upon
annual inspection, inspection tag shall be affixed.
   B.   Maintenance Required: The owner of any sign as defined and regulated by
this chapter shall be required to have properly painted at least twice every
five (5) years, all parts and supports of the said sign, unless the same are
galvanized or otherwise treated to prevent rust.
   C.   Illumination:
      1.   Gooseneck reflectors and lights shall be permitted, on a permanent
basis, on freestanding signs, ground signs, parapet   signs, roof signs and
wall signs; provided, however, the reflectors shall be provided with proper
lenses concentrating the illumination upon the area of the sign so as to
prevent the glare upon the street or adjacent property.
      2.   It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain any sign which
extends over public property which is wholly or partially illuminated by
floodlights or spotlights.
      3.   Indoor illuminated signs. It shall be prohibited to place marquee
lighting on any indoor illuminated sign or building structure, including but
not limited to windows, doors, parapet, exterior walls, support beams, roofs
and balconies. The use of such lighting shall be restricted to wall signs, and
marquee signs.
   D.   Maintenance: Any type of sign shall be considered in violation of this
subsection if there is a visible lack of aesthetic maintenance, this includes,
but is not limited to: peeling of paint, cracks or broken portion of signs,
rust, burned out lights (if illuminated) and information which is no longer
legible due to weathering.
   E.   Number And Placement Of Signs:
      1.   There shall not be more than one advertising sign for each six
hundred feet (600') of parallel street frontage, except back to back sign
structures.
      2.   There shall be no "V" shape arrangements of back to back signs.
      3.   More than one advertising sign may be erected within six hundred
feet (600') of another sign structure if the face of the signs show in opposite
directions. No such structure shall contain more than one advertising sign per
each facing.
      4.   Advertising signs shall not be arranged so as to block the view of
signs which advertise the business on the adjacent property.
      5.   Notwithstanding any other provision in this code in the C-l, C-2 and
M-l zoning districts there shall be no more than two (2) ground signs on any
corner lot and one ground sign on any interior lot except that double faced
signs as permitted or allowed shall be deemed to be one sign.
   F.   Notice And Fines: The Village may provide written notice of a violation
of this section to the sign owner, permittee, or owner of the property upon
which the sign sits each of whom shall be jointly and severally liable for any
such violations. Upon receiving a written notice of a violation of this
section, the sign owner, permittee, or the owner of property upon which the
sign sits shall have twenty one (21) days to cure the violation. If the
violation is not cured within twenty one (21) days from receipt of the notice
of violation then the owner and/or person or entity listed on the sign permit
application shall be subject to a fine of not less than twenty five dollars
($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day the
violation exists after the twenty one (21) day period to cure the violation
shall be considered a separate violation.
   G.   Illumination Standards: Any sign that is illuminated, shall only be
illuminated by steady, stationary, shielded, and shaded light sources directly
solely at the sign, or internal to it so that the light intensity or brightness
does not create either a nuisance to adjacent property or a traffic hazard for
motorist or pedestrians. In no instance shall the lighting intensity of any
sign whether resulting from internal   illumination or external illumination,
exceeding the following:
      1.   Illuminated signs shall produce no more than XXX-foot candles of
illumination, four feet (4’) from the sign.
      2.   The source of light for external illuminated signs shall be located,
shielded, and directed in a manner that the light source is not visible from a
public street or private residence.
Any pre-existing Illuminated signs shall be classified as "Non-Conforming,"
pursuant to the Section
6-8-9 of this Chapter. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-7: REMOVAL OF UNSAFE AND UNLAWFUL SIGNS:
If the division of building, planning and zoning or other inspector as
designated by the Department of Community Development and Growth Management
shall find that any sign or other advertising structure regulated herein is
unsafe or insecure, or is a menace to the public, or has been constructed or
erected or is being maintained in violation of the provisions of this chapter,
it shall give written notice to the permittee thereof. If the permittee fails
to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards herein set
forth within ten (10) days after such notice, such a sign or other advertising
structure may be removed or altered to comply by the division of building,
planning and zoning at the expense of the permittee or owner of the property
upon which it is located. The Department of Community Development and Growth
Management shall refuse to issue a permit to any permittee or owner who refuses
to pay costs so assessed and division of building, planning and zoning may
cause any sign or other advertising structure which is in immediate peril to
persons or property to be removed summarily and without notice. In the event
that a fire has caused immediate peril to persons or property, then the fire
chief, or in his absence, the senior fire officer present, may order the
removal of the sign. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-8: SIGNS OBSTRUCTING PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY:
   A.   Ingress And Egress: No sign shall be erected, relocated or maintained
so as to prevent free ingress to or egress from any door, window, fire escape
or fire hydrant. No sign of any kind shall be attached to a standpipe, fire
escape or fire hydrant or light pole.
   B.   Utility Wires: Signs shall be installed so that there shall be a
minimum clearance of three feet (3') between the sign and any overhead utility
wires. Where the wires pass over the sign, the wires shall be protected as
recommended by the utility company owning or maintaining the wires.
   C.   Traffic Obstructions: No sign or other advertising structure as
regulated by this chapter shall be erected at the intersection of any streets
in such a manner as to obstruct free and clear vision; or at any location
where, by reason of the position, shape or color, it may interfere with,
obstruct the view of or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or
device; or which makes use of the words "Stop", "Drive-In", "Danger" or any
other word, phrase, symbol or character, in such manner as to interfere with,
mislead or confuse traffic.
   D.   Projections Into Public Rights Of Way: No permanent or temporary sign
or portion of a sign or its supports shall extend into or over the property
line into the public right of way, except as noted for wall signs and portable
sidewalk signs.
   E.   Nuisance: Any sign placed in the public right of way in violation of
this chapter shall be considered a nuisance and subject to abatement by the
Village. The person or entity responsible for the illegally placed signs may be
responsible for reimbursement to the Village for the Village's costs of removal
or abatement of the illegally placed signs in addition to being charged with
violating the provisions of this chapter and subject to any fines or costs.
(Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-9: NONCONFORMING SIGNS:
   A.   Any sign which was erected in conformance with the sign ordinance in
effect at the time of its erection but which currently fails to meet the size,
location, or other applicable requirements of this chapter, as amended, shall
be considered nonconforming and shall either be removed or brought into
compliance with this chapter's requirements within the period of time
prescribed herein dating from the effective date of this section.
   B.   All nonconforming signs shall be removed or brought into compliance
with this chapter's requirements in accordance with the abatement schedule set
forth below. In order to utilize the abatement schedule, the owner of record,
or his agent, shall make available the market value, as of [March 1, 2019], of
any sign or signs which have been deemed nonconforming by these regulations.
The market value of nonconforming signs shall be based on the original cost,
including cost of installation, of said sign less ten percent (10%) of the
original cost per year for each year said sign has been standing prior to the
effective date of this section.
   C.   The date of the erection of any nonconforming sign shall be established
by the presentation by the owner of record of the sign, or his agent, of a
certified copy of the corresponding sign permit on file with the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management. Any sign erected without the
issuance of a valid sign permit shall be deemed an illegal sign and shall be
removed immediately.
   D.   All required documentation concerning the market value and erection
date of any nonconforming sign shall be presented to the Department of
Community Development and Growth Management within ten (10) days of receipt of
notice of nonconformance. The Department of Community Development and Growth
Management shall determine to its satisfaction the validity of all presented
documentation. Any decision of the Department of Community Development and
Growth Management may be appealed to the Appeals and Review Board.
   E.   Abatement Schedule:
Adjusted Market Value Abatement Date
Adjusted Market Value    Abatement Date
Less than $500.00        June 1, 2019
$500.00 to $999.99       September 1, 2019
$1,000.00 to $1,499.99   December 1, 2019
$1,500.00 to $1,999.99   March 1 ,2020
$2,000.00 to $2,999.99   June 1, 2020
$3,000.00 to $3,999.99   September 1, 2020
$4,000.00 to $4,999.99   December 1, 2020
$5,000.00 to $7,499.99   March 1, 2021
$7,500.00 to $9,999.99   June 1, 2021
$10,000.00 to $12,499.99 September 1, 2021
$12,500.00 to $14,999.99 December 1, 2021
$15,000.00 to $19,999.99 March 1, 2022
$20,000.00 and over      June 1, 2022
 
   F.   Any sign that is in noncompliance with the regulations of this chapter
shall be removed prior to or upon the date designated for removal in the above
abatement schedule. If the owner of, or the person or persons responsible for
the sign fails to remove the nonconforming sign, the owner of the premises upon
which the sign is located shall be responsible for the removal of the sign and
the work shall be done within ninety (90) days following the abatement date.
The procedure for the removal of all nonconforming signs shall be as follows:
      1.   The Department of Community Development and Growth Management after
proper notification, may cause the removal of any nonconforming sign and shall,
at its discretion, charge the costs incurred against any of the following, each
of whom shall be jointly and severally liable for said charges; provided,
however, that any decision or determination of the Department of Community
Development and Growth Management may be appealed to the Appeals and Review
Board:
         a.   The permittee.
         b.   The owner of the sign.
         c.   The owner of the premises on which the sign is located.
         d.   The occupant of the premises on which the sign is located.
      2.   A sign removed by the Village shall be held not less than thirty
(30) days by the Village during which time it may be recovered by the owner
upon payment to the Village for the costs of removal and storage. If not
recovered prior to expiration of the thirty (30) day period, the sign and
supporting structures shall be declared abandoned and title thereto shall vest
in the Village and the cost of removal shall be billed to the owner of the
sign. (Ords. 9-13-41, 9-16-65)
6-8-10: PROHIBITED SIGNS:
   A.   Any sign not expressly permitted in this Chapter is prohibited.
   B.   No person or entity shall display any of the following signs within the
Village of Oak Lawn:
      1.   Signs by which color, location, or design resemble or conflict with
traffic control signs or signals.
      2.   Portable signs.
      3.   Commercial signs on a vehicle where said vehicle is parked adjacent
to or near the right-of-way for the purposes of identifying or calling
attention to the business, such as utilizing directional signage, and is not
used for daily operations or during the regular course of business, or is not
licensed, insured, or operational.
      4.   Billboards, off site identification signs, or outdoor advertising
signs not existing at the time of the adoption of this Chapter. Any replacement
or erection of a billboard, off site identification sign, or outdoor
advertising sign shall be prohibited.
      5.   Any signs or attention getting devices, that rotate, revolve, or any
visible moving parts or that gives the appearance of movement, including, but
not limited to, searchlights, spinners, streamers, banners, balloons, barrels,
and other similar devices, or ornamentation designed for purposes of attracting
attention, promoting, or advertising, unless otherwise provided for in this
Chapter.
      6.   Any sign or structure which constitutes a hazard to public health,
safety, or welfare, including dangerous construction or sight obstructions.
      7.   Any sign located in the public right-of-way, unless otherwise
provided for in this Chapter.
      8.   Pole signs. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-11: OBSOLETE AND ABANDONED SIGNS:
Any sign now or hereafter existing which no longer advertises a bona fide
business conducted, or a product sold on the premises where said sign is
located, or any sign that is located on property that has failed to maintain a
valid business license or that becomes vacant and unoccupied for a period of
six (6) months or more will be deemed to have been abandoned or obsolete and
shall be taken down and removed including the sign face, supporting structures,
and structural trim by the owner, agent, permittee, or person having the
beneficial use of the building or structure upon which such sign may be found
within thirty (30) days after written notification from the division of
building, planning and zoning.
Upon failure to comply with such notice within the time specified in such
order, the obsolete or abandoned sign shall be considered a nuisance and the
division of building, planning and zoning is hereby authorized to cause removal
of such sign, and any expense incident thereto shall be paid by the owner of
the building or structure to which such sign is attached. Where an owner fails
to pay such expenses, the Village may file a lien upon the property for the
purposes of collecting all reasonable costs including attorney fees associated
with removal of the sign. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-12: OUTDOOR ILLUMINATED SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern outdoor illuminated signs.
   A.   Box Or Drum:
      1.   Design: The design shall be such as to afford ample strength and
rigidity, to render the box practically weatherproof, to enclose all terminals
and wiring and to provide drainage for each compartment.
      2.   Joints: Where joints occur in a metal box or drum they shall be the
lap type. The lap shall be sufficient for weatherproofing.
      3.   Openings: All openings in the box or drum shall be provided with
covers arranged to lock securely. Unless hinged, the covers shall be secured to
the sign box by a noncorrosive chain.
   B.   Construction Of Faces, Boxes And Backs:
      1.   Approved plastic may be used for sign faces but not as a supporting
means.
      2.   If metal is used in the construction of illuminated sign faces on
box type signs or letters, it shall not be less than no. 24 U.S. gauge.
Metal used in faces of signs other than box type shall be not less than no. 18
U.S. gauge.
Metal shall be used for construction of backs of flat signs and shall be not
less than no. 24 U.S. gauge.
      3.   Box or drum shall be galvanized steel and painted or aluminum or
stainless steel, and drainage should be provided by means of one or more weep
holes, each not larger than one inch (1") or less than three-eighths inch (3/
8") in diameter. There shall be at least two (2) weep holes per compartment but
in no case shall the weep holes be less than four feet (4') on center.
      4.   Metal faces of all illuminated signs more than two feet (2') wide
shall be reinforced on the inside with galvanized iron stiffening channels or
angles and also stayed or braced to the frame or opposite side, such stays or
braces to be so placed that all surface areas of ten (10) square feet are so
reinforced.
   C.   Framework:
      1.   All signs having an area of twelve (12) or more square feet of one
face shall have an approved structural framework of galvanized steel angles or
the equivalent in strength to be not less than specified in the following
table:
FRAMEWORK TABLE
 
Area Of Face      Projecting Signs Single Faced Signs
12 to 20 sq.ft.   1 ½ x 1 ½ x 3/11 ½ x 2 x 3/16
21 to 40 sq.ft.   2 x 2 x 3/16     1 ½ x 2 x 3/16
41 to 70 sq. ft.  2 x 2 x 1/4      2 x 2 x 3/16
Larger than above 2 ½ x 2 ½ x 1/42 x 2 x 1/4
 
      2.   Signs of ten (10) or more linear feet shall have an intermediate
brace for every five (5) linear feet. If frame is made of angle larger than one
and one-half inches by one and one-half inches by one-sixteenth inch (1 ½" x 1
½" x 1/16"), the next size smaller angle may be used as a brace.
      3.   All connections between framework members shall be made with
galvanized machine bolts not less than three-eighths inch (3/8") in diameter or
riveted. Gusset plates or equivalent shall be used in making these connections
where the area of the sign is greater than forty (40) square feet. Metal sign
faces shall be bolted, screwed or riveted to flange of drum with a maximum
distance of eight inches (8") on center. If riveted, suitable tinned or cherry
rivets shall be used. If bolted, brass or galvanized bolts not less than eight
thirty-seconds (8/32) shall be used. If screwed, suitable sheet metal screws
shall be used.
      4.   Signs built in more than one section shall have provision for
connecting sections during the course of erection so that the entire structural
framework will act as a completely fabricated and assembled unit. Each section
shall be so constructed that the interior is accessible for maintenance and
inspection.
   D.   Materials:
      1.   Glass: The glass in a box type sign shall be double strength or
plate glass. The area of any one piece of glass in each face of a sign over
public property shall not exceed eight (8) square feet where double strength
glass is used, nor eighteen (18) square feet where plate glass is used. Each
such piece must be supported by a separate frame.
      2.   Plastics: Approved plastics shall mean only those slow burning
plastics such as cellulose acetate or methyl methacrylate or other plastics of
no greater combustibility as now approved by the Underwriters' Laboratories,
Inc., for sign use (UL 48), and may be used on signs under the following
conditions:
         a.   The material shall not be subjected to a temperature higher than
one hundred forty nine degrees Fahrenheit (149°F) unless such material is
certified by the manufacturer to be special heat resistant material, in which
case the temperature shall not exceed one hundred eighty degrees Fahrenheit
(180°F).
         b.   The sign shall be so constructed that the plastic material will
not come in contact with gas tubes or other source of illumination and shall be
kept at least two inches (2") from the nearest incandescent lamp.
         c.   The wiring and current carrying parts, other than lampholders,
shall be enclosed in metal.
         d.   When plastic material is mounted in a metal frame, proper
provision shall be made for the difference in expansion between the plastic and
the frame. One-sixteenth inch (1/16") total clearance for each twelve inches
(12") or fraction thereof, of the dimension perpendicular to the mounted edge
should be provided in the mounting system.
         e.   When plastic is held in place by flanges, troughs, channels or
clips, these means of attachment shall overlap the plastic by not less than the
following:
 
Width Of Panels Attachment Size
Up to 12"       3/8"
12" to 24"      7/16"
24" to 36"      ½"
36" to 48"      9/16"
Over 48"        3/4"
 
Flanges, troughs or continuous channels shall be made of galvanized sheet
metal, copper or aluminum, not less than twenty (20) gauge U.S. standard in
thickness. Where clips are used for attachment, they shall be made of
noncorrosive spring type material such as phosphor bronze or equivalent, the
thickness of which shall be not less than thirty two one-hundredths inch
(0.32"). Each clip shall not be less than two inches (2") wide and clips,
bolts, screws or rivets shall be spaced on not less than seven inch (7")
centers around the entire periphery of the plastic.
         f.   When bolts, screws or rivets are used to fasten plastic material
to a metal frame, washers shall be placed under the heads of the bolts, screws
or rivets. These washers shall be of metal of a noncorrosive material and have
an outside diameter of not less than six (6) times the diameter of the screw
being used. Washers are to be not less than thirty two hundredths inch (0.32")
in thickness.
         g.   Undue pressure of fastening devices against the plastic material
should be avoided by the use of suitable gasket material, sprint tension or
adequate clearance to allow for expansion.
         h.   Removable plastic panels not fastened to the frame or supported
on all edges shall be supported on their longest dimension by troughs on two
(2) opposite edges. Where such removable panels are made in more than one
section, the adjacent ends shall be pointed together, where the adjacent ends
exceed twelve inches (12") in length, by fastenings directly supported to the
frame of the sign. Such fastenings to be not less than twelve inches (12") on
centers.
         i.   The plastic decorations, faces, panels and letter facings shall
be demonstrated to be of sufficient thickness or so formed or supported as to
withstand twenty five (25) pounds' uniform load per square foot without coming
in contact with gas tubes or any other source of illumination and without
coming within two inches (2") of an incandescent lamp.
         j.   Plastic sheets may not be used as a supporting means for current
carrying parts or sources of illumination.
         k.   Approved solid type or hollow plastic letters or characters may
be used provided they are not used as a raceway.
         l.   The structure of the sign on which the plastic is mounted or
installed shall be noncombustible.
   E.   Catwalks And Ladders:
      1.   Catwalks for maintenance purposes on signs and sign structures shall
be constructed of metal.
      2.   Ladders on sign structures shall be at least fifteen inches (15")
wide. Ladders on signs shall be metal and shall not be less than ten inches
(10") wide.
   F.   Moving Parts: Signs employing the use of moving parts for animated
action as well as public clocks and thermometers shall be so designed that the
driving mechanism and the supporting bearings are securely anchored to the main
steel structure of the sign, and the supports for the movable portions of the
display must be calculated to support its weight plus the maximum wind pressure
to which the movable portions may be subjected. Mechanical motions having an
arc of rotation of less than sixty degrees (60°) may have their electrical
connections made through approved flexible rubber covered leads. Electrical
connections for actions greater than sixty degrees (60°) rotation must be
accomplished through the use of slip rings.
   G.   Method Of Hanging:
      1.   Flat signs shall be anchored below roof line except that additional
support other than chain may be provided over parapet to roof.
      2.   Projecting signs shall be rigidly hung on beams.
      3.   Separate projecting signs so hung as to appear as one sign shall be
rigidly hung on beams.
   H.   Poles Or Posts:
      1.   Poles or posts for the support of signs shall be of metal and shall
conform to accepted standard engineering design and loads; provided sign is not
more than twelve feet (12') above sidewalk, width is not more than half of
length, and hanging irons do not exceed two feet (2').
When pipe is employed, its trade size shall be not smaller than four inches
(4") and when supported by earth shall be firmly set in concrete with means to
prevent the pole from turning.
      2.   A sketch showing the size of the post and details of hanging shall
be submitted with the application for permit signed and stamped by a state of
Illinois registered architect or structural engineer.
      3.   Calculation for the size of the post shall be based on a combined
torsional and bending movement for a wind pressure of thirty (30) pounds per
square foot and a maximum fiber stress of sixteen thousand (16,000) pounds per
square inch.
      4.   Splices in pipe support standards shall be so constructed that they
develop required strength at that point. Splices shall be made at a point not
less than eight feet (8') above the foundation.
   I.   Safety Provisions: Facilities for proper protection of the public must
be provided during the erection or maintenance of all signs.
   J.   Restrictions: It shall be prohibited to place marquee lighting on any
outdoor illuminated sign or building structure, including but not limited to
windows, doors, parapet, exterior walls, support beams, roofs and balconies.
The use of such lighting shall be restricted to wall signs and marquee signs.
   K.   Illumination: [Discuss how to determine LED brightness from ground and
to determine length of frequency for LED]. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-13: GROUND SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern ground signs.
   A.   Materials: All ground signs for which a permit is required under this
chapter, shall have a surface or facing of incombustible material; provided,
however, that combustible trim and structural supports and bracing may be used,
and further that the surface or facing may be of approved combustible material
if the surface is no more than sixty four (64) square feet in area located no
closer to an existing building or property line than ten feet (10').
   B.   Letters And Characters To Be Secured: All letters, figures, characters
or representations in cutout or irregular form, maintained in conjunction with,
attached to, or superimposed upon any sign shall be safely and securely built
or attached to the sign structure and shall comply with all requirements in
subsections
6-8-4D and
6-8-8A and B of this chapter.
   C.   Height And Area: The height of a ground sign shall not exceed twenty
four feet (24') nor shall the area or surface of both sides of the sign exceed
three hundred (300) square feet including the structural trim.
   D.   Location: No part of any ground sign shall be nearer the street than
the property line established by law.
   E.   Maintenance: All ground signs and the property described in the sign
permit shall be maintained by the owner of the sign in a clean, sanitary and
inoffensive condition, and free and clear of all obnoxious substances, rubbish
and weeds. Failure to clean up the premises shall be sufficient cause for
revocation of any permit issued pursuant to this chapter. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-14: POLE SIGNS:
Pole signs shall be hereby prohibited. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-15: WALL SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern wall signs.
   A.   Materials: All wall signs for which a permit is required under this
chapter shall have a surface or facing of incombustible material or approved
nonrusting metal, paint, plastic or vinyl; provided, however, that combustible
decorative trim may be used thereon; and further provided, that combustible
facing not to exceed sixty four (64) square feet may be used if said sign is
nonilluminated or if there is no contact of any kind with the combustible
signs' materials and any or all electrical equipment, conduit, boxes or
attachments. Paint shall only be allowed to be placed upon a wall of brick or
masonry based construction, and must be used in conjunction with a suitable
primer prior to the application of paint and a protective clear coat following
the application of paint.
   B.   Location:
      1.   Placement And Area: No wall sign shall cover wholly or partially any
wall opening nor project beyond the ends or top of the wall to which it is
attached, and any one wall sign shall not exceed an area of two hundred (200)
square feet, unless approved by the Department of Community Development and
Growth Management. The maximum sign area shall be 7.5 percent of the area of
the first two (2) stories of building elevation on which it is placed, or in
the case of a multi-tenant industrial building, each tenant may have a sign not
to exceed 7.5 percent of the area of its leased exterior storefront.
      2.   Projection Above Sidewalk And Setback Line: No wall sign shall be
permitted to extend more than twelve inches (12") beyond the building line, and
shall not be attached to a wall at a height of less than ten feet (10') above
the sidewalk or ground.
   C.   Structural Requirements:
      1.   Supports And Attachments: All wall signs shall be safely and
securely attached to the building wall by means of metal anchors, bolts or
expansion screws of not less than three-eighths inch (3/8") in diameter
imbedded in said wall at least five inches (5"); provided, however, that such
signs may rest in, or be bolted to strong, heavy, metal brackets or saddles set
not over six feet (6') apart, each of which shall be securely fixed to the wall
as hereinbefore provided. In no case shall any wall sign be secured with wire,
strips of wood or nails.
      2.   Wind Pressure Requirements: All wall signs shall conform to the
requirements of subsection 6-8-4B of this chapter.
   D.   Nonconformance Criteria: A wall sign shall be considered nonconforming
due to the following conditions:
      1.   A visible lack of aesthetic maintenance. This includes, but is not
limited to, peeling of paint, rust, burned out lights (if illuminated) and
information which is no longer legible due to weathering.
      2.   Failing structure integrity. This includes, but is not limited to,
broken anchors, sign paneling which is easily moved in windy conditions, and
sign paneling which sags or peels away from the wall.
      3.   Obstruction by nature. This includes, but is not limited to, the
overgrowth of weeds and other plants at the base of the sign to a point where
the bottom of the sign becomes obscured and/or unreadable.
      4.   Illumination. The use of marquee lighting shall be allowed on wall
signs.
      5.   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Chapter,
the Illumination regulations of this Chapter shall not apply or be imposed upon
any currently existing wall sign following the passage of an ordinance
approving this Chapter. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-16: ROOF SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern roof signs.
A structure may have a wall sign or a roof sign but not both.
   A.   Materials: Every roof sign, including the upright supports and braces
thereof, shall be constructed entirely of galvanized or stainless steel;
provided, however, that combustible structural trim may be used thereon.
   B.   Height And Area: No roof sign shall have a surface or facing exceeding
fifty (50) square feet per side or one hundred (100) square feet for all sides,
nor have its highest point extended more than seventeen feet (17') above the
roof level, or the allowable height of the zoning district.
   C.   Location: No roof sign shall be placed on the roof of any building or
structure in such manner as to prevent free passage from one part of said roof
to any other part thereof or interfere with openings in said roof and shall
comply with subsections 6-8-8A and B of this chapter.
   D.   Structural Requirements:
      1.   Bracing, Anchorage And Supports: Every roof sign shall be mounted so
that no portion of said roof sign shall project into the public right of way.
The sign shall be physically mounted by means of a steel beam and/or steel pole
with no more than two (2) such beams or poles being utilized and erected in
accordance with standard engineering calculations. A-frames or other multiple
use of angle irons, chains or other lattice work erection systems are hereby
prohibited.
      2.   Wind Pressure Requirements: All roof signs shall conform to the
requirements of subsection
6-8-4B of this chapter. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-17: PROJECTING SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern projecting signs.
   A.   Construction Generally: Every projecting sign shall be sealed by a
structural engineer and shall be constructed of incombustible materials, shall
be illuminated and shall be two (2) faced.
   B.   Materials: The lettering or advertising designs to be illuminated may
be composed of glass or other transparent or semitransparent incombustible
material. Any glass forming a part of any sign shall be safety glass or plate
glass at least one-fourth inch (1/4") thick and in case any single piece or
pane of glass has an area exceeding three (3) square feet, it shall be wired
glass. One section, not exceeding three (3) square feet in area, constructed of
wire glass or safety glass, shall be permitted on each side of a sign.
C.   Height And Area: Projecting signs shall be limited in area to seventy five
(75) square feet per side and shall not exceed a height of the    zoning
district.
   D.   Location: Every projecting sign shall be placed at least ten feet (10')
above any sidewalk used by the public over which it is erected, and a distance
not greater than twelve inches (12") from the face of the wall to which it is
attached, measuring from the point of the sign nearest thereto. No sign or part
thereof shall extend onto public property or right of way.
   E.   Support Structures:
      1.   Projecting signs exceeding ten (10) square feet in area or fifty
(50) pounds in weight shall not be attached to nor supported by frame buildings
nor the wooden framework of a building. Said signs shall be rigidly hung on
beams.
      2.   No projecting sign shall be secured with wire, strips of wood or
nails, nor shall any projecting sign be hung or secured to any other sign.
   F.   Illumination:
      1.   The reflectors shall be provided with the proper lenses
concentrating the illumination upon the area of the sign and preventing glare
upon the street or adjacent property; and no floodlight or spotlight nor
reflectors of the gooseneck type shall be permitted on projecting signs.
      2.   Every nonconforming projecting sign over public property shall be
illuminated between sunset and one o'clock (1:00) A.M. every morning, Monday
through Saturday, on each side thereof, by at least five (5) watts per square
foot of sign surface, but in no case less than sixty (60) watts for each sign
surface.
      3.   The use of marquee lighting shall be restricted for use on
projecting signs.
   G.   Movable Parts: Any movable part of a projecting sign such as the cover
of a service opening shall be securely fastened by chains or hinges.
   H.   V-Shaped Signs Prohibited: V-shaped signs, consisting of two (2)
single-faced signs erected without a roof or ceiling, shall not be permitted.
(Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-18: MARQUEES:
The provisions of this section shall govern marquees.
   A.   Materials: All marquees, including the anchors, bolts, supports, rods
and braces thereof, shall be constructed of incombustible materials and shall
be designed by a structural engineer.
   B.   Location:
      1.   Height Above Sidewalk: No portion of a marquee shall be less than
ten feet (10') above grade or any public thoroughfare.
      2.   Setback From Property Line: No marquee or any part thereof shall be
permitted to extend beyond the property line into any dedicated public right of
way.
   C.   Area: Attraction board and other illuminated surfaces shall not exceed
five hundred (500) square feet in total, including all vertical surfaces.
   D.   Structural Requirements:
      1.   Supports: Marquees shall be supported solely by the building to
which they are attached, and no columns or posts shall be permitted as support
therefor.
      2.   Roof Live Load And Wind Pressure Requirements: The roof of any
marquee shall be designed and constructed to support a live load of not less
than one hundred (100) pounds per square foot. The wind pressure requirements
shall be those stated in subsection 6-8-4B of this chapter.
      3.   Anchorage To Wood Structures: No marquees shall be erected on any
building of wood frame construction unless attached to the masonry, concrete or
steel supports of the building.
   E.   Signs Attached To Marquee: Signs attached to, or hung from a marquee
shall be completely within the borderline of the marquee outer edge, and shall
in no instance be lower than ten feet (10') above a sidewalk or public
thoroughfare. No sign or advertising material shall exceed five feet (5') in
height exclusive of the name of the establishment exhibiting such marquee. No
advertising material shall be placed upon the roof of any marquee.
   F.   Roofs Of Marquees:
      1.   Drainage: The roofs of all marquees shall be leakproof and properly
guttered and connected to downspouts to a storm sewer.
      2.   Roof Use And Materials: The roofs of all marquees shall be used for
no other purpose than to form and constitute a roof and shall be of
incombustible material.
   G.   Illumination: It shall be allowed to place marquee lighting on marquee
signs.
   H.   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this Chapter, the
Illumination regulations of this Chapter shall not apply or be imposed upon any
currently existing marquee sign following the passage of an ordinance approving
this Chapter. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-19: AWNINGS AND CANOPIES:
The provisions of this section shall govern awnings and canopies for commercial
or public use.
   A.   Permits And Inspections: Permits for awnings and canopies shall be
required as provided in subsection
6-8-3A of this chapter. Awnings and canopies shall be subject to annual
inspection as required in section
6-8-5 of this chapter.
   B.   Materials:
      1.   Awnings: Awnings may be constructed of cloth or metal, no vinyl;
provided, however all frames and supports shall be of metal. The awning may not
be internally illuminated (no backlighting) although there may be lighting
directed downward.
      2.   Canopies: Canopies may be constructed of cloth or metal hood, no
vinyl; provided, however, all frames and supports shall be of metal. Canopies
may not be internally illuminated (no backlighting) although there may be
lighting directed downward.
   C.   Location:
      1.   Height Above Grade:
         a.   Awnings: All awnings shall be constructed and erected so that the
lowest portion thereof shall not be less than eight feet (8') above grade,
public thoroughfare, or any pedestrian walk.
         b.   Canopies: All canopies shall be constructed and erected so that
the lowest portion thereof shall be not less than nine feet (9') above grade,
public thoroughfare, or any pedestrian walk.
      2.   Setback From Property Line: No awning or canopy shall be permitted
to extend beyond the property line into public right of way.
   D.   Support Structures:
      1.   Awnings:
         a.   Every awning shall be securely attached to and supported by the
building.
         b.   Posts or columns shall not be permitted for awnings.
         c.   No awning shall be attached to the wood jambs, frames or other
wood members of a building (frame buildings excepted) when such building is
less than ten feet (10') from public property.
      2.   Canopies: The framework of all canopies shall be designed by a
structural engineer. All frames and supports shall be of metal and designed to
withstand a wind pressure as provided in subsection
6-8-4B of this chapter.
   E.   Advertising: No advertising shall be placed on any awning or canopy;
except, that the name of the owner and business, industry or pursuit conducted
within the premises may be painted or otherwise permanently placed on the front
and side portions thereof except as approved by the Department of Community
Development and Growth Management. The area of advertisement located on an
awning or canopy shall be limited and count toward the allowable wall signage.
(Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-20: TRANSPORTATION SHELTERS AND ADVERTIS- ING SIGNS:
Transportation shelters may only be erected with prior specific approval of the
Zoning and Planning Commission and the president and board of trustees. Public
hearings for variations of zoning are not required for the placement of the
transportation shelters on public rights of way or on privately owned property;
provided, that prior approval was given by said commission and board. All
transportation shelters and advertising thereon shall be covered by the clauses
and provisions of a specific contract which shall be executed by the
transportation shelter corporation, firm, person or association, and the
Village president and board of trustees. (Ords. 9-13-41, 19-16-66)
6-8-21: TEMPORARY SIGNS:
   A.   Construction: Temporary signs must be maintained in a structurally
safe, clean, unblemished, and presentable manner.
      1.   Materials: Temporary signs may be constructed of cloth, canvas,
light fabric, cardboard, wallboard, wood or other light materials, with or
without frames.
      2.   Support Structures: Except for pennants, banners, inflatable signs
and window signs, if any temporary sign is attached to a wall, such a temporary
sign shall be attached to the wall with wire or steel cables or similar safe
fastening, but in no case shall string, rope or wood slats or other uncertain
fastenings be used to support or anchor the sign to the wall.
      3.   Location: No temporary signs shall be located in or on the public
right of way, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare, nor shall such signs be
located in such a manner as to interfere with the flow of traffic or restrict
the visibility at intersections or driveways.
      4.   Inflatable Signs: Inflatable signs may be erected on top of
structures or on the ground. Inflatable signs erected on the ground shall not
be tethered or otherwise suspended above the ground, but shall be fastened
directly to the ground without any vertical clearance between the inflatable
sign and the ground.
   B.   Duration: Temporary signs shall be allowed for the specified periods
set forth below:
      1.   Inflatable Signs: No inflatable sign shall be permitted on the same
parcel for a period of more than seven (7) consecutive days in any year, nor
for more than a total of thirty five (35) days in any year, with a maximum
height of fifteen feet (15').
      2.   Pennants: No pennants shall be permitted.
      3.   Banners: Banners shall comply with the allowable number and area of
wall signs. All banners shall remain on the location where they are erected or
placed for a period of not more than sixty (60) days, and shall be removed
within five (5) days after the event to which they relate has ended.
      4.   Other Temporary Signs: All other temporary signs, except for
political signs and subject to any other exemptions found in section 6-8-22 of
this chapter, shall remain on the location where they are erected or placed for
a period of not more than sixty (60)days, and shall be removed within five (5)
days after the event to which they relate has ended.
   C.   Permitted Temporary Signs By Type And Zoning District: Temporary signs
shall be allowed in the Village in accordance with the following table:
PERMITTED TEMPORARY SIGNS BY TYPE AND ZONING DISTRICT
Y = Allowed without sign permit.

6-8-3 of this chapter.

Inflatable          Y1                   P                    P      P
Pennants            P1                   P                    P      P
All other temporary P1                   P2                   P2     P2
 
Notes:   1.   No commercial message allowed on sign, except for a commercial
message drawing attention to an activity legally offered on the premises.
2.   A temporary sign over 8 square feet in area shall obtain a permit and
comply with all sections of the sign code.
   D.   Permitted Number And Size Of Temporary Signs By Sign Type: The number
and size of temporary signs shall be allowed in accordance with the following
table:
