(Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-22: MOBILE SIGNS:
   A.   Number Of Days Permitted: No mobile sign shall be permitted to stand at
any address within the Village for a period of more than thirty (30)
consecutive days in any year, nor more than a total of sixty (60) days in any
year. No mobile sign permit shall be issued for consecutive thirty (30) day
periods without at least a period of thirty (30) days intervening.
   B.   Public Right Of Way: No mobile sign shall be permitted to stand upon
any public right of way. All mobile signs shall be placed on private property
only.
   C.   Traffic And Line Of Sight Hazards: All mobile signs shall meet all
Village requirements concerning traffic hazards and line of sight hazards.
   D.   Lights: No mobile sign shall be permitted with lights that flash, blink
or vary in intensity.
   E.   Compliance With Code: All mobile signs shall comply with all applicable
code provisions of the Village, including, but not limited to, the electrical
code provisions where the mobile sign is electrical.
   F.   Name And Address Of Owner: Each mobile sign shall have clearly and
permanently stamped, painted or affixed thereon in a prominent and visible
location, the name and address of the mobile sign's owner.
   G.   Electrical Mobile Signs: When a mobile sign is electrical, the
following regulations, in addition to all other applicable regulations, shall
apply thereto:
      1.   The total length of cord between the source of power and the mobile
sign unit shall be no more than twelve feet (12') in length.
      2.   The source of power shall be a weatherproof receptacle, grounded
type.
      3.   There shall not be any other connector of any kind between the
mobile sign and the source of power.
      4.   In no case shall the cord be in such a position that it will be
walked over by pedestrian traffic or be driven over by any form of wheeled
vehicle.
      5.   No mobile sign shall be operated with any power source unless the
mobile sign unit has a UL label affixed thereto.
      6.   Temporary electrical permits shall be required for electrical mobile
signs.
   H.   Maintenance: All mobile signs shall be maintained in good working order
and in a structurally safe condition, and the immediate area surrounding said
mobile sign shall be kept free from litter and debris.
   I.   Permit: It shall be unlawful for any person to place a mobile sign
within the Village without first having obtained a permit therefor from the
Department of Community Development and Growth Management. The application for
said permit shall be on a form provided by the Department of Community
Development and Growth Management and contain such information as required by
the Department of Community Development and Growth Management.
   J.   Permit Fee: The mobile sign permit fee shall be as set forth in
subsection
6-8-3D of this chapter and shall be in addition to any other permit or
inspection fees required by this code.
   K.   Permit Period: All mobile sign permits shall be valid for a period not
to exceed thirty (30) days and shall set forth thereon the date of issuance and
expiration.
   L.   Penalty Provisions:
      1.   Any person who places a mobile sign upon property within the Village
without first having obtained and kept in full effect a permit as required
above, shall be required to procure a permit for such sign, and shall pay a fee
therefor equal to twice the fee which is otherwise charged hereunder.
      2.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be fined
not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). A separate and distinct offense shall be regarded as having been
committed each day upon which said person shall continue any such violation.
      3.   Any person convicted of violating any of the provisions of this
section, in addition to the penalties provided herein, shall have his permit
revoked.
      4.   When the person responsible for violating the provisions of this
section cannot reasonably be determined, then the person holding the permit to
place the mobile sign at such location shall be the person who is in violation
of this section. In the event that at the time of the violation there exists no
valid permit for the particular mobile sign in violation, then the owner of the
sign shall be the person who is in violation of this section. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-23: EXEMPTIONS FROM PROVISIONS:
   A.   The provisions and regulations of this chapter shall not apply to the
following signs; provided, however, said signs shall be subject to the
provisions of sections
6-8-6 and
6-8-7 of this chapter; and further provided, any exempted permanent or
temporary sign as stated herein exceeding the limitations in the exceptions
shall come under all applicable provisions of this chapter:
      1.   House numbers, house nameplates, and professional nameplates not
exceeding two (2) square feet in area.
      2.   Signs painted on the exterior surface of a building or structure;
provided, however, if said signs have raised borders, letters, characters,
decorations or lighting appliances, they shall be subject to the provisions of
section
6-8-14 of this chapter and all other applicable provisions of this chapter.
Should the painted sign cover more than twenty five percent (25%) of the
subject wall, the sign owner shall petition the Department of Community
Development and Growth Management and upon their approval apply and pay for a
sign permit for said sign.
      3.   Traffic or other municipal signs, legal notices, railroad crossing
signs and danger signs. These signs are defined as governmental signs in
section
6-8-2 of this chapter.
      4.   Holiday decorations, signs or other material displayed in connection
with civic, patriotic or religious holidays.
      5.   Official flags, pennants, or insignia of any governmental or
nonprofit organization.
      6.   A sign advertising the sale or lease of a lot or space on which the
sign is placed. Such signs shall be subject to the public right of way location
restriction set forth in subsection
6-8-20A3 of this chapter, and shall not exceed eight (8) square feet per sign
face in area. Only one such sign may be placed on the lot or premises to which
it pertains, except that two (2) such signs may be placed on double frontage
lots. Such sign shall be removed within five (5) days after the buyer and
seller are mutually bound to conclude/consummate the sale or lease of the lot
or space to which the sign pertains.
      7.   A construction sign identifying the parties involved in the
construction to occur or occurring on the lot or premises on which the sign is
placed. Such signs shall be subject to the public right of way location
restriction set forth in subsection 6-8-20A3 of this chapter and shall not
exceed eight (8) square feet per sign face in area. Such signs may identify the
owner's name, the architect for the project, the contractor or contractors for
the project, the financing arrangements for the project, and/or the purpose for
which the project is intended. No products or services may be advertised on
construction signs. One construction sign may be placed on each part of the lot
or on each face of the building which borders or is oriented to a public
street. A construction sign shall be removed within five (5) days after the
final occupancy certificate is issued relative to the project.
      8.   Political signs displayed in accordance with an official election or
signs erected on behalf of candidates for public office. Such signs shall be
subject to the public right of way location restriction set forth in subsection
6-8-20A3 of this chapter and shall not exceed eight (8) square feet per sign
face in area.
      9.   Historical signs/iconic signs, as defined by the Oak Lawn historical
preservation commission and the office of quality control. [Listed provided by
Village]
      10.   Exempt Lighting. Any and all lighting used for temporary
emergencies to ensure public safety, lighting used for municipal construction,
lighting utilized for flags, lighting for radio, communication, and navigation
towers, and temporary exterior lighting approved by the Village.
   B.   No permit shall be required for normal painting or maintenance. (Ord.
9-13-41)
6-8-24: VIOLATIONS AND PENAL- TIES:
   A.   Any person found to be in violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be subject to a civil penalty of not less than twenty five
dollars ($25.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day
such violation is committed, or permitted to continue, shall constitute a
separate offense and shall be punishable as such hereunder.
   B.   All violations of this chapter shall be processed according to the
provisions of title 11, chapter 12, "Administrative Adjudication Of
Nonvehicular Regulations Violations", of this code.
   C.   The Department of Community Development and Growth Management or its
designee is authorized and directed to enforce the provisions of this chapter
and shall be responsible for interpreting this chapter's provisions. (Ord. 9-
13-41)
6-8-25: AUTOMOBILE "FOR SALE" SIGNS:
The provisions of this section shall govern automobile "for sale" signs.
   A.   Residents or property owners within the Village shall be allowed to
offer automobiles and other motorized vehicles for sale through the use of "for
sale" signs affixed to such vehicles in accordance with the provisions of this
section.
   B.   No more than a total of six (6) motorized vehicles, and no more than
one at a time, shall be permitted to be offered for sale by residents of any
one household or one property address per year.
   C.   Motorized vehicles bearing "for sale" signs shall be displayed on
private driveways only. No motorized vehicle bearing a "for sale" sign may be
displayed on commercial property within the Village without previous permission
of the property owner. Vehicles bearing such signs which are permitted to be
parked in commercial parking lots with the property owner's permission shall
not be displayed in such lots for a period exceeding twelve (12) hours in any
one day. Any such vehicle remaining on a commercial lot for a period in excess
of twelve (12) hours, or displayed on public property within the Village, may
be towed at the discretion of the property owner or the Village, at the expense
of the vehicle owner or of the person leaving the automobile in such location.
   D.   Such signs shall not block or obscure the vision of the driver of the
vehicle and shall not violate any provisions of the Illinois vehicle code.
   E.   All "for sale" signs shall be maintained by the owner of the sign in a
clean, sanitary and inoffensive condition.
   F.   It shall be unlawful for any person to violate the provisions of this
section. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subjected
to a fine not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) and not to exceed one
hundred dollars ($100.00). (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-26: VILLAGE DISTRICTS:
In order to regulate and limit the use of signs on lot areas and buildings, the
Village is hereby divided into four (4) districts, to be used only for the
regulation of signs, as follows:
   A.   Residential: This shall include the districts outlined in section
4-4-1 of this code known as R-1 (single-family residence district), R-2
(limited multi-family residence district), R-3 (multi-family residence
district), PD R-l (planned single-family residence district), PD R-2 (planned
limited multi-family residence district), and PD R-3 (planned multi-family
residence district).
   B.   Commercial: This shall include the districts outlined in section
4-4-1 of this code known as C-1 (general business district), C-2 (general
service district), C-3 (regional shopping district), O (office district), and
PK (parking district).
   C.   Manufacturing: This shall include the districts outlined in section
4-4-1 of this code known as M-l (restricted manufacturing district).
   D.   Public: This shall include the districts outlined in section
4-4-1 of this code known as PL (public lands district). (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-27: PUBLIC CLOCKS:
   A.   As defined by section
6-8-25 of this chapter, public clocks shall be allowed in
"commercial", "manufacturing", and "public" districts. Public clocks shall not
be allowed in "residential" districts.
   B.   Public clocks shall consist of one of two (2) types:
      1.   Circular Clock: A clock which consists of a flat panel covering an
electric motor, which powers a minute and hour hand. A second hand is allowed
but not required. The panel covering the motor shall have suitable circular
markings to denote its function as a twelve (12) hour clock.
      2.   Digital Clock: A clock comprised of electronic lights arranged in
such a pattern as to form numbers which display the current time. This type of
clock shall operate on a standard twelve (12) hour length. Both hour and minute
times must be shown; a blinking colon between hour and minute times, used to
show the progressing seconds, is allowed but not required. A digital clock
shall have no physical moving parts.
   C.   Any public clock found to be displaying an inaccurate time shall be
considered nonconforming, and have its owner notified of its discrepancy and be
given a fifteen (15) day repair period to correct the problem and restore the
clock to displaying the accurate time. The benchmark standard for accurate
Central Standard Time used is the National Institute Of Standards And
Technology (NIST). Correct time shall be defined as being within seven (7)
minutes of the NIST Central Standard Time. If the clock is not set to the
correct time following this fifteen (15) day period, the Village shall impose a
fifty dollar ($50.00) fine on the owner of the sign per every seven (7) days
which the clock continues to display the incorrect time.
   D.   All public clock owners shall be granted automatic fifteen (15) day
repair periods starting on the Monday after the second Sunday in March, and the
Monday following the first Sunday in November. These automatic fifteen (15) day
repair periods shall be granted to allow for the readjustment of their clock's
time in compliance with daylight savings time. If the necessary adjustments are
not made within this automatic repair period, the fine policy defined in
subsection D of this section will apply. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-28: ANIMATED SIGNS:
   A.   Animated signs shall be allowed in "commercial" districts, as defined
in section
6-8-25 of this chapter.
   B.   All rules of section
6-8-11. "Illuminated Signs", of this chapter also apply to animated signs.
   C.   Animated signs shall not be constructed and/or programmed in such a
manner in which causes them to be distracting motorists or pedestrians, putting
them at risk. Any degree of distraction shall be determined at a Village of Oak
Lawn code enforcer's discretion.
   D.   Animated signs shall only be permitted as accessories to other signs.
The animated portion of the sign shall not take up more than thirty percent
(30%) of the total square footage on one face of the sign. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-29: WINDOW SIGNS:
   A.   Window signs shall be allowed in "commercial" and "public" districts,
as defined in section §
6-8-25 of this chapter.
   B.   Window signs shall consist of waterproof fade resistant material
attached to the inside of a window, or a physical display of items which
extends inward to a horizontal depth of three feet (3') measured from the
inside of the window.
   C.   In situations where it is desirable to completely blank out a window as
to prevent light from coming through, occupants of the building or unit shall
be allowed two (2) options:
      1.   The glass shall be replaced with a nontransparent flat panel which
has similar structural characteristics as glass and does not require painting
as a regular maintenance task. This panel shall be colored in such a way as to
blend in with the colors of the building itself. Such a panel will thereafter
not be considered a window sign.
      2.   The interior of the glass shall be used to display tasteful artwork
in such a way which may promote the business as well as promote artistic
expression. The artwork may only be composed on the interior of the glass after
it has been checked for cracks, and may only consist of those materials which
are waterproof and fade resistant.
   D.   A window sign shall be considered nonconforming under the following
criteria:
      1.   The items or material used for the window sign become faded or show
signs of water damage.
      2.   The window itself becomes broken or cracked.
      3.   Signs of obvious neglect begin to show. This includes, but is not
limited to, the collection of dust, dirt, or other debris in the area
immediately inside the window.
      4.   If the window sign is not being used to blank out the entire window,
the sign takes up more than forty percent (40%) of the total square footage of
glass on the front of the unit. This nonconformance regulation shall only be
applied to those signs which are applied directly to the window or sit within
six inches (6") of the interior edge of the pane of glass. Window displays
shall be exempt.
In addition, a window without a window sign which remains undecorated with a
nondecorative, strictly functional item or item(s) directly behind the glass
shall be considered a nonconforming window sign until the installation of
either blank out option defined.
   E.   Illumination: It shall be prohibited to place marquee lighting on any
window sign or building structure, including but not limited to windows, doors,
parapet, exterior walls, support beams, roofs and balconies. (Ord. 9-13-41)
6-8-30: PORTABLE SIDEWALK SIGNS:
   A.   Commercial Districts: Portable sidewalk signs shall be allowed in
"commercial" districts, as defined in section 6-8-25 of this chapter.
   B.   Size: Portable sidewalk signs shall be no greater than six (6) square
feet in area and not exceed four feet (4') in height.
   C.   Number: No more than one sign shall be permitted per business customer
entrance. The Village reserves the right to limit the number of portable
sidewalk sign permits issued to ensure the proper flow of pedestrian and
vehicular traffic, and otherwise to protect the public health, safety, and
welfare. In that event, permits shall be processed and issued on a first come,
first serve basis.
   D.   Display: All portable sidewalk signs shall be removed:
      1.   When the business is not open for customers.
      2.   When the national weather service issues a high wind warning, a
tornado or severe thunderstorm watch or warning.
      3.   From public sidewalks during an accumulation snowfall event.
   E.   Permitted Locations: All portable sidewalk signs shall be located:
      1.   At grade level.
      2.   In front of the business property.
      3.   No more than fifteen feet (15') from the customer entrance to the
building for the business being advertised.
      4.   A minimum of two feet (2') back from the curb adjacent to parking
spaces.
   F.   Prohibited Locations: No portable sidewalk sign shall be located:
      1.   In landscaped areas or the parkway.
      2.   In parking aisles or stalls.
      3.   On or anchored to fences, planters, other signs, vehicles, utility
facilities or any structure.
      4.   In streets or alleys.
      5.   Within the Illinois department of transportation right of way.
   G.   Right Of Way Placement: Signs may be placed on a Village owned
sidewalk:
      1.   Pursuant to the issuance of an annual Village of Oak Lawn portable
sidewalk sign permit.
      2.   Subject to all requirements for insurance and indemnification as
provided below.
   H.   Construction And Maintenance: Signs shall be:
      1.   Constructed of exterior grade, rigid, weather resistant and durable
materials,
      2.   Of sufficient weight and durability to ensure the sign remains in
place during normal weather conditions, and
      3.   Maintained in a professional manner free of chipping paint, cracks,
gouges, loss of letters, and similar defects.
   I.   Elements Prohibited On Portable Sidewalk Signs: The following shall be
prohibited on portable signs:
      1.   Any form of internal or external illumination, including flashing,
blinking, or rotating lights;
      2.   Animation;
      3.   Attachments, including, but not limited to, sandbags or other items
to hold a sign in place, balloons, ribbons, flags, speakers, other copy or
graphics.
   J.   Clearance For Pedestrians: A clear pedestrian access path shall be
maintained as follows:
      1.   Public Sidewalks: A minimum of four feet (4').
      2.   Private Walkways: A minimum of three feet (3').
   K.   Insurance: The applicant for a portable sidewalk sign permit shall
provide, at its sole cost and expense, and shall thereafter maintain in effect
during the entire period of the permit, insurance in the following manner:
      1.   Comprehensive general liability insurance, including owner's
protective liability insurance and contractual liability insurance covering
claims for personal injury and property damage with limits of at least one
million dollars ($1,000,000.00) per occurrence and two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) aggregate;
      2.   Prior to issuance of a portable sidewalk sign permit, the applicant
shall provide the Village with copies of the certificates of insurance for the
required policies for each type of insurance naming the Village of Oak Lawn as
an additional insured party.
   L.   Indemnification: The permittee shall indemnify, defend, protect, and
hold harmless the Village, its corporate authorities, officers, employees,
agents and volunteers from and against any and all claims, demands, losses,
damages, liabilities, fines, charges, penalties, administrative and judicial
proceedings and orders, judgments, remedial actions of any kind, all costs and
cleanup actions of any kind, and all costs and expenses incurred in connection
therewith, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney fees, expert
witness fees and costs of defenses (collectively, the "losses") directly or
proximately resulting from permittee's acts or omissions, except to the extent
that the Village is the sole legal cause of said losses. (Ord. 9-13-41)
CHAPTER 9
DANGEROUS AND ABANDONED BUILDINGS OR STRUCTURES
SECTION:
6-9-1: Definitions
6-9-2: Nuisance Declared
6-9-3: Action by Village Officials
6-9-4: Authority to Close Building, Suspend or Revoke License
6-9-5: Costs to Owner
6-9-6: Occupying Unsanitary Building
6-9-7: Abatement
6-9-8: Court Proceedings
6-9-9: Alternative Actions
6-9-1: DEFINITIONS:
As used in this Chapter, the following words and terms shall have the meanings
prescribed herein:
ABANDONED BUILDING or STRUCTURE:
   A.   Any vacant building which is frequented by persons who are not lawful
occupants of such structure; or
   B.   Any vacant building which, by reason of lack of maintenance, or by
reason of the boarding up of its doors and windows, or other reasons, has a
substantial adverse effect on the value of the property in the immediate
neighborhood; or
   C.   A building or structure, the principal use of which has been abandoned,
and that no longer has any function or use; or
   D.   Any railroad trestle or siding no longer in use.
BUILDING or STRUCTURE: Includes anything constructed or erected, the use of
which requires permanent or temporary location on or in the ground including,
but not limited to, buildings of all types and use groups, advertising signs,
billboards, swimming pools, sheds, garages, fences or any other manmade
structure.
DANGEROUS BUILDING or STRUCTURE:
   A.   Any building or structure which is dangerous to the public health or
safety because of its construction or condition, or which may cause or aid in
the spread of disease or which may become a harborage for rodents or other
animals, or which may cause injury to the occupants thereof or of a neighboring
building or structure; or
   B.   Any building or structure which, because of faulty construction, age,
lack of proper repair or any other cause, constitutes or creates a fire hazard;
or
   C.   Any building or structure, which, by reason of faulty construction, age
or lack of repair is likely to collapse or fall, in whole or in part; or
   D.   Any building or structure which has been damaged by fire, wind or other
causes so as to have become dangerous to life, safety, morals or the general
health and welfare of the occupants or the people of the Village; or
   E.   Any building which has become or is so dilapidated, decayed, unsafe,
unsanitary or which so utterly fails to provide the amenities essential to
decent living that it is unfit for human habitation, or is likely to cause
sickness or disease so as to work injury to the health, morals, safety or
general welfare of those living therein; or
   F.   Any building or structure which has parts thereof which are so attached
that they may fall or injure members of the public or property; or
   G.   Any building or structure which because of its condition is unsafe,
unsanitary or dangerous to the health, morals, safety or general welfare of the
people of this Village; or
   H.   Any building or structure existing in violation of any provision of the
Building Code of this Village 1  or any provision of the Fire Prevention Code
or other ordinances of this Village 2 . (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ord. 77-6-
5)
 
Notes
1 1. See Chapter 1 of this Title.
2 2. See Title 7, Chapter 3 of this Code.
6-9-2: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any dangerous or abandoned building or structure, as defined by Section
6-9-1 of this Chapter, within the Village is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ord. 77-6-5)
6-9-3: ACTION BY VILLAGE OFFICIALS:
   A.   Notice: Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the Director of
Office of Quality Control, the Chief Building Inspector or to the Health and
Sanitation Officer that a building or structure is in a dangerous or abandoned
condition, such officer shall affix a notice on the building or structure, in a
conspicuous place on the exterior wall thereof, informing all persons to keep
out of said building. Any person removing, defacing or disturbing such notice
as affixed shall be liable to the penalties provided for in this Code.
   B.   Evacuation of Building: Whenever it shall come to the knowledge of the
Director of Office of Quality Control, the Chief Building Inspector or to the
Health and Sanitation Officer that a dangerous building exists with structural
faults that may cause the imminent collapse of the said building, or if any
building is in such condition as to make it dangerous to the health, morals,
safety or general welfare of its occupants, or that other conditions exist of
an emergency nature which may cause the death or injury of the occupants
thereof, such officer shall order the immediate evacuation of the occupants
from any such building.
   C.   Emergency Repair, Vacation or Demolition: In cases where it reasonably
appears that there is immediate danger to the life or safety of any person,
unless a "dangerous building or structure", as defined herein, is immediately
repaired, vacated or demolished, the Director of Office of Quality Control
shall cause the immediate repair, vacation or demolition of such dangerous
building or structure. The costs of such emergency repair, vacation or
demolition shall be collected in the same manner as provided in Section
6-9-8 of this Chapter. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ords. 77-6-5, 81-12-19; 1985
Code)
6-9-4: AUTHORITY TO CLOSE BUILDING, SUSPEND OR REVOKE LICENSE:
   A.   The Director of Office of Quality Control, the Chief Building Inspector
or Health and Sanitation Officer may order that no person shall be permitted to
enter, occupy or use a dangerous building or structure or any portion thereof
until the same shall have been made safe and habitable, and may post such order
in a conspicuous place on the exterior of such building or structure. No person
shall enter, occupy or use (except for the purpose of repairing and making
safe) any building or structure, or portion thereof, after the posting of such
notice until such building or structure or portion thereof shall have been made
safe and habitable.
   B.   If any building or structure or portion thereof which is dangerous or
abandoned shall be devoted to any purpose requiring a license, the President
may suspend such license pending the making of repairs and he may revoke such
license if the owner or person having an interest in such unsafe or abandoned
building or structure or portion thereof fails to make the same safe
immediately and at his own expense. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ords. 77-6-5,
81-12-19; 1985 Code)
6-9-5: COSTS TO OWNER:
If work has been done and expense incurred by the Village in connection with
the repair or demolition of any dangerous building or structure as provided
herein, a bill for such expense shall be rendered by the Village to the owner,
lessee, occupant or agent of the property. The Village may refuse to issue a
permit for the reconstruction, alteration or repair of any such building or
portion thereof until the expenditures incurred by the Village on account of
such repairs or demolition have been repaid. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ord.
77-6-5)
6-9-6: OCCUPYING UNSANITARY BUILDING:
It shall be unlawful to occupy for human habitation any building which is
declared by the Health and Sanitation Officer to be unfit for such habitation
by reason of defective sanitary conditions until such conditions have been
remedied and the premises approved by such Health and Sanitation Officer as fit
for occupancy. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ord. 77-6-5; 1985 Code)
6-9-7: ABATEMENT:
   A.   The Director of Office of Quality Control, the Chief Building Inspector
or the Health and Sanitation Officer may, prior to the action of the Board of
Trustees authorized in Section
6-9-8 hereof, give written notice to the owner or owner's agent of a dangerous
or abandoned building or structure, as defined herein, to repair or demolish it
within fifteen (15) days. Where, upon diligent search, the identity or
whereabouts of the owner or owner's agent of any building or structure is not
ascertainable, notice mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real
estate was last assessed is sufficient notice under this Section.
   B.   If, at the end of no less than fifteen (15) days and no more than
thirty (30) days from the date of the aforesaid written notice, the owner or
owner's agent has failed to take positive action to put such building or
structure in a satisfactory condition or to demolish it, the Director of Office
of Quality Control shall notify the Village Manager of such failure, and the
Village Manager shall advise the President and Board of Trustees that a
dangerous or abandoned building or structure exists and that no action has been
taken by the owner or owner's agent after written notice to repair or demolish
it. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ords. 77-6-5, 81-12-19; 1985 Code)
6-9-8: COURT PROCEEDINGS:
After notification to the President and Board of Trustees by the Village
Manager that no action is being taken to demolish or repair a dangerous or
abandoned building or structure, the President and Board of Trustees may
authorize the Village Attorney to apply to the Circuit Court of Cook County for
an order authorizing the demolition or repair of a dangerous or abandoned
building or structure, as defined herein, if the owners thereof, including the
lien holders of record after at least fifteen (15) days' written notice by mail
to do so, have failed to put such building or structure in a satisfactory
condition or to demolish it. It is not a defense to such cause of action that
the building is boarded up or otherwise enclosed. Where, upon diligent search,
the identity or whereabouts of the owner or owners of any such building or
structure, including the lien holders of record, is not ascertainable, notice
mailed to the person or persons in whose name such real estate was last
assessed is sufficient notice under this Section. The cost of such demolition
or repair incurred by the Village or by a lien holder of record is recoverable
from the owner or owners of such real estate and is a lien thereon, which lien
is superior to all prior existing liens and encumbrances, except taxes;
provided that, within sixty (60) days after such repair or demolition, the
Village or the lien holder of record who incurred such cost and expense shall
file notice of lien of such cost and expense incurred in the office of the
Recorder of Deeds of Cook County or in the office of the Registrar of Titles of
such County, if the real estate affected is registered under the Torrens
system. The notice must consist of a sworn statement setting out:
   A.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof;
   B.   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred; and
   C.   The date or dates when the cost and expense was incurred by the Village
or by the lien holder of record.
Upon payment of the cost and expense by the owner of or persons interested in
the property after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released by
the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and the release
may be filed of record as in the case of filing notice of lien. The lien may be
enforced by proceedings to foreclose as in case of mortgage or mechanic's lien.
Suit to foreclose this lien must be commenced within three (3) years after the
date of filing notice of lien. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-5-8; Ord. 77-6-5)
6-9-9: ALTERNATIVE ACTIONS:
In addition to the other remedies provided for here- in, the Village may
proceed in accordance with the provisions of chapter 24, sections 11-31-1 or
11-31-2 of the Illinois Revised Statutes, or may pursue any other remedy
provided by law. (1951 Code 21-15-1-21-15-8; Ord. 77-6-5)
CHAPTER 10
MOVING BUILDINGS
SECTION:
6-10-1: Permit Requirements
6-10-2: Lights Required
6-10-3: Prohibited Acts and Conditions
6-10-4: Compliance With Other Provisions
6-10-1: PERMIT REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Permit Required: No building shall be moved on or across any public
street, walk, alley or other public place within the Village by any person,
except upon a permit duly issued by the Village.
   B.   Fee 1 : Before the issuance of such permit, the applicant shall pay to
the Village a sum of money in payment for the occupancy of the street or
streets through which the said building is proposed to be moved, and said sum
to be determined by estimating the number of days which will be required to
move said building, on the assumption that the building will be moved five
hundred feet (500') per day, at the rate of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day.
   C.   Bond: In addition to the payment for street occupancy, there shall be
furnished a bond in the sum of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) with good and
sufficient sureties to be approved by the President, conditioned, among other
things that said party will pay any and all damage that may occur to any public
street, alley or public place over which said building may be moved, and to
reimburse the Village and any public utility company for the cost of removing
and replacing all overhead wires, cables and appurtenances and for the making
of the necessary repairs thereto.
   D.   Liability Insurance: Before any person, to whom a permit has been
issued under this Chapter, shall enter upon the moving of any building
authorized to be moved by the permit, he shall obtain from some reliable
insurance company, policies of liability insurance indemnifying the Village and
public for any damage or injury resulting to any of the workmen or employees of
such person engaged in the moving of such building, and also indemnifying the
Village and public for any damages or injury suffered by any other person
resulting from the moving of such building.
   E.   Issuance of Permit: If, upon consideration of such application and such
inspection as the Director of Office of Quality Control may deem necessary, it
shall appear to the Director that the work proposed to be done is in accordance
with this Code and the ordinances of the Village, the Director, upon the
payment to the Village of the fees and bond herein provided for, shall grant
the permit sought for such purpose. (1951 Code 21-13-1, 21-13-5; Ord. 81-12-19;
1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-1-7 of this Code for license fee.
6-10-2: LIGHTS REQUIRED:
On each and every night while a building remains on the public streets or
alleys of the Village, from dusk to sunrise, the person to whom the permit was
issued shall place and cause to be maintained at the center and each end of
such building, red lights, which lights shall be plainly visible during the
period above mentioned. (1951 Code 21-13-3)
6-10-3: PROHIBITED ACTS AND CONDITIONS:
   A.   Driving Stakes in Pavements or Railroad Crossings: It shall be unlawful
for any person to whom a permit has been issued under this Chapter, to drive
stakes in any pavement, public alley or at any railroad or railway crossing.
   B.   Obstructing Intersections, Railroad Crossings: No building which is
authorized to be moved in accordance with the terms of this Chapter shall be
permitted to stand or remain in the intersection of any streets, or any street
and public alley, or upon any railroad or railway crossing at any time during
the course of its moving. (1951 Code 21-13-2, 21-13-4)
6-10-4: COMPLIANCE WITH OTHER PROVISIONS:
No permit to move any building within the Village shall be granted unless the
construction and proposed use of such building on the proposed new site shall
conform in every way to requirements of this Title and of the Zoning Ordinance.
1  (1951 Code 21-13-1)
 
Notes
1 1. See Title 4 of this Municipal Code.
CHAPTER 11
FENCES
SECTION:
6-11-1: Definition
6-11-2: Permit Required; Fee
6-11-3: Design And Construction Regulations
6-11-4: Cost Of Construction
6-11-5: Fencing For Construction And Demolition Activity
6-11-6: Fence Variations
6-11-7: Penalty
6-11-1: DEFINITION:
A "fence" is hereby defined as a manmade structure forming a barrier which is
not a part of any building or structure, and is more than two feet (2') in
height over existing grade. (1985 Code)
6-11-2: PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE:
It shall be unlawful for any person to erect or construct any fence within the
village limits without having first obtained a permit from the director of the
office of quality control. The fee for said permit shall be thirty dollars
($30.00). (Ords. 87-9-32, 94-4-13, 05-23-86)
6-11-3: DESIGN AND CONSTRUCTION REGULATIONS:
   A.   General: Every fence shall be designed and constructed to resist a
horizontal wind pressure of not less than twice that required for buildings, as
set forth in the building code. Where the distance from the lot line to the
face of any fence is less than the height of the fence, such fence shall have
lateral supports on one side with structural braces extending to the top of the
fence.
Where the style of the fence is such that the fence posts and support pieces
between fence posts are located only on one side of the fence, the fence shall
be constructed such that the side of the fence with the fence posts and support
pieces faces the interior of the fence owner's property (facing away from
streets, alleys and neighboring properties).
   B.   Residential Requirements:
      1.   The maximum fence height in a residential use district shall not
exceed six feet (6') between buildings or in the rear yard behind the building.
All height dimensions shall be measured from the established grade to the
topmost section of the fence.
      2.   No fence shall be built, constructed or erected so as to extend past
the front yard building line as established by the zoning ordinance 1 ; nor
shall any fence be built past the side street yard on a corner lot as
established by the zoning ordinance. No fence shall be erected in any public
right of way.
No fence shall be built, constructed or erected in any easement except wherein
a release is given to the village prior thereto, absolving the village from all
liability and damages resulting from subsequent entry for the purpose of
repair, inspection, maintenance, installation or removal of utilities. Any
fence allowed or permitted in an easement shall be so constructed that the
fence and posts may be readily removable. The village shall in no way be held
liable for the replacement of any fence removed, or any other expense entailed
by the removal or reerection of any fence in said easement.
      3.   A gate or opening shall be provided in all fence enclosures.
      4.   Any suitable construction material may be used for a fence, except
chicken wire, square welded mesh wire, barbed wire, electrically charged wire,
temporary snow fence, or solid concrete block; or be topped with sharp edged
material, except that this shall not be construed to prohibit picket fences.
The entire length of the fence shall be constructed of the same or harmonious
materials.
   C.   Commercial, Office Or Manufacturing Zoning District Requirements:
      1.   The maximum height of any fence in any commercial, office or
manufacturing use district shall not exceed six feet (6') in height.
      2.   No fence shall be built, constructed or erected so as to extend past
the front yard building line as established by the zoning ordinance 2 , nor
shall any fence be built past the side street yard on a corner lot as
established by the zoning ordinance. No fence shall be erected in any public
right of way. Fence construction shall be such that it provides a clear and
unobstructed view from the building line to the property line. A clear and
unobstructed view shall be construed to mean that at least 90 percent of any
object on the opposite side of the fence shall be clearly visible at all times.
No fence shall be built, constructed or erected in any utility easement, except
wherein a release is given to the village prior thereto, absolving the village
from all liability and damages resulting from subsequent entry for the purpose
of repair, inspection, maintenance, installation or removal of utilities. Any
fence allowed or permitted in an easement shall be so constructed that the
fence and posts may be readily removable. The village shall in no way be held
liable for the replacement of any fence removed, or any other expense entailed
by the removal or reerection of any fence in said easement.
      3.   Any suitable construction material may be used for a fence, except
chicken wire, square welded mesh wire, electrically charged wire, or temporary
snow fence; or be topped with sharp edged material, except that this shall not
be construed to prohibit picket fences.
      4.   Barbed wire may be used in commercial, office or manufacturing
zoning districts, provided that such barbed wire can only be constructed above
a minimum height of seven feet (7') from the established grade, and further
provided that such barbed wire shall be turned to the inside of the property
where so erected, and that no barbed wire shall be permitted closer than five
feet (5') from any public street, sidewalk, alley, park or public right of way
or public place. The entire length of the fence shall be constructed of the
same or harmonious materials. (1951 Code; Ords. 21-16-2, 21-16-3; 1985 Code;
Ords. 89-21-64, 89-21-66; 21-14-70)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 4 of this code.
2 1. See title 4 of this code.
6-11-4: COST OF CONSTRUCTION:
In case of dispute over the cost of erecting a division fence by adjoining
landowners, such dispute shall be settled according to the provisions of 765
Illinois Compiled Statutes 130/0.01 et seq. (1969 Code 6-163)
6-11-5: FENCING FOR CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION ACTIVITY:
   A.   When a permit is issued by the village authorizing the demolition of an
existing building or construction of a new building, then the applicant for
said permit shall, prior to commencing any work pursuant to said permit, erect
a chainlink fence on the subject property, of not less than six feet (6') in
height, around either:
      1.   The perimeter of the building being demolished;
      2.   The perimeter of the building under construction; or
      3.   The perimeter of the entire subdivision or work site in relation to
which the permit has been issued.
The fence shall be installed not more than seven (7) days prior to the
commencement of any construction or demolition work on the subject property,
pursuant to the permit issued by the village. Said fence shall remain in place
until such time as the village's department of quality control has confirmed
that the building, or addition thereto, is secure from unpermitted entry
thereto (i.e., all doors and windows have been installed and can be locked) or,
in the case of demolition activity, until such time as all demolition debris
has been removed and any hole left by said demolition has been properly filled.
   B.   Any gate in a fence installed pursuant to subsection A of this section
must be closed at all times except to allow ingress and egress to and from the
work site. Said gate must be locked at all times other than when construction
or demolition activity is taking place on the work site.
   C.   Fencing, as required by subsection A of this section, shall also be
required for any building construction or demolition project of the village,
the Oak Lawn park district, any school district or any other governmental
entity, whether or not a permit has been or is required to be issued by the
village relative to said construction or demolition project.
   D.   When the building/demolition permit applicant, general contractor or
property owner is notified of a violation of the provisions of this section,
said person so notified shall have two (2) hours from receipt of said notice to
correct the violation. If the violation is not corrected, the village shall
have the right, but not the obligation, to correct the violation. The costs and
fees associated with such corrective action shall be charged to the building/
demolition permit applicant, general contractor or property owner, as the case
may be. The village shall also have the right to issue an immediate "stop work"
order applicable to the work site until compliance is achieved and/or the
costs, fees and/or fines are paid.
   E.   Any person who violates any of the provisions of this section shall be
fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day such violation continues shall constitute a
separate and distinct offense.
   F.   In addition to the penalty set forth in subsection E of this section,
no certificate of occupancy shall be issued relative to the construction in
question until such time that all costs incurred by the village under
subsection D of this section, and all fines imposed pursuant to subsection E of
this section, have been paid in full. (Ords. 00-19-61, 07-21-60)
6-11-6: FENCE VARIATIONS:
   A.   The following actions may be taken administratively by the director of
quality control upon petition of a property owner:
      1.   To grant a variation to subsection 6-11-3B2 of this chapter to allow
a fence to be built to the side property line on the side yard of a corner lot;
and
      2.   To grant a variation to subsection 6-11-3B4 of this chapter to allow
fence material to be used on a property to match surrounding fence material or
to use different fence material in a rear yard from that used in a front yard.
Such administrative variations shall be granted if deemed to be reasonable
requests by petitioner. An appeal of any decision made by the director of
quality control under this provision may be made to the Appeals and Review
Board under the provisions of title 2, chapter 2 of this code.
   B.   A variation from the fence height limitations of this chapter may be
applied for and granted; provided, that a finding is made as to each of the
following conditions:
      1.   That the plight of the petitioner for the variation is caused by
unique circumstances; and
      2.   That the variation, if granted, will not alter the essential
character of the immediate surrounding area; and
      3.   That a fence, in full compliance with the maximum height limitations
of this chapter, would not adequately serve the same purposes as a fence of
increased height; and
      4.   That strict adherence to the fence height limitation requirements of
this chapter would cause particular hardship upon the petitioner for the
variation.
All requests for the aforementioned variation shall be heard by the Appeals and
Review Board pursuant to subsection
2-2-2C9 of this code.
   C.   A variation from the fence location limitations of this chapter may be
applied for and granted by the Appeals and Review Board; provided, that a
finding is made as to each of the following conditions:
      1.   That the plight of the petitioner for the variation is caused by
unique circumstances; and
      2.   That the variation, if granted, will not alter the essential
character of the immediate surrounding area; and
      3.   That strict adherence to the fence location limitation requirements
of this chapter would cause particular hardship upon the petitioner for the
variation. (Ords. 93-14-53, 98-20-92, 07-05-17, 19-16-65)
6-11-7: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
of not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars
($750.00). (1985 Code; Ord. 99-5-11)
CHAPTER 12
SWIMMING POOLS
SECTION:
6-12-1: Permit Required, Compliance With Building Code
6-12-2: Approval Of Plans And Specifications
6-12-3: Fences Required
6-12-4: Electrical Requirements
6-12-5: Maintenance And Inspections
6-12-1: PERMIT REQUIRED, COMPLIANCE WITH BUILDING CODE:
   A.   A permanently constructed pool shall require a permit from the building
department and the construction of said pool shall conform with the building
code 1  of the village.
   B.   All pools, whether above or below ground, shall require an electrical
permit from the electrical inspection department. The fee for said permit shall
be as set forth in chapter 2, article A of this title.
   C.   All pools, whether above or below ground, shall require a swimming pool
inspection permit from the electrical inspection department. Said swimming pool
inspection permit shall not require a fee. (Ord. 84-13-34)
 
Notes
1 1. See chapter 1 of this title.
6-12-2: APPROVAL OF PLANS AND SPECIFICATIONS:
No swimming pools shall be constructed unless and until the plans and
specifications for the same are submitted to and approval by the director of
office of quality control of the village.
The plans and specifications for a swimming pool shall provide for an adequate
enclosure by proper fencing or other means as a safety measure. (1951 Code 21-
17-1; Ords. 170, 81-12-19)
6-12-3: FENCES REQUIRED:
   A.   Permanent Pools: All permanently constructed swimming pools shall be
protected by a fenced enclosure as required for residential use, with a height
of not less than six feet (6') and shall be equipped with a self-closing gate
and a latch four and one-half feet (41/2') over grade. For the purposes of this
section, permanent swimming pools shall be defined as inground pools and
swimming pools with metal or solid structural material frames.
   B.   Temporary Pools: All temporary, portable, sectional construction,
aboveground or nonpermanent pools shall be protected by a fenced enclosure as
required for residential use, with a height of not less than four feet (4') and
shall be equipped with a self-latching gate. For the purposes of this section,
temporary swimming pools shall be defined as those swimming pools that do not
have solid, rigid structures, including those with inflated or vinyl sides with
PVC or metal tubing.
   C.   Exception: Fences are not required for swimming pools below twenty four
inches (24") in height. (Ord. 10-23-52)
6-12-4: ELECTRICAL REQUIREMENTS:
The following electrical requirements shall apply to swimming pools:
   A.   Location Of Conductors: No electrical service conductors shall be
installed above the swimming pool or within an area surrounding the pool for a
distance of ten feet (10') horizontally measured from its perimeter, including
diving structures, observation stands, decks, towers or platforms.
   B.   Conduit: Galvanized rigid conduit shall extend from a pool outlet box
to a distance of fifteen feet (15') from the pool, and shall be pitched down to
provide drainage.
   C.   Outlet Boxes: Outlet boxes shall be cast type with threaded hubs.
   D.   Threaded Connections: Threaded connections shall be made at boxes and
couplings within fifteen feet (15') of any pool outlet box (pressure connectors
are not acceptable).
   E.   Conductors: Conductors shall be approved for wet locations.
   F.   Fixtures:
      1.   Fixtures shall be Underwriters Laboratory approved for submersible
use when installed within the pool.
      2.   Fixtures shall be approved for wet locations when installed closely
adjacent to the pool.
      3.   Each fixture shall be grounded by means of a grounding conductor
which shall extend from the source (cut out cabinet or distribution cabinet) to
each fixture. All rails and diving boards shall be grounded.
   G.   Submersible Lighting: Submersible lighting for swimming pools,
reflector pools and display fountains shall be grounded by the following:
      1.   The voltage shall not exceed twelve (12) volts.
      2.   Step down transformers shall be used in conjunction with the
lighting and shall be remotely located from the units they supply. Overcurrent
protection shall be provided for both the primary and secondary windings.
      3.   A main disconnect shall be installed on the primary feed to the
transformer, also the transformer shall be properly grounded. (Ords. 66-23-62,
84-13-34)
6-12-5: MAINTENANCE AND INSPECTIONS:
   A.   All swimming pools shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary
condition by either filtering or refilling at periodic intervals and all
equipment shall be maintained in a satisfactory operating condition. Any
swimming pool that does not have a filtration system shall be emptied weekly.
   B.   The water shall be maintained in a proper condition through the use of
an appropriate chemical treatment.
   C.   All pools shall be subject to inspection by the duly designated village
officials at such times as the village shall deem necessary and prudent. (Ord.
10-23-52)
CHAPTER 13
SOUND CONTROL
SECTION:
6-13-1: Definitions
6-13-2: Standards Adopted
6-13-3: Sound Control Regulations
6-13-1: DEFINITIONS:
The following definitions shall be used in applying the provisions of this
Chapter:
APPROVED SOUND LABORATORY: A sound laboratory which conforms to all ASTM
requirements for facilities, staffing and testing procedures using ASTM
standards and is approved by the Village.
DETACHED SINGLE-FAMILY DWELLING: Any single-family dwelling which is separated
from adjacent buildings by six feet (6') or more.
FLANKING SOUND: Sound which is transmitted into a dwelling unit from other
dwelling units or common areas within the building by paths other than directly
through the rated partition of floor- ceiling assembly except from the outside
exterior wall of the dwelling unit.
IMPACT INSULATION CLASS (IIC): A single figure rating for floor-ceiling
constructions which has been determined by tests conducted in an approved sound
laboratory according to ASTM E492-73T.
SOUND TRANSMISSION CLASS (STC): A single figure rating for floor-ceiling and
interior partition construction which has been determined by tests conducted in
an approved sound laboratory according to ASTM E90-70 and as defined by ASTM
E413-73. (Ord. 75-27-105)
6-13-2: STANDARDS ADOPTED:
The following standards are hereby adopted by reference, three (3) copies of
which shall be and remain on file in the office of the Clerk, and shall be used
in applying the provisions of this Chapter:
   A.   ASTM E 90-70, "Laboratory Measurement of Airborne Sound Transmission
Loss of Building Partitions".
   B.   ASTM E336-71, "Measurement of Airborne Sound Insulation in Buildings".
   C.   ASTM E413-73, "Determination of Sound Transmission Class".
   D.   ASTM E492-73T, "Laboratory Measurement of Impact Sound Transmission
Through Floor- Ceiling Assemblies Using the Tapping Machine".
   E.   ASTM E497-73T, "Installation of Fixed Partitions of Light Frame Type
for the Purpose of Conserving Their Sound Insulation Efficiency". (Ord. 75-27-
105; 1985 Code)
6-13-3: SOUND CONTROL REGULATIONS:
The following sound control provisions shall apply for partitions and floor-
ceiling assemblies between dwelling units:
   A.   General: In buildings where persons may be residents, permanently or
temporarily, airborne sound control for partition assemblies, and airborne and
impact sound control for floor-ceiling assemblies shall be provided, where
these assemblies separate dwelling units, efficiency dwelling units, light
housekeeping rooms, guest and patient rooms, or similar residential uses, from
each other and between all such residential units and other common use spaces,
such as interior public corridors, stairwells, lobbies, service areas, garages,
commercial areas and all building mechanical equipment rooms or systems.
   B.   Partitions: Partition and wall assemblies shall have a minimum sound
transmission class of not less than fifty (50) (STC-50). Partition and wall
assemblies which have been tested and rated by an approved sound testing
laboratory shall be considered as meeting the requirement of this Section
providing that the assembly is not compromised by penetrations or flanking
sound transmission (ASTM E 497-73T) in field construction.
Penetrations of partitions and walls shall be limited to the following and
shall be protected as provided.
      1.   Entrance doors from interior corridor, provided the door and/or jam
is equipped with a perimeter seal and the doorway has a sealed threshold. The
door shall be at least a one and three-quarter inch (13/4") solid core door.
      2.   Required electrical outlet boxes and bathroom cabinets, provided
they are installed in accordance with the recommendations of ASTM E497-73T or
are installed and separated (not back to back) in a manner that will not result
in lowering the required STC rating of the partition.
      3.   Ventilation/exhaust ducts in the corridor partition or common to
more than one residential unit in party walls, provided the ducts are lined,
insulated, located or specially designed to maintain the required STC partition
rating.
      4.   The installation of bathtubs against metal or wood framed separation
partitions is not permitted unless the water-resistant wallboard is extended
behind each tub as recommended in ASTM E497-73T.
      5.   All joints at the perimeter of separation partitions and at the
perimeter of penetration openings, which are not sealed, shall be sealed with a
nonhardening, permanently resilient acoustical caulking compound.
   C.   Floor-Ceiling Assemblies: Floor-ceiling assemblies shall have a minimum
sound transmission class not less than fifty (50) (STC-50) and shall have an
impact insulation class of not less than fifty (50) (IIC-50). Floor- ceiling
assemblies which have been tested and rated by an approved sound testing
laboratory shall be considered as meeting the requirements of this Section,
providing that the assembly is not compromised by penetrations or flanking
sound transmission (ASTM E497-73T).
      1.   Carpeting and pad are required as the finish floor covering in all
common interior corridors and hallways (stairwells are optional) and for the
floors in the individual residential units except for kitchen and bathroom
floors. Kitchens and bathrooms of residential units as well as care facility
floors may use carpeting if the carpeting is readily cleanable with normal
cleaning products or may be of tile if underlayed with an approved design
assembly which meets the required STC and IIC.
      2.   Penetrations of the ceiling, in an approved floor-ceiling assembly,
such as lighting fixtures shall be protected with insulation and the perimeter
of the opening shall be sealed with a nonhardening, permanently resilient
acoustical caulking compound.
   D.   Mechanical Penetrations: All conduits, ducts, vents and pipes within
the required partition or floor-ceiling assembly which may be in structural
contact with more than one residential unit shall be isolated from the
structure at support points by means of resilient mounts designed to provide
acoustical isolation. All openings through which conduits, ducts, vents and
pipes pass shall have the excess openings filled and sealed with a nonhardening
permanently resilient, acoustical caulking compound.
   E.   Approvals: All partition and floor-ceiling assembly ratings (STC and
IIC), sound control designs and various materials to be used to conform with
these requirements shall receive prior approval from the Director of Office of
Quality Control. (Ords. 75-27-105, 81-12-19)
CHAPTER 14
FLOOD CONTROL AND PROTECTION
SECTION:
6-14-1: Definitions
6-14-2: General Flood Plain Regulations
6-14-3: Flood Hazard and Damage Prevention

6-14-3-2: Maps and Profiles
6-14-3-3: Streams and Floodwater Runoff Channels and Basins
