   A.   An organization plan shall be known to the staff and available for
public information in the licensed facility. The document shall clearly set
forth the organization, duties, responsibility, accountability and
relationships of professional staff and other personnel. All owners,
administrators, professional staff and ancillary personnel shall act in
accordance with this document. This document shall be submitted to the Village
Medical Director with the initial application and thereafter will be reviewed
at regular inspections by the Village Medical Director.
   B.   Management and/or the owner of the ambulatory surgical treatment center
shall maintain proper standards of professional work in the licensed facility.
   C.   A qualified consulting committee shall be appointed in writing by the
management and/or owner of the ambulatory surgical treatment center and shall
establish and enforce standards for professional work in the facility and
standards of competency for physicians. The consulting committee shall meet not
less than quarterly and shall document all meetings with written minutes. These
written minutes shall be maintained at the facility and shall be available for
inspection by the Village Medical Director.
   D.   The membership of the consulting committee shall reflect the types of
procedures performed. If the facility performs more than fifty (50) procedures
per month, or more than ten percent (10%) of the total procedures performed are
in a specific specialty area, then there shall be a consulting physician of
that specialty on the consulting committee.
   E.   The consulting committee shall review development and content of the
written policies and procedures of the center, the procedures for granting
privileges, and the quality of the surgical procedures performed. Evidence of
such review shall be recorded in the minutes.
   F.   Credentials shall be provided by those physicians seeking practice
privileges. These credentials shall be reviewed by the credentials committee
and specific practice privileges identified and recorded. Record of such
accepted practice privileges shall be available for facility staff use and
public information within the facility.
   G.   A physician granted specific practice privileges shall provide evidence
that he/she has equivalent practice privileges in at least one licensed
Illinois hospital. Documentation of said evidence shall be available for
inspection by the Village Medical Director. A list of such privileges granted
each physician on the staff of the ambulatory surgical treatment center shall
be posted at all times for the staff of the center.
   H.   Physicians operating in the facility shall document that they are
active staff members of a licensed hospital with verified credentials including
admitting, not more than fifteen (15) minutes' travel time or five (5) miles,
whichever is less, from the facility wherein the surgical procedures will be
performed.
   I.   The consulting committee shall act as a tissue committee and shall
review at least quarterly all pathological reports from procedures performed by
each physician on the staff. Evidence of such review shall be recorded in the
minutes.
   J.   The management/owner of the ambulatory surgical treatment center shall
formulate a written policies and procedures manual. This shall be done in
cooperation with the medical and professional staff and shall be approved by
the consulting committee. These procedures shall provide for the acceptance,
care, treatment, anesthesia services, discharge, referral, and follow-up of all
patients and all incidental operations of the facility. This manual shall be
available to all staff in the center and shall be followed by them at all times
in the performance of their duties. (Ords. 79-24-42, 87-5-18)
8-3-8: LICENSED FACILITY PERSONNEL:
   A.   Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall have written personnel
policies including job descriptions for each staff position, which shall
include minimum qualifications required for the position. These shall be a
documented procedure for orientation of new employees to the facility's
policies and procedures, as well as the personnel policies including a copy of
the appropriate job description.
   B.   A qualified physician shall be present at the facility at all times
during the operative and post-operative period for all patients.
   C.   At least one registered professional nurse with post-graduate education
or experience in surgical nursing shall direct and supervise the nursing
personnel and the nursing care of patients and shall be on duty at all times on
the premises when patients are present.
   D.   Nursing care may be provided by student nurses and licensed practical
nurses who have been trained in observation and emergency techniques for pre-
operative and post-operative care of surgical patients and who are under the
direct personal supervision of a registered nurse at all times.
   E.   At least one person who is certified in "basic life support", by the
American Heart Association shall be on the premises while patients are present.
   F.   Each ambulatory surgical treatment center shall have one of the
following:
      1.   A qualified medical technician who is certified by the American
Society of Clinical Pathologists or is the holder of a letter, certificate, or
record from the Bureau of Quality Assurance of the Department of Health,
Education and Welfare and he/she has passed the Federal Proficiency Examination
Program for Clinical Laboratory Technologists, to perform required laboratory
procedures.
      2.   A written agreement with a laboratory, licensed by the Department of
Public Health of the State of Illinois to perform required laboratory
procedures. (Ord. 78-24-42)
8-3-9: EQUIPMENT, SUPPLIES AND FACILITY MAINTENANCE:
   A.   Equipment shall be in good working order and shall be available in
numbers sufficient to provide good patient care based on the procedures to be
performed in the facility.
   B.   There shall be monitoring equipment, suction apparatus, oxygen and
related items available within the surgical and post-operative recovery area.
Cardiac pulmonary resuscitation equipment shall be available in all facilities.
   C.   There shall be written procedures governing the care, use,
sterilization, storage and disposal of materials to insure that an adequate
supply of sterile equipment is available for each procedure. The section on
"Sterilization and Disinfection" from the most recent edition of Infection
Control in the Hospital, American Hospital Association, shall be used as the
standard.
   D.   There shall be written procedures to assure safety in storage and use
of inhalation anesthetics and medical gases. The current edition of the
National Fire Protection and Association Code (Standard No. 56a) shall be used
as the standard.
   E.   There shall be written procedures to assure the safety in storage and
use of all narcotics and medications in accordance with State and Federal law.
   F.   The ambulatory surgical treatment center shall insure maintenance of a
sanitary facility with all equipment in good working order. Written procedures
shall include provisions for garbage and refuse removal, insect and rodent
control, maintenance of water, heat, ventilation and air conditioning, and
electrical service.
   G.   It shall be demonstrated to the Village Medical Director and to the
Village Fire Department that a nonambulatory patient can be removed from the
building in which the center is located, as follows:
      1.   By demonstrating that the building has an elevator sufficiently wide
to accommodate a full-length stretcher in a prone position; or
      2.   By demonstrating that a stretcher owned by the licensee has an
adjustable head section which can be adjusted so that the stretcher can be
accommodated in the building elevator; or
      3.   By demonstrating that a stretcher can be transported down the
stairway in a position so as not to jeopardize the patient's health, in a
reasonable period of time. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47, 87-5-18)
8-3-10: PRE-OPERATIVE CARE:
   A.   Where medical evaluation, examination, and referral are made from a
private physician's office, hospital or clinic, pertinent records thereof shall
be available and made a part of the patient's clinical record at the time the
patient is registered and admitted to the ambulatory surgical treatment center.
   B.   A complete medical history shall be obtained and the physical
examination shall be complete. A hematocrit and complete urinalysis shall be
performed by a qualified laboratory technician prior to the following
procedures:
      1.   Those performed with general anesthesia;
      2.   Those performed with local anesthesia;
      3.   Those performed to terminate pregnancy;
      4.   A written statement indicating informed consent and a signed
authorization by the patient for the performance of the specific surgical
procedure shall be procured and made part of the patient's clinical record.
(Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47)
8-3-11: POST-OPERATIVE CARE:
   A.   To insure availability of follow-up care at a licensed hospital, the
ambulatory surgical treatment center shall provide written documentation of the
following:
      1.   A transfer agreement with a licensed ambulance service for the
transportation of patients to a licensed hospital within fifteen (15) minutes'
travel time, or five (5) miles, whichever is less, of the facility;
      2.   A statement that each physician operating in the facility has full
admitting privileges in, and is an active staff member of, a licensed hospital
within fifteen (15) minutes' travel time, or five (5) miles, whichever is less,
of the facility, and that he will assume responsibility for his facility
patients requiring such follow-up care.
   B.   Written instructions signed by the attending physician shall be issued
to all patients in accordance with the standards approved by the consulting
committee of the ambulatory surgical treatment center, and shall include the
following:
      1.   Symptoms of complications associated with procedures performed.
      2.   Limitations and/or restrictions of activities of the patient.
      3.   Specific telephone number of a qualified professional associated
with the facility, to be used by the patient, at any time, should any
complication or question arise.
      4.   A date for follow-up or return visits after the performance of the
procedure, which shall be scheduled within six (6) weeks.
      5.   Telephone number of Village Medical Director.
   C.   Patients shall be discharged only on the written signed order of a
physician. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47)
8-3-12: RECORDS AND REPORTS:
Accurate and complete clinical records shall be maintained for each patient,
and all entries in the clinical record shall be made at the time the surgical
procedure is performed and when care, treatment, medications, or other medical
services are given. The record shall include, but not be limited to the
following:
   A.   Patient identification;
   B.   Admitting information including patient history, physical examination
findings, diagnosis or need for medical services;
   C.   Pre-operative counseling notes;
   D.   Signed informed consent;
   E.   Laboratory tests' reports, pathologist's report of tissue, and
radiologist's report of X-rays;
   F.   Anesthesia record;
   G.   Operative record;
   H.   Medication and medical treatments;
   I.   Recovery room and progress notes;
   J.   Physician and nurses' progress notes;
   K.   Condition at time of discharge;
   L.   Written patient instructions. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47)
8-3-13: ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS, OBSTETRICAL/GYNECOLOGICAL PROCEDURES:
Abortions shall be provided to the public with the same standards of safety,
effectiveness and regard for patients' rights as any other health service.
   A.   Personnel: At least one registered professional nurse with post-
graduate education or experience in obstetrical or gynecological nursing shall
supervise and direct the nursing personnel and care of patients having
obstetrical procedures.
   B.   General Patient Care:
      1.   Examination:
         a.   Prior to obstetrical procedures, blood typing and Rh factor,
coagulation profile, hematocrit, and urinalysis, shall be performed by a
qualified laboratory technician for every patient.
         b.   The physician performing an abortion procedure shall establish
the diagnosis of pregnancy by chemical and physical examination prior to
performing an abortion procedure.
      2.   Counseling:
         a.   Counseling shall be provided following disclosure to the patient
of the diagnosis of pregnancy, and prior to performance of any surgical
procedure. It shall be done individually and in a room designated for such use
which shall not be the procedure room.
         b.   Counseling shall be done by a person qualified to:
            (1)   Discuss alternatives for dealing with an unwanted pregnancy;
            (2)   Describe the procedures used in the facility;
            (3)   Explain the risks and possible complications of each
procedure.
Demonstration of such counseling qualifications shall be required by the
Village Medical Director.
      3.   Preoperative Requirements:
         a.   Surgical procedures shall not be performed on patients having
medical, surgical or psychiatric conditions or complications as specified by
the consulting committee in the facility's written policies.
      4.   Postoperative Requirements:
         a.   Each obstetrical/gynecological service shall provide Rh factor
sensitization prophylaxis to all Rh negative patients according to standard
medical procedures.
         b.   All tissue removed during the performance of an abortion shall be
weighed and examined by a qualified pathologist who is affiliated with a
licensed laboratory or hospital, who shall determine the presence or absence of
both fetal and placental tissue by the most appropriate methods. He shall,
within seven (7) days, provide a written report of the examination and findings
to the attending physician, and the ambulatory surgical treatment center. A
copy of the report shall be included in the patient's clinical record.
      5.   Reports:
         a.   A report of each abortion procedure performed in an ambulatory
surgical treatment center shall be made to the Village Medical Director on
forms provided by him. These reports shall be submitted not later than ten (10)
days following the month in which the abortion was performed. Reports shall be
submitted on procedures performed whether or not the patient was pregnant.
         b.   Reports shall not be filled out in such a manner or at such a
time as to avoid accurate reporting of complications.
         c.   If the facility becomes aware of a complication following the
submission of the original report, then an amended report shall be submitted to
the Village Medical Director.
         d.   Reports shall be kept confidential, and shall be available for
statistical purposes only. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47, 87-5-18)
8-3-14: DENIAL, SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSE; NOTICE AND HEARING:
   A.   The Village Medical Director, after notice and opportunity for hearing
to the applicant or licensee, may deny, suspend or revoke a license to open,
conduct and maintain an ambulatory surgical treatment center in any case in
which he finds that there has been a substantial failure to comply with the
provisions of this Chapter or State law or the standards, rules and regulations
established by virtue thereof.
   B.   Such notice shall be effected by certified mail or by personal service
setting forth the particular reasons for the proposed action and fixing a date,
not less than fifteen (15) days from the date of such mailing or service, at
which time the applicant or licensee shall be given an opportunity for a
hearing.
   C.   The hearing shall be conducted by the Village Manager and the Village
Health and Sanitation Officer and, if in the opinion of the Village Medical
Director it is necessary, outside medical experts, designated in writing by the
Village Medical Director as hearing officers to conduct the hearing. On the
basis of any such hearing, or upon default of the applicant or licensee, the
hearing officers shall make a determination specifying their findings and
conclusions. A copy of such determination shall be sent by certified mail or
served personally upon the applicant or licensee.
   D.   A full and complete record shall be kept of all proceedings, including
the notice of hearing, complaint, and all other documents in the nature of
pleadings, written motions filed in the proceedings, and the report and orders
of the Village Medical Director and hearing officers. All testimony shall be
recorded by a court reporter but need not be transcribed. A copy or copies of
the transcript may be obtained by any interested party on payment of the cost
of preparing such copy or copies. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47, 87-5-18)
8-3-15: INSPECTIONS:
   A.   The Village Medical Director shall make or cause to be made such
inspections and investigations as he deems necessary but in no case less than
four (4) inspections of any licensed facility in a fiscal year.
   B.   Every facility licensed under this Chapter and any premises proposed to
be conducted as a facility by an applicant for a license shall be open at all
reasonable times to an inspection authorized in writing by the Village Medical
Director. No notice need be given to any person prior to any inspection.
   C.   Whenever an inspection of any ambulatory surgical treatment center
discloses that the continued operation of such facility constitutes an imminent
and serious menace to the health or safety of the patients thereof, the
inspector is authorized to immediately close such facility. Once the facility
has been closed, the personnel employed there shall cease any activity related
to the patients, unless continued treatment of any given patient is necessary
to protect his health or life. A written order setting forth the grounds on
which any action under this Section is based shall be served on the licensee
within twenty four (24) hours after such action is taken. Any licensee whose
ambulatory surgical treatment center has been closed may, within ten (10) days
thereafter, by written notice, request that the Village Medical Director
conduct a hearing and a reinspection under the provisions of this Chapter. If a
subsequent inspection discloses that the violations of this Chapter or rules,
regulations, or standards have been abated, the Village Medical Director shall
cancel the order of closing and permit patients to be treated therein. The
remedies provided in this Section are in addition to and not exclusive of any
other remedy provided by law. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47, 87-5-18)
8-3-16: COMPLAINTS:
The Village Medical Director shall establish by rule a procedure for receiving
and investigating complaints regarding any ambulatory surgical treatment center
or any physician practicing in any such facility. (Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47,
87-5-18)
8-3-17: PENALTY:
Any person opening, conducting or maintaining an ambulatory surgical treatment
center without a license issued pursuant to this Chapter shall be guilty of an
offense punishable by a fine of seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and each
day's violation shall constitute a separate offense. For violation of any other
provision of this Chapter, such offender shall be guilty of an offense
punishable by a fine of not more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
(Ords. 79-24-42, 79-25-47, 99-5-11)
8-3-18: SEVERABILITY:
If any provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part of this Chapter,
or application thereof to any person or circumstance, shall, for any reason, be
adjudged to be unconstitutional or invalid, said judgment shall not affect,
impair or invalidate the remainder of this Chapter and the application of such
provision to other persons or circumstances, but shall be confined in its
operation to the provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section, or part
thereof directly involved in the controversy in which such judgment shall have
been rendered and to the person or circumstances involved. It is hereby
declared to be the legislative intent of the Village President and Board of
Trustees that this Chapter would have been adopted had such unconstitutional or
invalid provision, clause, sentence, paragraph, section or part thereof not
been included. (Ord. 79-36-83)
CHAPTER 4
LICENSE EXEMPT BUSINESSES
SECTION:
8-4-1: Registration With The Village
8-4-1: REGISTRATION WITH THE VILLAGE:
Nonmedical, health related businesses expressly exempted from being subject to
the village of Oak Lawn licensing procedure by the state of Illinois, shall not
be required to register with the business license officer. These businesses
include, but are not limited to: barbers, cosmetologists 1 , carrier pigeons 2
, dieticians and nutrition counselors 3 , and massage therapists 4 . (Ords. 06-
10-55, 07-04-14)
 
Notes
1 1. 225 ILCS 410/1-3.
2 2. 510 ILCS 45/8.
3 3. 225 ILCS 30/180.
4 4. 225 ILCS 57/55.
CHAPTER 5
GARBAGE, REFUSE AND ELECTRONIC RECYCLING
SECTION:
8-5-1: Purpose
8-5-2: License Required For Private Disposal
8-5-3: Private Scavengers
8-5-4: Garbage Deposits, Accumulations Restricted
8-5-5: Containers Required, Specifications
8-5-6: Collection Regulations, Requirements
8-5-7: Charges For Village Collection
8-5-8: Refuse Vehicles
8-5-9: Consumer Electronic Recycling
8-5-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the disposal,
accumulation and removal of refuse and to eliminate unhealthy, unsanitary and
unsightly conditions in the village. (1951 Code
6-6-1)
8-5-2: LICENSE REQUIRED FOR PRIVATE DISPOSAL:
No person except as herein provided, acting as a private scavenger, shall
remove refuse from any premises in the village or transport refuse through the
streets, alleys or public ways of the village, or dump, incinerate, or in any
other manner dispose of refuse, or contract for any such removal,
transportation or disposal of refuse without first having secured a license for
such services from the village clerk, in accordance with title 3, chapter 1 of
this code 1 . (Ords. 72-31-66, 72-38-71, 72-41-77, 73-17-22, 73-19-28, 73-24-
42, 73-42-89, 74-11-15, 74-13-22; 1985 Code)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-1-7 of this code for license fees.
8-5-3: PRIVATE SCAVENGERS:
   A.   Number Limited: The number of private scavenger licenses authorized to
be issued shall be as amended from time to time by ordinance adopted by the
president and board of trustees and on record in the office of the village
clerk.
   B.   Financial Statement: Each original application and each renewal
application for a scavenger license with the village shall be accompanied by a
current financial statement of the applicant.
   C.   Public Liability Bond: Every application for a scavenger license shall
be accompanied by a public liability bond in the amount of ten thousand dollars
($10,000.00) in favor of the village.
   D.   Hold Harmless Agreement: Upon application for a scavenger license, each
licensee shall provide the clerk with an agreement to hold the village harmless
for any acts of the licensee relating to its use of the village streets and
alleys in such a manner as to cause injury or loss to persons or property. Such
agreement shall be approved by the village attorney prior to its filing with
the clerk.
   E.   Revocation Of License: The requirements of subsections B, C and D of
this section are conditions precedent to holding a scavenger's license in the
village, and the failure of a licensee to conform thereto shall cause the
revocation of the scavenger license 1 . (Ords. 72-31-66, 72-38-71, 72-41-77,
73-17-22, 73-19-28, 73-24-42, 73-42-89, 74-11-15, 74-13-22; 1985 Code; Ords.
96-3-10, 06-10-55)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  3-1-6 of this code for license revocation and hearing provisions.
8-5-4: GARBAGE DEPOSITS, ACCUMULATIONS RESTRICTED:
   A.   Placing On Property Or Exposed To Wind: No garbage or refuse of any
kind shall be deposited in any street, alley, public way or on any other
property except that of the owner, except as is provided in this chapter; and
no such refuse shall be so placed that it can be blown about or scattered by
the wind.
   B.   Accumulations Prohibited Except In Containers; Removal Required: No
occupant, person, owner, owner's agent, or tenant of any private or public
premises shall permit refuse to accumulate on such premises except in covered
containers as provided hereinafter, located in either the side yard or rear
yard of said premises, at a location no closer than ten feet (10') to any door
or window of any building located on a neighboring parcel; and all such refuse
should be removed once every seven (7) days or more often if necessary to
protect the health of the inhabitants of the village. (1951 Code 2-6-18, 6-6;
Ord. 87-22-96)
8-5-5: CONTAINERS REQUIRED, SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Every occupant, person, owner, lessee or tenant in possession of any
house, building, condominium, or apartment in the village shall at all times
maintain in good order and repair a container or containers for trash and
garbage.
   B.   A container shall be a can of galvanized iron or noncorrodible
material, rodentproof, watertight, with a tightfitting lid, and of the type
commonly sold as a garbage can, of a suitable gauge and construction to ensure
durability, of a capacity of not less than ten (10) gallons and not to exceed
thirty three (33) gallons for single-family and two-family residences.
   C.   Filthy, leaking or defective receptacles should be cleaned, repaired or
replaced as directed by the appropriate representative of the village. (1951
Code 2-6-26, 2-6-17,
6-6-3; Ord. 06-10-55)
8-5-6: COLLECTION REGULATIONS, REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Hours, Placement Of Containers For Collection: No garbage or refuse
container of any kind shall be stored or deposited in any street, alley or
public way, except for the purpose of pick up, and then only between the hours
of five o'clock (5:00) P.M. the day before pick up and nine o'clock (9:00) P.M.
the day of the pick up.
   B.   Hours Of Collection; Days Prohibited:
      1.   Under its powers as a home rule municipality the village restricts
the time of refuse and garbage collection within the village limits by firms
under contract to the village and by firms licensed by the village to do so to
five thirty o'clock (5:30) A.M. until six thirty o'clock (6:30) P.M.
      2.   No collection of garbage shall be made on Sundays or holidays.
   C.   Private Collection From Commercial Establishments: Occupants, tenants,
or persons in possession of commercial buildings may arrange for disposal of
refuse by private contract but shall establish proof to the satisfaction of the
Village that refuse is being properly removed from the premises. A designated
representative of the Village, in the absence of proof that means of disposal
or removal have been contracted by or provided for, may inspect the premises
and remove therefrom any and all refuse found therein for which removal the
required fees shall be paid by the person in whose name the Village carries the
water account of the subject property.
   D.   Village Collection Required For Residences: Every occupant, person,
owner or person in possession of a dwelling place in the Village shall be
required to have accumulations of refuse removed and disposed of by the Village
or its delegated representative and for such refuse removal services shall pay
to the Village the sum specified for such services. (1951 Code
6-6-4,
6-6-6; Ords. 64-18, 74-3-3, 06-10-55)
8-5-7: CHARGES FOR VILLAGE COLLECTION:
   A.   Effective October 1, 2024, refuse collection charges for each
residential and nonresidential account shall be as follows:
      1.   Residential quarterly billing:
         a.   Seniors (over age 65): Sixty-seven dollars and forty-four cents
($67.44);
         b.   Person(s) with a disability: Sixty-seven dollars and forty-four
cents ($67.44);
            (1)   “Person(s) with a disability” as used in this section means
any person who is, and who is expected to indefinitely continue to be, subject
to any of the five (5) types of disabilities consistent with the term as
defined in the Illinois State Statute, 15 Illinois Compiled Statutes 335/4A; or
person(s) with a disability that are receiving social security or SSI benefits.
This reduction shall only apply to homeowners with a disability as defined
above or alternatively, legal guardians of a person with a disability who
reside in the residence of the applicant seeking the reduction.
            (2)   The Village of Oak Lawn recognizes that it lacks the
resources to establish a system for determining whether an applicant under this
section is a “person(s) with a disability” as defined herein. As a result, in
order to receive the reduction allowed under this section, the Village of Oak
Lawn will only accept the following documents as validation of proof that the
applicant is a “person with a disability” or has a disability and is receiving
social security or SSI benefits:
               (A)    Person(s) with a disability validation. The applicant
must provide a valid “Illinois person with a disability identification card”
obtained through the Illinois Secretary of State as provided for in 15 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 335/4.
               (B)   Social security validation. The applicant must provide a
current social security or SSI benefit verification letter which contains the
applicant’s current residence, age and disability.
         c.   Nonseniors: Seventy-six dollars and seventy-four cents ($76.74).
      2.   Nonresidential monthly billing:
         a.   All customers: Twenty-five dollars and fifty-eight cents
($25.58).
         All charges shall be billed to and paid by the occupant, owner or
owner’s agent, tenant, or individual in whose name the water account appears,
or otherwise as the Village Collector may provide. Collection of the charges
for water provided, sewage treated and refuse collected shall not be collected
separately from each other. Wherever refuse disposal is not required for a full
billing cycle, the individual furnished the service shall pay on a pro rata
basis for portions of the billing cycle during which he receives services. The
basic charge shall entitle each account to a weekly collection of all household
waste including garbage, rubbish and recyclables.
   B.   Only one of the following listed items may be placed out for pick up,
without additional charge, each week:
      1.   Furniture and large household goods, to include, but not be limited
to, televisions, hot water heaters, sofas, dressers, lamps, chairs, tables,
mattresses, rolls of carpet (not more than 4 feet in length).
      2.   Small amounts of sod, earth, and rocks, provided the items listed
are put into a suitable container not exceeding sixty (60) pounds.
      3.   Construction material (except new construction) including, but not
limited to, furnaces, bathtubs, shower stalls, doors, windows, and other items
that are considered part of a dwelling. It shall also include loose remodeling
and repair construction materials, provided such items are put in a suitable
container or in a bundle not exceeding four feet (4') in length, and not
weighing over sixty (60) pounds.
Customers who wish to set out more than one of the items listed per week will
be directed to contact the contractor to make arrangements for collection at an
additional cost.
Dead animals and white goods (such as refrigerators, air conditioners,
freezers, washing machines, dryers, dishwashers, microwaves, etc.) will be
collected at no additional charge.
   C.   Organic (living) Christmas trees shall be collected, free of charge, a
minimum of two (2) weeks after January 1 of each year from each dwelling
serviced under this contract. Christmas trees shall be collected on regularly
scheduled collection days.
   D.   In an effort to encourage management of landscape waste at a location,
the pick up of landscape waste is to be provided on the same day and as part of
the regular refuse pick up, between April 1 and November 30 of each year.
Bundles of brush or tree clippings shall be collected as part of the regular
landscape waste pick up, provided the weight of such bundles does not exceed
sixty (60) pounds, the length of material does not exceed four feet (4'), and/
or the diameter of each bundle does not exceed three feet (3'). Logs over four
inches (4") in diameter must be stacked separately at the curb and cut into
lengths of twenty four inches (24") with individual pieces not exceeding eight
inches (8") in diameter. The foregoing does not include any branches or trees
cut by private contractors hired by the customer. (Ords. 13-15-56, 14-04-10,
14-13-25, 15-05-18, 16-06-12, 17-04-09, 18-24-83, 19-23-74, 20-19-56, 21-21-98,
22-19-64, 23-15-60, 24-16-60)
8-5-8: REFUSE VEHICLES:
   A.   Vehicles To Be Covered: All refuse vehicles shall be covered whenever
possible so that refuse or garbage being carried will not be open except when
necessary.
   B.   Disinfection Of Vehicles: Any person owning or controlling any refuse
vehicle shall cause all such vehicles to be thoroughly disinfected at least
once a week unless the same shall not have been used since the last
disinfection thereof.
   C.   Parking Refuse Vehicles: No person owning or controlling any vehicle
used for the carrying or transporting of any garbage, ashes, miscellaneous
waste or manure shall cause or permit such vehicle when in use for such purpose
to stand or remain before or near any building or premises occupied by any
person for an unreasonable or unnecessary length of time. (1951 Code 6-6-7)
8-5-9: CONSUMER ELECTRONIC RECYCLING:
   A.   Consumer electronics or covered electronic device means any computer,
computer monitor, television, printer, electronic keyboard, facsimile machine,
videocassette recorder, portable digital music player that has memory
capability and is battery powered, digital video disc player, video game
console, electronic mouse, scanner, digital converter box, cable receiver,
satellite receiver, digital video disc recorder, or small-scale server sold at
retail.
   B.   In the event that the Village hosts a collection program or one-day
collection for consumer electronics or covered electronic devices, the Village
may charge a thirty-five dollar ($35) collection fee for each television or
monitor collected.
   C.   The effective date of the imposition of the fee is January 1, 2021.
(Ord. 21-01-04)
CHAPTER 6
WEEDS
SECTION:
8-6-1: Definition
8-6-2: Duty To Cut Or Destroy; Destruction By Village
8-6-3: Failure To Cut Or Destroy Prohibited
8-6-4: Lien For Cost Of Destruction; Release Of Lien
8-6-5: Botanical And Ecological Areas Designated
8-6-1: DEFINITION:
"Weeds" as used in this chapter shall include, but not be limited to, the
following: all grasses, annual plants, burdock, ragweed (giant), ragweed
(common), thistle, cocklebur, jimson, blue vervain, common milkweed, wild
carrot, poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lamb's quarters, wild lettuce,
curled dock, smart weeds (all varieties), poison hemlock and wild hemp. (Ord.
19-05-09)
8-6-2: DUTY TO CUT OR DESTROY; DESTRUCTION BY VILLAGE:
It shall be the duty of every owner of real estate or person having a
beneficial interest therein to cut, control, or otherwise provide for the
destruction and proper disposal of weeds on his property at all such times as
may be necessary so that such weeds shall not exceed four inches (4") in
height, and should said owner or person fail to comply with the requirements of
this chapter, then the Village shall cause the weeds to be destroyed, cut or
controlled. (Ord. 230; 1985 Code; Ord. 06-10-55)
8-6-3: FAILURE TO CUT OR DESTROY PROHIBITED:
It is hereby declared to be illegal and a nuisance for the owners of real
estate or persons having a beneficial interest therein to refuse or neglect to
cut or otherwise control or destroy weeds on said real estate, the abutting
parkway or an abutting alley, when such weeds shall reach a height in excess of
four inches (4"). (Ord. 08-25-84)
8-6-4: LIEN FOR COST OF DESTRUCTION; RELEASE OF LIEN:
Should the weeds be cut, controlled or otherwise destroyed by the Village after
providing three (3) days' notice by mail to the property owner of record as
listed as the last person who paid Real Estate Taxes for the property, and
posting a notice on the front door of the property, or in the case of vacant
lot, in a conspicuous place, a bill for the costs incurred will be sent.
Failure to pay the charges within thirty (30) days will result in a lien of the
cost and expense therein incurred by the Village to be recorded in the
following manner: The Village or the person performing the service by the
authority of the Village in its or the owner's name may file notice of lien in
the Office of the Recorder of Deeds of Cook County. The notice of lien shall
consist of a sworn statement setting out:
   A.   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification thereof.
   B.   The amount of money representing all the costs and expenses incurred or
payable for the service plus interest calculated at one percent (1%) per month,
twelve percent (12%) annual percentage rate until satisfaction of the lien.
   C.   The date or dates when said cost and expense was incurred by the
Village.
Said notice of lien shall be filed within sixty (60) days after the costs and
expenses are incurred.
Upon payment of the cost and expense, plus interest at the rate of one percent
(1%) per month, after notice of lien has been filed, the lien shall be released
by the Village or person in whose name the lien has been filed and the release
shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of the said lien.
(Ord. 19-05-09)
8-6-5: BOTANICAL AND ECOLOGICAL AREAS DESIGNATED:
   A.   Where competent botanists and ecologists determine that a certain area
in the Village contains plant life which is valuable for botanical and
ecological study, the provisions of section
8-6-2 of this chapter shall not apply.
   B.   Upon notification in writing by the Village, the owner or owners of
property which the Board of Trustees declares to be a botanical and ecological
area shall not be required to cut down weeds or other plants on said property.
   C.   Notwithstanding the provisions of this section, the property owner
shall cut such weeds and noxious plants back to a point fifteen feet (15') from
the street or property line, whichever is the furthest.
   D.   Nothing contained herein shall require the property owner to maintain
the botanical and ecological area, and the option to use the property in any
legal manner desired remains the unqualified right of the owner. (Ord. 75-27-
103; 1985 Code)
CHAPTER 7
DUTCH ELM DISEASE
SECTION:
8-7-1: Nuisance Declared
8-7-2: Enforcement
8-7-3: Notice, Removal Of Violations
8-7-4: Abatement Of Violation And Lien For Costs Of Tree Removal
8-7-5: Release Of Lien
8-7-1: NUISANCE DECLARED:
Any tree of the species of elm which is infected with Dutch elm disease is
hereby declared to be a public nuisance, and shall be removed within thirty
(30) days following notification of the discovery of such infection. It shall
be unlawful for any person being the owner of property whereupon any such
diseased tree is situated, to possess or keep such a tree after the expiration
of thirty (30) days following notification of the discovery of said infection.
(Ord. 95-22-96)
8-7-2: ENFORCEMENT:
The Department of Public Works is charged with enforcement of this Chapter and
to that end may enter upon private property at all reasonable hours for
purposes of inspecting such premises for the presence thereon of trees infected
with Dutch elm disease, and may remove such samples, portions, or specimens
therefrom as are required to determine whether any tree thereon is infected. It
shall be unlawful for any person to prevent the Department of Public Works from
entering upon private property for purposes of carrying out its duties
hereunder, or to interfere with said Department of Public Works in the lawful
performance of its duties under the provisions of this Chapter. (Ord. 95-22-96)
8-7-3: NOTICE, REMOVAL OF VIOLATIONS:
The Department of Public Works shall give to the owner of the premises where
the public nuisance described in Section
8-7-1 is found, a written notice of the existence of such nuisance. Service of
the notice required by this Section shall be by personal service or by
registered mail to the person who is listed as the taxpayer of record for said
property. In addition to advising the owner of the existence of the nuisance,
said notice shall include the following:
   A.   A copy of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-20-12;
   B.   A copy of Title 8, Chapter 7 of the Village Code;
   C.   The common address for the property in question;
   D.   The permanent tax index number for the property in question;
   E.   An identification of the specific tree or trees affected; and
   F.   A statement indicating that if the identified nuisance is not remedied
within thirty (30) days of the date of the notice, the Village will enter upon
the property, abate the nuisance by removing the diseased tree(s) and bill the
property owner and/or lien the property for the reasonable cost of said
abatement. (Ord. 95-22-96)
8-7-4: ABATEMENT OF VIOLATION AND LIEN FOR COSTS OF TREE REMOVAL:
If, after the giving of notice as required by Section
8-7-3 above, the property owner refuses or neglects to remove the identified
infected tree(s), the Public Works Department may enter upon the property in
question and abate the nuisance by removing said tree(s). The reasonable cost
for said removal shall be billed to the property owner. If said property owner
refuses or neglects to pay said bill, a lien in the amount of said costs shall
be recorded/registered with the Cook County Recorder of Deeds/Registrar of
Titles. Said lien shall be recorded/registered within sixty (60) days after
such costs are incurred by the Village, and shall consist of a sworn statement
setting forth the following:
   A.   The legal description of the property;
   B.   The permanent tax index number of the property;
   C.   The common address of the property;
   D.   The cost incurred by the Village in removing the tree(s); and
   E.   The date(s) on which the tree removal work was performed.
Upon the recording/registering of said lien, a copy thereof shall be forwarded
by first class U.S. mail to the taxpayer of record for said property. (Ord. 95-
22-96)
8-7-5: RELEASE OF LIEN:
Upon receipt of payment consisting of the amount of the lien, the Village's
actual cost for recording the lien and a fifty dollar ($50.00) fee for the
Village's administrative costs in preparing the lien and the release, the
Village shall issue a release of lien to the person making said payment. (Ord.
95-22-96)
CHAPTER 8
PROPERTY CONDITIONS
SECTION:
8-8-1: Statement Of Purpose
8-8-2: Notice To Clean Up Property, Remove Debris
8-8-3: Failure To Abate; Abatement By Village
8-8-1: STATEMENT OF PURPOSE:
The purpose of this chapter is to regulate and control the physical conditions
of property and to eliminate unhealthy, unsanitary, dangerous and unsightly
conditions, attractive nuisances, mosquito producing, and rodent breeding
areas. (Ord. 19-05-09)
8-8-2: NOTICE TO CLEAN UP PROPERTY, REMOVE DEBRIS:
It shall be the duty of the Health and Sanitation Officer or chief building
inspector to send a notice by mail to the property owner of record as listed as
the last person who paid Real Estate Taxes for the property, and posting a
notice on the front door of the property, or in the case of vacant lot, in a
conspicuous place, informing him that he is in violation of this chapter. The
notice to clean up the property shall direct the owner to remove any existing
debris, garbage, bushes or piles of other organic material, building materials,
abandoned household goods, automotive parts, paper products, food and beverage
containers and all other types of refuse not indigenous to the vacant lot in a
natural state. The notice shall also direct the owners to cut existing foliage
and vegetation to a height of no more than four inches (4") over the surface of
the property. It may be required to bulldoze property where there is densely
overgrown land, which could provide harborage for rodents, vermin, insects that
jeopardize the health of man or which may be used as shelter from police
patrols, which might serve to further illegal activities, and the property
shall be cleared of bushes, and other growing foliage, as well as tall grass,
weeds, etc. The notice shall provide three (3) days, upon receipt of the
notice, for the owner to cause abatement of complained upon conditions of his
property. (Ord. 19-05-09)
8-8-3: FAILURE TO ABATE; ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
   A.   If, three (3) days after receiving the notice or its return
undelivered, the owner has failed to abate conditions, the Village, through its
agents, servants or employees may go upon the property and take such measures
as are necessary for abating the conditions complained of.
   B.   The costs and expenses incurred by the Village, including
administrative and legal costs for work and materials under this chapter, shall
be charged against the property, and a bill for services shall be sent. Failure
to reimburse the Village within thirty (30) days will result in a lien filed on
behalf of the Village as provided by statute, plus interest at the rate of one
percent (1%) per month, or twelve percent (12%) per year, until satisfaction of
the lien. (Ord. 19-05-09)
CHAPTER 9
RODENT CONTROL
SECTION:
8-9-1: Rodent Control Requirements
8-9-2: Notice Requiring Abatement Of Infestation
8-9-3: Failure To Abate; Abatement By Village
8-9-4: Penalty
8-9-1: RODENT CONTROL REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   All structures and properties shall be kept free from insect
infestation and rodent infestations. All garbage, debris and refuse shall be so
stored in a garbage can and / or dumpster free of holes with lids completely
closed as not to invite insects or rodents or be unsightly or a nuisance.
Exterior storage of items not manufactured and intended for outdoor
recreational yard use are not permitted. Acceptable items are items such as
patio furniture, grill, and play yard equipment. All non-conforming items must
be stored inside an enclosed structure, or removed.
   B.   All structures and/or properties in which insect infestation or rodent
harborage is found or suspected shall be promptly exterminated at the property
owner’s expense by a village-approved rodent abatement/control company.
   C.   All residential rental properties and multi-family properties,
including, but not limited to, condominiums, apartments, modular or
manufactured housing, shall be treated around the exterior of the property not
less than on a quarterly basis by a licensed rodent control company. For
purposes of this Section, “treat,” “treated” and “treatment” means “structural
pest control” as defined in the Illinois Structural Pest Control Act, 225 ILCS
235/3.09, as amended from time to time. Activity result reports and / or
receipts shall be made available to the village upon request of a village
inspector. If, upon inspection of any residential property, there is found or
suspected to be insect and / or rodent infestation in more than one (1)
dwelling unit, the landlord / owner shall contract with a licensed rodent
control company to treat all common areas and infested dwelling units on no
less than a monthly basis for twelve (12) consecutive months. Tenants shall
cooperate with the landlord / property owner in the control, treatment and
eradication of all rodent and / or insect infestation found, or reasonably
suspected to be, in the tenant’s rental unit. A tenant’s cooperation may
include making any necessary preparations, such as cleaning, vacuuming or
removing personal property for proper treatment recommended by the licensed
rodent control company. (Ords. 21-20-91, 21-22-102)
8-9-2: NOTICE REQUIRING ABATEMENT OF INFESTATION:
It shall be the duty of the health and sanitation officer or chief building
inspector of the village to give notice in writing, by personal service thereof
or by certified mail to the owner, agent, or occupant in charge of any
building, structure, premises or vacant parcel of land, and persons interested
therein, requiring them to take immediate measures for preventing ingress or
the harborage of rats, rodents or vermin to or on their property, building,
structure, premises or vacant parcel of land and the extermination thereof. The
health and sanitation officer or chief building inspector shall provide
technical advice and assistance upon request, but it shall be the
responsibility of the owner, agent, or occupant so notified to bear the
responsibility and expense of the extermination of the rodents. (1951 Code 15-
5-1; Ords. 184, 74-11-16; 1985 Code; Ords. 06-10-55, 20-08-21, 21-20-91)
8-9-3: FAILURE TO ABATE; ABATEMENT BY VILLAGE:
   A.   When measures for the prevention of ingress of rats, rodents or vermin
and the extermination thereof are not complied with within forty-eight (48)
hours after receipt of notice from the health and sanitation officer or chief
building inspector, and if the health officer or chief building inspector deems
the situation to be of sufficient danger to the residents of the area, whereby
the health officer or chief building inspector declares a health and sanitation
emergency, then the village, through its agents, servants or employees may go
upon the premises and take such measures as are necessary for the extermination
of rats, rodents or vermin therein, and the prevention of ingress.
   B.   The cost and expenses incurred by the village for work and materials
under this chapter shall be charged to and collected from the owners of and
persons interested in the property, premises, building or structure or vacant
parcel of land, and the village or persons performing work or furnishing
necessary materials on its behalf shall have payment within thirty (30) days of
billing. Failure to provide payment within the prescribed time period will
result in a lien being filed on behalf of the village, in addition to payment
of interest at the rate of one percent (1%) per month, or twelve percent (12%)
annual rate, until satisfaction of the lien.
   C.   When rats, rodents or vermin are discovered in a public way i.e.
Village of Oak Lawn alley or public road, the Village of Oak Lawn shall be
responsible for the abatement program. Should it be discovered that the origin
of those rats, rodents or vermin found in public way are from a property,
premises, building or structure or vacant parcel of land, then said owners of
and persons interested in the originating property shall be responsible for the
cost and expenses incurred by the village for work and materials under this
chapter shall be charged to and collected from the owners of and persons
interested in the property, premises, building or structure or vacant parcel of
land. (1951 Code 15-5-3; Ords. 184, 74-11-16; 1985 Code; Ords. 06-10-55, 20-08-
21, 21-20-91)
8-9-4: PENALTY:
If, after proper notification as stated in this chapter, the owner, agent,
occupant or persons interested therein fail to comply with the abatement notice
in forty-eight (48) hours or if the village shall take direct action to
safeguard the health and safety of the residents of the area, then the owner,
agent, occupant or persons interested therein so failing to abate shall be
further fined as provided in section
1-4-1 of this code. (Ords. 74-11-16, 06-10-55, 20-08-21, 21-20-91)
CHAPTER 10
BUNGEE CORD JUMPING
SECTION:
8-10-1: Definitions
8-10-2: Bungee Cord Jumping And Reverse Bungee Cord Jumping Prohibited
8-10-3: Penalty
8-10-1: DEFINITIONS:
BUNGEE CORD JUMPING AND BUNGEE JUMPING: The sport, activity or practice of
jumping, falling, stepping out of, dropping or otherwise being released into
the air while attached or fastened to any type of cord or rope or other device,
including cords made of rubber, latex or other elastic-type material, whether
natural or synthetic, whereby the cord stops, lengthens or shortens the fall of
any person, allowing the person to bounce up and down, ultimately intending to
bring the person to a stop at a point above the surface.
REVERSE BUNGEE CORD JUMPING AND REVERSE BUNGEE JUMPING: The sport, activity or
practice of attaching or fastening one's self to any type of cord or rope or
other device, including cords specified in the definition above, whereby a
person is located below a device or structure or machine from which a cord or
rope is suspended or attached and is released to cause the person to be
propelled, catapulted or otherwise launched out of a fixed position into the
air, allowing the person to bounce up and down, ultimately intending to bring
the person to a stop at a point above the surface. (Ord. 92-19-71)
8-10-2: BUNGEE CORD JUMPING AND REVERSE BUNGEE CORD JUMPING PROHIBITED:
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in bungee cord jumping or reverse
bungee cord jumping in any form whatsoever, whether open to the general public,
or for demonstration, exhibition, or any other purpose, within the corporate
limits of the Village or on any property owned by the Village. (Ord. 92-19-71)
8-10-3: PENALTY:
Any person violating the provisions of this Chapter shall be fined an amount
not exceeding seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00). (Ords. 92-19-71, 99-5-11)
CHAPTER 11
HOSPITALS
SECTION:
8-11-1: Definitions
8-11-2: License Required
8-11-3: License; Application; Inquiry
8-11-4: License Fee
8-11-5: Code Compliance
8-11-6: Inspections
8-11-7: Reports Filed
8-11-8: Penalties For Violations
8-11-1: DEFINITIONS:
CHILDREN'S HOSPITAL: A hospital devoted exclusively to caring for children or
any facility within a hospital or on the campus of a hospital devoted
exclusively to caring for children.
HOSPITAL: A health facility as defined in section 3(A) of the Illinois hospital
licensing act 1 . (Ord. 07-04-14)
 
Notes
1 1. 210 ILCS 85/3.
8-11-2: LICENSE REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful for any person, firm or corporation to operate any
hospital or children's hospital within the village without first obtaining a
license therefor. (Ord. 07-04-14)
8-11-3: LICENSE; APPLICATION; INQUIRY:
An application for such hospital/children's hospital license shall be made in
conformity with the general requirements of this code for all business
licenses, as set forth in title 3, chapter 1 of this code. In addition, the
applicant shall file a copy of the application with the department of quality
control and shall state the location or proposed location of the hospital/
children's hospital, the purpose for which it is to be conducted or operated;
the accommodations or proposed accommodations for those housed therein, the
nature and kind of treatment given or proposed to be given therein, the name
and address of the chief physician, surgeon, or attending chief physician or
surgeon, or board of physicians or surgeons attendant therein, as well as the
name and address of said hospital's/children's hospital's business manager/
chief administrator.
The department of quality control, upon the presentation of such application
for a license shall make, or cause to be made, inquiry into the facts set out
in such application to ascertain whether such hospital/children's hospital is,
or is intended to be, so conducted as to afford proper accommodations for the
care of persons received or proposed to be received therein, and that the chief
physician or surgeon, or intended chief physician or surgeon, or board of
physicians or surgeons thereof, at the time of such application gives, or is
under agreement thereafter to give, such attendance therein as does or will
render him, her or them responsible, professionally, for the medical or
surgical treatment given or to be given to any and all patients therein, and
that such chief physician or surgeon, or board of physicians or surgeons is
regularly authorized to act as such under the laws of the state, and that such
hospital/children's hospital complies or intends to comply with all the laws,
rules and regulations which shall then be in force concerning the management
operation and control of such hospital/children's hospital. A copy of the
hospital's/children's hospital's current license from the state of Illinois
shall accompany any such application. (Ord. 07-04-14)
8-11-4: LICENSE FEE:
   A.   The license fee to be paid for each hospital/children's hospital shall
be as set forth in section
3-1-1-7 of this code.
   B.   Each original application and renewal application shall be accompanied
by a certification from the Illinois department of public health setting forth
the approved number of beds relative to the hospital/children's hospital.
   C.   A separate license shall be required for a children's hospital
hereunder, notwithstanding the fact that said children's hospital may be
affiliated with and/or located on the same property as a hospital. (Ord. 07-04-
14)
8-11-5: CODE COMPLIANCE:
The building or buildings used or to be used as a hospital/children's hospital
shall comply with all applicable village code provisions, including, but not
limited to, all provisions relating to building construction, zoning, fire
prevention, health and sanitation. In addition, all hospitals/children's
hospitals shall be operated and maintained in full compliance with all
applicable rules and regulations of the Illinois department of public health
(77 Illinois administrative code section 250.110 et seq.) as well as all
applicable state and federal laws. (Ord. 07-04-14)
8-11-6: INSPECTIONS:
Every hospital/children's hospital shall at all times be open to inspection by
the authorized representatives of the village, whenever and as often as the
village shall deem proper. (Ord. 07-04-14)
8-11-7: REPORTS FILED:
The village shall annually file a report with the Illinois department of public
health, setting forth whether the hospital(s)/children's hospital(s) licensed
by the village is/are being operated and maintained in full compliance with
this chapter. (Ord. 07-04-14)
8-11-8: PENALTIES FOR VIOLATIONS:
Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of this chapter shall
be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00), and a separate and distinct offense shall be
considered as having been committed for each and every day on which said
violation continues. In addition to said fine, the license revocation
provisions of section
3-1-6 of this code shall be applicable to a hospital/children's hospital
license. (Ord. 07-04-14)
CHAPTER 12
SMOKING IN PUBLIC PLACES
SECTION:
8-12-1: Prohibition
8-12-1: PROHIBITION:
   A.   Except as hereinafter provided, in accordance with the terms and
provisions of the smoke free Illinois act 1 , as now existing or hereafter
amended, which is adopted by reference herein, smoking and the use of
electronic cigarettes in public places or places of employment within the
village is hereby prohibited.
   B.   Pursuant to section 65 of the act, which permits municipal regulations
to be more restrictive than the act, the following additional restrictions
shall apply within the village:
      1.   Smoking and the use of electronic cigarettes are prohibited within
fifteen and one-half feet (151/2') of any entrance to a public place or place
of employment; and
      2.   Smoking and the use of electronic cigarettes are prohibited in
enclosed common areas and hallways of multi-unit residential and condominium
buildings.
   C.   A person who smokes or uses an electronic cigarette in an area where
smoking and the use of electronic cigarettes are prohibited under this section
shall be fined in an amount that is not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00), nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). A person who
owns, operates or otherwise controls a public place or place of employment that
violates the provisions of this section shall be fined not less than two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), or more than five hundred dollars ($500.00)
for the first offense, not less than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a
second offense, and not less than two thousand five hundred dollars ($2,500.00)
for each subsequent offense occurring within one year from the date of the
first offense. (Ord. 16-02-08)
 
Notes
1 1. 410 ILCS 82/1 et seq.
CHAPTER 13
SNOW REMOVAL REGULATIONS
SECTION:
8-13-1: Snow Removal Required
8-13-2: Penalty
8-13-1: SNOW REMOVAL REQUIRED:
Every owner, lessee, tenant, occupant or other person having charge of any
business premises in the Village, including a building or lot utilized for
business purposes, abutting upon any public way or public place, and every
owner, agent or manager of a rental dwelling as defined in section
6-5B-7 of this Code shall utilize their best efforts to remove snow and ice
from the sidewalk in front of such business premises, or rental dwelling
sidewalk and parking facility, as quickly as possible on the day on which said
precipitation falls or by ten o'clock (10:00) A.M. on the day following an
ongoing snow or ice event.
In case the snow and ice on the sidewalk, or parking facility ancillary to the
use by a rental dwelling, shall be frozen so hard that they cannot be removed
without injury to the pavement, the person having charge of any building
premises, or rental dwelling, as aforesaid shall cause the sidewalk abutting
the said premises, to be strewn with ashes, sand, sawdust, salt or some similar
suitable material and shall, as soon thereafter as the weather shall permit,
thoroughly clean said sidewalk. (Ord. 18-05-17)
8-13-2: PENALTY:
Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be advised of his
violation on the first occurrence and may be fined not less than fifty dollars
($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each
subsequent offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each
day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord. 18-05-17)
CHAPTER 14
RECYCLING FOR MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURES 1
SECTION:
8-14-1: Definitions
8-14-2: Non-Mandatory Recycling Area
8-14-3: Maintenance Of Recycling Area
8-14-4: Reserved
8-14-5: Penalty
 
Notes
1 1. This chapter shall be effective July 1, 2012.
8-14-1: DEFINITIONS:
For purposes of this chapter:
   MULTI-FAMILY STRUCTURE: A building with more than one residential living
unit which does not participate in the village of Oak Lawn curbside refuse,
recyclables and landscape waste collection and disposal services.
   OWNER: Any person or entity such as a condominium or homeowners'
association, jointly and severally having an ownership interest in the property
or being otherwise responsible for refuse or garbage collection. (Ord. 12-09-
29)
8-14-2: NON-MANDATORY RECYCLING AREA:
Owners of multi-family structures shall maintain a recycling area for residents
located within a common area in or near the building and consisting of bins or
other containers for the purpose of collecting and recycling items including,
but not limited to:
   A.   Paper:
      Chipboard or paperboard.
      Corrugated cardboard.
      Junk mail.
      Kraftbags.
      Magazines and catalogs.
      Newspaper.
      Telephone directories.
   B.   Nonpaper:
      Aluminum foil/formed containers.
      Clear/colored glass bottles/jars.
      Clear/colored HDPE bottles.
      Clear/colored PET bottles.
      Metal food and beverage cans. (Ords. 12-09-29, 20-08-22)
8-14-3: MAINTENANCE OF RECYCLING AREA:
The owner shall maintain the recycling area including the containers and/or
bins in a clean, sanitary, and litter free manner. (Ord. 12-09-29)
8-14-4: RESERVED:
Repealed by Ord. 25-07-11.
8-14-5: PENALTY:
Any person or entity found to be in violation of any of the provisions of the
chapter shall be subject to a fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and
not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) per violation. (Ords. 12-09-29, 20-
08-22)
TITLE 9
PUBLIC WAYS AND PROPERTY
CHAPTER 1
STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND PUBLIC WAYS
ARTICLE A. GENERAL PROVISIONS
SECTION:
9-1A-1: Village Responsibility, Supervision
9-1A-2: Streets Village Property
9-1A-3: Street Construction Requirements
9-1A-4: Building Construction, Sidewalks And Parkways Required
9-1A-5: Repairs, Maintenance Required
9-1A-6: Barricades
9-1A-7: Parking Strip Beautification
9-1A-8: Numbering Of Premises
9-1A-9: Encroachments
9-1A-10: Erection Of Poles, Wires; Permission Required
9-1A-11: Stairways, Openings; Permit Required
9-1A-12: Prohibited Acts, Conditions
9-1A-13: Dumpsters On Public Rights Of Way
9-1A-14: Camping Prohibited In Public Places
9-1A-1: VILLAGE RESPONSIBILITY, SUPERVISION:
   A.   Village Responsibility Declared: It is hereby declared that the village
has no responsibility to construct a street or streets within the village at
village expense and that the obligation of the village is to maintain and
repair village streets after they have been constructed under the supervision
of the director of office of quality control.
   B.   Supervision Generally, Enforcement: All public streets, alleys,
sidewalks and other public ways in the village shall be under the supervision
of the public works department. Said department shall be charged with the
enforcement of all ordinance provisions relating to such public places, except
traffic ordinances, and is hereby authorized to enforce such ordinances. (1951
Code 6-1-8, 6-5-1; Ord. 81-12-19; 1985 Code)
9-1A-2: STREETS VILLAGE PROPERTY:
   A.   Permission Required To Create, Close: All streets, public alleys,
public easements and thoroughfares in the village shall be the property of the
village under the control and management of the president and board of
trustees; and no additional streets, easements or alleys shall be created and
no existing streets or alleys shall be closed without the permission of the
village board.
   B.   Conveyance To Accompany Dedication: When any plat is submitted to the
village board for approval or when any portion of land is to be dedicated to
the village for a public thoroughfare, such dedication or plat shall be
accompanied by an instrument conveying full title to the village, instead of
easement rights, in the portion to become a public thoroughfare. (1951 Code 6-
1-1, 6-1-2)
9-1A-3: STREET CONSTRUCTION REQUIREMENTS:
   A.   Datum Adopted: All elevations shall be referred to the city of Chicago
datum.
   B.   Grades: Except as otherwise provided in title 5 of this code relating
to subdivisions, grade levels prevailing at the time this code becomes
effective shall be the official grades for all thoroughfares flanked by one or
more houses; provided, however, that in any block where no houses are located,
no grade level will be deemed to exist. Prior to erection of any edifice in any
block where no grade level is established, the owner or contractor erecting
such edifice shall make application to the village board for the establishment
of a grade level. The term "grade level" with regard to existing levels shall
be understood to mean the crown of any thoroughfare currently maintained by the
village, county or state.
   C.   Widths Of Streets: All streets in the village shall be of the widths
prescribed by the president and board of trustees.
   D.   Location Of Curb Lines: The curb line of all streets shall be set by
the village board. (1951 Code 2-8-3, 6-1-3, 6-1-6)
9-1A-4: BUILDING CONSTRUCTION, SIDEWALKS AND PARKWAYS REQUIRED:
   A.   Public sidewalks shall be installed on all public rights of way as per
village requirements by any building contractor or permittee. If the existing
sidewalk is in bad repair or cracked, the public sidewalk shall be replaced by
the permittee. All such construction or replacement shall be in accordance with
sections
6-1G-1 through
6-1G-3 of this code.
   B.   The public parkway shall be planted in grass and trees in all R-1, R-2,
R-3, planned R-1, R-2 and R-3 districts. Driveways crossing the parkway shall
be permitted, but no parking of vehicles shall be allowed, nor shall the
parkway be blacktopped, stoned or concreted other than the required public
sidewalks and access driveways. In other zoning districts, the parkway shall be
planted in grass and trees where required by this section. (1969 Code 6-39;
Ord. 94-10-44)
9-1A-5: REPAIRS, MAINTENANCE REQUIRED:
   A.   Repairs Required, Supervision: All public streets, alley and sidewalk
pavement shall be kept in good repair. Such repair work, whether done by the
village or by the abutting owner, shall be under the supervision of the public
works department and shall be performed in accordance with sections
6-1G-1 through
6-1G-3 of this code.
   B.   Maintenance Of Parkways: It shall be the duty of each person residing
on property abutting on the village streets to maintain the area between his
lot line and the curb line free from weeds and other noxious herbage or matter
1 . Any person notified by the public works department to remove such offensive
matter from the area fronting upon his place of residence and failing to comply
therewith within seven (7) days shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
   C.   Notice Of Defects, Village Employees: It shall be the duty of every
village officer or employee, becoming cognizant of any defect in any street,
alley or sidewalk, or any obstruction thereof, to report the same to the public
works department as soon as possible. (1951 Code 6-1-5, 6-1-13, 6-1-14; 1985
Code; Ord. 94-10-94)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 8, chapter 6 of this code.
9-1A-6: BARRICADES:
   A.   Barricades Required:
      1.   Any person laying or repairing any pavement on a street, sidewalk or
other public place, or making an excavation or opening in any such place shall
maintain suitable barricades to prevent injury to any person or vehicle by
reason of the work. Such barricade shall be protected by lights at nighttime.
      2.   Any defects in such pavement shall be barricaded to prevent any such
injury; and any person properly maintaining any opening or excavation in any
such place shall guard such opening or excavation while the same remains open
by proper barricades and lights.
   B.   Disturbing Barricades, Warning Lights: It shall be unlawful to disturb
or interfere with any barricade or lights lawfully placed to protect or mark
any new pavement or excavation or opening in any public street, alley or
sidewalk. (1951 Code 6-1-17, 17-4-14)
9-1A-7: PARKING STRIP BEAUTIFICATION:
   A.   Permission To Beautify: The village hereby grants a revocable
permission for each citizen to beautify the portion of land owned by the
village and located between his premises and the adjoining curb line; provided,
however, that no encumbrance other than bushes, grass, flowers, trees,
decorative rocks, and fences be established thereon. The permission to beautify
granted herein shall include all other rights of possession exercisable against
all but the duly appointed or elected representatives of the village acting in
official capacity.
   B.   Trespass: An action for trespass may be brought by the landowner whose
property adjoins the parkway strip described in subsection A of this section
with respect to trespasses upon said parkway strip adjoining his property,
exclusive of the area occupied by the public sidewalk.
   C.   Obstructing Drainage Ditches: All open drainage ditches in the streets
shall be left open by the individual property owner and shall not be
obstructed. (1951 Code 6-1-4; 1985 Code)
9-1A-8: NUMBERING OF PREMISES:
Each building or premises in the village shall be designated by a number, which
number shall be visible in the front thereof and be of such size and clarity as
to be easily deciphered from the curb line of the street. A number shall be
assigned to each house by the director of office of quality control. The owner
of any house or building in the village who does not ascertain and post his
house number in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall be guilty
of a misdemeanor. (1951 Code 6-1-7; Ord. 81-12-19)
9-1A-9: ENCROACHMENTS:
   A.   Generally: Except as otherwise specifically allowed in this chapter, it
shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any building or structure that
encroaches upon any public street or property.
   B.   Street Improvements, Encroachment Regulations: The village of Oak Lawn
and/or Cook County and/or the state of Illinois, acting by and through its
department of public works and buildings, division of highways, have entered
into agreements relative to certain street improvements as follows, with
project right of way lines and encroachment plans being on file with the
village:
      87th Street between Cicero Avenue and Harlem Avenue.
      95th Street from 54th Avenue to New England Avenue.
      West 95th Street from 49th Avenue to 54th Avenue.
      Harlem Avenue.
      Illinois Route 50 (Cicero Avenue), known as FAP Route 128, state section
(50YZ-1,461,3182)WRS-1(83), village section 83-00131-00-WR.
      Southwest Highway between 95th Street and Ridgeland Avenue. (1951 Code 6-
1-19, 16-1; Ords. 67-16-4, 69-5-14, 75-4-8, 76-14-28, 80-16-35, 84-11-29, 06-
15-91)
9-1A-10: ERECTION OF POLES, WIRES; PERMISSION REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to erect or maintain any poles or wires on or over any
public street, alley or other public way without having first secured
permission as required by article E of this chapter. (1951 Code 6-1-24; Ord.
06-15-91)
9-1A-11: STAIRWAYS, OPENINGS; PERMIT REQUIRED:
It shall be unlawful to construct or maintain any opening or stairway in any
public street, sidewalk or alley without a permit from the village board. All
such lawfully maintained openings shall be guarded by a suitable strong cover
or a railing, to the approval of the public works department. (1951 Code 6-1-
128; 1985 Code)
9-1A-12: PROHIBITED ACTS, CONDITIONS:
   A.   Obstructions: It shall be unlawful to:
      1.   Generally: Cause, create or maintain any obstruction of any street,
alley, sidewalk or other public way, except such as may be specifically
authorized by ordinance or by the public works department.
      2.   Selling, Displaying Goods: Use any street, sidewalk or other public
place, as space for the display or sale of goods or merchandise.
      3.   Obstructing Drains: Obstruct any drain in any public street or
alley.
   B.   Deposits On Streets, Sidewalks:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to deposit on any street, public sidewalk or
alley, any material which may be harmful to the pavement thereof, or any waste
material, or any glass, or any articles which may do injury to any person,
animal or property.
      2.   Coal, merchandise or other materials may be deposited in streets,
sidewalks or alleys preparatory to delivery or use, provided such deposit does
not reduce the usable width of the:
         a.   Roadway at such point to less than eighteen feet (18'), and
provided that such material or coal, other than material to be used in actual
building construction, shall not be permitted to remain on such street for more
than three (3) hours.
         b.   Walk to less than four feet (4'), and provided that no such
article shall remain on such walk for more than one-half (1/2) hour.
      3.   Any such material or coal shall be guarded by lights if the same
remains upon any street during nighttime.
   C.   Damaging Pavements, Streets:
      1.   Damaging, Defacing Pavements: It shall be unlawful to:
         a.   Walk upon or drive any vehicle or animal upon, or injure any
newly laid street or sidewalk pavement while the same is guarded by a warning
sign or barricade, or to knowingly injure any soft, newly laid pavement.
         b.   Write or mark any signs or advertisements on any pavement.
      2.   Vehicles Injuring Streets: No tractor, traction engine, motor truck
or other vehicle shall be operated across, over or along any street in the
village, if such vehicle has on the periphery of any of the road wheels any
block, stud, flange, cleat, ridge, lug, or any projection of metal or wood
which projects radically beyond the tread or traffic surface of the tire;
except that this prohibition shall not apply to tractors or traction engines
equipped with what is known as crawler type tractors, when the same does not
contain any projections of any kind likely to injure the surface of the road,
nor to tractors, traction engines and similar vehicles which have upon their
road wheels V-shaped, diagonal or other cleats arranged in such a manner as to
be continuously in contact with the road surface. In no event shall the surface
of any street be used as an area or space for turning any tractor or other farm
machinery in carrying on or performing any farming operations upon the adjacent
land. Provided, that nothing in this section contained shall prohibit the
operation of tractors, traction engines or motor trucks across any street in
order to reach adjacent lands if the street is protected by putting down solid
planks or other suitable devices to prevent such vehicle from injuring the
surface of the street.
   D.   Cellar Doors Above Sidewalk Surface: No cellar door shall rise or
project above the surface of the sidewalk.
   E.   Playing Games: It shall be unlawful to play any games upon any street,
alley or sidewalk, where such games cause unnecessary noise, or interfere with
traffic or pedestrians. (1951 Code 6-1-12, 6-1-15, 6-1-18, 6-1-20, 6-1-21, 6-1-
22, 6-1-23, 6-1-27, 16-1, 17-4-5; 1985 Code)
9-1A-13: DUMPSTERS ON PUBLIC RIGHTS OF WAY:
   A.   Definition: For the purposes of this section, the word "dumpster" shall
be defined as any roll-off container, used for the collection of garbage and
debris, which, when transported, is transported by way of a truck equipped with
an industrial roll-off hoist.
   B.   Location: Any dumpster used within the village, when not being
transported, shall be located only on private property. In cases of undue
hardship, where it is not feasible to locate a dumpster on private property in
conjunction with its use for the collection of garbage and debris, any person,
firm or corporation, upon notification to the village public works department,
shall be allowed to locate said dumpster on a street or parkway, as determined
by the public works department, provided the following conditions are complied
with:
      1.   The dumpster shall be located on skids so not to cause damage to the
roadway or parkway;
      2.   The dumpster shall be surrounded by warning barriers with flashing
lights; and
      3.   The dumpster shall only be located on the roadway or parkway between
the hours of eight o'clock (8:00) A.M. and four o'clock (4:00) P.M.
   C.   Penalty: Any person, firm or corporation violating the provisions of
this section shall be fined not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00). (Ord.
86-15-60)
9-1A-14: CAMPING PROHIBITED IN PUBLIC PLACES:
   A.   Definitions:
   CAMP FACILITY: Includes, but is not limited to, tents, tarpaulins, cots,
beds, boxes or cartons, hammocks, makeshift shelters, cardboard, sleeping bags,
bedding, blankets, mattresses, any other temporary physical shelter or sleeping
equipment, and portable stoves or other cooking paraphernalia.
   CAMP OR CAMPING: To place, erect, maintain, pitch or occupy camp facilities
for sleeping, storing personal property, or other habitation purposes.
   PUBLIC PLACE: Any public property owned by the village of Oak Lawn,
including, but not limited to, any public street, public right of way, public
alleyway, public parking lots, public passageway, publicly owned or maintained
