9-4C-12-1: Definitions
9-4C-12-2: Protection From Auxiliary Water Supply
9-4C-12-3: Administration; Enforcement
9-4C-13: Use Of Groundwater As A Potable Water Supply; Prohibition
9-4C-14: Use Of Fire Hydrants By Unauthorized Personnel; Permit Required
9-4C-1: SERVICE SUBJECT TO CONDITIONS OF CHAPTER:
Every consumer of water shall take the same upon the conditions prescribed by
this chapter. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-2: RIGHT TO SHUT OFF WATER RESERVED:
The Village reserves to itself, through its President and Board of Trustees,
the right to shut off the water supply of any consumer, at any time, without
preliminary notice, and all consumers of water shall be subject, at all times
to this reservation and right. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-3: RIGHT OF ENTRY OF PERSONNEL, OBSTRUCTIONS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Ready Access: The Director and every person authorized by him, all
meter readers and inspectors shall have ready access to the premises, place or
buildings where water is furnished for the purpose of reading, examining,
testing and repairing meters and examining and testing the consumption, use and
flow of water, and examining fixtures and pipes, at any time between the hours
of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day.
   B.   Interfering With, Obstructing Village Officers: It shall be unlawful to
interfere with, prevent or obstruct the Director or such other person in his
work hereunder. No person shall in any manner obstruct, or cause to be
obstructed, the free access of any duly authorized officer or employee of the
Village to any stop cock shut off valve, water meter, remote reading device and
associated wiring, buffalo or shutoff box or connection with any water main or
service pipe by means of any coal, lumber, brick, building material, or by any
other means or device whatsoever, or to prevent free access thereto by such
officer or employee whenever such officer or employee shall desire access
thereto. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-4: WATER CONNECTION REQUIREMENTS, PERMITS:
   A.   Application For Service Required; Contents: Any person desiring to make
any connection with the Village water system or plant, or use water therefrom,
shall first make application to the Director upon a blank form or forms to be
furnished by the department. Said application shall contain an agreement on the
part of the applicant that all rules and regulations, conditions and provisions
of any ordinance relating to the water and sewer system will be complied with;
that all water rates, assessments and rents, and all fines and penalties
assessed, charged or imposed against said applicant or the property described
in said application will be paid.
   B.   Issuance Of Connection Permit: When the applicant hereunder has
complied with all the provisions of the ordinances of the Village, a permit
shall then be issued by the Director authorizing the connections to be made and
specifying the size thereof.
   C.   Plumber To Perform Connection Work: All plumbing and plumbing work and
all excavating, filling and replacement of pavement shall be done by a plumber
authorized by this Code and the ordinances of the Village to do such plumbing;
provided, however, all such replacement of pavement shall be done by the
Village in accordance with the provisions of this Code or other applicable
ordinances. The permit shall authorize any such plumber to do such plumbing and
plumbing work as is described in the permit.
   D.   Village To Tap Main: Whenever any permit for a connection with the
water mains of the Village is issued hereunder, the Director or an employee of
the Village designated for the work by the Director, shall tap the main of said
system where such connection is to be made and shall insert the corporation
cock. The plumber is required to furnish and install tapping sleeve and install
the corporation cock for any service one and one-half inches (11/2") to two
inches (2").
   E.   Size, Depth, Type Of Pipe:
      1.   Minimum Size Of Connections: No connection with any water main of
the Village shall be of less than three-fourths inch (3/4"). For larger size
taps special prices may be made.
      2.   Depth Of Connection Pipe: The connection from the main to the
service cock shall be placed at least five feet (5') below the level of the
ground, and the copper pipe (type K) shall be laid in a straight line on solid
ground to prevent breakage from unsettled ground.
      3.   Type Of Service Pipe: The pipe to be used in connection of the
service pipe from the shutoff box to the meter shall be of type K copper pipe
of the same specifications as prescribed for the service pipe between the water
main and the shutoff box.
   F.   Proximity Of Water Service To Other Trenches: No water service shall be
laid nearer than eighteen inches (18") from a parallel trench.
   G.   Breaking Seals Placed By Department: No seal placed by the department
for the protection of any meter, remote reading device, valve, fitting or other
water connection shall be defaced or broken except on written authority from
the Director.
   H.   Manner Of Connection: Each water service pipe shall be connected with
the main water pipe and shall extend horizontally at right angles with said
main water pipe to a point at least eighteen feet (18') from the centerline of
the street and shall be provided with a brass stop cock of not less than three-
fourths of an inch (3/4") in diameter to be installed within a telescopic
shutoff box of the best quality of cast iron or first grade steel pipe.
   I.   Shutoff Required, Location: There shall be a shutoff provided for every
connection or top, which shutoff must be in what is commonly called a buffalo
box and shall be located as near the outer sidewalk edge as conditions will
permit. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-5: METERS:
   A.   Required: All water consumers supplied by the Village shall be supplied
water through water meters only. The Director shall in all cases determine the
kind and pattern of water meters to be adopted and no other kind shall be
installed at any time.
   B.   Ownership, Purchase: All meters used in connection with the water and
sewer system shall be the property of the Village and shall be purchased by the
Village.
   C.   Placement, Location Of Meters:
      1.   Water meters shall be located at such place and in such manner as
the Village, through the Public Works Department, shall direct. Such meters
shall be placed in accordance with specifications to be prescribed by the
Village.
      2.   Each and every meter shall be installed inside of the building,
structure or premises to which the meter applies. Said area of installation
must be heated so as to prevent the freezing of water flowing through said
meter and damage to said meter at all times whether premises is occupied or
not.
   D.   Stop Cock Or Valve Required: A stop cock or valve shall be placed on
each side of each water meter.
   E.   Tampering With Meters: After a water meter is placed, only officers or
employees of the department shall be allowed to repair, remove or in any manner
interfere with the same. No person shall prevent or deny any access to any
authorized officer or employee to read, inspect, repair, convert or replace any
water meter or reading device. If an inspection or the automatic reading
network reveals that a meter and/or buffalo box has been removed, or if there
is evidence of tampering with the meter or seal, or buffalo box, then a fine of
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first violation and seven hundred
dollars ($700.00) for subsequent violations shall be imposed on the owner of
the property for which such meter, reading device, and buffalo box is
installed. The owner of the property shall be served with a written notice
stating the notice of the violation and providing for the violation to cease
immediately. If a violation is not ceased within twenty four (24) hours of the
service of notice, the Village shall have the right to cut off the water supply
to such property, and shall not again be permitted to be turned on until such
owner of the property shall have paid to the Village the penalty stated above
and the cost and expense of cutting off and turning on such water supply.
   F.   Responsibility For Repairs, Liability For Damage: The cost of keeping
each water meter in repair shall be paid by the person upon whose application
such meter was installed or repaired, as soon as the bill therefor is
presented. The person upon whose application any meter is installed shall be
liable for any breakage or any loss or damage to such meter in any way, except
by ordinary use and wear, and the cost of making good such loss or damage to
such meter in any way, shall be paid by the person upon whose application such
meter was installed or repaired, as soon as the bill for same is presented, and
the amount thereof shall be a lien against the premises for which said meter
was installed to the extent and with the same effect as water rates.
   G.   Request For Water Meter Testing: Any customer who disputes the accuracy
of the water meter serving their property may request that such water meter be
tested. Upon payment to the Village of a testing fee, in the amount of three
hundred dollars ($300.00), the disputed water meter will be removed and
replaced with a like type meter by representatives of the Village and will be
delivered to a testing facility designated by the Village. The meter will be
tested in accordance with the American Water Works Association Meter Testing
Procedures. If, after such testing, the water meter proves to be within limits
set forth by the American Water Works Association, the fee paid shall be
retained by the Village to cover the costs of removal, testing, and
reinstallation of the meter. If, after such testing, the meter over records in
aggregate amount exceeding limits defined by the American Water Works
Association Meter Testing Procedures, the meter shall be replaced at no cost to
the customer, and the testing fee shall be refunded in full. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-6: SERVICE PIPE REQUIREMENTS, SPECIFICATIONS:
   A.   Installation, Maintenance, Size: Every person supplied with water from
the Village water system shall, at his own cost and expense, have installed and
kept in repair all pipes leading from the buffalo or shutoff box to his
building, structure or premises which is supplied with water through such
service pipe. All service pipes laid from the water main to the buffalo or
shutoff box, and from the buffalo or shutoff box to the building, structure or
premises, shall not be less than three-fourths inch (3/4") internal diameter.
   B.   Protection From Freezing, Breaking, Rupture: All water service pipes
shall be so laid so as to prevent freezing, breaking or rupture by settling.
   C.   Pressure Test Of Service Pipes: All water service pipe installed of
size three-fourths inch (3/4") internal diameter to two inch (2") internal
diameter shall withstand a test of seventy five (75) pounds pressure for a
period of ten (10) minutes without leaking. All water service pipe installed of
size three inch (3") internal diameter or larger shall withstand a test of one
hundred fifty (150) pounds pressure for a period of one hour with an acceptable
loss of five (5) pounds within the one hour period.
   D.   Responsibility For Repairs: All repairs to service pipes and
connections therefrom shall be at the expense of the owner or tenant of the
premises supplied, excepting repairs on the section of the pipe included
between the corporation cock at the main and the curb cock in the parkway.
   E.   Gooseneck Required: A gooseneck shall be provided for each water
service pipe and must be supported by means of brick built up from the bottom
of the trench.
   F.   Inspection, Approval Of Service Pipes: All water service pipes and
connections shall be inspected and approved by the Director or other persons
under his direction, and no such service pipes shall be covered until they have
been so inspected; provided, however, that the provisions of this subsection
shall not apply to work done under the jurisdiction of the Board of Local
Improvements.
   G.   Service Pipes Supplying More Than One Premises: No service pipe shall
be laid or used to supply water to two (2) or more distinct premises or
buildings unless separate stop cocks for each of the premises or buildings
shall be placed outside of such premises in the parkway and a permit shall be
obtained for each service. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-7: PRESSURE INCREASING DEVICES:
No booster pump or other apparatus intended to increase water pressure shall be
installed unless an approved reduced pressure principle backflow preventor
assembly (RPZ valve) and/or a tank or reservoir be provided between the meter
and such pump or apparatus. Said RPZ valve shall be properly drained and in
compliance with all Village Plumbing Codes. Said tank or reservoir shall be
covered, and shall be provided with a vent or overflow to atmosphere, and shall
be so designed as to prevent a direct hydraulic connection between the meter
and the pump or pressure increasing apparatus. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-8: ALTERATIONS IN WATER FACILITIES:
No alteration, change of location or addition of any kind shall be made to any
water meter, water cock or service pipe, connected in any way with the Village
supply to any building or premises, without first obtaining a written permit
from the Village Director. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-9: SPECIAL CONNECTIONS FOR FIRE PROTECTION:
Any person who is a regular consumer, may be permitted by the Director to make
special connections with the street mains, together with hydrants and house
cocks, to be used in case of fire. For such permit, and for all water used for
fire purposes, there will be no charge, but all such work in connection with
the sewer and water system must be done by the Village or under the direction
of the Director of Public Works and the Oak Lawn Fire Department. (Ord. 19-11-
26)
9-4C-10: WATER USE RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Furnishing Water To Others: No person, whether owner or occupant, in
possession or control of any building, structure or premises into which water
is supplied through the Village water system shall be allowed, without
permission from the Director, to supply other persons or families, or to supply
water from such building or premises to any building, structure or premises. If
any person violates any of the foregoing provisions of this section, the supply
of water to the building, structure or premises, shall be shut off and stopped
forthwith, and the water shall not be turned on to such building, structure or
premises from which it was cut off until there shall have been paid to the
Village such sum of money as the President and Board of Trustees shall deem
properly due the Village.
   B.   Unauthorized Use Of Water: No person not duly authorized shall turn on
any service cock, or use water therefrom when so turned on, and the person so
using or wasting water shall be liable to pay therefor at the regular water
rates without discount.
   C.   Using Water From Fire Hydrants: All hydrants or plugs placed in the
Village for fire purposes are hereby declared to be the public hydrants, and no
person, except such as have been authorized by the Director, shall open or draw
water therefrom, or in any manner interfere with same except in case of fire.
   D.   Fraudulent Representations, Misuse Or Waste Of Water: If after the
water supply shall have been turned on to any building, structure or premises,
it shall be found that fraudulent representations have been made by an
applicant for such water supply or that water is being used in or upon such
building, structure, or premises for purposes not set forth in the application
for such water supply, or that there is wilful and unreasonable use or waste of
water, the proper officer or employee of the Village shall have the authority,
and it shall be his duty, to cut off and stop the supply of water to such
building, structure or premises forthwith, and the water shall not be turned on
to such building, structure or premises until the person responsible for such
fraudulent representation or for such use of water or wilful or unreasonable
waste thereof shall pay to the Village such additional sum of money for such
water supply or on account of such unreasonable waste of water as the President
and Board of Trustees shall find properly to be due the Village.
   E.   Restrictions On Lawn Sprinkling And Other Water Uses:
      1.   Subject to the two (2) tier emergency restrictions set forth below,
in order for the Village to comply with the Illinois Department of
Transportation's "Rules and Regulations for the Allocation of Water from Lake
Michigan" dated January 1985, as amended November 3, 1988, commencing from May
15 through September 15 of each year, it shall be unlawful for any person: a)
to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens, except
between the hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
or seven o'clock (7:00) P.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) P.M. on an odd/even
basis (on odd calendar days if the last digit in the street address is odd or
on the even calendar days if the last digit in the street address is even); or
b) to use an automatic lawn sprinkler or irrigation system for the purpose of
watering lawns or gardens, except between the hours of twelve o'clock (12:00)
midnight and five o'clock (5:00) A.M. on an odd/even basis.
Under emergency conditions, as determined by the President or the President and
Board of Trustees based on the recommendation of the Village's Director of
Public Works relative to the operational capacity of the Village's water
distribution system, the demands placed on the system by the users and the risk
of damage to or failure of the system, it shall be unlawful for any person to
use water for: a) the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens, or b) an
automatic lawn sprinkler or irrigation system to water lawns or gardens, except
during the permitted days and hours set forth below:
         a.   Tier I (conservation emergency): Sprinkling or irrigation of
lawns or gardens shall be permitted only on an odd/even basis between the hours
of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and eleven o'clock (11:00) A.M.
         b.   Tier II (total ban): Sprinkling or irrigation of lawns or gardens
(manually or by an automatic lawn sprinkler or irrigation system) is
prohibited.
The President or the President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Oak
Lawn, or their designee, shall provide notice by telephone, facsimile
transmission, e-mail, United States mail, messenger delivery or personal
service to the Mayor/President or the Manager or Administrator, or one of their
designees, to each municipality that purchases water from the Village whenever
one of the tier I and tier II restrictions is in effect; the notice shall
specify the type of tier emergency restriction and the duration of such
restriction. Upon receipt of notice from the Village that such an emergency
restriction is in effect, the Mayor/President, or his or her designee, shall
provide the same notice in accordance with subsection E3 of this section of the
necessity to limit or suspend the use of water within the municipality for
sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purpose
(s) under the municipality's own code.
The President, or his or her designee, shall provide notice in accordance with
subsection E3 of this section whenever the President or the President and Board
of Trustees limit or suspend the use of water within the Village for the
sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special purpose
(s) under this chapter.
      2.   The Village reserves the right to further limit the use of water for
the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or for any other special
purposes whenever the President and Board of Trustees shall determine that the
public exigencies require such action. If public exigencies so require, the
President may unilaterally take such action prior to the earliest opportunity
available for consultation with the Board of Trustees.
      3.   Whenever the President or the President and Board of Trustees limit
or suspend the use of water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and
gardens or for any other special purpose(s), it shall be unlawful for any
person to use water for the sprinkling or irrigation of lawns and gardens or
for any other special purpose(s) designated, other than during the times
allowed for such use(s) of water, provided that said person has been given
notice of said limitation on, or the suspension of, the use of water, from the
Village, by telephone, facsimile transmission, e-mail, United States mail,
messenger delivery or personal service. In addition, the Village shall post the
notice of the water use restriction, including the type and duration of such
restriction, within the customary posting place in the Village Hall, on the
Village's cable access television channel, its website and in any other medium
normally used by the Village to communicate information of public concern to
the residents and public.
   F.   Violation: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be
fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00) for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed
committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. (Ord.
19-11-26)
9-4C-11: FIRE HYDRANTS:
   A.   Jurisdiction And Supervision: The Public Works Department, under the
direction of the Director of Public Works and such other officers and employees
as may be from time to time appointed, shall have supervision, management and
control of the inspection and maintenance of all fire hydrants, both public and
private, controlled by the Village. The Village shall inspect, at no charge to
the property owners, all fire hydrants which are located on private property
within the corporate limits of the Village at least twice per year.
   B.   Right Of Entry Of Personnel: The Director of Public Works and every
person authorized by him shall have ready access to the premises for the
purpose of testing and maintaining the fire hydrants at any time between the
hours of seven o'clock (7:00) A.M. and six o'clock (6:00) P.M. of any day. It
shall be unlawful to interfere with, prohibit or obstruct the Director or such
other persons in his work hereunder.
   C.   Obstructing Village Officers: No person shall in any manner obstruct or
cause to be obstructed the free access of any duly authorized person or
employee of the Village to any fire hydrant located within the Village. All
repairs to any domestic or fire line water services which must be made on
private property are the responsibility of the property owner to properly
maintain and repair. If any person in the employ of the Village observes any
leak or other damage in any domestic or fire line water service, he shall
immediately notify the property owner to make whatever repairs are necessary
within twenty four (24) hours or less. If the proper repairs are not made
within the twenty four (24) hour limit, the Village may, at its option,
discontinue service to that property until such time as the proper repairs are
made.
   D.   Hydrants Declared Public: All fire hydrants placed within the corporate
limits of the Village are hereby declared to be public hydrants, and no persons
except such as have been authorized by the Director shall open or draw water
therefrom, or in any manner interfere with same except in case of fire.
   E.   Accessibility Of Hydrants: It shall be unlawful for any person to
restrict the access to any fire hydrant within the Village by any trees,
shrubs, bushes, weeds, plants, fences or any other means, unless he has first
secured in writing, permission from the Director.
   F.   Location And Type Of Hydrants: The Director shall determine the type
and location of all fire hydrants located within the Village.
   G.   Inspection Procedures, Report: All fire hydrants located within the
Village corporate limits shall be inspected as indicated in subsection A of
this section. All inspections and repairs, when required, shall be conducted in
accordance with the American Water Works Association Manual M-17.
A copy of the report of the findings of the Public Works Department and the
results of its inspection shall be forwarded to the property owner stating, but
not limited to, the type of inspection made, the results of those inspections,
any repairs which have been made and the charges for same. Such report shall be
dated and signed by the person making the inspection. This report shall
guarantee the condition of the fire hydrant at the time of inspection only. The
Village assumes no liability for any damages which may occur through accident
or act of God between inspections, which may render the fire hydrant
inoperative. If any property owner or his agent observes any fire hydrant which
may have been damaged by accident or act of God, he shall immediately notify
the Water Division to make whatever repairs are necessary.
   H.   Painting Of Hydrants: The Public Works Department shall, as necessary,
paint each and every fire hydrant located on private property. Payment for same
shall be as hereinafter provided in subsection J of this section.
   I.   Responsibility For Restoration: Whenever during the course of repairs
it becomes necessary for the Public Works Department to in any way excavate,
dig or otherwise disturb the ground around a fire hydrant, the responsibility
for restoring the ground to its original condition shall lie with the owner of
the property. The Village shall backfill the excavated area and place four
inches (4") of topsoil over the entire excavated area and leave same in a
reasonable condition so as to allow the planting of grass or sod.
   J.   Charges For Repairs: If any fire hydrant which is located on private
property is determined to be in need of repairs and/or maintenance, the Public
Works Department is hereby authorized to make any and all such repairs to
maintain a fire ready operation of said fire hydrant, and shall bill the owner
of the property for the actual costs of all labor and materials expended to
make the necessary repairs.
      1.   All charges for the repairs or painting of any fire hydrants located
on private property shall be due and payable on or before twenty (20) days
after the date when statements of such charges are returned and shall become
delinquent if remaining unpaid thereafter.
      2.   It shall be the duty of the Director to cause statements for these
charges to be delivered within ten (10) days after the actual completion of the
work.
      3.   Whenever any charges for the work, as outlined herein, are remaining
unpaid for a period of more than thirty (30) days from the date of the
statement, the water, at the option of the Director, shall be turned off from
the premises of such delinquent premises and the service shall not be restored
until all bills and arrears have been paid.
      4.   Such delinquent charges are liens upon the real estate. It shall be
the duty of the Director of Public Works, upon the request of the department,
to file said lien against the real estate in the Office of the Recorder of
Deeds or Registrar of Titles as provided for in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes
5/11-139-8 of the Illinois Municipal Code.
   K.   Violations Of Provisions: Any violations of this section shall be
punished as provided in section
1-4-1 of this Code. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-12: CROSS-CONNECTION AND BACKFLOW PROTECTION:
9-4C-12-1: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this section
9-4C-12, the following definitions shall apply unless the context clearly
indicates or requires a different meaning.
AIR GAP SEPARATION: A physical break between a supply pipe and a receiving
vessel. The air gap shall be at least double the diameter of the supply pipe
measured vertically above the top rim of the vessel, and in no case less than
one inch (1").
APPROVED CHECK VALVE: A check valve that seats readily and completely. It must
be carefully machined to have free-moving parts and assured watertightness. The
face of the closure element and valve seat must be bronze composition, or other
noncorrodible material which will seat tightly under all prevailing conditions
of field use. Pins and bushings shall be of bronze or other noncorrodible,
nonsticking material, machined for easy, dependable operation. The closure
element (e.g., clapper) shall be internally weighted or otherwise internally
equipped to promote rapid and positive closure in all sizes where this feature
is obtainable.
APPROVED DOUBLE CHECK VALVE ASSEMBLY: An assembly of at least two (2)
independently acting approved check valves including tightly closing shutoff
valves on each side of the check valve assembly and suitable leak detector
drains plus connections available for testing the watertightness of each check
valve. Unless otherwise authorized by the Director of Public Works, a pressure
relief valve, rated at no more than fifty (50) pounds per square inch greater
than the water service pressure, shall be installed on the downstream side of
the double check valve assembly.
APPROVED REDUCED PRESSURE PRINCIPLE BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE: A device
incorporating two (2) or more check valves and an automatically operating
differential relief valve located between the two (2) checks, two (2) shutoff
valves, and equipped with necessary appurtenances for testing. The device shall
operate to maintain the pressure in the zone between the two (2) check valves,
less than the pressure on the public water supply side of the device. At
cessation of normal flow the pressure between the check valves shall be less
than the supply pressure.
In case of leakage of either check valve, the differential relief valve shall
operate to maintain this reduced pressure by discharging to the atmosphere.
When the inlet pressure is two (2) pounds per square inch or less, the relief
valve shall open to the atmosphere thereby providing an air gap in the device.
To be approved, these devices must be readily accessible for maintenance and
testing and installed in a location where no part of the device will be
submerged. Unless otherwise authorized by the Director of Public Works, a
pressure relief valve rated at no more than fifty (50) pounds per square inch
greater than the water service pressure, shall be installed on the downstream
side of the reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device.
APPROVED WATER SUPPLY: Any water supply approved by, or under the public
supervision of the Director of Public Works. In determining what constitutes an
approved water supply, the Director shall have the final judgment as to its
safety and potability.
AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY: Any water supply on or available to the premises other
than the Village water supply.
CONSUMER: Any person to whom water is sold and furnished from the Village water
supply by the Village.
CONTAMINATION: An impairment of the quality of the Village water supply by the
presence of any foreign substance (organic, inorganic, radiological or
biological) to a degree which creates a hazard to the public health through
poisoning or through the spread of disease.
CROSS-CONNECTION: Any unprotected connection between any part of the Village
waterworks system used or intended to supply water for drinking purposes, and
any source or system containing water or substances that are not or cannot be
approved as safe, wholesome, and potable for human consumption.
DIRECTOR: The Director of Public Works of the Village or his authorized
representative(s).
PERSON: Any natural person, firm, association, organization, partnership,
trust, or association of persons, joint venture, corporation, or company.
PREMISES: Integrated land area, including improvements thereon, undivided by
public thoroughfares or water distribution mains of the Village where all parts
of the premises are operated under the same management and for the same
purpose.
PROTECTIVE DEVICE: Any of the following devices:
   A.   Air gap separation;
   B.   Approved reduced pressure principle backflow prevention device; or
   C.   Approved double check valve assembly.
SERVICE CONNECTION: The terminal end of a service connection from the Village
water supply at its point of delivery to the consumer. If a meter is installed,
service connection means the downstream end of the meter. No unprotected
takeoffs from the service line ahead of any meter or backflow protective device
located at the point of delivery to the consumer shall be permitted.
WATER SUPPLY OF VILLAGE OR VILLAGE WATER SUPPLY: An approved water supply sold
and delivered to consumers' premises through the waterworks system of the
Village. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-12-2: PROTECTION FROM AUXILIARY WATER SUPPLY:
   A.   All potable water systems shall be protected from contamination due to
backflow of contaminants through plumbing connections, fixtures or
appurtenances by compliance with those provisions of the Illinois Plumbing Code
and Illinois Pollution Control Board Regulations pertaining to such backflow.
If in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code or in the judgment of the
Director, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of
the public water supply system, the Director will give notice to the water
customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer
shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in
a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental
Protection Agency and all applicable local regulations, and shall have
inspections and tests made of such approved devices upon installation and as
required by the Illinois Plumbing Code, Illinois Environmental Protection
Agency and local regulations.
   B.   Any cross-connection control device installed pursuant to this section
shall be approved by the Director prior to installation or the name of the
manufacturer or the device to be installed shall appear on a list of approved
manufacturers and devices maintained and available for public viewing at the
Office of the Director.
   C.   No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the Village may enter the supply or distribution system of the
Village, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the
Director and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency.
   D.   It shall be the duty of the Director to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of commercial, industrial and other properties served
by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to
the public water supply may exist. Such surveys and investigations shall be
made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two (2)
years, or as often as the Director shall deem necessary. Records of such
surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least
five (5) years.
   E.   The approved cross-connection control device inspector shall have the
right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to
the distribution system of the Village for the purpose of verifying the
presence or absence of cross- connections, and the Director or his authorized
agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served
by a connection to the distribution system of the Village for the purpose of
verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross-
connection control inspection. On demand, the owner, lessees or occupants of
any property so served shall furnish to the Director any information which he
may request regarding the piping system or systems, or water use, on such
property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the
discretion of the Director, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper
connections as provided in this chapter.
   F.   All users of the water supply of the Village are also subject to the
rules and regulations of the Village pertaining to cross- connection control
which shall be promulgated by the Director. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-12-3: ADMINISTRATION; ENFORCEMENT:
   A.   The Director shall deny or discontinue, or take such other
precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of
contamination of the public water supply distribution mains, after reasonable
notice to the occupants thereof, the water service to any premises wherein any
backflow prevention device required by this chapter or the rules and
regulations of the Village is not installed, tested, maintained and repaired in
a manner acceptable to the Director, or if it is found that the backflow
prevention device has been removed or bypassed, or if an unprotected cross-
connection exists on the premises, or if a low pressure cut-off required by
this chapter or the rules and regulations is not installed and maintained in
working order.
   B.   Water service to such premises shall not be restored until the consumer
has corrected or eliminated such conditions or defects in conformance with this
chapter and the rules and regulations and to the satisfaction of the Director,
and paid a fee for resuming water service in the amount stipulated in section
9-4B-5 of this chapter.
   C.   Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the
Director is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public
water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written
notification of the cause of disconnection. Immediate disconnection without
notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated
contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the
reasonable opinion of the Director or the Illinois Environmental Protection
Agency, such action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or
pollution of the public water supply.
   D.   Neither the Village, the Director, nor the Village's agents or assigns
shall be liable to any customers of the Village for any injury, damages or lost
revenues which may result from termination of said customer's water supply in
accordance with the terms of this chapter or the Village's rules and
regulations, whether or not said termination of the water supply was with or
without notice.
   E.   The consumer responsible for back siphoned material or contamination
through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs
through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or
repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of
cleanup of the potable water supply system.
   F.   Any person found to be violating any provision of this chapter or the
rules and regulations adopted pursuant thereto shall be served with written
notice stating the notice of the violation and providing a reasonable time
limit for the satisfactory correction thereof. The offender shall, within the
period of time stated in such notice, permanently cease all violations.
   G.   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter or the rules
and regulations adopted pursuant thereto in addition to the fine provided by
this Code, shall become liable to the Village for any expense, loss or damage
occasioned by the Village by reason of such violation, whether the same was
caused before or after notice. (Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-13: USE OF GROUNDWATER AS A POTABLE WATER SUPPLY; PROHIBITION:
   A.   Except for such uses or methods as are in existence on or before May
13, 1997, the use of, or attempted use of, groundwater, from within the
corporate limits of the Village, as a potable water supply, by the installation
or drilling of wells or by any other method, is hereby prohibited, including at
points of withdrawal by the Village.
   B.   For purposes of this section, "potable water" is any water used for
human or domestic consumption, including, but not limited to, water used for
drinking, bathing, washing dishes, preparing foods, watering lawns, or watering
gardens in which produce intended for human consumption is grown.
   C.   Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to
a fine not to exceed seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each violation.
(Ord. 19-11-26)
9-4C-14: USE OF FIRE HYDRANTS BY UNAUTHORIZED PERSONNEL; PERMIT REQUIRED:
   A.   It shall be unlawful for any person, except a duly authorized officer,
agent or employee of the Village, to cause water to flow from any public or
private fire hydrant without a fire hydrant use permit issued by the Director
of Public Works, or his/her designee.
   B.   Each applicant for a fire hydrant use permit shall be required to
deposit with the Village the sum of two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for the
use of a large hydrant meter and hydrant wrench, or two hundred fifty dollars
($250.00) for the use of a small hydrant meter and hydrant wrench. The fire
hydrant meter must be installed by the applicant and maintained in good
condition for the duration of the period during which the fire hydrant is in
use. Upon completion of the fire hydrant use, the hydrant meter and hydrant
wrench shall be returned to the Village in good operating condition. Water use
recorded on the hydrant meter shall be charged at the rates specified in
subsection C of this section, to which shall be added a minimum daily fee of
six dollars ($6.00) for the use of the large hydrant meter, and three dollars
($3.00) for the use of the small hydrant meter, excluding weekends and
holidays. These charges shall be deducted from the aforementioned deposit, and
the balance of the deposit shall be refunded upon return of the hydrant meter
and hydrant wrench. Any damages to the hydrant meter or hydrant wrench shall
also be deducted from the deposit before refund is made. Any damages to the
Village's water system caused by the careless opening and closing of hydrants
shall also be paid by the applicant from the deposit, or otherwise, if in
excess of the deposit balance.
   C.   Water used from any fire hydrant shall be billed and charged at a rate
per one thousand (1,000) gallons or portion thereof, designated by the Water
Rate Ordinance in effect at the time the permit is issued.
   D.   A fire hydrant use permit shall be valid for a period of thirty (30)
days or date otherwise agreed upon from the date of issuance. Within three (3)
days of the expiration of a fire hydrant use permit, the permittee shall return
the fire hydrant meter and hydrant wrench to the Village. If the permittee
fails to do so, a written notice to return the hydrant meter and hydrant wrench
shall be forwarded to the permittee, by first class U.S. mail, at the address
indicated on the fire hydrant use permit application. If the permittee fails to
return the hydrant meter and hydrant wrench to the Village within seven (7)
days of the date of said notice, the permittee shall be deemed to have
purchased said hydrant meter and hydrant wrench from the Village for the amount
of the deposit referenced in subsection B of this section, and the Village
shall retain the entire deposit. The retention of said deposit, however, shall
not relieve the permittee from his/her/its obligation to pay for the cost of
the actual amount of water used by the permittee. (Ord. 19-11-26)
ARTICLE D. SEWERS
SECTION:
9-4D-1: Stormwater Sewer Defined
9-4D-2: Sanitary Sewer Required
9-4D-3: Permits Required, Fees
9-4D-4: Discharging Sanitary, Industrial Waste To Storm Sewers
9-4D-5: Draining Storm And Surface Water To Sanitary Sewer
9-4D-6: Notice, Inspection Of Sewer Connection
9-4D-7: Street Openings
9-4D-8: Manholes And Gravel Basins
9-4D-9: Garage Drainage, Public And Private
9-4D-10: Manual Of Procedures For Administration Of Metropolitan Sanitary Sewer
Permit Ordinance
9-4D-11: Extraneous Flows Into Sanitary Sewer System
9-4D-1: STORMWATER SEWER DEFINED:
In this article the term "stormwater sewer" shall be construed to mean a
conduit or sewer which carries storm and surface waters and drainage, but
excludes wastewater, sewage and industrial wastes. (Ord. 94-3-10)
9-4D-2: SANITARY SEWER REQUIRED:
No building for habitation shall be erected on any lot or parcel of land within
the village unless a functioning sanitary sewer is provided to serve said lot
or parcel of land. (Ord. 132)
9-4D-3: PERMITS REQUIRED, FEES:
   A.   For Work Affecting Sewers: No house drain or private sanitary sewer for
connection to the general sewage system of the village shall be laid, nor any
of the work in connection therewith commenced or prosecuted, nor shall any
excavation under or around any sewer be made, nor shall any person lay, alter
or disturb any part of any sewer or drain connected with any sewer belonging to
the village, without first having obtained a written permit for such work.
   B.   Sanitary Sewer Connection Permit, Fee: No person shall connect a house
sewer system to the sanitary sewers in any street, alley or easement without
having obtained a permit therefor from the village office. The charge for such
permit shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) plus an inspection fee of one
hundred dollars ($100.00); provided, however, that when the lateral sewer to
which the connection is to be made was constructed and paid for by said person
desiring such connection, only the inspection fee shall be charged.
   C.   Stormwater Sewer Connection Permit, Fee: No person shall connect any
stormwater sewer system to the stormwater sewers in any street, alley or
easement without having obtained a permit therefor from the village office. The
charge for such permit shall be three hundred dollars ($300.00) plus an
inspection fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00); provided, however, that when
the lateral stormwater sewer to which the connection is to be made was
constructed and paid for by said person desiring such connection, only the
inspection fee shall be charged. (1951 Code 5-5-1, 21-12-1; Ords. 67-10-27, 77-
38-71, 83-26-77, 94-3-10, 08-17-46, 08-19-55)
9-4D-4: DISCHARGING SANITARY, INDUSTRIAL WASTE TO STORM SEWERS:
No person shall permit, make or cause to make, a connection or otherwise
discharge sanitary sewer water or industrial wastewater into any storm sewer
located in the village. (1951 Code 5-5-2, 5-5-3, 21-12-5; Ords. 550, 67-12-30,
69-5-13)
9-4D-5: DRAINING STORM AND SURFACE WATER TO SANITARY SEWER:
No storm or surface water from any house shall be permitted to drain into any
public sanitary sewer. As used in this section, the term "house" shall also
include any store building, apartment building, or other principal structure
upon any parcel of land. (1951 Code 21-12-7)
9-4D-6: NOTICE, INSPECTION OF SEWER CONNECTION:
A written notice of intention to make a connection with a public sewer shall be
filed at the office of the director of public works at least twenty four (24)
hours, exclusive of Sundays and holidays, before such connection is made. Every
such connection shall be left uncovered until it has been inspected and
approved by the director, or an inspector from his office. (1951 Code 21-12-3;
1985 Code)
9-4D-7: STREET OPENINGS:
The provisions of chapter 1, article C of this title shall apply to any street
openings made in connection with sewer work. (1951 Code 21-12-2)
9-4D-8: MANHOLES AND GRAVEL BASINS:
   A.   Where it is necessary to make a change in direction of the house sewer
between the building and the public sewer, such change of direction shall be
made by means of a manhole to be constructed as the director shall direct.
   B.   All manholes and gravel basins shall be constructed of concrete, either
monolithic or block, composed by volume of one part of Portland cement, two (2)
parts sand and four (4) parts gravel or crushed stone, mixed with sufficient
water. They shall be circular in section, with an interior diameter of three
feet (3') except that the top shall be drawn into two feet (2') beginning at a
point three feet (3') below the top so as to fit and support the cover. The
walls of such manhole or gravel basin shall be four inches (4") in thickness if
built monolithic, or five inches (5") if built of blocks with full joints of
mortar composed of one part of Portland cement to two (2) parts of sharp clean
sand, mixed with sufficient water. Each manhole or gravel basin shall be
provided with a six inch (6") concrete floor with the invert, if any, molded
smoothly in the concrete or formed of sections of vitrified pipe imbedded in
the concrete. Each said manhole or gravel basin shall be provided with a cast
iron cover and cast iron or concrete frame. The floor of all gravel basins
shall be three feet (3') below the flow line of the outlet. (1951 Code 21-12-8)
9-4D-9: GARAGE DRAINAGE, PUBLIC AND PRIVATE:
Floor drains of garages shall be connected with the sanitary sewer system. Such
drains shall have intercepting grease traps approved by the director. (1951
Code 21-12-11)
9-4D-10: MANUAL OF PROCEDURES FOR ADMINISTRATION OF METROPOLITAN SANITARY SEWER
PERMIT ORDINANCE:
   A.   Overhead Plumbing Required In Certain Buildings: After December 31,
1970, all new buildings with basements, floors, rooms or occupancy areas below
ground level at the building site and served by a public or private sewer
system within the corporate limits of the village shall have overhead plumbing.
   B.   Footing Drains: Foot drains shall be connected to sump pumps and
discharge shall be made into storm sewers or drainage ditches. No footing
drains or drainage tile shall be connected to the sanitary sewer. After
December 31, 1970, all new construction shall conform to the requirements of
this subsection.
   C.   Sump Pumps: Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge ground wastes
or other storm waters shall be connected to the storm sewer or discharge into a
drainage ditch.
Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge floor drainage or other sanitary
sewage shall be connected to the sanitary sewers. A sump pump shall be used for
one function only, either the discharge of storm water or the discharge of
sanitary sewage.
   D.   Adoption Of Manual Of Procedures: The manual of procedures for the
administration of the metropolitan sanitary district sewer permit ordinance, as
adopted by the president and board of trustees of the metropolitan sanitary
district on September 3, 1970, as amended from time to time, is hereby adopted
by the village of Oak Lawn. Three (3) copies of said manual shall be and remain
on file in the office of the clerk. (1951 Code 71-3-10; 1985 Code)
9-4D-11: EXTRANEOUS FLOWS INTO SANITARY SEWER SYSTEM:
   A.   Prohibited, Defined: It is the purpose of this section that the entry
of extraneous flows into the sanitary sewer system be prohibited and be
discontinued, where such entry may be occurring accidentally or knowingly.
Extraneous flows are those flows, other than domestic sewage or industrial
waste, consisting of ground waters, surface waters, storm waters and other
drainage or clear waters.
   B.   Discharges, Connections Regulated:
      1.   It shall be unlawful to discharge or cause to be discharged,
directly or indirectly, into the sanitary sewer system of the village any
ground waters, surface waters, storm waters or any other extraneous flows.
      2.   It shall be unlawful to make a connection or to maintain or operate
a connection which serves any home, building or any other establishment,
premises or facilities, and which contributes, directly or indirectly, to the
sanitary sewer of the village, any ground waters, surface waters, storm waters
or any other extraneous flows.
   C.   Certain Drains Considered Illegal Connections: All drains or
connections designed or intended to receive and discharge ground waters,
surface waters, storm waters and other drainage, shall be considered illegal
connections if they discharge directly or indirectly into the sanitary sewer
system. Such illegal connections include, but are not limited to, roof drains,
downspouts, footing drains, areaway drains, drain tiles (and sump pumps used to
collect and discharge same), yard drains, catch basins and inlets, and such
connections shall not be allowed to discharge directly or indirectly into the
sanitary sewers.
   D.   Responsibility Of Owner To Maintain Connections To Sanitary Sewer: The
proper maintenance and operation of a building service sewer, house connection
or sanitary sewer line to the point of connection to the municipal sanitary
sewer system shall be the responsibility of the owner of the premises served by
said sanitary sewer pipes. "Maintenance" means keeping the sanitary sewer
connection, sewer lines or other sewer facilities or structures in satisfactory
working condition and good state of repair (including, but not limited to,
preventing any obstructions or extraneous materials or flows from entering said
facilities, protecting said facilities from any damage and keeping same free
from defects or malfunctions), and making necessary provisions and taking
necessary precautions to assure that said sewer facilities are at all times
capable of satisfactorily performing the services and adequately discharging
the functions and producing the final results and purposes said facilities are
intended to perform, discharge or produce. Notwithstanding the foregoing, so as
to ensure the proper restoration of dedicated right of way under the
jurisdiction of the village, where maintenance or repair to the building
service sewer, house connection or sanitary sewer line by the owner of the
premises served by same requires that work be performed in the dedicated right
of way under the jurisdiction of the village, the village shall perform any
necessary street or alley restoration work within said dedicated right of way,
after said maintenance or repair work is complete, and shall perform any grass,
sidewalk, concrete driveway apron or bituminous concrete driveway apron
restoration work within the parkway portion of the dedicated right of way,
after said maintenance or repair work is complete. Any parkway area restoration
work other than as referenced above (e.g., nongrass landscaping, brick paver
driveway apron, stamped concrete driveway apron) shall be the responsibility of
the owner of the premises served by the building service sewer, house
connection or sanitary sewer line that is subject to the maintenance or repair
work.
   E.   Discharges From Roof Drains, Footing Drains And Sump Pumps: All
downspouts or roof drains shall discharge onto the ground or be connected to
storm sewer, drainage ditches or drainage system. Footing drains shall be
connected to sump pumps and discharge shall be made into storm sewers, drainage
ditches or drainage system. Sump pumps installed to receive and discharge
ground waters or other storm waters shall be connected to the storm sewer or
discharge into a drainage ditch or drainage system. Sump pumps installed to
receive and discharge floor drain flow, laundry tubs or other sanitary sewage
shall be connected to the sanitary sewers. A sump pump shall be used for one
function only, either the discharge of storm waters, or the discharge of
sanitary sewage.
   F.   Program To Eliminate Extraneous Flows; Visual Inspections; Corrections
For Compliance:
      1.   Because of their almost instantaneous impact, their injurious
results, substantial contributions, and relative ease of correction, the
village will institute a priority program for the elimination of extraneous
flows entering into the sanitary sewer system through downspouts, roof drains
and other visible or outside connections which are connected directly or
indirectly to the sanitary sewer system.
      2.   Within a period of one year from the date hereof, and at no expense
to the property owner, the village will make visual outside inspections of all
properties within the village, with specific attention to downspouts, roof
drains and other visible or outside connections, and, if requested by the
property owner, the village will enter into the premises to ascertain if
illegal connections are present. Upon completion of the visual outside or
inside inspection, the village public works department, will advise the
property owner in writing if any illegal connections are observed, and will
advise on the manner of corrections for compliance with the provisions of this
section. After the corrections are made, the village will, at no expense to the
owner, make further inspections of the corrections to ensure compliance with
this section.
   G.   Disconnecting Illegal Connections Upon Notice; Fee To Correct
Downspouts:
      1.   Within ninety (90) days after written notice to the property owner
by the public works department, public works director, of the presence of
illegal connections, the property owner shall disconnect all illegal
connections observed and discharges of extraneous flows into the sanitary sewer
system, directly or indirectly, shall be discontinued.
      2.   At the request of the property owner, the village will furnish parts
and labor to correct drainage from downspouts at homes and apartment buildings.
The charge to the property owner for said parts and labor shall be the
village's actual costs.
   H.   Authority To Make Tests And Inspections: In addition to visual
inspection on the outside or the inside of the premises as indicated in
subsection F of this section, the village may make other tests and inspections
of the municipal sewer systems as it deems necessary in order to locate such
illegal connections and sources of extraneous flows as may exist. The village,
at its option, may also invoke other legal powers vested in it or implied by
the statutes for the protection of the health and welfare of the public, or
institute such legal action as it deems necessary to discover and order the
disconnections of any illegal connections that may exist.
   I.   Cost Share Program for Private Property Infiltration and Inflow
Reduction Improvements:
      The Village of Oak Lawn hereby establishes a cost share program for
private property infiltration and inflow reduction and improvements. The
purpose of this program is to reduce the instantaneous impact, injurious
results, and substantial contributions of extraneous flows to the village's
sewer system and to promote the relative ease of correction, which may be
undertaken by certain infiltration and inflow reduction improvements.
As such, the village shall allocate certain funds annually, which the village
in its discretion may provide as a reimbursement to persons who apply and are
approved for financial assistance in relation to performing infiltration and
inflow reduction work at a person's residence which may include, but not be
limited to, disconnection of downspouts from the public sewer system,
disconnection of footing drain pumps from the public sewer system, and
replacement or rehabilitation of defective sewer laterals.
      1.   Beginning on January 1, 2020, following the payment of an inspection
fee, the village will begin to make visual outside inspections of properties
within the village, with specific attention to downspouts, roof drains, and
other visible or outside connections, and if requested by a property owner, the
village will enter into the premises to ascertain if illegal connections are
present. Within five (5) days upon completion of a visual outside or inside
inspection, the village Public Works Director will advise the property owner in
writing, through a summary of findings inspection report, if any illegal
connections are observed and will advise on the manner of corrections for
compliance with the provisions of this section. In addition, the Public Works
Director will issue a proof of inspection certificate to the property owner.
      2.   If there is a determination by the Public Works Director that an
illegal connection exists at the premises, the Public Works Director will
provide the property owner with a copy of this section and the cost share
program for private property infiltration and inflow reduction improvement
("program") application materials. The Public Works Director and/or Village
Manager shall review the application materials submitted by the property owner
to determine if the property owner is eligible for the program.
      3.   If the application of the property owner is approved, the village
and the property owner shall enter into a program agreement providing the terms
and conditions whereby the village and property owner are governed in relation
to the village providing certain reimbursable funds toward the completion of
infiltration and inflow reduction work at the premises. The village shall only
provide funds pursuant to the program agreement following post-construction
verification shall include that the following documents be submitted to the
village:
         a.   A statement attesting to the completion of the infiltration and
inflow reduction work and that all documents provided are true and accurate
copies;
         b.   A complete list of contractors who performed any of the
infiltration and inflow reduction work;
         c.   A scope of work and documentation of all repairs made in relation
to the infiltration and inflow reduction work; and
         d.   A complete accounting of all costs associated with the
infiltration and inflow reduction work; and
All infiltration and inflow reduction work shall meet current village plumbing
and building codes. In addition, the property owner shall agree to allow the
village to re-inspect the premises following the completion of the work.
      4.   The eligibility for cost reimbursements pursuant to this section
will only be for monies spent towards infiltration and inflow reduction work
related to the village's sewer system. As such, monies paid for private
property improvements, building or structural improvements, property
restoration, or landscaping will not be reimbursed through the program. There
shall be no valve-actuate connections between the village's sewer system and
backyard discharge and footing drain disconnection must be physically and
completely disconnected from the village's sewer system.
      5.   The village's allocation of funds will be prioritized to houses in
neighborhoods with higher measured infiltration and inflow volumes as documents
in the village's 2012 Sewer Master Plan. Any amounts reimbursed through the
program shall be up to fifty percent (50%) of the total project cost but not
shall not exceed five thousand dollars ($5,000) per applicant. When the annual
that are allocated pursuant to this section are depleted, the village shall not
issue any additional funds for that calendar year until the allocated funds are
replenished. The total annual funds allocated to the program shall be at the
village's discretion based upon the available budget. All costs reimbursed
issued pursuant to this section shall be capped at three hundred fifty thousand
dollars ($350,000).
   J.   Point of Sale Inspection, Certificate of Inflow and Infiltration
Compliance: No person shall transfer title of real estate located in the
Village as evidenced by the recordation of a deed or assignment of said real
estate, whether investing the new owner with the beneficial interest in or
legal title to said property or merely the possession or use thereof to the new
owner for any purpose, without first obtaining a certificate of inflow and
infiltration inspection from the Village. A certificate of inflow and
infiltration inspection from the Village shall only be required if the transfer
of title to real estate results in the possession of the real estate by a new
person, and if the persons possessing the real estate prior to the transfer no
longer possess it. It is the Village's intent to exclude from the inspection
requirements of this Section all transfers of title to real estate that do not
result in complete changes to possession of the real estate, such as, but not
limited to, transfers to or from trusts where the persons possessing the real
estate do not change and transfers to remove one of several persons on title
where a person remaining on title continues to possess the real estate. The
Village will grant a sewer inspection report upon inspection of the property's
sanitary sewer system and a confirmation certificate if the sanitary sewer
system meets the Village's requirements.
      1.   Inspection Process:
         a.   A person who owns real estate in the Village and is required to
obtain a certification of inflow and infiltration compliance, shall schedule an
infiltration and inflow inspection thirty (30) days prior to seeking a Real
State Transfer Stamp as provided in section
3-2-7 of this Code. The Village or the Village’s authorized representative
shall conduct an inspection to determine whether the property is in compliance
with the requirements of this Chapter. The applicant is responsible for making
the entire real estate and all buildings on the property available for
inspection. The fee for such inspection shall be one hundred dollars ($100).
         b.   If the property is new construction, the infiltration and inflow
inspection will be completed by a Village authorized sewer inspector as part of
the building inspection process. Compliance and Expiration.
         c.   The Village will issue a certificate of infiltration and inflow
inspection upon inspection and when the following private property infiltration
and inflow sources have been corrected in conformance with this Chapter: roof
leaders and downspouts have been properly disconnected from the sanitary sewer
system missing or damaged sanitary sewer cleanout caps have been replaced, and
area or yard drains have been properly disconnected from the sanitary sewer
system.
         d.   The certification of infiltration and inflow inspection is valid
for a period of three (3) years following issuance and used for the sale or
transfer of property.
         e.   The certificate of infiltration and inflow inspection must be
provided to property buyers. The applicant is responsible for providing
potential buyers, gift recipients or other persons to whom it intends to
transfer the title as to the property's receipt of the certificate of
infiltration and inflow inspection and documentation of inspection results.
      2.   Correction Notice:
         a.   Sale of transfer of real property is not permitted by the Village
until a certificate of infiltration and inflow inspection is issued.
         b.   If an inspection discloses that a property is not in accordance
with this Chapter, the applicant must complete corrections to bring the
property in compliance with this Chapter and schedule another inspection.
      3.   Repeat Inspection:
         a.   Upon inspection, if the property is not in conformance with the
obligations and standards as set forth in Chapter, the applicant shall be
entitled to a second inspection. If, as a result of this second inspection, the
Village inspector determines that all violations have been corrected, the
Village shall issue a certificate of infiltration and inflow inspection. The
Village reserves the right to charge an inspection fee for a third inspection.
   K.   Violations; Penalty: Failure on the part of the property owner to
comply with the provisions of subsections A through E and G of this section
shall be considered a violation which, upon conviction, shall be subject to a
fine of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than seven hundred fifty
dollars ($750.00). Each day shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ords. 73-41-80, 74-17-36; 1985 Code; Ords. 99-5-11, 01-17-65, 02-19-82, 19-28-
96, 20-01-06, 20-08-23, 21-02-17, 22-08-26)
ARTICLE E. WATER USE AND CONSUMPTION TAX
SECTION:
9-4E-1: Water Use And Consumption Tax Defined
9-4E-2: Definitions
9-4E-3: Tax Imposed
9-4E-4: Rate Of Tax
9-4E-5: Collection And Payment Of The Tax
9-4E-6: Deposit Of Funds
9-4E-1: WATER USE AND CONSUMPTION TAX DEFINED:
The tax shall be known as the "Water Use and Consumption Tax" and is imposed in
addition to all other taxes imposed by the Village of Oak Lawn, the State of
Illinois or any other municipal corporation or political subdivision of the
State of Illinois. (Ord. 18-10-26)
9-4E-2: DEFINITIONS:
When any of the following words or terms is used in this article, it shall have
the meaning ascribed to it in this section:
FEE: Means the fee, charge, rate or other amount billed to a purchaser for
street rehabilitation. "Fee" does not include: a) any interest or penalties
related to a fee, or b) the tax imposed by this article, or any interest or
penalties related to the tax.
FINANCE DEPARTMENT: Means Oak Lawn Department of Finance.
PERSON: Means any natural individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership,
association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability
company, municipal corporation or political subdivision of the State of
Illinois, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed
by order of any court.
PURCHASER: Means any person who purchases water or sewer service from the
regional water system.
REGIONAL WATER SYSTEM: Means Oak Lawn regional water system.
VILLAGE: Means the Village of Oak Lawn, Illinois. (Ord. 18-10-26)
9-4E-3: TAX IMPOSED:
Except as otherwise provided by this article, a tax is imposed upon the use or
consumption in the Village of water that is purchased from the regional water
system. The ultimate incidence of and liability for payment of the tax is upon
the purchaser. (Ord. 18-10-26)
9-4E-4: RATE OF TAX:
   A.   For water use beginning on January 1, 2025, Section 9-4(E)-4 is hereby
amended to include a tiered tax based on water consumed or used as set forth
below. This tax shall be applied to each billing period.
      1.   0 to 9,000 gallons at a fixed amount of $7.70.
      2.   9,001 to 120,000 gallons at $1.55 per 1,000 gallons.
      3.   120,001 to 240,000 gallons at $2.09 per 1,000 gallons.
      4.   240,001 to 360,000 gallons at $3.05 per 1,000 gallons.
      5.   Over 360,000 gallons at $4.55 per 1,000 gallons. (Ords. 18-10-26,
21-01-10, 21-11-56, 24-21-82, 25-04-08)
9-4E-5: COLLECTION AND PAYMENT OF THE TAX:
The Finance Department shall collect the tax by billing it as a separately
stated item on its unified statement of charges to purchasers of water service.
The purchaser shall pay the tax to the Finance Department on or before the due
date of the Finance Department's first bill that includes the tax. A late
payment is subject to the regulations in section
9-4B-5 of this chapter. (Ord. 18-10-26)
9-4E-6: DEPOSIT OF FUNDS:
All proceeds resulting from the imposition of the tax imposed by this article,
including any interest or penalties related to the tax, shall be deposited in
the Village's General Fund and shall be used to meet the Village's ongoing
financial obligations. (Ord. 18-10-26)
CHAPTER 5
BROADBAND COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM FRANCHISES
SECTION:
9-5-1: Purpose
9-5-2: Definitions
9-5-3: Franchise Requirement, Authority Granted By A Franchise
9-5-4: Terms And Conditions For Each Franchise
9-5-5: Selection Of Grantees
9-5-6: Franchise Agreement
9-5-7: Franchise Fee
9-5-8: Nature Of The System
9-5-8-1: Technical Standards
9-5-8-2: Services
9-5-9: Construction Of The System
9-5-10: Operation And Maintenance Of The System
9-5-11: Rates And Charges
9-5-12: Records And Reports
9-5-13: Indemnification And Insurance
9-5-14: Reviews, Modifications, And Renewal Of The Franchise
9-5-15: Termination Of The Franchise By Reason Of Default
9-5-16: Insolvency Proceedings
9-5-17: Procedures Following Revocation Or Expiration Of Franchise
9-5-18: Hiring And Employment Practices
9-5-19: Prohibition Of Preferential Practices; Other Business Activities
9-5-20: Subscriber Privacy
9-5-21: Sanctions
