Illinois of the exercise by the Village of any of its police powers shall not
diminish, impair, alter, or affect any contractual benefit to the Village or
grantee nor any contractual obligation of the grantee under any franchise
issued hereunder. Any and all rights, powers, privileges and authorizations
arising under this Chapter or any franchise agreement are each and all hereby
declared by the Village and any grantee accepting any franchise hereunder to be
contractual in nature and to be for the benefit of the Village.
   F.   Right to Make Rules and Regulations: There is hereby reserved to the
Village the right to impose rules and regulations, reasonably required, in
order to better carry out the purpose and intent of this Chapter. Before any
such rules and regulations are adopted, the Village shall give notice to the
grantee and afford the grantee an opportunity to be heard. (Ord. 80-14-27)
9-5-23: CONTINUING REGULATION AND ADMINISTRATION BY THE VILLAGE:
   A.   Continuing Supervision by Village Board: The Village Board shall have
continuing supervision over the operation of any franchise granted hereunder.
Routine responsibilities in the administration of this Chapter and any
franchise agreement hereunder shall be performed by the Village Manager.
   B.   Responsibilities Of The Village Manager: The Village Manager shall have
the following responsibilities and duties, together with such other
responsibilities and duties that the Village Board may assign to him:
      1.   Review and audit all reports and filings submitted to the Village as
required hereunder and such other correspondence as may be submitted to the
Village concerning the operation of the BTN and review the rules and
regulations established by each grantee.
      2.   Assure that all rate schedules and rules pertinent to the operation
of the BTN are made available for inspection by the public at reasonable hours.
      3.   Confer and coordinate with each grantee on the interconnection of
the BTN with other similar networks.
      4.   Advise the Board on matters which might constitute grounds for
revocation of the franchise.
      5.   Conduct evaluations of the BTN at least every three (3) years.
      6.   Make recommendations to the Village Board for amendments to this
chapter. (Ords. 80-14-27, 90-6-24, 05-13-40, 17-15-56)
9-5-24: DISPUTES:
At the option of either the Village or the grantee, any matter in controversy
or dispute between the Village and the grantee may be submitted to arbitration
in all cases where the judgment of a court of law could be sought. This option
shall be exercised by serving written notice. Such arbitration shall be
conducted in accordance with the rules of the American Arbitration Association.
(Ord. 80-14-27)
9-5-25: UNLAWFUL ACTS:
   A.   Unlawful Interception Of Communications: It shall be unlawful for any
person to make any unauthorized connection, whether physically, electrically,
acoustically, inductively or otherwise, with any part of a grantee's BTN for
the purpose of enabling such person or any other party to receive any signal,
information or intelligence transmitted over the BTN, without payment to the
grantee of full amount properly due for such signal, information or
intelligence.
   B.   Unlawful Tampering With Equipment: It shall be unlawful for any person,
without the consent of the owner, to wilfully tamper with, remove, or injure
any cable, wires or other equipment used for the distribution of signals,
information or intelligence over a grantee's BTN.
   C.   Penalties: It shall be a misdemeanor punishable by a fine of not more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for any person to violate any of the
provisions of this section. (Ord. 80-14-27)
9-5-26: MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS:
   A.   Compliance With Applicable Laws And Regulations: Each grantee, at its
expense, shall comply with all laws, orders and regulations of Federal, State
and Municipal authorities and with any directive of any public officer pursuant
to the law who shall legally impose any regulation, order or duty upon the
grantee with respect to the franchise.
   B.   Diligence By Grantee: Each grantee shall diligently apply for all
necessary permits and authorizations required in the conduct of its business,
and shall diligently pursue the acquisition thereof, including necessary pole
attachment agreements, and necessary authorizations from the Federal Aviation
Agency to construct such receiving antenna towers as may be required, and any
necessary authorizations or waivers from the FCC, and shall assist the Village
in filing its application to the FCC for waiver of franchise fee limitations.
   C.   Notification To Village Of Certain FCC Communications: Each grantee
shall not apply for any waivers, exceptions or declaratory rulings from the FCC
or from any other Federal or State regulatory agency without prior written
notification to the Village Manager.
   D.   Transfer Of Village's Rights, Powers And Duties: Any right or power in,
or duty impressed upon, any officer, employee, department, or board of the
Village shall be subject to transfer by the Village to any other officer,
employee, department or board of the Village.
   E.   Village's Rights Of Intervention: A grantee shall, at the sole risk and
expense of the grantee, upon demand of the Village made by the Village
Attorney, appear in and defend any and all suits, actions, or other legal
proceedings, whether judicial, quasi- judicial, administrative, legislative, or
otherwise, brought or instituted or had by third persons or duly constituted
authorities against or affecting the Village, its officers, boards,
commissions, agents, or employees, and which arise out of or pertain to the
exercise or the enjoyment of the grantee's franchise or the granting thereof by
the Village; provided, that neither grantee nor the Village shall make or enter
into any compromise or settlement of any claim, demand, cause of action,
action, suit, or other proceeding, without first obtaining the written consent
of the other.
   F.   No Waivers By Village: A grantee shall not be excused from complying
with any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or the franchise agreement
by any failure of the Village, upon any one (1) or more occasions, to insist
upon the grantee's performance or to seek grantee's compliance with any one (1)
or more of such terms or conditions.
   G.   No Recourse Against Village: Except as expressly provided otherwise in
this chapter, the grantee herein shall have no recourse whatsoever against the
Village for any loss, cost, or expense or damages arising out of the terms,
conditions and provisions or requirements of this chapter or because of the
Village's enforcement of this chapter.
The grantee expressly acknowledges that upon accepting the right, privilege and
franchise granted by this chapter, it did so relying upon its own investigation
and understanding of the power and authority of the Village in connection with
the BTN and this chapter. By the acceptance of this franchise, the grantee
agrees that it will not at any time set up against the Village in any claim or
proceeding any provision, condition or term of this chapter as unreasonable,
arbitrary or void or that the Village had no power or authority to make such
provision, term or condition as part of this chapter, except as to those
matters preempted by Federal or State law.
   H.   New Developments: The Village Board may amend this chapter or the
franchise agreement whenever necessary to enable the grantee to take advantage
of any developments in the field of transmission of communications signals
which will afford it an opportunity to more effectively, efficiently or
economically serve its customers; provided, however, that this subsection H
shall not be construed to require the Village to make any such amendment.
   I.   Construction Of Chapter: This chapter shall be construed and
interpreted according to the following principles:
      1.   All ordinances or parts thereof in conflict with the provisions of
this chapter are hereby repealed.
      2.   Words in the present tense include the future.
      3.   Words importing the singular number may extend to and include
plural, words importing the plural number may extend to and include the
singular, and words in masculine gender shall include female gender.
      4.   The specification in this section of principles to apply in the
construction and interpretation of this chapter shall not be a limitation as to
other applicable principles.
      5.   Whenever this chapter shall set forth any time for any act to be
performed by or on behalf of the grantee, such time shall be deeded of the
essence and any failure of the grantee to perform within time allotted shall
always be sufficient grounds for the Village to terminate, cancel and revoke
the grant or use other remedies.
   J.   Reimbursement Of Village Expenses: In connection with the grant of all
franchises, each successful grantee shall reimburse to the Village all actual
expenses incurred by the Village in granting a cable TV franchise, including
expenses incurred for legal services and consultants. Upon receipt of all such
excuses, the Village Manager shall transmit to grantee an itemized listing of
all such expenses and the grantee shall then reimburse Village within thirty
(30) days after receipt such listing. (Ord. 80-14-27)
CHAPTER 6
ELECTRIC AGGREGATION PROGRAM
SECTION:
9-6-1: Electrical Aggregation Plan Of Operation And Governance
9-6-1: ELECTRICAL AGGREGATION PLAN OF OPERATION AND GOVERNANCE:
   A.   The corporate authorities of the village of Oak Lawn hereby are
authorized to aggregate in accordance with the terms of the act residential and
small commercial retail electrical loads located within the corporate limits of
the village, and for that purpose may solicit bids and enter into service
agreements to facilitate for those loads the sale and purchase of electricity
and related services and equipment.
   B.   The corporate authorities of the village of Oak Lawn are granted the
authority to exercise such authority jointly with any other municipality or
county and, in combination with two (2) or more municipalities or counties, may
initiate a process jointly to authorize aggregation by a majority vote of each
particular municipality or county as required by the act.
   C.   The aggregation program for the village of Oak Lawn shall operate as an
opt out program for residential and small commercial retail customers with a
single rate for all customer classes.
   D.   The aggregation program shall be approved by a majority of the members
of the corporate authority of the village of Oak Lawn.
   E.   The corporate authorities of the village with the assistance from the
Illinois power agency and progressive energy group shall develop a plan of
operation and governance for the aggregation program and shall conduct such
public hearings and provide such public notice as required under the act. The
load aggregation plan shall provide for universal access to all applicable
residential customers and equitable treatment of applicable residential
customers, shall describe demand management and energy efficiency services to
be provided to each class of customers and shall meet any requirements
established by law concerning aggregated service offered pursuant to the act.
   F.   As an opt out program, the corporate authorities of the village of Oak
Lawn shall fully inform residential and small commercial retail customers in
advance that they have the right to opt out of the aggregation program. The
disclosure and information provided to the customers shall comply with the
requirements of the act.
   G.   The electric aggregation shall occur automatically for each person
owning, occupying, controlling, or using an electrical load center proposed to
be aggregated in the corporate limits of the village of Oak Lawn, subject to a
right to opt out of the program as described under this section and the act.
   H.   The corporate authorities of the village of Oak Lawn hereby grant the
village president or his designee in writing the specific authority to execute
a contract without further action by the corporate authorities and with the
authority to bind the village with the following limitations:
      1.   A term no longer than thirty six (36) months.
      2.   With an electric price at least ten percent (10%) lower than ComEd
tariffed rates in the June 1, 2012 through May 31, 2013 time frame.
      3.   With a term that the winning electric supplier must match any ComEd
tariffed rate, or allow village residents and small businesses to revert back
to ComEd tariffed rates if the ComEd tariffed rates are ever lower than the
contracted price.
      4.   Winning electric supplier must utilize ComEd as the billing/
invoicing agent.
      5.   The contract contains no early termination fees.
      6.   Village is to be reimbursed for administrative and legal fees up to
one thousand dollars ($1,000.00). (Ord. 12-23-73)
TITLE 10
POLICE REGULATIONS
CHAPTER 1
POLICE DEPARTMENT
SECTION:
10-1-1: Composition, General Duties Of Department
10-1-2: Officers And Employees Of Department
10-1-3: Divisions Of Department
10-1-4: Compensation
10-1-5: Police Training Program
10-1-6: Police Pension Fund
10-1-7: Requirements And Restrictions On Department Members
10-1-8: Duty To Assist Police
10-1-9: DUI Emergency Response Fees
10-1-10: Handi-Cop Program
10-1-1: COMPOSITION, GENERAL DUTIES OF DEPARTMENT:
The police department of the village shall consist of such policemen as may be
appointed. It shall be the duty of each member of the police force to enforce
all orders relative to the preserving of the peace, health and good order and
quiet of the village, and to prosecute all violations of this code and the
ordinances of the village. (1951 Code 3-1; Ords. 68-29-92, 89-16-44)
10-1-2: OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Chief Of Police:
      1.   Appointment, Term: The village manager is authorized to appoint,
suspend or discharge the chief of the police department without the consent of
the board of trustees.
      2.   General Duties: The chief of police shall be the keeper of the
village jail, and shall have custody of all persons incarcerated therein. He
shall keep such records and make such reports concerning the activities of his
department as may be required by statute or by the village board. The chief
shall be responsible for the performance by the police department of all its
functions.
   B.   Marshals: In cases of emergency and in order to do all things necessary
to preserve the peace of the village, the president, with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees, may appoint as many marshals as he shall deem
necessary. Such marshals shall be under the jurisdiction of the chief of police
during the term of their hiring.
   C.   Police Matron: A police matron shall, when necessary, be appointed
according to law. Her duties shall be to assume charge of all female prisoners
who may be in custody.
   D.   Code Enforcement Officer: The code enforcement officer shall be a
civilian, nonsworn officer of the police department and shall be employed for a
maximum of thirty five (35) hours a week as a part time employee.
      1.   Appointment, Term: The chief of police is authorized to appoint,
suspend or discharge the code enforcement officer without the consent of the
board of trustees.
      2.   General Duties: The code enforcement officer shall particularly
enforce village parking regulations, but shall also enforce any other village
ordinances as assigned by the chief of police and shall in relation to said
enforcement, be empowered to issue citations and tickets for violations of this
code.
   E.   Deputy Police Chief: There is hereby established the position of deputy
police chief of the police department. The chief of police shall have the
authority to appoint an individual from the rank of sergeant or above within
the police department to the position of deputy police chief, which shall be an
exempt rank and unclassified position. The individual so appointed to this
position shall receive such extra compensation for the duties of this position
in an amount set, from time to time, by the village board of trustees in the
annual salary ordinance, or as recommended by the police chief and approved by
the village board of trustees.
If a member of the police department is appointed as the deputy police chief
prior to becoming eligible to retire on pension, he or she shall be considered
as if on furlough from the rank he or she held prior to the appointment. If the
deputy police chief resigns, or is discharged as deputy police chief, he or she
may revert to and be established in such prior rank, and thereafter be entitled
to all benefits and emoluments of such prior rank at the discretion of the
chief of police. The village board, by ordinance, and consistent with the
Illinois Compiled Statutes, may prescribe the duties, define the powers, and
fix the term of appointment. The term of office shall be in accordance with the
Illinois Compiled Statutes and at the discretion of the chief of police. The
position of deputy chief of police is specifically exempt from the provisions
of 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-1 et seq. (1951 Code 3-2, 3-3, 3-5,
17-1-9; Ord. 68-25-70; 1985 Code; Ords. 87-12-47, 89-13-30, 92-02-10, 92-08-32,
93-5-13, 94-21-96)
10-1-3: DIVISIONS OF DEPARTMENT:
   A.   Divisions Created, Composition: There are hereby created the following
three (3) divisions of the police department:
      Detective and juvenile division
      Service and training division
      Uniform division
Each division shall consist of one lieutenant and such subordinates as the
chief of police may determine are needed to efficiently carry on the duties and
functions of the respective divisions.
   B.   Assignment Of Personnel To Divisions; Duties And Functions: The chief
of police shall assign the respective lieutenants to each of the divisions as
he may consider qualified by experience and training to properly perform the
duties and functions of the respective divisions. Each division shall perform
such duties and functions as may be assigned and prescribed by the chief of
police. (1951 Code 3-3A; Ord. 65-21-3; 1985 Code)
10-1-4: COMPENSATION:
   A.   Generally: The chief of police and other police officers shall receive
for their services amounts to be fixed by the village board from time to time.
   B.   Marshals: No marshal shall receive any compensation unless on duty by
special order or direction of the chief of police, or in case of emergency, if
ordered to perform duties. The compensation for services as a marshal shall be
prescribed by the village board. (1951 Code 3-7, 3-12)
10-1-5: POLICE TRAINING PROGRAM:
   A.   Election To Participate In State Program: The village hereby elects to
participate in the program provided for in the Illinois police training act,
being 50 Illinois Compiled Statutes 705/1 et seq.
   B.   Certification Required: Before an individual may commence regular
employment as a policeman, he must have been certified by the Illinois local
governmental law enforcement officers training board as having successfully
completed an approved training course as provided by law.
   C.   Completion Of Training Required: Such basic training must be completed
by the trainee within his probationary period of twelve (12) months and
specifically within six (6) months of the date of his initial employment.
   D.   Amendment Of Rules Required: The police department is hereby instructed
and directed to make the necessary amendments to the personnel rules, the
manual of rules of the Oak Lawn police department, and rules of the board of
police and fire commissioners 1 , requiring that any person appointed to the
police department of the village pursuant to the provisions of 65 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/10-2.1-29, and the said Illinois police training act, shall
not become a regular member of the police department until and unless he shall
have completed the approved training course within six (6) months of the date
of his initial employment. (Ords. 66-28-77, 75-36-126)
 
Notes
1 1. See title 2, chapter 6 of this code.
10-1-6: POLICE PENSION FUND:
   A.   Fund Created 1 : There is hereby created a police pension fund in and
for the village for the purpose of providing pensions for members of the police
department under the terms and regulations hereinafter set forth.
   B.   Financing: The board of trustees shall annually levy a tax upon all the
taxable property of the village at the rate on the dollar which will produce an
amount which, when added to the deductions from the salaries or wages of
policemen and receipts available from all other sources as hereinafter referred
to, will equal a sum sufficient to meet the annual requirements of the police
pension fund. The annual requirements to be provided by such tax levy shall be
equal to the reserve prescribed by 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-127. The
tax shall be levied and collected in like manner with general taxes of the
village, and shall be in addition to all other taxes now or hereafter
authorized to be levied upon all property within the village, and shall be in
addition to the amount authorized to be levied for general purposes as provided
by 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8-3-1.
The police pension fund shall consist of the following monies which shall be
set apart by the treasurer of the village:
      1.   All monies derived from the taxes levied hereunder.
      2.   Beginning July 1, 1909, and prior to July 23, 1943, one percent (1%)
of the salary of each policeman (except that prior to July 1, 1921, not more
than $1.00 per month shall be deducted, and except that beginning July 1, 1921,
and prior to July 1, 1927, not more than $2.00 per month shall be deducted),
and beginning July 23, 1943, and prior to July 20, 1949, three percent (3%) of
salary, and beginning July 20, 1949, and prior to July 17, 1959, five percent
(5%) of salary, and beginning July 17, 1959, seven percent (7%) of salary. Such
sums shall be paid or deducted monthly.
      3.   All monies accumulated by the village under any previous legislation
establishing a fund for the benefit of disabled or superannuated policemen.
      4.   Any donations, gifts or other transfers referred to in 40 Illinois
Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq.
   C.   Applicability Of Section: This section is applicable to all policemen
of the village who meet the qualifications set forth in 40 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/3-101 et seq.
   D.   Persons Eligible For Benefits: All policemen and widows or dependents
who qualify under 40 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/3-101 et seq., are eligible
for benefits from the fund. (1951 Code 3-26, 3-27, 3-28, 3-30, 3-32)
 
Notes
1 2. 40 ILCS 5/3-101.
10-1-7: REQUIREMENTS AND RESTRICTIONS ON DEPARTMENT MEMBERS:
   A.   Deliver Prisoners For Trial: In all cases where arrests shall be made,
it shall be the duty of the police officer making the same to take the person
so arrested before the court for trial.
   B.   Preservation Of Order At Polls; Political Activity Prohibited: On all
general and special election days, it shall be the duty of the public officers
or marshals to preserve order at the polls, but in no case shall they interfere
for or against any candidate at any such election.
   C.   Service Of Process: No member of the police department, except the
chief, shall serve any process except on command of the chief of police.
   D.   Frequenting Saloons, Playing Games On Duty: Every police officer and
marshal is hereby prohibited, when on duty, from spending his time in saloons
or public houses, or playing pool, cards, or any other games in such places.
(1951 Code 3-4, 3-6, 3-12)
10-1-8: DUTY TO ASSIST POLICE:
It shall be the duty of any person in the village, when called upon by any
member of the police department, to promptly aid and assist him in the
execution of his police duties. (1951 Code 3-8)
10-1-9: DUI EMERGENCY RESPONSE FEES:
The following costs and charges are hereby established as the village's costs
and charges relative to emergency responses in regard to DUI cases:
 
Emergency Response                 Cost 
(Per Hour Per Vehicle)
Each on scene police officer/squad $47.50
 
(Ord. 17-06-14)
10-1-10: HANDI-COP PROGRAM:
The chief of police is hereby authorized to institute a "handi-cop program"
whereby handicapped individuals may volunteer to assist the police department
in handicapped parking enforcement by taking photographs of motor vehicles
which are illegally parked in handicapped parking places. Prior to instituting
such a program, the chief of police shall prepare a detailed plan for
implementation of the program. Said plan shall include, but not be limited to,
detailed provisions in regard to the screening, training and monitoring of the
volunteer participants. In addition, said plan shall provide that all
volunteers be required to execute an "indemnification of, and waiver and
release of claims against, the village of Oak Lawn" form prior to participating
in the program. The plan, as prepared by the chief of police, shall be approved
by the president and board of trustees prior to the implementation of any such
"handi-cop program". (Ord. 92-08-31)
CHAPTER 2
PARADES AND DEMONSTRATIONS
SECTION:
10-2-1: Short Title
10-2-2: Definition
10-2-3: Exceptions
10-2-4: Permits Required, Contents
10-2-5: Application for Permit; Fee
10-2-6: Standards for Issuance of Permit
10-2-7: Action on Application; Procedure Upon Denial
10-2-8: Revocation of Permit
10-2-9: Notice to Village Officers of Permit Issuance
10-2-10: Compliance With Permit, Regulations
10-2-11: Duty to Carry Permit
10-2-12: Prohibitions and Restrictions
10-2-13: Penalty
10-2-1: SHORT TITLE:
This Chapter shall be known, cited and enforced as the "Parade Ordinance".
(Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-2: DEFINITION:
As used in this Chapter, "parade" means any parade, march, ceremony, show,
exhibition, pageant, demonstration, or procession of any kind, or any similar
display in or upon any street, park or other public place in the Village.
(Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-3: EXCEPTIONS:
This Chapter shall not apply to:
   A.   Funeral processions;
   B.   Students going to and from school classes or participating in
educational activities, providing such conduct is under the immediate direction
and supervision of the proper school authorities;
   C.   A governmental agency acting within the scope of its functions. (Ords.
68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-4: PERMITS REQUIRED, CONTENTS:
   A.   Permits:
      1.   Parades: No person shall engage in, participate in, aid, form or
start any parade, unless a parade permit shall have been obtained from the
President and Board of Trustees.
      2.   Public Assemblies: No open air public meeting, sit-in, camp-in, or
demonstration of ten (10) or more persons shall be held on any public grounds
in the Village until a permit in writing therefor shall first be obtained. The
relevant provisions of this Chapter regarding permits or regulations of parades
shall apply to open air public meetings and/or demonstrations.
   B.   Contents of Parade Permit: Each parade permit shall state the following
information:
      1.   Starting time;
      2.   Minimum speed;
      3.   Maximum speed;
      4.   Maximum interval of space to be maintained between the units of the
parade;
      5.   The portions of the streets to be traversed that may be occupied by
the parade;
      6.   The maximum length of the parade in miles or fractions thereof;
      7.   Such other information as the Chief of Police shall find necessary
to the enforcement of this Chapter. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33; 1985 Code)
10-2-5: APPLICATION FOR PERMIT; FEE:
   A.   Application Required; Fee: A person seeking issuance of a parade permit
shall file an application with the President and Board of Trustees on forms
provided by such officer. There shall be paid at the time of filing the
application for a parade permit a fee of fifty dollars ($50.00), which fee
requirements shall not apply to the following:
      1.   Federally chartered war veterans' organizations;
      2.   Religious, civic or social groups of the Village.
   B.   Time for Filing Permit Application:
      1.   An application for a parade permit shall be filed with the Chief of
Police not less than thirty (30) days nor more than forty five (45) days before
the date on which it is proposed to conduct the parade.
      2.   The Chief of Police, where good cause is shown therefor, shall have
the authority to consider any application hereunder which is filed less than
thirty (30) days before the date such parade is proposed to be conducted.
   C.   Contents of Application: The application for a parade permit shall set
forth the following information:
      1.   The name, address, and telephone number of the person seeking to
conduct such parade.
      2.   If the parade is proposed to be conducted for, on behalf of, or by
an organization, the name, address and telephone number of the headquarters of
the organization, and of the authorized and responsible heads of such
organization.
      3.   The name, address and telephone number of the person who will be the
parade chairman and who will be responsible for its conduct.
      4.   The date when the parade is to be conducted.
      5.   The route to be traveled, the starting point, and the termination
point.
      6.   The approximate number of persons who, and animals and vehicles
which, will constitute such parade; the type of animals and description of the
vehicles.
      7.   The hours when such parade will start and terminate.
      8.   A statement as to whether the parade will occupy all or only a
portion of the width of the streets proposed to be traversed.
      9.   The location by streets of any assembly areas for such parade.
      10.   The time at which units of the parade will begin to assemble at any
such assembly area or areas.
      11.   The interval of space to be maintained between units of such
parade.
      12.   If the parade is designed to be held by, and on behalf of, or for
any person other than the applicant, the applicant for such permit shall file
with the Chief of Police a communication in writing from the person proposing
to hold the parade, authorizing the applicant to apply for the permit on his
behalf.
      13.   Any additional information which the Chief of Police shall find
reasonably necessary in a fair determination as to whether a permit should
issue. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33; 1985 Code)
10-2-6: STANDARDS FOR ISSUANCE OF PERMIT:
The Chief of Police shall issue a permit as provided for hereunder when, from a
consideration of the application and from such other information as may
otherwise be obtained, he finds that:
   A.   The conduct of the parade will not substantially interrupt the safe and
orderly movement of other traffic contiguous to its route.
   B.   The conduct of the parade will not require the diversion of so great a
number of police officers of the Village to properly police the line of
movement and the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police
protection to the Village.
   C.   The conduct of such parade will not require the diversion of so great a
number of ambulances as to prevent normal ambulance service to portions of the
Village other than that to be occupied by the proposed line of march and areas
contiguous thereto.
   D.   The concentration of persons, animals and vehicles at assembly points
of the parade will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection
of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such assembly areas.
   E.   The conduct of such parade will not interfere with the movement of
emergency vehicles.
   F.   The conduct of the parade is not reasonably likely to cause injury to
persons or property, to provoke disorderly conduct or create a disturbance.
   G.   The parade is scheduled to move from its point of origin to its point
of termination expeditiously and without unreasonable delays en route.
   H.   The parade is not to be held for the sole purpose of advertising any
product, goods or event, and is not designed to be held purely for private
profit.
In order to comply to the standard of this Section, the Chief of Police may
issue the permit subject to additional restrictions as to interference between
marchers, compliance with traffic-control signals and the directions of
officers controlling traffic and pedestrian movements. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-7: ACTION ON APPLICATION; PROCEDURE UPON DENIAL:
   A.   Action, Notice of Denial: The Chief of Police shall act upon the
application for a parade permit within five (5) days after the filing thereof.
If the Chief of Police disapproves the application, he shall mail to the
applicant within five (5) days after the date upon which the application was
filed, a notice of his action, stating the reasons for his denial of the
permit.
   B.   Appeal From Permit Denial: Any person aggrieved shall have the right to
appeal the denial of a parade permit to the President and Board of Trustees,
which appeal shall be taken within ten (10) days after notice. The President
and Board of Trustees shall act upon the appeal within fourteen (14) days after
its receipt.
   C.   Alternative Permits Authorized; Acceptance: The Chief of Police, in
denying an application for a parade permit, shall be empowered to authorize the
conduct of the parade on a date, at a time, or over a route different from that
named by the applicant. An applicant desiring to accept an alternate permit
shall, within five (5) days after notice of the action of the Chief of Police,
file a written notice of acceptance with the Chief of Police. An alternate
parade permit shall conform to the requirements of, and shall have the effect
of a parade permit under this Chapter. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-8: REVOCATION OF PERMIT:
The Chief of Police shall have the authority to revoke a parade permit issued
hereunder upon application of the standards for issuance as herein set forth 1
. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
 
Notes
1 1. See Section
  3-1-6 of this Code for permit revocation procedure.
10-2-9: NOTICE TO VILLAGE OFFICERS OF PERMIT ISSUANCE:
Immediately upon the issuance of a parade permit, a copy thereof shall be sent
to the following:
   Chief of Police
   Director of Public Works
   Fire Department
(Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33; 1985 Code)
10-2-10: COMPLIANCE WITH PERMIT, REGULATIONS:
A permittee hereunder shall comply with all permit directions and conditions
and with all applicable laws and ordinances. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-11: DUTY TO CARRY PERMIT:
The parade chairman or other person heading or leading such activity shall
carry the parade permit upon his person during the conduct of the parade.
(Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-12: PROHIBITIONS AND RESTRICTIONS:
   A.   Interfering With Parades, Assemblies: No person shall unreasonably
hamper, obstruct, impede or interfere with any parade or parade assembly, open-
air public meeting, or with any person, vehicle or animal participating or used
in a parade.
   B.   Driving Through Parades: No driver of a vehicle shall drive between the
vehicles or persons comprising a parade when such vehicles or persons are in
motion and are conspicuously designated as a parade.
   C.   Parking On Parade Routes: The Chief of Police shall have the authority,
when reasonably necessary, to prohibit or restrict the parking of vehicles
along a highway or part thereof constituting a part of the route of a parade.
The Chief shall post signs to such effect, and it shall be unlawful for any
person to park or leave unattended any vehicle in violation hereof. No person
shall be liable for parking on a street unposted in violation of this Chapter.
(Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33)
10-2-13: PENALTY:
Any person violating or failing to comply with any provision of this Chapter
shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than seven
hundred fifty dollars ($750.00) for each offense. (Ords. 68-3-2, 68-12-33, 99-
5-11)
CHAPTER 3
ANIMAL CONTROL
ARTICLE A. ANIMALS AND FOWL
SECTION:
10-3A-1: Cruelty To Animals
10-3A-2: Running At Large Prohibited
10-3A-3: Wild Animal Exhibitions, Permit Regulations
10-3A-4: Keeping Certain Animals Prohibited
10-3A-5: Keeping, Selling Live Poultry
10-3A-6: Diseased Animals
10-3A-7: Beehives, Requirements For Maintaining
10-3A-8: Hunting
10-3A-9: Poisoning Animals
10-3A-10: Offensive Premises, Animal Wastes
10-3A-11: Total Number Of Four Legged Animals
10-3A-12: Inoculation Of Cats And Ferrets
10-3A-1: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
Whoever shall be guilty of cruelty to any animal in any of the ways mentioned
in this section, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00):
   A.   By overloading, overdriving, overworking, cruelly beating, torturing,
tormenting, mutilating, or cruelly killing any animal, or causing or knowingly
allowing the same to be done.
   B.   By cruelly working any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal, or
causing, or knowingly allowing the same to be done.
   C.   By unnecessarily failing to provide any animal in his charge or
custody, as owner or otherwise, with proper food, drink and shelter.
   D.   By abandoning any old, maimed, infirm, sick or disabled animal or by
abandoning any animal on any highway or public way or in any other place where
it may suffer injury, hunger or exposure or become a public charge.
   E.   By carrying or driving, or causing to be carried or driven or kept, any
animal in an unnecessarily cruel manner.
   F.   By selling, offering for sale, bartering or giving away living baby
chicks, ducklings or other fowls as pets or novelties when such fowl have been
dyed, colored or otherwise treated to impart an artificial color to them.
Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to prohibit the sale of natural
chicks, ducklings or other fowl or their display in proper brooder facilities
by hatcheries or stores engaged in the business of selling them for commercial
purposes 1 .
Humane officers, police officers, sheriffs and health officers shall seize all
fowl which are sold, bartered or given away or offered for sale, barter or gift
in violation of this subsection and provide the necessary care and attention
for them. Such fowl or pets shall not be returned to the owner until all
expenses for such care and attention have been paid.
   G.   By keeping or using, or in any way being connected with or interested
in the management of, or receiving money for the admission of any person to any
place kept or used for the purpose of fighting or baiting any bull (bullbaiting
is interpreted to include a bloodless or mock bullfight), bear, dog, cock or
other creature. Every person who shall visit such place so kept or used, or who
shall be found therein, shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor
more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   H.   By using or permitting the use of any leg hold animal trap or similar
device with spring activated jaws of the type used for the trapping of
furbearing animals which is capable of inflicting cruelty upon dogs, cats or
other animals, or which constitutes a hazard to small children.
   I.   By using any animal, reptile or bird for the purpose of soliciting any
alms, collection, contribution, subscription, donation or payment of money, or
by using any animal in connection with any business for the purpose of
attracting trade upon any street, highway or public park or at any fair,
exhibition or place of amusement, recreation or entertainment or by owning,
keeping or having in his custody any animal, reptile or bird for any such
purpose. Any person convicted of violating this subsection shall be fined not
more than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00), but no provision of this
subsection shall be construed so as to apply to the exhibition of any animal,
reptile or bird by any educational institution or in connection with any
theatrical exhibition or circus. (Ord. 12-01-06)
 
Notes
1 1. See section
  10-3A-5 of this article.
10-3A-2: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
   A.   At Large: It shall be unlawful for any person owning, harboring,
keeping or in charge of any domesticated animals to permit said domesticated
animal to run at large in the village.
   B.   Dangerous Animals: It shall be unlawful to permit any dangerous animal
of any kind to run at large within the village. The members of the police
department, or any person in the village, are authorized to kill any dangerous
animal of any kind when necessary for the protection of persons or property.
   C.   Violation; Penalty: Any person violating subsection A or B of this
section shall be fined not less than twenty five dollars ($25.00) nor more than
five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
   D.   Impounding; Fee: In addition to the fine set forth in subsection C of
this section, any domesticated animal caught while running at large in any
public place shall be impounded, unless more severe action, as outlined in
subsection B of this section, is required. It shall be the duty of the police
department of the village to impound any domesticated animal found running at
large within the village. Such domesticated animal shall be humanely disposed
of by the police department or relinquished to the animal welfare league, if
not redeemed within seventy two (72) hours after the apprehension of such
domesticated animal. When the owner of the domesticated animal impounded is
known, notice shall be given by telephone or by mail to the last known address.
If the owner of any domesticated animal impounded shall claim such domesticated
animal, supporting such claim by proper evidence of ownership, and shall
exhibit a current, duly issued license for such domesticated animal, where
required, the police department shall redeem such domesticated animal to the
true owner thereof upon receipt of the animal welfare league boarding fee/
impounding fee, and upon receipt of the village impounding fee of fifteen
dollars ($15.00). (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-3: WILD ANIMAL EXHIBITIONS, PERMIT REGULATIONS:
Exhibitions of animals which are ferae naturae in the eyes of the law may be
conducted only upon securing a permit from the president and board of trustees,
and persons conducting such exhibitions shall be required to adequately
restrain, secure and control all wild animals so as not to endanger the health,
safety and welfare of the citizens of the village and/or viewers of the
exhibition. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-4: KEEPING CERTAIN ANIMALS PROHIBITED:
   A.   Livestock, Wild Or Dangerous Animals: It shall be unlawful to keep any
dangerous or wild animals including, but not limited to: live swine, pigs,
horses, ponies, mules, donkeys, cows, calves, sheep, lambs or goats in the
village. It shall further be unlawful for any person to have, keep, maintain or
have in his possession or under his control, within the village, any poisonous
reptile or serpent, or any other dangerous or carnivorous wild animal or
reptile, or vicious or dangerous domesticated animal or any of the following
animals or reptiles: baboons, chimpanzees, gibbons, gorillas, orangutans,
siamangs, bears, cheetahs, crocodilians twelve inches (12") or larger,
constrictor snakes, coyotes, foxes, hyenas, jaguars, leopards, lions, lynxes,
ocelots, margays, piranha fish, pumas, raccoons, tigers and wolves. This shall
not apply to circuses when properly licensed by village officials.
   B.   Noisy Animals: It shall be unlawful to harbor or keep any animal which
disturbs the peace by loud noises at any time of the day or night. (Ord. 12-01-
06)
10-3A-5: KEEPING, SELLING LIVE POULTRY:
It shall be unlawful to keep, sell, or offer for sale, barter, or give away
live baby chicks, ducklings, goslings, pigeons, fowl or other poultry, domestic
or otherwise in the village except in stores or other commercial establishments
engaged in the business of selling baby chicks, ducklings, goslings, pigeons,
fowl or other poultry for commercial purposes, and not less than six (6) of
each of the aforementioned variety shall be sold to any one person 1 . It shall
be unlawful to raise poultry for home or domestic purposes of any kind in the
village. (Ord. 12-01-06)
 
Notes
1 1. See subsection 10-3A-1F of this article.
10-3A-6: DISEASED ANIMALS:
No domestic animal afflicted with a contagious or infectious disease shall be
allowed to run at large, or to be exposed in any public place whereby the
health of man or beast may be affected; nor shall such diseased animal be
shipped or removed from the premises of the owner thereof, except under the
supervision of the health and sanitation officer or of the state veterinarian.
No such diseased animals shall be brought into the village. The health and
sanitation officer or animal control officer shall have the authority to
humanely destroy any stray animal found running at large with symptoms of any
contagious or infectious disease. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-7: BEEHIVES, REQUIREMENTS FOR MAINTAINING:
   A.   It shall be a misdemeanor and nuisance to own or maintain a beehive or
hives within the corporate limits for commercial purposes.
   B.   A person properly licensed by the state may maintain a single,
protected hive for educational purposes or as a hobby by meeting the following
requirements:
      1.   The hive shall be completely surrounded by a six foot (6') high
chainlink or comparable fence which shall be no less than three feet (3') from
said hive at any point.
      2.   The top of the enclosure shall be covered by the same type of
fencing.
      3.   A gate with a lock shall be provided as a means of ingress and
egress.
   C.   Nothing contained herein shall apply to a beehive maintained by a
school for educational or scientific purposes. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-8: HUNTING:
No person shall hunt game or wild fowl within the territorial limits of the
village. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-9: POISONING ANIMALS:
No person shall place, leave or expose, in any place accessible to birds, fowl,
domestic animals, dogs, cats or other such animals with the intent to kill or
harm such birds, fowl, animals, any poisonous substance or ingredient, or any
edible or any other substance or ingredient which has in any manner been
treated or prepared with any poisonous substance or ingredient. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-10: OFFENSIVE PREMISES, ANIMAL WASTES:
   A.   It shall be a misdemeanor and a nuisance to own, use or keep any yard,
pen, place, railroad car or premises, in or upon which animals shall be
confined or kept, so as to be offensive to those residing in the vicinity, or
any annoyance to others.
   B.   No person shall allow or permit any animal owned, housed, under his
control, custody, or subject to his immediate response or call, to defecate or
urinate in the village, or on any alley, roadway or curb in the village, except
on property owned or leased by said person.
   C.   No person shall fail to remove any feces deposited by the person's
animal, except service animals, upon the public ways, within the public places
of the village, or upon the premises of any person other than the owner's
without that person's consent.
   D.   For purposes of this section, the term "control" means any owned animal
that is either secured by a leash or lead, or confined within the premises of
the owner, or confined within a crate or cage or confined within a vehicle, or
within the premises of another person with the consent of that person. (Ord.
12-01-06)
10-3A-11: TOTAL NUMBER OF FOUR LEGGED ANIMALS:
   A.   As of January 13, 2012, no more than three (3) 4-legged animals of
three (3) months of age or older shall be housed or maintained at any residence
within the village. This restriction shall not apply to duly licensed pet
shops, animal hospitals or grooming establishments.
   B.   Should it be determined that a person is housing or maintaining more
than three (3) 4-legged animals, the owner of the premises shall be subject to
a fine of no less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and no more than seven hundred
fifty dollars ($750.00). Each day the violation exists shall be considered a
separate offense.
   C.   If a person lawfully housed or maintained more than three (3) 4-legged
animals prior to January 13, 2012, such animals shall not be subject to
prohibition in this section and the owner will not be subject to fine. In order
to prove that the owner lawfully housed or maintained more than three (3) 4-
legged animals prior to January 13, 2012, the owner must be able to provide
proof a village license for each animal. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3A-12: INOCULATION OF CATS AND FERRETS:
   A.   Every owner of a cat or ferret four (4) months of age or older within
the village shall cause such cat or ferret to be inoculated by, or under the
supervision of, a licensed veterinarian, with a prophylactic vaccine, approved
by the U.S. department of agriculture or the Illinois department of
agriculture, to prevent rabies. This inoculation shall be obtained annually, or
at such other interval that is suggested by the drug manufacturer, provided the
drug has been approved for use by the U.S. department of agriculture or the
Illinois department of agriculture. A certificate of inoculation against rabies
for such animal so inoculated shall be issued by the county rabies inspector,
or by his deputy, or by a licensed veterinarian, showing the date the animal
received the inoculation. The owner's name, the breed, and the name of the cat
or ferret shall be included on such certificate, and will be maintained by the
owner and, upon request, shown to the animal control officer, health inspector,
or a police officer. (Ord. 12-01-06)
ARTICLE B. DOGS AND CATS
SECTION:
10-3B-1: Purpose
10-3B-2: Definitions
10-3B-3: Report, License Required, Fee
10-3B-4: Tag Required, Display
10-3B-5: Running At Large Prohibited
10-3B-6: Dogs And Cats Prohibited From Certain Places
10-3B-7: Impoundment Procedures, Disposal, Redemption Fee
10-3B-8: Rabies Case Procedure
10-3B-9: Dog Bite Procedure
10-3B-10: Accident Report, Assistance
10-3B-11: Cruelty To Animals
10-3B-12: Animal Defecation, Requirements
10-3B-13: Enforcement Of Article
10-3B-14: Vicious And Dangerous Dogs
10-3B-15: Penalty
10-3B-16: Report Of Violation
10-3B-17: Administrative Adjudication Of Violations
10-3B-1: PURPOSE:
The purpose of this article is to promote a harmonious relationship between man
and dogs and cats through the establishment of defined procedures when man and
dogs and cats interact. The defined procedures will include these situations or
conditions:
   A.   Protection of dogs and cats from abuse, neglect, and rabies.
   B.   Provide security of residents from annoyance, intimidation, injury, and
rabies by dogs and cats.
   C.   Establish the village's method of response to residents regarding
situations involving dogs and cats.
   D.   Develop a program designed to encourage responsible dog and cat
ownership. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-2: DEFINITIONS:
For the purpose of this article the following definitions shall apply:
DOG OR CAT OF LICENSING AGE: Any dog or cat which has attained the age of seven
(7) months or which possesses a set of permanent teeth.
OWNER: When applied to the proprietorship of a dog or cat shall include every
person having a right of property in such dog or cat and every person who has
such dog or cat in his keeping.
PROPER CONTROL: A dog or cat shall be deemed under proper control if on the
enclosed premises of its owner or on a leash and under the control of a
responsible person. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-3: REPORT, LICENSE REQUIRED, FEE:
   A.   Every owner of, and every person who harbors or keeps a dog or cat of
licensing age within the limits of the village shall report to the
administrative services department annually within thirty (30) days after
January 1 in each year, his name and address, and the name, breed, color, sex
and age of each and every dog or cat owned or kept by such person, and obtain a
license and a tag for such dog or cat. Such person shall pay the department of
administrative services the sum of five dollars ($5.00) for each dog or cat.
   B.   The owner of any newly acquired dog or cat of licensing age or of any
dog or cat which attains licensing age, shall make application for license and
tag for such dog or cat within ten (10) days after such acquisition or age
attainment.
   C.   Dogs used as guides for blind persons and commonly known as "seeing
eye" dogs, shall be registered as other dogs, except that the owner or keeper
of such dog shall not be required to pay any fee therefor.
   D.   Every owner of a dog or cat within the village shall cause such dog or
cat to be inoculated by, or under the supervision of, a licensed veterinarian,
with a prophylactic vaccine, approved by the U.S. department of agriculture or
the Illinois department of agriculture, to prevent rabies. This inoculation
shall be obtained annually, or at such other interval that is suggested by the
drug manufacturer, provided the drug has been approved for use by the U.S.
department of agriculture or the Illinois department of agriculture. A
certificate of inoculation against rabies for such animal so inoculated shall
be issued by the county rabies inspector, or by his deputy, or by a licensed
veterinarian, showing the date the animal received the inoculation. The owner's
name, the breed, and the name of the dog or cat shall be included on such
certificate, and will be maintained by the owner and, upon request, shown to
the animal control officer, health inspector, or a police officer.
No person shall receive a dog or cat license unless he shall present to the
village department of administrative services a certificate or other statement
from a veterinarian, or other authorized person, that the dog or cat has been
inoculated against rabies.
   E.   The department of administrative services and police department shall
keep a complete registry of all licensed dogs and cats, describing the same by
name, breed, color and sex, and showing the name, address and telephone number
of the keeper, as given, and the number of the village license tag. (Ord. 12-
01-06)
10-3B-4: TAG REQUIRED, DISPLAY:
The village department of administrative services shall provide each and every
year, such number of metal tags as may be necessary (the shape to be changed
every year), having stamped thereon the year for which the tax is paid, the
letters O.L.D.T., and also the number of the tag. It shall be the duty of the
department of administrative services to deliver one of such metal tags to the
person having paid the tax upon such dog or cat, the number of each tag to
correspond with the registry of the dog or cat.
Any person who shall own, keep or harbor a dog or cat of licensing age shall
place upon each such dog or cat a collar or harness with the metal tag securely
fastened thereto. Any owner or keeper of a dog or cat, failing to provide such
collar and tag shall be subject to a fine of not less than ten dollars ($10.00)
nor more than seven hundred fifty dollars ($750.00).
No person, except an officer in the performance of his duties shall remove a
tag from the collar of any dog or cat without the consent of the owner, nor
shall any person attach a tag to a dog or cat for which it is not issued. (Ord.
12-01-06)
10-3B-5: RUNNING AT LARGE PROHIBITED:
It is prohibited for any dog or cat owned, harbored or kept by any persons to
run at large. Any owner, harborer or keeper of such dog or cat is liable for
the prohibited act of running at large by such dog or cat under any
circumstances which precipitate the dog's or cat's engaging in the prohibited
behavior. A dog or cat shall be deemed to be running at large when off the
premises of its owner, or of the person keeping or harboring such dog or cat,
if the dog is not on a leash, tether, chain, rope, or the like, and if such
leash, tether, chain or rope is not held by its owner or other person able to
control such dog.
   A.   Length And Type Of Leash: When being walked on public property, all
dogs must be bound by a leash of no more than five feet (5') in length. Reel
type extender leashes may not be extended for more than five feet (5') while
walking a dog on public property.
   B.   Restriction While On Owner's Property: It shall be prohibited to allow
an unsecured dog to roam an owner's property. While on an owner's property, all
dogs must be restricted to a fence enclosed yard. If the owner's property is
not encompassed by a fence the dog must be restricted by a cage, stake and
chain, or wire dog run. The choice of restriction must be secure enough to
restrict the dog to the owner's property and comply with the provisions of
section
10-3B-11, "Cruelty To Animals", of this article. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-6: DOGS AND CATS PROHIBITED FROM CERTAIN PLACES:
   A.   Public Halls, Food Establishments: It shall be unlawful for any dog or
cat, even though on leash, to be in or enter upon any public hall, restaurant,
confectionery shop, coffee shop, ice cream parlor, soft drink parlor, office,
store, grocery, meat market, bakery or any store or shop for the sale of food,
except any shop for the sale of animal pets, anywhere within the village,
during the time that any of said places or establishments are open for use by
the public or persons entitled to use the same. This provision shall not apply
to "seeing eye" dogs leading blind persons. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-7: IMPOUNDMENT PROCEDURES, DISPOSAL, REDEMPTION FEE:
It shall be the duty of the police department of the village to impound any
stray dog or cat found running at large upon the streets, alleys, public
places, parks, school grounds, or upon property belonging to any person other
than the owner. Such dog or cat shall be humanely disposed of by the police
department or relinquished to the animal welfare league, if not redeemed within
seventy two (72) hours after the apprehension of such dog or cat. When the
owner of the dog or cat impounded is known, notice shall be given by telephone
or by mail to the last known address. If the owner of any dog or cat impounded
shall claim such dog or cat, supporting such claim by proper evidence of
ownership, and shall exhibit a current, duly issued license for such dog or
cat, the police department shall redeem such dog or cat to the true owner
thereof upon receipt of a boarding fee and penalty of ten dollars ($10.00). If
the owner does not have current rabies inoculation or dog or cat license, he
shall be required to deposit a fee to cover the cost of the rabies inoculation
and the dog or cat license, plus payment of the ten dollar ($10.00) redemption
fee.
If a tranquilizer gun is used to apprehend a stray or vicious dog or cat which
cannot be captured by normal means, the village and its agents shall not be
responsible if the animal shall succumb as a result of the use of the
tranquilizer gun. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-8: RABIES CASE PROCEDURE:
Whenever a case of rabies has occurred in the village, the Cook County animal
control administrator shall be notified immediately via a phone call. The Cook
County animal control administrator then shall act to prevent the spread of
rabies. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-9: DOG BITE PROCEDURE:
   A.   The official procedure for dog bite cases shall be as follows:
      1.   When the police department receives information that a person has
been bitten by a dog, the dog's owner shall be instructed to have the dog
examined by his veterinarian within twenty four (24) hours.
      2.   If the dog bite occurred off the dog owner's property or when the
dog was left without proper control, a citation shall be written against the
dog owner.
      3.   The police department shall fill out the Cook County animal bite
report in full and he shall send this report within twenty four (24) hours to
the local public health department or to the Cook County department of animal
control.
      4.   All dogs that bite must be impounded for ten (10) days, following
the first examination.
      5.   Impoundment at home or at a facility under the observation of a
licensed veterinarian shall be dependent upon a current rabies vaccination and
the ability of the dog owner to confine the biting dog.
      6.   When an owner of a biting dog has no personal veterinarian, or
refuses to obtain the services of a veterinarian, the police department shall
have the animal impounded for the ten (10) days.
      7.   A record shall be made of all impounded dogs. The record shall
include the dog owner's name, address and telephone number, if available;
species or breed, color, sex, and license or tag number if available; and the
time and date impounded.
      8.   The veterinarian examining the biting dog shall fill out and then
send within twenty four (24) hours the Cook County rabies observation notice to
the Cook County department of animal control.
      9.   Following the examination of the biting dog at the end of the ten
(10) day confinement period the veterinarian shall complete the Cook County
rabies release report and he shall send this report within twenty four (24)
hours to the Cook County department of animal control.
   B.   The animal owner is responsible for all costs relating to the
examination and impoundment of the biting dog.
   C.   Any person having knowledge of a biting dog that has not been properly
examined and who does not report this fact to the police department is in
violation of this article.
   D.   It is unlawful for the owner of a biting dog to euthanize, sell, give
away, or otherwise dispose of such animal until it is released by the Cook
County animal control administrator or his authorized representative. (Ord. 12-
01-06)
10-3B-10: ACCIDENT REPORT, ASSISTANCE:
Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a dog or cat shall
stop at once and render such assistance as may be possible and shall
immediately report such injury or death to the dog's or cat's owner. In the
event the owner cannot be ascertained and located, such operator shall at once
report the accident to the police department. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-11: CRUELTY TO ANIMALS:
No person or owner of an animal shall:
   A.   Beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise
abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, or other combat
between dogs or between dogs and humans.
   B.   Abandon any animal.
   C.   Knowingly poison or cause to be poisoned any animal.
   D.   Keep or permit to be kept on his premises any wild or vicious dog for
display or for exhibition purposes. This subsection shall not be construed to
apply to zoological parks, performing animal exhibitions, or circuses.
   E.   Fail to properly feed and hydrate animal.
   F.   Fail to provide proper protection of any animal from the elements.
(Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-12: ANIMAL DEFECATION, REQUIREMENTS:
It shall be unlawful for any person owning, harboring, keeping, or in charge of
any animal to cause, suffer, or allow such animal to soil, defile, defecate on
or commit any nuisance on any common thoroughfare, sidewalk, passageway,
bypath, play area, park, school grounds, or any place where people congregate
or walk, or upon any public property whatsoever, or upon any private property
without the permission of the owner of said property. The restriction in this
section shall not apply to that portion of the street lying between the curb
lines, which shall be used to curb such animal under the following conditions:
   A.   The person who so curbs such animal shall immediately remove all
excreta deposited by such animal by any sanitary method.
   B.   The excreta removed from the aforementioned designated area shall be
disposed of by the person owning, harboring, keeping, or in charge of any dog
curbed in accordance with the provisions of this article, in a sanitary manner.
   C.   Every dog owner shall be responsible for the immediate removal and
sanitary disposal of any excreta deposited by his animal on any and all public
property. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-13: ENFORCEMENT OF ARTICLE:
Any police officer or agent of the village performing any duty under this
article is hereby authorized to go upon any premises to seize for impounding
any dog or cat which he may lawfully seize and impound when such police officer
or agent is in immediate pursuit of such dog or cat. Such police officer or
agent enforcing the provisions of this article shall not be held responsible
for any accident or property damages which occur while in the pursuit of any
dog or cat. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-14: VICIOUS AND DANGEROUS DOGS:
   A.   For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply:
   DANGEROUS DOG: Any individual dog which when either unmuzzled, unleashed or
unattended by its owner, or a member of its owner's family, in a vicious or
terrorizing manner, approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack
upon streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or places.
   ENCLOSURE: A fence or structure of at least six feet (6') in height, forming
or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and
suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other measures which may
be undertaken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of a vicious dog within
the enclosure (e.g., a dog run or dog kennel). Such enclosure shall be securely
enclosed and locked and designed with secure sides, top and bottom and shall be
designed to prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure.
   FOUND TO BE VICIOUS DOG:
      1.   The village's administrative adjudication hearing officer, the
village's animal control officer, or a village police officer has conducted an
investigation and made a finding in writing that the dog is a "vicious dog" as
defined herein, and based on that finding, the village's administrative
adjudication hearing officer or the village's animal control office has
declared in writing that the dog is a vicious dog; or
      2.   The circuit court has found the dog to be a "vicious dog" as defined
herein and has entered an order based on that finding.
   IMPOUNDED: Taken into the custody of the public pound.
   VICIOUS DOG:
      1.   Any individual dog that when unprovoked inflicts bites or attacks a
human being or other animal either on public or private property;
      2.   Any individual dog with a known propensity, tendency or disposition
to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the
safety of human beings or domestic animals;
      3.   Any individual dog that has as a trait or characteristic and a
generally known reputation for viciousness, dangerousness or unprovoked attacks
upon human beings or other animals, unless handled in a particular manner or
with special equipment;
      4.   Any individual dog which attacks a human being or domestic animal
without provocation; or
      5.   Any individual dog which has been found to be a "dangerous dog" upon
three (3) separate occasions.
No dog shall be deemed "vicious" if it bites, attacks or menaces a trespasser
on the property of its owner or harms or menaces anyone who has tormented or
abused it or is a professionally trained dog for law enforcement or guard
duties. Vicious dogs shall not be classified in a manner that is specific as to
breed.
   B.   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any dog which
has been found to be a vicious dog unless such dog is at all times kept in an
enclosure. The only times that a vicious dog may be allowed out of the
enclosure are:
      1.   If it is necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care
for the dog; or
      2.   To transport the dog relative to a sale or transfer, subject to
complying with the notice requirements set forth in subsection E of this
section; or
      3.   To comply with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction;
provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a chain having a
tensile strength of at least three hundred (300) pounds and not exceeding three
feet (3') in length, and shall be under the direct control and supervision of
the owner or keeper of the dog.
   C.   Any dog which has been found to be a vicious dog and which is not
confined to an enclosure shall be impounded by the village's administrative
adjudication hearing officer, the village's animal control officer or any
village police officer and shall be turned over to a licensed veterinarian for
destruction by lethal injection. If the owner of the dog has not appealed the
impoundment order to the circuit court within seven (7) working days, the dog
may be humanely dispatched.
   D.   A dog found to be a vicious dog shall not be released to the owner
until the village's administrative adjudication hearing officer or the
village's animal control officer approves the "enclosure" as defined herein.
   E.   No owner or keeper of a vicious dog shall sell or give the dog away
without giving the village's animal control officer notice thereof at least
five (5) business days prior to said sale or disposition. Said notice shall
contain the name, address and phone number of the person or entity to whom said
vicious dog is being sold or transferred.
   F.   The owner of a vicious dog shall, as part of the licensing of said dog
in accordance with section
10-3B-3 of this article, be required to show proof of liability insurance,
relative to and covering said dog, as a condition precedent to the issuance of
the required license.
   G.   Guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support dogs for the
physically handicapped, and sentry, guard, or police owned dogs are exempt from
this section; provided, the attack or injury to a person or domestic animal
occurs while the dog is performing duties as expected. To qualify for an
exemption under this subsection, each such dog shall be currently inoculated
against rabies in accordance with 510 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/8 and
properly registered with the administrator of the animal control act, 510
Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/1 et seq. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-15: PENALTY:
   A.   Unless otherwise provided for in this article, any person found guilty
of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be fined as follows:
      1.   For a first offense, not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more
than five thousand dollars ($5,000.00).
      2.   For a second offense, not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
nor more than seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00).
      3.   For a third or subsequent offense, not less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) nor more than ten thousand dollars ($10,000.00).
   B.   If the owner of a dog subject to enclosure pursuant to section
10-3B-14 of this article:
      1.   Fails to maintain or keep the dog in an enclosure; and
      2.   The dog inflicts great bodily harm, permanent disfigurement,
permanent physical disability upon any other person or domestic animal, or
causes the death of another person or domestic animal; and
      3.   The attack is unprovoked in a place where such person is peaceably
conducting himself and where such person or domestic animal may lawfully be;
the owner shall be charged under the animal control act, 510 Illinois Compiled
Statutes 5/1 et seq., and not under this article. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-16: REPORT OF VIOLATION:
Any person may report alleged violations of this chapter to the Oak Lawn animal
control officer or his or her authorized designee. Upon receipt of such a
report, the animal control officer or his or her authorized designee shall
conduct a prompt investigation. (Ord. 12-01-06)
10-3B-17: ADMINISTRATIVE ADJUDICATION OF VIOLATIONS:
Any violation of this chapter shall be administered in accordance with title
11, chapter 12, "Administrative Adjudication Of Nonvehicular Regulations
Violations", of this code. (Ord. 12-01-06)
ARTICLE C. CATS
SECTION:
10-3C-1: Responsibilities Of Owners Of Domestic Cats
10-3C-1: RESPONSIBILITIES OF OWNERS OF DOMESTIC CATS:
   A.   Owners of domesticated cats shall provide appropriate and adequate
food, water, and shelter for their cats.
   B.   The owner of a domesticated cat shall exercise reasonable care to guard
against the cat creating nuisance.
   C.   Owner of domesticated cats shall not permit their cats to roam
unsupervised off their property.
   D.   An owner of a cat shall not abandon a domesticated cat. (Ord. 12-01-06)
CHAPTER 4
MINORS
SECTION:
10-4-1: Curfew
10-4-2: Regulation Of Tobacco Products
10-4-3: Parental Responsibility
10-4-3-1: Definitions
10-4-3-2: Responsibility Required
